title: Editorial | Expertise Is Dead, Long Live Prof. Google
biliner: When all knowledge can be gained from Google, are experts even required anymore?
body:
- Vishesh Kashyap, Editor-in-Chief

During our recent training seminar, I overheard a professor irately recall a viva he had just taken. “I’ve spent half my life leading power plant projects. This kid can hardly distinguish a chimney from a cooling tower, and I know he’s never even been to a plant, far from interning in one. But he dares to tell me that designs have changed nowadays! Based on what? Google Images!”

Increasing awareness of the powers of the internet has had its impact on fields whose knowledge was hitherto limited to dingy corners of large libraries. While the positive effects of making a vast repository of knowledge conveniently available to the general public cannot be understated, so can’t be the illusion of knowledge brought about by an unlimited supply of information.

Nowhere is this illusion more evident than in medicine. One in four people self-diagnoses as an alternative to visiting the doctor. Most of this self-diagnosis is on the internet, where multiple websites are happy to provide tools to identify one’s disease through a series of multiple-choice questions. Online symptom checkers have been found to be accurate only 34% of the time, with the correct diagnosis being a part of the top twenty results in less than 60% cases. The availability of symptomological data on the internet undoubtedly makes the user feel empowered, often enough to be able to question diagnoses of doctors with multiple years of study and practice.

"Uncited data from WhatsApp forwards must now be treated with the same respect as evidence from multimillion-dollar studies, and opinions based on emotions and top-ten Google search results given the same accord as years-mature scholarly arguments."

This confidence forms the basis of the Dunning-Kruger effect (illustration above), a cognitive bias whereby people are unable to assess the limits of their abilities. In terms of knowledge, the less you know, the more you think you do. As your knowledge increases, so does your acceptance of its limits until you have enough of it to recognize your expertise. In an age fuelled by Wikipedia and driven by Google, the relevance of facts has gradually been undermined by popular belief. Uncited data from WhatsApp forwards must now be treated with the same respect as evidence from multimillion-dollar studies, and opinions based on emotions and top-ten Google search results given the same accord as years-mature scholarly arguments.

In 2015, a study conducted in the U.S. asked respondents their opinion on bombing Agrabah. 55% of Democrats and 43% Republicans had a for-or-against opinion on the matter. Agrabah is a fictional city from Disney’s Aladdin. In a post-truth world of alternative facts, the effect of demonstrable evidence on people’s entrenched opinions has continuously been decreasing. Anti-intellectualism has made its most robust global comeback since the end of the Second World War, as multiple dispensations across the world dismiss scholarly opinions and data in favour of ideology. Even in subjects with as clearly verifiable effects as those of global warming and vaccination, millions have been unwilling to cede to strong expert opinion against their own beliefs (often backed up by selectively-Googled articles), putting lives in danger.

"We live in complicated times, menacingly inclined against specialists, yet unable to do without them."

The demise of expertise is hardly the end of experts themselves; it represents the total capitulation of trust in their judgement. Experts themselves are partly to blame – errors in judgement on their part have caused phenomena as devastating as the financial crisis of 2008, and they are often culpable of extending their title to domains they have little knowledge of. Even so, today every aspect of our daily life is governed by devices and processes way past our understanding. We live in complicated times, menacingly inclined against specialists, yet unable to do without them.

When knowledge and evidence fail to matter when faced with feelings, beliefs and often propaganda, the societies that emerge are based on fabrication, misrepresentation and untruth. It befalls the general public, experts included, to protect against this dystopia, and re-establish trust in science, evidence and rationality.

title: DTU Times' Best of 10
biliner: We present a collection of 10 unique articles from the decade past.
body:
Conceived at the turn of the decade, DTU Times has charted a path of constant growth in through the 2010s, from being an 8-page newsletter to a full-fledged media body. This growth has been led by some of DTU’s most talented writers, who have contributed to our editions and the blog with articles on topics covering a wide range of subjects. Here, we present some of our most unique pieces, one from each year of the previous decade, which remain relevant as we continue into the next.

2010 
I Write To Keep Sane (Edition 11, Page 17)

Arushi Arora, Class of 2013 elaborates on the importance of writing, and her theory of how the process of writing helps rid the mind of lingering thoughts, Using analogies from computer science, the article elucidates on the role of writing in ‘keeping sane.’

2011 
Where is Hindi? (Edition 16, Page 15)

Why don’t we read Hindi literature as much as we do English? When we do, why are we often so painfully slow at it? Arushi Arora, Class of 2013 analyses the reasons behind the relative scarcity of Hindi novels, and the youth’s aversion to reading Hindi.

2012 
Why Not a Single Tech Fest? (Edition 18, Page 19)

Call it foresight or simply good old divination, this article by Prateek Dagar, Class of 2013 played its role in laying the foundation of what is now Invictus, DTU’s techfest. Using costing and logistics as basic principles, the article is emphatic in its recommendation in favour of a single techfest conducted by all technical societies.

2013 
Jugaad! (Edition 23, Page 31)

This article by Isha Gupta, Class of 2015 studies the global nature and need of the fundamentally Indian idea of Jugaad. Using examples from across the world, it makes the case for an increased focus on the ‘Jugaad approach.’

2014 
Is Percentage a Reflection of Intelligence?

Using a for/against approach, the article studies the merits and demerits of the percentage system of grading students and judging their abilities. It further goes on to elucidate on the features of this system applied specifically to DTU.

2015 
DTC vs Me

Garima Mishra, Class of 2017 describes her experiences using the DTC bus for travel. Comparing the ride to a soap opera, she recounts the peculiar situations faced daily by the average bus rider.

2016 
A Walk Down the TnP Lane

“At the centre of DTU and in the hearts of its dwellers lies a circular building where dreams come true.”

Garima Mishra, Class of 2017 describes in vivid detail the start of her day as a placement coordinator, figuring out the ever-elusive answer to the fundamental question: Why do you want to be a placement coordinator?

2017 
Figure 8

It is tempting to think of our banal routine as a disease of agency and control: the inability to relinquish high self-reflexive consciousness for the vulnerable, ignorant regions of slumber which puts us into an infinite loop that has us stuck in this cycle forever. Shivam Jha, Class of 2020 writes about an insomniac trying to count sheep to sleep, but something else bothers him every night.

2018 
Call Me By Your Strengths And Weaknesses Part 1 | Part 2

In a two-part article, Aishwarya Mishra, Class of 2018 recalls her experience of the TnP Department as she revisits her placement season. In a hilariously-detailed account, she recollects the average candidate’s day at the TnP.

2019 
रामचनर काका 2.0

इतनी भीषण गर्मी में भी बिना बिजली के आप गांव में तो रह सकते हैं पर दिल्ली में बड़ी मुश्किल से गुजारा होगा।इस हालात में आप कुछ खास नहीं कर सकते।ऐसे में बचपन का हर वो दिन जो गांव के बरगद के पेड़ के नीचे बिना बिजली के गुजरी हो का याद आना स्वाभाविक है। ऐसे ही उनमें से कुछ यादों को शब्दों में उकेरने की कोशिश की गई है, लोकेश नारायण शंकर, क्लास ऑफ़ 2021 द्वारा।

Honourable Mentions 

Among the scores of articles published over the past decade, a number of equally unique articles could not make the list. Here are a few honourable mentions among them.

What My Seniors Should’ve Told Me 
The Result 
The Dilli Metro Feel 
That DCE vs This DTU 
An Open Letter to Juniors 
41 Travails of a Day Scholar at DTU 
वो इश्क भला क्या इश्क हुआ, वो काम भला क्या काम हुआ? 
Nadar Bien

title: Interview | Sports Council, DTU
biliner: DTU Times interviewed the members of the current Sports Council, DTU- Siddharth Chauhan (General Coordinator), Rishav Sethi (Sports Manager), Ishaan Gauri, Eshita Yadav (Sports Secretaries), Ayush Garg (Treasurer), Pankaj Kanwat, Arshiya Thukral (Joint Sports Secretaries), Mrigank Singh (Joint Treasurer) and Anubhav Gaba (Sports Advisor).
body:
DTU Times interviewed the members of the current Sports Council, DTU- Siddharth Chauhan (General Coordinator), Rishav Sethi (Sports Manager), Ishaan Gauri, Eshita Yadav (Sports Secretaries), Ayush Garg (Treasurer), Pankaj Kanwat, Arshiya Thukral (Joint Sports Secretaries), Mrigank Singh (Joint Treasurer) and Anubhav Gaba (Sports Advisor).

Q. What all responsibilities does the Sports council, DTU has when it comes to organizing the annual sports and athletics event- Aahvaan?

More than 2000 participants from all across India participate in Aahvaan, the annual sports fest of DTU. The primary responsibilities of the Sports Council in Aahvaan include- drafting a suitable budget along with inviting all the universities across India as well as publicizing the fest. It’s the Sports Council’s duty to build a strong PR and publicity team for the fest. Hospitality is another significant section that needs our attention. It includes providing proper accommodation and food facilities to the participants. More than thirteen sports are played in Aahvaan and arranging proper equipment and officials for the fair play of these sports is also our responsibility.

Q. What are the different problems that you encountered during last year's events, and how do you plan to resolve them?

There were a few significant problems that we encountered during last year's fest. A strong team is required at the core for any fest; a fest cannot be great with just a handful of people working for it. This year we will make sure to build a proper team for every department which will hopefully fulfil lasts year's voids. We also faced issues due to the dates of the fest. Last year's dates were coinciding with the semester examinations of several universities. This resulted in a significant drop in participation. The dates of Aahvaan have been set keeping these factors in mind. 

Q. What steps can the council take in order to increase the participation of students in outdoor games?  How can you motivate students so that they involve themselves in sport, which is an essential discipline in life? 

Incorporation of sports in the curriculum is something that DTU has adopted through FEC, since the batch of 2018, which has proven to be a golden move to encourage participation in outdoor games. Besides this, proper grounds and facilities will surely help in encouraging more students to spend their time outdoors.

Sports Council also organises two outside-Delhi tours for our sports contingent. This brings motivation to all the players to practice hard and make it into the team. An inter-department sports fest, Arena, is also conducted annually, which is open to all the students for participation.

Q. What are your views regarding the coaches and support staff presently at DTU, and how does the council plan to improve the current scenario of mentors for various sports?

DTU introduced the coaching staff in 2018 with the introduction of FEC-Sports. Since the arrival of coaches, the level of sports in DTU has elevated drastically. We have performed brilliantly in various inter-university tournaments including the sports fest of IIT-K and BITS-Goa. DTU has left a positive mark in almost every major sporting event in these universities. Some of the sports do not have a coach yet, but the council is continuously working to appoint qualified coaches for these sports.

Q. What new initiatives has the Sports Council planned for this year?

The council has multiple new initiatives in mind and will try its level best to execute them over the course of the year. These include organising multiple mini-marathons for students as well as faculty members of DTU, easing the process for providing sports equipment to each and every student of DTU, organising an inter-hostel sports fest- Aaghaz and focussing on female matches for all sports to further improve the participation of girls.

title: Best Interviews of the Decade 2010s
biliner: We present a collection of the best interviews conducted in the previous decade.
body:
Compiled by: Shivam Jha, Editor-in-Chief

Since its conception in 2009, DTU Times has steadily built its reputation as one of the top university newsletters and media platforms across the country. From being an 8-page newsletter to a full-fledged media body, this growth was accompanied with exemplary and exhaustive coverage and reportage of all campus events perfectly encapsulating 'the DTU Life'. During this decade-long journalistic jaunt, our team members had the opportunity to interact with and interview some prominent guests and some exceptionally high achieving alumni, who have become the face of numerous success stories of our university. 
Here, we list out some of our notable interviews of the past decade from a set of remarkably diverse fields, in no particular order.

Prof. Yogesh Singh, Vice Chancellor, Delhi Technological University

"You’ll only do B.Tech once. I want to help make it count."
In 2015, DTU Times was privileged to have the opportunity to meet and interview the newly appointed Vice Chancellor of Delhi Technological University, Prof. Yogesh Singh. He discussed the plans he had and shared in vision for the development of the university.

Anand Vardhan, AIR 7, UPSC CSE 2016

"Selecting an optional subject for Mains examination is a strictly personal choice based on one’s interest. I chose Political Science because of considerable overlap with General Studies and a genuine interest in it."
Anand Vardhan, Class of 2013, Mechanical Engineering, secured an All India Rank of 7 in the UPSC Civil Services Examination, 2016. Interestingly, he had also served a tenure as an Associate Editor at DTU Times during his time at the university.

Bijesh Amin, Co-founder, Indus Valley Partners

"We have been hiring students from both engineering and business colleges in India for a really long time and what we have seen is that, there are no characters. Everybody looks the same, everybody talks the same and everybody puts the same thing on their resume. We give you a topic, discuss it in a group, 80% percent of the cases it’s almost like a formula. Everyone wants to talk first, during the talk there will be one person who won’t be saying anything, and then one person will ask that person would you like to say something because you haven’t said anything yet. It’s all like a dance recital." 
We interviewed Bijesh Amin, Co-founder, Indus Valley Partners on the changing job environment and placements from the employer’s perspective.

Madhur Gupta, 100%ile, CAT 2017

"This was my first CAT attempt, and I gave every mock test as if it were the CAT exam and I gave the CAT exam as if it were just another mock test."
Madhur Gupta, Class of 2016, Mechanical Engineering, was one of the twenty people in the country to achieve a perfect 100 percentile in the Common Aptitude Test, 2017.

Mrudang Mathur, PhD Candidate, UT Austin

"I always wanted to go work in an R&D role professionally and to get such a job in Mechanical Engineering a PhD is required. Hands-on experience trumps classroom learning any day of the week. Find projects in the area of your interest and follow them till the end. If you’re unsure of what interests you, speak to seniors and then cycle through sub-fields till you find the right topic."
Mrudang Mathur, Class of 2018, Mechanical Engineering, received admits from the University of Texas, Austin for Ph.D., the University of Oxford for D.Phil. and the University of California, Los Angeles, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor and Cornell University for M.S. in Mechanical Engineering.

Piyush Mishra, (Page 16, Edition 38) 

" मैं फैज़ और भगत सिह से बहुत प्रेरित हुआ था, जिनकी झलक मेरी रचनाओं में भी नजर आती है। आप सभी को स्वतंत्र सोच रखनी चाहिए। अपनी जिंदगी आपको अपने बल पर गुजारनी है। आप अपने निर्णय पर भरोसा रखिये और अपने दिल की बात सुनकर देखिये, आप खुद प्रेरणा के स्रोत बन जायेंगे | "
सुप्रसिद्ध रचनाकार एवं अदाकार पीयूष मिश्रा (who was a guest at Engifest 2017) का साक्षात्कार |

Dr. Dave Parry, Auckland University of Technology

"I think that there are three important things- first being to recognise yourself. You need to know what you like doing, whether you like writing programs, doing analysis or developing algorithms. Second most important thing is who you’re going to work with- a team or a supervisor that you’re going to have an effective collaboration with. Lastly, you need to know what exactly you’re going to work on."
Dr. Dave Parry is Head, Department of Computer Science, Auckland University of Technology, New Zealand, and was at DTU for a one-day international seminar on Recent Trends in Big Data Analytics, organised by the Department of Computer Science and Engineering.

Sidharth Raja, Placed at Uber (Page 28, Edition 39)

Since its conception in 2009, DTU Times has steadily built its reputation as one of the top university newsletters and media platforms across the country. Anand Vardhan, AIR 7, UPSC CSE 2016

"Selecting an optional subject for Mains examination is a strictly personal choice based on one’s interest. I chose Political Science because of considerable overlap with General Studies and a genuine interest in it."

Everyone wants to talk first, during the talk there will be one person who won’t be saying anything, and then one person will ask that person would you like to say something because you haven’t said anything yet. It’s all like a dance recital."

title: Interview | Abhijeet Singh, Founder, StepVue
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Abhijeet Singh, Founder, StepVue, who was in DTU for a Career Consulting Workshop organized by ACS-DTU and IIChE DTU Chapter in collaboration with StepVue.
body:
Photograph by: ACS-DTU and IIChE DTU Chapter

DTU Times interviewed Abhijeet Singh, Founder, StepVue, who was in DTU for a Career Consulting Workshop organized by ACS-DTU and IIChE DTU Chapter in collaboration with StepVue.

How does coming back to DTU after all these years feel?

DTU has been a home to me right from the start, and whatever I am today is because of this place. Coming back here always feels like a homecoming and is one of the most amazing feelings one can ever experience. The excitement and vibes you get on the campus, especially the beauty of its design, always makes me feel upbeat.

How does being an alumnus of DTU impact you professionally? Is there anything that college taught you that made a special contribution to your career?

I think that one gains a lot of experience in a place like DTU. It is here that I learnt the importance of having a great network and a cooperative peer group. Most of the things that I achieved in the early days of my career were due to the network of people that I created during my college days. They were superbly supportive of me, even when I graduated and moved out. Not just your batchmates, but also the seniors who graduate prior to you and are in the job market are ever ready to assist you. DTU has one of the strongest student communities and the alumni of DTU will help you out through thick and thin. No matter what phase of life you are in, there is always guidance available if you reach out.

How did you handle the switch between DTU and the Rotterdam School of Management?

When I joined GAIL after college, I was at a very comfortable place in my life, but the leisure is what got to me. Hence, I decided to switch things up. Human beings have a tendency to get used to their comfort zones, yet I have always tried to come out of mine. After spending some years at GAIL, I decided that since I had lived in India all my life, I needed some overseas experience. I wanted to have a global outlook towards business and that is what drove me towards Rotterdam.

The experience at RSM was phenomenal. Everything was extremely organized, people went out of their way to help you, and the structure and order in your everyday life was extremely inspiring. I was used to chaos, and the difference made me a little uncomfortable at first. I learnt the importance of having a functional work-life balance, and gained a lot of insight and professionalism because of the time I spent in the Netherlands. The immense diversity was also very motivating - I had classmates from 35 different nations, all studying together! Everyone came from very different backgrounds, from marines to fashion, and yet we were learning the same curriculum.

How is networking with the peer group at a foreign institute different from networking at an Indian institute?

At an Indian B-school such as the ISB or an IIM, if there are a hundred students enrolled, nearly 80 students would be getting a job in India and hence, would be residing here. However, if you want to build a global network, that is where Rotterdam School of Management - or any other foreign B-school, for that matter - would be a real help to you. You spend a whole year with students hailing from a multitude of countries. Once the program is over, they go in different directions, different countries and different roles. This diversifies your network. Thanks to this, my network has expanded to Japan, Australia, the whole of Europe and even Africa. This gives you the avenue of getting to know a country first-hand, as I can call up any of my acquaintances and get the required information easily. I can do this for any part of the world, since my alumni network is spread across almost every country. I have been with people of varied nationalities, and each one of them has imparted me with a life experience of their own. When you work with a global team in a time bound-environment, it helps you to understand how their cultures shape their personalities.

What were the key factors which made you decide to establish a company in India instead of establishing it elsewhere?

I had an opportunity to work with Adidas Netherlands on a living management project. Though it wasn’t exactly an internship, it provided some useful insights into how Adidas worked. After completing my MBA program, I moved back to India. There is an inherent advantage in founding a company in India due to high demand. Imagine that you are doing something niche which caters to a specific section of the total population. In a country with a total population of 2 million, your product would target a small audience, and you might not even find a break in that country. India, however, is one of the biggest markets in the world. This is because of the huge chunk of population that resides here. Due to this, no matter how good or bad your product is, you will always a healthy market for it in India. Hence, founding a start-up in India makes the economies of scale work in favour of that start-up, as the market, the opportunities, and the possibilities are huge.

Since you have worked in the core technical as well as the consulting industry, how has the transition between the two sectors been?

I believe that it is not difficult to make a transition between the two industries. The only major transition which one needs to make is a change of mindset. When you are working in a PSU, you need to possess a certain mindset. There is a specific workflow which is the right way of doing things in a public sector environment. However, when you transition into a corporate or a start-up environment, you need to adjust your mindset. You have to be clear about what is expected from your new role, and you shouldn’t bring the ‘baggage’ from the previous role. Do not get stuck with the old workflow; whatever is being offered at the new company, appreciate it and adapt yourself.

Is there any final advice you would like to share with the students of DTU?

For the students of DTU, I would suggest that you should enjoy your time here. It might sound like a cliché, but the four years you spend here are going to be some of the best memories of your life. The friends you have made at DTU will stick with you for quite a long time in your career. You cannot say the same for an MBA or any other post-grad journey. This place is special, and so are the people who come here. One should focus on academics as well, but try to follow a balanced approach towards learning and experiencing the vast aspects of college life.

title: National Seminar by Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Awardees
biliner: Department of Applied Physics, DTU will be organising a one-day National Seminar on Recent Trends in Applied Physics and Engineering (RTAPE-2020) by Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar (SSB) Awardees Padma Shri Prof. K.L. Chopra and Prof. V. Ramgopal Rao, on 10 February 2020.
body:
Department of Applied Physics, DTU will be organising a one-day National Seminar on Recent Trends in Applied Physics and Engineering (RTAPE-2020) by Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar (SSB) Awardees, on 10 February 2020. Padmi Shri Prof. K.L. Chopra, SSB Awardee and former Director, IIT Kharagpur will be the Chief Guest, and Prof. V. Ramgopal Rao, SSB Awardee and Director, IIT Delhi will grace the seminar as the Guest of Honor.

The Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Award for Science and Technology is awarded annually by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) for notable and outstanding research in science, engineering, medicine and mathematics. The award was instituted in the honor of Late Dr. Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar, Founder Director, CSIR in 1958. Dr Bhatnagar was instrumental in developing Science & Technology infrastructure in the post-independence era. He was conferred Order of the British Empire (OBE) in 1936, Knighted in 1941 and elected Fellow of the Royal Society, London in 1943. He was awarded Padma Vibhushan in 1954.

Other speakers in RTAPE-2020 include Prof. Ajoy Ghatak, Meghnad Saha Fellow of NASI, Prof. Vikram Kumar, Former Director, NPL, Delhi and SSPL, Delhi, Prof. S.C. Dutta Roy, Former Professor, IIT Delhi, Prof. Kehar Singh, Former Professor, IIT Delhi and Prof. Anurag Sharma, Professor, IIT Delhi. 

The event will be chaired by Prof. Suresh C. Sharma, Dean (Academic-PG), DTU and convened by Dr. Bharti Singh, Assistant Professor, Dept. of Applied Physics, DTU.

Complete details about the event can be found here.

title: Interview | Literature and Film Council, DTU
biliner: DTU Times interviewed the members of the current Literature and Film Council, DTU- Sahil Bansal, Himanshu Hooda (Fest Secretaries), Nikhil Pal and Niyanta Mehra (Treasurers).
body:
DTU Times interviewed the members of the current Literature and Film Council, DTU- Sahil Bansal, Himanshu Hooda (Fest Secretaries), Nikhil Pal and Niyanta Mehra (Treasurers)

 

Q. Yuvaan always has very interesting themes with layers of perception underneath them. What leads to the creation of such unique themes? This year's theme is Eden De Übermensch, meaning- Garden of Superheroes. How would such a theme influence the events and competitions in Yuvaan?

Yuvaan aims to touch upon themes through which we can explore everything relevant to literature and films. These ideas are born from the simplest of things we are surrounded by that go unnoticed, which is the essence of literature and art. The theme should always be open to interpretation and each one should have their own unique set of expectations from the theme. As for this year’s theme- Eden de Übermensch, it is to commemorate the superheroes in and around us. Since it is a broad theme, it wouldn’t directly reflect in the events and competitions to be held, but there is definitely an indirect link. We believe it represents the very fiber of being for this fest.

Q. With the advent of the digital age, e-books and online subscriptions to magazines, how do you think literature has morphed in modern times and what role does it hold now?

In this day and age, opening a book and diving right into it for pleasure has transformed into much more technologically advanced hobbies. Now, we have material to read online, audiobooks, etc. This adds a new perspective to literature, as now people can even read their favorite stories on the go and in more compact forms. Although, the advent of such technology has caused old-fashioned reading to take a backseat, it’s not necessarily a disadvantage as this has opened avenues for a different set of people to take up reading.

Q. Last year's fest saw many renowned guests. How do you think college students benefit from motivational speakers and celebrities alike?

The guests during our fest are personalities many college students look up to for various reasons. Inviting them and giving the students a chance to see their real-life heroes and listen to what they have to say creates a huge impact. title: Interview | Mr. Vinod Dham
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Vinod Dham, ‘Father of the Pentium Chip’, a DCE alumnus of the 1971 batch, who was the Chief Guest at Convocation 2019. We also interviewed his batchmates Mr. Gulshan Kapoor, Mr. Subha Rao, Mr. Sudhir Khanna, Mr. Suman K. Kwatra, and Mr. Umesh Chaddha.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Vinod Dham, ‘Father of the Pentium Chip’, a DCE alumnus of the 1971 batch, who was the Chief Guest at Convocation 2019. We also interviewed his batchmates Mr. Gulshan Kapoor, Mr. Subha Rao, Mr. Sudhir Khanna, Mr. Suman K. Kwatra, and Mr. Umesh Chaddha.

What are the major changes you have seen between DCE of 1971 and DTU of 2019?

The DCE in 1971 was a small place. I can draw a whole map for you consisting of the library and the four departments. This campus is a huge one, of area 165 acres, while our campus was only around 10 acres at Kashmere Gate. There is no comparison; what you are doing here is amazing. In 1971, probably less than 250 students passed out, while here, almost 1800 students graduated this year. 

Engineers today in India are failing to capture the wide gap between the academic curriculum and industry requirements. What do you think students should do at an individual level to bridge this gap?

There always will be a difference in the industry here and the industry abroad, and that is why I went abroad to get my Masters degree. Nowadays, however, I see a lot of PhD students here, so hopefully, we are improving the scope for higher studies here as well. But earlier, going abroad was the only way to dig deeper into a subject. There are a number of job-ready courses these days which are gaining prominence. These are aimed at bridging the gap between what is taught in the university and what is required in the industry.

Don’t work too long for one organisation. 5-7 years is a good time to switch. If you are there in any organisation, look for opportunities to show your brilliance. Every organisation has, whether you like it or not, Power Centers, which would really put you into a proper perspective. Don’t just blindly work and deliver, but also observe the people around you and learn from them. 

A lot of engineers generally go for non-technical jobs, as opposed to core technical work. How can we interest more students in the core field?

Engineering gives you excellent analytical skills which are used in every field. Lots of engineers go into business-related sectors and many of the skills taught in engineering come in handy there. Nowadays technology is in everything, so to maximise your benefits, you have to be able to utilise the best of both. To be honest, I don’t think it’s a negative thing. Some students have an aptitude in the sciences, but it is not practical for everybody to go towards research. You will find a lot of engineers in the civil services as well. It’s a way of life. 

The alumni of DCE are in every single industry in the world. How do you think that the alumni network of DCE will be able to help future students of DTU who will enter different industries?

In Silicon Valley, there are a substantial number of DCE graduates who are doing amazing things. There are lots of them, dozens and dozens. I don’t know how to bring all of them together but I wish there was a network like there is in Harvard. Harvard has a brilliant alumni network which the alumni constantly use for years after graduation to get jobs and connections. Maybe the newer batches can take an initiative towards making a social networking website exclusive to DTU students and alumni.

title: Interview | Ran Mor, Founder of the LifeArt Festival
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Ran Mor, Founder of the Life Arts Festival, who was a Guest of Honour at the Inauguration Ceremony of Yuvaan Literature and Film Festival 2020.
body:
You’re the Founder of LifeArt Festival. What has been your motivation to come up with this concept that has turned into a worldwide phenomenon?

For the past 30 years, I’ve produced so many festivals, shows, and movies and I’ve seen the industry change. I believed in creating a single stage for every artist, Film star or even a YouTube celebrity. At the end of the day, all of them create art. We’ve created a platform where you can submit your film and can communicate with the global community of artists. We’ve just launched and already received thousands of submissions from around the world.  With Life Arts, we’re trying to create a supportive network of artists with no intention of commercialisation.

You had earlier mentioned that the industry has been changing due to platforms like YouTube and Netflix. Do you think that these platforms have changed our perception of art?

Yes, of course. First of all, fewer people are going to Cinemas or Film Festivals because everyone has a list of movies they’d like to see on Netflix. The rules are different now and these are great platforms for the future. There’s a lot of creative freedom and this is a more democratic form of art. The festival gives professionals a chance to engage and see what’s happening in the industry.

Nowadays, everyone has access to several platforms where they can create art. Do you think that the quality of art that is produced on these platforms gets degraded due to open access to everyone through online mediums?

I believe that the biggest present for any artist is to help change consciousness. Good art is something that can alter people’s attitudes. It doesn’t matter if you have scores of followers or none, you can still create art and share it globally; a YouTube star may make less money as a celebrity, but creatively, he might influence more people.

 If you create something and that has an impact on someone, that is art; and it doesn’t matter what platform it has been created on. Although the mediums that we create art on has been revolutionised, it is what connects our spirituality, and creativity, and brings people together. The key is to make sure it keeps on growing.

title: Interview | Juliette Ménager, Juliette Ménager, Casting Director and Founder, Joule Studio, Paris
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Juliette Menager, Casting Director and Founder, Joule Studio, Paris, who was a guest at the Yuvaan Literature and Film Festival 2020.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Juliette Menager, Casting Director and Founder, Joule Studio, Paris, who was a guest at the Yuvaan Literature and Film Festival 2020.

You’re essentially an experienced Casting Director. What are the main requirements for anyone wishing to take this up as their profession?

Casting directors have to keep their eyes open for new protégées, and it has to be done in collaboration with the director, his or her script, the story, and of course, the budget. Casting directors scout for talent that aligns with the projects that people undertake. Whether in films, fashion, music or TV serials, every platform has different requirements and prerequisites. 

When did you plan to become a casting director and how do you think the profession has changed over the years?

You can tell a lot about people just by the way they shake hands, and no amount of online knowledge can ever compensate for that. 

Cinema is a field that runs on insight. A lot of casting directors are women, perhaps because casting has a lot of feminine aspects. They have become increasingly important because of the shortage of time. Platforms like LifeArt thus become integral, as here one can upload their profile and can create communities, increasing their reach to the masses. The means of becoming famous have changed now. Before, one had pictures and papers; but now with the advent of Netflix, Amazon, Hulu and a lot of other online streaming platforms, talent has to be scouted at a much faster rate. However, I believe you still need to see the people, audition them and walk the old-fashioned path. You can tell a lot about people just by the way they shake hands, and no amount of online knowledge can ever compensate for that. 

What do you look for when you’re casting someone for a specified role?

Charisma. The person should be someone I can remember, and someone who can remember me in return. Looking for someone to cast in a role is very much like looking for someone to fall in love with; and I believe love is always at first sight. There are many other factors that come into play later, if the actor is right for the film, or if the director and producer would get along with him; and when the relationship is finally established - it is a little bit like a marriage. You have to know that someone is the right fit, and then work with them through all upcoming challenges. 

What are the differences between the various platforms that portray cinema?

It’ll take anyone an entire year to understand the intricacies of the varied platforms. Films need people who are willing to work for longer duration and have specific skills, while on a music video, appearance becomes vital. In India, sometimes a very famous model goes on to become an actress. It depends on whether one has to talk, dance or listen. Every role has different requirements. I’ve been a casting director all around the world, and each industry wants something different. 

Do you see any parallels between the French and Indian culture?

I have been to India before. I love this country and am very pleased to be received here again. Coming to the universities as a representative of the LifeArt Festival always makes me feel special. The two countries have had a beautiful relationship for many years. This year, we’re celebrating the year of India at our Book Fair. Oxford Bookstore from Delhi will be showing their book collections and representing India at the fair.

You’ve worked with top names like Brad Pitt. How has your experience been with the bigwigs like him?

The experience has been great, and Brad Pitt is especially a very lovely man. I have known him personally and working with him always had us catering to his huge fan following; all of whom wanted to see him. He’s extremely sweet and gentle. We worked together in Morocco, Africa for Babel, which was a very interesting film. 

In India, women are often typecast into the same roles repeatedly. What do you think about female representation in upcoming cinema around the world?

Unfortunately, the scenario is similar in most countries. If you talk about Indian cinema, it has become a melting pot for various cultures. You have Nora Fatehi - she’s Morrocan-Canadian and has been really successful here as a dancer. Then there’s Kalki Koechlin, who is French and has carved a place in Bollywood. Most women, however, are inevitably typecast despite their talents. This is because all film industries want women who are younger, and looks often become the primary criterion.

title: Interview | Filtercopy Cast
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Ayush Mehra, Kriti Vij, Devika Vatsa, Priyam Saha, who often feature in FilterCopy videos, and Bollywood actress Sanjana Sanghi. The guests were present for the La Gossipe panel in Yuvaan Literature and Film Festival 2020.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Ayush Mehra, Kriti Vij, Devika Vatsa, Priyam Saha, who often feature in FilterCopy videos, and Bollywood actress Sanjana Sanghi. The guests were present for the La Gossipe panel in Yuvaan Literature and Film Festival 2020.

Did you ever plan to become a YouTube celebrity or was it something you stumbled upon?

Ayush: My plan was very simple as I was always interested in the world of films. The beautiful cinematic representations of mundane things were always exciting. I wanted to stick in this field. Even if I hadn't been acting, I would either be writing or producing. I wish to direct my own feature someday.

Kriti: I had zero plans. Initially, I wanted to be Miss World but I fell short in terms of height. I really enjoyed acting and I was always looking to get away from studies. During college days, I started acting in street plays fell in love with it. I believe I am extremely comfortable in front of the camera due to my time doing theatre in school. The camera was my best friend. I never planned this career and just went with the flow.

Sushant Singh Rajput is an alumnus of our University. Did you ever feel the engineer vibes while working with him?

Sanjana: I definitely felt the vibes. There was a lot to learn from him because he is a very good actor. We were both very nerdy about how we approached the script and our method was slightly similar as well. He uses markers and post-its quite efficiently. I used to think that my script was worn out but his script used to be so very wholesome.

Ayush: I also remember working with him for the movie ‘Drive’. He had an entire notebook about his backstory for the film. In psychology, there is something called the personality test and he gets it done for his characters. He makes an entire file out of it.

What do you consider when selecting a script and acting it out?

It’s a lot which goes in. I generally don’t like repeating what I have been doing (the romantic stuff). So there is not much scope in that. body:
1. DTU Times interviewed Dhruv Sehgal, Ambrish Verma and Viraj Gehlani from Filtercopy during Yuvaan, the Literature and Film Festival of DTU, 2020

    It wasn’t a lot about the relevant skills added to what I'm doing but I did a lot to the characters. I learnt how to draw my characters from real life. Moreover, college was a very important part of my holistic and personal development. I learnt how to talk to people, see the thick and thin through life, how to manage work etc. All of these lessons are essential for everyone, regardless of the field they’re going in.  

    In a climate as socially sensitive as ours, what guidelines have you set for yourself while writing in order to ensure that your content is positively received across all generations? 
    I always try to make my next project better than my last one. Even if it doesn’t turn out as well as the previous one, there’s always an attempt to put in more effort and thought into it.  
    I try to see the audience of the content I’ll be posting. It depends on whether the video will have more shares or more tags, the type of community that will relate to this video the most. These 3 factors are kept into account along with our previous experiences.  

    What’s the difference between writing for a streaming service or YouTube channel or your social media platform? 
    You try to gauge the type of audience that predominantly uses the platform. Audience differs from platform to platform. TikTok has a mass audience, whereas YouTube has a combination of mass as well as an urban audience, Instagram - on the other hand - consists primarily of an urban audience. You get to know about your audience after experimenting. You fail a couple of times and get to know about it through comments. There’s a thing in the digital industry, it’s that you get immediate feedback now. Earlier, a movie would get released and the filmmakers would have to wait over the weekend to see what the critics have to say.

    It also helps in taking the edge off your acting skills. If you write yourself a character, you’ll naturally be more comfortable in doing that part since it’ll be a heavy reflection of how you actually behave in real life.

    It differs a lot on the basis of the craft. If you’re making content for YouTube, you know that you have him for a minute but if you’re making a movie, you know that you have to gauge the audience’s attention for at least 30 minutes.

This shows that your content needs to be very crisp, popping and attention grabbing to get the audience. This really helps you know how much work you need to put in.  
    It’s also very important to know that you’re working for the right platform. Say, you’re a phenomenal writer but you might suck at YouTube; that’s because you might write something with intricate emotional depth but YouTube’s audience isn’t the one that’s interested in content like that. They’re the ones who just want to watch something at the end of the day that helps them unwind and relax. Hence, you can’t go overly emotional on YouTube. However, Netflix has an audience that has specially paid to watch content that’s different from the content on YouTube. Therefore, if a creator wants to experiment with content, he should know his platforms and the audiences that come along.  

    Do you prefer to work freelance or be associated with an organisation? 
    Every organisation has a mandate that’s different from the other. If you’re working for a company, the mandate of your personal/work life should match with the mandate of that organisation. So, it wouldn’t matter even if you want to write the best detective story ever if your organisation simply doesn’t want it. In totality, your core values should match with the core values of the people you’re working with. That, in my opinion, is the biggest thing to find.

    It’s the best time to be in this industry. It’s the best time to be writing because now you’re actually getting paid for it. There’s a very big luck factor attached to it. Now that you’re getting paid for it, that means you’ll be held responsible and accountable for it. That’s why it’s important to not take up on projects that offer money but force you to do something that isn’t your cup of tea. It’s crucial to work but to simultaneously retain your individuality during the process. Because at the end of it, your writing should reflect your essence and your personality. If it doesn’t do that, then you’ll become quite replaceable.  
    Everyone has different ways of achieving career fulfillment. If you feel like doing mainstream content continuously to earn enough that you can finally take a 2-year-break and work on your script, go do that. Just be happy with the direction you’re going in. Because earning money is, too, very important because you’re able to get access to better production and better people with more money.  

    A couple of years ago, neither of you knew you’d be doing what you’re doing right now. All of you found your calling along the way and made your path. What are your biggest takeaways from your own journeys? 
    My only takeaway was, “Try first, then regret.” You must take all the chances and shots that you’re given. The regret of passing up on an opportunity and then thinking about it later is something that eats you up. Try doing as many things as you can, rather than contemplating about them later.  
    My takeaway revolved around Ikigai. You should try to find what you like doing and try it out. But you should also see if you’re good at it and find a method to make it financially sustainable.  
    I think the biggest takeaway is the desire to be better, but at the same time not losing your life/individuality because of your work. It’s very important to have a very healthy personal life; to love your parents, to love your friends, to be there for them and simultaneously be a good professional. This profession is too romanticised now, which it shouldn’t be. It’s a job at the end of the day. Work for those 8 hours during the day and then go live your life in a healthy manner, one in which your work doesn’t consume your entire life.

title: Editorial | Death of a Bachelor
biliner: Has death become so commonplace and trivial that we fail to consciously commit ourselves to grieve the loss of someone or empathise with someone's sorrow?
body:
-Shivam Jha, Editor-in-Chief

For all I know, a death in your acquaintance circle has an acute, dissecting effect on all the people who shared a common lifescape with the person. It pierces the fathomage of your soul and hides in corners you didn’t even know existed until now. Loss doesn’t occur in a vacuum, it is often followed by smaller, more shallow, less finite losses that dilute your perspective on life. 
And since life is always seemingly teeming with intentions and meanings, the death of each human, or even each creature, really is a catastrophe. But we must live with it anyway; for all we know, the alternative is the most desperate and convoluted of denials. 

Through a lapse in my indifference, I was drawn into this recent catastrophe, drawn to make his death my death. This series of events threw me into contemplation and jerrybuilt a number of questions. After all, what are the factors that shape the length and depth of our sorrow? 

Our degree of agony is not proportional to the distance separating us and the site of death but rather inversely proportionate to the degrees of separation between us. No matter how much we try to deny it, the tacit normalisation of suicides in universities and schools is a byproduct of the institutionalized apathy and stigma inculcated through a bland curriculum. 

On average, 28 students committed suicide every day in 2018 in India which comes down to more than one (successful) student suicide every hour, making up 8% of the total in the country. And shockingly, every 3 seconds someone attempts suicide in India. The problem may not be a simulacrum of India’s widespread mental health crisis. And despite these figures, India only spends 0.06% of its health budget on mental healthcare, compared to the 4% or more typically spent by developed nations. Staggering, right?

At the core of the problem lies the forbiddance to discuss or even acknowledge the presence of the problem in our community (classic Indian tactic). Instead of confronting our own mortality, many of us tend to label such talk as “morbid” and try to stave it off — along with death itself — as long as they can. This horror at the death of others is intimately bound up with horror at the prospect of one’s own demise. 

We try to hush over the demise of someone, particularly when it's a suicide, afraid that bringing this up will lead to an uncomfortable conversation. However, in order to break through the silence and avoidance that shape contemporary Indian attitudes toward student deaths, we need to have more uncomfortable conversations. We must teach young people different ways to engage with the end of life, rather than shield them from the spectre of mortality. Understandably, not everyone is in an emotional place to have such conversations; it is one thing to study death from the safety and privilege of a classroom setting and another to feel its looming presence. 

Such catastrophes occur each day, and after a brief perfunctory display of dismay, people go on with life like it's usual. Our insensitivity towards the loss of someone with an oblivious coexistence is deeply internalised in our behaviour. With this attitude coupled with administrative apathy and the urge to muffle incidents before they become news, we proceed to overlook the abundance of deaths around us. 

But especially in the urban terrains of a third world city such as New Delhi , a metropolis where there are no quiet places in sight, every death will go noticed. A city with a million cars and rooftops and windows and humans and stories; a city that bustles around the clock amid the well-rehearsed commotion of crowds; a city with people and traffic louder than the next thunder scream and air that’ll smother you in the pretence of keeping you alive. In a city that breathes and chokes by its own density, there are no closed, clear spaces for suicide.
Everything and everyone jammed in, all in an earshot of each other, each one privy to the next one’s pain and suffering. In a city like this, almost every death will be done in public. Every suicide by another body living, breathing, being, and coexisting alongside the brick and steel and concrete crowding the pathways.

While some deaths won't even fortunate enough to receive an obituary or grieved upon, some will be buried - not in graves - but in statistics; and some even worse - forgotten.

title: रामचनर काका 3.O: आधुनिकता का अत्याचार
biliner: माननीय मुख्यमंत्री श्री अरविंद केजरीवाल जी के पिछले दो कार्यकालों से प्रभावित होकर दिल्ली की जनता विधानसभा चुनाव के बाद केजरीवाल 3.O का स्वागत  कर रही है ऐसे में हम अपने पाठकों की मांग पर लेकर आ रहे हैं रामचनर काका 3.O, रामचनर काका की दिलचस्प बातों की इस श्रृंखला में आगे पढ़ते हैं आधुनिकता का अत्याचार।
body:
- लोकेश नारायण शंकर, तृतीया वर्ष, आई टी

माननीय मुख्यमंत्री श्री अरविंद केजरीवाल जी के पिछले दो कार्यकालों से प्रभावित होकर दिल्ली की जनता विधानसभा चुनाव के बाद केजरीवाल 3.O का स्वागत  कर रही है ऐसे में हम अपने पाठकों की मांग पर लेकर आ रहे हैं रामचनर काका 3.O, रामचनर काका की दिलचस्प बातों की इस श्रृंखला में आगे पढ़ते हैं आधुनिकता का अत्याचार।

"विवेक जांगड़ा ने लगातार चार गेंदों पर चार विकेट झटक कर एक अलग कीर्तिमान स्थापित किया है - ऐसा लग रहा लसिथ मलिंगा आज डीटीयू के खेल मैदान में गेंदबाजी कर रहे हैं, जिनके समर्थन में समर्थक झूमते नज़र आ रहे हैं।"

हाल ही में संपन्न हुए वार्षिक खेल महोत्सव में एक क्रिकेट मैच की कमेंटरी का कुछ हिस्सा है जो हॉस्टल के कमरों में साफ़ सुनाई दे रहा था। ऐसी कमेंटरी सुनकर वो दिन याद आ गया जब रामचरण काका की मौजूदगी में पीपल के पेड़ के निचे क्रिकेट में दिलचस्पी रखने और न रखने वाले लोग एक ही रेडियो से कान लगाकर देश-विदेश में हो रहे मैचों का सीधा प्रसारण सुनते थे। ये भीड़ क्रिकेट के अलावा देश-विदेश की ख़बरों को भी एक साथ ही सुनती थी जिसमें बीबीसी हिंदी से अंतर्राष्टीय, आकाशवाणी के दिल्ली केंद्र से राष्‍ट्रीय तो वहीँ आकाशवाणी के पटना केंद्र से आने वाली स्थानीय ख़बरों का मिश्रण होता था।

आखिर की दो संस्थाओं से समाचार का प्रसारण पूर्ववत चलता रहेगा लेकिन पिछले 80 वर्षों से हिंदी समाचार सुनाने वाली बीबीसी हिंदी ने समाचार का प्रसारण बंद कर दिया। काका की जनता पर इसका असर पड़े या न पड़े लेकिन इसका अफसोस हर उस छात्र को होगा जो शहर से दूर रहकर भारतीय प्रशासनिक सेवा जैसी अन्य परीक्षाओं में आनेवाली करंट अफेयर्स की तैयारी बीबीसी के करंट अफेयर्स के एपिसोड में करता था। ऐसी परीक्षाओं में आने वाले निबंधों की तैयारी उस विशेष एपिसोड पर निर्भर करती था जिसमें विश्व के महत्त्वपूर्ण हिस्सों के किस्सों पर गहन चर्चे हुआ करते थे। अब तो सुबह साढ़े छह बजे का "ब्रिटिश काल" का "नमस्ते भारत" आजकल "अमेरिकी काल" में "नमस्ते ट्रम्प" ने ले लिया है तो वहीं शाम साढ़े सात पर आने वाली "दिन भर" को टेलीविजन चैनलों ने अपने तरीके से मत-प्रचार में समाहित कर लिया है, लोग मूर्ख बनाये जा रहे हैं अवास्तविक झूठे छल-प्रपंचो से भरे समाचारों के माध्यम से,आधुनिक तौर तरीकों से।

अब आधुनिकता से लड़ते-लड़ते मेरे रामचनर काका आधुनिकता के शरण में आ गए हैं जिसका उन्हें अंदाज़ा नहीं शायद। बात दरअसल ऐसी है कि पिछली छुट्टी में मैं जब गांव गया तो देखा काका स्मार्टफोन चला रहे हैं, मेरी पहली प्रतिक्रिया थी...काका ई कवन लाइन धर लिए आप? काका भौंहें चढ़ाकर तिरछी नज़रों से मेरी तरफ देखे तो पर बिना कुछ बोले वापस व्हाट्सएप में आये मेसेज को मात्रा में मात्रा मिलाकर पढ़ने लगे…

"हम उठ गए हैं जल्दी गुड मॉर्निंग बोल दो और हाँ लाइन से बोलना धक्का मुक्की नहीं करना",

समझे बचवा इसके बाद देर तक काका मुझे बिठाकर एक-एक करके सारे फॉरवारडेड मेसेज को जबर्दस्ती सुनाने में लगे थे, अब चूंकि ठंड बहुत थी क्या करता चुपचाप सुनता रहा काका की अटकती हिंदी को, उस अलाव के सहारे। कोई बहाना बनाकर वहाँ से भागना भी थोड़ा अशिष्टाचार में गिना जाता...खैर काका इन फॉरवारडेड संदेशों को पढ़कर फूले नहीं समा रहे थे - वजह ये थी काका को इतना अपनापन वास्तविक ज़िन्दगी में कभी न मिला, इतनी भारी मात्रा में "राम-राम काका" थोड़े ही सुनने को मिलता है काका को। इक्के-दूक्के लोग ही बोलते हैं। बाकी जो चिंता की बात थी वो ये थी कि काका का जितना वक़्त समाज सुधारक बयानों में ज़ाया होता था उससे कहीं ज्यादा अब स्मार्टफोन में हो रहा है। वैसे ये वक़्त तो काका के लिए रेडियो पर समाचार सुनने का था पर आधुनिकता की मार ऐसी पड़ी की उनके रेडियो से अब समाचार चैनल गायब से होने लगे हैं।

इन बातों की चिंता काका को पहले ही खा चुकी है, काका पहले फड़फड़ाने लगते थे अब तो अस्त होने लगे हैं। ऐसा लग रहा जैसे आधुनिकता अब उनके चौखट पर है जो कभी गाँव की चौहद्दी तक आने में हिचकिचाती थी।

इतना कुछ सोच ही रहा था तभी काका फ़ोन लगाने लग गए दूर शहर अपने बेटे को ये बताने के लिये हाँ वो अहमदाबाद स्टेशन पर पहुँच गया है जैसे उसको ये खबर ही न थी, दरअसल उनका बेटा अभी कुछ दिनों पहले गाँव आया था और उनको ट्रेन के रनिंग स्टेटस के बारे में जानकारी अर्जित करने की विधि बता गया था। रामचनर काका इसका इस्तेमाल अपने तरीके से करते हैं बेचारे बेटे को हर घंटे फ़ोन करके बताते हैं।

"तू इंहा पहुँच गए हो न"

"हाँ बाबा अभी इसी स्टेशन पर हैं, आप देखिए न फ़ोन में, बार-बार बताने की जरूरत नहीं है"

"अरे नहीं हम तो ई चेक कर रहे हैं कि ई ऐप्पवा सही बता रहा है कि नाहीं"

ये वार्तालाप अब काका के आसपास रहने वाले लोगों के लिए आम हो गया है।

वहीं दूर ट्रेन में सफर कर रहे बेटे के लिए दुविधा ये है कि 

"इसे पिता-पुत्र का मोह समझे या आधुनिकता का अत्याचार"।

title: Interview | Adarsh Nair, CEO, Wynk Limited
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr Adarsh Nair, CEO, Wynk Limited and Chief Product Officer, Airtel, who was one of the keynote speakers in Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell, DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr Adarsh Nair, CEO, Wynk Limited and Chief Product Officer, Airtel, who was one of the keynote speakers in Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell, DTU.

How would you describe your journey with Wynk and Airtel?

My journey with Airtel has been a very good one. I chose to come to Airtel because India is one of the last bastions where there is a very big chance of growth happening in the next ten years. For any product manager, the dream is to be part of such a group. Also, the problems in India are very real, for example, if you look at the number of people with life insurance in this country, it is 22%, one of the lowest in the world. If you think about how people are doing transactions in this country, then you see that the penetration of digital is very small. So the problem is very real and it is a product manager’s dream to go behind such a problem. Airtel is a company where you have 300 million customers and 2000 enterprises, so it has already got a scale. Trying to sit with Airtel, and innovating with Airtel and reaching out to all these challenges in the country is a dream come true. That is how I see l progression in India and at Airtel. Wynk is one part of the problem where we are trying to solve how entertainment is delivered to the country but the larger problems which interest me are the ones around health, data, learning, education. And that is why I feel that Airtel has a huge role to play.

There are a lot of international competitors in the areas that you have mentioned. What would be the role of Airtel in those sectors?

We have thought a lot about it. Airtel has got four platforms which are data, network, distribution and payments. If you talk about data, we have one of the largest repositories of data in India. In innovation, we reach about 300 million people. In payments, 300 million people pay us. And we are the network, so we know the location and all those things. Any business that sits at the edge of these four will build. So we have built IoT. Advertising is another company which we should build because we have distribution and data. Anything else, we will support other companies. Vahan is a good example of a company which is trying to provide jobs to help the economy. So we will give our distribution and data to them and make them strong. So through partnership and our businesses, I think we can help India grow.

How do you plan on solving the problem of trucks in India?

If you look at Rivigo and BlackBuck, they are all companies which are trying to solve the Indian trucking problems. I do not differentiate. I rather believe in focusing on the problem. If I put the system that I built in the US in India, maximum truck drivers won’t be able to use the app which will be in English.

So you have to start looking at the problem in India. There are probably 25 languages which have come from all these different states. You have to build technology which works for them. So I don’t differentiate. I focus only on the problem and then find the solution to the problem. I always say “Love the problem, not the solution”.

title: Interview | Atul Kunwar, Chief Technology Services Officer, Sutherland Global Services and Ex-President, Tech Mahindra
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Atul Kunwar, Chief Technology Services Officer, Sutherland Global Services and Ex-President, Tech Mahindra, who was one of the keynote speakers in Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell, DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Atul Kunwar, Chief Technology Services Officer, Sutherland Global Services and Ex-President, Tech Mahindra, who was one of the keynote speakers at Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell, DTU.

Being an alumnus of DCE, what differences do you find in current DTU and DCE? 

I’ve come back after 35 years and this campus didn’t even exist back then. Some things have improved tremendously: the infrastructure, the number of students and their happiness levels! I am really pleased by how the college has evolved. Having missed it all these years, coming back is a pleasant experience. 

You have been the President at Tech Mahindra and now you are the Chief Technology Services Officer at Sutherland Global Services, and have had a lot of leadership experience in the past as well. Do you think leadership qualities are innate or built over time? 

What really helps when you go into the corporate world is having empathy and treating people with dignity so that you get respect in return. At the same time, you must never compromise on results.

Leadership is something you learn in college. My initial college days were a learning experience. In my college days, at DCE, one spent a lot of time doing a variety of things. I recollect that we had our own Students’ Union and I was elected. We had a lot of responsibilities, including running the festivals that would take place. The Students’ Association was one of my first places to learn and then subsequently lead.

Once, we had an all India tour via train. There were about 80 of us, and it was difficult in those days to travel so extensively. I learnt a lot of practical skills on our journey. That one trip taught me how to handle situations while having fun; and that’s where I think my instinct to lead comes from. 

Although, what really helps when you go into the corporate world is having empathy and treating people with dignity so that you get respect in return. At the same time, you must never compromise on results. Your outcomes and results define what you can achieve but at the same time, you don’t have to be harsh. You can be demanding, but you still need to be empathetic. 

You have handled leadership positions both in New York as well as India. What are the differences and challenges that you faced at the two places and how do you think the market at both these places differs? 

At the core level, people are the same. The difference comes across more in terms of cultural elements. For instance, in the formative years, as we were an evolving country with an evolving economy, people were willing to work harder. While in the West, sometimes they would be very clear about wanting to lead a balanced life. After 5 PM on Fridays, everything would shut off for the weekend. One has to learn to adjust to both of these circumstances. Although, the kind of productivity that you get from the workforce in the US is much higher. The other element is that their teams have a much wider exposure; they know how to connect the dots and tap into their creativity. You get more experienced resources in more evolved Western markets. In India, we have good coders but their skills somehow don’t translate into real life problem solving. Domain expertise also had a gap, which has narrowed down over the past few years. 

What would you suggest the upcoming generations on how they should mitigate the knowledge and infrastructural gaps?

In today’s day and age, to say, “I was disadvantaged, so I couldn’t do it”, is not a valid argument.

In my view, neither an infrastructural gap nor a learning gap exists. The world has become closer from a ‘learning’ point of view. It depends on how you adapt. The way you work across with it, really makes a difference. Opportunity is where you exploit it. In today’s day and age, to say, “I was disadvantaged, so I couldn’t do it”, is not a valid argument. It is clear that people get opportunity if they seek one. You’re getting it once you come to an institute like this. So, make the best of it and compete with the world. 

What should the students inculcate in themselves to become a better leader or a better person to manage their corporate roles and academic roles when they grow up?

One of the key elements is that you should know what you’re good at. In the past it was said that you should know your strengths and weaknesses, you must focus on your weaknesses. I believe the opposite. I believe that you should focus on your strengths because if you focus on your strengths you can do more things. I believe that working on your strengths has a cumulative effect. You already have a key strength and you can improve yourself more easily using that skill.

My kids are working, and they are off my payroll; and my clear instruction to them is to work very hard in the initial years and to make sure you earn a lot because life is going to be different. And I challenge them to earn their first million before they turn 30. It’s not the things you can do with that kind of money, but it’s the degrees of freedom you have; you can choose whatever you want to do in life. That makes a big difference. 

Above all, one must never stop learning. There is so much happening in the world, and there is so much to learn. Focus on your strengths and your interests. And, don’t get into a company just to get a job. If you are better at doing something consumer-oriented then focus on the consumer side of it and if you enjoy working with machines, factories and automation, then focus on that. Different people have to be good at different things and their styles of operation have to be different too. For example, someone may have a bossy working style, one could be more submissive as a person, and one could like to contribute as much as they can. But if all of these people make a team, it would be a heterogeneous team and that’s how a team should be. One must get a wider exposure to people. If we are with the same kind of people, we get similar ideas.

title: Interview | Jyoti Gupta, Co-founder, RankMeOnline
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Ms. Jyoti Gupta, Co-founder, RankMeOnline, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Ms. Jyoti Gupta, Co-founder, RankMeOnline, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

What sets RankMeOnline apart from its competitors?

RankMeOnline started with the focus of using AI-related solutions for businesses. There aren’t many companies in India who are doing this. It’s mainly US and European companies involved in this. Many of our counterparts have built solutions which are still manual, while we have done the same through AI. It is advantageous because first,  I can bring down the prices as US technology or manual solutions, both will be costlier. Secondly, it helps me scale my businesses. I can approach multiple brands and get the product out. RankMeOnline sits at a base where it can cater to a lot of companies directly.

As you said, not a lot of companies in India have incorporated AI. What challenges did you face when you were taking up something as novel as AI?

The only challenge that I faced was getting my foot in the door and then eventually squeeze in the market. The problem was majorly getting clients because I’m from a technical background and didn’t have much access to networks or brands to get onboard. For that, I used a lot of Startup India challenges to get an idea of the corporate world where we pitched solutions to companies as something that could help their businesses. Since almost all corporates identified that our business solution works for them, they were able to use RankMeOnline in their companies. We’re still facing that problem; we haven’t completely cracked the code. We’re hiring more people in Sales - those who have more experience and can help scale the business.

We’re surrounded by people pursuing engineering at DTU. What can someone, who’s inclined towards entrepreneurship and building a startup, incorporate in their lives while handling engineering at the same time?

Try to make at least 6 hours a day available to you; where and how you spend these 6 hours is up to you. A lot of people spend it on watching sitcoms and playing games. You can also use your time to focus on your talent, something more than your academics. If you’re good at expressing yourself on social media, then focus on that too. It can also give you the benefit of understanding how certain communities work or how people think. Use whatever there is to improve yourself. As we can see during the E-Summit, there is already a lot of focus on startups that are excellent. So, whatever you do, do it with a passion and excel at it. You can use your 6 hours to do anything in a better, professional way, and that will also reap you benefits. You’ll be disciplined and more focused on whatever path you’ve chosen for your own growth - whether it is entrepreneurship or working in a big company.

You’re from a technical background and you’ve used your technical skills to build your startup. What advice do you have for all the women pursuing a career in science and technology, which is primarily male-dominated field?

I’ll tell you from my personal experience. I graduated in 2012, and I had offers from three companies- Amazon, Directi, and Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS). The idea is to not get botched down by placements - you’ll always get placed. There will be times when it is hard for you, being the lesser part of the pie. In the very start of my professional career, there were times when meetings would go on till midnight for which I had to stayback in the office, and my parents would be very concerned about my safety. Sometimes, you’ll have to behave like a man and take your decisions upfront. You cannot play down and feel the pressure of your parents, otherwise it’ll just make your career go downhill. The other thing is that you need to be confident that you are at par with others. Let’s say that there’s an opportunity to be grabbed, and you feel that you’re not good enough for it. The other person might also be feeling the same way - it’s just a matter of who speaks up first. So, be ready for all the opportunities, be confident, and be ready to face the world. Don’t get botched down- be the person that you are.

title: Interview | Anubhav Tiwari, Head Outreach, CIE, IIIT Hyderabad
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Anubhav Tiwari, Head Outreach, Centre for Innovation and Entrepreneurship, IIIT Hyderabad, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020 organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Anubhav Tiwari, Head Outreach, Centre for Innovation and Entrepreneurship, IIIT Hyderabad, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020 organised by E-Cell DTU.

What basic points do you look for in an idea that can be termed as feasible for a startup?

The idea should be big enough to cater to the problems that exist. The ideology that ‘my college is facing this problem, so I should build this product’ is wrong. Since your college is not accurate market size, you will have to see whether that problem is actually being faced by the masses. Any potential idea should be the solution to a problem being faced by the masses. That’s when you have the potential to scale.

Over the past few years, startups have shifted from product-based business to service-based business. What could be the reason for that?

The shift is different in different geographies. If you consider the case of Hyderabad, for example, in the early 90s product-based companies were more but by the late 90s, there was a considerable rise in service-based companies. However, after 2007, there was a shift again in favour of product-based companies. To be fair, we cannot make a general comment about this shift as scenarios everywhere are different. If you ask me, though, as someone who has been in and around the ecosystem for several years now, I'd say the transition is more towards the product side, that is, people are shifting to product-based companies rather than service-based ones. 

Do you think the use of Artificial Intelligence in startups today is a beneficial step?

AI is the future and it is catching up. If you're building something around AI, you're being futuristic since it will cover most of the operational aspects of your company sooner or later. Everything is based on data nowadays and it depends on you that how you convert that data into information, information into insights and the insights into decisions. If this process involves fewer humans and more unbiased algorithms, the results will surely be better. 

If you ask me how the trend was during the ’90s, I would say that it was the IT boom. Right now, it’s the AI boom.

How does an entrepreneur's experience different if he pitches directly to a venture capitalist, rather than approaching an incubator first?

"Why can't I sit for Boards right now, without going to school?"

VC comes into the picture at a much later stage. When you go to an incubator first, you get a lot of help at the initial stage. It is like a first grader asking the question "Why can't I sit for Boards right now, without going to school?" There is a reason why schools and other academic institutions exist and there's a reason why we go to them. You can say you'll get the books, take home tuitions, won't go to school and still learn. Of course, you will learn but the institutions provide a structure to the learning process and you will miss out on that. 

Getting into an incubation centre is good as you get to learn from the mistakes of others and know exactly what to avoid. You can get some very critical strategic help at early stages. Plus, you get the infrastructure support so you don't have to worry about the services you require when building the company. Once you get an incubator's tag on you, it becomes the responsibility of the incubator to bring investors for you.

What, according to you, is a better step for entrepreneurs - to do a startup as a fresher or after 5-6 years of industry experience?

The industry experience disciplines you, teaches you how to work with a team, and also gives you the domain knowledge of the industry. When working on a startup, you don’t have anyone to tell you about right or wrong, and you aren’t mature enough to take such decisions right after college. So a few years of working under someone in the corporate world actually gives you a disciplined and organized way of running projects. Ultimately, a startup is also a project - a pretty big one! So if you are disciplined enough, know team cohesiveness, know how to build it and take it forward, it definitely adds on. 

This doesn’t mean that if you don’t have this experience, you won’t be successful. There are many good stories involving people who haven’t worked anywhere and are successfully running startups. But it’s always a standard practice to work prior to running a startup. It’s like saying that people have qualified for UPSC without going for coaching. Well, how many do? Very few.

Does age become a barrier for entrepreneurs, given that the willingness to take risks is generally varying? 

Age is just a number!

No, it’s not like that. PUBG was developed by a 62-year-old photographer, not even a game developer. So, age is just a number.

The problem is not age, it’s the liabilities one has to take care of. If you have to take care of education loans or some other liabilities, it will stop you from taking risks. If you have a family to look after, you won’t put everything at stake for a start-up. So, it’s the liabilities that stop you, not the age.

What final message would you give to the students planning to venture into entrepreneurship?

Yes. Before you start, please use Google first. It’s the simplest and easiest thing that everybody avoids, but it eventually matters. You need to understand your market, you need to do a lot of research, and you need to build things that people need, not what you think people need.

title: International Seminar on Quality Indices in High Education (ISQIHE-2020)
biliner: Delhi Technological University, in collaboration with Engineering Staff College of India,  will be organising a three-day International Seminar on Quality Indices in High Education (ISQIHE-2020), on 19th-21st March 2020.
body:
Delhi Technological University, in collaboration with Engineering Staff College of India,  will be organising a three-day International Seminar on Quality Indices in High Education (ISQIHE-2020), on 19th-21st March 2020. The main aim of the conference is to spot achievements and challenges of higher education system from the perspective of quality assurance, to share good practices, and to discuss further perspectives. The conference is dedicated to discussing the tasks ahead in implementation of new education policy in India. 

The summit will have four tracks, namely, ‘Accreditation System’, ‘Governance, Policy & Leadership in higher learning institution’, ‘Ranking System’, ‘Technology, Innovation & Entrepreneurship’. The tracks will broadly be covering Teaching learning process, NBA Accreditation, NAAC Accreditation,  National Education Policy, Governance issues in higher learning institutions, NIRF Ranking, India, QS World University Ranking, Technologies for evaluation and assessment, etc. The summit will also include ISQIHE Hackathon, a hackathon organised in association with E-Cell DTU. 

The speakers in ISQIHE-2020 include Padma Shri Prof. Anil Kumar Gupta, IIM Ahmedabad, Prof. P. Ranjan, VC, DY Patil International University, Prof. S. G. Deshmukh, IIT Delhi, Prof. Rajeev Tripathi, Director, MNNIT Allahabad, Prof. NJ Rao, IISC Bangalore, Prof. Yogesh Singh, VC, DTU , Prof. Anu Singh Lather, VC, Ambedkar University, Prof. J.P. Singh Joorel, Director, Inflibnet, Prof. Sarit K Das, Director, IIT, Ropar. 

The conference will be coordinated by Prof. Madan Mohan Tripathi, Director, IQAC, Delhi Technological University and Er. Sai Kishore P., Head (FDP Cell) & Head (Corporate Relations and Outreach), Engineering Staff College of India.
