title: Interview|Harsh Sawnani, Talent Acquisition Leader, Deloitte
biliner:
DTU Times interviewed Harsh Sawnani, Talent Acquisition Leader, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
DTU Times interviewed Harsh Sawnani, Talent Acquisition Leader, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
DTU Times interviewed Harsh Sawnani, Talent Acquisition Leader, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
Failure as a topic was often touched upon in the discussion today. You mentioned that you failed in your college exams ten-fifteen years ago. How have the challenges changed over a span of fifteen years? Do you still feel dejected when you fail, or do you just view failure as an opportunity?

There are two parts to your question. I’ll answer the latter first. I look at failure the same way as I did fifteen years ago. It’s how you keep evolving your mental setup that counts. One thing is for sure, more opportunities are bound to come. Don’t get me wrong, I fail now as well- but over time I’ve learnt to incorporate my past expertise to overcome the challenges presented to me. I often say ‘This too shall pass’ since it has already occurred and I was able to overcome it then hence, I’ll be able to overcome it now.

As for the former question, things have changed dramatically over the past fifteen years. Every five years, there is a generation change. I’m talking about the time when I had Nokia 3315 and today the scenario is completely different. Opportunities are limitless. You get many more options now, the avenues are much wider. You can do a lot of things and know about a lot of things. Back then we were stuck with a few options and were not aware how others were looking at them due to restricted flow of information, but it isn’t the same anymore. Problem solving has a whole different array of options to choose from. Instead of the emphasis being on success, like it was twenty years back, today it is okay to fail. Spanning from sports teams to world leaders, failure is acceptable. So, that acceptance of failure and the presence of alternate avenues has changed.

With the huge influx of students into the area of entrepreneurship, what would you say are a few red flags they should be aware of?

Don’t just follow the rat race, don’t do it because others are. I said one thing very prominently in my speech earlier, that is there is a marked difference between an idea and intellectual property. You can have a great idea but till the time it converts into an intellectual property, in terms of becoming a business unit or revenue generating model, you are still just maybe playing with fire and hoping against hope. So, it’s important for you to be wary of the fact that a great idea is great but if you don’t have a plan to convert it into an intellectual property, then you are stepping into uncharted territory where you’re bound to encounter many pitfalls. 

Secondly, I think you should always have a Plan B in your mind, because there’ll be obstacles. When I talk about Plan B, I’m not talking about an escape plan, I’m talking about how and what you’ll do if a certain aspect of your plan doesn’t pan out as you wanted it to,. Also, be very well versed or aware of your competition. Know your competition. Nokia failed because it was never able to cope up with the evolution around. Hence, it’s important for you to have alternate options available, concrete plans to convert your idea into an intellectual property and to remain aware about the changing trends.

You have talked extensively about ‘Mindset: The New Psychology of Success’, a very successful book written by Carol Dweck. So, what would you say are the books which will help budding entrepreneurs develop and eventually achieve success?

At the moment, I can only think of this book. But I think they should focus on learning more about people who have succeeded and more importantly, they should read about people who have succeeded in recent times. What worked earlier may not be working today but the ground rules and the structure remains the same. The way you deal with people in a certain situation does not change. If you read about people who have succeeded now, you’ll realise that there are some absolute mavericks who have changed the world. Conditioning your mind that it has worked for other people and it will work for me too, is essential. To realise your potential books are great but practical knowledge is essential and can’t be avoided. You can’t master cricket without playing it on the field. Practical knowledge is something that you must focus more on, rather than the theory. Theory is necessary to have some perspective but implementing it and practising it with experienced people is imperative for growth.

You said that there’s a generation change every five years. Do you think it aggrandises the situation concerning the Indian market, which is already a tough nut to crack, for new companies who are trying to thrive in it?

I would like to look at it more positively. There’s more opportunity in a market like India because it is still not highly developed, and it is still not struggling in terms of basic infrastructure. There is a push by the government too and you also have NGO’s. There’s an emphasis on crowdfunding as well. I don’t think a changing environment is a challenge, I think it’s an opportunity for you to see your ideas turn into intellectual property. Regarding the frequent changes in the way generations think, again, I would like to look at it as an opportunity for you to keep yourself fresh and new.

You mention that one of the key things that you look for in a candidate is the attitude they bring to the table. So, what are the characteristics you look for in a candidate?

I think passion is the word. If you’re passionate and if it comes across, then it sets the tone for you to be successful in whatever field you want. If you’re not good at something, you will get better at it if you keep working on it. Most successful people on this planet are people who have been extremely passionate. If it’s an idea that you want to turn into success, you must be absolutely hawk-eyed with blinkers. The gravitational pull of that passion will make sure that you keep evolving. For me, passion is paramount, and everything boils down to that. You gain more knowledge if you’re passionate. If you’re passionate about leaving an impression, then you’ll make sure that you invest in your subject matter expertise as well. If you’re passionate about clearing your interview, then you will do your research on it, you will talk to people who have cleared it in the past. That research, that growth mindset, all of it will follow if you have passion in the first place.

title: Interview | Atul Tiwari
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Atul Tiwari, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Atul Tiwari, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

With so much talk going on about entrepreneurship, do you think that today’s fresh graduates are not as inclined towards securing a job as their predecessors?

I do feel that because nowadays there are a lot of avenues that people are aware of and they definitely want to explore something non-conventional, unlike what it used to be earlier. People really know what the problems at hand are and how they can be solved. 

People often are reluctant to switch from a cushy job in a big firm to becoming a part of a startup. What are some of the aspects that one must keep in mind while deciding if or not they should switch?

 You could have a great idea, a great thought process and a solution to a great problem but if you don’t have the right ecosystem, then it is all in vain. 

It all depends on how you as an individual are, what your needs are and what kind of an ecosystem you have. You could have a great idea, a great thought process and a solution to a great problem but if you don’t have the right ecosystem, then it is all in vain. An ecosystem- it includes you as an individual, your mindset, your thought process and other aspects like funding and the sustainability of a particular idea- is something which definitely helps you. Otherwise if you see, it is always safer at times to get a job, identify the nuances, and then go for something typically more aspirational. Nevertheless, you might face some new problems altogether. But still, it is better to have a known devil than an unknown one. It is also alright if one decides to go for a startup without securing a job first.

What was the one thing which helped you transition into such starkly different roles in different companies?

Be fluid like water. Having an open mindset is also very important. Do not have preconceived notions and water-tight compartments in your mind about what you want to do and be stuck to it. Always remember that what you are doing is not only for your professional growth but also for you as an individual; it defines your personality, which gives you freedom, satisfaction, and a sense of success. It is very important to realise that what took you to one position may not take you to another. Now you need to reap something differently to reach another level. You need to develop agility with respect to changing roles and the different expectations which come with them.

You mentioned earlier in your talk that when you were starting out, you would have preferred a corporate role to a business role. Why was that?

This was a preconceived notion of mine. I thought that it was the safest path at that point of time. But when I was given a business role, it gave me a different perspective altogether about the organisation- how it works, its vision, and the realisation that I could contribute in a much better way here than in a corporate role. I don’t mean to say that a corporate role does not provide you with the same kind of visibility, but it provides you with limited visibility. When you are in a business (role), you know what you are into. It also allows you to apply what you have learnt and your experiences. You also find a context to deal with a problem and a vision that you have to attain. Hence, I was fortunate to have been pushed into a business role and get the opportunities to learn.

You talked about how one of the characteristics of a good entrepreneur is in how he handles chaos and ambiguity. What are some other important traits?

Chaos and ambiguity are constants. One very important thing is capacity, both in terms of skill set and patience. Even if you are faced with a very difficult situation, you must not get bogged down by it, distressed by it or deviated from your vision. So, capacity does define one of the major traits of an ideal entrepreneur or a part of an entrepreneurial organization.

Are long stints at firms still as fruitful as they used to be as far as career progression is concerned?

I think the tenure does not matter, rather what value you add to the organisation and what value you get from the organisation are what matter. Tenure, be it of one year or ten years, does not matter. Till the time you do not get the feeling that you have contributed whatever you could to the organisation, you should continue with the work. But you must also consider the opportunities and the values that you are getting from the organisation. If both the parameters are being met, then the number of years don’t matter. 

Why do you say that people who have failed as entrepreneurs can do well in corporate jobs?

That is not always the case but this is what seems to be the trend now. They seem to have the guts to take initiative, and they have experimented because of which they have developed creativity, which is important since nowadays mundane things do not work. Hence, employers will go for such people who can do something new since that is the need of the hour. Entrepreneurs also have risk-taking ability and capacity. They have also experienced hardships, which is why they do not have a rosy picture of the organisation painted in their minds. They seem to have more hunger and fire in them, which is required and expected nowadays. So, even hundred-year-old corporations need such people to change the wheels. They act as catalysts in bringing about change.

How do you think that the startup culture has changed over the years?

It has not changed a lot since it has just started but there are a few changes in terms of how they are approaching- they are more conscious about the problem that they are tackling and are now keeping users at the center rather than the solution to the problem. There are two things: the destination and the journey. Now, the journey is something that startups are focusing on. They are focusing on what kind of journey the users are experiencing while using the product. That is very important.

title: Interview | Rajesh Das, CEO, Founder of InLog
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Rajesh Das, CEO, Founder of InLog, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Rajesh Das, CEO, Founder of InLog, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

Start-ups are not very popular amongst students. How do you think that we can teach students that this risk is worth taking?

In my opinion, every university should start an incubator. A lot of collaborative work with the huge DTU alumni network also needs to be done. For reaching out to students who are more academically inclined, courses related to startups should be introduced.  Lack of knowledge agitates people; one may have an idea but not the proper skillset to execute it.

Do you think the DCE/DTU nostalgia still exists? Do the people consider DCE better than DTU?

People do have a tendency to think that 'their' time was better. However, I feel that today's environment is extremely different and needs to be appreciated in its own way.

How do you think the startup culture has changed over the years?

People have seen the opportunities in this sector only recently.  We now explore ourselves more as individuals. Earlier, people were organisation dependent but now, they are more open towards starting their own companies and being entrepreneurs.

How can the quality of startups improve?

Newer ideas need to come in the picture. As of now, there is a shortage of ideas. The quality of ideas is a latter concern.

How do you think E-summit helps to change the mindset of the students?

Students can now seek inspiration from live examples, 'the Doers'. The hesitation of taking the first step has vanished. The incubation center can play a huge role in changing mindsets. 

What are the challenges faced while building a startup?

Shortage of money is one problem. While exploring one's ideas, it becomes difficult to look for venture capitalists. There is a shortage of availability of seed funds as well. 

What is your advice for students who would like to venture in the entrepreneurship field?

Search for yourself.  We need to understand that the world is changing and  there is an ecological division. People need to connect, understand the purpose and relate with your ideas.

How do you think people can pursue their calling, if it's too late to start?

It is never too late to start. It is a journey. You can always change your career, all you need to do is explore and find your passion and develop it. The fear of failure needs to go away. We need to attach to ourselves by spending more time with nature.  Most CEOs always try to find peace in nature and get into the process of self realization. One should start thinking and connecting with the sources in our vicinity.

title: Interview | Rajiv Juneja, Co-founder and Director of Projects, Reliable Business Management Support Systems
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Rajiv Juneja, Co-founder and Director of Projects, Reliable Business Management Support Systems, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Rajiv Juneja, Co-founder and Director of Projects, Reliable Business Management Support Systems, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

You mentioned that you had been in a job for forty years before you began your own venture. Why motivated you to do so and what does your new job entail?

I switched to consultancy because after my superannuation, I wanted to engage myself, to keep myself active, so I started a small venture of my own – a reliable businessmen support system. We support sick units – people who are doing very good but somehow, due to operational problems or market conditions or any other reason, they went into loss. We try to restore their health. We try to improve their profitability and help them increase their avenues so that they can garner more market share. It’s going well. As a matter of chance, when we were doing all this, one of the team members came forward and said that they wanted to have one more vertical. So, we are now supporting e-vehicles as well. However, the investments involved in it are huge, so we will not be able to invest but we can support them. We can tell them about the best technology available and how they can adopt those technologies. How, in the future, we can build those products here in India because sometimes it pinches me that, as engineering graduates, we are not able to give back that much. When we graduated, the difference between India and China was not that great but now there is such a huge gap. I don’t how we can plug that gap. Anyway, let’s forget about that, bad memories. You shouldn’t keep them with yourself (laughs). So, now we need to put in our best. We are now supporting some businesses and their e-vehicle ventures.

The current start-ups in the Indian market follow a certain trend, like we have a lot of e-commerce websites. What do you want to see changing in the current start-up scenario?

Nowadays, we have all started repeating, more or less. We have come to a stage where we see Ola, Uber, Swiggy, Zomato and UrbanClap. There is a lot of repetition now which leads to pointless competition amongst us. The manufacturing sector, however, has a lot of wiggle room. We are not utilising our engineering skills where, again, China is much far ahead. Sometimes, it really pains me that any device I pick in my house has ‘Made in China’ written on it and that’s not good so we need to catch up on the manufacturing sector now. Swiggy, Zomato, Paytm will all have a lot of competition among them. A lot of MNCs will come and they would like us to compete and ultimately, we’ll hand over our businesses to them. So, the next ten years must be utilised for the manufacturing sector because USA, Europe and all the countries of the world want to exit China, they have given enough indicators. But we are not coming forward. When we go to China, we literally develop a complex that we will not be able to reach this level. So that complex needs to be resolved and we must focus on manufacturing because otherwise, giving employment to such a large population is not possible. Swiggy is giving employment to a delivery man but I have seen engineers delivering food. So, I think that we need to focus more on the manufacturing sector. The service sector is good and very safe – lesser profits, lesser loss but still, manufacturing sector is much better so we must focus on that. We need to give a good challenge. Please tell the authorities in your college to focus more on the manufacturing sector as a part of the curriculum. You must have seen the people in ‘Excel Technologies’ and that is a very good idea that needs to be promoted.

You were talking about the competition between India and China. So, sometimes it becomes very difficult for small ventures to survive or to thrive in this environment. So how do you think these small business ventures can cope?

We must follow China’s model. When China was starting some fifty-sixty years back, where we are today, they were taking technologies from Japan, Europe or some other country. They mastered those technologies to such an extent, that the best mobile and laptop companies come from there at one-third the price at which they are sold to us. That means that there is a lot of room in between. An I-phone priced at $3,000 is sold at $700 so there is a lot of room in between. And it is not a very competitive market so we can replace them. The US and Europe both want that. We have to come forward now, we have to say, “We are ready to invest”. Now, the problem is that there are a lot of funds available in the market, that can be invested, provided that strong teams are there that are able to convince them that these ventures are profitable. All these corporates are literally sitting on money. They have a lot of profit coming in and they are sitting on a lot of money which they can invest. All we must do is convince them that we can compete with China. If they are convinced, it is done.

What measures do you think that the manufacturing sector can take to improve?

There is a problem with our business sector, overall. They have been family-centric and the business or the industries are handed over from families to the nearest one. New talent used to go there but they are not able to retain that talent with them for a long time. So, we need to have more professionalism. We must infuse professionalism into the family run businesses. You may still have executive chairman; you can have managing directors, but family run businesses should not provide employment only to the family members but must do something else. They must do that because the time has come now. They must place economic intelligence above the interest of the family and that is how we can progress. Otherwise, it is the same old story. We have a lot of expectations from the new generation, on this count.

A lot of questions have been raised about the employability of engineering graduates, in general. So, do you think that it affects the jobs that they take up and the start-up culture in general?

Starting a start-up means employing yourself. I don’t find any difference between giving employment to yourself and generating employment for other people. So, that should not hold us back. We must choose any path wherein we are able to use our engineering. Everyone runs after IIM and FMS. So, that makes us forget a lot of things about engineering. Even the youngsters in my own family after graduating from IIM want to forget engineering and this is bad because the institute spent so much on them. It is another form of brain drain and that’s where we need to do something. Maybe, we can go for specialization after B.Tech.. Research is one area where we must invest our resources and engineering graduates are the optimal candidates for that. It may take a while to pay you, but when you finally receive payment, it will be worth it. One good research idea and you’re in luck. This is what we need to do.

Often, many students leave the country and go to US or any other country because they complain that the research infrastructure in India is lacking and this leads to brain drain. What are your thoughts on this matter?

Yes, brain drain is real but then there are people like Narayan Murthy. They are running incubators. It all depends on how we think. There are a lot of small organizations doing research. So, there are good examples but going to US is the easier option. The problem is the way our country is manipulated. In the US, majority of the kids drop out after twelfth grade. They are happy working in McDonalds or something like that. They are not born rich, so they need talent and they are utilising us. Students of DTU and IITs rush to US and if not the US, then Canada or Australia or even UK. Now, Europe is providing opportunities as well because these countries have a small knowledge base and they want us. People can still come back; it depends on them. However, they will only come back if they find the infrastructure here comparable to what those countries have. At some point, we hope that they will return and help. I agree that, fifteen-twenty years back, opportunities in the country were not that great, but today they are. Earlier, one had to struggle to get gas cylinders and open bank accounts, but today, that is not the case. Things have changed a lot. The level of transparency has increased, and the tax department doesn’t trouble you anymore (laughs).

I switched to consultancy because after my superannuation, I wanted to engage myself, to keep myself active; so I started a small venture of my own – a reliable businessmen support system. We are now supporting some businesses and their e-vehicle ventures. We support sick units – people who are doing very good but somehow, due to operational problems or market conditions, they are suffering market loss. We try to restore their health. We try to improve their profitability and help them increase their avenues so that they can garner more market share. We are now support e-vehicles as well; we can tell them about the best technology available and how they can adopt those technologies. 

Sometimes it pinches me that, as engineering graduates, we are not able to give back that much. When we graduated, the difference between India and China was not that significant but now there is such a huge gap. So, now we need to put in our best to plug in that gap.

The current startups in the Indian market follow a certain trend, like we have a lot of e-commerce websites. What do you want to see changing in the current start-up scenario?

Nowadays, we have all started repeating, more or less. We have come to a stage where we see Ola, Uber, Swiggy, Zomato and UrbanClap. There is a lot of repetition now which leads to pointless competition amongst us. The manufacturing sector, however, has a lot of wiggle room. We are not utilising our engineering skills where, again, China is much far ahead. Sometimes, it really pains me that any device I pick in my house has ‘Made in China’ written on it and that’s why I believe that so we need to catch up on the manufacturing sector now. A lot of MNCs have evolved and they would like us to compete and ultimately, we hand over our businesses to them. The next ten years must be utilised for the manufacturing sector because USA, Europe and all the countries of the world want to exit China's businesses. But we are not coming forward. When we look at China, we develop an inferiority complex that we will not be able to reach their level. That complex needs to be resolved and we must focus on manufacturing because otherwise, giving employment to such a large population is not possible. The service sector is good and very safe – lesser profits, lesser loss. I think that we need to focus more on the manufacturing sector. Courses that help students understand about the manufacturing sector must be introduced in the curriculum as well.

You were talking about the competition between India and China. It often becomes very difficult for small ventures to thrive in such a competitive market. How do you think these small businesses and startups can cope?

We have to say, “We are ready to invest”. 

We must follow China’s model. When China was starting around fifty-sixty years back, where we are today, they were taking technologies from Japan, Europe or some other country. They mastered those technologies to such an extent, that the best mobile and laptop companies come from there at one-third the price at which they are sold to us. An iPhone priced at $3,000 is sold at $700; there is a lot of room in between. And, it is not a very competitive market so we can replace them. The US and Europe both want that. We have to come forward now, we have to say, “We are ready to invest”. 

Now, the problem is that there are a lot of funds available in the market that can be used for investment, provided there are strong teams are there that are able to convince these investors that these ventures are profitable. All these corporate companies have a lot of profit coming in and they are not utilising the money which they can invest. All we must do is convince them and we can compete with China.

What measures do you think that the manufacturing sector can take to improve?

There is a problem with our business sector as a whole: They have been family-centric and the business or the industries are handed over from families to the nearest one. Even if new talent would go there, they wouldn't be able to retain that talent with them for a long time. We must infuse professionalism into the family run businesses. You may still have executive chairman, or managing directors, but family run businesses should not provide employment only to the family members but to others as well. They must place economic intelligence above the interest of the family and that is how we can progress. Otherwise, it is the same old story. We have a lot of expectations from the new generation, on this count.

A lot of questions have been raised about the employability of recent engineering graduates, in general. So, do you think that it affects the jobs that they take up and the startup culture in general?

One good research idea and you’re in luck!

Starting a startup means employing yourself. I don’t find any difference between giving employment to yourself and generating employment for other people. So, that should not hold us back. We must choose any path wherein we are able to use our engineering. Everyone runs after IIMs and FMS and that makes us forget a lot of things about engineering. Even the youngsters in my own family after graduating from IIM want to forget engineering and this is unfortunate because the institute has spent so much on them. It is another form of brain drain and this is where we need to act. Maybe, we can go for specialisation after B.Tech. Research is one area where we must invest our resources and engineering graduates are the optimal candidates for that. It may take a while to pay you, but when you finally receive payment, it will be worth it. One good research idea and you’re in luck. This is what our focus should be.

Often, many students leave the country and go to the US or any other country because they complain that the research infrastructure in India is lacking. What are your thoughts on this?

It all depends on how we think. There are a lot of small organisations doing research. So, there are good examples but going to US is the easier option. The problem is the way our country is manipulated. Students of DTU and IITs rush to US and if not the US, then Canada or Australia or even the UK. Now, Europe is providing opportunities as well because these countries have a small knowledge base and they want us. People can still come back; it depends on them. 

However, they will only come back if they find the infrastructure here comparable to what those countries have. I agree that, fifteen-twenty years back, opportunities in the country were not that great, but today they are. Earlier, one had to struggle to get gas cylinders and open bank accounts, but today, that is not the case. Things have changed a lot. The level of transparency has also increased. At some point, we hope that they will return and help.

title: Interview | Harsh Sawnani, Talent Acquisition Leader, Deloitte
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Harsh Sawnani, Talent Acquisition Leader, Deloitte, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020 organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Harsh Sawnani, Talent Acquisition Leader, Deloitte, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020 organised by E-Cell DTU.

What are some characteristics you look for in a job candidate?

I think passion is the word. For me, passion is paramount, and everything boils down to that. If you come across as passionate, it sets the tone for you to be successful in whichever field you want to pursue. If you’re not good at something, you will get better at it if you keep working on it. Most successful people on this planet are people who have been extremely passionate. If it’s an idea that you want to turn into success, you must be absolutely hawk-eyed with blinkers. The gravitational pull of that passion will make sure that you keep evolving. You gain more knowledge if you’re passionate. If you’re passionate about leaving an impression, then you’ll make sure that you invest in your subject matter expertise as well. If you’re passionate about clearing your interview, then you will do your research on it, you will talk to people who have cleared it in the past. That research, that growth mindset, all of it will follow if you have passion in the first place.

The topic of failure was often touched upon in the discussion today. You mentioned that you failed in your college exams 10-15 years ago. How have the challenges changed over a span of fifteen years? Do you still feel dejected when you fail, or do you view failure as an opportunity?

I was talking about the time when I had a Nokia 3315, and today the scenario is completely different. Things have changed dramatically over the last fifteen years, since every five years, there is a generation change. Now, opportunities and options are limitless. Back then, we were stuck with a few options and were not aware of how others were looking at them due to the restricted flow of information, but it isn’t the same anymore. Problem solving has a whole different array of options to choose from. Instead of the emphasis being on success, like it was twenty years ago, today, failure is acceptable. So, that acceptance of failure and the presence of alternate avenues has changed.

I look at failure the same way as I did fifteen years ago. It’s how you keep evolving your mental setup that counts. One thing is for sure, more opportunities are bound to come. Don’t get me wrong, I fail now as well, but over time I’ve learnt to incorporate my past expertise to overcome the challenges presented to me. I often say ‘this too shall pass', since it has already occurred and I was able to overcome it then; hence, I’ll be able to overcome it now.

What would you say are a few red flags that students venturing into entrepreneurship should be aware of?

Don’t just follow the rat race, and don’t do something just because others are doing it. There is a marked difference between an idea and intellectual property. You can have a great idea, but till the time it converts into intellectual property, in terms of becoming a business unit or a revenue generating model, you are still just maybe playing with fire and hoping against hope. It’s important to be wary of the fact that a great idea is great, but if you don’t have a plan to convert it into intellectual property, then you are stepping into uncharted territory where you’re bound to encounter many pitfalls. 

Secondly, I think that you should always have a Plan B in your mind, because there’ll be obstacles. When I talk about Plan B, I’m not talking about an escape plan, I’m talking about how and what you’ll do if a certain aspect of your plan doesn’t pan out as you wanted it to. Also, know your competition. Nokia failed because it was never able to cope with the evolution happening all around. Hence, it’s important for you to have alternate options available, concrete plans to convert your idea into intellectual property, and awareness about the changing trends.

You have talked extensively about ‘Mindset: The New Psychology of Success’, a very successful book written by Carol Dweck. What would you say are the books which will help budding entrepreneurs develop and eventually achieve success?

At the moment, I can only think of this book. I think budding entrepreneurs should focus on learning more about people who have succeeded, and more importantly, they should read about people who have succeeded in recent times. What worked earlier may not work today, but the ground rules and the structure remain the same. The way you deal with people in a certain situation does not change. If you read about people who have succeeded now, you’ll realise that there are some absolute mavericks who have changed the world. Conditioning your mind to think 'it has worked for other people and it will work for me too' is essential. To realise your potential, books are great, but practical knowledge is essential and can’t be avoided. You can’t master cricket without playing it on the field. Practical knowledge is something that you must focus more on, rather than the theory. Theory is necessary to have some perspective, but implementing it and practising it with experienced people is imperative for growth.

You said that there’s a generation change every five years. Do you think it aggrandises the situation concerning the Indian market, which is already a tough nut to crack, for new companies who are trying to thrive in it?

I would like to look at it more positively. There are more opportunities in a market like India because it is still not highly developed, yet it is not struggling in terms of basic infrastructure. There is a push by the government too, there are NGOs, and there’s an emphasis on crowdfunding as well. I don’t think a changing environment is a challenge, I think it’s an opportunity for you to see your ideas turn into intellectual property. Regarding the frequent changes in the way generations think, again, I would like to look at it as an opportunity for you to keep yourself fresh and new.

title: Interview | Mr. Rajesh Das, CEO and Founder, InLog
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Rajesh Das, CEO and Founder, InLog, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Rajesh Das, CEO and Founder, InLog, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

Startups are not very popular amongst students and there is a lot of inertia against the startup culture. How do you think that we can inculcate in the students that the startup risk is worth taking?

In my opinion, every university should start an incubator. A lot of collaborative work with the huge DTU alumni network needs to be done as well. I am not aware of the current course structure, but for reaching out to students who are more academically inclined, courses related to startups and entrepreneurship should be introduced too. Most of the times lack of knowledge also agitates people; one may have an idea but not the proper skill set to execute it. An incubator centre can definitely help nourishing that skill set.

Talking about the startup culture in India, how do you think it has evolved over the years?

People have seen the opportunities in this sector only recently as earlier the availability and access to the resources was also less. Today, there is a realisation that we can explore ourselves more as individuals and can help resolve the issues around us. Earlier, people would depend on an organisation to implement our ideas. But today with that realisation, I as an individual, with the help of my colleagues and friends can innovate things around us ourselves. We have become more open towards starting our own companies and becoming entrepreneurs.

Given the current startup scenario, what do you think is lacking in terms of the ideas or approaches and how can the quality of startups improve?

Firstly, the number of people with ideas needs to increase. Once we have a sufficient number of ideas, we can always develop a collaborative approach to build around that idea. If there is a dearth of ideas at the university level, the Alumni wouldn't be able to do much either. Once we have newer ideas in our frame, the Alumni can help a select few of them to grow. The quality of ideas is a latter concern.

Also, with more Entrepreneurship Summits like this, people see more success stories and students can now seek inspiration from those stories. The hesitation of taking the first step will thus vanish. The incubation centre can also play a huge role in changing mindsets. 

What are some of the challenges one must be prepared for before starting a startup?

I believe that the challenges one faces can be on two levels: the challenges during the exploration of the idea. A shortage of money can be one of the problems. While exploring one's ideas, it becomes difficult to look for venture capitalists. Incubation centres play a really important role in this as most often than now, there is a shortage of availability of seed funds as well. 

How do you think people can pursue their calling, if it's too late to start?

It is never too late to start. Finding your purpose is a journey in itself. Once you start that journey, you can redefine your purpose. You can always change your career, all you need to do is explore and find your passion and develop it. This can only happen once you start believing in yourself. The fear of failure or not doing well needs to go away.

What is your advice for students who would like to venture into the entrepreneurship field?

Search for self.  We really need to understand that the world is changing and there is an ecological division, social division, and self-division.  People need to connect with each other, understand their purpose and relate with their ideas.

title: Interview | Ashish Mediratta, Head, Global Talent Acquisition, Tata Communications
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Ashish Mediratta, Head, Global Talent Acquisition, Tata Communications, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Ashish Mediratta, Head, Global Talent Acquisition, Tata Communications, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

Today's talk revolved a lot around the definition of an ideal entrepreneur. What would your description of an ideal entrepreneur be?

It is imperative to know your domain, to surround yourself with relevant people, to have that vision to convince others, and to have that will and resilience to absorb pressure, work hard, and not take a no for an answer while taking failures in your stride. You will be hit by challenges everyday, but that is something that happens to all of us in the corporate world as well. Even when students are working on their projects, they face challenges. However students here are in this university, because they have proven their worth to be in the finest colleges in India. There is no iota of doubt in my mind that if they go after anything in life, they can easily crack it.

Also, when you look at highly successful people such as Mark Zuckerberg and Bill Gates, their personalities have something special about them. However, could these people have been successful without teamwork? It is important to know in which areas you are not a specialist and get those relevant people around you to guide you. While you have the instinct of being a leader, you would also need to have the skills of teamwork and cooperation.

You were talking about how AI is making great strides in the recruitment and the overall hiring procedures. How do you think this changes the dynamics of the traditional hiring procedure?

There are a long list of changes: for example the way your profiles will be read by corporate companies will be heavily influenced by your social media. The way you come across from LinkedIn or Facebook will allow them to know more about you, what kind of activities you are involved in, your likes and dislikes, projects or initiatives. For example, GitHub today is a very important channel for the IT industry. People rate you amongst many others. This is a small part of a public profile, which is not present in your CV and I, as an interviewer, would get to know more about you. Everyone on campus has a standard 1 page CV, so which is your special trait that is not known in the CV? 

Secondly, technology will evolve so much, for example if someone was looking at a particular skill and notices that a firm needs someone well versed in it, AI will soon be proficient enough to tell us the gap between skills, how much time it will take people to cross the gap and learn that new skill. It helps us in retention of talent, removing the need to hire from outside. In the corporate world today, there is a big HR conundrum, whether one should hire from outside or, look for growing talent internally. 

A lot of critics have argued that although AI will reduce the human effort during recruitment, it can also be biased and never at par with the quality traits that a human assesses during a one-on-one interview. How do you think we circumvent this problem?

I believe that the inherent question here is, who is the one training this AI? The answer is, humans. Are we implying that humans are not biased? We often encounter racism during an interview, and other interview panelists who are biased, and hence, we shouldn’t be blaming AI for its shortcomings. Artificial Intelligence will learn, through mistakes or through people who are going to help solve those bugs. However, the bugs in the human mind can be equally difficult to squash.

AI can sort profiles based on the candidates’ technical qualifications or based on who they are. However in a one-on-one interview format, we can gauge their emotional aspect as well, which is essential apart from their other quality traits. Can AI aim achieve this feat?

AI is here to assist, not to replace.

This is something AI can’t do, at least today. Currently, what AI does is, to break jobs into skills and their requirements, and it also looks at CVs to turn those into skills. If you have had success throughout your career, it will reflect: AI will match those skills through the CV to base its recommendation. An AI program will only look at, say, 100 profiles and recommend the top 5 of them, that is where human intervention comes in, so that I don’t need to look at a 100 resumes to hire those two people, going through those selected five to hire the two candidates is what I care about. AI is here to assist, not to replace.

Apart from talent acquisition, what are some other applications of AI and ML?

I’d say the most relevant application is in the learning and development areas. AI can, through the gaps of your skills, judge your learning ability - how fast you can learn. It can notify me about the average learning rate, compared with mine, and thus posing a question - do I want to stick in this career, or where is it that my talents are most suited? These things will start solving issues for future talent management, learning and development, and eventually all these areas will start getting closer together.

How do you think the startup culture has changed over the years?

You need to have the resilience to work 16 hours a day to keep your startup afloat.

Fortunately or unfortunately, there are fewer jobs available outside, leaving not many choices out there either. The amount of inertia that used to earlier exist against startups has turned itself in the favour of startups. Therefore, we have quite a few firms looking to fund promising startups. Being an entrepreneur, you also have to figure out other parts and challenges that you will face. You need to have the resilience to work 16 hours a day to keep your startup afloat, but do you have the resources and the right people around you to make it a success? All said and done, it’s a terrific time to start a startup.

Given the booming startup scenario in India, are the fresh graduates of this generation as inclined towards landing a job as compared to their predecessors?

If you compare people pursuing degrees like MBA to people willing to land government jobs, they sit on two opposite ends of a spectrum. Some people are MBAs and doctors but still crack the UPSC and get into government jobs. This conundrum exists in everybody’s life. You have to, first of all, discover a little bit about yourself. After that, you can take a call, keeping in mind where you see yourself. The options will always be in front of you, which path you take is up to you to decide, and once you do, you should just stick to it.

Some people often believe that they have spent a very long time to figure out what they want to do further in life or what their true calling is, that when they wish to finally pursue it, the age barrier hinders them from doing so. How do you beat this kind of mindset in people?

Beyond a point you don’t have to beat that mindset out of people. Self-doubts are going to remain anyways. At the end of the day, as long as you know your calling in life, that is extremely important. If you follow your passion, you will do extremely well in life. 

For example, my 23-year-old nephew happens to be a music lover, and he is solely committed towards it and towards the number of challenges he has seen, be it labour problems or quality assurance. Putting in 16 hours per day, almost 7 hours a week shows the immense dedication he has towards his passion. I believe that is the kind of commitment required to be successful and in the end, it’s all about your attitude and will.

In following their passion, people often end up working 16 hours a day, 7 days a week, as you mentioned. Do you think this is the prime reason which leads to burnouts amongst youth?

Definitely. Why would one want to be saddled with say, an MBA and take up a job offer when you have the potential to scale up your business or even make it global, something people yearn for? 

If one has worked relentlessly to establish himself and now that one has achieved some degree of success, one should keep on working for it. Obviously, 16 hours a day is not sustainable, so one should know where to draw the line. I would suggest to add more people around you so that you can delegate your work and you do not have to work so hard. 

How do you think the research infrastructure at the university level aids in building the entrepreneurial mindset in the students?

I think research infrastructure is one part of what you require, the other thing is getting into those projects which will impart you the learning. Today, we have programs for skill development, etc., but what is missing today is their practical experience. If I hire from outside, how will the internal assets grow? Therefore, we at Tata Communications have built a project marketplace. If I, as a manager, have a certain project where I want employees to work on it in their free time, we put that in the marketplace where employees can apply for it and we can select them for the same, giving them the precious hands-on experience for those products. It is the practical exposure of these skills that will set you apart. Surely, you may not have an experience of more than a few months, but what you have shown through this exercise is a drive to take initiative and showing interest in a particular skill, which I believe is extremely crucial.

title: Interview | Anubhav Tiwari, Head - Incubation & Corporate Innovation, CIE, IIIT Hyderabad
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Anubhav Tiwari, Head - Incubation & Corporate Innovation, Centre for Innovation and Entrepreneurship, IIIT Hyderabad, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020 organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Anubhav Tiwari, Head - Incubation & Corporate Innovation, Centre for Innovation and Entrepreneurship, IIIT Hyderabad, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020 organised by E-Cell DTU.

What basic points do you look for in an idea that can be termed as feasible for a startup?

The idea should be big enough to cater to the problems that exist. The ideology that ‘my college is facing this problem, so I should build this product’ is wrong. Since your college is not accurate market size, you will have to see whether that problem is actually being faced by the masses. Any potential idea should be the solution to a problem being faced by the masses. That’s when you have the potential to scale.

Over the past few years, startups have shifted from product-based business to service-based business. What could be the reason for that?

The shift is different in different geographies. If you consider the case of Hyderabad, for example, in the early 90s product-based companies were more but by the late 90s, there was a considerable rise in service-based companies. However, after 2007, there was a shift again in favour of product-based companies. To be fair, we cannot make a general comment about this shift as scenarios everywhere are different. If you ask me, though, as someone who has been in and around the ecosystem for several years now, I'd say the transition is more towards the product side, that is, people are shifting to product-based companies rather than service-based ones. 

Do you think the use of Artificial Intelligence in startups today is a beneficial step?

AI is the future and it is catching up. If you're building something around AI, you're being futuristic since it will cover most of the operational aspects of your company sooner or later. Everything is based on data nowadays and it depends on you that how you convert that data into information, information into insights and the insights into decisions. If this process involves fewer humans and more unbiased algorithms, the results will surely be better. 

If you ask me how the trend was during the ’90s, I would say that it was the IT boom. Right now, it’s the AI boom.

How does an entrepreneur's experience different if he pitches directly to a venture capitalist, rather than approaching an incubator first?

"Why can't I sit for Boards right now, without going to school?"

VC comes into the picture at a much later stage. When you go to an incubator first, you get a lot of help at the initial stage. It is like a first grader asking the question "Why can't I sit for Boards right now, without going to school?" There is a reason why schools and other academic institutions exist and there's a reason why we go to them. You can say you'll get the books, take home tuitions, won't go to school and still learn. Of course, you will learn but the institutions provide a structure to the learning process and you will miss out on that. 

Getting into an incubation centre is good as you get to learn from the mistakes of others and know exactly what to avoid. You can get some very critical strategic help at early stages. Plus, you get the infrastructure support so you don't have to worry about the services you require when building the company. Once you get an incubator's tag on you, it becomes the responsibility of the incubator to bring investors for you.

What, according to you, is a better step for entrepreneurs - to do a startup as a fresher or after 5-6 years of industry experience?

The industry experience disciplines you, teaches you how to work with a team, and also gives you the domain knowledge of the industry. When working on a startup, you don’t have anyone to tell you about right or wrong, and you aren’t mature enough to take such decisions right after college. So a few years of working under someone in the corporate world actually gives you a disciplined and organized way of running projects. Ultimately, a startup is also a project - a pretty big one! So if you are disciplined enough, know team cohesiveness, know how to build it and take it forward, it definitely adds on. 

This doesn’t mean that if you don’t have this experience, you won’t be successful. There are many good stories involving people who haven’t worked anywhere and are successfully running startups. But it’s always a standard practice to work prior to running a startup. It’s like saying that people have qualified for UPSC without going for coaching. Well, how many do? Very few.

Does age become a barrier for entrepreneurs, given that the willingness to take risks is generally varying? 

Age is just a number!

No, it’s not like that. The problem is not age, it’s the liabilities one has to take care of. If you have to take care of education loans or some other liabilities, it will stop you from taking risks. If you have a family to look after, you won’t put everything at stake for a start-up. So, it’s the liabilities that stop you, not the age.

What final message would you give to the students planning to venture into entrepreneurship?

Yes. Before you start, please use Google first. It’s the simplest and easiest thing that everybody avoids, but it eventually matters. You need to understand your market, you need to do a lot of research, and you need to build things that people need, not what you think people need.

Things have changed dramatically over the last fifteen years, since every five years, there is a generation change. Now, opportunities and options are limitless. Back then, we were stuck with a few options and were not aware of how others were looking at them due to the restricted flow of information, but it isn’t the same anymore. Problem solving has a whole different array of options to choose from. Instead of the emphasis being on success, like it was twenty years ago, today, failure is acceptable. So, that acceptance of failure and the presence of alternate avenues has changed.

I look at failure the same way as I did fifteen years ago. It’s how you keep evolving your mental setup that counts. One thing is for sure, more opportunities are bound to come. Don’t get me wrong, I fail now as well, but over time I’ve learnt to incorporate my past expertise to overcome the challenges presented to me. I often say ‘this too shall pass', since it has already occurred and I was able to overcome it then; hence, I’ll be able to overcome it now.

What would you say are a few red flags that students venturing into entrepreneurship should be aware of?

Don’t just follow the rat race, and don’t do something just because others are doing it. There is a marked difference between an idea and intellectual property. You can have a great idea, but till the time it converts into intellectual property, in terms of becoming a business unit or a revenue generating model, you are still just maybe playing with fire and hoping against hope. It’s important to be wary of the fact that a great idea is great, but if you don’t have a plan to convert it into intellectual property, then you are stepping into uncharted territory where you’re bound to encounter many pitfalls. 

Secondly, I think that you should always have a Plan B in your mind, because there’ll be obstacles. When I talk about Plan B, I’m not talking about an escape plan, I’m talking about how and what you’ll do if a certain aspect of your plan doesn’t pan out as you wanted it to. Also, know your competition. Nokia failed because it was never able to cope with the evolution happening all around. Hence, it’s important for you to have alternate options available, concrete plans to convert your idea into intellectual property, and awareness about the changing trends.

You have talked extensively about ‘Mindset: The New Psychology of Success’, a very successful book written by Carol Dweck. What would you say are the books which will help budding entrepreneurs develop and eventually achieve success?

At the moment, I can only think of this book. I think budding entrepreneurs should focus on learning more about people who have succeeded, and more importantly, they should read about people who have succeeded in recent times. What worked earlier may not work today, but the ground rules and the structure remain the same. The way you deal with people in a certain situation does not change. If you read about people who have succeeded now, you’ll realise that there are some absolute mavericks who have changed the world. Conditioning your mind to think 'it has worked for other people and it will work for me too' is essential. To realise your potential, books are great, but practical knowledge is essential and can’t be avoided. You can’t master cricket without playing it on the field. Practical knowledge is something that you must focus more on, rather than the theory. Theory is necessary to have some perspective, but implementing it and practising it with experienced people is imperative for growth.

You said that there’s a generation change every five years. Do you think it aggrandises the situation concerning the Indian market, which is already a tough nut to crack, for new companies who are trying to thrive in it?

I would like to look at it more positively. There are more opportunities in a market like India because it is still not highly developed, yet it is not struggling in terms of basic infrastructure. There is a push by the government too, there are NGOs, and there’s an emphasis on crowdfunding as well. I don’t think a changing environment is a challenge, I think it’s an opportunity for you to see your ideas turn into intellectual property. Regarding the frequent changes in the way generations think, again, I would like to look at it as an opportunity for you to keep yourself fresh and new.

title: Interview | Rajesh Das, CEO and Founder, InLog
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Rajesh Das, CEO and Founder, InLog, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Rajesh Das, CEO and Founder, InLog, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

Startups are not very popular amongst students and there is a lot of inertia against the startup culture. How do you think that we can inculcate in the students that the startup risk is worth taking?

In my opinion, every university should start an incubator. A lot of collaborative work with the huge DTU alumni network needs to be done as well. I am not aware of the current course structure, but for reaching out to students who are more academically inclined, courses related to startups and entrepreneurship should be introduced too. Most of the times lack of knowledge also agitates people; one may have an idea but not the proper skill set to execute it. An incubator centre can definitely help nourishing that skill set.

Talking about the startup culture in India, how do you think it has evolved over the years?

People have seen the opportunities in this sector only recently as earlier the availability and access to the resources was also less. Today, there is a realisation that we can explore ourselves more as an individual and can help resolve the issues around us. Earlier, people would depend on an organisation to implement our ideas. But today with that realisation, I as an individual, with the help of my colleagues and friends can innovate things around us ourselves. We have become more open towards starting our own companies and becoming entrepreneurs.

Given the current startup scenario, what do you think is lacking in terms of the ideas or approaches and how can the quality of startups improve?

Firstly, the number of people with ideas needs to increase. Once we have a sufficient number of ideas, we can always develop a collaborative approach to build around that idea. If there is a dearth of ideas at the university level, the Alumni wouldn't be able to do much either. Once we have newer ideas in our frame, the Alumni can help a select few of them to grow. The quality of ideas is a concern that comes after we resolve this.

Also, with more Entrepreneurship Summits like this, people see more success stories and students can now seek inspiration from those stories. The hesitation of taking the first step will thus vanish. The incubation centre can also play a huge role in changing mindsets. 

What are some of the challenges one must be prepared for before starting a startup?

The challenges during the exploration of the idea can be a huge setback. Shortage of money can be one of the problems. While exploring one's ideas, it becomes difficult to look for venture capitalists. Incubation centres play a really important role in this as most often than not, there is a shortage of availability of seed funds as well. 

How do you think people can pursue their calling, if they believe it's too late to start?

The fear of failure or not doing well needs to go away.

It is never too late to start. Finding your purpose is a journey in itself. Once you start that journey, you can redefine your purpose. You can always change your career, all you need to do is explore and find your passion and develop it. This can only happen once you start believing in yourself. The fear of failure or not doing well needs to go away.

What is your advice for students who would like to venture into the entrepreneurship field?

Search for self. We really need to understand that the world is changing and there is an ecological division, social division, and self-division. People need to connect with each other, understand their purpose and relate with their ideas.

title: Interview | Atish Bhattacharya, Head, TAL, DGM HR, Greenlam
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Atish Bhattacharya, Head, Talent Acquisition Leader, DGM HR, Greenlam, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Atish Bhattacharya, Head, Talent Acquisition Leader, DGM HR, Greenlam, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

How do you think the appeal of DCE has changed ever since it transformed into DTU?

DTU has always been a brand name in itself. It is still one of the top choices for engineering aspirants. The campus size has increased after the transition and the facilities have also been upgraded. I have been a recruiter at DTU and realized that the students of this college have recognizable leadership qualities. This makes us want to visit the campus year after year.

What is that one red flag that you recognize before you decide to hire any failed entrepreneur?

I think that it's not about failure but the situation that one has been through. This depends upon many factors such as the market not being ready, the target audience not being the exact fit, or the marketing strategies not working out. Although these things might lead to failure, they do not judge a person's capabilities in the long run. Organisations are happy to have workers back if they work diligently.

Perception is also a major factor. Once upon a time, Bata wanted to launch its brand in Africa. But a lot of critics were against this idea with the argument that the majority don’t wear shoes in Africa. Someone saw this as an opportunity and it eventually became a big hit. It is important to remember that every company starts with just one problem statement. Thus, it is important that a candidate can look through any problem statement and devise their ideas around it.

How do you think that Entrepreneurship Summits like these can help a student inculcate an entrepreneurship mindset?

One of the best things about this generation is that you people start thinking from a very early age. Fifteen years back, job was the only opportunity seen by the youth. Businesses were directly inherited by some people from their families, otherwise, everyone was literally pushed into jobs. In this field, a lot of work is being done. Many international companies like AliBaba have started to invest in our country. We have the skills and opportunities. They just need to fund us and we are ready to grow with them.

It becomes very difficult for startups to thrive in the competitive market of MNCs. Would you have any advice for startup founders or students are potentially seeking to become an entrepreneur to cope with the competition? 

One should know three things very well - their target audience, their market and their product. Not every day is rainbows and sunshine. There will always be a boom time and then there would be times when your risk-taking abilities would be challenged. There is no rocket science to it but only sticking true to the belief that one would sail through the tough times!

title: Interview | Sandro Stephen, Regional Head, Indian Angel Network
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Sandro Stephen, Regional Head, Indian Angel Network, who was a guest at Internship Fair-2020, organized by USME.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Sandro Stephen, Regional Head, Indian Angel Network, who was a guest at Start-up Conclave 2020, organized by USME.

What factors do you think are instrumental in distinguishing a start-up from its competitors in India? What advice would you give out to young entrepreneurs to pitch their ideas?

Mostly, everything in today’s day and age can be copied. However, the crucial and differentiating factor is how you execute the idea. The entire value of the product lies in its execution. If you can seamlessly execute the idea, then you will encounter fewer obstacles through your journey. 

A critical piece of advice that I generally give out is that one should find a mentor. A mentor can immensely change the face of the company by thoroughly shaping the idea. Mentors bring the ‘magic-sauce’ with them, and their vast knowledge can help the company in numerous ways.

In the 90s, almost every venture was somehow trying to incorporate Information Technology. Today, that place has been replaced by Artificial Intelligence. Do you think these trends affect the entrepreneurship sector when it comes to inducting them?

In my opinion, technological advancements such as Artificial Intelligence are more like enablers. In the long run, these technologies will adapt to the ventures and will be the norm. For example, in the past, having a website was itself rare for a venture. Eventually, it became routine, and mobile apps were the new trend. Similarly, AI too, will become a fundamental part of an enterprise in the future.

How can university students with hazy start-up ideas and lack of direction make the best use of start-up Incubators?

Incubators help you to shape your ideas holistically. This is because they provide you mentors, rather than you having to hunt for them. Alternatively, you can also identify the people who you would want as your mentors and request the Incubator Manager to aid you in connecting with them. This will, in turn, help to improve yourself in multiple aspects.

title: Interview | Akhil Choudhary, Chairman, UDAAN Association, and CEO, Binary Semantics
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Akhil Choudhary, Chairman, UDAAN Association (startup initiative by DCE-DTU Alumni Association) and CEO, Binary Semantics, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Akhil Choudhary, Chairman, UDAAN Association (startup initiative by DCE-DTU Alumni Association) and CEO, Binary Semantics, who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

You started Binary Semantics 34 years ago. What were the difficulties you had to face when you were starting out, especially when people weren't open to the startup culture?

One of the hardest things in the startup culture is convincing your family about pursuing a startup. Even when we were a couple of years down the road, we had already started Binary, there were many people who were questioning my parents as to why they didn’t discourage me from leaving my public sector job. Another challenge was the flow of capital. There was nothing like incubation or seed fund back then. Even the banks wouldn’t give us a loan because we started Binary Semantics as a software company and banks did not understand the word ‘software’. 

 Even the banks wouldn’t give us a loan because we started Binary Semantics as a software company and banks did not understand the word ‘software’. 

Initially, we didn’t have the capacity to employ too many people either. Even in the Software Development field, I was playing the roles of a developer, an analyst, a tester, project manager, and a program manager; and there’s a wide variety in all these fields and it also involves multiple technologies and expertise in multiple domains.

As you mentioned, as an entrepreneur, one has to play multiple roles. Did this excessive workload ever burn you out?

We would do a lot of small and simple things ourselves as well, and our roles would range from being a salesperson on the street to roles involving being a finance person. Because initially, we didn’t have the capacity to actually employ a finance person and coordinate each and everything. Those were days we did not even have a fax machine; so to go send a fax, we had to run to the market and use a fax machine. 

I believe I have played numerous such roles and I’m just talking about a few of them here. I think you just have to figure out a way to do them and enjoy what you do; when you enjoy what you do, the goal is clear and then adaptation is the least of problems. 

There were times when I had to work for eighteen hours straight. However, if I had to do just one thing for eighteen hours, I would get a burnout. Doing five different things gave me more energy. After all, variety is the spice of life.

What was your vision when you started and what’s been motivating you all these years?

I was passionate about entrepreneurship right from my childhood. Despite not having businessmen in my family, it somehow came into my head. When I was in school, I wanted to be a doctor and set up a chain of hospitals. Back then, my vision was limited to just India. I eventually ended up in engineering and computer sciences, and my vision changed to something global.

How do you see Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence impacting the Indian Market?

Several people think that Machine Learning will reduce jobs. I believe that it is going to change the nature of jobs. It will reduce some jobs and it will increase the number of jobs as we need a variety of skills. We see a huge number of opportunities all around but there are still very few takers.

What role do you think the research environment at a university level can play, to inculcate an entrepreneurial mindset in the youth?

With the kind of manpower and resources that we have across the country, better research facilities accompanied by better research ecosystem will be helpful, because it's not just the facilities, but also it is the mindset.

A lot of times people are driven by the glamour of being able to do something very quickly overnight, although any area that you take up, success might be guaranteed, but it doesn’t happen overnight. So, along with the facilities, the ecosystem also plays a significant role. The way the word ‘startup’ has gained respect in the last ten years, ‘research’ also must be respected and glamorised.

What, according to you, is the key element that most entrepreneurs end up overlooking?

One of the key things people miss out on is, the vision or purpose. When starting something new, some people consider making more money as their objective. However, money is something we all need - like air - and hence it can’t be a sole vision to build something new.

title: Interview | Adarsh Nair, CEO, Wynk Limited
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Adarsh Nair, CEO, Wynk Limited and Chief Product Officer, Airtel, who was one of the keynote speakers in Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organized by E-Cell, DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Adarsh Nair, CEO, Wynk Limited and Chief Product Officer, Airtel, who was one of the keynote speakers in Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organized by E-Cell, DTU.

How would you describe your journey with Wynk and Airtel?

My journey with Airtel has been a very good one. I chose to come to Airtel because India is one of the last bastions where there is a very big chance of growth happening in the next ten years. For any product manager, the dream is to be part of such a group. Also, the problems in India are very real, for example, if you look at the number of people with life insurance in this country, it is around 4%, one of the lowest in the world. So the problem is very real and it is a product manager’s dream to go behind such a problem. Airtel is a company where you have 300 million customers and 2000 enterprises, so it already has scale. The opportunity to innovate at airtel and go after these problems is a dream come true. 

That is how I see progression in India and at Airtel. Wynk is one part of the larger problem where we are trying to solve around how entertainment is delivered to the country. Other areas where we are helping are around health, data, learning, education. In summary, the journey at airtel has been nothing short of incredible.

There are a lot of international competitors in the areas that you have mentioned. What would be the role of Airtel in those sectors?

We have thought a lot about it. Airtel has got four platforms which are data, network, distribution, and payments. If you talk about data, we have one of the largest repositories of data in India. In distribution, we reach about 300 million people. In payments, 300 million people pay us every month. And we are the network. Any business that sits at the edge of these four pillars, we will build. So we have built IoT which is a combination of network and data pillars. Advertising is another area where we will invest and build because we have distribution and data. 

For other business verticals like agriculture, health, etc., we will support other companies. Vahan is a good example of a company that is trying to provide jobs to migrants to help the economy. Airtel is partnering with Vahan to power their business through the pillars of distribution and data. So through partnerships and our core strengths, I believe we can help India grow.

How do you plan on solving the problem of trucks in India?

You are referring to the work I did at Convoy in the US. If you look at Rivigo and BlackBuck, they are Indian companies that are trying to solve the Indian trucking problems. Airtel is not focused on this problem at this time. We believe in supporting the young startups that are solving this problem. 

If we put the systems that we built in the US in India, truck drivers won’t be able to use the app which will be in English. So you have to start looking at the problem from the India perspective. We need to solve for the various languages that drivers in India speak. Maybe we need a voice-first platform. You have to build technology that works for them. The bottom line here is that we should focus on the problem and then find the solution to the problem. One of our values is to “Love the problem, not the solution”, something I learnt at Convoy.
