title: Interview | Abhinav Mathur, Founder Director, Million Sparks Foundation
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Abhinav Mathur, Founder Director, Million Sparks Foundation, who was a speaker at Start-up Conclave - 2020 organised by USME, DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Abhinav Mathur, Founder Director, Million Sparks Foundation, who was a speaker at Start-up Conclave - 2020 organised by USME, DTU.

The impact a teacher has on a child’s overall development and learning cannot be undermined. The role of a teacher has always been the most challenging yet rewarding experience, as your organisation rightly emphasises. How do you think the duties and responsibilities of teachers have changed over the years?

Essentially, I believe it was a very coveted profession. However, now the status quo has changed and it is not as coveted as before. The best minds of our society are not opting for teaching as a profession. On the other hand, the profession has become more demanding and there are more responsibilities bestowed on teachers. I believe the administrative work is only increasing for them and the environment around education is not very conducive as such. The Right to Education Act and the No-detention policy have also caused a lot of issues in the country. I believe the profession has become very challenging and not as rewarding as it previously was.

One cannot deny the high degree of inequality that prevails in our society consequent of which, technology-aided educational tools haven’t been introduced in the rural areas. However, the most affluent educational institutions of the country have almost completely been dependent on such tools in carrying out learning activities. How is your organisation addressing this problem of inequality and working to overcome these challenges?

In our view, inequality will always persist if more focus and emphasis is given to technology led solutions. There is an effect called the ‘Matthews effect’ which basically states that the affluent strata will be able to access more of the benefits from these solutions than the people who are not as affluent. Therefore, in our view, if equitability and inclusiveness has to be ensured in education, it has to be done by ensuring that the teachers are educated to teach and that is our entire approach, we are trying to bring all teachers the learning opportunities so that they can learn better and hence, teach a better class.

What inspired you to start Million Sparks Foundation and what is your advice to aspiring investors who are just starting out?

The driving force which motivated me was the current deplorable condition of the education system in the country. In my opinion, there is a lot to be done and unless we do something about it, the future of close to 400-500 million children in the next decade or so, is at stake. 

The future of industry is very different from what we are experiencing today and the kind of skills which will be required will be quite divergent. Today, the focus is on numeracy and literacy. There is no way through which you can continue to be able to provide jobs to 50 - 100 million children for another 30 years, solely on the basis of numeracy and literacy. They will definitely be required to possess a multitude of skills which are imparted only through teachers. My advice to investors, is that I have no advice!

title: Interview | Prof. Ajoy Ghatak, Emeritus Professor, IIT Delhi
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Prof. Ajoy Ghatak, Emeritus Professor at IIT Delhi, who was a speaker at the Recent Trends in Applied Physics and Engineering (RTAPE-2020) organized by Department of Applied Physics, DTU. He is also an awardee of the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize for Science and Technology.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Prof. Ajoy Ghatak, Emeritus Professor at IIT Delhi, who was a speaker at the Recent Trends in Applied Physics and Engineering (RTAPE-2020) organized by Department of Applied Physics, DTU. He is also an awardee of the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize for Science and Technology.

One of the fields you specialize in is quantum mechanics. Now that many countries are upping their funding for quantum technology, how do you see it affecting the life of the ordinary citizen in the near future?

It is very difficult to predict, but you can see how technology has affected our lives. How you use the Internet or YouTube is in your hands. You can either waste your time, or you can actually learn stuff by listening to the lectures of Richard Feynman. However, if you want to harness technology and effectively reduce poverty, you must back it via education. I met a taxi driver, and I asked him why he hadn’t registered himself as an Uber driver. He said he cannot speak English. This man could've earnt 4 times as much with technology, but he is hampered by his education. Education and health must be in the hands of the government and cannot be privatized. Women’s education is also very important. I recently gave an interview at a college of Delhi University and I said the same thing - we require Nobel Laureates and great minds, but we also require industry builders, institution builders, people who lay the foundations for others to succeed on, like Jamshedji Tata, Abdul Kalam, Meghnad Saha, Homi Bhabha, Vikram Sarabhai etc. What one man creates leads to more innovators in the future and more development for the country.

You are one of the leading authors in the field of Optics. How do you feel about your book 'Optics' being the go-to reference for such an important topic, especially in undergraduate courses? 

I feel really happy, but everything does require improvement. It’s a good book, but it could be better. I am currently working on the 7th edition; earlier it used to be in black and white, but now the publishers said they will bring out a 4-coloured edition. There is always room for improvement and whatever it is that you do, you should always seek to better it, be it for yourself or for your country.

We have seen a trend where science and religion often end up in conflict over their separate ideologies. As future researchers, how can we ensure the existence of science and religion in harmony?

What is religion? Religion is meant to make you a good human being, to make sure you have compassion for others so that you can do good for society. Islam teaches you that if your neighbour does not have food, then your food is of no value. You must share your food and give sevai to the entire community on the occasion of Eid. Religion is a philosophy of life which teaches you to be good to others, but people make it divisive, and that is wrong. Religion is supposed to make you a better person irrespective of the religion you follow. I tell all my younger relatives that the most important thing is compassion towards mankind as a whole. Have compassion towards those 300 million who live below the poverty line and are much less privileged than you. However, India’s strength has and always will be our diversity. Homi Bhabha was a Parsi, Jamshedji Tata was a Parsi, Abdul Kalam was a Muslim, Meghnad Saha a Dalit. When the Constitution doesn’t discriminate, why should we? 

Any message you would like to give to the students of this University who one day might hope to become as accomplished as you?

Much better than me, I hope! I have just worked hard. Bhatnagar award is a good thing, and I am very lucky to get it. There are n number of people who are more competent than me and still haven’t secured it. This is true even for the Nobel Prize - Satyendra Bose or KS Krishnan could’ve received the Nobel Prize. I often start my speeches with the statement that on 28th February, 1928, KS Krishnan discovered the Raman Effect, making him the first person to discover the Raman shift of spectral light. Yet most of us do not know about him, as he was a student of Raman. I, therefore, place Meghnad Saha and Homi Bhabha much higher than CV Raman. They built institutes for us, for the future generations to follow in their steps. My message is that your generation has technology in its hand; use it judiciously, use it wisely. You have so much information available to you; learn from it, and whatever you do, give back to the society, use your technology to build institutes, and to uplift the people.

title: Interview | Dr. Shailja Vaidya Gupta, Office of the Principal Scientific Adviser, Government of India
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Dr. Shailja Vaidya Gupta, Senior Adviser, Office of the Principal Scientific Adviser to Government of India, who was one of the keynote speakers on the 126th Birth Anniversary celebrations of Dr. Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar and National Science Day, organised by the Department of Applied Chemistry, DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Dr. Shailja Vaidya Gupta, Senior Adviser, Office of the Principal Scientific Adviser to Government of India, who was one of the keynote speakers on the 126th Birth Anniversary celebrations of Dr. Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar and National Science Day, organised by the Department of Applied Chemistry, DTU.

The theme of today’s talk was Women in Science. What do you think deters young girls in middle and high school from entering STEM related fields?

We need to break this out into two categories: one comprises the privileged class who have access to the best facilities in this country, and the other is the unprivileged class, where young  boys and girls are the first generation in their families to get proper education. I focus on the challenges that the latter face. Mostly, it is the financial challenges that come forward; however it is the societal challenges that act as the first barrier. A lot of them still think that a woman needs to get married the moment she turns eighteen and that this is her prime duty. This mentality needs to change, and that is why initiatives like ‘Beti Padhao Beti Bachao’ are of utmost importance. You have to educate a child. The first step in educating a girl child is to start within the family. The first societal change we have to make is to increase awareness among the parents about the importance of education. The societal pressure of getting a girl child married can be destroyed only by making higher education more accessible to them.

Do you think societal barriers are overpowering the financial barriers in real life?

Yes, I do think social barriers have become the primary cause of concern now. Even if you look at the well-to-do families, an orthodox mentality still persists. They think that after a certain age a girl becomes too old to get married. That is the primary social barrier of marriage. During my 20s, if a girl turned 25, she was considered past her marriageable age. I got married when I was 28, and that is something society talked about a lot in those days. 

Numerous studies have found that women in the STEM field publish less, are paid less for their research and do not progress as far in their careers. According to you, what steps should be taken so that women are able to enter this conventionally male-dominant sphere?

I think this is a very Western narrative. A lot of western narratives don’t fit into Indian contexts.

I don’t think women are paid less in India. Once they enter science fields and have the same job as a man, no woman is paid less. In fact, I think we have an added advantage of tax rebate. The situation is quite contrary in the West. How can two people; irrespective of their gender, doing the same job, be paid less? This is something I tweet about a lot. 
I think there exists another social barrier: the belief that women can’t do physics or math; that they are not as good with technology. A fear is birthed in our minds if we are told repeatedly that we can’t handle technology. The developed world is equally regressive, even if you look at the highly developed countries like the USA, women have a hard time breaking into male dominated areas. This is a misconception that prevails in all parts of the world. 

Don’t you think the journey of women to the same position as that of a man is tougher?

I agree, it is tougher. We have to manage our home, kids, parents and even in-laws. I think the current and coming generations will face this problem. Eventually this may become more equal. Apart from that, there also exists a gender bias, especially in my generation. We face it almost every day. A woman is not expected to laugh too loudly or intermingle with men too much. She has to be too straight-jacketed. That limits her on her way up, professionally. She’s not able to network due to her family or societal restrictions. A  lot of invisible barriers exist on every step. So, I think she is more careful and works twice as hard. 

Even though women have made remarkable achievements in STEM fields, there is barely any acknowledgment. Only 3% of Nobel prize awardees are women. Why do you think the world finds it tough to acknowledge their achievements?

 Our culture will have you believing that women cannot be thinkers.

Again, this is due to a very strong mindset among people which has been prevalent for perhaps thousands of years. If I am saying something which makes sense, it is likely to go unacknowledged simply due to my gender. But If the same thing comes from a man, his words will be considered pearls of wisdom. This is a genuine problem in the current scenario. Words coming from a man are given more weightage than those from a woman. We have to constantly fight against this.

Do you think this effect will wear out with time, and that things will start equalizing?

It will depend on how much the next generation gives weightage to women’s thoughts and their contribution to the development of society. I think it is possible, for I see the younger generation being more open-minded, empathetic and feminist. So, I am very positive and hopeful. I have seen changes within my life span and I think women are in good position now.

You joined the Office of the Principal Scientific Adviser as a Senior Adviser in 2019. What does the job entail and how has your experience been till now?

I was with the Department of Biotechnology within the Ministry of Science and Technology, which is a funding agency. We were funding biological sciences across India. I was responsible for the international collaborations, and was working with the international community across the world. When I came to this office, the canvas grew widely. Now I have to look at Artificial Intelligence, the National Education Policy and the new National Research Foundation which is being setup. Also, I handle science outreach programmes like ‘CodeIndia’, where we put in efforts to teach the school students how to code. We are looking and setting up astronomy labs across schools in India.  

My main role is to take up Waste-to-wealth projects, like finding ways to get rid of dumpsites in Ghazipur or Okhla, cleaning our water bodies, eradicating the waste that surrounds us etc. Through policies, I want to get the government to change the way they perceive the relation between science and economic growth. Why can’t we have Raman spectrophotometer manufacturing units here? I would like to see young students like you make a difference, or at least a contribution. We will be reaching out to all of you to help in these projects, which is welcome to contributions by the whole country.

You talked about the foreign collaborations wherein you had collaborated with Stanford University to bring in the Foldscope and the Barapullah Drain project. How do these collaborations shape and influence the works that you do?

We did the Foldscope collaboration with Stanford University, developed by Prof. Manu Prakash. The Foldscope is a foldable microscope and the cheapest in the world, costing less than a dollar. We provided these in some of our government schools. Bringing such affordable and easy-to-use technology to our most resource constraint areas is our motive. If you visit the government schools in Delhi, you won’t find any apparatus or laboratory equipment. The situation of state government schools is worse. So, getting these technologies at cheaper rates and making them accessible to the students, to the extent that they can keep a foldscope like a geometry box in their bags can change the way we think about science. Having a foldable microscope in every child’s bag will bring out the scientists within them. 

The Barapullah Drain project was again brought about by working with various other countries. When we collaborate with other countries, we have to make an impact. Doing minor things together is not going to work. The Barapullah Drain is the second largest in the city and cleaning it will be challenging task, that is why we are very excited about the project.

Do you have any message for the budding female engineers of DTU?

Don’t let anything deter you. Don’t let people tell you what you can and cannot do. Break the stereotypes. Believe in yourself; you really are the future. With more and more women entering DTU, you will see the difference in how the college performs and how it eventually becomes better.

title: Interview | Commodore (Dr.) RK Rana
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Commodore (Dr.) RK Rana, Honorary Startup Advisor who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Commodore (Dr.) RK Rana, Honorary Startup Advisor who was a guest at the Entrepreneurship Summit 2020, organised by E-Cell DTU.

We will start the discussion with Navy. You have spent a long time serving in the Navy. Can your experiences when you started out and how did it change in all these years in terms of technology and infrastructure?

Considering the technological development within the Naval Environment, we started with the good old boilers and steam turbine. I am a mechanical engineer. The technology has over a period of time improved considerably, whether you see the main propelling system of our generation or the weapon system, as the computing technology has advanced so has the ability of the weapon systems or the control system. What used to be controlled manually in now being controlled using screens and other technological appliances. The capability of the ships has also increased considerably. We are now getting ships with enhanced stealth because the signaling management onboard the ships have been gaining a lot of importance. We have submarines that can detect ships within a radius of 1 mile. Whether it is onboard ships or self-noise generation, we have improved upon technology considerably. 

Another thing of pride is that the Indian Navy has been designing and building ships for last six decades unlike the Army and the Air Forces who have been buying their fighting platforms. I was a part of the design team designing the Air Craft carrier for seven years at the Directorate of Naval Design at Delhi. As a Principal Director, I was looking at mapping and enhancing the self-reliance capability of the Navy. So, I was a part of the designing team of the said air craft carrier which is one of the largest ships designed and being built. It is already in water and will be getting commissioned shortly. Over a period of time, thanks to the technological improvement and the education level of the officers, we have much potent fighting capability within the country.

You made your career in military , then you shifted to consulting and now you help people in their businesses and startups . What is your take on this transition?

I initially worked with a global British MNC for four years handling their business and now I am more into social work. In the private environment you have to do everything yourself, in the Fauj, everyone has a big paraphernalia, I had the luxury that when I would get out of the car, someone would open the door, someone would pick up my luggage. I never needed all of that however, I always did all that myself. When I shifted to the private sector the first thing they asked me was whether I'd be needing a large staff or not since they know the lifestyle we are accustomed to.  One has to be independent in the private sector. I never really felt the difficulty since I used to work by myself, hence the transition was simple for me. 

Mostly after engineering, the obvious choice is to go for further studies or jobs. How did you realize what was your calling and what made you join the military?

I am from a military background, my father also being in the Army. I grew up in that environment where my father was constantly travelling between postings. It has been a tradition that somebody from a military family would always join the armed forces, and that is what motivated me to join the armed forces.

I had the mindset to do my best in whatever I will do. Fortunately, I have been lucky enough to gain an experience in all domains while serving in the Navy. When people look at the Navy they see it as only a ship fighting. However, there is a lot which goes on as the support activity for the fighting platform to deliver its best. A ship has a huge amount of other activities going on and I have faced many challenges during operations because of our activities in extraneous circumstances. Many people ask me about these, so I tell them that the moment we join armed forces, we sign our death warrant on day one. That is how our mindsets are. 

When I initially joined, I was on a ship which faced a storm. The ship was operating near Visakhapatnam. I was in a tanker but still the waves could be felt. I find myself lucky that I am alive and speaking today. It was raining heavily, the time of heavy monsoons. We were facing sea state 3 or 4 and there was a defect and some roof was leaking. So I went out and my commanding officer did not know but we took a small turn and we slipped out. I happened to hold the stantion for support and pulled myself in. Otherwise it was pitch black and I wouldn't be here today. 

In south east Asia, all the tycoons are named. In the year 2000, we went to south china sea on a diplomatic mission and we faced almost sea state 8 or 9, the highest, roughest there is. The ship was jumping up and down. Those were difficult environment, even the machinery gets bad, but because of the determination and bravery of the men, they had been repairing and maintaining them to ensure that the propeller keeps moving. Making it out of these situations leaves you with a sense of accomplishment and camaraderie between your brothers in arms.  

What do you feel about the transition of DCE from DTU? Do you think this has impacted the functioning in some way?

DCE as a part of Delhi University had a lot of limitations. The faculty was highly experienced but there was a deficit of opportunities. I feel that DTU has opened many gates for the students and the situation has definitely improved. It is not a routine environment of lectures and practicals anymore. DTU conducts many startup events to help the students, extra curricular activities, more societies have opened to up to help the students follow their passion. Many people still believe that DCE was better, however I am not of that mindset. 

Most of engineering graduates don’t know the opportunities that exist in the military etc. what would you want our readers to know more about these opportunities and jobs?

The best resource available to you is to make use of the alumni that are involved in these forces and take their assistance in visiting these ships, to see how things are arranged. We have similar kind of machinery on board as in the industries, but the scales are very different. The density of the equipment is very different. In a factory, space is a luxury, whereas on a ship, everything has to be packed inside a set volume. On a submarine it is even worse, you have to literally crawl around to do maintenance and operation.

The armed forces do have an outreach program, where they are taking in individuals and innovators in far flung areas, such as deserts, to have a practical feel of the environment in which they would have to operate. I have always felt that the Indian mind, is a very innovative and fertile mind and which needs to be leveled upon by the country. I used to be very instrumental in putting people across, to facilitate visits to the ships and have taken a lot of initiatives to encourage the young. 

How do you think that we can improve the Research and developments opportunities of DTU?

Earlier research was considered to be a bad word. I would like to thank Prime Minister Modi for inculcating this term in the mindsets of youngsters since 2014. In many countries, children are asked to explore and do research in many fields so it helps them in many ways in order to grab research opportunities. Meanwhile, in India, students are not encouraged enough or sometimes even mocked for taking up research as a career option. But now the government is helping the students a lot which should have been done 60-70 years ago. Many MNCs have R&D sectors in India and if given opportunities, Indians can do wonders.

title: Ripples of COVID-19 in the Global Economy
biliner: Apratim Shrivastav, 1st Year, COE, explains how COVID-19 might affect economies around the world.
body:
Currently, the world feels less like reality and more like an episode of ‘Black Mirror.’ Only a few months ago, it was beyond our wildest imaginations that an epidemiological threat such as the novel coronavirus was in store for us. The virus has disrupted not only our entire way of living but also threatened the global economy at an unprecedented level.

Kristalina Georgieva, the Managing Director of IMF, called the virus "the world's most pressing uncertainty". The prime reason for this is the economic significance of the country wherefrom the virus originated: China. After the virus was discovered in Wuhan, which is one of the commercial capitals of China, the government began assessing the extent of the infection. Upon realizing that the virus was not limited to Wuhan, the Chinese government shut down factories in the affected regions. The major implications of this move were trade-offs in terms of short-term employment prospects for migrant workers and, more significantly, long-term effects on global supply chains.

In economic terms, a global supply chain is a dynamic worldwide network that arises when a company purchases or uses goods or services from a different overseas company. Disturbing a single link in the chain can cause it to fall apart. 

As manufacturers dependent on Chinese production are forced to decrease their production every day, corporations across the world suffer the consequences. The effects are multiplying with the global movement of the virus. The viral outbreak in Northern Italy, for instance, shut down a firm that supplies electronic parts to automakers across the European Union, meaning auto plants in several countries may need to halt.

While the markets continue to suffer, cash flow is needed within the system to improve the chances of recovery. This move is exceedingly difficult in the current paradigm due to rampant hoarding by consumers. There are a few effects that need to be considered here. With social distancing and self-isolation quickly becoming the need of the hour, people are less likely to buy certain goods such as food and beverages prepared outside and avail services such as air travel and hotel accommodation. People are more likely to cut back on non-essential spending in order to save for emergency spending in the future. If we add this to the growing problems posed by lack of paid leave and companies laying workers off due to the slowdown, it ultimately results in people having a lot less disposable income to spend on certain sectors, reducing overall demand. However, the current magnitude of these effects is unknown. With more countries joining the list, it may eventually lead to a supply-shock.

A question that usually pops up at this point is, "How is any of this new?". We have had bad economic crises in the past; we survived. However, the reason the current scenario presents a unique challenge is because of the uncertainty involved. A basic economic rule: markets run on speculation. Their functioning, the rise and fall of stocks, economic decisions made by corporations, etc. are all based on calculations: determining the best possible outcome based on statistics, experience, and market information. The volatility of the coronavirus situation makes any sort of calculated action an impossibility. 

As a result, investors cease to invest and this decelerates cash flow. Businesses may hold off on investments because they are unsure of the extent to which supply chains and international customers are impacted. Internationally, it is not known where and how far the virus will spread. This makes it hard or even impossible to assess the outcome. As these effects are difficult to evaluate, businesses will be unable to determine whether they should continue with various investments. Households, with no idea of how things might pan out, will prefer to save instead of continuing with their regular spending habits. Financial institutions such as banks may reprice credits as they can’t assess the risk of lending to individuals, corporations, or countries.

With supply chain disruption, reduction in demand, and economic uncertainty, the global economic structure appears to be in crisis. While the virus may not affect a lot of people directly, its ripple effects on society may require a longer period of recovery.

title: क्या भारत कोरोनावायरस से लड़ने को तैयार है?
biliner:
कोरोना वायरस का केंद्र चीन में ना हो कर भारत में होता तो क्या विश्व भर के हालात और भी भयंकर होते? 
इस विषम समय में लोगों के दिमाग में ऐसे प्रश्न बहुत आम हैं। कपिल शर्मा, प्रथम वर्ष, सी.ओ.ई. इस प्रश्न का उत्तर देने का प्रयास करते हैं।
body:
“ अच्छा है कोरोना वायरस का केंद्र भारत में ना हो कर चीन में है क्योंकि यहाँ होता तो कोई उसके लिए कुछ करता ही नहीं और जान आदि का नुकसान कई गुना अधिक हुआ होता। "

चीन ने जब कोरोनावायरस के केंद्र वुहान में रिकॉर्ड 9 दिनों में 1000 बिस्तरों वाला अस्पताल बना कर जग भर से अपनी शीघ्र प्रतिक्रिया के लिए सराहना पाई तो उसमें काफी लोगों का प्रत्युत्तर कुछ ऐसा भी था। मैं इस बात को पूर्णतः निरर्थक नहीं कहूँगा किन्तु यह दिखाने का प्रयास करना चाहूँगा की भारतीय प्रशासन पूर्णता निष्क्रिय नहीं है। इसके लिए मैं केरला में 2 वर्ष पूर्व हुए निपाह वायरस के प्रकोप का उदाहरण लेना चाहूँगा जिसके पश्चात फिर वर्तमान स्तिथि पर कुछ तर्क प्रस्तुत करूँगा।

उससे पहले आपको निपाह के बारे में संक्षिप्त में बताना उचित होगा। निपाह एक ऐसा वायरस है जिसके संक्रमित मनुष्यों के साथ साथ कुछ पशु-वाहक भी हैं। इसको फैलाने वाले प्रमुख जीव हैं फल-चमगादड़ और सूअर। संक्रमित व्यक्ति के संपर्क में आने से एवं संक्रमित चमगादड़ के झूठे फल खाने से भी आप इस वायरस की चपेट में आ सकते हैं। इसके लक्षण तेज़ बुखार, सर दर्द, साँस लेने में दिक्कत होना आदि हैं। इस संक्रमण की विषमता का अनुमान इस बात से ही लगाया जा सकता है की इसका मृतयु दर 50-75% है (इसकी तुलना में कोरोना का मृत्यु दर 1.0-3.4% है)। निपाह वायरस का अब तक कोई स्पष्ट उपचार नहीं है।

2 मई 2018 को केरल में इस बीमारी से पीड़ित पहले व्यक्ति, मोहम्मद साबित को अस्पताल में भर्ती किया गया। निपाह की पुष्टि से पूर्व ही साबित का देहांत हो गया अतः उसने मरने से पूर्व 18 अन्य जनों को संक्रमित कर दिया था। कुछ दिनों बाद जब साबित के भाई को समान लक्षणों से अस्पताल में भर्ती किया गया तब निपाह की पुष्टि हुई। इसके तुरंत बाद प्रशासन ने स्थानीय वायु यात्रा पे रोक लगा दिया एवं फलों-सबज़िओ की बिक्री पर भी कुछ विराम लगाए। सभी स्थानीय डॉक्टरों को सूचित कर निपाह के लक्षणों के प्रति सतर्क रहने को कहा गया। इसके साथ ही ऑस्ट्रेलिया से अपूर्ण क्लीनिकी क्षोध की उपेक्षा एक ऐन्टीबाडी आयात(import) करने का प्रबंध हुआ। दो विशेष दलों का गठन किया गया जिनमें से एक का लक्ष्य वायरस के स्त्रोत की खोज करना था। दूसरे दल को 19 संक्रमित लोगों के संपर्क में आए सभी लोगों की पहचान का काम सौंपा गया जिसके निष्कर्ष के पश्चात लगभग 2000 लोगों को संगरोध (quarantine) में जांच के लिए स्थानांतरित किया गया।
सभी अनुरूप लोगों की कर्मनिष्ठा एवं अथक निरंतर प्रयासों के फलस्वरूप 10 जून 2018 को केरल को निपाह-मुक्त घोषित किया गया। निपाह से भारत की लड़ाई सराहनीय और उदहरणात्मक, दोनों ही थी।

यह तो हुई अतीत की बात, पुनः वर्तमान पर आते हुए, कोरोनावायरस के मामले में भी भारत की प्रतिक्रिया की समय सूची मैं सामने रखना चाहूँगा जिसके पश्चात आप स्वयं उसकी तुलना अन्य देशों से कर सकते हैं। 

17 जनवरी : जग भर में मात्र 41 पुष्टिकृत कोरोना के मामले एवं वुहान मे 1 मृत्यु के पश्चात ही भारत ने चीन से आने वाले सभी यात्रियों के लिए थर्मल स्क्रीनिंग अनिवार्य एवं चीन जाने के विरुद्ध लोगों को सावधान किया गया।

4 फरवरी : वुहान से भारतीयों के निकास के कारण भारत में प्रथम 2 संक्रमित लोगों की पुष्टि। राज्य सरकार द्वारा आपातकालीन स्तिथि की घोषणा।

4 मार्च: भारत में कोरोना के 10 मामलों की पुष्टि। वायरस समर्पित प्रयोगशालाओं में 3 गुना बढ़ौती। संबंधित दवाइयों के निर्यात(एक्सपोर्ट) पर रोक।

11 मार्च: कोरोनावायरस द्वारा प्रथम भारतीय का देहांत। सभी पर्यटक वीज़ा रद्द।

इसके अतिरिक्त राज्य सरकारों द्वारा अन्य कदम जैसे विद्यालयों, विश्वविद्यालयों, अन्य भीड़ भाड़ वाले स्थलों में संक्रमण रोकने के लिए आवश्यक पूर्वोपाय तथा लोगों को घर से ही काम करने का प्रोत्साहन।

कोरोनावायरस अभी हमारे समक्ष एक वीभत्स समस्या है, इसके निवारण की जितना उत्तरदायित्व प्रशासन का है उतना प्रत्येक नागरिक का भी है, आप सभी से अनुरोध है की अपने स्वास्थ्य की ओर उपयुक्त कदम उठाएँ।

इस विषम समय में लोगों के दिमाग में ऐसे प्रश्न बहुत आम हैं। कपिल शर्मा, प्रथम वर्ष, सी.ओ.ई. इस प्रश्न का उत्तर देने का प्रयास करते हैं.

title: Kuch Toh Corona
biliner: Is being quarantined boring you out of your mind? Anoushka Raj, 2nd Year, ENE, Pratiksha Pradhan, 2nd Year, ECE, and Srishti Mittal, 3rd Year, PSCT, bring to you a list of activities to help keep you busy at home.
body:
Is being quarantined boring you out of your mind? Anoushka Raj, 2nd Year, ENE, Pratiksha Pradhan, 2nd Year, ECE, and Srishti Mittal, 3rd Year, PSCT, bring to you a list of activities to help keep you busy at home.

Exhausting midsems often leave you craving an extended break, but what if that comes at the heavy price of a pandemic? With COVID-19 slowly extending its reach to Delhi, it is essential to stay home and practice social distancing to slow its spread, even if you haven’t been in contact with anyone infected. However, shutting yourself up inside your house without the option of stepping out can quickly get boring. After all, there is a limit to how much you can binge-watch. To help alleviate some of this boredom (and for the times when your parents say ‘sirf sote aur khaate ho, kuch toh corona’), we bring to you a list of things to do while in self-quarantine. 

  1. Catch up on your sleep. With the hassle of trying (and failing) to maintain the unachievable trinity of classes, extracurriculars, and a social life, college makes you believe that sleep is for the weak. Now that you don’t have assignments and files to tearfully keep you up all night, take this time to get your sleep cycle in order.
  2. Social distancing does not mean not communicating with loved ones. Been intending to have a lengthy conversation with a friend about something that troubles you? Honestly, there’s never been more time, and they’ll have no valid excuse to get them out of this, so get real with your feelings. Text that old friend from school that you haven’t met in a while, reply to the unread texts from your hostel friends, and talk to your family.
  3. Just because you can’t physically meet doesn’t mean you and your gang can’t do anything together. You can have a Netflix Party with your friends. Finally plan that trip to Goa and cover all the loopholes so that when it’s time to go, no one can back out.
  4. Write. Paint. Master the guitar that you haven’t picked up in years. With solitude at your fingertips, it is easy to pick up a hobby from where you left off. There are some great resources available online for learning various instruments, such as OnlinePianist, which offers piano tutorials for popular songs.
  5. Clean out your virtual space by sorting through your hard disk, your phone’s camera roll, your Google Drive files, and the old pen drives gathering dust on your desk.
  6. Work on your vocabulary. We recommend Word Power Made Easy; it improves your grammar and vocabulary in short 30-minute sessions per day.
  7. Keep that mind going - an idle mind is the devil’s workshop, so don’t loaf around! With no proper schedules telling you what to do, it is easy to fall out of the habit of studying. You can do online courses on Coursera or DataCamp, learn a new language, or even study that subject whose mid-semester exam made you collapse into a nervous wreck.
  8. Exercise. It’s important to keep your body active. Don’t sweat it out at the gym, since it’s one of the places where the virus spreads most rapidly due to excessive contact and sharing of equipment. Instead, clear out space in your house and work out with the help of fitness and yoga videos which are readily available on YouTube.
  9. Spend some quality time with your family. You might not get this luxury again for a while once we return to our fast-paced lives. Help them with chores, watch some movies together, or discuss politics. Take out the rusty board games gathering dust in your cupboards and relive a page of your childhood. It’s a great way to bond with your family, and flipping the board over when you lose will let out some frustration. You’re broke in real life too, Monopoly can’t really hurt you any further.
  10. Remember that working from home and staying in is a privilege, not an inconvenience. In a developing country like ours, scores of people have to be on the streets to earn their daily wage. If you have the advantage of staying home, be mindful of and courteous to those who don’t. Tip generously, and be sure to spread the right information to people who might not have access to it.
  11. Try to spend some time taking care of something that probably won’t give you the virus - we mean pets or potted plants. Now that you’re quarantined to your house the entire time, there’s no excuse for why the plant wilted away and died.
  12. For those of you who have no opportunity to learn cooking either because you’re confined to your hostels or your academics don’t leave you with much time to get innovative in the kitchen, now’s a perfect time to learn. It’s a vital life skill - don’t run away from it! Plus, it’ll give you something to rub in the faces of all those aunties and uncles who keep asking about your progress in the kitchen rather than in life.
  13. Coronavirus is a massive threat to everyone and has certainly taken the limelight, but that doesn’t diminish any of the other threats that we and our planet face. Just because you have to wash your hands regularly does not mean that you have to leave the tap running and waste water. Be mindful of your energy and water consumption. Climate change and global warming are still very much real, please! We don’t require another crisis once this one quietens down.
  14. This cannot be stressed enough - prioritize not only your physical but also your mental health. When you’re constantly being bombarded with Coronavirus notifications, it’s easy to get worked up and anxious about the pandemic. Take some time to detox from anything Corona related. Flip through some happy and uplifting news to keep your mind from collapsing. Curate the content you consume through social media to keep you at peace. Be it pupper videos or Good-Advice Cupcake, find something that will remind you of hope and goodwill.

title: Interview | Vikrant Batra, Co-founder, Cafe Delhi Heights
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Vikrant Batra, Co-founder, Cafe Delhi Heights, who delivered a guest lecture at Internship Fair 2020, organised by USME, DTU.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Mr. Vikrant Batra, Co-founder, Cafe Delhi Heights, who delivered a guest lecture at Internship Fair 2020, organised by USME, DTU.

You described your start-up experience in the beginning as a period of “planned chaos”. How would you advise anybody going through a similar phase during her/his start-up to overcome those challenges which one encounters initially?

The most important thing is the evaluation of what you want to do and not to be afraid of following your passion because if you’re happy doing something, you are bound to be successful. If doing business was so easy, then everybody would become an entrepreneur but don’t be scared of doing something which you think is not easy. You have to fight the situations and fighting the situations will help you learn a lot which in turn will not only help you in your profession but also in your personal life. The key mantra is ‘Don’t stop working hard’ and to be very persistent about what you’re doing and be disciplined. 

Sometimes when we’re studying, we don’t realise what the educational institution is giving us with its morning prayers and morning classes which may seem very monotonous but help inculcate discipline and work harder. 

Back in the day, the only café was Nirula’s (which was technically a family restaurant), and Barista and Café Coffee Day were only selling coffee. There was no proper café serving a multi-cuisine menu which we did. I broke the rules of the industry and gave a new concept to the city. 

You believe that the industry can do much better and become a more substantial economic driver if it gets proper government support. You mentioned there are a lot of unnecessary licenses. What else do you think comes under a lot of government scrutiny and needs more liberalisation? 

Can’t you see that the only sport in this country is cricket because the government supports it?

Absolutely! Today the kind of time we devote towards unnecessary government compliances takes away a lot. I would have opened 250 restaurants rather than 25 restaurants so you can imagine the intensity of pain which the government gives us. They don’t have a single-window system as most of their laws are impractical; they plainly don’t know the ground reality. The support of the government is the most significant factor which makes any industry prosper. The support given to us is very minimal, and we keep on fighting for our cause.

Do you have any parting message for the students of DTU?

Enjoy what you do! Keep working hard but enjoy what you do. Make your own rules and don’t think somebody has imposed work on you. Always enjoy your work, and you will be successful!

title: Interview | Prof. V. Subramanian, Former Professor, JNU
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Prof. V. Subramanian, Internationally Renowned Water and Environment Researcher and former Professor, JNU, who was a guest speaker at the National Conference on Strategy for Water Sustainability for Human and Developmental Needs, organised by the Department of Environmental Engineering, DTU and Green Institute for Research & Development.
body:
What do you think is missing in the curriculum of environmental engineering? How can environmental fields of study be transformed so that more students opt for it as a career choice?

Nowadays, the learning process has become straightforward. Earlier, it used to have a lot more depth. In our times, there was no computer. Data collection, laboratory analysis and interpretation were very time-consuming and done manually. This trend has changed with time. There are many factors which must be considered now in order to build a career.

Study of the environment is not only science and technology, but it is also about human beings and values. One of the essential elements which is missing in the curriculum is the set of social issues. For example, the problem of water crisis is being taught to the students, but the skill set on how to deal with it practically is something which needs to be inculcated. Economic, social and environmental factors must be included in the curriculum of environmental engineering. The practical application of the solution needs to be stressed upon. 

People are very ignorant about the issue of climate change. They assume that nature will "resuscitate" and revive itself. What is your take on that?.

Change is inevitable, but the rate of change taking place today is unprecedented.

The concept which needs to be considered is not the change, but the rate of change. Earlier, there wasn't any human impact, so the change was gradual, but now the system cannot adjust to this rapid change. So, awareness must be spread about that. Water crisis has been a significant problem for a very long time. I always wanted to work on water-related issues much before people thought of it as a major concern.

What has been the biggest challenge in your teaching career so far? What should be the approach of dealing with the problems?

I enjoy teaching a lot. I always wanted to be a teacher and have been doing it for the past forty years. After completing my studies when I returned to India, it was tough to implement projects here. The rooms were not very well equipped with gadgets and machines, so I had to raise money for the fieldwork and the sources. Finally, I built the ecosystem which I had always desired.

The students should take an interest in the areas which challenge them. Facing the challenges and overcoming them is something which needs to be done. Dedication, sincerity and an innovative approach are required to excel in the field.

title: Interview | Dr. Priti Nanda Sibal, CEO and Founder, Medi-Skool Health Services
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Dr. Priti Nanda Sibal, CEO and Founder, Medi-Skool Health Services, who was a guest at the Internship Fair, organised by USME.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Dr. Priti Nanda Sibal, CEO and Founder, Medi-Skool Health Services, who was a guest at the Internship Fair, organised by USME.

What is the current attitude of Indians towards preventive healthcare? How is Medi-Skool working towards changing this attitude and urging citizens to take preventive measure?

Back then, when I had just started, preventive healthcare was not something that people were practicing. People used to get their blood test done and didn't know what to do next. They were not aware that if they had high levels of blood sugar or fatty liver, it could be reversed. Now, if people come to me, I can reverse their fatty liver and make it perfect. The awareness is increasing, now that the issue of preventive healthcare is being taken up by youngsters like you.

India has a long way to go in terms of healthcare. What invention in the field of healthcare can improve the current scenario, especially in rural areas?

If rural India looks up to urban India and changes and gets inspired by the western world, the healthcare there will change for good. Another important factor is our lifestyle, including air, food, water. We must follow our traditional practices again and should inculcate fitness into our lifestyle.

title: Going Against Instinct
biliner: In a world where societal norms often contradict the human instinct, Ishaan Gupta, 2nd Year, ME, questions the very legitimacy and the foundation that modern civilization is built upon.
body:
A few months ago, I was talking to a friend of mine about monogamy. He talked about how the practice of monogamy among human beings was all but a religious facade. To strengthen his standpoint, he started talking about the evolutionary standpoint of polygamy: that men are wired to seek as many suitable partners as possible.

40% of unmarried relationships and 25% of married relationships go through at least one incident of infidelity. It is, indeed, a strong argument to support polygamy by labelling it as an instinct in a world where infidelity is universal. I felt that it was important to entertain this thought, because he wasn’t wrong. After all, there’s no justifiable way to condemn a universal instinct. On the other hand, monogamy is a product of civilisation. If we extend this debate above this topic, we get a deeply intriguing question on our hands.

How often do civilisation’s norms go against human instincts?

The answer, albeit counterintuitive, is a relatively sensible one. They mostly don’t. If you were to talk about an age of non-commital freedom in companionship, most men would fantasise about it. Some would even express contempt over what it would be like to live in a society that didn’t scorn on polygamy. However, they don’t think about the consequences of companionship becoming a free market. Most men, in the absence of monogamy, would be sexually excluded. There would be a huge disparity between the number of partners associated with a desirable male and a relatively less desirable male. Moreover, a bi-parent system is scientifically more effective in raising a child than a single parent. Thus, the values of long-term companionship, security, and fostering a family come into the picture. It would be logically sound to say that civilisation alters the human experience and talks about overcoming animalistic instincts that were once important. The entire process depends upon realising that those instincts wouldn’t be the most valuable to a modern-day human in the long run.

In order to further study the contradiction between instinct and civilisation, we can entertain another example. The cultural norm of abstinence is a topic over which there’s been vigorous back-and-forth argument ever since its inception. The desire to procreate is an instinct through which animals keep themselves from going extinct by ensuring the reproduction of future generations. However, in a world that suffers from overpopulation, this instinct loses its significance and the habit of acting on sexual desires becomes voluntary. Cultural norms suggest that you control your libido so that you don’t get addicted to the chemicals released in your brain during acts of procreation. It is so because addiction to these chemicals has detrimental effects on your mental faculties and subsequently, your life.

One last case to consider is obesity. Have you ever looked at yourself in the mirror and cursed God for making high-calorie foods so deliciously tempting? We’re instinctively drawn towards high-calorie foods because there was a time when food wasn’t delivered to our doorsteps. There was a time when human beings had to hunt or search for their meals. Since the status of the next meal was always uncertain, it was grossly favourable that the hunter-gatherer eat high-calorie foods at every chance he got. It was the only way that helped him store extra energy, keeping him energetic for extended periods. But now, in the time of food security, it is culturally mandated that you try to follow a balanced diet and ditch high-calorie foods.

As time goes by, our survival patterns change along with our surroundings. All of these instincts were created because of patterns drastically different from the current ones. It is only logical that we try to tame them and create our own system of rules which better fits our present lives. This doesn’t mean that having urges towards polygamy makes you a sinner or a terrible human being. It makes you human. No one is instinctively wired towards monogamy, but that doesn’t mean one cannot strive for it.

Civilisation is a by-product of the one quality that only human beings possess — self-awareness. What distinguishes us is our capability of observing, assessing our own experiences, and comparing them with the experiences of other people to derive some form of meaning from them. It encourages us to create beliefs and pass down valuable insights for our progeny. This never-ending cycle of tweaking our behaviour in accordance with experience is what makes a civilisation truly worthy of its name.

title: Interview | Sharad Sagar, Founder CEO, Dexterity Global
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Sharad Sagar, Founder CEO, Dexterity Global, who was a speaker at Internship Fair 2020 organised by USME, DTU.
body:
Since, you have been working in the field of education, public service and entrepreneurship. Which two areas significantly come under the government’s control and how do you think private-public partnerships through entrepreneurs can be helpful to India?

The parts that are significantly under the government’s control have a great impact on education and the people of the country. Millions of people go to government schools, as that may be their only option. The education delivered within government schools, that caters to a significant population, is heavily under government’s control. There are a lot of non- and for-profit organizations that have built new technologies and came up with new methods to reform education. It is interesting that a lot of research and experience is equipped by a large number of upcoming organizations. The government should be open and willing to listen to these organizations because many of them have first-hand grassroot knowledge that other institutions may not have. This can be in terms of knowledge sharing, research or in terms of capacity building. This public-private partnership is possible. Of course, we can see and make sure of its ethics, the transparency, and how the contextualization of it is always kept alive and merited.

You are also known as the Vivekananda of the 21st century. How do you think the principles of Vivekananda can be adopted in the 21st century by the University students? How can they help the students become disciplined and focused individuals, who can also help building a sustainable community?

I delivered a speech at Vivekanand hall in Baroda, where Swami Vivekanand had stayed. I got a chance to stay there and to deliver a lecture that crossed over a million views on social media. It was then when the media house declared me as the Vivekanand of the 21st century. I see myself as Swamiji’s worker. Swami Vivekanand once said, “India’s coming glory shall be so great that it’s ancient glory may feed in front of it.” Some people say his thinking was more whimsical or too optimistic. He also said, “My faith lies in the younger generation, out of them will come my workers who will work out the whole problem like lions.” So, instead of being seen as the Vivekanand of the 21st century, I would like to be seen as one of Swami’s workers which he used to talk about. Swamiji frequently talked about education being the manifestation of perfection that is already within. He talked about each soul being potentially divine. He said, ”All the power in the world is within you and it is us who have kept our hands over our eyes and cried about darkness”. He asked the young people to not to go outside and look for consolation or solace. You are divine. You are powerful. You can manifest the education and power from within. That is something that more and more young people should remember. I would like to add something here, this was when somebody from the West asked Swamiji, “What should I do?”, and Swamiji said, “Love India.” That’s the kind of love Swamiji had for India. Swamiji once went to Kanyakumari, to meditate. The place he went to, is now famous by the name Vivekanand Rock Memorial. He meditated there for three days straight and only focused on the past, present and future of India. A patriotic monk, who felt deeply for India, said, ”India being lifted up, can help lift humanity up.” This is the sum and substance of a lot of things that Swamiji used to say. One must become such, who can help others, too, to be the best version of themselves. These are the things that young people should definitely incorporate in themselves.

What was your journey like, from being home-schooled in Bihar to studying abroad? What inspired you to start Dexterity Global?

I studied at Tufts University on a full scholarship. But I turned down an offer from Harvard. That was what truly happened. My own lived experiences, being home-schooled for the first twelve years of my life. Reading the newspaper was compulsory as my parents had mandated it. I used to read about other kids winning competitions, securing scholarships that made me wonder if I could do the same. So, I started writing down these opportunities and at the age of twelve I attended school for the first time and started participating in these opportunities. Represented India in over 6 different countries, won over 200 competitions by the time I was in 12th standard. Our education must build leaders for India. We’re teaching them technology to limit themselves. The technology should uplift the people. They teach journalism, then journalism should be lifting them up. If they’re being taught medical science, then that must lift them up. That is the larger idea behind Dexterity. First trying to work hard and strive on my own, and now enabling the youth to do so.

How do you think Corporate India could be encouraged to take up bigger roles and execute their job and duties in adherence with the model responsibilities that often underlie when working for profitable ventures in other big firms?

The responsibilities lie with everyone. Corporate India should not see its work limited to corporate social responsibility and that CSR should not just be seen as a formality. We need corporations that set up in the first place to solve challenging problems. Henry Ford did not just set out to make money. He faced the problem and thought there must be a better way for people to go from one place to another. Mark Zuckerberg thought there must be a better way for people to connect with each other. Bill Gates thought about computers running the world and increasing human productivity. So, we don’t just need corporations writing a cheque to a non-profit. We need corporations that set out on a mission to make things that are less carcinogenic, more organic, and can try to lower the price point in a part of industry. So, the role of corporations is also to see that with talent and workforce, to solve a challenging problem.

How do you think leadership roles have changed in the 21st century in the view of one of your seven visions for repairing the 21st century leadership? What qualities one must expect the leader of the 21st century to imbibe according to you?

Leadership has not changed in any century. It is the challenges that we must be prepared for, which continue to change and in the 21st century as we continue to advance. I delivered a TED talk once where I talked about how on one end, we need nuclear energy and on the other end, we need nuclear disarmament. On one end, we need more machines and robots and on the other end we need to make sure that we still have that human touch in the products we build. At the pace we’re moving, many challenges have not yet been introduced. So, one needs to build a new company that can grow fast, serve a lot of people and yet not pollute the climate. We need travel companies that connect a grandmother with her grandchild. But, in the process, they should also plan about cutting down on the carbon footprint of the entire journey, that is as beautiful. Air planes have contributed greatly for the Grandmother but must also make sure that her grandson has a better planet to breathe in. These are the challenges. The quality is what we need. Present day leaders need four skills; critical thinking, research, communication and leadership. Two core values; empathy and fearlessness. Two core commitments; public service and nation building and finally they must be driven by a scientific temperament. They must be grounded in spiritual values and those spiritual values shall be focusing on the inner journey as well as being integrated with self and society, and not getting detached.

What important message would you like to give us and to our leaders?

Smart people should take action, they should build things, and in a different space. A better space that every young Indian should aspire to contribute towards. Wherever I am, I will build new things. I’ll fix a few old things, I’ll make sure that my presence makes the surroundings better, be it my office or my dinner table discussion. That is something that every young person in the country should strive for, we can truly lead the world if we do this.

title: FLYING HIGH, FALLING HARD
biliner: With the world economy struggling to breathe in the tightening grip of unfathomable events, Prakhar Chaudhary, 2nd Year, BAE, tries to analyse another addition to the economic environment - the Yes Bank fiasco.
body:
Quotes and speeches that motivate us to dream big and be ambitious should perhaps come with a precautionary note – ‘Be aware of your current position while doing so’.

This will significantly improve our financial system, because adding its name to the list of reckless dreamers is the Yes Bank. This private lender, by all accounts, was an ambitious entity which believed in speed. Going against the general flow of the Indian economy, the growth curve of Yes Bank saw an unprecedented rise. When giant Non-Banking Financial Corporations like IL&FS and DHFL, various industries like automobile, fertilizers and the agriculture sector were reverberating with echoes of the economic slowdown, Yes Bank-in a time span of 15 years became the fourth largest private lender of India with total assets of ₹4 lakh crores. This flight unfortunately had a crash landing, which became the epicenter of tremors that could be felt all across the Indian economy.

What led to this crash?

According to reports, more than 25% of Yes Bank’s loans were extended to Non-Banking Financial Corporations, real estate firms and the construction sector- three sectors that have been struggling for quite some time. Over exposed to toxic assets and still continuing with their lending spree which led to their advances rising by 334% between financial year 2014 and 2019, Yes Bank collapsed under the weight of its Non-Performing Assets (NPA). As the bank faltered on NPAs, its share prices fell. With a decrease in the public confidence, the number of fresh accounts became meager and the public made huge withdrawals. Yes Bank, thus, lost out on capital from both depositors and debtors.

State Bank of India to the rescue?

Reserve Bank of India announced a reconstruction scheme for Yes Bank under which State Bank of India will be spearheading this mission by taking over 49% of the shares at a minimum price of ₹10 per share and not reducing its holding below 26% for 3 years. A host of other changes like placing the bank under a moratorium, forming a new board, writing off all tier-1 capital etc. was announced. But the question here is whether the proposed bailout warranted and what lies ahead for the wider financial sector.

Why SBI?

Whenever a non-governmental financial organisation faces fund shortages, the first option is to have private investors come in and infuse their money into the ailing organisation. Yes Bank was given time to work out this way, but due to its NPAs it could not get any investors. The next option is that the government nationalises the private bank i.e. transfers the control and ownership of the bank from private bodies to the state. The government, already struggling with severe fiscal deficits could not afford to do this and hence was reluctant to nationalise Yes Bank. As the last resort, the government got a public sector bank, SBI, to lead this rescue.

Should Public Sector Banks save distressed Private Banks?

According to various economists, having a public sector institution to go out of its way for helping another ailing organisation should always be the last resort. As per the latest Financial Stability Report, public sector banks have 12.5% of gross NPAs. The government, over the past few years, has had to infuse ₹3.5 lakh crore of equity into the public sector banks. This clearly shows that the overall banking system is not very healthy and is overburdened with NPAs. In such a scenario, it is never good for a public sector bank to step into the chaos and attempt to facilitate rescue plans. This severely hampers their future growth prospects and scale of functioning, making the financial ecosystem even more fragile. But when we have financial intermediaries like the Yes Bank, which are so interconnected with other banks, mutual funds, NBFCs, real estate firms etc. at the verge of failing, the financial stability of the entire country is at stake and some kind of intervention is required. In this case, with this crisis emerging at the heel of the IL&FS, DHFL fallout and the economic slowdown leaving the government incapable of rescuing Yes Bank themselves, there was no other option left.

What will be the long-term consequences of such events on the Economy?

While steps are being taken by RBI and the government to solve the Yes Bank issue which is an immediate problem, a series of continuous fall outs of various important financial organisations has led to a very large trust deficit in the financial ecosystem. The damage to public confidence caused by placing Yes Bank under moratorium and putting a cap on withdrawal of deposits of ₹50,000 is very evident by the fall that several private bank stocks have seen in the past few days. Looking at the larger picture, the very basic foundation of a sound financial ecosystem is trust. If the investing public does not trust the reports on asset quality, direct implications can be seen on funds and financing of the firm. While we have the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code and the National Company Law Tribunal, they are not sufficient to handle the burden of NPAs that our market is engulfed under. There are more than 2,000 cases pending at the NCLT courts. All this indicates the need of having a one-time solution and a process that facilitates the full and actual disclosure of the state of affairs of a firm. This can significantly reduce the problems of information asymmetry in the market and enhance trust. A sound foundation of trust will create a financial system that will be able to fund the growth trajectory that we aspire for. Otherwise, it will all end where it started – in an ambitious dream.

title: How to Avoid Shaking Hands
biliner: Amid Corona and Otherwise...
body:
Humorous? Not anymore. The storm clouds, by the name COVID-19, are here bringing upon trouble among the Homo sapiens. The friendliest ones have started keeping it to themselves. Well, it’s important so, why not? The situation calls for it.

I recently traveled to a workshop in another city. Keeping in mind all precautions and prevention I read about travelling amid the pandemic; washing hands often, maintaining distance from potentially infected ones, keeping a pocket sanitizer ready but when it came to avoiding close contact from people it felt awkward. Upon reaching the workshop, I realized I was bound to greet new people with a handshake with the continuous feeling of not offending anybody by refusing to do so. Although, I was able to dodge some of those coming at my side. 

Over the next few weeks or months, while greeting new people these might help you navigate this potentially awkward situation:

Accept that it’s going to feel awkward

These feel like some small unnoticeable gestures; however, they carry great importance in defining one’s impression. You can never know how the other person perceives your ‘rejection’ to a small gesture such as a handshake. He may take it lightly or seriously depending upon the nature of the person or the bond you two share. According to Andy Molinsky, a professor at Brandeis, “transgressions of professional norms like these can feel awkward because your actions break the routine and script of how you tend to express warm greeting”. This worrying that you feel that you may make a bad impression or send an unfriendly message is normal to exist. The situation can become even more challenging when a superior entity shall be present in front. The reason this situation might be risky is misinterpretation of each other’s gestures or misunderstanding, constantly trying to figure out what you both feel comfortable with – touching elbows? Feet? Fist bumping? Just a wave and who takes the lead.

Decide ahead of time what you feel comfortable with

Just before you have to greet a person, make sure of what gesture you want to use so that you feel confident. This will stimulate confidence in the next person as well because the situation becomes clearer. At the workshop, I decided to keep my hands in my pockets to avoid touching, and with a smile on my face I met new people by saying “Since, we’re not allowed to shake hands now…” followed by an elbow bump.

Maggie Stieg, a senior facilitator with The Ariel Group, explains, “We explored the ways Emirati women let others know they did not shake hands. One of the methods that worked best was simply to place the right hand on the chest (as in the posture of pledging allegiance to the flag). No words seemed necessary with that posture,” during her research program in UAE.

“A quick wave from a farther distance, before returning your hand back to your pocket, is useful to non-verbally signal that we’re going to forego the normal ritual.” Says Molinsky, after his keen observations on the social life of normal people.

Use humor to mitigate the awkwardness

Humor is a great ‘socializer’, as long as it’s light-hearted and intended to connect. People connect better when humor is involved, especially for the fresh meets. It is so powerful that even while breaking a social norm such as a handshake in this case, it can be used as a tool to defuse the discomfort. However, humor should be used wisely and strictly situations specifically and should never come at the expense of somebody’s respect.

Avoid Judgement

Under the current circumstances, showing rejection towards physical contacts is legit and you’re not guilty of not expressing your regrets or apologies to anybody. Both of you probably have the same thoughts/judgments about yourselves at the moment; “I’m doing this for the good”, “Am I really scared of this virus?” or “is it such a big deal?”. Now, instead of worrying how your behavior is perceived from the next person, you should realize that we are all under a constant risk, so taking preventive measures is a necessity after all. In India we can use our beloved ‘Namaste’ as a means to greet, this comes with a whole package such as, most importantly, no touching involved, expresses a respectful gesture and No Judgments. Even if you’re not a ‘namaste’ person, reserving judgment and not worrying what others think of you is good advice at all times. Do what you feel like doing, and assume others will understand.
