title: Interview | Prof. Peer M. Sathikh, Associate Chair (Academic), School of Art, Design and Media, NTU, Singapore
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Prof. Peer M. Sathikh, Associate Chair (Academic), School of Art, Design and Media, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, who was a guest speaker at the Form Exploration Workshop, organised by the Department of Design.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Prof. Peer M. Sathikh, Associate Chair (Academic), School of Art, Design and Media, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, who was a guest speaker at the Form Exploration Workshop, organised by the Department of Design.

You are a visiting professor at IIT Bombay, an adjunct professor at VIT and an associate professor at ADM. What differences or striking qualities have you observed over the map of India?

Over the map of India, in the last ten years, there has been an increase in awareness regarding design and design education. Not just design and design education, but more and more engineering programmes are also understanding that design is not just designing components; it must be all-encompassing and holistic, involving human beings in the process too. For example, take IIT Bombay and VIT. They have different accents. IIT’s have been traditionally experimentalists. They still try to inculcate experimentation and maybe failure is not tolerated, but deviations from the mainstream are. VIT, on the other hand, wants to have a structured education program and it may not look like it, but their end goal is to get their students jobs whereas IIT Bombay is sure that its students will find jobs, so they’re pushing for innovation and creativity. The ideology of IIT Bombay doesn’t centre around finding jobs for its students. They allow their students to prepare their folio, and then the student must stand for himself and seek a job.

So, it’s assumed that ultimately, all students will manage to bag a job, so they urge the students to be fresh and creative.

Exactly. VIT is worried about where its students will end up after four years, so even though their teaching pedagogy is like that of IIT, the students’ expectations are different. The students at IIT want to pick my brain, with good reason, because they want to achieve what I have achieved in certain spheres. At VIT, they want to know how I got my job and how I progressed in my career. What was built in me through IIT was so natural, that once you’re prepared, you can attend the job interview and I’m sure you’ll do well. It’s not arrogance but its confidence. That’s the difference. Overall in India, the design industry and education are at their best right now.

Do you think there will be an increase in awareness about design education in the future?

There will be a plateau. Everybody wants to know where their model of design education stands, but in my opinion, each area has its own set of ideologies and philosophy. If you’re able to understand the underlying set of ideologies, it will work all over. 

You must know what has to be embedded and what has to be portrayed.

So, this is my experience of the last ten years of teaching. 

You are the Associate Chair at the Nanyang Technological University. What differences do you see in design education in India and Singapore?

In both countries, the students are interested in sustainability. They are a little concerned that their children may not be able to enjoy the world as it is today. The main difference is that you are looking at Singapore, an island city, and only so many designers and media artists can find jobs within, so we are preparing our students for a global experience. You could be in Singapore, but you may be designing for India or China. 

Whereas if you look at India, the population is enormous, and there seems to be an internal environment and demand for designers and media artists. So, it brings me to my point. Our way of looking at students is different, and we decided that we can’t be a master of a single element of design and media. At the same time, we cannot water down our efforts so we give a chance to our students to build an interdisciplinary design education curriculum which they would like to pursue. We show them the different courses that are available and what pathways those courses will take you along and depending on what frame of mind you are in at that point of time, we can predict where you will be in five years. The students get to choose. Some of them would say “I want to do product design only” and some of them would graduate as a general designer. So, they can fit into the industry where they are looking for generals.

We must remember that the mindset of the student and their job functions are different in Singapore. More often than not, most of the students don’t want to join a big company, for the reason that such companies don’t exist. They exist as a headquarters but never as manufacturers. So, they see themselves trying to club together to form short-term companies like joint ventures, or they would like to have shared offices. They try to find jobs which they can do together and make money. But if they get a product-based design job, that’s fine too. “We are a team”, is a trend which is catching on in Singapore. 

Do you think it will catch on in India too?

The urban society? Yes. But where it is needed is in the suburbs and rural community where our education as designers gives us certain skills, which may be useful to help solve some of the problems of rural India. For example, sanitation has been the biggest issue, but the PwD can’t solve it. We must come up with a more creative way of dealing with it.

And if this is going to happen, you will see an increase in the numbers of design entrepreneurs who are committed to a social cause. My concern is, where is the business model. At the end of the day, when you settle down, or you are with your mom and dad, they will ask you where the bread and the butter is coming from.

Altruism is not going to give you a business model.

You can have a Gandhian perspective, but it’s not right if you say everything is for free. Because you have a wife and a child to look after and a society to look after. So, what kind of design entrepreneurs will come and how would they portray their business, so people won’t perceive them as taking advantage.

This is a dichotomy which we all face. We want to make social progress, but we cannot do it if we cannot have our bread and butter. The equation changes when I want to have bread on the table and my son wants to have a cake. So, with that in mind, if I have a business model, and I apply it to a social cause, the powers that be might think I am trying to exploit them. So, this is going to be a challenge for Indian design entrepreneurs.

You are a REP fellow at Nanyang Technological University. Can you tell us about the Renaissance engineering program?

Renaissance engineering program is a high-level engineering program in Singapore. It is based on the Renaissance movement that happened long ago in Italy, where art, science, engineering and technology came together as one. Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci cannot be classified as artists. They were architects, engineers, artists and designers, and that eventually led to the Italian Renaissance.

Renaissance engineering program is a program in which students learn, not just engineering, but they understand other aspects of art, design, economy and it gives them an advantage as to what working for a Renaissance artist would be like.

So, this is like moving from a design-centric approach to a broader perspective. 

Yes, it’s like a shift in narrative and a shift in effort. I mean, I go and teach what industrial design is. You might grow up to be leaders or heads of corporations, but you require someone to design a campaign, who to look for and how to use it. Similarly, economics is taught in a manner that it is useful for them, not as a subject. So, at the end of the day, they have a Capstone project which will combine all of this.

The Renaissance engineering program gives you a bachelor’s degree plus a master’s in management plus one year of studying in one of the best universities in the world. REP fellows are selected based on the capabilities to teach and lead. 

You co-founded Inovasia Design in Singapore and are a successful design entrepreneur. Keeping in mind the dichotomy that exists in society, how can budding entrepreneurs achieve middle ground and rise?

It can be achieved very well and effectively, when human beings are the heart and soul of your consulting.

You’re not designing for the interest of the marketing; you’re not designing purely for the profit or for that the management that wants this product. You are designing it for the human being. If that is the central aspect of yours, everything else will fall in place. Focus on the user. 

For example, if you want to design medical equipment, there are three people who will predominantly be the users. One is the patient, second is the paramedic staff, who takes you around, and the third is the doctor. If you design an equipment, the doctor may not want to touch it, for some odd reasons, they will touch it with a pencil. If you design a control panel, they’ll keep punching it and if it breaks down, I failed as a designer because I didn’t foresee this. 

Secondly, the nurse will touch it. They will clean their hands and clean their equipment. Thirdly, if I am designing a medical product, I need to care for the patient, and I want to see his comfort. Moreover, he should not be intimidated by the display. What the doctor needs to know, the patient doesn’t. In movies, many times, the doctor would walk in and say, “Oh! The heart rate is 56, and it’s going down.” That’s the last thing the patient wants to hear. There should be a cautionary message that’s sent to the nurse and the doctor so that they can come and correct it. So, the design of medical equipment is multi-faceted. You come to the aesthetic of it. It should exuberate confidence. You don’t skip into a ward wearing a skirt. (laughs)

You must be prepared for it. Similarly, a product with a thousand wires around it won’t give you confidence. We need to have foresight while developing. The nurse too, must know which coloured wire to press and which to put. Designers have traditionally had this mindset, colour-coding things so that they are easier to use. 

You interned as a student at the Sony Design Centre in Tokyo. How was your experience, and how did it help you evolve as a product designer?

See, IIT taught me to be a designer of the Ulm School, where everything was very organised, and there is some structure to it but embedded with Indian ethos and culture. As a designer, I was confident in conceptualising and sketching and all that. At Sony, I realised that a designer has to have discipline. You are not an artist; you are a designer. Someone asks you to design a Sony Walkman. You have to know that there are two targets in mind. One, it has to be a saleable product, as defined by the marketing or as per your definition. Second is that this product has to be reliable, in terms of its mechanics, which is the art of an engineer but those two things have to come together in a usable structure that allows the user to know that this is the right thing I have and this is going to work correctly. Sony built its reputation on this very foundation. You are not playing games with yourself, but artistically you are playing a game, you are enjoying this moment. So, discipline is if I told you I’m going to submit it today, I will, because, for each delay, there are repercussions.

I also realised that the product is bigger than yourself.

Even if you’re designing a little hearing aid, the product is bigger than yourself. You cannot go out and show off that you designed a hearing aid, nobody wants to know. When they use the hearing aid, and they feel it has served its purpose, the look on their face, and the happiness that time when someone says you know what, Peer & Partners must have designed this, that’s the goal. So, let the work speak for itself. You can always leave your signature, to say that I designed this, and people will find out. We never marketed Inovasia Design when we were in Asia, it was always word of mouth. The confidence our clients had in us was also very motivating. It is the calmness that my Indian education has brought to me and my professors who taught me. If you have not understood your own design, it’s not going to work. 

Do you have a message for students of the design program?

Make the most of these four years to explore and gain. You must have your own opinion as to what works, what doesn’t, what is the human factor, what are the aesthetics, what is the emotional conviction that the product must have. The product is bigger than you, and to do that, we cannot rush to the destination, even if we have a deadline. If you rush into a product, you will make mistakes.

My message is, do not try to impress people, express yourself.

title: The Ghost of the 21st Century
biliner: With access to other forms of entertainment in the 21st century, voluntary social exclusion is becoming more and more prevalent. Mihir Ranjan, 2nd Year, EE captures the world from the perspective of the modern ghost, the silent observer detached from the social circles near him.
body:
With access to other forms of entertainment in the 21st century, voluntary social exclusion is becoming more and more prevalent. Mihir Ranjan, 2nd Year, EE captures the world from the perspective of the modern ghost, the silent observer detached from the social circles near him.

And there I stood, watching over the rest.

Not in the dark, in today’s time the light or rather its absence wasn’t necessary to go by unnoticed. No one seems to mind my presence - as a matter of fact - neither my absence, as if my existence begs apathy. And I don’t mind that. We know a ghost to be an apparition of sorts, something otherworldly, manifested in our realm. And well, one could say that I am in many ways similar to a ghost. Not that I was a nebulous image here with malignant intent, rather I was disembodied from the machinations of modern society, the cog that won’t turn. 

People are interesting, rather the things they choose to squabble about are. When you boil their psyche down to the very base, their workings are well defined, as if a universal law of human behavior pervaded this universe, quietly. Over the years, I learnt many things as I observed my peers. I wouldn’t call them new, since it's always about the same old droll and drama. It’s surprising how something so predictable can still be fun. Rather, I should say predicting things is fun, there’s a certain pleasure in playing the detective. A temporary high of being a puppet master, knowing the exact reaction to your targeted action. Socializing moved from being a necessity to a pastime, something to stimulate the senses rather than survive. 

Living in the information age, knowledge is power, and I’m still to find the knowledge that could be more useful than the knowledge of the human psyche. Mankind is a social being, accept it or reject it, one cannot refute it. Since time immemorial, the definitive act of entertainment has always been social acts, be they festivities or feasts. The place where one feels at home is in the presence of others. In a civilization that survives around human contact, living without feeling an incessant urge to socialize felt surreal and to actually prefer it, supernatural. 

Granted it leads to detachment from social circles, but that’s a consequence I accepted. One cannot be a ghost unless they’ve faded from existence.After all, one cannot be a ghost if they haven’t faded from existence.

I would not say I am anti-social, nor would I call myself an introvert. I am very well capable of meeting and bonding with new people. Just because I can, doesn’t mean I derive satisfaction from it. Once one breaks out of the system of common livelihood, and sees the day to day struggles of people, he naturally feels no inclination to partake in them. It became insignificant to me who said what about whom, or how the latest pop culture movie was. To be cognizant of the woes of the people and excluding myself from them. Was it my fortune that I avoided the problems of the 21st century? Or was it my curse to not experience this adventure as many before me had?

I never realized when I became the modern ghost, I don’t think anyone does. Between a quest for independence and a search for a greater truth, the lines of my reality blurred. As I moved from my life onto this afterlife, I take respite in the fact that there are many more to follow in my wake.

title: Arthur Fleck, a way of life
biliner: In a world where Joker's actions are frowned upon, Anushka Sharma, 3rd Year, MAM, emphasis upon the darkness that is bestowed upon him and everyone of us, by the society we call to be our own.
body:
In a world where Joker's actions are frowned upon, Anushka Sharma, 3rd Year, MAM, emphasis upon the darkness that is bestowed upon him and everyone of us, by the society we call to be our own.

An agent of chaos, but a survivor at heart
he was spreading happiness, 
until they tore him apart.
Doesn’t his paranoia resonate with you too?
Because more often than not, 
that’s what this world does to you.
Demurring your every move,
every slight step you ever take, 
preventing you from feeling whole
And then calling you a fake.
Burning cars and burning streets
seemed metaphorical to me,
They were amorphous emotions brought to life,
That condemned the ever eminent glee.
The gun in his hand, betrays his will to exist
And the happiness that follows,
Is symbolic of feeling like he finally fit in.
Calumny is a way of life,
That no one wants to recover from,
And disinterested is what everyone pretends to be,
When humanity should stand together, strong.
Equivocality is tearing us all apart,
And would invariably continue to be extant,
In spite of the creation of
such thought provoking art.

 

Illustration by Vishrut Sharma

title: To Think or Not To Think
biliner:
Overthinking is often categorised as a negative term which acts as an invite to stress and anxiety. Does overthinking create problems that didn't even exist or is it a way of finding myriad solutions to one problem? 
N. Krithika, 1st Year, ENE contemplates on the various aspects of overthinking which has its own pros and cons.
body:
Illustration Credits: Tejasv Mohan

There was a strange silence prevailing inside my room that day. The four-walled room seemed to be quite chaotic. The sofa, which was lying on one side and seemed to be pragmatically dark, was over-crowded with my bag, headphones and some books. The antique wooden furniture quietly tolerated its demotion and became a dumping ground rather than serving its real purpose. There was a jacket, which concealed my unfinished painting, illustrating my futile attempt to become a Picasso and also highlighting my relentless fervour of trying out new things.

The bed, which seemed to be a space hogger, surprisingly was very tidily kept with pillows and a colourful bed sheet which was a testament of my disarrayed and kaleidoscopic mind. The big round clock on the wall was constantly ticking and  resounded in my mind, jarring out all the silence of the room. The vexed question of why the third hand of a clock is called a 'second hand' was gyrating inside my mind. 

A warm yellow light with a hint of tangerine entered through the window, irradiating my evocative paintings, which outlined my desire to express my mind and emotions in a subtle way. The study table was cluttered with all the knick-knacks, evoking a sense of nostalgia. I looked at the mirror and pondered, ''What must be its actual colour?" The room was congested but had enough space for my room of thoughts with multitudes of emotions flowing inside my mind.

The incidents suddenly transformed into a virtual reality game in which all my embarrassing moments, awkward scenarios where I failed to ‘prove’ my point appeared like different levels and were moving with a speed of 100 km per second. There was me, with the adrenaline coursing through my veins, with all the scenarios whipping my face like wind and I was trying to dodge them with my comebacks that I could have used in the real realm.

I suddenly realised that it's been an hour since I have been overthinking about the myriad aspects of my life.

The questions have started to consume my thoughts and teleported me to a world where I am contradicting my own arguments.

I constantly re-examined what people actually meant when they said ‘okay’, does that mean they aren’t agreeing with the point?

What about ‘maybe’, are they actually confused or just acting with their mind already made up and they just don’t wish to tell me?

I was trying to decipher the hidden meaning behind these simple words, which formed a perpetual trail of stress, fear, anxiety, and frustration where I logically crushed my own creative thoughts. The motivation and zeal to overthink somehow became obscure. Overthinking becomes obnoxious and I do realise this a couple of times and spend ample amount of time thinking about the ways in which overthinking can harm my mental peace.

For some, the art of overthinking  is just a piece of threadbare cloth with torn and tattered memories which strikes discomfort and pangs of self-guilt inside one’s body. While for some, it is like a blanket of woven memories, which radiates expressions of love and warmth. It unfolds the countless layers of nostalgia which brings comfort and peace to the mind.

I sometimes feel that overthinking is not completely debilitating. We think of the happy and sad memories and relive the moments, which form a beautiful concoction of feelings, facts, opinions and some unspoken words. It completely depends on the way we choose to act and react in the situation. It somehow prepares us for the worst situation possible as we already have our ‘backup’ ready for whatever the situation may throw at us. We already may have analysed every aspect of the situation vividly, creatively and logically however trivial the possibility maybe. 

What we need to learn is to balance this bittersweet art, which helps us indulge in reminiscence.

title: Plugging In Romance
biliner: Read on as Akanksha Tanwar, 2nd year, IT student tries to delve into the 'chemical-mixture' which flows through our wifi modem, as we try to find a way through the sea of our soulmates.
body:
Have you ever sent out a text to a person who seemed like a heavy texter, all anxiety-ridden sweat falling off your face only to be saddened by the double ticks flashing before your eyes?

Yeah, me too.

I would start making up scenarios in my head next. Maybe, his phone fell into the nehar just outside college? Or maybe he fell into the nehar himself?

It’s still better than wondering what wrong did that nonchalant text sent from my phone painted me like, before a stranger’s eyes.

Online dating has its origin in the 1960s, with the emergence of the first computer dating services.[1]

These services claimed that they could leverage the new power of computers to help find the luckless their true soulmate. If we view it from this angle, it looks like social service; you are helping a lonely person pair up with someone equally lonely (and toxic). Even though online dating started way before in developed countries, to India this still remains a sunrise concept. Our parents are reluctant to let us meet strangers we have been talking to over the phone, without first acquiring a recommendation letter from our relatives.

What’s the problem with online dating? Well, let’s analyze:

The main boon and bane for sites like Tinder is the option of choices. If we could hire a time machine and go to the time when our parents got married, we would realise arranged marriages had some limited criteria for filtering out candidates. For instance, my mom was probably selected because she was fair and homely. I am sure my dad didn’t want a girl who was fair, homely and a fan of F.R.I.E.N.D.S, had followers>following on Instagram, perfect grammar, iPhone person. . . you get my point. This is known as The Paradox of Choice.

A professor of psychology at Swarthmore College explored the possibility of choices being directly proportional to happiness.[2]

That’s the catch here, the internet hasn’t provided us with the best option but instead introduced us to so many choices, creating an illusion of the best option existing somewhere; resulting in the belief- the current option is not it. Probably that is why you hear so many committed people saying, ‘I am missing out on something’.

Whereas, in reality, we would be happy with a good enough choice instead. Earlier a mottled character of a person was the reason to move on to other options, whereas now we’d be mad if our sitcom choices didn’t align with our potential partner.

Let’s take a look at the paradigm of limited options. Am I saying that having a narrower pool of options was way better than having a plethora of right thumb techniques? Probably not. They had way more pressure to ‘lock it down’ and felt rather sidelined, had they not been married by their mid-twenties.

To be happy with what you have on your plate and not being distracted by the trendy unicorn ice-cream is undoubtedly hard. But I would rather choose to have plain old vanilla every day and be happy with its consistent good enough taste. It’s about not being too specific, giving a chance to people and letting them evolve to a better version before cancelling their Netflix and Chill ticket.

Let us assume you muster up the courage to handpick your best photographs (sudden realization why you need to go spelunking with a puppy ASAP!). The following [3] dilemmas might create small hiccups during your journey:

  1. The Generic ‘Hey’ Text: Who would have thought that hey impressions would mean a lot more than first impressions? What’s a hey impression you ask? A relatively harmless text might set the mood for your whole conversation. Try to imagine it from the other side, it seems like you are creating a half parallel plate capacitor, “hey hey hey hey” arranged vertically on one side and it is figuratively drawing a picture of your love life- it’s just not working.

 

  1. The Secretary Problem: This happens when both the parties are constantly going back and forth to settle on a date to meet up, but end up looking like secretaries who have their calendars absolutely booked. This leads to a fizzling out frenzy- the conversation which was once fun and flirtatious now turns into a with-regards email text. It is natural to go over the possibility whether the other party is even interested in you.

 

  1. Grammar/Spelling: Even if you have a doggo besides you, a great body and the most chiseled face, I am sorry to inform you that, those might help you get past the swiping phase but you would never go beyond that. People, in general, perceive “uh are prettay” and “You are pretty.” as the difference in the number of grey cells you might have. Uh r definitely going 2 to get unmatched.
  2. The Infinite Loop of Swiping: You knew that we were coming to this. If no one swipes right, how the hell are you supposed to land up with your soulmate? You just reach the end of Tinder; it’s a metaphorical representation of Tinder giving up on you. What should you do next? Pack your bags, become an avid traveler. If you are able to score some pictures of yourself while meditating on the Alps, bingo! Also, go find a puppy.

This list is just never-ending. To add to your misery, this list isn’t even the bible that you should be following. The acceptable slangs, your ethnicity, your lifestyle and if there is room for your education, might affect if a person would even consider you subconsciously in the first place. If you have the right skills to master the art of keeping a person engaged please start a YouTube channel and teach the world the hacks to master the science of waiting.

Online dating can/was/will never be enough. Even if you surpass all the phases and hurdles and meet the person in real life, don’t bind any expectations. Treat online dating as a rather introductory service. Just take a look, chat a bit and just meet the person before a pandemic takes over the world again!

My final advice: Just don’t ask women if they would like to “hang out” with you.

Inspired by 'Modern Romance' a novel by Aziz Ansari with Eric Klinenberg

[2] Improvised expert from the book.

title: A Eulogy For Niceness
biliner: As humankind heads into a precarious future, it has borne witness to the gradual perishment of a primordial emotion, niceness. Cast aside, niceness succumbed to the pernicious school of thought which mistook it for cowardice and timidity. Read on, as Angad Sethi, 2nd Year, COE, delivers a heartfelt eulogy for one of mankind’s oldest companions.
body:
Illustration By Medhavi Thakur

As humankind heads into a precarious future, it has borne witness to the gradual perishment of a primordial emotion, niceness. Cast aside, niceness succumbed to the pernicious school of thought which mistook it for cowardice and timidity. Read on, as Angad Sethi, 2nd Year, COE, delivers a heartfelt eulogy for one of mankind’s oldest companions.

It's a regular Saturday night. I lay on my bed, bereft of energy, cupping a mug of tea in my hands as the subtle warmth seeps into my skin, when my phone lures me into its trap with a docile ‘Google News’ notification. I scoop up my phone and with one last burst of energy, frantically scroll through the endless stream of advertisements to reach the news. The video on autoplay is practically screaming for attention. There are two men, fighting over the last crate of water bottles in a supermarket, the market having been emptied in a senseless state of frenzied hoarding fuelled by panic, fear, greed and one resilient virus. As this frame shimmers away, the screen is filled with the visual of a senior citizen, woefully viewing the empty aisles of the supermarket, her eyes betraying sorrow, hopelessness and fury as she traverses aisle after aisle, searching for groceries. She turns to face the camera and, in that instant, in that infinitesimal of a second, I know what has happened. I am aware, yet I refuse to let that feeling sink down, my heart barricading itself in lieu of that fateful moment, when it actually hits me. By the time, I raise my eyes to read the heading, the overbearing feeling has just metamorphosed into realisation as I scroll through the rest of the article in a haze of sorrow and denial, lamenting the loss of niceness.

It all began when humankind began confusing niceness with cowardice.

I would love nothing more than to declare that niceness died a painless death, swift and without suffering, yet, to fool you, my reader, is not my intention. If I’m being completely honest with myself, I have seen niceness suffer innumerable blows during my relatively short time on this planet. It all began when humankind began confusing niceness with cowardice, its reputation marred by an ever-increasing group of people who believed that being nice and amiable was the hallmark of the weak. I had the ill-fortune of meeting a person who belonged to this insidious school of thought.

Our university is located in a deserted corner of North Delhi, untouched by the luminescent, warm glow of fast-food chains that the students of Delhi University get to bask in, every day and houses a canteen where the cooks don’t even attempt to hide their sheer lack of talent. Nevertheless, a group of loyal students flock to this canteen, every day and I was in tow on a fateful day. Having acquired a token from the cashier, I marched towards the counter to take what was rightfully mine. I stood in the queue. Although the queue was only a single student, I stood behind him, in favour of public decency and decorum. The student had ordered an idli and yellow water, which the server insisted on calling sambhar, and was about to begin a perilous journey towards one of the benches, his only goal to reach before the water overstepped its boundaries and began to obey gravity. It was at this very moment, that another guy appeared from thin air, stepped right next to me. In a blatant disregard for the decorum and decency that I held so dear to my heart and in a rather high-decibel voice, shoved his colourful token into the server’s face and demanded his food. Though it wasn’t his insensitive behaviour or cacophonous voice which distressed me, it was the subsequent sequence of actions that truly horrified me. The server, unperturbed, began assembling his dish. Ignoring me, the epitome of public decency, the person who had been patiently watching him as he clumsily handled the dishes, the server immediately began serving the loudmouth. Never before have I gone through emotions this quickly, seamlessly shifting from absolute fury to profound shock and finally settling for a lingering feeling of despondence and helplessness. I started walking back, lamenting the loss of niceness.

Niceness lived with everyone, a transcendent beam of light with the power to pierce dogma and societal constructs or so, I believed. All it took was some solemn, black text on white paper to make me realise that a majority of Indians still reside in capricious bubbles of taboo and stigma, that were rigid enough to reject niceness. On one such fateful day, I was listlessly turning the pages of the newspaper, when I came across a rather disturbing article, detailing the extremely public humiliation of a teenage girl in India. Strolling about in the city, she, unexpectedly, got her period and hence, a red stain on her dress. With intense discomfiture and profound terror written on her face, she begins walking fast in search of a toilet notwithstanding the pathetic and deplorable state of sanitation in India. As she walks, hordes of men start pointing and cracking jokes around her. Much like those inhuman humans who film victims of accidents rather than helping them. These men, with their inherent chauvinism and a morphed sense of masculinity, felt the compelling need to publicly pander to the toxic institution of patriarchy. Menstruation is such a taboo topic in India that just saying the word will invite scornful glances from all humans around you. Nevertheless, the least someone would have expected from a fellow human was an iota of niceness, something as basic as lending a jacket or guiding her to the nearest toilet. And here is where niceness passed away, writhing in agony and utter torment, riddled with the bullets that we, humans, fired at it, as its last moments passed in a fiery gorge of anguish.

I know it’s the norm to narrate funny anecdotes at a funeral and believe me, if I had anything even remotely resembling that, I would do so. The fact of the matter is we didn’t deserve niceness, much like we don’t deserve a lot of things that we have. Niceness was a god among us mortals, whose genial warmth and compelling kindness were so profound that they exist with us even after it has passed away. Off you go, my reader, bask in the afterglow of niceness, while you still can, as I lament its loss.

meta_description: As humankind heads into a precarious future, it has borne witness to the gradual perishment of a primordial emotion, niceness. Cast aside, niceness succumbed to the pernicious school of thought which mistook it for cowardice and timidity. Read on, as Angad Sethi, 2nd Year, COE, delivers a heartfelt eulogy for one of mankind’s oldest companions.

title: Why is Feminism Widely Misunderstood?
biliner: Feminists do not abhor men, and, for what it’s worth, not all men deserve the scorn or lack of space that they’re given. Gehna Sharma, 3rd Year, BAE writes about some common misconceptions about feminism.
body:
Illustration credits: Dhruv Vyas

Feminists do not abhor men, and, for what it’s worth, not all men deserve the scorn or lack of space that they’re given. Gehna Sharma, 3rd Year, BAE writes about some common misconceptions about feminism.

Feminist ideology is, more often than not, misunderstood, and opinions on its status quo seem polarised. Its broad objective is to attain political, social and economic equality for women; however, there is confusion surrounding its meaning and scope stemming from misconception and misuse. Feminists are often accused of being fuelled by anger and a desire to subdue; and consequently, some ‘extreme’ feminists are often labelled as a ‘feminazi’ or a ‘pseudofeminist’. While in reality, not all men are here to patronise, and not all of us understand feminism for what it truly is. 

Human beings as a species have a proclivity for exercising dominion. Patriarchy is one such example of systematic oppression that can only thrive as long as the weaker are held subject to it. In its essence, feminism strives to bring all genders in conjunction to create a safe space where each individual feels respected while being given the same opportunities as the rest. As opposed to certain beliefs of a marginal group of people about completely shifting the concentration of power away from men and into the hands of women under the banner of feminism. Feminists rally for gender equality, and the first step in attaining equality is empowering oppressed women. Those who vouch for gender equality have iterated that feminism is not about putting women on a pedestal. It's about understanding others' struggles and giving them credit where it is due while upholding the integrity of each individual.

Millions of women continue to face atrocities by not just men but also other women and little attention is paid to their misery due to their circumstances or lack of support or both. However, we need to push the narrative forward that men’s issues aren’t any less important than women’s, especially vulnerable men who are subjected to brutality and are exploited relentlessly with little protection and become even more hapless from the lack of public admissibility and reporting of such issues. 

An increasing number of people believe that feminists are here to radicalise the movement by threatening the equilibrium. They’re under the mistaken impression that feminists are determined to put women above everyone else, disregarding the rights and merit of men. One cannot deny that the misuse of any ideology to the benefit of one gender is prevalent. People in the past have used it and will continue to do so to justify actions and behaviour which are otherwise questionable. Both men and women have, at some point, been biased towards their sex either consciously or subconsciously. But, to be there for each other by including men in the conversation and not letting women get the benefit of the doubt every single time under the pretext of Feminism is a topic that needs to be given the center stage amidst all the rubbishing of feminist claims as male-biased and misconception of their objectives as those aiming at the vilification of all men. 

Feminists do not wish to denigrate men, and not all men deserve the scorn or lack of space that they’re given for what it’s worth. To feel a sense of belonging and inclusion both men and women collectively need to persevere for instating gender parity.

title: "Wake up India, they're dead"
biliner: By Pratiksha Pradhan, 2nd Year, ECE
body:
"Wake up India, she's dead," said the headline of a newspaper, on 29th December, 2012. This piece of news set in action a long list of events to the path of justice, the outcome for which we finally get to witness 7 years later on 20th March, 2020. 

Jyoti Singh, Priyanka Reddy, Asifa- why do we know these names? Unfortunately, not because they worked hard and went on to fulfil their aspirations (which they were fully capable of doing) and made a significant impact in society, but because they were robbed of this very opportunity by being the victims of some of the most gruesome rapes that shook this country. These names aren't known to us because of what they did for us, but because of the gross injustice they had to go through. 

Everyone's heard of the statistics but of course, no one remembers them- they're just a bunch of women reduced to numbers through the trauma they go through. But still, let's take a look. Figures from the National Crime Records Bureau show that 33,977 cases of rape were registered in 2018 - that's an average of 93 cases a day. The victim could be a six-month-old or a senior citizen, there's no discrimination here. And these are just rape cases. Registered rape cases. We still have thousands of unregistered cases, hundreds of brides murdered for dowry, and a multitude of incidents of marital rape. 

Every time there is some horrific incident like this, it's all over national television, in the newspapers, in our regular conversations- it's all anyone talks about. There are protests and rallies and furious people on the streets- for about a week. But then it all simmers down, people return to their daily lives, and it's the women who continue to live on with the residual fear of the gruesome incident that just occurred, thinking to themselves, "That could've been me" or "That could be me next." 

In the past few years, Asha Devi, the mother of the victim in the Nirbhaya gang-rape case, has become the face of the fight that stems from the frustration many Indians face due to an incompetent system which fails victims of some of the worst crimes. The hanging of the rapists is a huge win for her. Her patience and perseverance are commendable. Not only was she able to ensure justice, even though delayed, for her daughter, she fought long and hard to ensure that this historic day would come- the day women across the country feel safer. So that the loved ones of the girls in this country can heave a sigh of relief at the fact that there are people out there fighting hard to make this country a safer place for women. At least the barbarians out there will think twice before committing such heinous crimes. All this was possible despite the delay tactics implemented by the convicts and their lawyer till well into the morning of the execution day, mere hours before the set time for execution. But amidst the celebration of this feat, an important question arises- Does this hanging actually make India a safer place for women? The answer to that would easily be a no. 

Because punishments like the death penalty, no matter how harsh, are not effective enough deterrents. The only solution to this, as we all know, is a drastic change in the collective mindset 
of people living in this society that treats women like property. But in a country like India where people are so set in their ways, it'll be a while for such a change to be fully implemented. Until that happens, how do we ensure the safety of half the population of India? By doing what we've always done- imposing restrictions? 

According to the International Labour Organization, in developing countries, the lack of safe and accessible transportation is the most challenging factor for working women since too often, women risk facing harassment and even sexual assault on their daily commute. So, what do women do next to try and protect themselves? Give up on opportunities at work that demand them to stay back late because of safety reasons, thereby, restricting their career growth. What do government educational institutions do to ensure that their students are protected and no incident of this sort occurs when the female students are under their watch? Impose unrealistic rules and set a curfew so that the female students are confined to their rooms, again, restricting them. What do our parents do to ensure that their girls are safe and unharmed? Impose restrictions- ones that apply only to the girls of the households- restricting their freedom yet again. Because of course, "Who's going to harm the girls on the streets when there are none, right?" 

What we, India's women, want is less of political agenda, cosmetic outrage, and empty promises. What we want is to remove loopholes in the system so that no one has to go through such uncalled-for trauma. Writing some strongly-worded article or posting on social media doesn't make matters better either, these are mere outlets for those of us who're helpless, those of us stuck in their homes after 8 p.m. because their parents are too scared to let them out after that, to make our voices heard. But maybe someday, someone, somewhere will hear and pay heed to these voices. Someday, this broken system of ours will be fixed. Someday, we'll get justice- hot and fresh- not 7 long years later. These crimes may not stop entirely but when they happen, someday we'll see in our newspapers, "Wake up India, they're dead". Because this one hanging might not solve all our problems, but it sure as hell lit a fire that's not dying down anytime soon.

title: Vice Chancellor's Interview | Administrative Decisions Amid COVID-19
biliner: With the University closed due to the outbreak of COVID-19, there were a lot of doubts and queries regarding the semester schedule, end-semester exams, internships and placements. DTU Times interviewed Prof. Yogesh Singh, Hon’ble Vice Chancellor, to gain clarity on some of these questions.
body:
With the University closed due to the outbreak of COVID-19, there were a lot of doubts and queries regarding the semester schedule, end-semester exams, internships and placements. DTU Times interviewed Prof. Yogesh Singh, Hon’ble Vice Chancellor, to gain clarity on some of these questions.

What is the current update on the reopening of the university? Is there a timeline that the administration has in mind?

We really do not know when the university will open, nobody does. It will depend on a number of factors. A number of decisions have been taken, but when it comes to the opening of the university, it depends upon many elements and we really do not know.

As of today, we have taken a number of decisions. Firstly, theory classes will be completed by 30 April. We have requested teachers to organise practical classes online or using simulation if possible, so wherever possible, we would like to organise practicals online. If it isn’t in some cases, we are looking for alternative ways. Secondly, we are in the process of framing guidelines for evaluation. If the university opens this month, there won’t be a problem; we will be able to make up a lot of ground. But if it doesn’t, we have to look at the possibility of online examinations or evaluation of courses. So, we are working on that, based on international guidelines and what top universities of the world are doing. We are in discussion with such universities also. Within a week, we will have some guidelines for our teachers. So, those who are in the final year and pre-final year don’t have to worry about this; we will conduct their examinations online.

In case the closure of the university is extended, is there a plan to extend the semester up to a certain date?

Taking advantage of technology, if we are able to finish theory by 30 April, the only question that remains is that of practicals and projects. We have requested our teachers to give online projects to students. We do not want to extend the semester for final and pre-final year students. For first and second year students, we have not taken a decision as of today. Their classes will be over, for practicals some arrangements will be made online, and then offline when the university reopens. Everything depends on the date of reopening of the university. Students should not worry about this, we are taking care of everything, and all engineering and management final year students will get their degree on time.

Is the university providing financial support to the mess and sanitation workers, who are the first ones to get affected due to lockdown?

We have released salaries to everyone, including those employed through outsourced agencies. If there are some construction workers in DTU, we have made arrangements for them to collect food from the hostels.

A number of final year B.Tech. and M.Tech. projects, as well as PhD research, would’ve included significant experimental or computational work which is not possible now, causing projects to be delayed or possibly not be completed on time. Have there been any decisions regarding project evaluation?

We have requested all HoDs to look into other possibilities, for example, conducting viva voce online in which the students give a presentation followed by questions. We understand difficulties regarding experimentation; it is very difficult to conduct experiments in such a situation. We have entrusted HoDs and faculty with evaluation in their respective departments, and they will certainly find a way.

The grading of bachelors and masters projects was supposed to be directly associated with conference or journal publication. However, a number of conferences have been cancelled and journal reviewing has been suspended. Has there been any thought regarding relaxing the grading guidelines?

There is a significant number of students facing this problem, so we will look into this. We understand the difficulties, most conferences have been cancelled and some have been converted into online conferences. These are difficult times and special care must be taken, so we will explore all possibilities in the interest of our students. I request all students of Delhi Technological University to not worry, we all are with you, we understand everything, and we will take all steps under the limitations of rules and regulations to finish your semester on time, so we can start the next semester on time as well. Every alternate day, we are conducting meetings with HoDs and Deans, and HoDs are also taking regular meetings with faculty online. The faculty members take classes and are hence in contact with the students. There is no need to worry; the situation is not in our hands but from the university's side, we are taking appropriate steps to minimise damage wherever possible. We are very open to considering all suggestions from students as well.

A week ago, AICTE issued a notice instructing all the affiliated institutes not to allow their students to go for internships outside their institutes. A lot of pre-final year students had secured internships with top-tier companies. Will the university allow them to pursue these?

If the country is in lockdown, the only type of internship that is possible will be online. If the situation eases out, the university will allow students to pursue internships.

All international research internships stand cancelled for this summer. Does the university plan to compensate students for this through some research work in-house?

This is very doable, and we will take steps to ensure this once the situation is more clear in a week or so.

When the institute opens, there will be a large influx of students and social distancing will be difficult to maintain. How is the university preparing to stem the spread of disease?

Decisions to the effect will be taken once we know the day of reopening. As of today, we are carrying out fumigation every day in the University, since a number of faculty members and a few hostelers still live on campus. We have also provided sanitisers all around campus.

Do you have any message for the students who might be anxious due to the current situation?

I assure all students that they need not worry. Study online and prepare for your examinations. If the need arises, we will conduct examinations online and give all final year students their degree on time. We will keep on taking decisions in the interest of the students, and are conducting regular meetings online. I request all students to take care of their health and adhere to guidelines, because coronavirus is a really serious pandemic. We know nothing about it and in our lifetimes, we haven't seen anything of this sort. However, do not worry, we are taking steps and will be able to address many issues.

title: Socialism: Equalizer or Economic Disaster?
biliner: Fed up with increasing income disparity and crony capitalism, a significant number of young voters are increasingly turning towards socialism as a means to iron out the kinks in the economic system. But is socialism really all that noble?  Ananya Kapoor, 1st year, EE analyses why socialism might not be the saviour it is often projected to be.
body:
Illustration credits: Ikshvaku Shyam

Fed up with increasing income disparity and crony capitalism, a significant number of young voters are increasingly turning towards socialism as a means to iron out the kinks in the economic system. But is socialism really all that noble? Ananya Kapoor, 1st year, EE analyses why socialism might not be the saviour it is often projected to be.

As the United States of America elects its 46th President in November this year, there is one term - ‘democratic socialism’ - which has popped up in election-related discourse quite frequently.

Democratic socialism, as popularised by Senator Bernie Sanders, essentially advocates for a socialist economy working alongside a democratic political system of government. But what exactly is a socialist economy? In simple terms, a socialist economy is one which works by ceding the control of production and distribution of goods and services to the government. In turn, the government ensures an equal distribution of wealth and opportunities to all strata of society.

On paper, a socialist society seems to be nothing less than a utopia built on the admirable principles of equality and economic justice. But if the loss of Bernie Sanders to Joe Biden is any indication, a significant chunk of the electorate still doesn’t seem to be warming up to its ideals. Why is this so? Why would people reject a system that seemingly benefits all?

The primary reason for this mistrust lies in socialism’s innate belief that the government knows what is right for its citizens rather than the citizens themselves. Command economies, a permanent fixture of the socialist model, are a good example of this ideology. In a typical command economy, the state imposes checks on investment and production and takes ownership of all major industries, eliminating all competition from the private sector. The motivations behind this kind of economic system appear to be quite honourable, as it aims to meet the demand for all sorts of goods and not just profitable ones. It also checks profiteering by putting a ceiling on prices. Unfortunately, in the pursuit of these noble goals, this system ultimately ends up hurting the consumer by allowing monopolisation of industry and shortage of goods. An example of the disaster of nationalisation is the country of Venezuela which currently faces huge food shortages, blackouts, and even lack of medicines due to the bureaucratic control of all major industries instituted by former president Hugo Chavez and his successor Nicolas Maduro.

Another aspect of socialism which has generated widespread resentment is higher taxation for the rich. Advocates of socialism often try to counter this sentiment by arguing that  redistribution of wealth is the only way to create an economically homogeneous society. Though this approach appears to be prudent from a moral standpoint, it actually possesses many flaws, the foremost being that higher tax rates empower the state at the cost of the citizens by decreasing their economic freedom, something which goes against the very ethics of democracy. Higher taxes are also perceived as being hostile to entrepreneurs, who often outsource their businesses to other countries, leading to a loss in revenue. Economies with higher tax rates also see more cases of tax evasion as individuals scramble to use unethical means to avoid incurring the cost of taxation. However, the most worrying aspect of higher taxes is by far the fact that the socialist model almost always diverts them into populist measures like welfare schemes and subsidies, which can prove to be disastrous for economic growth.

At this point, the reader may wonder what exactly is wrong with welfare schemes. Aren’t they supposed to alleviate financial distress? The answer to this is that welfare schemes do alleviate financial distress - but only temporarily. In the long run, they lead to economic ruin. Let us see how.

In a typical welfare state, the government provides financial assistance to all people who are unemployed or earning below a certain threshold. In countries where a large chunk of the population lives in poverty, this requires a significant amount of financial investment which often comes from slashing the resources allocated to upcoming industries. As a result, the industrial sector fails to expand. This cuts down future employment opportunities and slows down the production of tools and machines. Ultimately, a stage is reached when a large section of the populace remains unemployed and depends on the state for subsistence, leading to increased deficits. The country also remains technologically backward. 

Perhaps the best example of a country exhibiting all the above trappings of socialism and none of the benefits is our very own - India. The history of socialism in India dates back to the Independence era when its ideology was aggressively championed by the stalwarts of the Indian National Congress, including Jawaharlal Nehru, who envisioned India as an ideal socialist republic. The government takeover of major industries and banks in the 1950s and 1960s was a major step towards the fulfilment of this agenda, and the blocking of foreign investment further consolidated the country’s position as a socialist state. A plethora of welfare schemes was also incorporated over the years, and income tax remained high, peaking at 97.75% during the 1970s.

Based on the promises of card-carrying socialists, by now, India should have emerged as a poverty-free nation with efficient industries and employment for all. But the reverse seems to have happened. Unemployment remains high, poverty refuses to release its grip on the nation, and state-owned enterprises have turned into bloated, non-performing assets. The high taxes which were inveigled out of the middle class have been funnelled into fiscally irresponsible welfare schemes, and the condition of state-run schools and hospitals remains as pitiful as ever. The only improvement this country has seen over the past few years has been a result of liberalisation and foreign investment.

So where does this leave us with regards to our original question? Does increasing income inequality warrant a comeback of the old socialist model? If we go by historical precedent, the answer would be an emphatic ‘no’. The list of failed socialist states is simply too long to ignore and acts as a damning indictment against socialism’s impracticality. It is high time we acknowledge this fact and move away from socialism’s destructive policies, otherwise the consequences of our naïvete could prove to be extremely dire.

The history of socialism in India dates back to the Independence era when its ideology was aggressively championed by the stalwarts of the Indian National Congress, including Jawaharlal Nehru, who envisioned India as an ideal socialist republic. The government takeover of major industries and banks in the 1950s and 1960s  was a major step towards the fulfillment of this agenda and the blocking of foreign investment further consolidated the country’s position as a socialist state. A plethora of welfare schemes were also incorporated over the years and income tax remained high, peaking at 97.75% during the1970s.

Based on the promises of card-carrying socialists, by now, India should have emerged as a poverty free nation with efficient industries and employment for all. But the reverse seems to have happened. Unemployment remains high, poverty refuses to release its grip on the nation and state owned enterprises have turned into bloated, non-performing assets. The high taxes which were inveigled out of the middle class, have been funneled into fiscally irresponsible welfare schemes and the condition of state run schools and hospitals remains as pitiful as ever.The only improvement this country has seen over the past few years has been a result of liberalization and foreign investment.

 So where does this leave us with regards to our original question? Does increasing income inequality warrant a comeback of the old socialist model? If we go by historical precedent, the answer would be an emphatic ‘no’. The  list of failed socialist states is simply too long to ignore and acts as a damning indictment against socialism’s impracticality. It is high time we acknowledge this fact and move away from socialism’s destructive policies, otherwise the consequences of our naïvete could prove to be extremely dire.

title: Interview | Prashant Kumar, Gail Limited
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Prashant Kumar, EE, Class of 2020, who got placed at Gail Limited, as a
body:
DTU Times interviewed Prashant Kumar, EE, Class of 2020, who got placed at Gail Limited, as a

How is the recruitment process for PSUs like GAIL different from that of other companies, and what was your preparation strategy for the placement season?

The recruitment process of PSUs is quite different from that of the other companies. PSUs don't conduct online aptitude tests to shortlist students for the interviews; they consider the academic performance of the students and their resumes. The shortlisted students have to appear for a GD round followed by personal interviews based on which the final selections are made.

I focused on improving my aptitude skills and worked on the subjects related to the job profiles of the companies I was aiming for. For the technical interview preparation, I worked hard on core subjects, especially which were related to my projects and internships. 

How important a part did the academic curriculum of your course play for you in the process, and to what extent does one's CGPA matter?

Our academic curriculum includes all the subject matter and knowledge that is essential to crack the placement tests and the interviews of core companies. Therefore, studying and learning my core subjects played a vital role in my selection. When it comes to CGPA, it is crucial to maintain a decent score because the CGPA cut off for most of the core companies range from 7.5 to 8.5. Sometimes CGPA becomes a decisive factor in the interview process and can eventually affect the selection of the candidate. Students who are up for PSUs are required to maintain their CGPA at least 9.0 to get shortlisted for the interview.

Was getting a good job at a PSU/core company always a part of the plan or were/are there other options you had/have in mind? If yes, which ones?

I never had any other plans other than securing a placement at a core company.

Were you part of any society or tech team in our college? How major a role do you think these play if someone is aiming for a core job?

I never joined any society or tech team because as a day scholar it was difficult for me to find balance between my academics and the society work. However, if someone does get into a good society or tech team, it would definitely help enhance his/her practical knowledge and provide him/her with good exposure to innovative ideas which would work as an added advantage over other candidates during the placement process.

What are your views on the increasing shift of interest among students to get into consulting/analytics domain rather than going for a core/technical job?

In general, the companies in the consulting/analytics domain pay well compared to core companies and relatively have a higher number of vacancies. In my opinion, these are the two main reasons that have caused this shift in interest among students.

How would you suggest your juniors with similar interests as yours or those seeking employment in PSUs to go about their college journey?

There could be many pieces of advice in this regard but one of the most important necessities is 'consistency'. All those who want to secure good core jobs should learn the importance of consistency. When you learn engineering concepts and techniques in your curriculum, you must work diligently to get in-depth knowledge of the subject. Always keep on revising the concepts because if you do a tough job regularly it becomes a habit and then eventually, you begin finding it easy. Persistent learning will help you to build strong fundamentals.

Always remember that 

"Energy can neither be created nor be destroyed"

, so whatever effort you put in today will not be wasted and will come back to you tomorrow for sure.

title: Interview | Ankush Mangla, AIR 2, ESE 2019
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Ankush Mangla, ECE, Class of 2019, who secured AIR 2 in Engineering Services Exam (ESE-2019), and is currently an ADST Grade Engineer.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Ankush Mangla, ECE, Class of 2019, who secured AIR 2 in Engineering Services Exam (ESE-2019), and is currently an ADST Grade Engineer.

Can you walk us through the whole process of the interview, from the IES exam to getting posted?

The IES exam is a 3-tier exam combining- the prelims, mains, followed by an interview. One can appear for the mains only after clearing the prelims. The interview focuses more on the current affairs and questions related to one’s personality. They give several case studies regarding social issues, and there is no scope of bluffing.

After clearing the interview, there is a training process of 78 weeks in which you are required to travel across the country. Currently, my joining date has been postponed due to the prevailing circumstances. 

Did you focus solely on these competitive exams or you prepared for the campus placements as well?

In my first year, I wanted to pursue post-graduation from abroad. However, I got an internship in my 2nd year with Samsung and then a PPO as well. It was then that I realised I didn’t want to work in a private sector firm. I wanted to pursue a career in government service. Consequently, I started preparing for the Engineering Services Exam and casually appeared for my first attempt with little hopes. I was lucky enough to have fared well in my initial attempt.

When did you start preparing for this exam, and why did you prefer IES over other civil services?

I wasn’t regular in my coaching classes, and my attendance fluctuated. I had to miss four months of classes due to my internship. I began preparing on my own. I used to study for 10- 12 hours on the weekend. I believe that self-study played a crucial role in my journey. 

Honestly, the idea of becoming an IES officer hadn’t crossed my mind. After the end of the third year, I was truly motivated to pursue civil services. Being an engineering job, it involved a lot of technical aspects along with the management part. It has a very dynamic approach, and every day you are faced with new challenges to overcome. You can even switch to other civil services later if you wish. It is flexible in that aspect.

How much do projects and internships matter when appearing for this exam?

They don’t matter that much in the case of engineering services. But being a fresher, that is, appearing for the exam right after college and reaching till the final round gives you an edge over others and fetches you more marks. But at times they do ask about the projects and internships. So, they do hold some importance in the interview round.

What kept you motivated throughout the journey?

I would say I was not motivated initially. Since I had got the PPO, so there wasn’t any pressure on me. After September, there was nothing to do, and I had a lot of free time in the final year. So I decided to prepare casually for it, and I cleared the prelims. It was then I decided to study hard for the next round. Maybe clearing the prelims round was the motivation.

What advice would you like to give to fellow students who aspire to pursue civil services?

I feel that one should definitely have a backup option. Always prepare for the campus placements as well. When one is in college, there isn’t much pressure of clearing an exam, but once you enter the corporate field, it becomes difficult to manage the job as well as the preparation. So, one should judiciously utilise the free time available in college. The core mantra is to be motivated throughout the process. One should always have self-confidence and belief. There are ample opportunities and courses available on the internet. Keep a limited number of sources that you refer to, and revise multiple times to have a better understanding of the topic.

title: "Dard -e -Dil, Dard -e -Jigar"
biliner: Read on as Zara Khan, Student Head pens down a tribute to the legendary Rishi Kapoor on his untimely demise.
body:
The 70’s and 80’s Bollywood was known for action, the Angry Young Man and the ever so stylish bell-bottoms. It was also known for melodious tunes, romance, and comedy, all of which had one person in common - Rishi Kapoor. 

He shot to fame with Bobby (1973), a love story which subsequently set his career with similar romantic roles. Coming from a highly respected Bollywood family, he had the additional challenge of proving his individuality which he duly did through his charming looks, versatile acting and his widely acknowledged affable persona.

“Acting was in my blood and there was simply no escaping it,” Kapoor wrote in his autobiography Khullam Khulla. Having spent his childhood on film sets surrounded by the film fraternity, there was nothing else that he wanted to do more than acting. 

The manner in which he emoted the feelings of love and betrayal in Chandni or the humour and joy in Amar Akbar Anthony is unparalleled. While he played an incurable romantic in his heydays, he took on a diverse range of roles in the latter half of his career. From Akbar Illahabadi, Rauf Lala, Mr. Joseph Furtado to Veer Singh, Santosh Duggal, and Murad Ali Mohammed. 

Most actors phase out in their twilight, but Rishi Kapoor fully embraced the changes and took on roles that added overwhelmingly to his illustrious legacy. He played a rogue don in D-Day alongside the brilliant Irrfan Khan and he also brought to life a disgraced lawyer fighting for his family’s honour in Mulk directed by the effervescent Anubhav Sinha, there is no doubt in saying that he did complete justice to all the characters that came his way. 

“Whatever the quality or outcome of the project, Kapoor’s output was unwaveringly steady and dependable, the shield of trust that came free with a movie ticket.” - Scroll.In

Apart from his identity as a superstar, he was well known for his bon vivant, his exuberant personality and witty remarks. A complete family man, Chintu Kapoor’s on screen and off screen chemistry with wife and co-star, Neetu Singh has always been a spectacle to behold. 

In the past few years, he had become an avid Twitter user and his camaraderie with his co-stars and fans was well documented. He never shied away from speaking his mind which was sometimes curt but never malicious. 

A day after the loss of Irrfan Khan, Rishi Kapoor’s demise came as a huge shock to everyone who knew him. The film industry has lost a gem who will live on through his work which will continue to make us laugh and fall in love with life.

title: A Nawab's Legacy
biliner: At the end of one’s life, all there’s left to ask is how much did one take from this world and how much did one give back to it. Read on, as Ishaan Gupta, 2nd year, ME, pays a tribute to one of the most visionary actors of our time.
body:
Illustration: Sourajit Bhattacharjee

Artwork: Shanal Bhele

At the end of one’s life, all there’s left to ask is how much did one take from this world and how much did one give back to it.

The long-standing debate on the separation of art and the artist is a glaringly accurate critique of a world where artists are pardoned for their monstrous behaviour depending on the work they’ve done in their fields. But then, there are always some performers who make the entire debate, the entire premise feel debased by the simple act of living their own opinion. Irrfan Khan was one such man. 

Right off the bat, Bollywood is not an easy industry to be a part of. It’s rampant with nepotism, rigged film awards and the occasional PR stunts shrouded as celebrity feuds. The institution can very well be compared to a circus as it makes its performers walk on the tightrope of perfection in front of the audience, i.e. us. Amidst this process, it's exceptionally hard to retain professional dignity, and one’s personal responsibility to their art. Irrfan Khan was one of the few actors of his time who recognised this very early on. Instead of surrendering into the way things were, he took the decision to stay true to his work, his viewers and most importantly, himself. Fortunately, he exercised his power to sway the Indian audience towards real emotion, beauty, and grit; that is the true cinema. 

“I can't think of a more pathetic situation for an actor than to do a film and not connect to it. And I pray to God that I never face that situation.” 

He used to frequently express his grief over the absence of a culture of realistic acting in India. Over the years, he felt that one of the biggest disadvantages of the commercialisation of movies was the betrayal of his definition of what the word meant to him. He felt that a movie must be emotionally and intellectually engaging; he felt that a lesser and lesser number of movies did that over the years. This belief of his can be seen throughout his vivid career, which redefined the meaning of versatility when it came to Indian cinema. 

“You cannot reduce the power of story with the tag of money because it's not a share market. So you must know the seriousness of the power of storytelling.”

Be it an aesthetic marvel as Maqbool, a critically acclaimed gem as The Lunchbox or a heartwarmingly quirky journey as Puzzle; Irrfan Khan had a rare quality that helped him serve up to all his roles perfectly. His exceptional method acting was a result of his complete sacrifice of the self for the discovery of his character’s mental state. Because of his flawless technique and exceptional hard work, he could always induce a special feeling among his audience. One could watch him in a light-hearted comedy as Blackmail or along with Tom Hanks in Inferno and still feel that he belonged in that frame. In hindsight, it is difficult to fathom how one man can play both, a former puzzle tournament champion in one movie and a simple barber/family man in another.  

With time, his vision, humility and self-cultivated charm of a Nawab led him down a path of critical acclaim internationally. He was one of the very few Indian actors who regularly represented India in Hollywood. Cracking Hollywood is one of the biggest milestones that an Indian actor can achieve in his life. Even though Irrfan Khan had reached this pedestal in his acting career, he stuck to his roots and remained loyal to India’s film making. One such act of his was rejecting an opportunity to work alongside Christopher Nolan for Interstellar back when he was shooting The Lunchbox. 

The details of his roles, his methods of acting are as astounding as they are unending. However, the tale of his life far exceeds the plot of any movie he has partaken in. The biggest role in any man’s life, actors included, is the one he plays from the moment he’s cluelessly dropped onto the world. As hard as it is to be a good actor - to be the epitome of retaining meaning into an industry that doesn’t appreciate it enough - it’s significantly harder to be a good person. To give yourself into your work, your discipline and yet not surrender your humanity in a culture that rewards it, is the mark of what makes his legacy as authentic as it is.
