title: Editorial | Dear Class of 2020
biliner: In a heartfelt open letter, Shivam Jha, Editor-in-Chief, attempts to construe the myriad of emotions associated with graduating at the time of a pandemic.
body:
Dear Class of 2020,

My calendar serves as a bleak reminder that just over a month ago we were making plans for the ‘lasts’ that we have to tick off the list before the semester ends, and now we don’t even know when we will meet next. Despite your best efforts to optimistically sugarcoat the heartache, I suppose by now most of us have come to terms with the harsh reality that this year, there will be no batch photoday, no week-long farewell, no last exam shenanigans and all the paraphernalia in between as leave without a flurry of emotional goodbyes, or teary eyed last photographs.

When we are graduating in such a numerically balanced year, it had to be particularly prolific after all.

For the past four years, most of us had pictured this exact moment, and even passenger-ed with our seniors who enthusiastically exalted about the last semester being objectively the best time of your life. All of us had mentally rehearsed the unfolding of the events of the last month, but perhaps your last midsem ended up being your last day in college, and your quixotic Goa trip probably never happened.

But what we do have with us, is a far greater appreciation and gratitude for the time we spent here. Regardless of this cold, unceremonious ending, our college years together have been nothing short of a dream — a dream full of late nights suffocated with haphazard revisions, loud nights immersed in indie music from someone’s borrowed bluetooth speakers in the hostel, intoxicated night(out)s drowning in the hysterical laughter over the same old joke somewhere on the streets of Delhi - nights that are now stories worth commemorating for years.

It seems like forever and a half ago when after the initial apprehension of first year, we discovered how this place carries an intrinsic charm with herself. Over time, things unravel like a montage of orchestrated chaos as she engulfs you in and marinates herself within you; slowly, and then all at once. 

Au contraire, these days -  they seem slowly sinking, wishfully reminiscent of the ones when every morning was an avenue into working with excited accountability, every day was a quest to quench the tireless thirst for fresh experiences and every night soaked in a gratifying slumber.

But now that anticipatory celebration is gone with no sight of closure, instead of receiving the space we need to overcome this tragedy, we’re pressured to fill our time with activity and feel guilty about our self-pity. We will have enough time to read books, make music, listen to podcasts, try cooking, and be better, but today — today it’s okay to grieve. And even though we may have to maintain six feet of social distance between us even after this ends, let’s allow each other more social space to grieve in the way we each need to.

Somewhere between the briefly comforting messages of ‘We are all in this together’, we stumble upon some sporadic resilience; resilience which has been permeated with the proficiency in navigating through the crowd at Amul to find your friends; or accentuated by the perseverance perfected via 8-hour FIFA sessions followed by sleeping at the wake of sunrise; or ingrained through the patience cultivated while waiting for Chandan’s maggi; or the resilience which has been soaked in you while consuming the misery sprinkled in the mess food.

So, dear class of 2020, it has been nothing short of an honour learning and growing with all of you. In these past years, I have found the most passionate and ambitious people. Dreamers and doers. People who will never stop fighting for what they believe in. 

In the distant future, we would be remembered as the ones who faced unprecedented challenges right before stepping into the ‘real world’. Having the infliction of being at the cusp of this inflection point, we will be a part of a new wave of problem solvers who will approach challenges in a radically different manner without taking future opportunities and relationships for granted. 

gam zeh ya’avor - because that’s the only inevitable thing we have as of now to hold on to.

Your fellow batchmate,
Shivam Jha

title: Daikin Europe N.V. | Placement Interview
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Harshit Tanwar, ME, Class of 2020, who got placed at Daikin Europe N.V. as a Development Engineer.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Harshit Tanwar, ME, Class of 2020, who got placed at Daikin Europe N.V. as a Development Engineer.

What motivated you to opt for a career in the field of mechanical engineering?

For me, it is really fascinating to understand how different mechanisms and components work and equally exciting to design them. I enjoyed designing components and applying different concepts of physics and mechanics to day-to-day life.  Therefore, choosing a career in the field of mechanical engineering will provide ample opportunities to utilise my learnings in the company.

How is the placement preparation for core profiles different from that of coding/non-tech roles, and what are some must-have skills for candidates?

Placement preparation for core profiles is similar, in my opinion, to coding/non-tech roles. Preparation for language proficiency, Data interpretation and aptitude are the same in any profile you are looking for. The difference occurs in the technical section where one has to study hard, practice and go through a lot of questions in their respective domain.

Candidate has to be confident and must have excellent communication skills. It makes a huge difference when someone speaks proficiently and confidently at the time of personal interviews or GDs. He/she must go through every word of their resume because it is the only piece of information interviewers have about you before the personal interviews.

Does being a part of a tech team/society provide you with an edge in the process?

It does help to be a part of a tech team/ society. I was the team captain of Deltech Baja, and it has provided me with massive exposure and in-depth knowledge in the field of designing and an all-terrain vehicle. It also taught me to work with and manage a team.

Interviewers at the time of my interview kept on asking questions about the team, what we do, how we do it and different conceptual questions related to the domain they are interested in. If you have been a part of the team, then be prepared for answering questions on the department you were working for.

What are your views regarding the increasing number of students interested in consulting/analyst and non-tech roles rather than pursuing a career in engineering?

In my view, there is an increasing demand in the industry for analyst or other non-tech roles, which has resulted in students being more inclined towards pursuing it as they believe there are more opportunities for the same. But if anyone is focused and determined enough, he can get a placement in core engineering companies too.

How much of a part did the academic curriculum of your course play for you in the placement process and to what extent does one's CGPA matter?

Academic curriculum plays a supporting role in the placement process because oftentimes, a question can directly be asked from the subject that was taught to you. Although in one of my interviews, out of the book questions were asked about ‘HVAC’, something that has never been a part of our curriculum. Therefore, it is necessary to learn and understand concepts that are in depth and often not in the course.

A CGPA above 7 will get you shortlisted in most of the placement rounds of companies. Post this, it is totally up to you, on how well you have prepared for it. A low CGPA will not hinder you much as long as you have skills and knowledge to showcase and defend the reason for your academic performance.

What would you like to say to your juniors who want to pursue a career in the core domain but are demotivated by the lack of placement opportunities in the same?

If you really want to pursue a career in the core domain, then you will definitely find a way to land a placement offer. Do not get demotivated by the lack of core companies visiting the campus since there is always an option of off-campus interviews. The TnP department too, does a lot of hard work in inviting core domain companies. One should always keep trying, believe in one self and never give up.

title: Interview | Madhusudan Bansal, SSB Tri-Service Recommended
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Madhusudan Bansal, AE, Class of 2020, who got recommended for the Indian Army, Navy as well as the Air Force.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Madhusudan Bansal, AE, Class of 2020, who got recommended for the Indian Army, Navy as well as the Air Force.

When did you realise that you wanted to join the Armed Forces after B.Tech. rather than taking the NDA route?

My best friend, Krishna Lohiya, whom I met in my drop year, told me about the comprehensive selection process of SSB when he was conferenced out by the AFSB in 2015. Motivated by that, I took the NDA exam and appeared for the SSB interview at Bhopal in 2016. It was my first exposure to the military. The perfectly maintained lush green lawns, the unspoken discipline that everybody followed. I felt like I belonged there. Meeting boys from Sainik schools, Military colleges and listening to them talk about swimming, adventure sports and horse riding, I was excited to spend the next 4 days with them. I had already started imagining myself learning these activities in the academy. However, I got screened out on Day 1, and then aged out from the NDA entry. 

Over the next 2-3 years I met officers, who were serving or retired from the forces, through my relatives and friends. That gave me a real picture of what the Armed forces were all about; what they offered and what was required to be a part of them. I finally found strong reasons that encouraged me to join the forces- personal growth, adventure, and escaping the monotonous 9 to 5 lifestyle.

What was your preparation strategy for the exam and the SSB Interview?

Having cleared JEE, passing end semesters and aptitude tests at TNP, I think we all have enough strategies to ace any written exam. The real challenge was the SSB, with a selection rate of around 3-5% and many batches having zero selections.

It is said that the first step towards improvement is acceptance. So, I began to observe my behaviour, actions and emotions while trying to keep judgements away. This helped me become more aware of myself and my surroundings. I joined a Toastmasters Club that gave me a platform to speak my mind, working in and leading a team. SSB is not about reading particular books and memorising facts. Their assessment is based on 15 OLQs (Officer Like Qualities). My strategy was to understand their requirements and build those OLQs from within. Everybody has it in them. The trick lies in being able to present them in the right manner.

What was the most challenging aspect of the interview for you? How did you prepare for it?

The SSB is divided into three phases of assessment - Psychological Testing (Manasa), Interview Testing (Vacha) and Group Testing (Karmana). For me, the tricky part was to analyse my psychology and mould my responses in the way they sought in an ideal candidate. Some present their ideas impromptu and believe in spontaneity. I believe in practice, so I strategise accordingly. Writing stories, sentences, practising reactions and self-description was something I made a habit. 

Even after my first recommendation, I continued working on improving the quality of my responses with my other defence aspirant friends. Evaluating each other helped us to identify gaps, come up with better ideas and keep the motivation high. The interviewing officer may even dig into intimate details of your life, including bad habits, girlfriends, biggest mistake, fears, weaknesses, regrets, etc. The best thing about truth is that you don’t have to memorise it. I am not that truthful, to be honest. I prepared for my lies, looked him directly in the eye and told him stories that I had rehearsed to support those lies. My father tells me, “Speak the truth, always. But when you have to lie, do it with confidence”.

How was your overall experience of the 5-day selection process? How did you deal with the pressure involved?

The overall experience depends much on the result. Once you get through, you stop thinking about the mistakes you've made, or the questions you didn't know the answers to. You stop worrying about the parts you messed up. Once you’re in, it becomes a memorable experience. You reminisce the witty answers you gave in the interview, the point in the group discussion that flummoxed everybody. Up until then, it's a lot of pressure, anxiety and mental exhaustion. You force a smile on your face, trying to make everyone like you, especially the assessors and your groupmates. The SSB is like playing a sport. The pressure is part of the process. You can't let it get to your head or reflect on your face. The trick is to smile through it.

What suggestions would you like to convey to other Armed Forces aspirants of DTU?

There is no defined path to crack the SSB. Some don't even prepare for it and get through and then wonder if it's something even worth pursuing. Some wouldn’t clear it in 15 attempts and some may do in their 18th. Though, I have observed that most of the recommended candidates have a similar thought process, similar value system and similar responses to certain situations. Some people just fit in the mould that the armed forces try to match us against.

I would like to say that don’t make cracking SSB the one and only goal of your life. Make the best out of all the opportunities that come your way. Having a solid backup will give you the confidence to face the result. We can't control the medicals anyway. Also, don’t believe anyone blindly, especially blogs over the internet. Find like-minded people and prepare in groups. Try giving constructive feedback to each other. Reach out to your seniors and don’t hesitate to ask for help.

title: Interview | Prajya Sharma, MBA Admits - Stanford & Harvard Business School
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Prajya Sharma, EE, Class of 2015, who received admits for the MBA program from Harvard Business School, Stanford Graduate School of Business, Wharton and Kellogg School of Management.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Prajya Sharma, Electrical Engineering, Class of 2015, who received admits for the MBA program from Harvard Business School, Stanford Graduate School of Business, Wharton (University of Pennsylvania) and Kellogg School of Management (Northwestern University). She has also received the Stanford Reliance Dhirubhai Fellowship, which is awarded to only 2-3 students in the entire country. 

What motivated you to apply for an MBA abroad against studying in India?

Studying in a global business school, especially the top universities in the world has always been my dream. If you see the statistics in any of these business schools- above 40% of their classes have international students and they come from 150 different universities across the globe. Hence, the learning environment is quite progressive. The relationships you make, things you learn about businesses, governments and happenings across the world are quite intriguing. While the education system in India is great, I feel like we lack global exposure.

Despite the shortcomings that we face in the Indian education system, what would you identify as the positive factors while studying in DTU that pushed you towards achieving these goals?

The logical and analytical abilities we develop through our rigorous coursework and the challenging entrance exams and time management. These abilities come in handy wherever you are and not just in applying to B-Schools. It definitely helps in securing a good GMAT score and also in our professional lives. I also felt that studying in a good university like DTU  gives you a great ecosystem - a network of peers who are driven and accomplished  and a launchpad for your career. The progressive environment really eggs you on and pushes one to achieve more. Also while I was at DTU, I got a chance to explore and get involved in research projects, community initiatives etc. that were pivotal in understanding what career I want to pursue and bolstered my B-school application.

You received an on-campus offer from PwC. How did that work experience help you charter your journey?

Yes, I had worked for two and a half years at PwC. I was placed in the risk advisory consulting practices but that was not the profile I wanted. I wanted to work in the Energy and Utilities practice but at that point in time they were very apprehensive about taking girls in that practice. So, I eventually took the risk advisory role and after 8-9 months was able to move to E&U where I worked on renewable energy projects across India and Southeast Asia. My work in E&U built my foundation in the cleantech/renewable energy sector and gave me exposure to international markets and different work streams (policy advisory, business planning) and sub-sectors (solar, wind, hydro) etc. Needless to say, this diverse work experience helped me not only in getting job offers  but also in distinguishing myself in my B-school application.

Pro-tip: Be proactive and seek out opportunities and projects that are diverse, niche and give you a chance to be intrapreneurial and lead initiatives within your team/organization  - this is what I did in PwC. 

How important would you say it is to bag an offer from a reputed firm, if one dreams of making it to Harvard or Stanford?

It is NOT necessary to work in MBBs, other top consulting and IB firms to get into reputed MBA programs; however, starting your career in any top companies from any sector, say Fortune 500s (say Amazon, Microsoft, Exxon Mobil, Chevron, Shell, GE, GS, JP Morgan etc.) and global unicorns such as Airbnb, Uber etc.  will give you an edge. 

My understanding is that since these companies and consulting firms have rigorous recruitment processes, it serves as a checkpoint for the admissions committee - if a candidate was able to qualify for such companies, s/he must be a worthy candidate.

Having said that, I don’t imply that it’s not possible for the people who have not worked in these companies to get through. Look for differentiated work experience and the companies that are doing well in their respective domain - data analytics, fintech, impact consulting etc.. Things have changed now, there are a lot of admitted students who are also coming in with start-up experience. Many admitted students moved from consulting/IB to work in start-ups such as UrbanClap, Ola, Swiggy, Rivigo, 1mg etc. 

Pro-tip: Start your career in a reputed company. After 1-3 year, you can go for second jobs in start-ups, VC/PEs, policy, global  not-for-profits etc. 

How would you say your experience in the social sector, both from Engineers without Borders and WeRise India, helped you in your application? Is volunteering a major chunk of the differentiating factor when it comes to applications?

That’s a good question. The reason why business schools look at extracurriculars is because they want to know how you are as a person outside of work - your value and motivation, and if you are passionate about something to spend time on it after office hours.

I was in my second year when Engineers Without Borders was started by two of our seniors. It was a very low-key operation. The idea behind it was for us to use our engineering skills and design products for community development. 

WeRise is an organization that I started a year out of college to promote gender progressive behaviour among adolescents after having faced gender bias as the only female in the E&U practice at PwC. We’ve conducted gender sensitization and menstrual hygiene workshops for disadvantaged youth in Delhi. Both causes were close to my heart and were backed by a strong rationale/story - i.e. a personal experience/discomfort that led me to drive positive change and that's why it reflected positively on my MBA application. 

A 'cookie-cutter approach' to work for a large-scale NGO or a soup kitchen in hopes of a volunteering certificate does not work. Because it’s neither authentic nor genuine. Don’t volunteer just for the sake of it. Say someone is passionate about photography and s/he has a photography blog, has put up some exhibitions, or has helped out a few social enterprises with a photography project - this itself is a genuine way to showcase impact. Also, prioritize quality over quantity - work for or get involved in 1-2 activities but do it well and create measurable impact. 

You have also worked for Invest India, which is a not-for-profit under the Ministry of Commerce. How would you compare this profile with your job at PwC?

It was a complete shift from my previous profile. After 2.5 years of working in the consulting domain, Invest India offered the perfect opportunity for me to diversify and work at the intersection of investing and public policy. It is an organisation registered under the Ministry of Commerce and offers a startup-like environment to grow. We were a small team of 80 people when I started, and I got an opportunity to lead multiple  initiatives and  work with private and public sector enterprises. 

Would you suggest doing things that specifically tailor one’s profile, or pursue one’s passion and hope that coincidentally it helps with the applications somehow?

I would suggest one to choose a middle ground. Whichever sector/career trajectory you are interested in (consulting, energy, data analytics, investing etc.), find job opportunities in the top few companies in that space. Find accomplished people who are working in that sector and follow their career trajectories as a reference to chart out your own path. 

Don’t be naive and just pick projects that you think might help to build your B-school profile as recruiters and admissions committees will see right through these; be smart about these things. In your career, always seek out international project opportunities, secondments, identify upcoming projects/teams/initiatives and get involved in building it, seek out promotions/increasing work responsibilities to show career progression, find mentors and build strong relations with managers/seniors.

What advice would you give students aspiring to study at top international business schools? 

I would suggest students utilise their time in university judiciously. Work in areas you are interested in and build something out of those experiences - do research projects, get involved in impactful community initiatives, maybe even start your own project/start-up/non profit, research about B-schools, talk to students and alumni and attend admissions events, find opportunities to intern/work remotely with overseas organizations/colleges abroad etc. 

You are never going to have this time again so do something that makes an impact, but don’t neglect your CGPA. Stellar academic performance is very important - graduate with high honors. Also, give your GMAT in 1-2 years after graduating (don’t procrastinate and delay it till the very end) so that you can focus on building your profile and application in the time leading upto the application deadline.

title: Interview | Gul Asnani, MBA Admit- IIMA, Placement- Google India, PPO- Samsung R&D
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Gul Asnani, Computer Engineering, Class of 2020, who received admit for the MBA program from Indian Institute of Management, Ahemdabad. She also received a placement offer from Google India and a pre-placement offer from Samsung R&D Bangalore.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Gul Asnani, Computer Engineering, Class of 2020, who received admit for the MBA program from Indian Institute of Management, Ahemdabad. She also received a placement offer from Google India and a pre-placement offer from Samsung R&D Bangalore.

How did you simultaneously prepare for the placement season and CAT? What was your thought-process while deciding these options?

As I got an early PPO, I was lucky enough to be spared from the placement season. It is always a blessing to get an intern early in the season. The companies which come early give a higher proportion of PPOs, and also have a higher rate of acceptance of PPOs by students. This is, of course, the most ideal scenario. There have been times when I had more than one thing to focus on. Although there were relatively few overlaps, whenever I faced one, I tried to prioritize stuff and take-on one thing at a time. When you have to focus on multiple things and a number of uncertainties attached to your daily routine, it is better to plan flexibly and do whatever comes your way. It was usually not that difficult a task, but it did keep my hands full at times. The intention behind choosing both fields was a result of a dilemma- I wanted a career in one and also wanted to keep the other as a backup.

What was your reaction after every achievement of yours? Did each of these change the definition of success for you?

There's always a gradient to everything. You feel elated the first time, but gradually you realise that it's all too transient to be celebrated that hard. It's because once you get something you wanted, that moment of happiness flies away in a jiffy and things get back to normal. Gradually, you start thinking about the other things you have on your to-do. It makes you realise how elusive success is.

What was the single most valuable habit that you think helped you achieve these laurels?

I worked for everything as much as I could, and judiciously utilise the slightest bit of time. However, working hard is something everyone does; what's even more important is having a positive attitude and a constant belief in oneself– it helps you maintain focus.

Now that you have done such a commendable job of securing prospectus offers, which one are you most drawn towards and why?

I'm yet to figure out exactly, so I guess only time will tell. But yes, there is an inclination towards working for now, as coming back to software after doing an MBA is not possible, which is not the case otherwise.

What was your lowest point while running in the rat-race for placements and entrance exams?

There were quite a few times when it was stressful, but I was lucky enough to have some really amazing people around me to help me get through them. If I have to choose one, it was the time when I was just about to leave for my CAT exam test centre. We had our first end-semester exam the next day, and it had already been quite an eventful week. I was dead tired and broke down thinking of how I wanted that day to be, and how it was turning out to be. I was also thinking of all the gaps in my preparation and how I wanted to do it all again. But again, there were friends in the same situation much stronger than me, pulling me forward.

What all extracurricular activities did you take up during these four years? What role did they play in determining your success?

I was a part of NSS DTU and DTU Times. I received immense love from both the communities, and they really helped me grow as a person in very subtle ways. I got all kinds of exposure- ranging from understanding how things work in an organisation, to how to deal with people and work in harmony. They helped me build an amazing network of really inspiring people, including my juniors, seniors as well as batchmates. Handling responsibilities in such communities helped me believe in myself and played an important role in uplifting my confidence.

What suggestions would you give to juniors who are sitting for internships or placements this year? What is the best way to practice and how should one formulate his or her plan?

Placement and internship seasons are very unpredictable. Your company tests will test your knowledge, whereas the overall process of landing up an opportunity during the season will test your mental strength. Hence, it is important to work on both these skills. Everybody gets what they deserve sooner or later. One needs to be patient. 

Regarding the question of laying out a plan, I would suggest some pointers to keep in mind. It is important to be aware of the kind of preparation required, what is asked in company tests/interviews, resources to study from, platforms to practice on, etc. It is best to seek guidance from your seniors and branch PCs. Work out a plan accordingly with set deadlines. This goes for both tech and non-tech. Decide upon your resources and then practice religiously. If you are a beginner, don't worry; start from scratch, gradually increasing the difficulty level of the problems.

Build a strong resume with good quality projects. If you're worried about your projects, be aware that you still have time, and talk about the kind of projects you should take up with your seniors. Your resume should be well worded, properly indented and presented. Try and get it reviewed by a senior, if possible. It is crucial as your resume speaks volumes about you. Work on the soft skills that'll help you speak about what you know. Soft skills include your way of addressing an interviewer, way of communication, confidence, etc.

Since times are uncertain, try to stay calm and not let the negativity affect your mental health; try not to overthink about the impact of the crisis on your future. Everyone's in the same boat as yours, and the uncertainty might go on for long. In such circumstances, building your skills is all you can do right now, and if you let the crisis play with your mind, you might lose out on productivity. Stay focussed, stay calm!

title: Interview | Varun Jain, Account Director, LinkedIn
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Varun Jain, Account Director, LinkedIn, who conducted a webinar titled, "The Brand YOU". He speaks about his experience and gives insights on how a student can professionally make the most of LinkedIn.
body:
What are some of your insights on making more visually/factually appealing presentations?

The presentation skills of both the approaches are different from each other. The western talent focuses more on the practical skills. The strategy firms, business giants want crisp data, they mainly look for the skill of accommodating multiple data on a single slide. The presentation must be precise, informative, with crystal clear points so that it has a proper story line which one can go about. One can take ideas from presentations of the top consulting firms such as Accenture, BCG etc, and by incorporating their suggestions and ideas one can ace a presentation. 

Professional fields such as Data analysis, Data science is something a lot of students wish to pursue as a career. LinkedIn has numerous people with certificates of data science which somehow saturates the job opportunities. How can people make their profile stand out in order to get through the competition?

There is a stream of people coming up with the same courses but this is how the real talent can be filtered out. The real courses which are actually given weight-age are the courses which have a long duration of 120 hours or so with regular exams so as to test the knowledge of the person.  In order to have an edge over others one should aim for the courses which are real, which makes one test their skills. Posting a certificate on LinkedIn does not make you stand out. Knowledge is the key. One should only post about something he/she is confident about and has a grip over it. One should also emphasize on posting research works and technical projects so as to make one’s LinkedIn profile stand out. Being a part of interesting projects will differentiate oneself from the larger set of audience. If you have relevant coursework and a strong GPA— add it to show what you’ve worked hard for. Adding causes and volunteer experience is a great way to round out your professional identity. Almost half of all hiring managers say they view volunteer experience as equivalent to formal work experience.

What is your take on cold calling especially in today’s scenario where COVID-19 has minimized the job opportunities in all the sectors? Do you feel that there is a change in the job trends now?

The job trends have surely changed due to the current scenario. Job opportunities have been minimized and one should be well versed with technology at this point. I don't feel cold calling is the right approach to reach out to recruiters. One should not diminish their talent and should not fall into the trap of getting a job, one should be thorough with the decision and evaluate it patiently in order to come up with a plan. It is always better to wait rather than hurrying into a decision. I myself waited 3 months before joining a management consultancy because I wanted to be thoroughly equipped  with the best skills be it presentation, excel or advisory. One should exactly know about their passion and be properly aligned with the correct thought process to make one’s growth and productivity efficient. 

Research the profiles of alumni who inspire you and track their LinkedIn timeline to see how they got from the university to where they are now. Don’t be shy. Reach out and ask to hear about their path, advice, tips. One thing to make it more productive is to be polite about it, be professional and exhibit an interest in their interests. Finding a common ground with them would help your message stand out among the dozens of messages they may be getting everyday. Growing your network this way opens up opportunities and shows employers you’ve made an effort

There are a lot of students who don't wish to continue their engineering career and rather go for coding or business consulting related jobs. How can they make their profile stand out considering the fact that their interest and their degrees won’t be showcased in the same alignment? Will it cause any hindrance?

It is a very common scenario that the students don’t find themselves aligned with the course they are pursuing and eventually wish to change their career paths and there is absolutely no problem in doing so. The effort, the skills, the research and the proactive approach is what matters. Companies today hire people from diverse backgrounds. Even if a person is doing Mechanical engineering but has exceptional coding skills, he/she can definitely work for a technical firm irrespective of the branch. One should just be confident in what he/she is doing. 

The optimal number is unique to each person. Include a mix of high level and niche skills and be specific. Get Endorsements -Add skills that your connections can endorse you for and recognize those you’ve worked with on their professional skills. There are over 3 billion endorsements given to date on LinkedIn. Take advantage of the loads of information LI has to offer. Also on company pages you can see who has a job you might like and could follow them. You could also set up job alerts in order to further curate content to your liking. To sum it up, you can use LinkedIn to your advantage only if you learn how to do it by putting in time regularly.

LinkedIn stands out as a popular professional platform. What differentiates LinkedIn and makes it exceptional?

One thing which makes LinkedIn stand out is it’s member driven approach. It keeps people engaged on a professional level. The trends, the statistics, the insights which LinkedIn provides helps an individual as well as an organization to expand their networking. The data and the tools which LinkedIn offers is what binds the family of 690 million people and makes the platform standout. 

If we were to broadly categorize three types of professions, like the split of our subjects we had sciences, commerce and the liberal arts. Is LinkedIn is in any way biased towards any of these disciplines, and how are the experiences of these different disciplines?

In LinkedIn, there isn’t any one stream that dominates. Nowadays, there are more bureaucrats active on LinkedIn, and we have more commerce students and medical students nowadays. The experiences are different, if you are from an engineering background, you are expected to be passionate about something in line with engineering, be it technology or strategy. There are obviously cross links, but as an audience people generally have a mindset approach towards these. Every person wants to fit in different things in their profile and get the edge over others, obviously if you are the last student to get interviewed you need to leave an impact.

A lot of people still get away with the one page resume, but nowadays more people are looking at LinkedIn profiles since it is a standardized format. No one has time to read a 100 CVs, but in LinkedIn you can glance at it and get an idea of their work experience in under a minute. Try to get into groups because they give you exposure to industry professionals that you wouldn’t see otherwise. You can learn about new roles that way. There are many ways for you to share what you know on LinkedIn, and to also learn from others who are sharing their expertise.

In every university, there are people who are at similar levels in terms of knowledge and skills but they aren’t on par in terms of communication skills, how can these students make more out of their degrees and maximize their potential?

Students from underprivileged backgrounds can utilize resources like LinkedIn learning, which are short, self explanatory courses of around 45 minutes teaching these soft skills. How to work on your communication, how to work on a presentation, how to dress up, the life skills which are essential to help people evolve. Back in BITS Pilani when I had a question, I had a doubt in my mind that I should only ask intelligent questions and what the class will think of my question. But I had the notion that any question is a question, that’s why students should learn these skills through these platforms.

Simultaneously, It’s not just about being on LinkedIn, it’s about using it strategically. Show off your talents and get noticed by hiring managers and recruiters. Go deeper with volunteer experiences to demonstrate skills, experience, and personality. Add project samples, such as images, documents and videos of your work. Add your skills and experience, but more importantly show them your unique path and personality.

Do you have any final words from your personal journey for students of our age?

I have a personal target of connecting with 2 new people, and for that I reach out to 10 new people. I don’t always meet the target, but I definitely do work for it. If I want to reach a person, I’ll work towards getting to know him and what he is doing, which panel discussions and conferences he's attending, what articles he's writing etc. Once I get a rough idea, then I have my bullet points on which points I am aligned with. When you approach someone and discuss their work over a course of months, they appreciate your attention to detail towards their work, it helps them know that you’ve been invested in their journey and further sparks an interest in them to be invested in your journey. This will help you establish a bond with them right from the very start. 

You must look at people and see them, not as a professional on LinkedIn but as a fully-rounded person with interests outside the sphere of their professional work environment.

title: On the path to healing
biliner: -Artika Sharma, 3rd year, Environmental Engineering
body:
Remember how you were sitting with your friends having the time of your life and then suddenly  fell quite as the conversation hit a topic or a note you felt uncomfortable dealing with? It’s relatable, right? Well, you’re not alone.

We're all spending every second of every minute of every hour of every day thinking, our thoughts like passengers on a train, each registered fleetingly as it moves past the train station that is our mind. One thought blends into another to give way to another and so on goes the train of thoughts. 

It is easy to seat a few of these thoughts, they fall into place effortlessly because they are called for, reached for, even seeked and are therefore not troublesome. The real trouble arises when we try to accommodate those that never bought a ticket, the thoughts that were uncalled for, that vapourised out of thin air and that we have no idea what to do with.

These thoughts are narcissists, they feel important and so they disrupt and destroy everything else around them. All the well-seated thoughts are yanked off their seats as these 'Mawalis' make place for themselves bullying all other thoughts into submission. And so, when the train stops at our mind's station, they're all we see in all their negative and toxic glory,  these uncalled for thoughts with their lathis and weapons out, prepared to hurt. 

And news flash about our masochist tendencies?  We let them. 

Maybe it is because we're too weak to stand up to them and say no, or maybe because we feel we deserve the hate and the hurt, but we let these thoughts house in our mind, to camp out at the station and stay, like the guests we dislike so much but don’t have the courage to stand up to and say “Leave.” This is where the problem lies. We refuse to acknowledge what's bad, we refuse to heal what's broken, we let it be and we keep pacing ahead in life, carrying the unwanted weight in our minds. 

In our own fancy mental constructs, it is brave to move on. Extremely brave to ignore and escape all that hurts, to not deal with them and walk on in life. And while that works for the less troubling Mawalis that get bored of the inactivity and leave the station in search of more thrill, the real sinister ones are unaffected by this constant motion. We're left with thoughts, issues and emotions we bottled up, that gnaw at our insides constantly, wounding us in the process. They become an unwelcome and untreated part of us. 

Moving on is, thus, too often romanticised for the worse. It is seen as brave to just let go of a matter and keep walking forward and onward and it's true, moving on is good, but only after we've given resolutions a shot. Our ignorance and our tendency to bury our feelings altogether stops us from that. We act as if any signs of weakness are sins and so we hastily put them out of sight, put on a brave face and go on and about with our lives and by doing this very thing, we create our very own demons, or in this context, our Mawalis. 

Resolutions need space, they need time. There is a certain negative image that is associated with not being in motion that needs to be broken. It's completely fine to move on in life and get on with other things but it's also completely fine to stall and take our time. It is completely fine and equally brave to deal with our demons, to drop down our weapons in this war that we wage against life and just sit down for a moment and contemplate even the necessity of this war. 

It's about time we take some time to focus on our healing. Afterall what do you do when you get physically wounded? Do you take some time to treat the wound or do you continue running off like a chicken even if causes you discomfort? 

Life is tough even without these Mawalis' constant interference and so every once in a while, it is fine and even fun to go off the "normal" roads-most-taken and figure ourselves out before we get back in to finally fight off those Mawalis with a strong bollywood hero front. 

That's one important action sequence that can wait to be awesome!
meta_description:
"What do you do when you get wounded? Do you take time to treat the wound or do you start running off like a chicken again even if it causes you discomfort? "

This blogpost is an attempt to break the often romanticised notion of "Moving On".

title: A Bona Fide Star
biliner: “We should never forget the inevitable, as we will lose everything eventually. So why fret over any kind of security? The idea is to just fly and experience it all while it lasts.” N.Krithika, 1st year, ENE, pens down a eulogy to one of the most talented and well-loved artists of Bollywood - Sushant Singh Rajput.
body:
Illustration: Naman Chadha

The young ticket collector sat on a bench on a lonely platform as a cold breeze swept his face. His baffled mind couldn’t make any decisions, his futile attempts to understand his own thoughts rendering him numb and cold. Staring at those distant tracks, he spotted a tiny glowing light and heard some raucous shrieks which heralded the arrival of the chugging train. The flickering reflections of the train's lights amidst the fog appeared like a ray of hope, a ray which transformed all his dreams and desires into a train that came rambling towards him.

This was a scene from the iconic movie MS Dhoni - The Untold Story, a movie which successfully managed to set a benchmark in the world of Indian cinema and won worldwide applause. It extensively unleashed the potential of its lead actor. The time for the fulfilment of the dreams of the reel life MS Dhoni - Sushant Singh Rajput - had come. 

From being a National Physics Olympiad winner to securing one of the top ranks in the AIEEE exam, subsequently getting admission in one of the most prestigious colleges in the country, Delhi College of Engineering, his academic achievements were exemplary. However, he decided to quit engineering and soon made his television debut. Rajput paved his way through one of the most challenging, nepotism-driven industries of the country - Bollywood. He set remarkably high standards through his awe-inspiring performances and the choices of the films he acted in. His dynamic debut in Kai Po Che is the embodiment of how sheer talent and hard work can make one achieve all the success in life. 

His raw talent swept the industry like a hurricane. He left the public awestruck and mesmerised by his performance in the MS Dhoni biopic. Be it a lighthearted comedy such as PK, an emotional, nostalgic story like Chhichhore, or a powerful narrative like Sonchiriya, the choices of such myriad classics showcase his versatility as an artist and as a performer.  

Sushant vividly portrayed his creativity through his Instagram handle, inspiring thousands of young minds. One such fascinating post was a picture of his bucket list, which enumerated a series of stunning and inspiring events. He explored the infinities of space and the scintillating stars through his telescope, yet always kept his feet firmly on the ground. 

He checked off many of the items on his bucket list, which included visiting his alma mater Delhi College of Engineering. The memory is still fresh in the minds of the thousands of students who happened to be present in the college that day. It was a tense Sunday morning, with nervous faces anxiously revising their notes and virtually anticipating the grades which they would be getting. However, Sushant completely altered the vibe through his dynamic demeanour and charismatic personality. 

Be it reel life or real life, he never failed to enchant his audience. His sudden demise has left us all horrified, creating a void which will remain hollow and unfilled. He has taught us the most crucial life lessons: the importance of love, hard work, faith in one’s dreams and most importantly, the brevity of human life.

The film industry has lost a precious star, a soul who with his outstanding performances illuminated the cinematic world and paved his way to the big screen. The avid stargazer concluded a beautiful journey and commenced on a new one, a journey where he now illuminates the boundless sky, scattering his sequin starlight like embers of a dying fire, winking and smiling at all his fans; for within their hearts, he shall always remain the number one star.

title: Unravelled: The Hidden Pandemic
biliner: Sushant Singh Rajput's sudden demise sent shock waves throughout the country, but it also served as a catalyst to bring up a conversation that Indians have been brushing under the carpet for years: mental health disorders that go unacknowledged. Read on as Anoushka Raj, 2nd year, ENE, Artika Sharma, 3rd year, ENE and Pratiksha Pradhan, 2nd year, ECE delve into the deplorable scenario of mental health facilities in the country.
body:
Illustration: Dhruv Vyas

Sushant Singh Rajput's sudden demise sent shock waves throughout the country, but it also served as a catalyst to bring up a conversation that Indians have been brushing under the carpet for years: mental health disorders that go unacknowledged. Read on as Anoushka Raj, 2nd year, ENE, Artika Sharma, 3rd year, ENE and Pratiksha Pradhan, 2nd year, ECE delve into the deplorable scenario of mental health facilities in the country.

The year 2020 has been synonymous with disaster. With a raging pandemic in place, it has left us all consuming content at the speed of light. The most recent tragedy in the list of the never-ending catastrophes that this year continues to inflict upon is the death of our beloved star and one of DTU's most renowned super-seniors, Sushant Singh Rajput, which almost every DTUite is struggling to deal with. 

Needless to say, Sushant Singh Rajput’s death is more than just a misfortune that struck Bollywood or the loss of a brilliant actor and a household name. It has served as a catalyst to get a country of 1.3 billion to finally open up about issues like mental health and depression. His suicide has served as a much needed wake-up call: we need to step up about mental health. It serves as a reminder to Bollywood, and to us, that mental health issues have always existed and will continue to exist if the current scenario does not undergo drastic improvements. 

Wherever you go on the internet, the narrative about Sushant's suicide and mental health seems to follow you. No one wants to stay mum anymore and everyone has something to bring to the table. While it is a first for quite a few of us who have kept our struggles hidden from the world, and a seemingly 'baby' step towards normalising the treatment of mental illnesses, some popular ideas that are currently being propagated are a tad troublesome. 

We see people quoting his entrance ranks, his good grades, his beautiful girlfriend, his movies with social messages, and his inspiring Instagram posts, and the first question they ask is: "What could have gone wrong in the life of a man who seemingly had everything?” It is also the only narrative that seems to concern the media. But there's something very inherently wrong with this question and mentality. It seems as if it's hard for us to dissociate the idol we found in him from the human being he really was.

What is important to realise is that our identities are more than just monetary successes, the people who look up to us for our achievements, and the struggles that we go through. Sure, these are important factors and everyday things that keep us going, but being at peace with ourselves, above all, is what gives us the ability to live with ourselves. 

Why exactly is it problematic for us, as people who never knew the real Sushant, to ask questions like "What went wrong?" whilst focusing on the most visible and material idea of success? Is it our outright insensitivity, or the temporary high of associating ourselves with a deceased celebrity?

Our idols aren't the superheroes we make them out to be. They're flesh and blood and bone, just like you and me. It's crucial, hence, that we focus on the right questions, questions that focus on what we can learn from this, and most importantly, how we can prevent others from facing the same fate. 

The primary step is to normalise the idea of seeking professional help. Therapy is a lot more than a cup of warm chamomile tea and listening to inspiring podcasts. Sadness is a multifaceted evil that affects everyone in different ways. For some, it is days in a blacked-out room without food; for some, it is overposting on social media; for some, it is a huge bucket of fried chicken eaten mindlessly over a daily soap; for some, it is a bottle of pills that provide temporary relief; and for some, it is a combination of all these. Depression cannot be quantified or compared. Those suffering from depression, thus, need scientific diagnosis and treatment which only professionals can provide. It is important to understand that you are not your own diagnosis. 

The help further needs to be coupled with support from loved ones and constant reminders that they are not alone, which brings us to the second idea that is often misunderstood and glorified: the idea of being there for someone. “Being there” doesn't equate to solving someone's problems or curing them of their illness. You can be there for someone as they take their steps into a therapist's office, by their side, telling them that it's okay to not be okay and it's okay to do something concrete about it. 

You can play more concrete roles too, of course. You can listen to them vent their hearts out, or hold them as they cry, but the question to ask yourself before you take the onus of sticking alongside a suffering individual is, "Are you truly capable of being emotionally available for another human being?" Check up on yourself first and ask yourself if you are capable of listening to them without your judgements and biases blinding you. Are you prepared to deal with the dark thoughts they might share? If the answer to these questions is 'no', then for the sake of your own mental health, please don't offer that kind of help. You cannot, after all, pour from an empty cup. Not only would it harm you, it would affect them as well if you suddenly withdraw yourself from the situation. Be there for them, but decide upon a level of involvement you can deal with and stick to it.

To do something for the cause, we have to be more proactive than just sitting and waiting around for people to come to us with sorrows that are eating them alive from the inside out. It needs to be more than just social media appearances of goodness; it needs to be a constant process of understanding, listening, changing, and knowing when to draw the line.

There is this another common misbelief associated with therapy - that it is for those who suffer from psychosis, hallucinations, or have some oddity that has consumed their brains. This school of thought needs to be nipped in the bud. The proactiveness that the Indian community shows while turning up at the physician, asking for antibiotics to cure a common cold overnight, is the exact seriousness and caution that this society needs when it comes to seeking help for probable mental disorders. The longer you wait to treat an illness, the more it spreads, till it plagues and torments you to the extent that quitting life seems less arduous than living through the pain. 

It is about time that help is made accessible to all. Therapy needs to be available, not just financially, but also emotionally. We need more counsellors who are objective and virtuous, and we need more institutions who help promote the importance of mental health.

It is tragic how conversations about mental well-being stir up only when a celebrity dies. We need constant dialogue in all communities, educational institutions, workplaces, and above all, families. A conducive environment that promotes communication is the need of the hour, or we will end up losing more and more promising individuals. Grief can no longer be commemorative. We need action from the citizens, and the willingness to be kinder and more understanding. We need to be told that the solution to improve one's mental health goes beyond “meditating” and “choosing to be optimistic”. As long as we don’t recognise trauma as a medical illness, we cannot progress. 

Sushant was one of the few extremely talented yet grounded artists to make it big in a predominantly nepotistic industry despite coming from a very humble background. He was self-made in its truest essence. There is no single way we can fill the void that is left after his passing, but the one thing we can do is to be better and to do better. 

The fact that journalists and media houses have the audacity to paint someone's tragic loss as a "Masala" story for the Indian audience to consume and discuss during dinner, while ignoring the underlying mental health issues that led to it, show how far we are from seeing suicide for what it really is: the ebbing away of hope and loss of willpower to fight with what's killing you. We're instead too busy playing the blame game, sometimes calling Sushant weak and cowardly, and other times abusing those around him. 

Sensationalising his suicide by presenting assumptions as facts is an insult to the memory of who he was, the legacy he’s leaving behind, and most importantly, the unthinkable grief consuming his family and loved ones. Invading the privacy of a bereaved family by showing images of the incident isn’t just journalism gone wrong, but can trigger a trail of copycat suicides too.

Mental health discourse in this country needs to reach out from our bright white mobile screens to our living rooms, where we feel uncomfortable talking about our problems, to the hospitals where mental health specialists are still not found, to governments that have never given it due recognition, to friends who brush off signs of mental illness as attention-seeking, to the counsellors that misdiagnose and get away with it, and to educational institutes and workplaces who take it as a sign of weakness and associate it with disinterest or unwillingness to cope up with the workload. 

We need to stop this cycle of hate and negativity that we're perpetrating. We need to stop pointing fingers and start holding each other's hands to come out of it together, stronger as a community. On a personal level, we need to look out for ourselves and those close to us, and the cycle will continue to create a chain of love and care. 

Let the memory of Sushant stay fresh in our heads as a cry for help that wasn't paid heed to, and so let's pay heed to the thousands of other cries that we can hear but not listen to. Let's not inadvertently drive more people to the edge of committing suicide, and let's ensure they get the help they deserve. Let's be there for each other, and above all, be there for ourselves!

title: Interview | Online Examinees of DTU
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Ananya Bajaj, 4th Year, IT and Harshit Meena, 4th Year, IT on their experience of giving online exams amidst the ongoing pandemic.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Ananya Bajaj, 4th Year, IT and Harshit Meena, 4th Year, IT on their experience of giving online exams amidst the ongoing pandemic.

How was your experience of giving an online exam in such a situation?

Ananya: Initially, I was hesitant but all of our issues were resolved within an hour. So our experience, on the whole, was pretty good.

Harshit: In this situation, online exams were the need of the hour. Our department provided us with a platform where we could give our exams and get our degree on time. All the students, faculty members, HODs and the Dean were really supportive. Many meetings were conducted on Google Meet about every possible issue that students could face while giving the exam. They provided us with a demo and all the issues and feedback were later sent to the authorities and were fixed on the same day, so that no one faced any issues on the examination day.

Did you face any difficulties while giving the online exam?

Ananya: Personally, I did not face any issues and the process was quite smooth. One of my friends did face a slight issue but those were also resolved really quickly. Our teachers as well as the support staff were on time and were attentive to all our calls. Everything was resolved at the earliest. Moreover, one of our teachers set up the same test the next day with different questions to make up for the slight issues faced by my friend while taking the test. Mostly everyone was fine with the whole process. There was a rule that we had to login within fifteen minutes in case of a power cut. Even so, I don’t think any of us faced any problems.

Harshit: I faced an issue in my third exam. My video camera was not working and was showing a black screen. The proctor told me to login again and start the test and in the meantime, I got a call from the respective faculty asking me if there were any issues to be resolved during that time. There were no disruptions in the examination process and the test picked up from the same place I had left it. So, basically it was all fine.

What was the situation like for students from lower financial backgrounds with poor internet connection? Did DTU take any provisions to make the exam process easier for them?

Ananya: Yes, they did. After the exam, all the students could report any problems, which included people in Kashmir who don’t have internet access. They were informed that they could give the offline exams later in case they performed poorly due to any issues while giving the exam. They have the option of giving a re-exam in July or August, when and if the lockdown lifts. 

Harshit: The students living in Jammu and Kashmir were given the option of appearing for the exam in a government organization closest to their homes, for example, police stations. For people in Delhi who were facing technical issues, they provided a personal cab so that these students could give the exam in the university itself.

At the end of the day, do you feel that the online exams were easier or tougher than the offline ones? How would you compare the two?

Ananya: It takes me two hours to reach college if I was travelling from home, so that time was saved. On the downside, I felt that you had to read between the lines to be to solve the MCQ questions. This made the online exams slightly more challenging. 

Harshit: The biggest advantage of online testing is that it saved me a lot of travelling time. Usually, it takes me one and a half hours to travel to college from my house. That time was saved in online examinations. I just logged in ten minutes before the exam.

Would you like to give any tips to students who are yet to give the exam?

Ananya: You should try to not move your head too much, otherwise you may get a warning. Other than that, you should study well and try to read between the lines.

Harshit: My tip would be to ensure that your connection is stable and that you have checked everything beforehand. Your laptop and Wi-Fi connection should be working correctly on the day of the exam. It is also advised to stay stable on the screen.

Which mode of examination do you prefer, online or offline?

Ananya: I would prefer offline mode but again, online was equally good. It is quite difficult to choose. Offline has an upper edge because we get time to freshen up and we’re in an environment where everybody is giving the test. That is the only thing better about offline testing, though online was pretty good for me. 

Harshit: I would say online mode is more preferable. 

Did you adopt any different preparation strategies for the online exam?

Ananya: Yes it was a little different. In the case of subjective exams, you tend to go through the content without actually reading between the lines or focusing on minor details as it is a majorly theoretical paper. But for the MCQ tests, we had to make notes and keywords for the important terms. We looked for and practised MCQs online as well.

Harshit: It was basically the same strategy. In an offline exam, you don’t really need to be very thorough with the material and can give the answers in your own words. But in the case of MCQs, you need to be very specific. You also need to practice a lot of MCQs beforehand to be prepared for the actual exam.

Do you think that online exams should be adopted as a viable alternative to offline ones?

Ananya: Overall, I feel that offline exams are much better because they provide a much better environment and don’t need an in-depth study of the topics. I think our preparation during online exams had to be two-fold. We were not only studying from the books but were practising MCQs from the internet too. That is why I would personally prefer offline exams.

Harshit: Online exams are a do or die situation. You either know the answer or you don’t. In offline exams, you get marks for diagrams and even for just deciphering the question. But in an online exam, you need to know the correct answer beforehand. There are no grace marks involved. So in the long run, offline exams would be much better.

title: BLOG | Mankind and its Resilience
biliner: It has been a troublesome year for mankind so far. The sudden recent events seem to plunge us into an abyss, taking us back to square one and bringing normalcy to a halt. In this grim situation, Mandeep Singh, 2nd Year, COE, attempts to spark hope of a brighter future.
body:
Taking a break and sitting in the balcony during a fine summer evening, I found myself battling with a nagging question. As I saw scores of people loiter around on their usual business and with the country returning to unannounced normalcy, my mind questioned, "How does humanity manage not to fall apart after all that has happened so far?". The present year needs no introduction, for its reference is enough to send jitters down one’s spine. A lot has happened during the year, with the exception being the thin line of sanity and chaos, trespassed multiple times. It is then prudent to assume that such an occurrence of events would traumatise any strong soul, let alone the regular human soul. Why then, do we see a sense of indifference inside the populace? Is it ignorance? Is it submission to fate? The answer is, it is neither.

As implausible as it might seem, the human grit does not seem to falter!

There’s this absurd thing about failure - it seems daunting when we first imagine it, baffling when we near it; and agonising when we encounter it. However, having faced it, we see the hope of succeeding. A year ago, if we had thought of the possibility of a pandemic derailing the entire world, we would have been haunted by it. Come March, if we had thought of the possibility of Covid-19 not disappearing within a few months, we would have been appalled. Yet, here we are, living through a health-wrenching pandemic as if it were just another one of our daily affairs. This is the potency of mankind’s moxie! Whether it be a once-in-a-century global health emergency or a war, humans are somehow always able to see the light at the end of the tunnel, digging through it even when it seems impossible!

The human grit does not seem to falter. When we allow our grit to face our failures, it is only then that we achieve true subjugation over it.

Such is the idea presented by Rahul Raj Singh, a DCE alumnus (2002, Civil Engineering), who in his upcoming song, “The Purge”, has radiantly conveyed hope to society in these dire times. The song has been created to uphold the belief in providence - faith in a belief that from this purge, shall emerge, a messiah to lead the World on, to once again become a safe, healthy and peaceful place!

Rahul’s journey has been a unique one as he completed his engineering, and consequently his MBA, finally rising in the corporate world to head the India Business of an American Consulting company; before immersing himself entirely into his passion for music production. Having learnt to play the guitar, while at DCE, his music had to wait a couple of years as he started his corporate career after MDI Gurgaon. The passion for music continued alongside demanding corporate roles; as he setup a small home studio and learnt music production. His collaboration with the new age music company GrooveNexus led to the production of his first song. The song will be available at www.groovenexus.com on 3rd July, 2020.

In his current repertoire, Rahul handles all aspects of music production from penning down the lyrics to composing the music, to playing the guitars and even lending his own voice.  His latest song strives to become the beacon of optimism for people in such trying times.

body:
As the COVID-19 pandemic ravages our country, it has brought with itself unforeseen challenges for the most economically vulnerable sections of our society. Faced with job losses and uncertain finances, they find themselves staring at an extremely bleak future. Fortunately, organizations like Delhi's Guardians have stepped up to the challenge. Read on as Ananya Kapoor, 1st year, EE examines the unique role played by Delhi's Guardians in generating employment for the ones worst hit by the pandemic while also providing high quality, affordable sanitation services to the public.

It is almost universally agreed that in all of recent history, few events can match up to the scale and disruptive potential of the current COVID-19 pandemic. Within a span of a few months, the world as we know it has changed, perhaps permanently. The closure of workspaces, malls, and restaurants, strict stay-at-home orders, and economic growth plunging to its lowest levels in recent times does seem to constitute a scenario straight from a cruel dystopian universe. One of the most pressing concerns regarding the pandemic has been its impact on the job market. As corporations and small businesses institute mass layoffs in a desperate bid to stay afloat, an already stressful period has turned into a financial nightmare for many, the worst hit unarguably being the ones at the bottom of the socioeconomic ladder. Over the past few months, as the country has been jolted by disturbing visuals of a veritable exodus of migrant workers, the possibility of a sustained unemployment crisis has become almost impossible to ignore. With many traditional channels of employment like restaurants, gyms, and hair salons becoming obsolete, there is an urgent need for these jobs to be compensated in order to provide gainful employment to a vast subset of our society.

At this point, most of us have realised that this pandemic is not something that can simply be wished away. The return to economic stability and employment generation can only be possible if we take a no-holds barred approach towards combating the virus. Luckily, this is not as difficult as it appears to be. Simple steps like wearing masks, maintaining social distancing, and regular sanitisation have been demonstrated to greatly reduce the spread of the virus. Sanitisation becomes doubly important in the case of patients who have been advised to home quarantine as it reduces the risk of transmission to their loved ones. Large workspaces also benefit from this practice as it diminishes the risk associated with a large number of people working in the same area. But with sanitation services charging extravagant amounts for even single-room accommodations, vast swathes of our population have been deprived of even this basic service. 

Fortunately, organisations like Delhi’s Guardians are working diligently to plug this gap. An initiative started by four budding entrepreneurs who possess degrees from eminent institutes like DCE and IIM Calcutta, Delhi’s Guardians is committed to providing affordable sanitisation services for a variety of spaces in Delhi, ranging from 1 BHK apartments to large office areas. Their noble approach of completely foregoing profits and only charging for the equipment used has reduced sanitisation costs to one-third of those charged by others. All this is done without compromising on quality, since the team only uses high quality chemicals approved by the FDA and WHO GMS along with hospital grade PPE equipment while performing their job. All professionals have the Aarogya Setu app installed on their phones and the team is WHO certified. Apart from the provision of affordable services, Delhi’s Guardians has also done its part in providing work to those who have seen their employment opportunities dry up during the pandemic. Their team includes restaurant and salon workers who have lost their jobs in the past few months but are now earning wages comparable to or even exceeding their previous ones.

Within a month of its establishment, Delhi’s Guardians has already received sixty orders from clients ranging from homeowners to commercial enterprises like the Bank of India. The team isn’t stopping here though. They are already planning an initiative to provide employment to the Madhubani painters of Bihar through the production of masks. This unique approach of helping disadvantaged groups become self sustainable micro entrepreneurs will go a long way in protecting the most vulnerable sections of our populace from the vagaries of the unpredictable job market. 

Delhi’s Guardians’ sustained efforts in providing essential services while generating employment deserve our whole-hearted appreciation and support. Kudos to this crop of new-age heroes! 

The Delhi’s Guardians team can be reached on their Instagram page or on their website.

Delhi's Guardians is also providing special offers to DTU students as well as their family members. Their services can be availed through their website.
