title: Interview | Anmol Vishwakarma, Ph. D. Student, Virginia Tech
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Anmol Vishwakarma, a Ph. D. Student in Civil Engineering at Virginia Tech for the DTU Times Podcast.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Anmol Vishwakarma, Class of 2016, ENE, a Ph. D. Student in Civil Engineering at Virginia Tech for the DTU Times Podcast.

Please tell us a bit about your background. Where did you do your schooling and what were your JEE attempts like?

I was born and brought up in New Delhi. I have three siblings. My father is an Electrical Engineer and my mother is a homemaker. My elder sisters are architects. I had an early exposure to engineering because of my dad and my sisters who were gearing up for architecture school and so, my decision to study engineering became pretty natural. I attempted the JEE twice. In my second attempt, I did get a rank but it was not good enough to land me the better IITs. I was relying on the AIEEE to get into DTU. My rank in AIEEE was right on the border and during counselling, I had the option of Environmental Engineering, Polymer Science and Chemical  Technology, and Biotechnology. I was lucky enough to get my first preference. I still remember how happy I was when I got through the spot round. My family was travelling that day, but I had friends who had already enrolled there. One thing I would like to point out is that I chose Environmental Engineering in DTU after talking to some alumni. Most of them were very successful. I thought that I could follow their path, but this is where I see a vacuum. When it comes to the niche branches, like Environmental Engineering, there are not many people who can give you a clear picture, especially when it comes to the technical side. Most alumni you will meet are more into Consulting or IT fields and this creates a bias in the minds of students. In my four years in DTU, I also faced something similar but I have seen a growing number of students who are passionate about this field as well.

You mentioned that Environmental was your first preference during counselling. Not many people coming right out of high school would be aiming for Environmental, primarily because what they know from their coaching and their seniors is that the current placement trend is more in favour of coding and circuital branches. A lot of people even take up core branches due to the availability of government jobs. In such a scenario, how would you justify the preference for Environmental Engineering? How can any other JEE aspirant do the same?

Well, my rank in the AIEEE was pretty borderline so I didn’t really have the option of core branches. I basically had to choose from amongst the three “bottom” branches. If I had the option, I would have also chosen a branch based on the previous cutoff trends. All the same, I’m really happy that I chose Environmental Engineering. Also, there were some students in my batch who chose Environmental Engineering despite having a really great AIEEE rank. It's all about how focused you are and how much you have thought about it in the past. 90% engineering students are directionless and they come to college looking to get the best out of that opportunity.

How did you tackle the pressure that comes with Environmental Engineering, especially in the first year when there is an inferiority complex associated with it? In the first year, when you interact with new people, the common point of conversation is about the rank and the branch.  People ask whether you have actually chosen the branch or landed up there. It does pervade into your mind till the end of the first year and even the fourth year when it comes to placements and the cutoffs and eligibility for various companies. According to you, how should an Environmental Engineering undergrad navigate the inferiority complex and negativity associated with this branch at DTU?

Unfortunately, what you say is very true. I personally did not face something like this because the friend circle I entered into was very diverse but I still get what you are trying to say. In my opinion, such a thing shouldn’t matter because a lot of us don’t exactly know about the branch and the opportunities it can give you for anything. Nowadays, whenever I open the newspaper or read an article, I find that anything and everything is probably related to Environmental Engineering and can be solved using it. For example, water and the air-related problems in Delhi happen to be related to the core aspects of Environmental Engineering. According to me, we should not pay much attention to the negative aspects and focus on what we can contribute towards society. That is where the mentality shift is needed. This is basically a cultural thing and I believe that if people from DTU or other good environmental engineers come up, we could get some very good role models to look up to.

Could you tell me a bit about your involvements in college? What societies were you a part of? Ultimately, how did the overall experience help you in your masters applications?

First, I would like to go back to my first semester when I got admitted in the spot round. The biggest challenge of getting through the spot round was that the midterms were in the very next week after I joined. I wasn’t really getting awesome grades and it also reflected in my final mark sheet. After that, I ensured that I passed every exam and improved my grades. I did get some good internship opportunities later in firms like IOCL and Havells. These were not on campus opportunities but the work culture and deliverables in these two internships were really good. Regarding societies, I was a part of the Solaris group. I was working on their corporate and PR side. The concept of Solaris was really impressive. Other than this, I participated in ‘Engineering Without Borders’ and also other very basic stuff for the societies. Still, most of my work came from the internships.  I think these are especially on the basis of research opportunities like technical writing. I would also like to stress the importance of the projects to get hands-on experience. These were really important points that helped me in navigating my journey through DTU. This is when you really know whether research interests you or not!

People should not be discouraged by working in environment opportunities. Even I was not very confident at first about getting into this, but then we soon collected a lot of quantitative and qualitative data from nineteen different parts of Delhi which we later analysed using computational and experimental methods during this process. So I really started getting interested in the computation side which usually deals with building models and analysing data. Environmental engineering goes hand in hand with data science. We need someone with domain knowledge to analyse the data. So you basically need to understand the importance of this field. It took me around three years, three to four internships, several classes and project work and some volunteer work to be able to find out something that interested me. Basically, the message I want to send across is that it is okay to be clueless about what you are going to do but you need to make an effort to try out different things. 

Could you briefly highlight something about DTU Solaris? I believe that a lot of students haven't heard of it, especially the students who have joined the college after 2016 or so. Is there an opportunity along similar lines or a similar team to create something like this? What are the student level competitions in this domain that students need to target and how can they go about it? 

Environmental engineering was previously dominated by mechanical engineering. After coming to the US, I have seen many opportunities in the environmental sector, like designing a water recharge facility within a city. They give you problems which require creative and innovative solutions, while also serving the public and conserving resources. Projects in this field are very case-study based, like in MBAs. The competitions held are very industry-specific. If there is a private industry, it might encourage research and collaboration with other industries. Some treatment projects have environmental engineering principles behind them and refining these six or seven processes can basically solve problems throughout the chain. An example could be of water coming in with pollutants and cleaning it in an environmentally sound, technical as well as creative way. 

How does one discover about these opportunities? How does an undergraduate student find competitions that are happening out there. If someone really wants to excel in this domain, what are the skills they should have before tackling any of these competitions? 

That’s a really great question. There is the KWWA site for US-based competitions, which is at the national level. There are separate ones at the state level which organise most of these activities and scholarships. As for skills, I would like to mention that it depends on what kind of subdomain you are looking into. The major subdomains you have in environmental engineering are water engineering, wastewater engineering, air resources, solid waste management and sustainability and policy. Robotics has also revolutionized the industry in many cities. The skills of any kind of research are disciplinary skills. You have to be interested in what you do. I would like to recommend a course called “Learning How to Learn”, which is all about learning mechanisms and trying to build chunks of knowledge and creativity. Certain programming skills are also needed. These are essential skills that you need to have. Things will be interdisciplinary in the future, so that is where everyone should be headed. Of course, this applies even if you want to work in the industry, because no two jobs are the same. Focus on your passion and your interests.

You mentioned that your specialization deals with the computational side of environmental engineering. Basically, how Data Science can be used to help and generate inferential results to actually make an impact on our environment. So, how did you come to identify that this is the exact specialization you would like to pursue a Masters or a PhD in? Was it your coursework at DTU, your internships, or your major thesis?

The answer is actually all of these. We had coursework on wastewater infrastructure. When I was applying for my Masters, I didn’t know that I would be going into the water infrastructure domain. That is the area I’m currently working in. I’m trying to develop risk and life cycle economic models for the water pipeline infrastructures in USA. We are using data from 500 different water utilities- it’s a big data problem. We have to develop different statistical models. So, that kind of analysis is very computational. I knew I wanted to work in this area because computational work really interested me. So, when I was applying for Masters, I applied to different professors who were doing research in the computational domain. Based on the responses I got, I chose the best one. I thought that if I got a fully funded Masters, I would definitely do my PhD because then it would be less of a financial burden. When I got my fully-funded Masters, I thought to give myself one year to understand this research area and decide whether I really what to get into this or not, because PhD is a long commitment. So, I gave myself one year and then told my professors that I was really interested in taking this further and doing a PhD in this area. 

You mentioned that you’ve done a couple of significant internships. When it comes to finding internships in the core domain, it becomes extremely difficult if you don’t have a referral or an inside contact in the industry. And when it comes to on-campus opportunities, not a lot of core companies come in. So how should one find internships in reputed firms, and what exactly sets your applications apart when it comes to applying as an undergraduate for an internship?

I would like to stress on the fact that it’s really important to improve your networking skills right from the start. Because I’ve seen that even after coming here, it’s harder for Indian students to leave that mentality of placements. Even here, companies come for campus fairs, but they just come to introduce themselves and talk to you. So, that is where you need to shine- you need to have the personality, communication skills, and networking skills. If you have a good rapport with your professor, you can go ahead and ask them, and they will help you find some good internships. Usually, applying online might not be the best way; I would recommend emailing and following up. 

When did you decide to pursue Masters and not an M.Tech. in India? How did you go about preparing for the GRE exam? What would you say is the weightage of GRE as opposed to your application? How do you make a strong application that has a chance of acceptance into the top universities?

Right from the start I thought that if the education at the B.Tech. level is not able to give me the kind of an exposure to know more about the research side of things or what the industry is like, then doing an M.Tech. here would be the same thing again. So, I thought that I should get a different kind of exposure from a foreign university because their curriculum is very different, they’re more advanced, they have more research opportunities and better labs. If you’re looking for funding, it’s much better to come here as a Master’s student of Environmental Engineering as compared to that of Computer Science due to lesser competition. Initially, I wasn’t planning for Master’s. During my initial years at DTU, I was planning on getting an MBA. That is also a great path for Environmental Engineering students, especially from the perspective of environmental entrepreneurship- which we desperately need. While preparing for CAT, I realized that I wasn’t ready for an MBA. I had to study more environmental engineering and get some research experience. However, my CAT preparation helped me to quickly grasp the GRE material. I started preparing for the GRE in my 4th year. I got a Magoosh subscription, which is a question bank of relevant questions. Once in a while, I would give a full test from different content providers like Kaplan and Princeton Review. I found that the Kaplan tests were the most realistic. For the verbal section, I used the free Magoosh Android app. Anything above 165 in Math and 155 in verbal should be considered safe. I would really recommend the book Word Power Made Easy by Norman Lewis. I would also recommend everyone to develop a daily reading habit. I would really recommend The Hindu and The Indian Express editorial sections.

When you take the GRE, you’ll realize that the application process has just started. Find someone with a US news subscription, and use the data to prepare a spreadsheet to understand the different fee structures, rankings withing your domain, and research budgets. Choose 4-5 dream schools, 3-4 moderately ranked schools, and a couple of safe schools. I would recommend choosing schools from the Top 30 list. I have also found that State schools have better funding mechanisms as compared to Ivy Leagues. The next step would be do find a good combination of people to write letters of recommendation. Start early, and have at least 4 people- three professors, and one industry professional. You should have this finalized by October end, so that you can aim for early deadline colleges. Also, write your SOP on the side and get it reviewed. One point to note is that Indian students are acclimatized to being humble, but you must sell your strengths through the SOP. The selection process happens through two steps- first, the graduate school looks at your application and forwards it to the department if your GRE and TOEFL scores cross the cutoff. The departmental selection committee really looks into your application. Your essay gives an insight into how you are as a person and how you fit in. For people in Delhi, they should definitely take advantage of USIEF (United States-India Education Foundation). They have scholarship opportunities, and host a number of workshops to help you with your application.

Another aspect of the application procedure is getting the transcripts. You just need to go to the admin and ask them for however many copies you need. So, the application process is long and filled with challenges. So, start early, set your own deadlines, make friends along the way.

How important would you say it is for a person to have pursued research into their core domain in their undergraduate studies if you wish to pursue research further as well? Does it have a significant impact on your application selection?

Even if you’re not planning to pursue research, I would highly recommend everyone to pursue any research opportunities. They give you the push to practice theoretical thinking, literature review, and technical writing as well. In India, we’re not really taught to think of plagiarism. But schools abroad take this very seriously. Research experience make you aware of this. It teaches you to synthesize, paraphrase, and write coherently. Publishing papers or attending conferences definitely sets you apart from other aspirants. I didn’t have any publications, but I had presented my findings from my research in an international conference. So, that definitely helped me move forward. You can actually experience the process and know if that’s something you want to pursue in the future. Undergraduation is really the best time to explore your options.

How would you differentiate between an undergraduate degree in India and a postgraduate degree in the USA? What tips would you give a person completing their Bachelor’s from India, and then going abroad?

Since you invest a lot of money, you will be very serious about your Master’s. The teaching methodology is very different. They put a lot of emphasis on being creative and having your own answers. You are given an honor code to sign after each assignment to ensure that you haven’t copied it. And people follow it. That’s the difference in the teaching. You need to adapt and accept it. 

How was the experience of doing an undergraduate degree from India and a postgraduate from the USA? What are the differences when it comes to coursework? How serious is the faculty, how do you submit your assignments, study for your exams? Basically what are the inherent differences in education in the US and India? How does it change when you move from a lenient aspect of a B. Tech. life to a very serious, course intensive Masters degree?

I would like to say that the teaching methodology is very different, they put a lot of emphasis on creativity which is definitely not the case in India. There is a lot of trust that is given to you here in the form of an honour code for submissions and people follow it. It's basically the kind of cultural difference that you need to accept. It will be different, you will have to work for your assignments. Another big difference here is that there is a lot of focus on presentations in the US. In India most of the marks you get are from tests and assignments but here you have to do more presentations, team based projects, write/critique research papers. You can’t take any shortcuts here basically. But other than that, Indian students are really good with communication there in contrast to the Chinese students who face a lot of language based issues. Mostly we have been exposed to their culture by cinema and it certainly helps in getting their references and get along. Apart from that, I think it will be easier for an Indian student to get adjusted here because the infrastructure and the environment supports you in every way. If you want to study, you’ll be given high speed wi-fi with a clean studying space, there will always be enough books in the library, you’ll have access to all research papers online through your college portal and library website. They will make sure that you have all the resources you need for an optimal educational experience. 

Say if a person is not entirely sure about having a research based career and going completely into academia and if someone really wants to switch into the industry after their master and their PhD, what are the connections available in terms of the industry connect terms? How hard/easy is it for a person specifically in the environmental branch to shift to the industrial domain after their education? How do you get into those R&D rooms?

There are different options available for people who want to work in the industry like Apharm and Jacobs, these are very good consultancies. So they can provide you a variety of roles including analyst and consulting roles. You can go ahead and join water utility which will give you a lot of on ground experience as designers and jobs which are more implementation based than others. There are other possibilities as well to join policy development companies, for that you really need to change and structure your degree in a very specific way. The usual technical posts like designer and engineer would be less beneficial than courses like policy, systems and management related courses. So that is for industry and management positions. For academic positions, of course you can have a lot of research jobs within the industry as well. Even one of our professors is working in the industry as the research director in a firm. So you can go decide to work in the industry and come back to academia per your choice, a lot of my professors here came back to teach here after their work in the industry. There’s a lot of synergy and collaboration happening so you can probably end up in a research position as well. But those positions are offered by some bigger firms that have the resources to invest a lot in their R&D department. 

When it comes to financing your education in the US, because the finances are definitely a barrier for some students when it comes to people who wish to pursue Masters abroad but are unable to do so because of the lack of funding or the lack of scholarships so how does one try their best to secure a scholarship from one of these top universities? And if not a scholarship, then what can help you reduce that financial burden when it comes to pursuing an expensive degree abroad? 

So first of all, I would recommend you to know the difference between private and state universities and their tuition fee structure as it is very different. So for example, Columbia is an Ivy League university but might charge you upwards for 60-70 lacs an year whereas a state university like Virginia Tech. If you just compare environmental engineering, Virginia Tech is a better school but Columbia of course is an Ivy League school. So Virginia Tech charged about 40-45 lacs when I got in here. But that was the 1 year fee including all costs whereas it was 70-80 lacs for virginia tech. So try to understand that difference and what you can afford realistically. But of course, if you want to get research assistantships, I would advise you to be very persuasive, very persistent. Even in your application process, when you’re writing an SoP, you should take a very careful look at your SoP because that’s what helps you get scholarships. Try to apply within their funding deadlines which are usually 15 days prior to their final deadline. So getting a good GRA would be based on how much passion you can show for one area of research and you cannot lie about that. If you are really interested in the field and have researched enough, you can write that you want to work in that lab or you can write that you want to work with a certain professor and they would definitely send your SoP to that professor for consideration. There is no cheating in that process, they really want to hire people so your SoP does go through the proper channels and then they decide if they want to keep you or not. Whether they provide you the funding initially or after the first semester is completely the professor’s jurisdiction. So I had 2-3 conversations with professors from universities I’d gotten admitted into. So they could have let me join their research groups but they would not have been able to provide me with funding right away. Because I got a fully funded offer at Virginia Tech I decided to not go with those offers but you can get a host of responses based on what their needs are. So it's definitely a cheaper alternative than fully employed researchers and especially when it comes to international students, you’re only allowed to get paid for 20 hours but there’s usually no limit on however much you’re working. So they also want to hire good international students for their labs, they are all for diversity and our hardworking, smart attitude. So try to have a positive outlook when you’re writing your application and talking to the administration and the professors. Try to contact the department heads for asking about availability of teaching assistant positions because they’re usually the ones in charge of that. Even if they don’t have positions in their department, they can refer you to other departments. Like most of the departments in sciences they have a lot of engineering students in the science departments. For example, I took an environmental chemistry course in my degree which is primarily a science course. This is why there are more engineers in science courses. Moreover things can change with each college, I think it's a good idea to find like minded people in your college and I’m sure they would definitely try to help you. 

How would you suggest the upcoming scenario for the fall admit of this year or next year because of the COVID pandemic because a lot of students who got admits this year and getting deferred to next year. So all the potential applicants for the next year, what are the things they should be worried about or what things they can do in the present year to make sure that their application stands out for their next year? What do you think would be the impact in general for Indian students going abroad?

I definitely think there will be a drastic change because the classes would be held online. So a lot of colleges are already holding their fall semesters online including my own. While some have decided to have a mix of both. So the bigger classes will be held online so if you're having some courses in your degree, they’ll most probably be held online. So with those core courses the number of students is larger because they’re mandatory to take them. I personally would have preferred to have first semester offline because that would have helped me to get acquainted with the normal culture and the expectations of the course. My prediction would be that by 2021, things would be restored to normalcy at least for the most part. I would also like to add that for the most part usually during these recession times, the US government puts a lot of stimulus money within the universities to generate research opportunities. The reason is that it is cheaper to employ research assistants and Phd students than generating employment in the industry and it generates much more jobs in the long run and this happened in the 2008 recession as well. They put in a lot of money to research and it is a really good time to pursue a masters or a thesis start in a Phd. A lot people in the US maybe have been fired usually go back to schools to pursue higher education so a lot Phd students come and there is a lot of grant flow that takes place. But I would definitely say that you should do your own cost benefit analysis and check if you feel your online education is worth it for 1-2 semesters. So take your own call because I would say that the face to face experience is really worth it and you really learn a lot and it's a surreal environment. So I live in a college town, which is essentially a small town of 40,000 people wherein 30,000 are Virginia Tech students. If you have a composition like that in a place, it is very productive because you always find young people around you and they’re always active in doing different things. Losing that is very sad because that experience is very significant for someone to see when they come here. So I would just like to advise you to take your own call. It should get easier from now on and people that would be graduating in 2022, that is the people coming here this fall, would definitely be in a better situation as compared to the ones that just graduated. 

So any last words or advice for current undergraduate environmental engineers/students of DTU or students in general who wish to pursue masters abroad? What are things that you should focus on while building your application and what things are under your control to shape your inclination within a particular branch such that 5 years later you won't regret the decision of choosing to pursue academia over industry and let go of more lucrative things in life to get more knowledge in academia.

I would like to say that you will get ample opportunities to shift fields in the longer scheme of things. Usually you should just try to go with your gut instincts and put your hands into as many things that you can because that would help you eliminate options one by one. I think that's one strategy that has worked for me. Environmental engineering is not the hardest thing to score marks in and try to maintain a good academic record in case you want to study further. Try to find good opportunities and those chunks of knowledge and try to have that faith that it will possibly connect and that is where you will get those insights and those creativity flowing in so just have to have a little bit faith in yourself.

title: The End of Chapter One: Our Formative Generation Calls It A Day
biliner: Mahendra Singh Dhoni announced his retirement today. This is not a tribute piece to his career, but rather one to the group of cricketers, and the period of time in Indian cricket, that preoccupied the first chapter of the lives of millions of Indians and inspired them to take just the one extra step toward their ambitions.
body:
-Vishesh Kashyap, Editor-in-Chief


Mahendra Singh Dhoni announced his retirement today. This is not a tribute piece to his career, but rather one to the group of cricketers, and the period of time in Indian cricket, that preoccupied the first chapter of the lives of millions of Indians and inspired them to take just the one extra step toward their ambitions.

For many, the 2002 NatWest Trophy heralded a much-needed reboot of Indian cricket. For my generation, this was where Indian cricket started. Yuvraj Singh and Mohammad Kaif - two youngsters with a handful of international matches under their belt – taking India past the finish line against an experienced England team was just the push we needed to go all-in on cricket as our sport of choice.

For some context, this was still a time when TV sets were switched off and Akashvaani bid farewell half its viewership as soon as Tendulkar lost his wicket. The deference accorded to Tendulkar by the Indian public at large is unfathomable for any player in today’s times. Tendulkar was Team India. For any other player to showcase the capability – nay, have the audacity – to carry a match in which Tendulkar failed, was stuff of astonishment.

The months after India’s World Cup Final loss in 2003 saw the emergence of the new Indian team – one with a fair balance of declared legends and prospective legends. But more than that, this team gave my generation unprecedented freedom of choice. The sheer abundance of talent in this team allowed us to trust players apart from Tendulkar, at times even depend on them to win us a match. This was unthinkable just a few short years ago.

Indian cricket rose above its Bombay-Delhi hegemony. We could now admire MS Dhoni from Bihar, Suresh Raina or Mohammad Kaif from Uttar Pradesh and Harbhajan Singh or Yuvraj Singh from Punjab. We could win an away series in England and speculate how it felt to win a World Cup.

And then, we did.

Hardly any senior played the 2007 World T20. Most viewers took it as an experimental tournament with an experimental India captain – Dhoni. We couldn’t beat Australia or England outside India without Tendulkar, Dravid or Ganguly, could we? Why was a third of the Indian squad made up of names we’d never heard before? Wait, did we just win a World Cup?

India paraded its way to victory throughout the world for the next five years. Dhoni didn’t just turn out to be a good captain, but India’s best. Tendulkar found his second prime. Out of a team of eleven, up to nine Indian players were capable of bowling, and a similar number of batting. India won the Commonwealth Bank Series in Australia, drew a Test Series in South Africa and was virtually unassailable at home.

Our sights, though, were set firmly on the 2011 World Cup. We played a veritable league of legends – all the players our generation had looked up to for the past decade were now together, and raring to win. Rightly, win we did.

Eras seldom end in one clean stroke. Soon after the World Cup win, India began a gradual baton hand-over. Dravid retired in 2011 and VVS Laxman in 2012. Tendulkar retired, with the grandest retirement ceremony for any sportsperson in living memory, in 2013. Sehwag and Zaheer followed in 2015. By early 2020, Yuvraj, Irfan Pathan and Gautam Gambhir had all announced their choice to hang up their boots.

The retirement of Dhoni – their longest-serving captain – is also a declaration of the closure of this chapter of Indian cricket. In more ways than one, it is the Thank You slide of the presentation of Indian cricket in the new millennium. It comes at a time when many of our generation are at an inflection point, toying with what to do with the rest of our life. And, it comes with a message – It’s our turn to shine.

title: Interview | Prof. Peer M. Sathikh, Associate Chair (Academic), School of Art, Design and Media, NTU, Singapore
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Prof. Peer M. Sathikh, Associate Chair (Academic), School of Art, Design and Media, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, who was a guest speaker at the Form Exploration Workshop, organised by the Department of Design.
body:
You are a visiting professor at IIT Bombay, an adjunct professor at VIT and an associate professor at ADM. What differences or striking qualities have you observed over the map of India?
Over the map of India, in the last ten years, there has been an increase in awareness regarding design and design education. Not just design and design education, but more and more engineering programmes are also understanding that design is not just designing components, design must be all-encompassing and holistic, involving human beings in the process too. This is a huge trend.

For example, take IIT Bombay and VIT. They have different accents. IIT’s have been traditionally experimentalists. They still try to inculcate experimentation and maybe failure is not tolerated, but deviations from the mainstream are. VIT on the other hand wants to have a structured education program and it may not look like it, but their end goal is to get their students whereas IIT Bombay is sure that its students will find jobs so they’re pushing for innovation and creativity. The ideology of IIT Bombay doesn’t centre around finding jobs for its students. They give their students opportunity to prepare their folio and then the student must stand for himself and seek a job.

So, it’s assumed that ultimately, all students will manage to bag a job, so they urge the students to be fresh and creative.

Exactly. VIT is looking at, four years from now where my design students will go, so even though the teaching pedagogy is like that of IIT, the students’ expectations are different. The students at IIT, they want to pick my brain, with good reason, because they want to achieve what I have achieved in certain spheres. At VIT they want to know how I got my job and how I progressed in my career. It’s embedded in me because only when you ask me to deconstruct them, I start deconstructing, but what was built in me through IIT was so natural, that you be prepared and once you prepare you can attend the job interview and I’m sure you’ll do well. It’s not arrogance but its confidence. That’s the difference. Overall in India, the design industry and education are at their best right now.

Do you think there will be an increase in awareness about design education, in the future?

There will be a plateau. Everybody wants to know what their model of design education stands, but in my opinion each area has their own set of ideologies and philosophy and if you’re able to understand the underlying set of ideologies, it will work all over. You must know what has to be embedded and what has to be portrayed. So, this is my experience of last ten years of teaching.

You are associate chair at Nanyang Technological University. What differences do you see in design education in India and in Singapore? 

In both the countries, the students are interested in sustainability. They are a little concerned that their children may not be able to enjoy the world as it is today. The main difference is that you are looking at Singapore, an island city, and only so many designers and media artist can find jobs within, so we are preparing our students for a global experience. You could be in Singapore, but you may be designing for India or China.

Whereas if you look at India, the population is so huge and there seems to be an internal environment and demand for designers and media artists. So, it brings me to my point, our way of looking at students is different, and we decided that we can’t be a master of single element of design and media. At the same time, we cannot water down our efforts so we give a chance to our students to build an interdisciplinary design education curriculum which they would like to pursue. We show them the different courses that are available and what pathways those courses will take you along and depending on what frame of mind you are in at that point of time, we can predict where you will be in five years of time. The students get to choose. Some of them would say “I want to do product design only” and some of them would graduate as a general designer. So, they can fit into industry where they are looking for generals.

We must remember that the mindset of the student and their job functions are different in Singapore. More often than not, most of the students don’t want to join a big company, for the reason that such companies don’t exist. They exist as a headquarter but never as manufacturer. So, they see themselves trying to club together to form short-term companies like joint ventures or they would like to have shared offices. They try to find jobs which they can do together and make money. But if they get a product-based design job, that’s fine too. “We are a team”, is a trend which is catching on in Singapore.

Do you think it will catch on in India too? 

The urban society? Yes. But where it is really needed is in the suburbs and rural community where our education as designers gives us certain skills, which may be useful to help solve some of the problems of rural India. For example, sanitation has been the biggest issue, but the PwD can’t solve it. We must come up with a more creative way of dealing with it.

And if this is going to happen, you will see an increase in the numbers of design entrepreneurs who are committed to a social cause. My concern is, where is the business model. At the end of the day when you settle down or you are with your mom and dad, they will ask you where is the bread and the butter coming from.

Altruism is not going to give you a business model. You can have a Gandhian perspective, but it’s not right if you say everything is for free. Because you have a wife and a child to look after and a society to look after. So, what kind of design entrepreneurs will come and how would they portray their business, so people won’t perceive them as taking advantage.

This is a dichotomy which we all face. We want to make a social progress, but we cannot do it if we cannot have our bread and butter. The equation changes when I want to have bread on the table and my son wants to have a cake. So, with that in mind, if I have a business model and I apply it to a social cause, the powers that be might think I am trying to exploit them. So, this is going to be the challenge for Indian design entrepreneurs. 

You are a REP fellow at Nanyang Technological University. Can you tell us about the Renaissance engineering program?

Renaissance engineering program is a high-level engineering program in Singapore. It is based on the Renaissance movement that happened long ago in Italy, where art, science, engineering and technology came together as one. Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci cannot be classified as artists. They were architects, engineers, artists and designers and that eventually led to the Italian Renaissance.

Renaissance engineering program is a program in which students learn, not just engineering, but they understand other aspects of art, design, economy and it gives them an advantage as to what would working for Renaissance artist be.

So, this is like a shift in narrative from design-centric approach to a broader perspective.

A shift in narrative and a shift in effort. I mean I go and teach what industrial design is. You might grow up to be leaders or heads of corporations, but if you require someone to design a campaign, who to look for and how to use. Similarly, economics is taught in a manner that it is useful for them, not as a subject. So, at the end of the day they have a Capstone project which will combine all of this together

The Renaissance engineering program gives you a bachelor’s degree plus a master’s in management plus one year of studying in one of the best universities in the world. REP fellows are selected based on the capabilities to teach and lead.

You co-founded Inovasia Design in Singapore and are a successful design entrepreneur. Keeping in mind the dichotomy that exists in society, how can budding entrepreneurs achieve middle ground and rise?

It can be achieved very well and effectively, when human beings are the heart and soul of your consulting. You’re not designing for the interest of the marketing; you’re not designing purely for the profit or for that the management that wants this product. You are designing it for the human being. If that is the central aspect of yours, everything else will fall in place.

Focus on the user. For example, if you want to design medical equipment, there are three people who will predominantly be the users. One is the patient themselves, second is the patient care person, the nurse and all that, who take you around and the third is the doctor. If you design an equipment, the doctor may not want to touch it, for some odd reasons, they will touch it with a pencil. If you design a control panel, they’ll keep punching it and if it breaks down, I failed as a designer because I didn’t foresee this.

Secondly, the nurse will touch it. They will clean their hands and clean their equipment. Thirdly, if I am designing a medical product, I need to care for the patient, and I want to see his comfort. Moreover, he should not be intimidated by the display. What the doctor needs to know, the patient doesn’t. In movies, many a times the doctor would walk in and say, “Oh! The heart rate is 56, it’s going down.” That’s the last thing the patient wants to hear. There should be a cautionary message that’s sent to the nurse and to the doctor, so that they can come and correct it. So, the designing a medical equipment is multi-faceted. You come to the aesthetic of it. It should exuberate confidence. You don’t skip into a ward wearing a skirt. (Laughs)

You must be prepared for it. Similarly, a product with a thousand wires around it won’t give you confidence. We need to have foresight, while developing. The nurse too must know which coloured wire to press and which to put. Designers have traditionally had this mindset, color-coding things so that they are easier to use.

Sounds incredibly tough.

It is. It is complex rather than complicated.

You interned as a student at the Sony Design Centre in Tokyo. How was your experience and how did it help you evolve as a product designer?

See, IIT taught me to be a designer of the Ulm School, where everything was very organized and there is some structure to it but embedded with Indian ethos and culture. As a designer, personally, I was confident in conceptualizing and sketching and all that. At Sony, I realised that a designer has to have discipline. You are not an artist; you are a designer. Someone asks you to design a Sony Walkman, you have to know that there are two targets in mind. One, it has to be a saleable product, as defined by the marketing or as per your definition. Second is that, this product has to reliable, in terms of its mechanics, which is the art of an engineer but those two things have to be come together in a usable structure that allows the user to know that this is the right thing I have and this is going to work correctly. Sony built its reputation on this very foundation. You are not playing games with yourself but artistically you are playing a game, you are enjoying this moment. So, discipline is if I told you I’m going to submit it today, I will, because each for each delay, there are repercussions.

I also realised that the product is bigger than yourself, even if you’re designing a little hearing aid, the product is bigger than yourself. You cannot go out and show off that you designed a hearing aid, nobody wants to really know. When they use the hearing aid, and they feel it has served its purpose, the look on their face, and the happiness that time when someone says you know what Peer & Partners must have designed this, that’s the goal. So, let the work speak for itself. You can always leave your signature, to say that I designed this, and people will find out. We never marketed Inovasia Design when we were in Asia, it was always word of mouth. The confidence our clients had in us was also very motivating. It is the calmness that my Indian education has brought to me and my professors who taught me. If you have not understood your own design, it’s not going to work.

Do you have a message for students of the design program?

Make the most of these four years to explore and gain. You must have your own opinion as to what works, what doesn’t, what is the human factor, what is the aesthetics, what is the emotional conviction that the product must have. The product is bigger than you and in order to do that, we cannot rush to the destination, even though we have a deadline. If you rush into a product, you will make mistakes. My message is, do not try to impress people, express yourself.

title: The Oh-so-sweet Life When It’s All Terrible
biliner: Realising that what you are now is precisely something miserable stirs up a tasteless life, but then there are a few unstated and appreciable empathies that serve some sweetness. Read on as Rishika Sinha, 1st year, ENE talks about happiness in a dilapidated life and extends gratitude to everything that helps to soldier on.
body:
To all the reasons behind this little daisy; with all exuberance, blooming in my deserted yard, I shall never be able to say, “I have paid all my dues.”

With all certainty, it was an intolerable cold day when an enduring uneasiness gripped the eighteen-year-old. Frozen in a dream, she had not a bone to move. Stuck in silence, there was a slew of questions smothering her with sleepless nights and baffling vehemence. What did she have with herself? A song, some poetry, a clutter of words that seemed to somehow form nothing much but distortion. Every part of it, she approves, is what collocates with the devilish funny people, a discotheque with anecdoche and glitched jouska all around, the madness of everything. Every part of it, she hypothesizes, is a disarrayed salvo of metaphors and idiocy. 

“It is all simple. Imperfect, possibly. But not incomplete.”

Clueless, but I am here

I apologise to myself

And embrace the cold souls

They watch,

the cold breeze

They watch,

the acme I wanted in my lungs

Everyday

Everyday

I beg for freedom

Everyday

These jaws,

Bite the skin, alligatored

Everyday

These jaws,

Engulf the serpentine air

Inured,

Everyday

Heaves me away from myself

Warped,

My hunger wants nothing

Only Closure.

What’s acceptable is that this is just a pellucid sea full of lethargy and also some dejection. Maybe also a puerile interpretation of neonate experiences strung into an out-and-out nonsensical dictionary that holds complete validity only to the writer.

“But the culmination of times with biting winds that never end isn’t gloom and ominous tears, not always. Perhaps there are umpteen hearts that celebrate your milk and honey primes and the little big shots; they are happy when you are happy and they are never tired of doing so a great many times.”

“I am grateful for having a memoir that bears all this.”

“I am just grateful.”

Right beside the table where her Every Day would rest, the windows welcomed the moonlight that couldn’t outshine the feeble lightbulb dressed by solid fingerprints. The fingerprints; well, these composed the Home that rubbed out reclusion. With journals being inked with scribbles and sketches, with treasured anthology and with omnibus editions of uncommunicated flicks, steering through the downpour became easy.

“It’s all a disaster, even the smile’s cataclysmic. Where is home? Where is survival? Away from all of this, I am now, in this life, lying here beholden to the numerous who brought happiness when everything around was awful, only awful.”

Crumpling around, I was looking for the darkest room

That could cloak the complicated, the unclear details

Leafed through the untidy voids, through every terrible bloom

That would remind me of an ache, of all the stubborn, of all the overdone fails

Goodbye to the days I shall miss never again,

to where I’ll depart when closure comes.

The skin I used to live within is gone with the valedictory rain

There’s a shelter; it’s home, there is no sting that numbs

I know, I know, and I know it’ll all be better

It’s this love that kept me holding on

The only daisy that told me to look at blue, yellow, 

look at every colour, that nothing’s a terror

It’s this that kept me holding on

It was frightful, living in exhaustion

When it was cold, when it was dark,

When the city would sleep and leave me in this bedlam I created

But love never leaves, found me without a landmark

The oh-so-sweet life when it was all terrible,

It held on to me, patched it up, the marooned yard

Won’t die in the diminishing sun, won’t flee

Won’t die when every day comes, won’t not have peace

Merci.

Merci.

And like so, this is me being thankful for the unalloyed, genuine, and sometimes cryptic consolations, the oblique and lucid lauds, the few who show deference to the troubling silences and the wayward concealments, and the many lost contacts that I respect for existing as my souvenirs.

This is me being thankful for the undersized happiness struggling along with my days.

This is me being thankful to everyone who shall never leave.

title: Interview | Anjali Singh, MiM admit - HEC, Paris, Class of 2020
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Anjali Singh, CE, Class of 2020, who received an admit to the Masters in Management program at HEC, Paris.
body:
What was your preparation strategy for GMAT and how would you advise a candidate to approach the test?

There are two strategies which a student can follow. The first one is to do all the preparation by yourself and the other is to take help. In my case, I was working and my job was very hectic, so I decided to take up a course to get some clarity about where to study from and what to study. I took an  online course where they didn’t have tutors but videos, graded quizzes, mocks and analysis. Since it was an online course, I was able to complete it while I was at home. It turned out  to be so good that even after the exam I didn’t feel like there was anything that was out of syllabus.

Would you advise other candidates to go for an online course? Is it enough?

Yes, if you are in a position like mine and have a job and there is a lot that you have to balance then definitely go for a course because otherwise, you’ll just end up looking for materials from different places and that’ll take up a lot of your time. But, in case you have the time and the willingness to do it,  you can prepare without the course as well.

What prompted you to pursue a Master’s in Management? What was your motivation?

There were several types of courses available to me. After working for a year in consulting, I was sure about what I wanted to do, and that was to not  continue in consulting. I felt this was a good way to switch my career and if you have the certainty then why wait? I was sure that I wanted to do my master's from abroad but MBA didn’t seem like a great choice because I would have had to continue working for three to four years before going and I was already certain about what I wanted to do my master's in.  Masters in Management is a very upcoming course. It's on the positive side of the incline and it is getting a lot of people to move into Europe and the US so I felt that its popularity is only set to increase.

How would you compare MiM with MBA? Is having work experience a requisite?

For MiM it is not necessary to have work experience. Inside the MiM program that I’m in, students are encouraged to take one gap year in between the two years of education and to work in 2-3 different internships during that time. This has the advantage of making you aware of what your future career might look like at the end of your education. Even so, people generally do come here with about one to two years of experience, but not more than that. For an MBA, on the other hand, two to three years of work experience is mandatory. This is evidenced by the fact that most people who get admitted to prestigious MBA programs abroad have more than four or five years of experience. This is the first basis of comparison. 

The second one is the age group. The people in my batch have an average age of about twenty-three years whereas in the case of an MBA, the average age is about twenty-seven and the students are a bit more mature. I feel that if someone is in a profession they want to pursue, but are not sure about what they want to do their master’s in, they should continue working and then, once they are certain, they should go for an MBA. But, in case you're in a career that you want to switch, or you are certain that this is what you want to get in, then I think it's better to just go for a master’s early on, because then, even though you're still twenty-five or twenty-six, you already have all that clarity plus the education. 

Honestly, it just boils down to the personal choices of the student and how they want to go about their career path. Some people prefer to experiment by doing an MiM and various internships while they are young in order to have some assurance before entering that career. But there are others who have great satisfaction with what they're doing, and wish to work for a few years. 

If a student wishes to pursue a course in management after their undergraduate engineering degree, would MiM be a good choice ?

My opinion is that because we've studied four years of engineering, most students are not very informed about what goes on in the non-tech sector. Most often, we enter into the field of consulting blindly without realizing what it actually entails. I personally know of friends who have switched their careers entirely after their engineering education and it has worked for them. But, in my opinion, if one really wants to pursue non-tech or management, it is a good idea to have a year of work experience and DTU definitely gives you the opportunity to work in great companies after your engineering degree. This will have the advantage of giving you some much-needed experience and clarity of thought which will be beneficial during your master’s degree. 

What do you think was your biggest apprehension before starting off with your preparation journey? 

I was really particular about the schools to get into and because MiM is a very up-and-coming course, there are not many schools which provide it; the best business schools have just started taking up the course. For example, INSEAD just started the MiM course last year. It was important that I get into the best school because unlike an MBA, where you can do well even if you get into the top 15 or even top 20 colleges in the US, the quality of the MiM course heavily depends on where you do it from. I was very apprehensive about not getting into one of my dream colleges and about my future plans if such a thing actually came to pass.

Another factor to be considered was the duration of the course. For example, LBS offered only a year-long and INSEAD just 10 months!  I felt that the time was a bit too short for me and wouldn’t work out in the end. In a nutshell, the entire process of college selection was extremely tedious! 

Was HEC, Paris consciously your target from the very beginning?

Not really. Because I had done my graduation in engineering and never studied these subjects before, I wasn’t sure about whether I wanted to get into marketing, finance or company law, and they're all quite different fields. I didn’t like the idea of pursuing a one-year long course where you just get in and by the time you're figuring things out, you also have to start looking for internships and jobs. That extremely fast pace was something I didn't want. I was very fixated on doing MiM, which was a two-year long course which is why I rolled out of INSEAD and LBS and all the other schools as well. Another thing I like about the two-year courses is that they give you ample time to do your internships in Europe or the US or the rest of the world. This was a plus point for me because I had never worked outside of India and felt that it was important to get an idea about the work culture usually followed in other countries before I started working there. In the end, out of all the colleges that I liked, ESSEC and HEC were the only universities that were providing the two-year long course and I ended up applying to only these two B-Schools.

The location was not a conscious choice for me and I chose HEC because I really liked the course and the college. There was also one last, very conscious decision - I have done my engineering in the fields of  civil and environmental engineering; civil mainly, but I took up a lot of environmental subjects and that's what my major thesis was also about. I am inclined towards sustainability and incorporating that in management. HEC specifically lays a lot of focus on sustainability management, sustainability consulting, and trying to incorporate sustainability in whatever we are studying. They have a sustainability organization as well as many clubs which are actively working towards sustainability in general with brands or inside the campus. I really liked the fact that they've put so much focus on something that I have studied a little bit about during my graduation and which I would love to incorporate with my management degree. This is one of the reasons that made me choose HEC, not the rankings or the location.

Talk us through the different aspects of the application process. Was there a part in the application that you thought was unique?

I spent more than eight months on my application starting from the day I began preparing for my GMAT to the day I actually gave it. TOEFL was not required because I’d completed my engineering education in the English medium. 

Essays are another very important part of the application process after the GMAT. The essays took me a lot of time because I was expected to condense my life and make sense out of everything that had happened till now. Trying to view a story out of whatever had happened in my life and how to relate it to my desire to attend HEC was an extremely tedious task. Even after I did write the essay, I didn’t know whether it was good or not because there’s no particular way to go about this process.

The forms I had to fill during the application process were also really long and I was asked to submit recommendations. As I had already started working for a year, I had to go back to college to all the professors I knew and ask them if they remembered me!

The toughest part of the process starts after the forms have been submitted because HEC usually filters out 70% of the candidates at this stage solely on the basis of GMAT scores, essays and recommendations.

This round is followed by the interviews which are no less of an ordeal. In this round, the interviewers want to find out whether you're actually the person who you claim to be in your applications and if you really stand for whatever you've said. The interviewers are experts in their field and  dive deep into every aspect of your form. 

What I really liked about the HEC interview process was that they don't have a set pattern that you have to meet and the interviewers will dive very deep into your past experiences. During my interview, I was talking about sustainability and I was asked questions like “Where do you think in finance is sustainability playing a role and how do you think your engineering will actually come to use in our classes that will happen on campus?” In conclusion, they expect you to be clear about what you want, how you want to get it and why you want to be there. 

What, according to you, made your application stand out? Did you pursue any activities at college which you feel have helped you with your application?

Definitely! I had an active college life. During my first year I had no clue about societies but later I joined the dramatics society, where we did a lot of plays on social issues; we used to do a Nukkad in which we would spend one year researching about one particular social issue and then we’d go and perform about it on the streets. Then, I started an initiative called ‘Let's Talk’ with my best friend from college and that society is still going on! The main aim of ‘Let’s Talk’ was to form a bridge between students who wished to mentor younger students especially in terms of their spoken English, because a lot of college students don't feel so confident about the language and feel that it sets them back. I also did internships every summer and winter break, starting from my second year. For example, one of my internships was in the field of journalism, with Times Internet, which is the digital arm of the Times of India and another at IIT Kharagpur which was all about sanitation and environment.

With all these things in my CV, I had the content prepared by the time the application process started; I just had to connect all the dots and see what came out of my internships. I think my college, and the course that I was doing - civil and environmental - somehow helped me a lot because the biggest pitch in my HEC application was that I wanted to work in sustainability and management. And the sustainability domain only comes from my prior engineering education. A lot of people say that after engineering one must first work for three years in management in order to get into a good B-School. But I don't think that’s true anymore. In fact, engineering complements the management degree and that's how I think DTU worked out for me. 

What is a common mistake that you think could be a possible pitfall for candidates applying for the MiM program?

A common bias we have is that exam scores are the most important part of the application, but I know of people who had great GMAT scores but lagged in other parts of the application and ended up not being accepted.

I feel like the universities, especially the ones abroad, lay equal focus on all domains of your application. So don’t leave out or take for granted any part of the application, even if you think it’s a part where you’ll shine the most.

Secondly, as I have mentioned earlier, college and course selection are also extremely important. Ranking alone doesn’t determine the value of the college or the course you end up pursuing there. You’ll have to make sure that you like your course as well and have to make sure that it aligns with your career expectations. The course duration, location, culture and other personal reasons should also factor into your decision-making and it’s fine to rule out a college or course on that basis.

Is there any specific advice you have for a candidate who may apply for this program but hasn’t started out for it yet? How should someone go about deciding on it?

A practical advice would be to use LinkedIn. If you found someone currently working in the field that you are interested in, reaching out to them is a great way to know more about their journey. Not everyone will be willing to talk to you, but you’ll find some who will be more than willing to help you out.

In my case as well, I reached out to people from top universities and spoke to them about what the course was like. Making a good LinkedIn profile is important as people will try to get to know you better before connecting to you.

Also, it’s important to have certainty about what you are preparing for and why, as the process is six months long and losing sight of the goal could make the entire process feel more like a drag. That’s why even if it takes more time to be certain about your decision, it is wise to spend that extra time.

Is there a particular timeline that one should follow in college to get ready for the admissions abroad?

There’s no set timeline, and everyone can go about it differently at their own pace. Having some clarity as early as possible helps but isn’t vital to the process. But still, starting to think about your career path from the second year is beneficial.

Essays, as you mentioned, are crucially important in the process, so what do you think makes for a good essay and does the criteria for a good essay differ according to the university that you’re applying to?

Yes, essays do form a significant component of the application. There are a lot of online resources that tell you different ways in which you can come up with a good essay, but I feel like writing an essay yourself makes the writing personal and authentic. From my experience, a good, personalized story and a good understanding of cause and consequence of whatever we have done so far and why we want to pursue a particular path, makes for a well-rounded essay. Before starting to write, brainstorm around everything that has happened in your life and how it has led to one thing or the other. Now, how the different colleges look at your essays varies only to a little extent. How well you put your story across is all that matters. 

How has your experience been at HEC so far?

It has been lovely, especially because I have done everything online for the past one and a half year and getting to experience this offline is a really great change of pace. One thing about HEC that I really like is that they have tried to bring in one of the most diverse groups of individuals from across the world. For example, in the past two weeks that I have been here, I have gotten the chance to interact with people from Brazil, Cameroon, the USA, etc. Also, there have been some really fun experiences as well, like making two Italian people taste Pav Bhaji for the first time! DTU also has a diverse group of people in it to begin with, and I was glad I could continue to enjoy that experience on a much larger scale.

title: MITACS GRI | Internship Experience
biliner: Ney Vatsa, ME, Class of 2022, shares his internship experience as a MITACS Globalink Research Intern at the University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada.
body:
THE PREPARATION

I got to know about MITACS towards the end of my first year and right from then I had it in my mind that I have to apply here. I talked to seniors from our college who previously had been selected for the same and gathered information about everything - from profile building to the process involved and the interviews. I realised that to have a good chance of getting selected it's important to have some sort of research experience in the resume. The CGPA factor was definitely there in my head because I had heard that only people having CGPA more than 9 have a chance of getting selected and at the time of my application, my CGPA was only 8.1. But I would say it's just a myth and your overall profile is the key and not just your CGPA. From the beginning of my second year, I started gaining experience in different domains, acquired some technical skills and did some research work to build my profile.

PROCEDURE FOR APPLYING FOR MITACS GRI:

The first step in the procedure is to apply for the MITACS Globalink Research Internship on the MITACS website. The application includes several fields to be filled up by the applicant.

  1. Register on the MITACS portal – https://globalink.MITACS.ca/gri/index.html
  2. The ‘Personal Information’ section implores basic details. I understand everyone has a nicely structured CV/Resume of their own, however, MITACS wants it to be tailored according to their needs. So, strictly follow their guidelines for uploading the CV/Resume.
  3. Under the ‘Education’ section, you will have to upload your transcript (ignore the fact that they’ve asked it 4 times, just upload it once). The English proficiency exam is not compulsory and will not increase or decrease your chances of getting the scholarship.
  4. The ‘Research’ section is the most important and scrutinized one of all. It has four sub-sections. Take your time to fill out each of them. MITACS has a word limit, so you must learn to omit superfluous words and be succinct. 
  5. For ‘General Description of Skills, Background Knowledge, and Research Interests’, I wrote bullet points under each of the topics separately. Skills here refer to your software (and maybe soft skills) and technical skills. Jot down your coursework in the Background Knowledge and anything else if necessary.

‘Notable Achievements’ is pretty self-explanatory. Please include only those achievements that you think are noteworthy. Don’t use the terms which they might not understand - such as ‘Festember’, ‘Pragyan’ (give a brief description if you’re mentioning them). 

‘Research Rationale’ was the hardest for me to write despite it having a requirement of 100 words. When it comes to SOPs, the shorter the word limit, the harder it gets. Think about why you really want to pursue research, if you feel there is a personal and emotional connection to it then do mention it. If you’ve had any life-changing events or lectures, mention them. Write it once, come back after a day and read it afresh. Edit it and do the same at least 4–5 times. I would definitely not say that this decides whether you get through, but it is important.

The toughest part, I would say, is choosing the projects. And since there are so many (and we have amazing net speed here!), use as many filters as you can and narrow down the areas to suit your needs. I faced the problem where I had to make a trade-off between a good project and a good university. I went ahead with the good university, but I feel like that was a slight error on my part. If you have the same conundrum, go with a good project if you really like it.

Please don’t wait till the last day to do something! Finish your application 10 days in advance and keep proof-reading it every two days. Also, if you did not know already, DO NOT mail any of the professors separately. MITACS highly discourages that practice (which only saves you more time). Once you’re done with the application, you might or might not get interview calls from professors. I got two interviews but many of my acquaintances didn’t get any interviews. So, if you don’t, there is no need to worry. Some professors just like to talk and interact once before they take a student in and some feel that your application is enough whereas some might be just too busy.

AFTER APPLYING:

After the submission of the application, there are three categories:

  1. No longer under consideration: Under this category, you are either not eligible for the internship or there are some discrepancies in your application.
  2. Waitlist: Under this category, you will have to wait for the next round for consideration.
  3. Candidate under consideration: Under this, you will either have to sit for interviews or will be given tasks related to the project. If selected, you will be given a choice of reordering your projects. In the end, you will receive an offer letter having the details of your internship.

At first, I was waitlisted. My confirmation came in March. So, you just need to be patient and waitlisted doesn't always mean that you are rejected.

MY EXPERIENCE

I started my internship on May 3, 2021. I was selected by Dr. Seonghwan Kim of University of Calgary and the title of my project was ‘Novel Nano-metrologies for Advanced Visualization and Characterization of Soft Materials’. My role here was to do data analysis and visualisation of AFM data/images.

Nowadays, AFM or Atomic Force microscopy technique has become quite popular. The main reason behind this is that it enables imaging of almost any kind of surface like polymers, ceramics, composites, glass, or any other soft surface. This fact gives it an edge over techniques like scanning tunneling microscopy (which requires the specimen to be a conductor).

I had to first do a literature survey for which I read more than 100 papers, prepared a literature review, and submitted it to the professor. All these resources were made available to me by the professor and his postdoctoral fellow.

I later got training on how to use Open Access Software like Gwyddion and Anasys which were later used by me for the analysis of real time images.

I also studied the ‘Autocorrelation Function’ here and used it to find out the trends and patterns which were published later in the paper. Weekly meetings were held with my professor and a postdoctoral fellow was there every time to help me out in case of any doubts.  

At the end of my internship my professor also offered me to join him after my graduation and carry on the research meanwhile.

One key point which I want to mention is that till the time the internship started, I had switched my profile to non-tech and luckily due to the pandemic, the internship was done virtually and hence my work was more in the analytics domain. This helped me in during the placement session. But students should be careful while applying because it might ruin their profile in case of a profile switch later.

The whole internship was a dream come true; I could see my work being valued by such distinguished people. All in all, it was quite an enriching experience which gave me a lot of exposure.

My Advice:

  1. Your main resource is the internet, coupled with your persistence to succeed.
  2. Communication is important. You should know how to interact with strangers and keep up a good conversation.
  3. It happens quite often that students don’t know about the scholarships, and that automatically dents their chances of getting it.  Ask your professors and seniors continuously about scholarships and events and keep a constant vigil in your field of interest for other opportunities.
  4. Building a rich research profile in your specific interest is also advantageous. DTU has a plethora of opportunities for a young researcher in the form of tech teams, and students should make the best use of these.
  5. I don’t want to be a buzzkill here, but yes, GPA matters but not entirely.
  6. The first step is to identify your area of interest. As a fresher, you are often quite confused and that is natural. Don’t take undue pressure, just work towards your interest from the beginning. Usually, a slothful attitude won’t get you far in the race.
