title: Edition 55 | A Scent From Back Then
biliner: Memories are like marionettes, worked by the strings of emotions, togged up in the tints of an intrinsically fabricated memoir and vulnerable to every transitory encounter. The olfactory sense interweaves emotions and memories and prompts a ripple of the many souvenirs. Read on as Pranjal Srivastava, 3rd year, COE and Ritvik Nair, 3rd year, COE untangle the composition behind scents entwined with our childhood memories and describe how ‘pieces of memories are what we leave behind in the past, just like the playground we have outgrown’.
body:
The olfactory sense is the strongest sense for eliciting nostalgic memories. A scent or smell has the most profound ability to stir even the deepest corners of our memories. I remember a friend who told me that, as I felt a strangely familiar, warm smell on an unusually inimical winter evening. I know this smell from a similar evening, a similar walk back in the first year but with a very different me. The vague feeling of some known comfort somehow connected these different dots over the long stream of time.

Human beings perceive time on a logarithmic scale. That is to say, time picks up the pace as we steer our way through life. Childhood seems like something that lasted forever, not very long ago. Perhaps that is why we have the fondest memories from that time. We go back to these memories every time we encounter a relic from that guileless age—the toys we became too old to play with, the anecdotes that our mothers recount so adoringly on quiet afternoons. When we see kids living what we once lived through, it’s all a slice of that same vaguely familiar comfort. As we see the world around us unfolding, we seek more of it. 

Like the playground where we spent countless days with friends, we return there only to see the structures that towered over us are now barely taller than us. The monkey bars we used to struggle on now need us to crouch down to hold them properly. The swing where we pointlessly swung on now barely fits us. The slide that used to be the joy of our days is not even a second long, just like the ‘older kids’ of that time long gone, whom we remember doing the same thing as us today. It is a memory that we leave behind in the past, just like the playground we have outgrown.

Just by growing older, the very way we see the world changes. This realization hits especially hard when we return to an old house we lived in as a child after many years. The house feels surprisingly small. The ceiling, which used to be as far as the skies, is now just a stool length away. The floor, which took many strides to traverse, can now be scaled in just a few steps. 

Just like how scents and smells disappear after a while, our childhoods also fade away as we grow older. Yet the feelings and emotions we felt from them remain, much like how we return to the scents that we love, the memories of our past form a shelter where we can always come back to for a short while. Perhaps College is where this search is the most conspicuous. We rediscover pieces that were lost in the relentless pursuit of exams and seats. We paint the canvas of the new world around us with colors of what we have known in sheer childlike excitement. The slow moments of languor ironically remind us how fast time is making those things around us a part of that same nostalgic train. 

And it is to those moments I credit the realization that life is us filling in the blanks of new experiences. We become who we are through what we have lived. To come back to that solace is natural, and that is what nostalgia does. It sums up who we have been, like the known cracks and crevices of your own home. It gives perspective on what we could be. It’s an ease that relieves the turmoil of the new, and maybe make long walks like these a lot shorter.

title: CAT Diaries | Nilabh Jha, EE, Class of 2022
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Nilabh Jha, EE, Class of 2022, who secured a 99.9 percentile in the CAT 2021 examination.
body:
Why did you feel inclined towards preparing for the CAT out of all the different options available to you?

The decision to pursue an MBA was the key behind opting for CAT. Once I was sure about the first part, the list of potential exams boiled down to CAT and GMAT. MBA from abroad usually requires work experience and the situation in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic also acted as a deterrent, Therefore, I decided to prepare for CAT and complete my studies in India itself. 

Briefly take us through your preparation journey. What is it that you feel you did differently from others?

I started my preparation around the beginning of 2021 and joined Alchemist, a coaching institute. To begin with, I attempted a couple of actual CAT papers (2019 Slot 1 and 2020 Slot 3) to gauge my ability without any formal preparation. I focused on improving the flaws I discovered through this until May. After that, I gave mock tests from Alchemist and IMS till November. In terms of what was unique in my journey, I tailored the course according to my strengths and weaknesses instead of studying everything equally. The other thing that I did well, in my opinion, was that I took as many mock tests as I was comfortable with, contrary to the popular advice of a set number that an aspirant has to attempt per week on the basis of the proximity to the real exam.

How would you advise a candidate to approach the test?

My advice would be to attempt a few actual CAT papers in the beginning. If you are able to score over 50%, then just mock tests from any reputed coaching institute would suffice. If not, jot down the mistakes and look for recurring patterns. Start your preparation from the topics you are weak at and move towards your strengths. There is no best way that exists to attempt a section or the whole paper, so you will have to figure out the intricacies before building your own way of taking the exam through mock tests and their analyses.

What are your future plans after achieving such a phenomenal score?

In terms of my immediate future, I want to study at one of the top 3 IIMs or XLRI. Beyond that, management consulting intrigues me but I am still open to other options based on my interaction with the students, teachers and the subjects that will be taught in the above-mentioned colleges.

What advice would you like to give to your juniors who wish to pursue the same career path as yours?

Be determined about your decision to prepare for CAT or any other other entrance exams, as it will take up a lot of effort and pursuing MBA from one of India’s (or any other nation’s) top B-Schools is a significant financial investment. There will be a lot of uncertainty in your preparation phase regarding the mock test scores but take it as practice before a battle. The more you bleed here, the better you will be when you face the real test. 

College placements will be a crucial period since a lot of your friends will be getting selected at top companies; treat it as motivation for your journey instead of letting it affect your focus. Apart from all this, the one thing you need to trust the most is your ability to make decisions and execute them. There will be a lot of noise around; block most of it, listen to some good advice and trust yourself.

title: Interview | Literature & Film Council, DTU
biliner: DTU Times caught up with the Literature & Film Council of DTU and quizzed them on what goes into organising North India's biggest literature fest, Yuvaan, the crown jewel of the university's ensemble of fests.
body:
Yuvaan has always provided its audience with all sorts of engrossing events. And even with the shift of education to synchronised online learning, the events continued with a similar engagement. How did this shift affect the process of organisation and coordination for the team? What are the lesser known or unchartered differences that exist between offline and online events?

Ney Vatsa (Fest Secretary): During lockdown, when we were in second year of college, we were still holding the position of heads in Yuvaan and our council was yet to be released. We had just organised a beautiful fest of  Yuvaan 2020 and didn’t want things to go dormant. As we shifted to the online mode, we didn’t want the medium of entertainment to be a restraint. So, we began by researching how other online events were being organised. An online event wasn’t something that was happening for the first time. Many organisations had already been conducting their events online. So, we just had to bring this approach into our practice. This shift from offline to online learning was certainly huge. It is definitely easier to work and manage things offline than online. Nevertheless, being the fest secretary during this period, I learnt certain lessons. 

The first and the foremost lesson was that it is very important to motivate your own team members to come forward and participate. 

This is the first thing that one needs to tackle when they are a member of the council. Also, the major responsibility of our council was that we had to undertake responsibilities when the radical change from offline to online had just begun and being at the pitch of this transitional phase, it was also a major challenge to work with the first years as they only had had few months of offline college experience with not much knowledge of organising events. Merely participating in two fests doesn’t really give one the vision and the clarity of how exactly things take place behind the curtains. With all these factors clubbed together, we had to tackle these one by one. 

Meetali Choudhary (Fest Secretary): It is true that we were the council that undertook responsibilities when we shifted from offline to online and then back to the offline ecosystem. During that time, it was for the first time that all these fests were supposed to be conducted online at a college level and we required engagement there as well. When it’s a cultural fest, people are usually excited in their own way. However, when we talk about a literature fest, it is required that we acquaint the audience with it. In an offline fest, we would have events like book launches, we would have authors visiting us as a part of certain events. For the film fest, we would have short films streamed at the BR Auditorium. 

So, all this wasn’t a possibility if we were organising the fest completely online. We would have to approach the audience through a meet link instead of inviting them to spots like the OAT or the BR Auditorium, for them to enjoy literature and film. 

Along with that, the major problem that occurred was that we had to reach people through calls and messages. Additionally, it becomes difficult to motivate a team solely through online meets. Although adding to it, once the team was motivated, as everything was going online - from artists joining to making sure that technically everything was being managed well - we saw people grow and also learnt of better ways to motivate  people. 

We’ve always had the chance of witnessing a diverse ensemble of renowned guests through Yuvaan. How difficult does it get when it comes to approaching the guests for the events and how different is it for online and offline events?

Meetali: The way we approach guests is almost similar in both ways - offline and online. However, when things go offline, the availability of guests does reduce. But there was a phase in between our online period, when the spread of COVID was at its peak, asking people to be a part of Yuvaan’s events was a challenge as everyone was having their own issues due to the spread of COVID. But again, the way of approaching was much similar to what it used to be otherwise. Finding out and fixing slots for online events was much easier as when it’s offline, guests usually have different commitments already taking place.

Ebani Gupta (Treasurer): It certainly is largely the same when it comes to only approaching the artists and the guests. We used to reach out to them through Instagram, mails or through their managers or by approaching different event management companies. And all this was largely done via telephonic conversations or emails or messages. But, the large difference that came about was in their availability and also the kind of quotations that they brought about as we didn’t have to carry the expense of their travel or stay. We were aware of the expenses and the funds that we would be requiring, but considering the experience that Yuvaan always tries to provide and to keep up with the name we have tried to maintain, we had to take measures about a whole different scenario. And as we did not have much guidance to go about the working of online events, we had to find out ways on our own and altogether it was an enriching experience.

There are some challenges that come with being a part of a literary council especially in a college that is highly technical in nature with not a lot of people having an inclination towards literature which is an unlikely scenario in a university like DU. How do you manage to engage so many DTU students even with such little literary appreciation?

Ney: When we were preparing for JEE and looking for colleges later, most of us looked into how DTU’s fests were and probably ended up being mesmerised by the YouTube videos of Engifest. 

With these videos of Engifest already being a thing ingrained in our minds, we entered DTU with high expectations. 

So, it is a pressure to match that level and make sure that these expectations are satisfactorily met. In 2020, when Yuvaan conducted its fourth edition, it turned out to be a big hit. So, we had to match that level too and also take forward the legacy left behind by our seniors. Hence, maintaining motivation is certainly the key. This may have gained more traction in a DU college but we definitely don’t have less appreciation here as well. Yuvaan has a significant recognition for itself now and everyone is a part of it in one way or the other - be it directly or indirectly. It’s not just about being a literature enthusiast but it is also about enjoying the events in a way that you feel a sense of pride for being a part of its organisation. 

Meetali: Also, regarding the appreciation of literature in our college, we have Sahitya as a society and the members do have this sense of praise and acclamation towards literature. The percentage of people with this sense of recognition might differ when we compare our university with that of any DU college, but it isn’t completely absent. One of the major challenges that we usually have pertaining to this view is that we have to make sure we meet the expectations of the people who actually look up to literature fests. Even though the percentage of such literature enthusiasts is less, we need to ensure that we match up to their excitement and fulfil the expectations that they have. Along with this, luckily as we are not just restricted to our college, seeing people from other colleges participate with such enthusiasm motivates the students of DTU as well.

Ebani: The whole fact that technical fields and literature fields are viewed with such contrasts has a beauty in itself. How we can bring about diversity in our college with literature and how well it is appreciated is admirable. A certain DU college may have better recognition but seeing the response here in DTU also we get to know how diversified the personalities here are. 

As a part of the Yuvaan team, how have your perceptions and opinions on literature as a form of art been influenced?

Ney: I have been fond of literature since my childhood, I even used to write at times. That is the reason why I joined Yuvaan after being intrigued by it in my first year when Rajat Sood had performed in Pehli Mulaqat and some poets had performed as a part of it during our orientation. 

Entering such a challenging level where students were organising such huge events and inviting such renowned artists became one of the factors that motivated me to join the Yuvaan team. 

And I got to learn a lot about literature as a member of this team. I got to know about the various forms of literature. Also, I used to think I could write but now that view has completely changed. I am now following the Jaipur Literature & Film Festival and what all things are happening there. I am also following the Bangalore Literature and Film Festival and everything having relevance to it. There are a lot of personal changes that I have experienced as a part of this literature and film council. So, it is not just about the changes that you see overall but it is also about the personal changes.

Meetali: In my first year, I was not one of the literature enthusiasts. But, once I became a part of  Yuvaan - working as a volunteer, then as a head - I got to see a lot of artists performing and got to experience a lot of Kavi Sammelans. With this, there was a different inclination that I imbibed in myself & I realised how nice it all was. 

I then started exploring various poets and artists and later in my second year I began writing myself. 

I had never thought that this change would have taken place in me by just being a part of a fest. So, it is true that Yuvaan has had a different impact on me on a personal basis. The more you explore the more you begin to appreciate. There is change that then takes place. While you are exploring artists you also begin to start appreciating their work.

Ebani: We realise the importance of literature in every field. I remember, when we were once deciding the theme for the fest, we realised that every theme had its inception from literature itself. We ended up discussing exceptional ideas emerging from literature unlike the conventional ones which people usually associate with literature. Literature is much more and much beyond what we usually think of and this can be shared and presented to the whole world. It isn’t something that is merely kept restricted to oneself. 

What was your motivation to join the council and what kept you motivated to stay there? Now that you are graduating, what is your key takeaway from being a part of it?

Meetali: While we were working as heads in our second year, we realised ‌Yuvaan had reached a notable platform. It had grown from being a small fest to now being a big platform. While we were preparing for Yuvaan 2020, and putting in the hard work, calling for artists, and planning the events; we felt that this time we should do something big. Our motive was to show that literature has its own impact. When the day of the fest came and when we had our events, and we saw so many people appreciating the literature event, that motivated us like crazy. I remember the last day of Yuvaan, all of us were standing, and we knew that we had pulled it off. We had never thought that we could have a literature festival at this level, with people who appreciate literature to this extent. That was the time we realised that we have 2 years of college left, so we have to make sure we do something big. And we wanted to experience the same happiness and satisfaction each year.

As heads, we saw how our council members were working - going to meetings, going to the admin, and discussing events. We were in the background and engaging in ideas, but we saw the pressure the council had to go through and the amount of hard work they were doing. We were so motivated by them. Unfortunately, afterwards, things got online, so we couldn’t conduct an offline fest. Then there was another challenge with an online fest, to pull something new. Yuvaan had never been online before. When ‘Pehli Mulaqat’  took place for the first time, there were so many people in our college who were very excited and I had received so many requests stating that they also wanted to be a part of Yuvaan when the itinerary was released.

Our main takeaway would be that even if something is not huge but you believe it has the potential, and you pull it off, that can give you a lot of teachings along the journey and a lot of pride too.  

From just managing a team to having an artist onboard, every experience is a lesson in itself. Every person who approaches an artist for the first time, surely commits a mistake. These mistakes help you learn a lot. From managing the events with the team, managing what your team and faculty advisors want, you grow in so many ways. So if there's something that you think is difficult to pull off and if you take it as a challenge, it will be a different level of happiness when you actually do.

Ney: For me it all started with the 3-day event in 2020, when on the last day the sense of relief and pride I derived by looking at the crowd and the rush of emotions on realising we had done this and pulled this off. We knew it was just the beginning. We knew we needed to continue with this in order to go big. We didn't want to be compared with any other event happening in DTU, but we wanted Yuvaan to be recognised as something big, not only within DTU, but across Delhi and the country. We wanted it to be a celebrated fest that people would come to visit from Bombay or maybe some other college from the East. Even though things happened online, I'm satisfied that we, as a team, pulled this off. Even with the transition to online mode, and regardless of all other commitments and emergencies, we successfully organised this event. 

We tried to bring artists of different genres; and organised many events. The feeling and the sense of ownership that we got was our major motivation.

I have a lot of takeaways. I made a lot of friends, whom I can call and ask for anything at any time. Apart from that, I gained a perspective on how a team should be managed, the legalities you work with when you approach the clients, and the meetings you attend to. A lot of things were happening at the same time, so we had to stay grounded. We also had to think about the first years and their perspectives.

We have always witnessed ingenuity from Yuvaan's end. How does the team brew up such creative concepts and such great ideas? What goes behind the decision-making process?

Kshitiz Raj (Treasurer): It is the work of the team members who work together and come up with great ideas, with different points of view and thought processes. The diversity that we have in Yuvaan is what leads us to great ideas. People from different years, and from different colleges pitch in and I think this is the reason we are able to come up with different ideas about the themes.

Meetali: A healthy discussion is an important factor. 

Every person has either heard or knows about Yuvaan, so whenever all of us sit down for a discussion, everyone puts forward different opinions and ideas, adding novel ideas to the discussion. 

With everyone pitching their opinions, along with everyone else adding on to it, you put together something that you would have never thought of. And this is because this visualisation in the end isn’t an outcome of just one person’s opinions, but it is a mixture of various opinions and perspectives. As the final idea is a mix of everyone’s ideas, the mixture results in something huge, something which you had never thought of.

Ney: ‘More the merrier’ is an important venture when it comes to discussing ideas. It isn’t just my fest, it is everyone's fest so we want everyone to contribute to Yuvaan. So everyone participates in the decision making process. There is no particular process, but we keep the ideas coming in and then we settle on a decision unanimously.

Ebani: One point about brainstorming is that there is no hierarchy. It is totally flat in nature. Even a volunteer's point of view is taken into consideration as much as that of a council member. We just need to keep in mind what the authorities would not allow. Yet for effective brainstorming, everyone is involved. So we have a lot of meetings to just sit down and think about a lot of ideas.

What were some ‌responsibilities that you had to undertake as a member of this council? What were some ‌responsibilities that you felt were a transformative experience for all of you?

Kshitiz: Being a treasurer, I’d say managing funds during the fest is itself a huge responsibility. 

During the 3-day fest, I must have felt like the governor of RBI. 

I would say that managing funds, managing the people from different colleges and DTU students, managing the volunteers and the events which are happening is an enormous responsibility in itself. 

Ebani: I think realising where things can potentially go wrong and fixing it early is a responsibility. 

The frequency of hurdles we had throughout the journey has helped me come out as a much more patient person since I have to understand and analyse ‌every person's opinion. 

I can't simply disrespect the person's idea. So we have to respect each and every person. It just calms you down overall.

Meetali: I would say that there wasn’t any particular responsibility, personally speaking. Even the smallest of things that we think can create a lot of issues in the future. So we point them out and manage them.

What are some of the steps you took to maximise the traction? How do you deal with any undesirable interruptions or any challenges during the event?

Meetali: It is important to understand the target audience. The next thing is targeting and reaching out to them in various ways like social media, mails, collaborating with their college societies, partnerships, etc. 

Along with that, communication is important. Communication gaps will never help you solve any interruptions. 

I remember we had several emergency meetings to solve the issues. So, communicating with the entire council, each of whom will have a different idea to solve an issue. And then we can conclude to find an optimal way.

Ney: Handling the interruptions by listening. Generally, there is a reason behind it. Best way to deal with it is to listen and not react imprudently. Think about it before you react and then process it. And then take whatever appropriate action needs to be taken. This is something I learned as a fest secretary.

Ebani: You need to realise if there is a reason for the problem and think about how you can actually tackle that and hit the bull’s eye. Presence of mind plays a crucial role and you need to realise what is the need of the hour and how you can handle it accordingly. 

You need to solve the problem in the most efficient manner by being calm, because the frequency of such undesirable events is very high. 

As a council member, you realise that the responsibility is on you. So even if a volunteer makes a slight mistake, you are responsible for it. If a council member makes any mistake, then also you are responsible for it. So being calm and dealing with situations accordingly is an important factor one needs to take into account.

Kshitiz: There is a saying that ‘Mountains move for a determined team’. And I think these four people present here eliminated any problem that came during the fest in these three years and I think that the teamwork that we have had was the main reason behind the elimination of every obstacle.
meta_description: DTU Times caught up with the Literature & Film Council of DTU and quizzed them on what goes into organising North India's biggest literature fest, Yuvaan, the crown jewel of the university's ensemble of fests.

title: One Little Thanks
biliner: Throughout our lives, there is one person who always forgives us no matter what and warms us with their love. Read on as Ritvik Nair, 2nd year, COE shows a moment where one little thank you helps us reconcile with the one who cares the most.
body:
His tiny hands clenched his teddy bear tightly. Drops of his tears drenched the fur of the plush. With a trembling chin, he slowly opened his mouth only for no words to come out. The grip on his bear tightening, he gave it another go and in a trembling voice said, “Than-thank you.”

His words, like the sun on a winter day, melted her heart. Her anger and frustration thawed as she motioned him to come to her with open hands. She grasped him tightly within her warm and loving embrace. Her eyes overflowed with tears as she gently whispered into his ears, “You’re welcome.”

“I’m sorry for getting angry,” the boy mumbled. “I thought Teddy was gone because of you.”

“It’s okay,” his mother consoled. “But next time, just make sure with me, okay?”

The boy silently nodded in his mother’s grasps. With his tearful eyes closed, he stayed there a while longer, snuggling closer. The mother also didn’t let go, gratefully accepting her crying son.

After staying together for a while longer, they moved apart. They looked at each other’s faces that were covered in dried tears. Their eyes then moved to the snot-covered bear that had been crushed between the two. Then, their eyes met. Just with that, the silence broke into loud laughter.

“Looks like Teddy will be taking another bath,” the mother laughed.

“I-I won’t get angry this time when you take him,” her son said.

“Is that so?” the mother asked. “Put him in the laundry basket and let’s go have some dinner.”

title: Edition 55 | Runaway
biliner: Our childhoods are a mixed bag of both fond and tearful memories that form the person we now are. Read on as Shaurya Shekhar, 3rd Year, COE explores overcoming the fear of one's childhood.
body:
Soon after having a heated argument with her partner, Sandra left to visit her parents. Even as she was driving, she kept thinking of the fight, how she abruptly left in the middle of it, and how detached she felt at the moment. Upon reaching her parents’ home, she tried to continue with her routine, putting on a facade of indifference. 


She came across her childhood room, and as she went through her old things, she thought, “I guess I was always the one to run away.” She recalled the time when as a kid, she used to keep playing with her toys even as she heard screaming voices from downstairs, trying as hard as possible to ignore them and act confident. “Why did I even do that?” she exclaimed, “Why didn’t I ever go down to see what was going on?”. She remembered how her younger brother used to feel scared hearing those noises but would calm down on seeing her act normal despite everything. “I couldn’t have left him alone, I guess.” She started tearing up as she recalled all those times when after putting her little brother to sleep, she cried in a corner, with a pillow in her mouth, trying to stifle any voice that might disturb him. “I wanted him to be safe … I wanted to be safe.” 


After a couple of minutes, she wiped her tears and walked back to her car, still feeling hazy about her memories yet much lighter. She remembered how even when she saw her mother try to hide her bruises the morning after, she would pay no attention to it, as those bruises would bring back memories of the night before. “Why did I ignore those signs? … Why am I still trying to act tough?” She thought about the fight from before, how it all made sense that she ran away from it and how she acted aloof to her partner’s feelings. She called her partner up and said, “Hey! Let’s talk about today.”
meta_description: Our childhoods are a mixed bag of both fond and tearful memories that form the person we now are. Read on as Shaurya Shekhar, 3rd Year, COE explores overcoming the fear of one's childhood.

title: Edition 55 | बचपन की याद कभी भूल नहीं जाना रे
biliner: बचपन भी बड़ा कमाल का होता है, न कल की फ़िक्र होती है न ही आज का कोई ठिकाना। पढ़िए अपने बचपन की यादों को अक्षर के माध्यम से आप सभी के सामने रखते हुए अंकित कुमार , चतुर्थ वर्ष, आई. टी. का यह लेख।
body:
अंकित कुमाद, चतुर्थ वर्ष, आईटी. 


बचपन! जी हाँ, उसी बचपन की बात कर रहा हूँ जहाँ हर रोज़ घरों में शहनाई थजती थी। हाँ-हाँ, हर रोज़ शहनाई! हर एक दिन 
गुड्ढे-गुड़ियों की शादी जो करा करते थे, नाचना-गाना छोता था। वो मनोरंजन किसी असली शादी से कम थोड़े न था।
बचपन में मकर-संक्रान्ति के दिनों में घंटो पतंग की डोर थामे हम लोग उड़ा करते थे, और अब वक्‍त के साथ बचपन ऐसे सिमट रहा है मानो इसका वजूद ही खत्म हो जाएगा। बचपन की बात ज़िद्दु के बिना कभी खत्म हो सकती है क्या? दशहरे के मेले में खिलौनों की ज़िदद, दिवाली में पटाखों की ज़िद्द्‌ इत्यादि। और हाँ इतनी-सी ज़िद पूरी होने पर ऐसा लगता था जैसे की पूरी कायनात मिल गई हो। दिल की. हर एक आरजू, हर एक मुराद पूरी हो गई हो। और जहाँ तक मुझे लगता है तो ज़्यादा कुछ नहीं बदला है उम्र बढ़ने के साथ, सिर्फ बचपन की ज़िद्द समझौतों में बदल गई। 


अरे ! सपने संजोने थाली उन मासूम-सी आँखों का क्या कसूर, 
नादान दिल की वो तो प्लिर्फ एक छवि, एक पहवान हैं। 
 

बचपन का समय बहुत अधिक मिठास भरा एव चंचल रहता था और शायद इसीलिए 
हर एक इंसान बचपन को दोबारा जीना चाहता है। बचपन में धीरे-धीरे चलना, गिर 
पड़ना और फिर उठकर ऐसे चलना मानो गिरे ही न हों बहुत ही ज़्यादा याद आता है। 
तभी तो प्रसिद्ध गीतकार सुदर्शन फाकीर लिखते है : - 


ये दौलत भी ले लो,ये शोहरत भी ले लो, 
भले छीन लो मुझसे मेरी जवानी। 
मगर मुझको लौटा दो बचपन का सावन, 
वो कागज को कस्ती , वो बारिश का पानी॥

title: Interview | Archna Bhardwaj, Executive Director (Shipping), Indian Oil Corporation
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Ms. Archna Bhardwaj, noted alumna of DCE who currently holds the position of Executive Director (Shipping) at Refineries Headquarters, Indian Oil Corporation. Ms. Bhardwaj, in her 40-year long career, has achieved a series of milestones, the latest being her felicitation as the Woman of the Year in the Oil and Gas Industry by the Federation of Indian Petroleum Industry (FIPI). Her dazzling professional success becomes even more commendable on account of the many challenges she has faced in the workplace because of her gender. We hope that her journey inspires all of us to reach our goals despite all the roadblocks in our path.
body:
Could you briefly walk us through your experience in DCE as an undergraduate student? According to you, how has DCE impacted the various aspects of your life, both professionally and personally?

I had an eventful and enriching experience while studying at  DCE. My  interactions with students from various backgrounds were extremely interesting and served to broaden my horizons.  Joining DCE was not a pre-planned move from my side because there were no engineers in the family and I didn’t receive any guidance. It was only by chance that I filled up the admission form for DCE and got admitted into the engineering field. Getting educated in the DCE campus made me feel very proud because I was the first engineer in the family, and it groomed my personality. Now,  I can proudly say that  joining DCE was my destiny and  best decision of my life, both  personally and professionally.

Any anecdotes you would like to share from that time?

Our college life during those days was very disciplined and organised; there were simply no strikes or mass bunks! The atmosphere was conducive for studying with barely any distractions present nearby. We did have our fair share of fun, however, when we used to miss classes so that we could attend the International Trade Fair at Pragati Maidan. College elections, which used to happen in September every year, too were an extremely enriching experience as they gave us the opportunity to interact with probable candidates from various backgrounds. Overall, DCE was more reminiscent of a school with class tests being conducted every Monday and Thursday. Some subjects, particularly Mechanical Drawing and Applied Mechanics, were a nightmare for students who had no previous knowledge of them, with most of us struggling to clear those papers. Group assignments were also a truly memorable experience as students used to work around the clock to finish their work as the deadline drew near.

A particularly memorable incident occurred while at a survey camp at Dehradun. Staying in an Ashram at Dehradun was a very pleasant experience which deepened the bond between classmates besides enriching knowledge. The entire class was divided in four to five groups to survey the Dehradun-Mussoorie Road. Our group did the survey but at the time of plotting the readings,  the road which was supposed  to go to a hill was going towards a  valley.  Alarm bells rang and each one of us went again early in the morning and worked again and finally got the right ( desired)  readings.  This is one of the most memorable experiences of studying in DCE.

You have been recently honoured as the Woman Executive of the Year in the Oil and Gas Industry by FIPI. What factors would you credit as being the driving force behind this achievement?

I think my sincerity towards my job and my adaptability have been very important virtues. I am a Civil Engineer, basically, but I've been posted to various departments in IndianOil - in projects, training, administration, ministry coordination, handling materials and contracts, and for the last two years I have been handling shipping, which is an entirely different field not many people are conversant with. My posting in the Shipping Department was at a time when COVID-19 had just started and I was trying to learn the basics of Shipping.  There was a major challenge to maintain the supply of Crude Oil (major raw material) for our business to various refineries.  In spite of all the hardships and challenges, there was no break in the supply of Crude Oil and the company continued its business as usual.  

Last year, one of our huge carriers of crude caught fire near the Sri Lankan coast. Had those two million barrels of crude spilled in the sea, it would have been a major catastrophe from both the environmental and diplomatic point of view; the Sri Lankan economy is driven by tourism and had there been a spillage in the sea, it would have been disastrous.The engine of the vessel was totally damaged and there were doubts on its structural safety. A huge exercise was conducted for dousing the fire with the help of the Indian Navy, Indian Coast Guards, Sri Lankan Authorities and IOCL, a process  which  took almost a week. The casualty ship was towed by 7-8 tugboats and taken to a port in UAE after which it was transferred to some small vessels. This was a very tedious exercise because testing the structural stability of the ship enroute, a journey of more than two thousand nautical miles, was a challenge and many countries were involved during the journey. These included The Maldives, Oman and UAE, and diplomatic permissions were required. This was a very challenging task which we ultimately handled in time and managed to save crude worth Rs. 674 crore while averting a major potential environmental disaster.

Further, during the pandemic, a shortage of oxygen was felt all over the country.  In compliance with our company’s motto of ‘Pehle India Phir Oil’,  we arranged oxygen tankers from Singapore, airlifting some and transporting others through ships during the tough times when Oxygen was in acute shortage all over the country. I credit the senior management and the  team of the Shipping Department who supported me in handling these challenges. I, along with my senior team members did not miss a single day in office in spite of the COVID-19 outbreak. 

How did you overcome these ordeals?

I think a few things are very important, the first being sincerity and adaptability and the other, believing in yourself. Wherever you go, create your own brand value. Everyone does a routine job but you must do something different which distinguishes you from the others. I always tell my colleagues and the people who work with me to create their own brand value.

You've been a part of Indian Oil for almost 40 years at this point and you've worked for a variety of domains and projects. Is there one that you find particularly fascinating? And if so, why?

A project which is very close to my heart is the implementation of access control systems across all locations. This initiative was taken in 2003-2004 and at that time, biometrics were very remote in PSUs and government organizations with people in general not being very pleased about the system of entering and punching. It was very important to implement this system to ensure punctuality and then to find a suitable  technology to be implemented which would further survive another 30-40 years. I was inducted into a particular group because of this project, and I am very proud to say that this project was implemented successfully at 400 locations of IndianOil. We selected the technology which is still working across all locations.

Another important project was a grassroot Panipat refinery project for which I was associated right from the time we were selecting the land and getting the depository works done through the state ministries, township planning, refinery planning and further commissioning activities; commissioning is the time when a lot of activities happen at the site and even at the headquarters. I am very proud to be associated with the Panipat refinery project. This refinery is standing tall and one of the most modern refineries present in the country today.  As a materials and contracts head, I have faced many challenges like arranging things for various time bound projects. In any project, 60-70% of the work is procurement of materials and tendering. If you achieve that in time, the projects will also be completed in time. I have handled procurement for projects worth more than  one lakh crores  in IndianOil as well as smoothly facilitated the implementation of various GOI  policies like GeM, MSME and Public Procurement Policy. Our organization received the Super Buyer Award for implementing GeM policy and the first prize for implementing the MSME guidelines in the public sector. Implementing these policies was also a great challenge.

You also mentioned that you faced a variety of challenges as one of the few female engineers in your organization and had to juggle the responsibilities of motherhood with your professional commitments. How did you overcome these hurdles?

When I look back on the years, I can say it was definitely not very easy for me to come this far . I was married into an orthodox family which was not conversant with the pressures faced by a working woman. I had to balance  my domestic and professional roles which put immense pressure on me mentally and physically. While taking care of two young children with a challenging job, I often felt like leaving my job because the demands of the home were so much more. My mother and husband were a great support to me during that time. My mother was a principal of a government school and we were groomed in an atmosphere where the ladies of the house were working. Her continuous emotional support and motivation kept me going. The only reason I am here today is because of  my mother’s consistent encouragement  .

During this period, my husband also provided tremendous support in  handling tough situations with me. We were also lucky enough to avail the services of good house-helps. A part of the credit for my success goes to my house-helps as well; because of them, I could do certain things and devote much more time in the office. But yes, those five to six years during which my children were young were really tough.

One thing I would like to convey, particularly to working women, is to never let people feel that you would leave your work in between when the domestic need arises. You must make sure that you complete whatever job you take despite the domestic requirements.. Dependability is very important in a career as seniors will not give responsibility to a person who is not dependable.  Children must know the importance of the work you are doing and the accompanying benefits that result when both the parents are working. Sub-delegate your responsibilities; ensure that your husband and children also contribute to the functioning of the house.

Were there any particular challenges you faced in the workplace considering the male-dominated environment present in your organization at that time?

Yes, there were many challenges as I joined a male dominated field.  When I joined the Mathura refinery, I was the only woman working there. At that time, colleagues were not used to having women at work and basic facilities like ladies toilets were absent. Particularly during outside tours and training, women were never consulted and decisions made on their behalf  presuming that it will be difficult for them to leave home. As a result many good opportunities to visit various places and learn new skills were missed out. The situation at the workplace too was extremely challenging. It was difficult to find company even during the commute to the office as colleagues would find it difficult to mingle with their female counterparts. It was extremely lonely staying away from home for the first time and in a male dominated area.

My first job was to handle contracts and tendering and my boss was extremely protective of me, so much so that he refused to let me face contractors for opening the tenders.. The consequence of this was that I started developing an inferiority complex; I started to feel that I was being left out of some important tasks just because I am a lady. After 2-3 years, I started working under a different boss who asked me to open a tender. I had to tell him that I was unaware about the process, having never experienced it before. He then deputed a colleague to guide me during one or two tenders, following which I took up the responsibility myself. During my journey, I was guided by many such mentors who shaped my journey in Indian Oil and acted as pillars of support.

There were many such problems on the way. Initially, since the number of female officers were very less, there were incidents in which one of my bosses would get up and open the door of his cabin whenever I was present inside. I used to feel very bad about it initially. However, as the confidence between us grew and the situation changed, things took a turn for the better. I am very happy to say that I get along very well with my male colleagues and I don’t find any difference while working with them.

During your extensive career, what changes have you observed in the situation of women in the workplace?

Gradually, things are improving now as more women are joining these organizations with the mindset of male colleagues also changing in keeping pace with this new reality. Women are now posted in every department, including night shifts. The facilities offered to women at the unit-level and the plant-level have also increased proportionally.

In the earlier days, women engineers were not  assigned shift duties. Nowadays, they are deputed for night shifts and other male dominated departments. These women  are confident and smart; they are working as location incharges, in bottling plants and inside the refineries. It is extremely heartening to see them doing well in every field. Our organization is providing them with a large number of facilities as well and we are very proactive about the development of women and inclusive growth. We have many programs dedicated to furthering female leadership. Whenever there are any foreign training programs, 20-30% women are always deputed for these programs. This provides women with a large number of opportunities for their growth. We have a networking module called Maitreyi which is a  platform for women to come together to interact and guide each other and also have knowledge sharing sessions.

Overall, I’m quite happy with the way my organization is working towards women empowerment. The refineries division of IOCL is now going to be headed by a female director which is a very proud moment  for all the women of IOCL.

Over the years, there has been a radical shift in the career aspirations of many young professionals. With a lot of them opting to work in the private sector or choosing to move abroad for higher studies, the appeal of a job in the public sector seems to have lessened. According to you, what initiatives should be taken by public sector companies to make them more attractive to young professionals?

I think that because the young professionals of today are smarter and more digitized, the old ways of working will not appeal to them anymore. Companies need to become smarter to keep pace with this change. Even small things like attire or the way people conduct themselves is very different in a private sector company.

As far as remuneration is concerned, that is another big draw that attracts people to a private sector company. In a PSU, we are governed by government guidelines and cannot pay our employees as much as private sector companies do. Nevertheless, the job security and perks that one receives in a PSU cannot be weighed in money and are very important indeed. In the past 2-3 years, however, even PSUs have become very lucrative considering the lockdowns and layoffs that took place during that period. Youngsters from IITs and IIMs are also joining IOCL and day by day, PSUs are becoming more and more competitive and at par with their counterparts in the private sector. Even in our interactions with licensors and other private parties and in our discussions with them, we find that they are impressed by the way we do our jobs.

Do you feel that things would be even better if more PSUs encouraged the culture of research among the young professionals joining them?

I think that these days, almost all PSUs have their R&D divisions which promote research. The Prime Minister of India started a policy in which we give support to researchers and new startups. I think this is definitely very helpful.

Here in IOCL, we have a very big R&D setup with new licensing technologies. In fact, we have even provided these technologies to other organizations. We are doing very well in the sustainable environment field with the focus on biofuels, CNG, ethanol and hydrogen. There are a variety of new fields of research to attract youngsters to them.

Finally, what advice would you like to give to students who wish to achieve success in their respective fields? Is there a mantra for success that you personally follow?

According to me, there is no particular mantra or recipe for success. The only important things are self-belief, sincerity, adaptability and creating our own brand value. My experiences during my career corroborate this fact.

Skill upgradation and diversifying the portfolio as per need is also very important because the requirements of the trade are changing at supersonic speed and unless we keep pace with changing scenarios, we will be left out in the race.

title: KU Leuven | Internship Experience
biliner: Vishal Sharma, Electrical Engineering, Class of 2021, shares his virtual internship experience at KU Leuven, Belgium, as a Hardware Research Intern.
body:
Vishal Sharma, Electrical Engineering, Class of 2021, shares his virtual internship experience at KU Leuven, Belgium, as a Hardware Research Intern.

Back in November 2019, I decided to pursue a master’s in science at a top-ranked university after my bachelor’s. In a bid to diversify my resume, I began searching for a research internship. Having completed multiple iterations of Mars rover prototypes as a part of Team Inferno DTU, I was quite familiar with the concept of research and its methodologies, so I began to seek research opportunities outside India.

Around that time, I came to know about Mitacs (Canada), and that excited me a little. It was heart-breaking to find out that you needed at least 8 GPA to make the cut, whereas my GPA at the time was 7.94. I began hunting for similar programmes in India and abroad, and all of them required 8.5+ GPA. Some programmes like DAAD (Germany) and SN Bose (US) even needed 9.0+. Selections in these programmes hinge majorly on your GPA, with preference being given to those from IIT’s. Reality hit me hard.

Nevertheless, I continued my quest for a research internship and applied to every program I could find, with the hopes that my research experience would make up for my GPA. I applied to OIST (Japan), IST Austria, University of Helsinki, CERN, EPFL, and countless other programs. Each program required a statement of purpose, a resume and two letters of recommendation from either professors or employers (internships mentors count here). I did not have a dearth of professors who were willing to write a letter of recommendation on my behalf. However, these programmes required the professors to submit these letters using a link that would be sent to them, and this was just asking for too much. Inferno’s faculty advisor, Prof. P. K. Jain was kind enough to meet most of the deadlines. As for the other professors, the job was easier said than done.

After countless rejections, I got screened for the first time by a professor under the TEEP@AsiaPlus programme in Taiwan. I was directed to write a few essays about my academic background, research experience, and fields of interest. I was then shortlisted for an interview by laboratories at two different Universities in Taiwan. These were the Unmanned Aerial Vehicle, Aerospace Engineering, Computer Vision Lab at Tamkang University and the Process System Engineering, Process Optimisation, Process Simulation Lab at National Chung Hsing University. The interviews were held on Skype, and they discussed my resume for the most part. I was offered a two-month summer internship with a modest stipend of NT$ 10,000/month (around ₹ 25,000 PM) and accommodation. I accepted Tamkang’s offer because they were developing long-range UAVs, a field in which I had some experience, while NCHU was working on battery compositions, a role more suitable for chemical engineers.

After receiving my first internship offer, I felt confident and decided to find universities with research groups operating in the fields of robotics, electronics, and embedded systems. Once I had jotted down a list, I wrote emails to the professors heading these groups. I was honest and direct in my emails. A few of the professors reverted, others did not. In fact, only a few had the funds to support a 2-month summer internship.

A professor from KU Leuven, Belgium showed interest in my profile. KU Leuven ranks among the top 50 universities worldwide and is one of the most sought-after universities in Europe. I was interviewed twice by two PhD scholars on topics related to robotics, and I was given a task to prepare a preliminary research report on nano drones. Ultimately, I was selected. They offered a handsome stipend of €900 per month (about ₹ 80,000 pm) along with medical and travel insurance. I could not have been more excited.

Covid-19 Breakout

Even before I could apply for a visa, COVID-19 broke out. The pandemic hit Europe hard, and flight restrictions were imposed. The paperwork for the visa had already begun, but soon it was no longer possible to go there. Every research programme was cancelled, including MITACS, CERN, etc. A few of them started remotely like the Max Planck Institute. I was extremely upset. I had two offers, and I could not attend even one.

Fortunately, the professor at KU Leuven reached out to me and informed me they have deferred my internship offer to whenever it became possible to travel again. She also asked me if I wanted to collaborate remotely for the time being. I believed that even though it might not be as good as visiting the heart of Europe, it was still something, so I agreed.

(Remote) Hardware Research Internship: First of its Kind

My internship orientation was scheduled for 15th May. I was introduced to the project, which was to develop an Autonomous Nano Drone. This project was developed initially at the Robotics and Perception Lab, ETH Zurich. Our aim was to improve the performance of the drone. After preliminary research, we decided to achieve the goal by implementing a multi-camera array for visual feedback in the drone. I was part of a team supervised by Prof. Verhelst along with two PhD scholars, Mr. Nimish Shah and Mr. Steven Colleman.

However, the big question remained unanswered. How can we do this remotely? Don’t we need actual hardware to work? Does KU Leuven have the required resources and online infrastructure to facilitate the internship?

All my questions were answered as soon as my guest ID was created.

The Intranet

There is a separate intranet for each department in KU Leuven. This intranet is basically a hub to access the innumerable resources the university has to offer. The intranet has features such as Publication Tool, EDA Software (Any paid software you can think of), Rapid PCB Prototyping (Submit a PCB design, collect the PCB a week later) and so on.

The two resources I used most were: remote access to Linux or Windows servers & workstations and remote access to all the popular, cutting-edge FPGA development boards available.

To give you a perspective, they have eight extremely powerful Linux Servers and over a hundred Linux and Windows workstations, with top-end specifications, running 24/7. All of these have proprietary software such as Altium, MATLAB, Simulink, Solidworks, and Ansys pre-installed. Each user has a fast, virtual drive deployed as a samba server, and it is accessible in these workstations. 

The available FPGA boards are connected to these workstations, so to access a particular board, all you need to do is log in to that workstation. Any new development board can be ordered just by filling a form available on the intranet, and it is delivered to the lab within a week.

I had worked in a research team at DTU but had never experienced such a research-driven environment where you are not limited by the resources. This place is genuinely a researcher’s paradise.

Regardless of these resources, we faced a few issues due to the work from home situation. The PhD scholars working with me could visit their offices in KU Leuven only once or twice a week, so even if we had to disconnect a peripheral from the system, we had to wait for a few days. Also, the operating system running on these Linux servers was CentOS. At this point, I had been using Ubuntu for more than 2 years as my primary OS, but still, CentOS had its own problems. I developed all the preliminary code base on my laptop but found many compatibility issues with CentOS later on. Moreover, since these servers were shared resources, nobody had administration privileges, which made everything a bit more difficult.

To provide IT support, KU Leuven has implemented an IT Helpdesk which never goes offline. Once, I could not log in into the server because I had inadvertently changed the “bashrc” file in the Linux server. My issue was resolved within 12 hours. As for the other issues I faced, I received timely help from my mentors.

The Weekly Meetings

We held a weekly meeting every Wednesday to discuss my progress and the challenges I faced. Being the only intern among PhD scholars, I often felt out of place, but everyone was very welcoming and helpful. The people I worked with tremendously increased my interest in a master’s degree.

Moreover, Slack served as a platform to discuss anything and everything. I used it extensively to get help from these amazing people.

Fun fact: Apart from serious channels to discuss the project and other tech-related topics, they had a dedicated channel called #random just to share memes and silly stuff. Even professors shared hilarious memes on this channel.

The Result

The experience was nothing short of magical for me. Not even in my wildest dreams, had I imagined working on a cutting-edge research project from my home. I learned a lot and experienced, first-hand, how research should be done. The most important lessons I learned were consistency, self-management, and the power of routine & discipline.

My GitHub activity from those two months is something I look back upon with pride.

Here is the link to my project repository, please have a look if you are curious about the project:

https://github.com/VishalSharma0309/nano_drone

Since my invitation as an international visiting scholar has been deferred to the winter break, I hope the global situation improves, so I can visit KU Leuven in the upcoming winter. I can only imagine how enriching and fruitful the on-site experience would be.

A Few Takeaways

After having traversed the perilous journey of securing a research internship, here are a few points that you should keep in mind before you embark on the same journey.

  1. Aim for the Top 300
    Our university sponsors research internships to some extent (mostly travel fare and visa). However, the university inviting you must be among the top three hundred institutions 
  2. Follow a schedule while mailing
    Try sending out emails such that they are received around 9-10 AM on Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday at the target university. Absolutely avoid weekends! Trust me, this works.
  3. Personalise Emails
    Avoid using the same email for everything. Modify your e-mails according to the research focus of the particular faculty. Use the name of the professor in the salutation. Do not cc or even bcc these mails.
  4. Deadlines
    For a summer research internship, the programme deadlines usually start in November with the majority of them in January. Try submitting your application a week before the actual deadline, that will give you ample time to get your recommendation letters submitted in time. Similarly, start sending out emails in January for a summer internship.
  5. Devote Time to your Resume, SoPs and LoRs
    These carry a lot of weightage and it takes time to get them right. Don’t sell yourself short on these, but don’t make up stuff. You will have to modify these for each program.
  6. Finalise your “Recommenders” before-hand
    Contact at least two professors or internship mentors well in advance and tell them that they will have to send out quite a few recommendation letters on your behalf. Try drafting these LoR’s on your own before contacting them.
  7. CGPA Matters
    When I was applying, I had a CGPA of 7.94, while many programs had a minimum requirement of 8. So, yes, CGPA matters but so does research experience. Once shortlisted, your knowledge and experience are all that counts. Nevertheless, maintain a 7+ CGPA.
  8. Be Perseverant
    Don’t lose hope if you get rejected. In my experience, you will secure an interview for every 10 internships programs you apply to and get a reply for every 50 emails you send out.
  9. Corporate vs Research Internship
    First, decide whether you want to pursue an internship in a company or an institution. If you are looking to pursue an MS, a research internship is a good option. For reference, the following link has really good resources for students seeking a research internship:
    https://github.com/himahuja/Research-Internships-for-Undergraduates

title: INTERVIEW | PROF. MOHAN M. TRIVEDI, UCSD
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Prof. Mohan M. Trivedi, Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California, San Diego, who was the Guest of Honour at the 1st International Conference on Signal Processing, VLSI and Communication Engineering (ICSPVCE - 2019) organised at DTU.
body:
How have you seen the field of Computer Vision and Robotics evolve over the years?

" One of the most remarkable achievements was the incorporation of Machine Learning."

When you’re a part of the journey, you don’t notice much. But the key changes that have taken place are the resources that are required have increased multifold. When I was a graduate student doing object detection, we were looking at wildlife through aerial sensors and it would take us days to get the results. But today when the students perform such analyses, it gives vast results in no time. Prof. Raj Reddy, a pioneer in Robotics and Computer Vision, had a philosophy that the dissertation results weren’t accurate unless they worked on 4 different types of images. That time it was a rigid thing, but today we perform experiments on large datasets of images. One of the most remarkable achievements was the incorporation of Machine Learning. Earlier, we used predefined features, which needed specific knowledge of the data. Today we have data for every feature available for learning.

Collaboration between academia and industry is very important. In San Diego, as shown in your lecture, you’ve collaborated with industry giants. But in India, we seldom find such collaborations and the existing ones are too limited. What are your views on this?

I think everybody realises that we have the same objectives at a higher level. But we have different expertise and infrastructure. Unless we really put it all together, we cannot solve the problem and nobody wins. So once people have developed some trustworthy relationships, good things will start happening. The industry also is hiring students from universities, so they have a very good idea of happenings inside the universities. The task is the same but the difference in an industry is that there it is commercial and profit-making. The freedom to think freely might not be available in the industry. But if you know people with similar ideas and thinking, you’ll feel comfortable being and working with them.

It is often said that students need to be motivated to pursue research? Do you really think a motivating factor is needed, or this should come from within?

Most successful students I’ve seen have a high amount of self-motivation. Whenever I need to bring in new students, I tell them to interact with other students in the group because peer-to-peer interaction is very important. It might not be necessary for some theorist like Ramanujan, with high thinking skills, but this isn’t the case with us. We certainly want to emphasise that people are respectful of others ideas and help out each other. People understand that I might be helping you today, and you might help me tomorrow. People then enjoy working and collaborating.

What is the biggest challenge that the Robotics industry still faces even today?

"... works in real-life with continuous interaction, without humans feeling threatened"

Safety, Robustness, Generalisation and Human Centeredness. I believe that making one-of-a-kind is no big deal, but making it robust and able to work in a variety of situations as well as interact with humans is very important, and hasn’t been yet achieved. There are a lot of open issues left unresolved. A robot that works in an artificial environment is not needed; what’s required is one which works in real-life with continuous interaction, without humans feeling threatened or stressed.

What final message would you like to give to the students?

I am very impressed and glad to visit DTU. I really wish a large number of students from here contribute to the community of Robotics and Intelligent Systems. I’m sure you’ll be successful. I want to re-emphasise that particularly in this field you might end up building something life-saving. I wish you all the best!

title: JPMorgan Chase & Co. (Glasgow, United Kingdom) | Internship Experience
biliner: Manika Jain, Electrical Engineering, Class of 2023, shares her internship experience at JPMorgan Chase & Co., Glasgow, United Kingdom, as a Summer Analyst in the Software Engineering division.
body:
Manika Jain, Electrical Engineering, Class of 2023, shares her internship experience at JPMorgan Chase & Co., Glasgow, United Kingdom, as a Summer Analyst in the Software Engineering division.

“Ever tried. Ever failed. No matter. Try Again. Fail again. Fail better.”

This quote perfectly summarises my experience of applying for internships and how every rejection was a redirection to something even better. 

As the internship season nears, I reminisce about the time when I was indulged in meeting application deadlines, taking advice from seniors and clicking every link containing the word internship. My main motive for participating in internships was to get acquainted with the world of Information Technology and to gain exposure to the corporate sector. 

APPLICATION PROCESS 

My fellow interns and the campus recruitment team who made it what it was!

Eligibility: The internship is open for full-time third-year undergraduates in computer science or related branches enrolled in a university for the academic year 2022-23.

I applied for the 2021 EMEA Software Engineering Internship at Glasgow directly through their Careers website. The application is straightforward, requiring details of work experience and achievements. If your resume is shortlisted, you get invited to an assessment centre. This is an invitation to an online interview process consisting of various technical and behavioural rounds of 1 hour each determining troubleshooting skills based on CS Fundamentals, programming and leadership principles.

After getting my resume shortlisted, I too appeared for the assessment feeling a little nervous. On 4th November 2021 (the day of Diwali!), I received a call from an international number which I missed out on picking up since I thought it was a spam call. I finally answered the phone when I received multiple calls from the same number. It was the EMEA Recruiter on the other line saying, "We are happy to offer you a Software Engineering Internship in our Glasgow office for the summer of 2022."  I went berserk after what I heard and told my mom first about this news. She made me believe that it was real and I accepted the offer.

PRE- INTERNSHIP EFFORTS

Since the application required insights into the applicant’s resume, work experiences and social media links, I always tried to document my journey and experiences on my social media profiles and volunteered for programmes that elevated the representation of women in tech fields. 

During the same month, I also participated in and won the Code for Good Hackathon EMEA 2021, which provided me with good insight into software engineering in the firm through my mentors.

Code for Good is a series of Hackathons hosted in JPMorgan's global technology centres. During this event, participants spend 12–24 hours with the company's employees, developing creative solutions to help non-profits tackle real-world problems.

Since it was an on-site internship, there was a long process for obtaining a UK Visa and eventually completing all the onboarding formalities. Due to the ongoing Ukraine-Russia war, the immigration process for several European countries was severely impacted, which resulted in the late issuing of our visas. Still, the immigration team at JPMorgan handled everything effortlessly and with utmost efficiency. Before my internship started, I connected with my mentors and the team via LinkedIn to get familiarized with the tech stack and the project.

FINALLY, FROM DELHI TO GLASGOW!

I landed at the Glasgow International Airport on 16th June, and the first thing that I noticed was the pleasant weather! On the way to my accommodation, I admired the beautiful city. The roads were big and well maintained and one could soak in the grandeur of British architecture.

PROJECT

Induction day and JPMorgan Glasgow office

The campus recruitment team planned a formal orientation on the first day of our internship to get us kickstarted and get acquainted with our fellow interns and team members. I worked in the Onboarding Team for Asset and Wealth Management, where my project focused on creating widgets and metrics to track the growth and performance of the business using various frontend and backend frameworks. I was always interested in working on the client side of the business or the front office wherein the client’s needs and expectations are better understood to implement the solutions efficiently. Fortunately, my role came at the intersection of software development and business analysis. 

My managers provided a comprehensive overview of the project at the beginning, which allowed me to navigate the work more effectively. So once we got acquainted with the initial code, further progress became very easy. What I liked was the extensive freedom provided to interns to achieve the outcome, one can suggest and argue freely on the choice of framework, tool or implementation language. The evaluation progress was rigorous, and we were constantly evaluated at each touchpoint of our internship. 

My fellow teammates and our managers on International Intern’s day!

INTERNSHIP EVENTS

Mid-social ceilidh celebrations and Pride Lunch

Undoubtedly, the events organized by the campus recruitment team were the best highlight of the entire internship! From Ceilidh night to Corporate Social Responsibility Day, from pride events to networking events, they made the whole experience unforgettable. For me, the most cherished was the Winning Women in Technology event, where women in the highest leadership positions talked to us about their journeys and experiences at JPMorgan. Further in a fun game, they asked us to write five of our professional and personal accomplishments and, in small groups, talk about the top 1 from each category. It was an unparalleled feeling to say things in both categories and hear about others' achievements. It made us realize the importance of self-worth and urged us not to get scared of talking about one’s achievements. 

Various Senior Speaker sessions were also organised for us to hear from the firm's top management. The session with Mr. Jamie Dimon, the CEO of JPMorgan will be an unforgettable memory for me since it gave me a lifetime opportunity to hear and ask questions from him about the role and sectors in the firm, as well as the company’s motivations and goals. There was even an End Term Social event wherein we reflected upon our time in the company and appreciated the enormous growth we underwent in the two months. 

Winning Women in Technology Event

Corporate Social Responsibility Day at JPMorgan

FINAL WORDS 

The two months that I spent in Glasgow were absolutely amazing. From exploring the appealing cities of Edinburgh and Glasgow to travelling internationally for the first time, this was a life-changing opportunity for me. I got to interact with some of the best people in the industry, ask them questions about their work and talk about my work. The experience fostered a learning attitude and ignited a spirit of never hiding one’s limitations and understanding that it’s okay not to know but strive harder to achieve your goals. It has been a month since my internship ended, but every time I see a post from a fellow intern, it brings about a smile to my face and I start recalling all the amazing things we achieved together. 

The amazing team!

My Advice:

  1. “Cracking international off-campus internships is difficult” is a myth. The only restriction you will ever put on yourself is you.
  2. Primarily, organizations do not care about where you have majored as long as you possess the correct skillset and the eagerness to learn and grow. 
  3. Don’t apply everywhere. Be selective and invest your effort and time only in programs that align with your ideology.
  4. Don’t stop yourself from applying just because you think you don’t have a shot (Imposter Syndrome). You can do anything if you put your mind to it and are determined.
  5. Some key tips for the resume - Write your experiences (with bulleted descriptions), your academic, co- and extracurricular achievements, courses you’ve undertaken, projects and positions you’ve held or currently hold.
  6. Interviewers focus more on how you approach the question instead of the most optimized answer. Make sure to have clear concepts about the various data structures and algorithms.
  7. During the internship, make sure to strictly keep track of the workflow and deadlines to be on the same page with your managers. You may keep a record using a document or a note but this is important.

  6. Interviewers focus more on how you approach the question instead of the most optimized answer. Make sure to have clear concepts about the various data structures and algorithms.
  7. During the internship, make sure to strictly keep track of the workflow and deadlines to be on the same page with your managers. You may keep a record using a document or a note but this is important.
