title: Texas Instruments | Internship Experience
biliner: Harshal Chowdhary, ECE, Class of 2023, shares his internship experience at Texas Instruments, as a Tester Engineer(Digital Design).
body:
The Preparation

Before April 2022, I was heavily involved in coding. But then, after I organized a webinar regarding core placements with one of my friends under Piyush Tewari Sir’s guidance, I became very enthusiastic about Core. There was something about it that pulled me in. Everything about it excited me. However, I was on the fence about whether or not to sit for core placements.

Given that we only had a couple of months left before the intern season started, I was quite anxious. I contacted one of my friends, Mandeep, and the conversation with him propelled me to at least try for the core companies. He assured me that it would be worthwhile to at least prepare from my end.

I hustled for the next 2 months. I started with Digital Electronics, as that is often considered as one of the more challenging subjects. I scoured through many YouTube playlists and made sure to make a summary sheet for each unit. Similarly, for Analog Electronics, I revised my notes and watched YouTube playlists. I made sure to focus on my notes and revised them regularly and my Verilog-related lab work. To enhance my CV, I worked on 3 projects in the summer.

Before the Qualcomm exam, I practised multiple aptitude tests using YouTube. I was hoping that I would get selected for the next round but failed to clear the OA. That hit me hard and demoralized me. I tried not to let it deter me and gave OA for Texas Instruments on 4th August with full preparation. The results were announced close to midnight and I was selected for the interview round!

The Interview

My interview was scheduled for the following day, August 5th. Around 6 PM, I received the call for my interview. We started with some polite introductions and then he began the interview by asking me about flip-flops. Most people would advise you to outline the procedure, provide thorough explanations and give extensive information, but I immediately drew the conclusion and that set the tone for my interview. The interviewer gave me a 10-page pdf, each with 2 questions per page. We went over each question individually and I provided answers to all the questions. Whenever I fumbled or got stuck, the interviewer would give me hints to guide me. Finally, I was probed about my academic projects.

Each interview is allotted a time slot of 45 minutes but in my case, it went well over 1.5 hours.  I was told that HR would contact me later. By 9 PM, everyone started receiving their confirmations. I kept waiting but didn’t receive any call. I gathered I must have been rejected. That was heart-wrenching since I knew there were no more opportunities available on campus and even though my interview went very well, I was rejected. Everything felt overwhelming and I cried. However, when the final list was released and I was checking it to look for the people to extend my congratulations to, I found that I was also one of the selected candidates!

The limitless happiness I felt in that moment is indescribable, although I was still waiting for the HR to call me.

Intern Experience

I joined my internship on 16th May 2022 and worked for the High-Speed Signal Chain (HSSC) team under Jagadish Sakamuri Sir. The project I was assigned to was “Generate Test Code for ATE from Test Condition Matrix”. My responsibility was to write a script that, based on the test conditions, would first analyze the excel sheet that a tester engineer receives specifically for a device and then produce a test code programme for an automatic testing apparatus (ATE).

I initially found it challenging to even begin my assigned project. Considering that this was very different from the profile for which I was initially chosen. A friend of mine advised me that instead of focusing on the overall picture, attempt to evaluate each individual component of the project, learn about the necessary resources beforehand, and apply them side by side, just like you would with a typical college project. He advised me to divide my projects into multiple portions, and that helped me a lot. 

The first step was learning how to analyze an excel sheet. I performed a crash course in Python and Pandas in one evening, and then the following day (Day 2 of my internship), I began working on my projects. Within a week, I had finished 25% of my targets. I was terribly afraid that I would not be able to finish my tasks since data analysis and test code development were outside of my field of expertise. To compensate, I worked continuously through the nights.

Even though my target timeline suggested finishing the script by the end of the 7th week, I pushed ahead and completed the script by the fourth week. The only task left was to test the code on the tester platform.

On-Site

I received mail after my first two weeks of the internship stating that I am permitted to move this internship to an on-site internship. Since many didn’t have the same opportunity, I made sure to seize it. I feel that only on my first day on campus did I truly begin to learn.

I began working on site at Texas Instruments. You have no idea how anxious I was. But as soon as I stepped onto the campus, I realized that this is where I want to begin my corporate career. I don't know how to put into words the sensation I had. It was pure, unbridled joy for me. When I first introduced myself to my team, they corrected me, suggesting that I am now the tester engineer intern rather than the digital design intern.

One of my coworkers, Shivaranjni Devi Ma'am, led me to the tester lab where she gave me a lesson on the various ATE systems, how they test their products, and how much time they spend in the labs. The following day, my mentor showed up and showed me how to utilize the Eagle Testing System User Interface and how to determine whether a device is functioning properly. They also taught me how to use the ETS platform to test my test code.

The day I was supposed to have my midterm review, things didn't go as expected. The reason was that I was unable to sell my script and instead, I was attempting to educate my project in an improper manner. I received nearly full points for my midterm review, with the exception of the two marks that my team docked me for my presentation. I used to visit the tester lab every day with one of my teammates to learn more about the various ATE systems that were offered there. I completed three more projects over the course of the subsequent four weeks at the campus, all of which dealt with various ATE systems. I wrote the script for the development of test code for the ATE systems ETS364, V93K, and merging the tests. When my final term presentation took place, it went quite well. My mentor only deducted 1 mark this time.

Takeaway

Every day I learned something new from my team. I have the fondest memories from my time working with them. An honorary mention to my mentor, Jagadish Sakamuri Sir who has 17 years of expertise in this industry. He is one of the kindest people I have ever encountered. He would always ask for my input on a subject before offering his own. His enthusiasm and inquisitiveness and how he is never tired of learning new things are awe-inspiring. He made sure I wasn't just limited to working on my projects and helped me gain access to the tester lab, which is not authorized for interns. 

Advice for juniors

  2.  
  • For preparation in this core field, focus on topics like STA and FIFO as well and refer to Digital Electronics by Anand Kumar.

Implement parallelly whatever you learn, this helps your knowledge grow.

CGPA matters a lot. Doesn’t matter the company, a good CGPA will take you to many places. Try to manage a 9+ CGPA.

title: Nanyang Technological University, Singapore | Internship Experience
biliner: Ayush Sharma, SE, Class of 2023, shares his experience as a Deep Learning Research Intern at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore.
body:
Ayush Sharma, SE, Class of 2023, shares his experience as a Deep Learning Research Intern at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore.

ABOUT THE INTERNSHIP:

Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore has a specialised team of professors and students working on natural language processing, known as NTU-SpeechLab. It comes under the department of computer science at NTU. I worked under the guidance of a Professor (unnamed), and his PhD students on building state of the art natural language processing models using deep learning techniques. Over the past few years, NTU Speechlab has been conducting cutting-edge NLP research and providing some state of the art solutions and, having contributed to this system, I am equally glad and proud to be associated with it.  

During my internship at NTU, I worked on the task of text emotion recognition in conversation, i.e., identifying the emotion of the speaker (angry, happy, sad, etc) from the speaker's utterances (text dialogues) in the conversation. 

BEFORE THE INTERNSHIP:

To get accepted into a research internship at one of the top computer science institutes in the world is not an easy task. They look into your complete profile ranging from your CGPA to the amount of experience you have in the field. It really helps your profile if you have publications or research papers before applying. But, I would like to tell you all that it is not completely a necessity to have publications, as I did not have any myself before applying! If you can make up for the lack of research papers by a strong profile, good internships and projects in the area for which you are applying, your chances of getting selected are as good as anyone else. 

Before applying for this internship, I had already done a research internship with SystemOnSilicon Corporation, an Indo-US start-up based in San Francisco. There, I worked on similar machine learning problems, involving sequence models for predictions of crop prices in India for their apps. Also, I had learnt how to scrape data from websites, which became really useful while I was applying to NTU, Singapore. I had also done another internship at Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) at the Scientific Analysis Group. Apart from that, I had an array of good open-source machine learning and natural language processing projects to show on my resume. I was also the founder and President of the Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Society of DTU (AIMS-DTU) which really showed my passion for the field of AI. All these small factors helped me build a strong profile while applying for the internship at NTU, Singapore.

APPLICATION PROCESS:

I applied for this internship in March by sending a direct email to the professor I wanted to work under, looking at his previous work in the field. 

I would like to mention that while applying for research work, it is always good to see the previous work the mentor has done so that you can get a good idea about whether your interests and qualifications are relevant to the interests of your mentor. 

After my email, he replied back within 4-5 days, and set up an online interview with me. During the interview we discussed all of my past internships mentioned on my resume. He even looked at the code quality of all my projects on Github while sharing the screen and asked me questions regarding the ins and outs of those projects. A few mistakes were pointed out but overall, he seemed happy about my work. A few days later I was informed that I had been shortlisted for the further process. In this part, I was given a week to accomplish a task on my own. The task was to scrape websites and extract meaningful textual sentences from a website and all its children links, to create a large text corpus for language modelling. I managed to complete this task quite well and within the deadline. My work really impressed the Professor and I received the selection mail a week later in the last week of March!

DURING THE INTERNSHIP:

My topic of research was “Natural Language Processing” and the internship commenced in the first week of June. We had two weekly meetings in which we had to present our progress and also discuss the issues we faced. During the first phase of my internship, I was working with the language modelling team, extracting text corpuses from different sources to feed into the language modelling task. Then, after a few weeks I started working on my main project, with the Natural Language Understanding team, on an Emotion Recognition task. In this project my team had to create an NLP deep learning model which could take in a conversation between multiple speakers, and predict the emotion of each speaker after each dialogue. The emotion could be any one of the six–happy, angry, sad, frustrated, excited or neutral. We had multimodal data, i.e., audio, video and text to train the model on. It was a really exciting project and we achieved state of the art accuracy with our model. Moreover, I learned a great deal by getting hands-on experience of working with transformers (BERT, RoBERTa) and attention mechanisms in neural networks. All in all, it was a lot of fun!

ADVICE FOR JUNIORS:

If you want to land a research internship, the only advice would be to keep your CGPA good (9+). Keep gaining experience in your field of interest, either through internships, or through independent open-source projects of your own. Also, prior research projects are really a big boost to your profile, especially if you publish your work as a research paper. 

Don't be hesitant about applying for an opportunity thinking you might not be "good enough", you never know, you might be a perfect fit for the role! So, always apply to all the opportunities that interest you. 

PS: If you want to apply to NTU for research work, there is another way to go about it as well – through the “NTU India Connect programme”.

title: Twitter, Inc. | Internship Experience
biliner: Gurharpartap Singh Dhaliwal, COE, Class of 2023, shares his internship experience at Twitter, Inc., as a Software Engineering Intern.
body:
Gurharpartap Singh Dhaliwal, COE, Class of 2023, shares his internship experience at Twitter, Inc., as a Software Engineering Intern. 

I was preparing for and aggressively seeking SDE internships in 2021 so that I could gain an exposure to the corporate world right from undergraduate level. Twitter visited DTU campus in September 2021. It was open for four branches (CO, IT, SE, MCE). There were no CGPA requirements. I am glad that I was able to experience this internship and learn so much at Twitter. 

 

The Selection Process:

As part of the selection process, there were four rounds, each of which was rigorous and involved many factors. As we progressed through each round, all of our skills were tested in depth.

Round 1 - 2 Medium-Hard coding Questions to be solved on hackerrank within 60-75 minutes.

This was followed by 3 consecutive interviews. Each interview was 1-hour long.

Round 2-  2 Medium-Hard DSA questions were asked.

Round 3- This was a round dedicated to the core subjects of computer science and focussed on evaluating candidates in this domain.

Round 4- This round focussed on past projects, internships and cultural fit.

After a complex selection process consisting of the online assessment round and the multiple thorough interviews, six DTU students were chosen for the internship program.

 

Beginning with the Internship at Twitter, Inc.

For the internship, we had the option to either do it virtually or offline. I chose the latter and relocated to Bangalore. I have to admit that trying to find housing was a bit of a challenge and could make for quite an interesting story on its own! My internship started on 8th of May, and the journey from there on was nothing short of wonderful!

 

The Project

I worked at Twitter as a member of the Global Participation team. I had to collaborate with another intern (from DTU) on a project. The project we were responsible for required a blend of backend and machine learning knowledge.

  • The project was to create an interest taxonomy to power Twitter topic picker using different data sources (I cannot provide exact details of the project due to the company's privacy policy) Two mentors were assigned to us who guided us and helped us with the project.

The project was divided into 4 parts:

  • Data Visualisation- Representing the final result
  • Data Filtration - Removing anomalies in the data
  • Data Migration- Moving data to cloud
  • Data Extraction- Extracting relevant data from different data sources

These tasks were done async. We were free to use the tech stack of our choice. The biggest issue was managing the vast volume of data. But in the end, we were able to significantly reduce the amount of data and concluded our internship by providing a solid solution! 

 

Meetings

Every Tuesday and Thursday, we would meet our mentors to discuss the work accomplished during the previous stretch and to set goals for the upcoming week. These meets often included brainstorming sessions where ideas for effective yet straightforward solutions to problems were shared.

We spoke with ML engineers, who assisted us in getting started and offered their ideas. Slack was the main chat application used. We had slack channels for basically everything.

 

Fun Events

There were many memorable events that I enjoyed while we were at work. We played games like Pictionary and Treasure Hunt wherein we received rewards too. For the virtual interns, various fun online events were organised. We regularly dined as a team. Field trips were also conducted. 

 

At the end of this wonderful journey

Our internship ended on 29th July. The whole process went really smoothly. I learned how businesses operate and how real tasks are completed. 

The project we worked on can enhance the Home Time Line's User Active Minutes. It will also improve Tweet Click rate.

 

Advice For Juniors:

As you prepare for your journey, there are a few things I would recommend to you:

  1. Participate in a competitive programming contest.
  2. In-depth study of core subjects should be done.
  3. Communication skills are essential during the interview.
  4. Try to participate in team projects and have some open source contributions on your resume. It is extremely valuable.

During your internship, do pay attention to the following points: 

  1. Document everything you do as much as possible.
  2. Establish appropriate goals and strive to achieve them.
  3. Seek assistance rather than remaining stuck.
  4. Most importantly, communicate your progress to your mentor and manager.
  5. Take initiative in team tech discussions, fun sessions, and so on.

title: Carnegie Mellon University | Internship Experience
biliner: Aryan, ECE, Class of 2023, shares his experience as a Research Intern at the Robotics Institute, Carnegie Mellon University, received through the Robotics Institute Summer Scholars (RISS) programme by CMU.
body:
Among the many coveted research internships at foreign universities, the Robotics Institute Summer Scholars (RISS) programme offered by Carnegie Mellon University stands out as one of the most competitive internships in the field of Robotics. Having been selected for the DAAD-WISE and the MITACS GRI programmes as well, I had to choose between these two and the RISS internship programme. Since I was truly interested in research in robotics, I chose the Robotics Institute at Carnegie Mellon University due to its competitive nature and the extensive research opportunities it offers in this field. I spent my summer of 2022 immersing myself into comprehensive research and development and all in all, it was a challenging yet wonderfully amazing experience!

The Application Process

For RISS, the application usually begins around the 15th of November. There are certain documents that one needs to submit. You are required to submit a resume or curriculum vitae(CV), statement of purpose, two letters of recommendation from faculty advisors or instructors, and unofficial transcripts from your entire undergraduate period. The statement of purpose that you need to submit is similar to your master's application and it is a two-page essay where you need to tell them—“why you want this internship”,  “what exactly you would do during this internship”.  

After you submit your application, it goes through the initial process of shortlisting in the Robotics Institute at CMU. They then pick you up according to your profile and then forward your profile to two or three professors, with whom your profile would be compatible for the research internship. These professors then evaluate your profile to decide if they’d want to proceed with your application for the next step i.e. the interviews! You are invited for an interview with the professor if your application makes it through the previous steps of evaluation.

After the interview, if the professor finds your profile suitable and is satisfied with your performance in the interview, they offer to fund you for the two-months internship in the US. This is the complete process of making it through the entire application process and finally getting selected! 

An important factor to consider is to make sure your application stands out! A key part of my application was UGV-DTU (Unmanned Ground Vehicle-DTU)!  I’ve been working with the UGV-DTU team since my first year. The major benefit this provided me was the connection I formed with the professors. This helped me in getting a really strong letter of recommendation. I would say that in these kinds of internships, which are basically academia based, the LoR you submit matters a lot. The LoR I had received mentioned all the work I had accomplished accounting for my qualities and skills. Apart from this, I got research experience working within this team as I worked on many robotics-related projects. My area of interest was specifically in robotics perception (Machine learning, Computer Vision, etc.) and while I was in UGV, our works and discussions were related to robotics perception and other associated areas, which led me to secure an internship at IIIT Hyderabad. So, this was another major factor which was initiated by UGV and something that added substance to my profile. In addition to this, I also worked in the Samsung Research Lab at DTU for a few months and published a research paper related to my field. Hence, all of this in combination was a substantial addition to my profile.

"There will be obstacles. There will be doubters. There will be mistakes. But with hard work, there are no limits." - Michael Phelps. 

I did face some challenges while applying for this internship and all throughout my internship as well. Here are some suggestions I’d want to share:

 - People there are very hardworking. They work overnight, and sometimes not even go back home. You will need to adapt yourself to this fast-paced, diligent and industrious environment.  

 - Once you are selected, I’d suggest you have a proper plan laid out. They’d asked me to provide them a weekly plan chart for the two months of my working schedule over there. 

 - You need to find a research problem way ahead of time. It’s not like you first get selected and you decide your research field later on. You should initially have a basic research problem that you’d want to work on in mind. This would make it easier for you to write the two-page essay. 

 - The motivation letter that you are required to submit needs to be on point — you should clearly state your intentions and all what you’d want to do there as a research intern. 

 - The very first challenge was to receive a good letter of recommendation. As I said, letters of recommendation play an extremely important part. So to get selected for these kinds of  internships, you need to have a very good letter of recommendation, either from very good professors or the content in the letters should be very strong. 

During the Internship - It was simply great at CMU!

Just in two months in the USA, I found myself working 10-12 hours a day which was utterly exhausting. I had to complete my research in two months, which ideally people do in six or seven months. So, it was all very fast-paced.  Despite this, there were a lot of other things that I did. I visited many places — travelling to New York was a really fun experience!

Unlike most research internships, where there is a professor or a PhD student working on a project and you are working along with them on their work, in the RISS internship you need to  start your own project. You need to complete the research and publish a paper on it in which you're the first author of that paper. This might all seem extremely difficult but the Robotics Institute is so collaborative and supportive that it not only makes your journey much easier but also enriches your entire experience. You can approach anyone over there – any PhD, any Postdoctoral researcher, even any scientist or professor from another lab to solve your queries or suggest to you some other PhD student who can work with you or who’d be interested to work with you.

I remember I too had some problems initially— I was struggling to get a research idea. So, I talked to some people over there regarding it which helped me out to a great extent. Even during my entire research, many other PhD and Master’s students working in my lab helped me a lot. Apart from this, I even enjoyed the various other activities in the lab. We had  weekly meetings and we had monthly barbecue sessions! So, the connectivity and the collaborations were excellent.

The Project:

AirLoc: Object-based Indoor Relocalization

Indoor relocalization is vital for both robotic tasks such as autonomous exploration and civil applications such as navigation with a cell phone in a shopping mall. Some previous approaches adopt geometrical information or local textures to carry out indoor relocalization, but they are often not robust enough to hierarchical relocalization, namely a relocalization having different hierarchies such as building level, room level and object level. Inspired by the fact that humans often remember places by recognizing unique landmarks, we resort to objects, which are more informative than geometry elements for indoor relocalization. In this context, we propose a novel object-based indoor relocalization approach, dubbed AirLoc. To overcome the critical challenges including object reidentification and remembering object relationships, we extract object-wise appearance embedding and pixel-wise geometrical relationship. These objects are linked to rooms and further to buildings for a hierarchical scene representation. This results in a robust, accurate, and portable indoor relocalization system. AirLoc performs well for room-level relocalization and it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods by 12% in PR-AUC and 8% in accuracy. It is robust to severe occlusion, perceptual aliasing, viewpoint shift, deformation, and scale transformation as well. To the best of my knowledge, AirLoc is one of the first object-based hierarchical indoor relocalization approaches.

 

Takeaways from my Internship:

I initially wanted to do a PhD in robotics but during my internship as I interacted with many professors, some PhD and postdoctoral fellows and even some MBA students, I experienced the research environment in depth. I ended up realising that I should pursue a Masters in Robotics initially and then decide whether I am best fit for a PhD program or not. I also realised that the work environment in the US is way  better than in India. So I finally decided to go to the US for my Masters. 

Some advice for the juniors:

Having a publication specific to robotics in an internationally renowned journal is a worthy addition. I’d suggest you contact a professor or a PhD fellow under whom you can work for publishing a research paper. This is the best way to gain initial experience at conducting research and writing a research paper. This way you get to learn all about the process of writing and publishing your own research paper and how exactly things work!

For your Github Profile: For RISS, they just look into robotics-related projects or  some machine learning projects as well. All they want is something related to robotics. If you consider Mitacs or DAAD-WISE, they don't want you to be very  proficient in robotics. Any slightly related project which is nicely documented, is neat and clean, and intelligible to anyone can be a great addition for your Mitacs or DAAD -WISE application.

RISS, specifically, is a very competitive research internship. So, you need to have some prior  research experience as well. If somebody is in first or second  year, the main thing that they need to  do is to apply for some Indian robotics labs to get some research experience. After that  they should try to form some good connections with the professor so that they can write letters of recommendation to them. And lastly, they need to work on their resume! Things like your skills and a good Github profile also matter a lot.

title: Wells Fargo | Internship Experience
biliner: Mihir Joshi, COE, Class of 2023, shares his experience as an Analyst Intern at Wells Fargo.
body:
Mihir Joshi, COE, Class of 2023, shares his experience as an Analyst Intern at Wells Fargo.

BAGGING THE INTERNSHIP

I bagged the Wells Fargo internship on campus in my third year. There were two technical rounds and an HR round—a whole-day process where I was judged based on my technical knowledge and coding skills that included DSA, DBMS, OOPs, and COA. Even though the internship was virtual due to COVID-19, my experience was immensely thrilling!

DURING THE INTERNSHIP - Workshops, Meetings, Projects, Interactions & much more!

My internship at Wells Fargo began on 30th of May 2022 and lasted two months. Our eight weeks at the company was divided such that after each week or two, our progress would be evaluated by our mentors. The first week was mainly about us getting used to working as a group and learning how to be productive and efficient. We were given multiple problem statements and had to choose the one we felt would bring out the best of us. Each statement was unique, requiring us to think in all possible directions. 

Before starting off with my internship, I was apprehensive since it was my first time entering the corporate culture, but thanks to Wells Fargo, it was smooth sailing. During the internship, there were weekly workshops and seminars on how one should tackle moral and social problems in the corporate world.  This made the overall journey of my internship even more interesting and exhilarating!

Our team consisted of twelve interns who were managed by two mentors. Meetings with our mentors were held every alternate day to discuss their views and suggestions on the problem statement. Given the problem statement, we divided the twelve member team into three teams for UI/UX, Backend and Machine Learning respectively. I got to work in the ML team, where I explored various ML concepts and libraries such as NLP, NLTK, Spacy, BERT, and Roberta to tackle our problem statement. We used Google Colab to keep up to date with each other’s contributions to the project.

I opted for ML because I was familiar with the topic, as I had done multiple ML courses online. I had also done some ML projects previously such as ‘Stock price prediction using linear regression model’ and ‘Movie recommendation system using neural networks and backpropagation’ and a few more.

The frontend team focused on designing the appropriate web pages and connecting firebase authentication to react. The backend team made the necessary routes and connection with the database and any other required data. The tasks included storage of user details, and managing flow of data with the GUI. The Machine Learning Team, which I was a part of, pre-processed the data, developed the various models to test their efficiency on the dataset. 

After each team completed their work, each module was integrated with each other followed by testing and deployment if felt needed.

My Ever-so-exciting Eight Weeks at Wells Fargo:

Since the workflow of the internship was preplanned, the pace of the project went smoothly due to the preparation. During the eight weeks, week-1 was for assessing the problem statement, week-2 was given for documentation followed by week-3 and 4 when the implementation took place. After a month we had our first demo with the higher officials and the following two weeks were given to optimize and improve our work. Week-7 had our final presentation where we had to explain the problem statement and pitch in our solution to the problem and how it is beneficial to the company. The final week was our assessment week, both as a group and as individuals where we had to list our contribution to the project.

There were no fixed working hours. We did not have to login at 9 am and log out at 5 pm. We held daily meets regarding our flow of work in the morning, setting tasks for the day and discussing what we did the previous day. At the end of the day, we would meet virtually, overseeing each other’s works and ensuring that the task set for that day is completed.   

Overall, being an intern at Wells Fargo has been a huge learning experience for me – not only gaining the knowledge but also implementing it in such a friendly and helpful environment was enriching as an intern. 

Some Advice for Juniors:

1. CGPA is of the utmost importance as it is the first criteria on which a candidate is judged whether he is allowed to sit for the Online Assessment/Coding round or not. It’s also used as a tiebreaker for interviews, and thus maintaining a good CGPA is a must.

2. For technical interviews and assessments, having good knowledge of DSA is necessary to clear the round.

3. Be confident with your resume and know the ins and outs of all your projects. You shouldn’t be caught off guard with something that's on your resume.

title: Expedia | Internship Experience
biliner: Amishi Jain, ENE, Class of 2023, shares her internship experience at Expedia as a Software Development Intern.
body:
Last year, I reached a major milestone in my life – I got a two-month internship offer from Expedia Group, one of the largest travel tech companies in the world. It was my first opportunity to step into a new world and explore how the corporate world works. I was extremely excited to embark on this journey. Moreover, being the first student from my branch to get an opportunity to work with Expedia Group, I was pumped up to give my best, but was equally jittery about how things would unfold.

The Preparation:

During my initial years in college, I took my time to explore all possible avenues and choose the best fit for me. Setting foot into the tech industry did not seem easy at first considering the immense competition. However, for me, coding was not just a gateway to some high-paying tech job. It has always been more about the learning, the mental development it brings along, and the joy of solving problems and learning something new. Practice is what makes you perfect, especially in competitive programming. So I scheduled my DSA practice sessions and followed it religiously throughout my coding journey.

Bagging the Internship & the Journey thereon:

During the Intern-hiring season on our campus, I got the opportunity to apply for Expedia Group. I cleared the Online Assessment(OA) round which was followed by two technical interviews and a behavioral round. After receiving the results, I was overwhelmed with joy as I was hired as a Software Development Engineering Intern. 

In May 2022, when I got the opportunity to complete my summer-internship at Expedia Group which was my first corporate experience ever, I dived head-first into this new world of Tech! 

I was in the ‘Flights team’ under the Aether pod. I was assigned 2 projects by my manager that had to be completed in the 2 month duration of my internship. The first two weeks were spent training for the projects I would be working on. I got a lot of exposure to Confluence, Jira , Slack and AWS technologies during this journey. Then our actual work began. 

My project was on AWS and migration. It was a little intimidating at first and I had to undergo my campus to corporate transition and practically apply the theory I've learnt. But once I understood what was to be done and how things work, I enjoyed it! The process of adding changes to the code, making a PR (pull request), getting it reviewed, merging, taking it to deployment, releasing and monitoring...it was a great experience.

During this period, I learnt how the industry works.  Your team may not know everything about the tools you use, errors that occur, etc. but they are always there to listen to your doubts and help as much as they can. Sometimes you need to approach someone who knows it and ask for help. And that’s the best part at Expedia Group! You will get to interact with people across the globe. And the people here are so co-operative and helpful. They like to share their knowledge with others. 

Being involved in work, the days went so fast and we approached the end of our two-months internship. I delivered a presentation on my projects and exhibited it successfully. Soon after the presentation, I received a pre-placement offer from Expedia Group.

I believe that life is a series of learning new things. Success and failure are just by-products. And I have learnt a lot of things during my journey. I would like to share two of them.

● Consistency is the key. It is important to work towards your goal everyday with the same amount of determination.

● It is okay to not know everything. Until you are curious enough to solve all your doubts and courageous enough to ask for help , that’s all that matters. 

Finally, I’d like to quote Einstein as he said that “In the middle of every difficulty lies an opportunity”. So be wise enough to recognize that opportunity and always remember that if you don’t win, you learn.

title: DAAD WISE | Internship Experience
biliner: Disha Malik, Chemical Engineering, Class of 2023, shares her internship experience as a DAAD WISE Scholar 2022 at the Technical University of Munich, Germany.
body:
Disha Malik, Chemical Engineering, Class of 2023, shares her internship experience as a DAAD WISE Scholar 2022 at the Technical University of Munich, Germany

I got an amazing opportunity to explore research in an international laboratory during my three-month internship at TU Munich, Germany. It was a phenomenal experience- the learning, the travelling, and the experiences were surreal. I got to know about these highly competitive research internships during the lockdown and started building my profile by doing various internships, such as at IIT Bombay, DRDO, and Aditya Birla Chemicals (Thailand). I worked hard to maintain my CGPA and wrote research papers along with other extracurriculars. It wasn’t always easy and didn’t happen overnight- it was a slow and tedious process, but I was determined to land the coveted foreign internships. I wanted to explore academia in another country, and DAAD was truly worth it. 

BEFORE THE INTERNSHIP:

When the application process was near, I was hoping to get into MITACS (as I gathered positive responses from 5/7 professors I had applied under), and because DAAD seemed too ambitious a goal, given that it was awarded to a few in the country. 

However, things didn't go according to my plan, as life rarely does. I was dejected when I faced a stream of rejections. I began to question how better I could have built my profile. I began to doubt myself, and those sneaky little insecurities that I feared started crawling in again. I got rejected from multiple on-campus internships as well as from MITACS. My hopes were dashed again when even after getting a positive reply from multiple professors that I had applied under but got rejected. I had lost all hopes of bagging an internship, and DAAD had delayed the results that year. 

And then, out of the blue, I received the news that the results were about to be declared in the evening. Hit by nervous jitters, I anxiously checked and rechecked my phone as I hung onto the very last shred of hope I had. I felt that the chances of me getting selected at that point were very bleak. And then, the anticipated notification finally popped up on my phone at around 2 PM. I had no idea that a single email would change the course of my life so spectacularly. I was elated and overjoyed that all the hard work- the internships, exams, and projects had truly helped me achieve this incredible opportunity. 

The next few weeks went by in a blur, I couldn’t even tell anyone about it as it wasn’t allowed until the official formalities were complete. We now worked to complete the tedious Schengen Visa process, booking tickets and endless searching for accommodation in Munich. By the time I told everyone, the feeling had already sunk in. 

The DAAD WISE internship was a dream come true. I was very apprehensive when I was applying for it given the rigorous process and the fierce competition along with the low acceptance rate. But in the end, I was glad I took a chance to apply because this opportunity has given me the best exposure that I could have possibly asked for at an undergraduate level. 

THE APPLICATION PROCESS :

DAAD-WISE gives you funding to avail of an internship opportunity to pursue research in a German public-funded institute during your undergraduate years. To apply, you must be in your pre-final year (in a 4-year degree program).

Usually, international internships are competitive, and to outshine, one needs to have a balanced profile. Having a high CGPA (usually an aggregate above 9.2 or 9.3 is required), research projects or internships preferably at IITs, or industrial experience, as well as technical skills such as programming, and data analysis could add a silver lining to your resume.

The basic processes of the application include: 

  1. Drafting the perfect email
  2. Finding your host professor
  3. Applying on the scholarship portal
  4. Assembling your documents
  5. Await the results now and if selected, start the visa application process.

The first step is to compose the email that you are going to send across to all professors. In the beginning, you can begin with your introduction, your CGPA, followed by your research experience. You can then mention your interest in the professor’s work and why you are the right fit for them. Do mention that you do not expect to get paid in their lab. Because applying for a DAAD scholarship is the next step which would eventually look after your funding requirements. Finally, attach links to your Curriculum Vitae (CV) and transcripts. Getting a positive reply is both a stroke of luck and an abundance of dedication. Do not feel disheartened if you do not receive a reply within the first few days. Keep following up with the professors after a week or two.

Finding a German Host Professor:

This usually is a time taking process. I spent nearly 2-3 entire weeks doing just this. Your patience will be put to the test because cold emailing might be intimidating. You can search for TU9 universities and the chairs in which you are interested. Then for each of those universities, you can look through all the professors in the designated labs and see who is doing work that you like the most and aligns with your previous research experience. You can even CC your emails to the PhD students for better chances.

To apply for the DAAD Scholarship:

After the affirmative email, one is supposed to apply on the DAAD scholarship portal along with all the required documents. You are required to fill out an online application form which would ask for your basic details. Your letters of recommendation, letter of motivation, project proposal, invitation letter from the German host, and a few NOCs from your Indian university are required to be submitted along with the application form. Try to maintain a good rapport with your mentors so that you can contact them for your LORs. Try to reach out to those professors/mentors only under whom you have done any courses or projects. The LOR should express a good relationship between you and them along with your aptitude for research. You and your German host could potentially discuss the project proposal before you come up with your own. The printed summary must be sent to the DAAD Delhi office after all the required documents and the application form have been submitted. The result is usually out in the month of February or the beginning of March. 

THE PROJECT :

During my internship, I conducted research on 'X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy analysis of 3D transition metals' at TU München.

I worked on special equipment which was only present at the TU Munich laboratory and had to critically analyse, inspect, research, and study every element. I conducted my research with the help of state-of-the-art methods and lab-based XAS instrumentations for collecting the XAFS spectra of transition metal catalysts. The material synthesis and the associated results have diverse applications in the fields of catalysis, nanomaterials, and chemistry in general.

 

MY EXPERIENCE:

Despite popular belief, even after landing my internship, in the beginning, it was not all sunshine and roses. I faced certain difficulties when I started my journey. When I landed, I was more than overwhelmed to be a part of the Bavarian streets.

However, I struggled to find accommodation in Munich very much. Looking for one that would suit me for the next three long months was a difficult task, I had to also battle the waves of homesickness that kept creeping in. It was harder to adjust at first, to become accustomed to a way of living differently than what I was used to. But, I decided to pull up my socks to make the most of my experience, and then there was no looking back. But I had no idea that a rollercoaster ride was waiting ahead of me- one that would actually make life like sunshine and roses. I travelled to the most beautiful places on the planet that I could have never imagined. I travelled across most parts of Italy (Rome, Venice, Florence, Pisa, Milan), Vatican City, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, and the most beautiful and memorable experience of all time, Paris!

 

Managing the project and lab work, placement preparation, pulling off hectic trips, cooking for the first time, and carrying out daily chores was a task to pull off. But unknowingly and amazingly, this experience has taught me how to do it all and has made me more self-reliant and responsible than I could ever think of. 

ADVICE  FOR JUNIORS:

  • Consider customizing each email you send. Try establishing a connection between the professor's work, your skill set, and what you are willing to contribute.
  • The best time to send emails is between 9 and 10 am on weekdays (European Time). The chances of your email getting noticed are the maximum when the professors are usually checking their mailboxes with a cup of coffee!
  • Look for lodging well in advance. Finding student housing can be quite tough in some cities, such as Berlin and Munich.
  • Take this opportunity to travel through other European countries. It will teach you to be independent and trust yourself even more.

Even though adapting to working in an international workspace is sometimes tough. You must always be up-forward and honest with your professors about your work, and it is always difficult to get into good books as an international student. It was amazing to explore newer ways of academic research and learning that I got to work on my project.

I would highly encourage all eligible candidates to apply, as I count this as an excellent opportunity, especially for women in STEM.

title: Interview | Mr. Ganesh Krishnan, promoter of bigbasket.com, Portea Medical, HomeLane, and BlueStone (DCE Alumnus, BE 1982 Mechanical Engg.)
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. Ganesh Krishnan, promoter of bigbasket.com, Portea Medical, HomeLane, and BlueStone (DCE Alumnus, BE 1982 Mechanical Engg.) during the Convocation ceremony.
body:
You’re one of India’s top entrepreneurs. How did you end up becoming an entrepreneur? 

Back in 1982, there was no concept of entrepreneurship. Within six months of working at Tata Motors, Bihar, I realised I was not an excellent mechanical engineer. Along with my roommate, I decided to study for the CAT and eventually landed at IIM Calcutta. Working in small entrepreneurial companies inflicts confidence in us to take a giant leap, so I joined HCL. Short answer, I was an accidental entrepreneur. And entrepreneurship is like an addiction. My first venture was IT&T in 1990. Since then, there has been no turning back. 

What should aspiring entrepreneurs aim for to secure their success? 

Entrepreneurship is tough. 9 out of 10 startups don’t work out. The best analogy is a lottery. If you’re passionate or foolish to bet on a lottery, you should bet on something where the win is huge. If you want to pursue entrepreneurship, financially speaking, the expectations have to be high. In practice, this means going for a large sector. Roti, kapda, makaan, education, entertainment, and healthcare are all essential large sectors. It is as challenging as starting a BigBasket, but you will win with a minimal outcome. Go for big pain points, the must-haves and not the good-haves, to maximise your prospects. 

What is the secret formula behind choosing the winning bets like BigBasket and Blue Stone, the idea or the person behind the idea? 

There is no secret formula; it is a lottery game to place many bets. The player who made the winning shot determines the game, not the proportion of opportunities that got converted. I envision entering a brand-new industry with no precedents, something fresh in a greenfield with a blue-ocean approach. Choose something novel or with significant pain points, and disrupt it in a way no one else can. 

You have a very successful career and four successful entrepreneurship experiences. What were some of your challenges with raising money, scaling, and growing across many countries? 

There were a massive number of challenges. The lack of talent and expertise was a challenge to being a pioneer in a greenfield industry within the sphere of consumer-based businesses. Raising capital was a big challenge in convincing venture capitalists to invest. People seek the security and comfort of a well-paying job, so structuring a core team in a fragile setup of a new business was a tough nut to crack.  

How does a person develop a risk appetite? How does one decide between having a job or having a startup? 

If you incessantly think and keep your antenna up, a fraction of this attitude will come on its own. It took me two years to start my first venture. Because of my educational background, I knew I could find a job, even if not the best or highest-paying. Your ideas will start to germinate, which entails you taking risks.  

Do you have any messages or advice for the students of DTU? 

Today, the number of opportunities in India makes much more sense to maximise opportunities than to minimise risks. You would regret more if you missed opportunities when trying to play safe. One of the biggest challenges is that people take the well-trodden path. Ensure that you play with the possibilities proffered today.

title: Interview | Mr. S.R. Narasimhan, Chairman, and Managing Director POSOCO
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Mr. S.R. Narasimhan, Chairman, and Managing Director POSOCO, during the Golden Pride ceremony.
body:
You have been in the energy industry for the past three decades and have witnessed the technological advancements that have taken place. How do you view India’s progression concerning sustainability?

The country has enormous solar and wind potential; we have harnessed only a fraction of that to date. All sustainable energy sources require storage systems; hence, battery energy storage solutions are being explored, and a system with a capacity of 1000MW has already been engineered. A tender has been issued by Solar Energy Corporation of India for the implementation of the same. We also have a very ambitious green hydrogen energy program, wherein production figures of 5 million tonnes of hydrogen are anticipated. To produce 1 million tonnes of green hydrogen per annum, 8GW of electrolyzers would have to be in place, adding to the country's electricity demands. With the present technology, we can produce 15-20GW of electrolyzers, and this figure has to be ramped up going forward.

You have recently assumed the position of CMD of POSOCO. What are some of the changes that you wish to bring about?

My job now is to ensure that the next generation of system engineers has a very robust grid, which would ensure that their problems are minimal. That process begins with tweaking the standards. Standards for wind and solar energy storage equipment are of utmost importance. System behavior in faulty situations should be monitored, and the results obtained should be used to set the standards. We cannot afford to lose an entire energy processing system due to faulty or poor-grade equipment. Although standards are internationally agreed upon and are not in our direct control, we must advocate for airtight standards.

Your speech discussed ‘One Sun, One World, One Grid.’ What are the challenges we are faced with in accomplishing this initiative?

The major problem we face is getting an agreement from the bordering countries. There has been a conversation with the Sri Lankan government regarding this, where initial research pointed towards an underwater sea cable. However, further research has shown that an overhead line in places like Rameshwaram is possible as the depth is not much in those areas. We’ve been trying to reach a consensus, but the prime dilemma is who puts up the money for the cross-border line. Considering both countries' long-term welfare, India has considered financing it through grants. Cross-border communication between the system operators in real-time must be maintained through standard procedures.

Predicting electrical load requirements and accurately calculating the same would prove to be much better than a sustainable source. What is your take on this?

Load forecasting is increasingly becoming challenging with increased variable factors and frequent out-of-pattern load requirements. What we mean by ‘load’ as system operators is the load on the transmission system. If rooftop solar is implemented at the transmission level, the load on transmission effectively gets reduced. Minimizing errors in the load forecast is tricky as there are uncertain variables like weather, which also contribute to the load demand. A prediction for the day ahead can be made with an error of 3-4%, and subsequently, intraday statistical adjustments can be made according to usage patterns. A higher percentage of error would require a larger reserve as overhead.

title: Interview | Mr. Karnal Singh, former Chief of Enforcement Directorate (ED)
biliner: DTU Times interviewed hon’ble panelist of E-summit 2022, Mr. Karnal Singh, former Chief of Enforcement Directorate (ED).
body:
What differences do you see in the atmosphere of DTU from your times at DCE to what it is now?

I remember we had a really small ground, and did not have sufficient space. We had a really good faculty and I believe, the faculty of DTU is excellent even now. DCE was a brand name and continues to sustain its prominence. There certainly are many differences as the institute has evolved with time. The number of students being admitted in the university has radically increased and DTU has advanced in terms of the facilities it provides. The campus area is vast with excellent sports facilities and well-equipped labs. In addition, now there are more female students which is a great improvement. 

How does one overcome the challenges while promoting teamwork in an organization? 

Challenges always exist. Leadership that cultivates a sense of ownership amongst its workers is extremely important. An organization has different kinds of people. If the one who possesses the leadership position can create the concept of ownership and likewise every member understands this viewpoint, they all start working together. Creating a sense of ownership can instill a sense of teamwork.

How can someone work on developing their decision-making skill?

Decision-making requires getting proper input. Listening to the ideas of others, no matter how contradictory it is, and not being close-minded will enrich your thought process. Secondly, proper analysis is important. Analyze every possibility. Your decision is right if it is good for others as well. It is selfish if it is right only for you, and in the long run, society, people, and collaborations are more important.

The youth today often misinterpret our religious scriptures. How should we tell them about what they actually advocate? 

I believe, once the person reads these scriptures, they will form pertinent understanding. These scriptures have a lot of scientific principles which we can adopt even today. For example, the concepts of ‘Karma’ and ‘Rebirth’, ‘Sukta’ and ‘Nasadiya Sukta’ and all the other concepts in our scriptures incorporate most scientific and psychological principles. We need to propagate this idea to the youth that these scriptures can help them throughout their life.

Could you reiterate the importance of teamwork in an organization? Do you think there are any challenges faced while promoting this kind of an environment?

Challenges always exist. Leadership that cultivates the sense of ownership amongst its workers is extremely important. An organization has different kinds of people and if the one who possesses the position of leadership is able to create the concept of ownership and likewise every member understands this viewpoint, then they all start working together. As everyone’s personal goals are different, they neither align with each other nor with the organization’s goals. Creating a sense of ownership can solve this issue.

How would you advise someone on developing their decision-making skill?

Decision-making requires getting proper inputs. You should always listen to the ideas of others no matter how contradictory it may be and not be close minded. This will enrich your thought process. Secondly, proper analysis is important. Analyze every possibility. Your decision is right if it is good for others as well. If it is right only for you then that’s something selfish and in the long run, it is the society, the people and the collaborations that are more important.

title: Interview | Mr. Saurabh Srivastava, Lead South Asia, ASEAN and NoA, Reckitt
biliner: DTU Times interviewed hon’ble panelist of Esummit 2022, Mr. Saurabh Srivastava, Lead South Asia, ASEAN and NoA, Reckitt.
body:
What is the importance of teamwork in any organization? How do we decide the right people for our goals?

What is the complete form of a team? Together, we achieve more. Organizations win or lose because they have the right people in the right place. The team has one coach and a captain, and they're different. The captain commands others, and the coach gives liberty and space to grow. Room to succeed means you've got a vision, and the coach brings that synergy to the team so that everybody contributes 120 percent. So, every organization should have these two.

How does one establish a sense of ownership over his vision or idea?

I believe in 'keeping it simple'. Think of a mother who conceives a baby; she starts caring for the coming baby from the first day. Then finally, a day will come when it will start delivering the results to you. A dream is like a tree. You've to nurture it and take care of it at every step. Once your plan yields results, keep moving forward with new ideas. Narayan Murthy is one of the best instances of this. You are all students right now, you'll be in a different stage of life in a few years; your previous step is now in the past and no longer affects you. Life is constantly evolving.

Can you guide us on how to keep ourselves refocussing on our dream?

I'll quote Dr. Kalam, 'A dream is something that does not allow you to sleep.' You will find a way out if you are passionate about your dream. I feel that students are mature enough to recognise what knowledge is beneficial to them. If you've decided on a single goal, make a strategy for achieving it and by when you'll accomplish it. Begin keeping track of your everyday progress toward your goal. You'll feel content once you start completing trivial goals, and that confidence will lead you to your bigger ambitions one day.

title: Edition 57 | Inclusivity in STEM
biliner: The lack of representation of sexual and gender minorities leads to reduced visibility and manifests as prejudices against them. Read on as Ananya Rath, 3rd Year, B.Des. and Srijan Pandey, 3rd Year, B.Des. discuss what it feels like to live in a heterosexist environment and hope that people become more sensitized and supportive towards minorities in STEM.
body:
Growing up is a tedious process. You start to realize that the legends of your childhood are not mythical after all. Before you know it, you're thrown into the ocean to battle huge waves that were, only a few years ago, "things children need not worry about," with little idea of what you're doing. Any social barrier can seem insurmountable in a time like this, no matter how seemingly random and irrelevant. 

As a child, most of us are taught by everyone around us that we can achieve anything we want if we just work hard enough. And so we believe it. We spend years preparing for a vision, gearing up for a goal that over 2 lakh other peers have as well. Some of us don't make it. Some of us do. However, no one teaches us about the external factors that affect our success after this first checkpoint and how sometimes others' opinions and prejudices will precede our efforts and capabilities.

Being a queer undergraduate in STEM comes with challenges and under-representation. A queer representation of less than a percent within a class and not getting the platform to make queers aware of their rights and create safe spaces within institutions results in biases that are questioned at every point. While heteronormal people in STEM have been rooted in a deep sense of being intelligent, at the same time, they lack the empathy needed to create a space for people with various gender identities. STEM for queers requires role models and queers in positions of decision-making where policies are strategized. It took me a while to understand and express myself as a queer (non-binary) individual within this academic setup. I have been questioned and discriminated against by people at positions and even the faculties. 

As a woman in STEM, sure, I felt the judgement and dismissal all too well. The hushed whispers about diversity hiring as the antithesis of merit, snatching jobs from boys in a college that had a gender ratio of 87% skewed in their favor, always seemed to forget every diligent woman working twice as hard to earn the same amount of recognition, if she was lucky, as her male counterparts did. The devaluation of women's work and the evident systematic roadblocks that make a career in any field, especially STEM, challenging for women have reinforced the gendered division and perception of labor. This has left women in a vulnerable state in an already imbalanced society where men, the economy, and the country prosper at their expense. The probability of success decreases exponentially on a tilted stage where the rules were never made to be fair in the first place.

When it comes to STEM being accepting enough, it lacks vision and equality. Expression comes with a generous sprinkle of negative experiences resulting from a predominantly heteronormative and patriarchal society. The silences around identities and sexualities within the STEM spaces result in a less sensitized environment. This silence needs to be filled so that people have the sensitization to their pronouns and gender expression.
meta_description: The lack of representation of sexual and gender minorities leads to reduced visibility and manifests as prejudices against them. The article discusses what it feels like to live in a heterosexist environment and hope that people become more sensitized and supportive towards minorities in STEM.

title: Edition 57 | The Escape
biliner: To make sense of one’s emotions, as it engulfs one in an endless pitfall of overwhelming feelings, is an arduous journey which, more often than not, yields additional perplexity. Read on as Shaurya Shekhar, 4th Year, COE, strings together a tale of emotional baggage, gripped with the thread of memories, tightened to the point of breakdown.
body:
Going out on a picnic, the last thing on Amanda’s mind was the thought of her 2nd-grade friend turned enemy Cassandra, who she hadn’t seen since 8th grade. A flurry of emotions ranging from anger, which was suppressed for many years all the way to regret, to have lost someone who meant the world to them dawned on her. While both were at the same park, only Amanda was aware of Cassandra’s presence. As she saw Cassandra pass by the park's gate, she almost reflexively started sauntering her way to the other end of the park, so as not to arouse any suspicion. 

The park was a peculiar labyrinth in itself, having the byzantine characteristic of making your way out through the other end practically impossible without covering the entire park once. Scared of the idea of encountering her friend, Amanda kept trying to find the most evasive paths, howsoever circuitous that route turned out to be. What followed is a half-hour anxiety-fueled game of cat and mouse, where the cat wasn’t even aware of the mouse’s presence. Throughout this comical situation, Amanda kept getting reminded of all the ploys she had played to get back at Cassandra, or at least on the pretence of it.

While the emotion elicited by betrayal is almost ineffable, it carries with it a tinge of resentment and some parts of sorrow, all wrapped up in an insalubrious dose of regret. This was the case with Amanda, as she tried her damndest to play the most elaborate game of ‘hide and seek’ of her life. She recalled the time when despite having been friends for over two years, she ended up being left for better friends and how when she needed Cassandra to back her up, she left her completely deserted. Clouded with these thoughts, she hardly realized that she hadn’t seen Cassandra in a while. Upon regaining composure, she soon went into a frenzy trying to find her, but to no avail. 

Amanda sensed a strange presence from behind her, which to her felt almost akin to Svengali. Through the corner of her eyes, she saw Cassandra walking towards her. Petrified by being in her field of view, Amanda found herself incapable of moving. As Cassandra approached her, her heart raced faster, her palms started sweating, and her breath felt heavier. Despite all of this, the only thing she could fixate on was when would Cassandra find out about her. When Cassandra was about four feet away from her, she acknowledged her presence with a nod, much like one would with any stranger. Amanda looked into her eyes and saw no emotions: no regret, no sorrow, no anger, and no happiness.

The tacit realization of her not even recognizing Amanda brought out the most intense emotions in her, one that emerges from irretrievable loss. Trying to make sense of her emotions, she found herself becoming detached from her surroundings. Even as she stood gazing blankly, a thousand thoughts ran through her mind. Tears rolled down her cheeks as she came to terms with the meaninglessness of her fear, worries, concerns and regrets. Though feeling as if she had been rid of the albatross around her neck, she found herself to be empty and discombobulated, feeling like a large part of her life amounted to nothing.

title: Edition 57 | Chimerical Sense
biliner: The carefully crafted plans go wrong, but for the better, as all that seemed dreadful at first soon appeared to be enveloped by a blanket of comfort. Read on as Suvani Rohatgi, 3rd Year, BT, navigates through the chaos of college life and travels on the journey of self-discovery.
body:
The process of change, inevitably accompanied by the unsettling feeling of unfamiliarity, can seem daunting at first. The imperative need to fit in and the uneasiness that comes with the thought of failing to do so is an overwhelming feeling. 

The carefully crafted plans go wrong, but for the better, as all that seemed dreadful at first soon appeared to be enveloped by a blanket of comfort. Read on as Suvani Rohatgi, 3rd Year, BT, navigates through the chaos of college life and travels on the journey of self-discovery.

As soon as I entered the college gates, it was a unique experience. I saw hundreds of students walking toward their respective destinations. Some were busy talking their hearts out, some were devouring what seemed like food or fighting over it, while others were heading towards their classes, possibly. Simply put, it was all chaos. Although this crowd was a little overwhelming and intimidating initially, it sparked a “chimerical sense” or a world of illusions. 

Let me elaborate on my case. Before the beginning of the classes, I was glued to my laptop. I watched probably a bazillion videos on college life, especially on DTU. I became nervous and feared being left out. From the canteen to classes, daily life to friends, societies to events, I tried to plan it all out by watching those vlogs. I was so determined to showcase my talents and prove myself. 

Little did I know that everything I had mapped out so meticulously would blow up in seconds. Slowly as I started to blend in, I realized that my fellow students and teachers were something I had only hoped for. The sense of inclusivity and camaraderie behind the apparent chaos twisted my emotions altogether. Seniors, who have always been portrayed as the ones who live only to bully their juniors, became my chaperones. At least for me, I have been enlightened at each difficult step and received guidance whenever I needed it. I have seen people enjoying themselves in spite of handicaps and being one irrespective of different cultures, ideologies, and backgrounds. 

I think I have understood the true essence of life and what it really means to be a part of the youth dividend. I would love to delve deeper into the microcosmos we have created here at college while I explore my individuality in this safe space.

title: Edition 57 | After the Snowy Night
biliner: Nature is itself a soothing experience, but all it takes is to open up and realise that even our surroundings can heal us. One can get a lifetime of adventure from something as trivial as snow. Read on as Ritvik Nair, 4th Year, COE, describes a boy’s amalgamated emotions as he is out enjoying himself after a snowy night and is in complete bliss.
body:
Nature is itself a soothing experience, but all it takes is to open up and realise that even our surroundings can heal us. One can get a lifetime of adventure from something as trivial as snow. Read on as Ritvik Nair, 4th Year, COE, describes a boy’s amalgamated emotions as he is out enjoying himself after a snowy night and is in complete bliss.

Out came a young boy, stepping onto the white ground. Gush gush, the ground below his two thick boots crushed. A wide smile shone out of him, barely visible beneath his woolen scarf and beanie. His eyes sparkled as he looked at his surroundings. A tall white blanket covered everything from cars to the trees.

The boy leaped and landed shortly ahead of him. Bits of white fluff splashed everywhere, landing and assimilating into the rest of the white cushion. His mouth opened agape, letting out a fascinated gasp. He then spun in a circle, stomping his boots repeatedly onto the ground, laughing as each action led to fluffs flying in all directions.

After many such circles, the boy's attention shifted to the many cars that lined the white field in an orderly manner. Each car was wearing a flat white hat that covered its roof, a white eye mask on its windshield, and a white sweater on its bonnet and trunk. Next to some of the cars were white trees. Each tree periodically sheds some of its white leaves.

The boy waddled towards one of the cars. He took hold of the car’s hat with his small hands and effortlessly borrowed a piece of it. Even through his big gloves, the boy could feel the cold tingle from the small bit of the hat. Instinctively, he began to crush the bit of the hat. Small bits of icy white sand began to escape through the gaps between the boy’s fingers. The part left in the boy’s hands grew smaller and smaller until it was as hard as a rock. Marveled, the boy tried to further crush the smaller-than-his-palms white rock in his hands. Yet, nothing happened. Disappointed, he let go of the small white rock.

The boy looked up. The white tree leaves reflected in his eyes. Unable to reach them, the boy stood on his tiptoes-the boy slipped.

Gush - a loud sound followed.

A large indent of the boy’s figure formed on his landing spot. Having been saved by the large white carpet below him, the boy began to laugh. He laughed at the concerned voices of his parents till his stomach hurt. Finally, he smiled up at his relieved parents.

Illustration by Preeti Das, 3rd Year, COE

title: Edition 57 | Slave To Nostalgia
biliner: Have you ever found yourself yearning to go back in time? Do you, too, think of the good old days and wonder if you will ever be as happy again? At some point, we have all been nostalgic enough to answer "yes" to these questions, but with this piece, Ritwij Kashyap, 2nd Year, IT, makes us wonder if there is a cost that nostalgia comes at. Read on to find out.
body:
Have you ever found yourself yearning to go back in time? Do you, too, think of the good old days and wonder if you will ever be as happy again? At some point, we have all been nostalgic enough to answer "yes" to these questions, but with this piece, Ritwij Kashyap, 2nd Year, IT, makes us wonder if there is a cost that nostalgia comes at. Read on to find out. 

We're all familiar with a deceptive emotion of euphoria, triggering a wave of sensory overload and engulfing one in a fallacy known as nostalgia. Invoked by a familiar scent, a recognizable tune, or even a memento of the past, we've all had our encounters with nostalgia. Often attributed with a sense of comforting knowingness, this hazy recollection of our past is heavily distorted; or at least that's the way it has been for me.

Whenever my mind finds itself in a desolate place, a coping mechanism that it resorts to is reminiscing the past through a filter called the 'Good Ol' Days' and comforts itself with a glimpse of the so-called simpler times. 

The times have never been simple, never are, and never will be. It is merely the imperfect recollection of a distant memory that presents to us a flawless illusion of the past. 

My gripe with nostalgia is not that it evokes a rush of serotonin on encountering a fragment of the past, but rather the fact that it overshadows the present and convinces us to believe that the past was a better time. 

In a world where pure, constant happiness is a utopian quest, positive memories are golden but are often at the cost of taking the present for granted.

A detrimental consequence of being a slave to nostalgia is developing a dystopian vision. 

When one becomes addicted to viewing a glorified version of the past, everything since seems to pale in comparison, leading to the belief that things have only deteriorated up until now and, naturally, will continue to do so.

Don’t get me wrong—I'm not here to bash the concept of nostalgia into oblivion. I preach simply to tread with caution on a road that may seem very inviting at first but is plagued with deception and momentary gratification. As long as one can keep in touch with reality and not give in to the illusions of the past, nostalgia is nothing but a friendly reminder of a fond memory.

title: Edition 57 | Emotional Consequences of Broadcast Television
biliner: We spend so much of our lives trying to trap moments, not letting go, trying to bring back the things we have lost, that we forget the inevitable notions of time and change. Read on as Abhimanyu Dayal, 2nd Year, SE, navigates through the show of life.
body:
We spend so much of our lives trying to trap moments, not letting go, trying to bring back the things we have lost, that we forget the inevitable notions of time and change. Read on as Abhimanyu Dayal, 2nd Year, SE, navigates through the show of life.

I stared at the face reflected against the black mirror. It was solemn, silent, numb. Thoughts passed through my mind like bullets, yet my body couldn’t act on them, cryogenically frozen in this instance of time. 

Every show has a pilot, a middle, and a finale. The pilot, the day you entered this shiny new world—you’re curious, excited, even nervous. You meet different people - Some are outspoken, bold, and uncaring of your opinion of them, but you love them. Some people are toxic and nasty, and you wish for their deaths. While some people may just be side characters, you don’t care either way. The pilot sets the environment for you to find your comfort zone, enthralls you, welcomes you into this universe, and you willingly step in.

Many seasons pass, and new characters come and go. Every episode is different—be it an insane roller coaster ride that keeps you gripping the edge of your seat with wide, unblinking eyes, a moving dive into a character’s mentality, or a simple, uneventful sunny day, enjoying a cup of coffee at your favorite café. In each episode, you get to know your characters just a little better, and every day you smile quietly, unknowingly thanking God they’re a part of your life. 

A day comes, today, when you leave them. You know when the finale is coming, but you can never prepare yourself. The showrunners put effort into giving you a satisfactory ending and a chance to say your goodbyes. You tell yourself you won’t cry, but you never knew yourself if you believed that. The characters move on, and so must you. You cling, at times, to hopes of spinoffs and avidly rewatch old episodes, desperate for that nostalgic rush you felt the first time, but it's never the same. 

Cryogenically frozen in this instance of time, if only. Moments can’t be trapped in a bottle, even if they remain on film forever. Watching an episode the first time is a one-time experience, and you must take it in that spirit. The rush, the suspense, the emotions, you can never capture them on a rewatch, you can never capture them in your nostalgic memories. 

After these six seasons, I leave with tear-soaked cheeks and one simple realization, every episode is the pilot, and every episode is the finale. Every moment is just that, a moment. You don’t get a rewatch, because it’s never the same.

Illustration by Mehak Singhal, 3rd Year, B.Des.
