title: Edition 57 | Play/Stop
biliner: All of us have our fair share of  memories that seem to develop a stronghold on us, gripping us with fragments of the past, making it hard to let go. Music is a powerful memorabilia, capable of bringing back memories and invoking the strongest of feelings. Read on as Riya Singh, 3rd Year, MCE finds solace amidst what she loves, enchanted by the sounds that bring her peace, and in that moment of serenity, comes to the realization that her cherished moments have more parts of her than the people they remind her of.
body:
All of us have our fair share of  memories that seem to develop a stronghold on us, gripping us with fragments of the past, making it hard to let go. Music is a powerful memorabilia, capable of bringing back memories and invoking the strongest of feelings. Read on as Riya Singh, 3rd Year, MCE finds solace amidst what she loves, enchanted by the sounds that bring her peace, and in that moment of serenity, comes to the realization that her cherished moments have more parts of her than the people they remind her of.

At the time of writing this, I've spent more than two months trying to let go. And I'm the kind who will sever all strands of memories to let go of a person. 

I'm writing this on a metro ride back home from one of the most serene moments I've lived on campus. Sitting on a bench outside Pragya Bhavan, with pretty yellow flowers in front of me, a beautiful peacock coming out of the forest from the side, scattered clouds reflecting the orange of the setting sun, and a boy I somehow dared to ask out, sitting next to me. 

Before I knew it, I had asked him to open Spotify on his phone, and I played The Matchstick Pianoman's covers of The Beatles. There, absently staring at the sky with my chin resting on the bench, I found a moment in which I finally realized that the things that bring me calm are more about me than the people they remind me of. And like that, I listened to my favorite instrumental album for the first time in a while and felt at ease with myself. I felt a kind of peace—just sitting there, nearly drowsing off to the sounds that would’ve left me sleepless a month ago, next to a person who barely knew how much the album meant to me but still appreciated the beauty of it. 

With people, leaves music. But with music, come back pieces of me that fell apart in preventing bigger falls—the sights that made me teary-eyed, the sounds that overwhelmed me, the words I could not read, all the scents of the places—come back. 

I tell him, "Stop! Look at the canopies above us." And with me, he stands there staring at the sunlight barely making its way through the envelope of leaves that decorate the skies of Vice Chancellor's Lane. It reminds me of when I exclaimed, "Let’s go look at the full moon!" But they didn't. The point isn't that this person beside me looked up but that, regardless, I held my head high and looked at what I loved.

I had already stopped.

title: Edition 57 First Day
biliner: While the secret of getting ahead is getting started, we often overlook the strain that one initially reels under while embarking on a journey into an unknown abyss. There will certainly be times when the person would be plagued by self-doubt and worry but nonetheless, it is always the courage demonstrated on the "First Day" that subsequently becomes an evocation of self-belief. Take the plunge as "it gets better", assures Ishita Mehta, 3rd Year, SE while sublimely articulating the rush of emotions a person is posed by while starting on their odyssey to glory and self discovery.
body:
While the secret of getting ahead is getting started, we often overlook the strain that one initially reels under while embarking on a journey into an unknown abyss. There will certainly be times when the person would be plagued by self-doubt and worry but nonetheless, it is always the courage demonstrated on the "First Day" that subsequently becomes an evocation of self-belief. Take the plunge as "it gets better", assures Ishita Mehta, 3rd Year, SE while sublimely articulating the rush of emotions a person is posed by while starting on their odyssey to glory and self discovery. 

Pulsating heart and sweaty hands, and hesitancy in your steps. You shift your weight from one foot to another, and your muscles seem tightened. A million thoughts rush through your mind as if ready to spill and spatter everywhere. All the turbulent emotions fill every hidden crevice in your body, so much so that you don’t understand where one emotion ends and the other begins. 

“First days are rough.” 

Emotionally taxing and mentally draining, it isn’t supposed to be easy. You may not know anybody, and nobody would know you. You feel excited and elated but also nervous and anxious. Inwardly, you are ready to combust, yet shroud yourself with a thin veil of composure. Almost like a duck, regally calm above the water but frantically paddling beneath the surface.

Before you let your ungoverned emotions get the best of you, take a moment to look around yourself. The cerulean sky, the canopies of the trees, and the beautiful peacocks. Realize that each and every person comes in as a bundle of nerves. Vulnerable and with self-doubt. No one is perfect, after all. 

It gets better—if not now, then later. I can assure you that it only goes upward from here. And before you know it, you will have marked your identity, discovered things about yourself that you didn’t know before, and metamorphosed into something extraordinary. You might even be surprised by the place that you are now in. It casts a charm on you, and soon enough, it becomes a part of you. 

“First days are not so bad. It’s only the first stepping stone, after all.”

Illustration by Keshav Chauhan, 3rd Year, EE
meta_description: First Day/New beginnings

title: Edition 57 | Home
biliner: There’s something about a place called “Home” that doesn’t let go of you. Even when you move to a new place and leave behind all past memories. While reliving vague, fuzzy memories, you find buried pieces of yourself. Or with distinct ones, that are scented with the emotions of the past, they often gently remind you of a part of yourself that you would always keep close to your heart. Read on as Saujanya Sood, 3rd Year, IT plays a bittersweet symphony with her words and takes you along her journey of reminiscence.
body:
When I first moved to the city I now call home nearly five years ago, I wanted nothing to do with the old one. I wanted to erase all memories except those I had with my family. All of them seemed tainted with a slow black. Thinking about them made me realize what I had lost and what I would have to work to now gain. This new city was better, busier, and lowkey glamorous. I started getting used to its grey skies and the sight of no stars but a strobe light piercing the clouds every couple of minutes. 

But I would still go back home sometimes, and when I would, it would all come back to me. I left a piece of me there. This piece felt sweet when I’d think about the seven-year-old sitting in winter sunlight with her books. Still, it would turn bitter, spanning roads I spent hundreds of bus rides on in the euphoria of childhood with friends I no longer felt acquainted with. 

When I moved, I knew I never wanted to look at Delhi the same way I looked at my hometown. I was determined to make every memory feel great in retrospect. And so, every time I dive into nostalgia, I somehow find a way to make it seem pleasant. But as I write this, I enter the capital's borders again, and everything here seems bittersweet - from the metro to the flyovers, Aerocity to Bawana. 

I’m certain to move to a new place in a couple of years. I’ll visit here and probably feel overwhelmed and uneasy at times, but also happy as I get reminded of traffic jams in the rain I spent drowning into a Papon single and of all the epiphanies I had on metro rides home. It is, indeed, not all dreamy. But this is probably what happens when you decide to call a city home - you leave a part of yourself there. It’s not perfect, but it’s yours. And this city lets you relive it. It enables you to go back to a you that was probably more naive but one that felt little fear, a part you once wanted to forget but one you keep close to your heart now.

Read on as Saujanya Sood, 3rd Year, IT plays a bittersweet symphony with her words and takes you along her journey of reminiscence.

When I first moved to the city I now call home nearly five years ago, I wanted nothing to do with the old one. I wanted to erase all memories except those I had with my family. All of them seemed tainted with a slow black. Thinking about them made me realize what I had lost and what I would have to work to now gain. This new city was better, busier, and lowkey glamorous. I started getting used to its grey skies and the sight of no stars but a strobe light piercing the clouds every couple of minutes. 

But I would still go back home sometimes, and when I would, it would all come back to me. I left a piece of me there. This piece felt sweet when I’d think about the seven-year-old sitting in winter sunlight with her books. Still, it would turn bitter, spanning roads I spent hundreds of bus rides on in the euphoria of childhood with friends I no longer felt acquainted with. 

When I moved, I knew I never wanted to look at Delhi the same way I looked at my hometown. I was determined to make every memory feel great in retrospect. And so, every time I dive into nostalgia, I somehow find a way to make it seem pleasant. But as I write this, I enter the capital's borders again, and everything here seems bittersweet - from the metro to the flyovers, Aerocity to Bawana. 

I’m certain to move to a new place in a couple of years. I’ll visit here and probably feel overwhelmed and uneasy at times, but also happy as I get reminded of traffic jams in the rain I spent drowning into a Papon single and of all the epiphanies I had on metro rides home. title: Edition 57 | Shades of the Night
biliner: Walking with light, carefree steps under a cool night sky, lit with mischievous, winking stars, Aditya Mann, 3rd Year, ECE, introspects on the beauty of the night, and the quality of its darkness that makes it so colourful.
body:
Walking with light, carefree steps under a cool night sky, lit with mischievous, winking stars, Aditya Mann, 3rd Year, ECE, introspects on the beauty of the night, and the quality of its darkness that makes it so colourful.

The imagery of the night is tarnished. Only the bereft and nocturnals are said to keep awake. However, only the night provides refuge from all the noise and clamor of the day. The nights are dark to the dopey mind but look closely, and you will find a palette of shades beaming. Its trance is akin to the consumable intoxicants that leave you blurry and memoryless, yet, the most memorable. The magic of the night briefly alleviates the indulgence from the characteristically intangible distress of an inconsequential life that is otherwise taken very seriously. 
 

What about this monochromatic darkness makes it so colorful? This gloom spans a range of hues—jolly, crippling, blurry, introspective, agitated—but invariably melancholic as the dawn nears. 
 

What makes it so comforting? Black, not just figuratively, but also objectively, absorbs all colors in the visible spectrum. Internalize the blackness and see all the unparalleled vividness come to light. In the tryst with the night, the perception game is played, testing your senses and the lessons you have learned from the realms of the day—silent, quiet, and muted, sometimes a little too loudly deafening, but evocative nonetheless. So silent that the loudest of echoes within the head fall on deaf ears. 
 

A discreet leeway exists that, coupled with ear-bleeding silence, can make you rejoice with hope or let you shed tears spooked by the ghosts of the past. Either way, only you are privy to it. Visually, nothing loses its luster. It only brings out the true self, which is somewhat masked in colors during the day. If the sun shines and the moon wanes for an almost equal time, then why is it normative to define and view the world from a lens only between dawn and dusk. Is the sky really blue or the grass really green? The diurnal beings that we are must seek to subjugate the complexities of the night, for the reality that it presents us with is unquestionably vibrant—because nights are not just for dreaming but for finding solace in keeping awake.  

Illustration by Shreeya Shrivastav, 4th Year, B. Des.

title: Edition 57 | Surviving DTU
biliner: Some of us come to college with everything sorted out for the next four years - the job we want to land, the clubs we want to get into, the trips we want to embark upon with a friend group we think we have found in the first week of college - but somehow, by the end of it all, we end up questioning everything around us. Certainty is safe, but certainly not fun. Read on as Ananya Rath, 3rd Year, B.Des., helps you walk through the twisty, broken, yet forgiving path of DTU!
body:
Some of us come to college with everything sorted out for the next four years - the job we want to land, the clubs we want to get into, the trips we want to embark upon with a friend group we think we have found in the first week of college - but somehow, by the end of it all, we end up questioning everything around us. Certainty is safe, but certainly not fun. Read on as Ananya Rath, 3rd Year, B.Des., helps you walk through the twisty, broken, yet forgiving path of DTU!

My dear ingenuous fresher 

Congratulations on having made it to DTU! You did it. You survived JEE and years of back-breaking, mentally exhausting coaching for it. Everyone is so proud of you. Maybe you wanted to be somewhere else, but that's okay. You will make peace with it soon. 

You will (hopefully) take all your required classes and join societies and teams where you might find the best of friends, or lessons, depending on your luck and choices. In the end, if the TnP Gods are kind enough to bestow you with their blessings, maybe you will get to heave a sigh of relief in your ceremonial blue shirt after landing an internship or a job.

But that is a long walk from where you are right now. You are probably still trying to navigate through the maze of SPS classes and being amused by the OAT. If you’re living in the hostels, good luck with the Wi-Fi connectivity (spoiler alert: there’s none) but congratulations on all the experiences you’ll have. Don't worry. You might get better with navigation, and while the fountains will not work 364 out of 365 days in a year, I promise that the allure of things that are quintessential “DTU” in nature will never go away. 

When I started college -Sure, I was boxed up in my room during the first innings of COVID-19- I was excited to start working toward a career I loved. But most of all, I was so freakishly scared. I knew I got in, but what now? What was I supposed to do to be this best version of myself and all the pseudo-intellectual preach I read on Instagram? What would life be like here, and how did I plan for it?

I know you're expecting an answer, but the truth is, Like most of your seniors, I am still getting surprised every day—for better or worse. Plans change. Things don't work out. You don't get what you want. Life isn't always fair. Or sometimes, things do end up working out in your favor; you never know. And while I theoretically did know all of that, it took surviving DTU to realize the actuality of all this. 

So while I can't tell you what to do and expect, all I can tell with the infinitesimal wisdom of the mere few months I have over you is that college will make you learn. It is a dark and twisty road, and you will be learning to ride a bicycle all alone all over again right here, along with 2000 odd batchmates. These four years will allow you the luxury to be blatantly instinctive and free, and maybe time herself knows it. So she'll put you to the test, bend your back over and over—with mistakes, with the situations you’ll be wrongfully penalized in, with people you should not have trusted, with professors who make you wake up at 7 AM during frigid Decembers, and with every moment you spend here—you will be forced to learn through your laughter, tears, pain, exhaustion, and anger. More importantly, look at college life as a series of gambling tables and play at each table patiently and sincerely; know that there is always a chance and hope ahead; trust your instinct on when to move to the next table instead of betting all the coins at just one.

I am sorry if I catfished you into thinking this is your cheat sheet to surviving college, but in the words of Taylor Swift the Great (albeit wildly out of context), how can a person know everything at eighteen but nothing at twenty-two? And in your time here, should you happen to stumble upon a roadmap or maybe curate your own survival guide, make sure to have it published in Times!

title: Edition 57 | Dot-Com Bubble
biliner: "While the infinite assortment of images on the internet is condensed to resemble a mere bioscope, a pen and a poet have, for a long time, chronicled the wars and glory in their entirety." Read on as Manvi Nilaya, 3rd Year, ENE, explores and questions her interpretation of the dot-com bubble.
body:
My primary source of worldly wisdom is limited to a few episodes of Kaun Banega Crorepati that I stumble upon on television. The major credit for my subsistence amid Gen Z goes to acting as the interim-youngest-oldie among goshthis of grandparents. However, this is not close enough to know about the stock market shenanigans of the infamous dot-com bubble of the late 2000s. I am only bound to welcome you to my literal interpretation of the dot-com bubble where I reside.

My earliest literature memories from school were a few quintessential poets and writers. I only seem curious about the distinction of each piece of writing. Every article of work carries a degree of strangeness to the beauty of the same world we live in. While writers from the Age of Wordsworth exercised an imaginative impulse on their own perspective of the world, the writer penning this piece of work looks up to a lucent 14-inch window headed by titles with a '.com' suffix for inspiration. My minuscule creativity is fueled (or decelerated?) by occasionally letting myself sink into a seemingly endless haystack where I am meant to find a needle to weave those strands into a basket of stories. There is no longer a hunt for originality, but a quest for original perspectives or articulations remains. Whether that's crawling through artists I don't know well on Spotify or following an uncountable number of aesthetic Pinterest boards until I have forgotten about what I was initially concentrating upon, the palpitations of information trigger periods of thoughtlessness where I squeeze my head to document even a single paragraph. 

In the words of Satyajit Ray, "If you take some words at random and put them together, it becomes gibberish. But if you string together unrelated moving images, some people will always hold that the celluloid strip aims at some profundity."

While the infinite assortment of images on the internet is condensed to resemble a mere bioscope, a pen and a poet have, for a long time, chronicled the wars and glory in their entirety. The paralyzed creative anarchist within me questions—how?

title: Edition 57 | Friendly Neighbourhood
biliner:
Be it plucking up all the courage or the ultimate ceasing into composure; every new place is a different journey for everyone. Some dive right in like a duck to water, while others explore cautiously. Regardless, the first emotions are the same for most – expectations, excitement and apprehension.

Read on as Rishika Sinha, 3rd Year, ENE, intertwines all the trails of her relationship with her 'friendly neighbourhood' – walking from the initial sense of denial to steadily understanding, adapting, and ultimately evolving into accepting the transition, the warmth and the discomforts.
body:
Be it plucking up all the courage or the ultimate ceasing into composure; every new place is a different journey for everyone. Some dive right in like a duck to water, while others explore cautiously. Regardless, the first emotions are the same for most – expectations, excitement and apprehension.

Read on as Rishika Sinha, 3rd Year, ENE, intertwines all the trails of her relationship with her 'friendly neighbourhood' – walking from the initial sense of denial to steadily understanding, adapting, and ultimately evolving into accepting the transition, the warmth and the discomforts.

"There’s a discomfort in revelations and in understanding reality, and I might have sworn to secrecies that lie in the shrouds of metaphors.”

In every version of our make-believe world, we go far beyond our self-conceived limitations - I was antagonistic to some of the impressions I had created, yet they were not so to me. And so, one day in the late summer of this year, I popped open my eyes to decamp from my confidential entanglements as I settled in the midst of an unknown crowd. I agreed with myself to stay hush, even with a palpitating heart and a puppeteered will to indulge in conversations. I clenched my fist to feel my parched skin. I shut my ears to listen to the intonations. I lay inert, sunken into invisibility, on a tenanted warm bench, waiting to welcome fresh realisations. I debated the monologue on an ideal 20-year-old life. I fought against conventional agreements while I recited the hoaxed past two years and negotiated with the mistakes - an awful and unnecessary screenplay; all in my head. 

All this while, as I assigned myself superfluous roles, the downy soft turf, and the summer air hummed poems against my unmindful consensus to introduce me to their comforting prospects. And, as I began to walk around, acquainting myself with unblocked passages, I allowed myself to accept the poetry that followed. Although the verses seemed fuzzy, they persisted to call up my restricted senses. And I then began to harmonise with the cadence of the phrases I could not understand. I fought along with the imperfections they underscored. At the same time, I welcomed all the discomforts - a much-needed, inescapable segue into acceptance and metamorphosis. 

And so, on another day in the late summer of this year, I found myself collapsed on an empty bench in an empty classroom. I clenched my fist once again to feel the same parched skin. I shut my ears again to sing along with the same intonations. I appreciated the solitary conversations - I accepted the devoted affinity between a fictitiously cold, perhaps troubled, and ever-decrepit mortal, and her indissoluble friendly neighbourhood.

Illustration by Sarthak, 3rd Year, B.Des.

title: Readers' Week | I Drowned
biliner: Some days you dread waking up - you’re overwhelmed, depressed, lonely. You feel hopeless, all alone, yet surrounded by doubt and fear. Read on as Khushi Rustagi, 2nd Year, B.Des., puts those moments down on paper, to remind you that everyone has these days, and this too shall pass.
body:
Some days you dread waking up - you’re overwhelmed, depressed, lonely. You feel hopeless, all alone, yet surrounded by doubt and fear. Read on as Khushi Rustagi, 2nd Year, B.Des., puts those moments down on paper, to remind you that everyone has these days, and this too shall pass.

Messy bedsheets,
Pillows on the floor,
Torn bits of paper
That I didn't need anymore
Puffy eyes
Tear-soaked wipes
Cause I wept like a baby all night.

I don't know,
Why it felt hollow
Like the world was falling apart
I could feel
Something heavy
Something pressing down my heart.

I am lonely,
Yet feel surrounded
It is quite
Yet I hear sounds which
Scare me, hurt me, pull me down,
And here I am lying on the ground,
Staring for hours,
At a deep, black void
That I imagine on the ceiling,
but can feel inside.

I need help
But I can't cry
I'm too scared
No reason why
I can feel my head spinning
And the air gradually thinning
And in that huge sea of nothingness,
The smallest twig or leaf could have been hope.
And how I wish it was there
But nope.
I drowned.

biliner: Once you set the wheels in motion, the swivelling garners thoughts, memories, hope and despair. Anshita Garg, 2nd Year, COE inspects the disorder that comes in the absence of oblivion stemming from inability to stop something that has already been started and how one should approach the different facets of it including new experiences, rewards and guilt.
body:
Once you set the wheels in motion, the swivelling garners thoughts, memories, hope and despair. Anshita Garg, 2nd Year, COE inspects the disorder that comes in the absence of oblivion stemming from inability to stop something that has already been started and how one should approach the different facets of it including new experiences, rewards and guilt.

Every morrow brings a new experience; peculiar each day,
None of the same kind; nor I ever dare to say;
To do something out of the box,
Maybe invent a new orthodox.


It's all up there well charted,
You can not stop something that has already been started.
Maybe a punishment, maybe a reward,
Maybe some guilt, maybe a sword.
Practice the art of it,
You've only been endowed with a part of it.
 

Despite His overlooking, let your steps and kindness rhyme,
He's good people, bud, He's not always blind.
Something shall come your way, something has already departed,
You can't stop something that has already been started.
 

Insignificant should be the size of the bait,
Once it has been registered to be already too late.
Further in life, would you one day take note,
Of thoughts, you'd definitely quote-unquote.
'Somethings just did not ring the bell of men so very kind-hearted,
Because they could not stop something that had already been started.

title: Readers' Week | The One Who Knocked The Door
biliner: Loneliness can plausibly be paralleled with a blackhole. It can consume one in all it's entirety. Read on, as Utkarsh Sharma, 1st Year, SE poetically sketches how a person's self love can be a good escape to an eternal loneliness and how crucial it is to understand that it might not always be us who were at fault.
body:
Loneliness can plausibly be paralleled with a blackhole. It can consume one in all it's entirety. Read on, as Utkarsh Sharma, 1st Year, SE poetically sketches how a person's self love can be a good escape to an eternal loneliness and how crucial it is to understand that it might not always be us who were at fault. 


Sitting on a lonely couch,  
In a haunting, dark night,  
Glancing at the empty sky,  
Even the stars lost their light,  


Heard a strange sound,  
Wondering who it was,  
There was a knock on the door,  
But who was the one coming, inspite of all the flaws?  


Was in a unreal dilemma,  
Whether to be happy, or to be sad,  
Was it a friend who left me alone?  
Or it was the love i never had?  


Slowly and consciously,  
I marched towards the gate, 

Exploring the cracks of the walls,  
Wondering what would be their fate  


I turned towards the mirror,  
And found it all but torn  
Found my old dressing kit,  
Applied some scent and i combed.  


Saw the face again after eternity,  
Wondering what happened  
It lost all of its glory and charm,  
All I saw was unpleasant.  


I came back to.my cupboard,  
Wore my long English coat,  
Found some letters underneath,  
Some time ago I wrote.  


Went back to the door,  
And opened it with a smile,  
Saw nothing but darkness,  
And a letter, resting on a wooden pile.  


Opened the letter,  
Written in my name,  
Written by no one but me,  
Ain't it such a shame?  


"You look good dressed up,  
Do it much more often mate,  
Il always love you, be by your side...  
.  
Untill next time, I knock on the gate"

title: Readers' Week | The Joy of Being Oneself
biliner: Liberating yourself from the pretences that society often demands of us can be daunting. But when you finally seek freedom to embrace all of yourself, the feeling is like no other. Your strengths, vulnerabilities, and quirks are what make you authentic. Read on as Maanit Arora, 1st year, ECE, pens down his thoughts on ‘The joy of being oneself’ and celebrates his individuality as a form of self-love.
body:
Liberating yourself from the pretences that society often demands of us can be daunting. But when you finally seek freedom to embrace all of yourself, the feeling is like no other. Your strengths, vulnerabilities, and quirks are what make you authentic. Read on as Maanit Arora, 1st year, ECE, pens down his thoughts on ‘The joy of being oneself’ and celebrates his individuality as a form of self-love. 
 


"Why would I make me suffer 
By comparing myself with others?" 
My heart asked my mind. 
Ain't getting any answer yet. 
Both are still figuring out I bet. 

But the sun never wanted to be the moon. 
The light never wanted to be dark. 
The autumn never wanted to be spring. 
The flowers never wanted to be the mighty trees. 
They cherish in their own way 
Bloom in their own way. 

The warmth of my own self. 
Was something I should have known since the start. 
Should've praised myself since the start. 
Cause the place I'm at at this moment. 
The battles I've fought, won and forgotten. 
That ain't easy for anyone else, but me. 

So why should I, exactly? 
Both are still figuring it out, yet. 
But I'm glad both are trying.♥️

title: Readers' Week |  तुम्हारे बाद
biliner: शब्दों, ध्वनियों और लय में आत्मीय जुड़ाव के माध्यम से स्मृतियों और भावनाओं को जगाने का सामर्थ्य होता है। पढ़िए इसी दिशा में सार्थक, प्रथम वर्ष, बी.डिज़ाइन, का स्नेह, स्मृति, उम्मीदों और पछतावे से परिपूर्ण यह काव्यात्मक प्रयास ।
body:
शब्दों, ध्वनियों और लय में आत्मीय जुड़ाव के माध्यम से स्मृतियों और भावनाओं को जगाने का सामर्थ्य होता है। पढ़िए इसी दिशा में सार्थक, प्रथम वर्ष, बी.डिज़ाइन, का स्नेह, स्मृति, उम्मीदों और पछतावे से परिपूर्ण यह काव्यात्मक प्रयास ।

इश्क बहुतों से किया है मैंने तुम्हारे आने से पहले, 

पर ये दिल किसी पर आया नहीं कभी, 

तुम्हारे जाने के बाद ।

यूँ तो इश्क करना मुश्किल नहीं,

पर तेरे बिना इश्क में भी वह मज़ा नहीं,

मोहब्बत के बारे में सुनकर अक्सर तुम्हारा ही चेहरा आँखों के सामने आता है बार-बार, 

पर ये दिल किसी पर आया नहीं फिर, 

तुम्हारे जाने के बाद ।

शायद दिल की बातें मैं तुम्हें कभी ढंग से बता नहीं पाया, 

तभी तुम्हारे साथ रहने के ख़्वाब को मैं हकीकत बना नहीं पाया,

पर ख्वाबों में भी कहानियाँ मैंने तेरी ही सुनी हैं, 

बस तेरे बारे में ही लिखना है मुझे बार-बार, 

क्योंकि ये दिल फिर किसी पर आया नहीं कभी, 

तुम्हारे जाने के बाद ।

मेरे लिए तुम उन अल्फ़ाज़ों जैसी थीं, जिन्हें मैं रोज़ गुनगुनाया करता था,

मेरे लिए तुम उस गीत जैसी थी जिसे मैं कभी भूल नहीं सकता था,

तुम्हारे साथ रहने की आरज़ू अधूरी रह गई,

पर तुम्हारी यादों से ही कर लेता हूँ अब हर एक बात,

क्योंकि मेरे दिल में कोई नहीं आया फिर, 

तुम्हारे जाने के बाद ।

ये दिल न चाहते हुए भी तुम्हारा इंतज़ार करना चाहता है 

और तुम्हे आँखों के सामने देख कर बस बेवजह मुस्काना चाहता है,

मुझे पता है मैं तुम्हारे लिए कुछ नहीं, पर तुम मेरे लिए बहुत खास हो,

शायद तुम जैसा कोई मिलेगा नहीं मुझे, 

दिल भी जानता है ये बात, क्योंकि तुम रहती हो दिल में मेरे और दिल में कोई आया नहीं फिर, 

तुम्हारे जाने के बाद ।

title: Readers' Week | Serenading Silence
biliner: Love and affection make us plunge into a carousel of celebrations, a rollercoaster of emotions, and a sensation of tranquillity that is as soothing as a lovely tune. Read on as Purusharth dips a pen in his heart and creates a piece of writing that makes you imagine love, as much as he adores that feeling.
body:
Love and affection make us plunge into a carousel of celebrations, a rollercoaster of emotions, and a sensation of tranquillity that is as soothing as a lovely tune. Read on as Purusharth Seth, 1st Year, MCE, dips a pen in his heart and creates a piece of writing that makes you imagine love, as much as he adores that feeling.

I want you to imagine a cold, cold and dark room, with a little window peeking over and nothing but gloomy silence. The room is quiet, with no noise, a whisper of joy, or any delightful mumble. Then, suddenly, from the window, some light caves in,  maybe moonlight. And the room lights up, not to that shiny sunshine, yet enough for one to rejoice. The silence disappears to some foot thumping, perhaps- oh, no! It's drums that are beating,  THUMP THUMP THUMP! And back at the window, the moonlight is illuminating, and the room is lightening. It's lighting up with many hues! The room, it's full of vibrant colours, colours of joy,  colours of happiness, colours that may even put one to sleep. What is it- Oh!
 

The drums are beating faster, in a rhythm now, a true melody, maybe one that makes you sway your arms, lose yourself. Ah! And an angel appears in that vibrant room. Angelic and divine, she dances to the beat, to every thump, as if her soul finds peace in the much dearie calm to us. You hear another melody from behind,  a melody putting you to sleep, a deary lullaby. This melody, unlike the beating of drums, doesn't light your soul on fire, instead, this one tells you, it's alright, honey, it's okay. Everything will be okay. You fall away from all the earthly woes. Your soul relaxes, your body calms, and you finally smile peacefully. 
 

The room, that room is my heart, lady. That window is from where your love caved in as light. Those drums? That's my heart beating for you. That angel dancing, rejoicing? That's me being content in your presence. That other calming melody? That's you telling me how much you love me.

Read on as Purusharth dips a pen in his heart and creates a piece of writing that makes you imagine love, as much as he adores that feeling.

title: Readers' Week | Chess
biliner: A game so ancient, yet evergreen, the ultimate test of patience and strategy. The checkered battlefield donned with the pieces carrying within it the reflection of life. Riddled with complexities akin to nature, chess is more than just a game for Chirag Jha, 1st year, CE. Read on as he takes us on a journey through the game, unfolding this metaphor for life along the way.
body:
A game so ancient, yet evergreen, the ultimate test of patience and strategy. The checkered battlefield donned with the pieces carrying within it the reflection of life. Riddled with complexities akin to nature, chess is more than just a game for Chirag Jha, 1st year, CE. Read on as he takes us on a journey through the game, unfolding this metaphor for life along the way.

Chess is science, chess is an art,
it's a game of minds, and a game of heart.
Chess is black, and it's countered by white,
to launch the bishops, to place the knights.


Chess is so ancient, yet it's so new,
it's a feeling, understood only by few.
Silent, when it's war and debate,
chivalric, when it's time for checkmate.


Like life, it evolves from our decisions,
whether they are reckless, or with precision.
Square by square, when you push the pawns,
that is how your success dawns.


It tutors you, to harbor your intuition,
and mentors you, to avoid confusion.
Attack and defense, are parts of the plan,
to strengthen your position, to protect your clan.


It's less like a sport, and more like nature,
Where there's hierarchy, where there's stature.
Yet all beings, together they exist,
to offer their support, and to assist.


Found a good move? Look for better!
Think it through, so that you don't regret later.
Create your own identity, on a crowded board,
use your capabilities, let them be explored.


The straightforward rooks, the multi-talented queens.
many attributes of humans, we've all seen.
Chess is a game of patience and calm
and when it's right, you pounce and disarm.


How much more can you reflect the truth,
32 pieces of experience and youth.
A good game of chess is all you need,
to experience the state of a mind freed.

Read on as he takes us on a journey through the game, unfolding this metaphor for life along the way.

title: Readers' Week | लिखे जा रहा था
biliner: कलम में वह शक्ति है जो किसी इंसान को उसके सारे गमों से बाहर निकाल सकती है, इंसान को सुकून देती है और एक अलग दुनिया में ले जाती है। पढ़िये कैसे सुहंश वार्शने, प्रथम वर्ष, ई. एन. ने अपनी सुंदर कविता द्वारा लेखन की इस क्षमता का वर्णन किया है।
body:
कलम में वह शक्ति है जो किसी इंसान को उसके सारे गमों से बाहर निकाल सकती है, इंसान को सुकून देती है और एक अलग दुनिया में ले जाती है। पढ़िये कैसे सुहंश वार्शने, प्रथम वर्ष, ई. एन. ने अपनी सुंदर कविता द्वारा लेखन की इस क्षमता का वर्णन किया है।

जब मेरी दुनिया उजड़ रही थी, 

तब मैं शब्दो में खोया हुआ था 

जब मेरी रातो की नींद उड़ी हुई थी,

तब मैं कहानियां बुन रह था 

अपनी सांसों के बदले, 

अपने कलम की स्याही बिखेर रहा था 

मैं पहली बार ज़िंदा महसूस कर रहा था।

 

शौक शौक में शुरू हुआ ये सिलसिला, 

अब आदत सी बन चुका था 

 कभी सोचा ना था वो कर दिया, 

मानो जैसे करिश्मा स हुआ था 

मैं पहली बार काबिल महसूस कर रहा था।

 

किस्से कहानियों का खाज़ाना ढूंढने निकला था -

 अपनी ही कश्ती पर सवार,

 मैं दरिया घूमने निकला था,

 इस वाक्य की गहराई समझने निकला था,

 मैं कविताओं के समंदर में डूबने को निकला था

 मैं पहली बार आज़ाद महसूस कर रहा था।

 

मैं बेबाक होकर सारे नियम तोड़ रहा था,

 इस कला से अनजान अपनी ही रचनाएं रच रहा था,

 अपने हर एक ख्याल को पन्ने पर बटोर रहा था 

मैं व्याकरण को अपने ही तरीके से मोड़ रहा था

 मैं पहली बार ताकतवर महसूस कर रहा था।

 

जिस खामोशी की तलाश में में भटका दर दर था,

 जिस सुकून की आस में मैं भागा घर - घर था 

अब उसका एहसास कर रहा था, 

मैं ज़िन्दगी को पहली बार महसूस कर रहा था

 मैं तो बस लिखे जा रहा था।

title: Readers' Week |Life Currently
biliner: Capture moments of joy and nostalgia in the everyday, find solace in simple moments, accept the chaos of life — smile and be a little childish! As you amble through Aanya Aggarwal's, 2nd Year, B.B.A., poetic interlace of thoughts and sentiments, experience the sublimity of your quotidian existence — slow down and appreciate the world around!
body:
Capture moments of joy and nostalgia in the everyday, find solace in simple moments, accept the chaos of life — smile and be a little childish! As you amble through Aanya Aggarwal's, 2nd Year, B.B.A., poetic interlace of thoughts and sentiments, experience the sublimity of your quotidian existence — slow down and appreciate the world around!

Sometimes when I forget to write

Hustling through the week infinite

My heart starts rhyming with the thoughts

Truly, it barely misses a shot

Scanning the metro card

Or hitting the goal with a dart

Not getting lost in the flow

But owning the show

"What a weather!", exclaiming both in good and bad

Scorching heat or raining like it never had

Gossiping around the campus

Meeting the deadline like we mustn't

Peeking out of the window of a metro

Riding in an auto and jamming to retro

Rain droplets on closed eyes like feeling no other

Truly, no one gets you better than your mother

Not being like a mouse trapped in a wheel

Add your own twist to every day that reveals

Meet your friends now and then

Do not let them hanging on when

Make your outfit effortlessly stylish

Smile and be a little childish

Keep this writer alive

Slowly walk a mile

title: Readers' Week | सफ़र प्रेम का
biliner: दिलदार द्वारा दर्द-ऐ-दिल का अनुभव हर प्रेमी को होता है। क्या कहा, क्या अनकहा, कहा तो क्यों कहा, न कहा तो क्यों न कहा - ऐसे ही तो होते हैं मोहब्बत के मसले। पढ़िए इन्ही भावों का पंक्तियों में रूपांतर करती और प्यार की एक भावभीनी दास्ताँ रचती मुकुल सिंगला, चतुर्थ वर्ष, ई. ई., की यह मनमोहक कविता।
body:
दिलदार द्वारा दर्द-ऐ-दिल का अनुभव हर प्रेमी को होता है। क्या कहा, क्या अनकहा, कहा तो क्यों कहा, न कहा तो क्यों न कहा - ऐसे ही तो होते हैं मोहब्बत के मसले। पढ़िए इन्ही भावों का पंक्तियों में रूपांतर करती और प्यार की एक भावभीनी दास्ताँ रचती मुकुल सिंगला, चतुर्थ वर्ष, ई. ई., की यह मनमोहक कविता।

उसे छूने से हाथ जो ये कांप जाते है
मुझे अक्सर सर्दियों की याद दिलाते है
उसकी गली में अब घर बना लूंगा मै
मुसाफिरों का क्या है? आते है, चले जाते है
कभी धूप तो कभी छाव बनूंगा मै
मौसम तो आरजी है, बदल जाते है
चाह कर भी उसे कह ना पाए कभी
क्या करें? बोलने पे होठ थरथराते है
पूरा भरोसा है मुझे अपनी किस्मत पे
जो चाहते है वो हम कब पाते है?

इजहार-ए-मोहब्बत कभी की भी नही
बहुत बाते हुई मगर बात तो कभी कही भी नहीं
मना किया था ना तुमने बताने को ,
वो बात हमने किसी से की भी नही
हिज्र भी नहीं बोल सकते तेरे फिराक को ,
मोहब्बत तो कभी तुमसे थी भी नही

ना जाने कब खत्म होगी इस दिल की तन्हाई
अक्सर लड़ते रहते है, मै और मेरी परछाई

करते है जो बाते चाँद-तारे तोड़ने की ,
मैने अक्सर उन्हें दिल तोड़ते देखा है

सो नहीं पाते थे जिसकी यादों में,
अब तो उसे याद किए भी अरसा हो गया है।

Underscoring the notion that every person harbors dreams, and though the path to realizing them may prove difficult, life is abundant with prospects and alternatives, Ananya Rath, 3rd Year, B.Des., exhorts readers to relish life's simple pleasures and construct a magnificent, felicitous, and unforgettable mosaic using the myriad of experiences that comprise their existence. The fundamental idea is to derive joy from the journey, commemorate the minor triumphs, and craft a colorful and exceptional collage that kindles genuine happiness.

Livsnjutare | (n) A Swedish word meaning, “enjoyer of life” 

If you are reading this, congratulations! You’re a human. And if you are a human, there is no denying that you, too, have atleast one dream. Now, I am no one to say that this dream of yours is any lesser or more significant than Mr. Martin Luther King Jr’s dream. However, given that you are here, standing in DTU as a part of a crowd that walked into this place already as the creme de la creme of millions, chances are, you have, what most would consider big dreams.

An internship at the top recruiting tech company? Placement at an MBB? An ivy-league admit? Or maybe you are still figuring it out.

I am not going to lie—it is a daunting journey ahead. And the bad part is, you won’t always have a map. But the good part is, that the World is a big place, and if you are resilient enough, life finds a way. In college (and, extension, life), there is no one way to get what you want. It is a process with many milestones, opportunities, exits, and options along the way. 

So if it's a long, confusing, tiring journey ahead, why not celebrate every little thing that brings you joy? I promise you won’t lose sight of your destination if you stop and enjoy a cup of chai along the way. 

After all, what are you, if not an intricate mosaic of all the things, people, and experiences that have left an indelible mark on your life? So choose to make it a happy mosaic. One with millions of little colorful pieces, making it a vibrant, extraordinary, memorable mosaic. Most importantly, make sure it is a mosaic YOU love, your magnum opus celebrating a life so drunk on moments of euphoria and ecstasy that you experienced. Oh! * whispers * and to hell with what the World thinks.

In the end, you are not who you aspire to be. Still, you can always let your little dreams and achievements, and joys calcify into a beautiful life that you would’ve truly celebrated and enjoyed living.

title: Edition 58 | 7 Things Us Nerds Should Do At A Concert
biliner:
"Still, letting myself go for once and enjoying everything 
like those typical 'GenZ kids' did feel liberating, almost magical."

While the college hijinks smother us into a horde of assignments and deadlines, steal moments to make the most out of the ongoing fests out of the college. Read on as Riya Singh, 3rd Year, MCE, breaks her nerdy-shell blasting at a concert and brings to us seven concert-worthy essentials for our next concert.
body:
I think there are always some things we never do because we think they’re below us. Concerts, EDM, and party outfits were all those things for me. But a few weeks ago, I attended a concert from center stage with a bunch of strangers, and that made me realize how much - okay, seriously, HOW MUCH - I have been missing out on. As someone who proudly claims to be a 70s kid mentally, I will always love Frank Sinatra and Kishore Kumar more than dhupchik-dhupchik music. Still, letting myself go for once and enjoying everything like those typical “GenZ kids” do felt liberating, almost magical. So here, I strictly instruct you to follow my concert guidelines and have the most fun you can. It doesn’t matter if you don’t know the artist or if you don’t have the right people or the right clothes - just go ahead and have a wild, wild time.

Dress up! 
Do you want to know a secret? Nobody is looking at you at a concert. Everyone is too busy waiting for the artist to arrive or trying to find space to stand straight and not trip and fall over a stranger. So use this opportunity. Take out that dress, that co-ord set that you thought you could never wear. For once, give yourself the freedom to look too feminine, promiscuous, or tacky—no one’s watching, go all out with your wardrobe! 
Go closer to the stage! 
I took a risk with writing this point. Please don’t go break the barricades, scare off the artist, and get beaten up by security. In case you do, please don’t quote me as your muse. Some people prefer standing behind since there’s more dancing space. But for me, a non-dancer, I like being as close to the stage because of the lights. I absolutely love how even with my eyes closed, I can just jump to the flickers of concert lights, not to mention, when you look up, the whole sky is filled with confetti. It’s the most beautiful sight in a fest! 
Shut up and bounce! 
You probably don’t dance. But I know you want to. Even when you don’t know the song, even when everyone around you is dancing - because you’re too shy. So am I. And here I want you to remember the secret I mentioned in Point 1 - nobody’s watching. So do your silly little moves with pride! 
Click a selfie with a stranger 
Okay, you probably will photobomb someone’s picture at least once. If you can’t move elsewhere to avoid coming into someone else’s picture, you might as well pose for it—say cheese! 
Learn a dance move
Yes, you can get away with just jumping and flailing your arms in the air. But if you’re feeling a little comfortable, challenge yourself to a dance move! Hint: Just look around and find a good dancer to copy. Hint pt. 2: Please don’t creep someone out by staring for too long. 
Get a glitter tattoo!
It’s not a fest until everything, and everyone sparkles! Find the glitter tattoo stall and get a crazy (no, don’t try to be sophisticated here) tattoo that you never thought you would get! If you’re not catching everyone’s eye, what are you here for? 
Yell that song at the top of your lungs
We all have a song we’re too embarrassed to know all lyrics of. It’s at least true for someone like me who brags having an acquired taste in music. But you are in DTU, we’re a melting pot of musical tastes which might start with Prateek Kuhad or Dream Note, but it always ends with Jatta Ka Chhora. What do you have to be ashamed of?

All in all, go wild. Check these boxes after you do it. Trust me, you’ll feel so proud and liberated at the end of it. I hope you make this the best concert night of your life!

title: Edition 58 | Plateauing Dopamine
biliner:
You’re on the metro home. The concert’s over, you have an assignment due tomorrow, your midterms are two weeks later. The dopamine high wears off, leaving you tired, aching…. and sad?

You catch a glimpse of your reflection in the dark window. “What now?“

Read on as Saujanya Sood, 3rd year, IT, takes the homeward bound train, thinking the same thoughts, feeling the same ache.
body:
I fade in.

I am greeted by a mail this morning, from a professor I have been meaning to work under for months now, telling me he is willing to offer me a project under him. My heart skips a beat. I call my mother, my sister, and my friends, exclaiming, barely catching my own breath. Within a week, I have it all figured out - tickets booked, suitcases packed, university hotspots researched — I am psyched as ever. Oh, all the people I will meet, the things I will learn. I am on a train, going to a different city all on my own, and yet, I feel like I am running. I look outside — and I look back, my life has been a celebration in preparation for a rather larger celebration in the last week.

I fade out.

Here I am, a couple of weeks later, going home with a heart and a phone full of memories, and all my brain is asking me now is, “Now what?” Everything in the last three weeks has been like the train I am currently in. But now what? Where is my dopamine rush? Why am I suddenly uncomfortable? Why don’t I feel like I am home when I am not running? Running to a new city, to a new environment, to work, to party? I become a square wave, constantly on an adrenaline high but seeking short-term dopamine highs, again, and again, and again, somehow never finding a shore to rest on.

Is this how it is supposed to be? Unsettling as it is, I am living in the after-the-party’s-over zone and it forces me to rethink the act of seeking celebration and wondering whether such happiness really is the aim I mean to chase in life. We define landmarks in our lives, festivals, birthdays and achievements, selectively celebrating sand-dunes that are bound to shift, and throw us in the process, into a valley as we try to hold on to the peak.

title: Edition 58 | Anti-Hero
biliner: The perception of heroes as being infallible and immune to flaws puts them on a pedestal, which the naive child looks up to with awe and admiration gleaming in their eyes. The heroes' extraordinary feats, often exaggerated by the rose-tinted lenses through which they are viewed, masks the imperfections that make them human. Read on as Ishita Mehta, 3rd Year, SE, narrates the transition out of childhood, uncovering the true person behind our hero, and celebrating the unembellished anti-hero.
body:
The perception of heroes as being infallible and immune to flaws puts them on a pedestal, which the naive child looks up to with awe and admiration gleaming in their eyes. The heroes' extraordinary feats, often exaggerated by the rose-tinted lenses through which they are viewed, masks the imperfections that make them human. Read on as Ishita Mehta, 3rd Year, SE, narrates the transition out of childhood, uncovering the true person behind our hero, and celebrating the unembellished anti-hero.

The vivid surrealism of our childhood is what made it special. I’m not talking about waistcoat-wearing rabbits and a Mad Hatter, but surely the orange marmalades and long hours in the sun. It was a wonderland of joy and imagination and everything felt like it came straight out of Carroll’s head.

We didn’t have the Cheshire Cat by our shoulders faintly whispering to us, but we had our heroes as our guiding spirits. Simple, ordinary humans with extraordinary personalities. A teacher, a sibling, some public figure or maybe a neighbour. We looked at them with awe and adulation. And while we had a warped view of the world, limited by both our age and experience, we were sure these humans were perfect. Majestic, like a tiger, without any vulnerability. Someone who inspired us to see the world in a different way.

Strong. Compassionate. Resilient. We emulated all the things that we wished to be.  And found our own identities in the process of gaining their appreciation. Completely charmed and enamoured by our heroes, we would often look up to them in moments of uncertainty.

But once we came out of our rabbit holes to transform into pragmatists, we started to see the cracks in their armours. Our heroes— reduced, lessened, and humbled, perhaps, by the ageing process. With every pound gained, and every hair lost or turned grey, another layer chipped away. We started to see them much like who they were instead of beguiling ourselves with who we wished them to be. Maybe because it was punctuated by our sense of connection with them, or maybe because we didn't quite understand the full spectrum that life has to offer us. But while our perspective on people has evolved to realise their imperfections, we still have the choice to admire them regardless. 

There may not be an archetypal hero in our world, but we can celebrate our anti-heroes just the same, with affection and gratitude.

title: An Unfeigned Celebration
biliner: While expectations can set us up for disappointment, celebrations offer an opportunity to appreciate the efforts and love of those around us. Being grateful and showing kindness can make the celebration even more meaningful, and help us live life to the fullest. Read on as Suvani Rohatgi, 3rd Year, BT chooses to embrace the beauty of each moment and shifts the focus on celebrating the inner sentiment of an occasion.
body:
While expectations can set us up for disappointment, celebrations offer an opportunity to appreciate the efforts and love of those around us. Being grateful and showing kindness can make the celebration even more meaningful, and help us live life to the fullest. Read on as Suvani Rohatgi, 3rd Year, BT chooses to embrace the beauty of each moment and shifts the focus on celebrating the inner sentiment of an occasion.

“Whatever it is you're seeking won't come in the form you're expecting.”

― Haruki Marukami

Life is so constructed that the event does not, cannot, will not, match the expectation. Well, the same goes for celebrations too. Celebration is not just a physical event, it is more of an inner sentiment. Be it birthdays, anniversaries, victories or festivals, we try to create everlasting memories each time. People who are close to us make us feel delighted by organising a “great”  event and topping it off with a myriad of gifts. Over the years, the word “celebration” has taken on a factitious meaning. Today, we seek to be amused or entertained. It has become more of a materialistic and exaggerated effort. Our consciousness is almost completely preoccupied with expectations and so, often people don't get fully satisfied with whatever they get. The onerous efforts go in vain when people have high, lavish expectations of a celebration. Should we not be grateful for the heart that they have put into making us happy? Well it's the other way round too. We expect that whatever we have given or done will surely make the other person happy. These expectations perhaps make us weak. Weak in expressing, thanking and living life to the fullest. So, it's a forever learning that even if we don't get what we desire we should be thankful and appreciative of the feelings, efforts and hard work of the other person. We should not forget that life’s under no obligation to give us what we expect. We should behave decently without the expectation of rewards.

title: Edition 58 | Cherishing the Quotidian
biliner: The most sought after emotion for the masses seems to be happiness - the pursuit of which is perceived as a race by most. We’re constantly trying to “reach” somewhere that is happy, forgetting the less glamorous but possibly serendipitous milestones we pass on the route to the big celebration. Read on as Ritwij Kashyap, 2nd Year, IT, walks you through the smaller yet meaningful joys of life.
body:
The most sought after emotion for the masses seems to be happiness - the pursuit of which is perceived as a race by most. We’re constantly trying to “reach” somewhere that is happy, forgetting the less glamorous but possibly serendipitous milestones we pass on the route to the big celebration. Read on as Ritwij Kashyap, 2nd Year, IT, walks you through the smaller yet meaningful joys of life.

Waking up to the all too familiar alarm and peering at the phone screen through a wink, only to discover the blessed notification of that 8 AM class being cancelled. At that moment, the blanket feels warmer, the bed feels cosier, and no matter how short-lived, that feeling of total bliss seems unmatched.

Our lives are full of such little bundles of joy scattered across our quotidian quests. The subconscious celebration of these cherishable moments is one of the most beautiful ways of paying homage to the virtues of the human spirit. These moments may seem insignificant in the grand scheme of things, but our innate elation is evidence that we do not live in the grand scheme of things after all.

There are moments of obvious joy. I say obvious because there is usually a societal consensus on the celebration of such events. Birthdays, weddings, festivals - you get the idea. Now, sipping on that perfect cup of tea while basking in the sun may pale in comparison to the glamour of a party for some people. However, the joy that I derive from moments where there is no expectation of it distinguishes these nuggets of happiness from the moments of obvious joy.

At a time when happiness has become increasingly scarce, finding beauty and significance in the ordinary moments of life and recognizing that they can be just as meaningful as grand or extraordinary events is a boon to humankind. In the quest for true bliss, we tend to venture far and wide in the hope of coming across the secret to happiness, all the while neglecting the pieces of the puzzle we encounter on the journey.

I believe these unexpected moments of gratification are what inherently drives us and compels us to look forward to things. Perhaps what compelled me to write this was the subconscious expectation of the unexpected, the joy I can now experience, having finished writing.

title: Edition 58 | The Diary Of Pinocchio
biliner: Despite his admission of falsehood and imperfection, he lauds his unique qualities and the companionship that have allowed him to reveal his true self. Read on as Rishika Sinha, 3rd Year, ENE and Manvi Nilaya, 3rd Year, ENE follow the musings of Pinocchio, the narrator, as he contemplates his transformation from a simple piece of wood to a bona fide human.Pinocchio recognizes that his heart is now human despite its solid wooden shell, and he finds a deep connection to the world. He is thankful for the experiences that have shaped him and revels in his metamorphosis.
body:
Despite his admission of falsehood and imperfection, he lauds his unique qualities and the companionship that have allowed him to reveal his true self. Read on as Rishika Sinha, 3rd Year, ENE and Manvi Nilaya, 3rd Year, ENE follow the musings of Pinocchio, the narrator, as he contemplates his transformation from a simple piece of wood to a bona fide human.Pinocchio recognizes that his heart is now human despite its solid wooden shell, and he finds a deep connection to the world. He is thankful for the experiences that have shaped him and revels in his metamorphosis.

(Based on the story by Carlo Collodi)

“Once upon a time, there was a piece of wood, not an expensive piece of wood, a common block of firewood.” My name is Pinocchio, I am an ordinary piece of wood. As a leaf quivers, as a bird sets sail; as a mother sings, as this story begins - I remain ordinary, I remain masked. I am indifferent and mute; still and all, tender and impassioned. I am impatient, maybe ungrateful, impulsive, and naive. I like the mellow springs, I like the chilly nights. I am a little warm, enmeshed in strings - mute with a hundred poems, unveiled with assumed emotions.

“Lies, my boy, are known in a moment. There are two kinds of lies, lies with short legs and lies with long noses. Yours, just now, happen to have long noses.” After every lie was another lie; and a truth behind each. I refused to accept the roses, the sunflowers, the lilies; I refused to share the sunshine. “Good boys always tell the truth.” “I am Pinocchio, and I always tell lies.” I have been dishonest. I have been belligerent, and gluttonous, I know. But I have also walked past being barely human.“To-morrow I cease to be a puppet, and I become a boy like you and all the other boys.” Rummaging through the paraphernalia of my strings, I have always promised to prune them. I always fit into the shapes carved by others, colouring myself into their lines, and committing myself to a seamless marathon of fitting in. One for the laugh and two for the show, I begin my race. But how do I win when I want to lose this race?

I have danced my way through some beautiful days, forgetting when I’d trip and bumble and shamble. “I met some really nice people, Jiminy. They helped me and they didn’t even have to.” “Well, that’s what friends do.” Today, I celebrate my individuality - my peculiarity. I celebrate my flawed story with cheers, woo hoo, huzzah! And I write this to the friends and the toasts and celebrations, for the moments unforgettable, and to what has made me human - I am Pinocchio, I’ve got no strings to hold me down. And, to the celebration of truthful friendships - it is you why I have no wretched mask today, why I have uncovered my vulnerabilities and strengths, soaking emotions into my heart. I now feel the sentiments of humans being puppeteered by situations, and my heart beats enunciated, like a marionette in a high wind - I feel belongingness. I celebrate that today I have a human heart encased in a rock-solid piece of wood. I celebrate when I look out at the world, which is always so unusually sparkling, when I feel a sense of eeriness, just like a common human. I feel the wind, I adore its modesty, and fear the wrath. My name is Pinnochio, and I am a real boy.

Illustration by Sarthak Sharma, 3rd Year, B.Des.

He is thankful for the experiences that have shaped him and revels in his metamorphosis.

title: It's Not a Fest Day Anymore
biliner: Just a few days back, DTU was shimmering with lights and everyone was grooving to the craziest beats, be it at the OAT or the Concert Ground. But, all the lights, music, scrumptious food, and essentially the vibe, are now gone. The fest is OVER. Read on, as Riya Singh, 3rd Year, MCE, opens up about how it feels to look at the bare steps of OAT again and wonders what all the next fest season might bring for her.
body:
Just a few days back, DTU was shimmering with lights and everyone was grooving to the craziest beats, be it at the OAT or the Concert Ground. But, all the lights, music, scrumptious food, and essentially the vibe, are now gone. The fest is OVER. Read on, as Riya Singh, 3rd Year, MCE, opens up about how it feels to look at the bare steps of OAT again and wonders what all the next fest season might bring for her.

For anyone wise enough to live it thoroughly, DTU is not a college. It’s an experience. Fests are one thing I have been super excited about ever since Aarambh. Attending Raghav Chaitanya’s concert from center stage, with trippy lights that I could feel even with my eyes closed, was the beginning of my love for concerts. There has been no looking back. 

Concerts are like a big party for one. Everyone’s dancing to their own beat, barely concerned about what the people around them would think if they saw them making silly dance moves. For once, in your life full of impatience, you stand in lines and wait for an artist to arrive. You hoot. You shout. You laugh. You smile. You cry. You look up to the blinking lights, the confetti, the fireworks—and for once, you are not ashamed of anything. You hold your chest, and you cannot tell if what you’re feeling is the music or your heartbeat. It’s all one. Even standing there amongst hundreds of strangers, maybe a couple of friends, with very little space and a lot of dust—you’re a happy kid. 

I am a girl who only listened to 70s rock and western classical. But in DTU, you cannot remain restricted in your music taste. Since December, I’ve been the girl who plays Ndee Kundu, DG Immortals, Bollywood, EDM, and whatnot—on repeat. I never thought I would be the person crazily dancing to Jhotte or Kaleshi Chhori in a crowd of unknown people, but I am now. And I am more than happy and proud to be that kid. 

Fests from your own college always have a special place in your heart. I went to Mood Indigo in December, and ever since, I have been eagerly waiting to see what EngiFest would be like. For the last month, I have been planning outfits, daydreaming about walking into a decorated college, and going to concerts of artists I might not even know about. There was so much planning that went into it. 

But now, as I write this, it's not a fest day anymore. Around me, I see everyone packing up and cleaning, taking off stalls. I can see every staircase of the OAT today. There are no stage lights, no artist I am waiting for. Today, I’m just sitting in the OAT on a bench facing three lifesized posters and five strings of paper art hanging from the clocktower, wondering if it’s ever going to be the same again.

As a COVID student, I only get one more time at EngiFest. Maybe it's not the same next year—maybe my eighth semester workload overrides my urge to attend every concert next year, maybe I’m no longer with the friends who helped me pick my outfits this time, dealt with an overenthusiastic friend who kept moving from room-to-room with the only mirror in the flat, kept me safe in a Delhi crowd, let me glitter them up in every concert, taught me silly dance steps in afterparties, and stopped me from overdosing on chocolate. 

Maybe next year will be very different, with different people and different circumstances. Perhaps it’s too soon to be thinking about it already, I know it is. So I will try to keep myself sane by telling myself how times are fleeting, and hope for the best in the year to come.

title: Edition 58 | Commotion Beneath The Ice Sheet
biliner:
They watch you lightly tap your feet and twirl your fingers, your ears plugged, eyes distant and serene. They hear the faint buzz coming from your earphones, and they envy you. In this moment, the world cannot hurt you, for you’re beneath the ice sheets. In this moment, you’re immortal. 

Read on as Aditya Singh Mann, 3rd year, ECE, strings a beautiful melody of words describing his unique relationship with music.
body:
They watch you lightly tap your feet and twirl your fingers, your ears plugged, eyes distant and serene. They hear the faint buzz coming from your earphones, and they envy you. In this moment, the world cannot hurt you, for you’re beneath the ice sheets. In this moment, you’re immortal. 

Read on as Aditya Singh Mann, 3rd year, ECE, strings a beautiful melody of words describing his unique relationship with music. 

When Louis Armstrong sang, “What A Wonderful World”, life indeed seemed better. When David Gilmore’s chords made time stand still, the deepest dormant emotions jolted. When Adele hit a high note, eyes closed and the head lifted.

Music is just another apparatus to haul into a dimension only known to an individual away from the clang of the world that we all share. It’s like the sweet few seconds right after the splash when you dive into a pool completely feeling yourself and the sketchy fast moving thoughts halt guising as if it was until eternity before returning to the surface.

It is here, in this alternative reality that makes your head sway and body groove. If there are a thousand genres then there are a million more ways to unravel them because each melody attunes differently to various intonations since songs are tickets to a universe in your subconscious continuously being built by experiences and memories and aestheticised by perceptions wherein your creative self can unboundedly hover around, foray into a multitude of possibilities, dream, imagine and take comfort while basking in abundant emotions.

This space is yours to the hilt, celebrate and dance like nobody’s watching, cry as if it were a loyal friend you share profound sorrows with, abscond from the noise of existence and take refuge for it is your safe place. The belongingness here is comforting that stays put to the utmost degree of companionship.

From the facade of it, the life flourishing beneath cold and dry frozen lakes isn’t apparent but there subsists commotion, complexity and discomposure. Similarly, the rollercoaster of emotions steering from our sound of music within, making us go astray from the actualities of life, doesn’t manifest outside comprehensively making only us aware of it. The assortment of fantasies experienced as a main character in our la la land are far and wide but solely ours. Music can bring out a smile or leave you teary eyed, discerning abstractions of love, solitude, nostalgia, remembrance, immortality and regret amongst countless others.

title: Edition 58 | A Fireside Chat With Myself
biliner: Sometimes the best conversations are the ones we have with ourselves, by the fireside of our own minds. Conversing with oneself is honest in reflection and fearless in self-discovery. The realisation that perfection is an illusion, and true happiness lies in self-acceptance and gratitude for life's imperfections, allows us to live more authentically. Read on as Abhimanyu Dayal, 2nd Year, SE reminds us to embrace the journey and enjoy the ride.
body:
Sometimes the best conversations are the ones we have with ourselves, by the fireside of our own minds. Conversing with oneself is honest in reflection and fearless in self-discovery. The realisation that perfection is an illusion, and true happiness lies in self-acceptance and gratitude for life's imperfections, allows us to live more authentically. 

Read on as Abhimanyu Dayal, 2nd Year, SE reminds us to embrace the journey and enjoy the ride.

“Tea or coffee?”

“Would one be safe assuming you have milk?”

“Interesting choice. Was that a Tarantino reference?”

“You know me well. A glass of warm milk would be sufficient, thank you.”

I placed the glass in his hand and sat down opposite him, a cup of tea in mine. The fire crackled comfortably, loosening winter’s icy grip. I looked into his cold brown eyes, identical to mine, studying me as I did him.

“I’ll be honest, I was somewhat surprised to get your invitation. To what do I owe the pleasure?”

“We’ve known each other for over twenty years, lived together even, and yet we have never talked, just the two of us. There’s always been others present, and they’ve always been the topic of conversation. I want to talk to you, about you, just this once.”

“That’s fair. Let me start simple, then — how are you?”

“That’s the wrong question. Some days I’m happy, some days I’m not. In college, every day’s a new emotion. Better question would be, are you satisfied?”

He sighed deeply. “My expectations for life, sometimes it feels like I can never meet them, like I’m holding out for absolute perfection — the perfect grade, the perfect job, and I can’t be satisfied until that impossible standard is met. Is that crazy?”

“You didn’t answer the question.”

“No, I’m not satisfied with what I have, I want more. Always. Is it crazy?”

“Yes, it’s insane. Expectations need to end somewhere, else you’re just running into oblivion.”
“If you know that, then why do you do it? Why do you beat yourself up by setting impossible standards?”

“I’m worried, scared, that the world would chew me up if I’m not the best. It feels like a war, and nothing short of absolute perfection can get me through it.”

“Do you think your fears are justified? Are you actually as expendable as you think you are?”

“There are people who care about me, and to them I’m not. But there are far more people who don’t. To them, my grades, my skills and abilities, that’s what defines my worth.”

“How about me? What is my worth to you?”

“Do I care about you? I don’t know. I care about your happiness, but I accept that I have to sacrifice that sometimes. Is that caring? Sacrificing your happiness so you can grow?”

“Isn’t there a limit? How much happiness can you deny yourself? Or conversely, how much growth can you deny yourself? I can never reach a balance, where I can stop feeling guilty.”

“Quite paradoxical.”

It went silent. I could tell he was scared to continue, same as me. We sipped, quietly, taking in the warmth of the fire, even as our skins prickled with goosebumps. 

“What now?” It escaped me. 

“Life goes on. Things will shift and change, and we’ll change with it.”

“Will we?”

“Hopefully.”

title: Edition 58 | Interview - The Cultural Council, DTU
biliner:
It’s been a long way from Homecoming to Engifest, yet somehow, the Cultural Council has always kept us wondering how they pull off events of this scale. From enthralling performances that keep our eyes hooked onto the stage, to tiny events that keep us engaged throughout the day, the CC makes our lives feel more than just classes and assignments. 
Read on as the Cultural Council shares how they create magic out of thin air, and the numerous challenges they face on their journey from “Fest karana hai” to creating an epitome of grandeur at the campus.
body:
It’s been a long way from Homecoming to Engifest, yet somehow, the Cultural Council has always kept us wondering how they pull off events of this scale. From enthralling performances that keep our eyes hooked onto the stage, to tiny events that keep us engaged throughout the day, the CC makes our lives feel more than just classes and assignments. 
Read on as the Cultural Council shares how they create magic out of thin air, and the numerous challenges they face on their journey from “Fest karana hai” to creating an epitome of grandeur at the campus.

DTU Times interviewed the outgoing Cultural Council (2021-22) of DTU — Lovish Arya (Cultural Secretary), Avishek Bhagat (Treasurer), Aditya Chauhan (Joint Cultural Secretary), Shambhavi Chaturvedi (Joint Cultural Secretary), Vishesh Punia (Joint Treasurer), Himanshu Gill (Joint Treasurer), and Imane Elouaghzani (Community and Diversity Coordinator).  

Now that you are graduating, what are your key takeaways from being a part of the Cultural Council?

The past year has been a challenging one for cultural councils at universities all around, as the pandemic forced many events to be cancelled or moved online. One of the key strategies that the council likely used to manage the challenges posed by the pandemic was to embrace digital platforms and move events online. Additionally, we also focused on organising events that were more feasible to conduct during this time such as online poetry slams, online dance competitions, online debates and webinars on various topics. Furthermore, the cultural council also used this time to build their digital presence and engage with students through various social media platforms. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, the DTU Cultural Council demonstrated tremendous resilience and resourcefulness.

What is more difficult—reaching out to artists, planning the event or procuring sponsorships? 

The decision-making process for the DTU cultural council typically involves a combination of inputs from the council members, feedback and suggestions from the student body, and research on current cultural trends and events. The council meets regularly to discuss and brainstorm potential ideas for events and activities, taking into consideration factors such as feasibility, budget, and representation of various cultures. Ultimately, the Cultural Council's goal is to create inclusive and engaging cultural experiences for the entire DTU community.

Give a little insight into the decision-making process by the council and how it comes up with ideas and approaches artists? 

Each of these elements of planning a cultural event can present its own set of challenges. Reaching out to artists can be difficult for a number of reasons. For example, popular or well-known artists may be in high demand and have busy schedules, making it difficult to secure their participation in an event. Planning an event can also be challenging, since it involves coordinating a variety of different elements, such as securing a venue, arranging logistics and transportation, coordinating with artists and performers, and marketing the event. Procuring sponsorships can be a difficult task too, as it requires convincing potential sponsors that the event will be beneficial for them and that they will get a good return on their investment.

The Cultural Council in DTU is synonymous with grand events and fests on a huge scale. However, this past year has been a struggle for everyone, juggling and shuffling between online and offline modes of college. How was this managed and overcome by the cultural council?

Organising events as council members requires a great deal of leadership and teamwork. Through this experience, you learn valuable skills in teamwork, communication, and leadership. Planning of cultural events requires creative thinking and the development of innovative ideas as well, which hones one's creativity and problem-solving skills. The past year has also been a challenging one, with the pandemic changing the way events can be organised. Adapting to the situation and coming up with new ways to organise events and engage students despite the challenges is a valuable skill.
