body:
“College is a place where you really start to become what you are. This is because prior to that you are still being moulded and affected by parents but in college you are completely independent.”
DTU Times had the honor of interviewing Dr. Raj Soin, CEO of Soin LLC and distinguished alumnus of the 1969 batch of Mechanical Engineering. In this interview, he shared his insights on his time in DCE, entrepreneurship, and the Indian startup ecosystem along the importance of a concept-oriented education system. 

Read on as he offers valuable advice for budding entrepreneurs and emphasizes the significance of alumni associations in funding programs and infrastructure developments at universities.

How was your time at DCE?

College is a place where you really start to become what you are. This is because prior to that you are still being moulded and affected by parents but in college you are completely independent. I wish I had spent more time studying but I didn't. One of the things I realised was how much I liked studying. In our education system there is a lot of cramming and contrary to reality, you are expected to remember everything and perform every task.

How do you think India can move towards a more concept-oriented system of education?

It is slowly trying to. In my observation, education here seems to be a source of pressure. Education is extremely significant in high school because it builds the basics. Exposure in college is very different and the biggest thing to master in life is how to deal with people. You can keep learning but not be able to apply it. So college is the time where you learn how to learn. 

What prompted your shift to finance and business?

My interest was in motivating people, so I switched to industrial engineering, which had a lot more to do with statistics, psychology and management. I can walk into a room, talk to 5 people, lay out a dream and make sure they follow through with it, which is just motivating people. 

Since you’ve been into Venture Capital, a highly competitive space, what is your take on the Indian Startup Ecosystem and any piece of advice for budding entrepreneurs?

I think it's getting a lot of traction right now. In this instance, I have suggested that professors work with alumni to assist them with financing, as they are in a better position to guide them. There is no dearth of ideas, but problems arise when Venture Capitalists are unable to identify the needs of the country. This is where the role of entrepreneurs comes in. 

Do you think Indian universities should also form alumni associations that periodically contribute to their institutions?

I’m a strong advocate of alumni associations funding programmes and infrastructure developments at universities and have spoken to people about the same. Alumni organisations should represent the campus, be managed by the campus and not by external organisations. A certain pride is associated with being an institution's alumni, and it is important that alumni have the opportunity to contribute to similar initiatives since we ourselves feel we owe the institution a debt of gratitude.

In your opinion, what is the motivation behind funding the dreams of entrepreneurs and what is your thesis for identifying successful companies?

You get about a hundred ideas a month and only consider a handful of them for further evaluation. You can cull the number down further to just one while having a strong understanding of that sector. At the founder’s level, they need to be extremely convinced and passionate about their idea. Your belief needs to be very strong because Venture Capitalists are not just investing in a concept but also in the ability of the team to actually make something happen.

What advice would you give to the students of DTU?

Enjoy your time. One talent you must have is the ability to communicate. You may have the most brilliant idea but if you cannot present it effectively, you can’t make progress. This applies in all spheres of professional life. So, take time and become a very proficient communicator.

title: Edition 58 | Interview - Mr. Vinod Dham
biliner: “I believe the advice I will offer is to make a difference. That is, make the planet you leave a better place than the planet you came into." DTU Times had the pleasure of interviewing Mr. Vinod Dham, the ‘Father of the Pentium Chip’ and a DCE alumnus, during his visit as the Guest of Honour at the Inauguration Ceremony of the newly constructed Raj Soin Hall & the Homecoming Alumni Meet 2022. Read on as he explains his belief on how it's okay to fail and that failure can lead to success.
body:
“I believe the advice I will offer is to make a difference. That is, make the planet you leave a better place than the planet you came into." DTU Times had the pleasure of interviewing Mr. Vinod Dham, the ‘Father of the Pentium Chip’ and a DCE alumnus, during his visit as the Guest of Honour at the Inauguration Ceremony of the newly constructed Raj Soin Hall & the Homecoming Alumni Meet 2022. 

Read on as he explains his belief on how it's okay to fail and that failure can lead to success.

You are famously known as the “Father of the Pentium Chip”. Can you tell us a little bit about your experience at Intel?

The reason why I’m associated with that title is that I led the team responsible for the Pentium program to success and glory. Now to earn that responsibility, I had to work on the predecessors of the Pentium. Having worked on earlier versions of the chip, I had experience of chip design and fabrication. I had consistently shown the management that I could handle complex projects, deal with setbacks, and manage a team of engineers through thick and thin. 

Do you believe in the ideology that multiple failures can lead to success?

The key is to learn from failure. Whenever we say that it is okay to fail, we are referring to striving hard to accomplish something, and in doing so, it is implicit that you will fail. Consequently, you’ll try more, learn more and, as a result, get farther each time. Another thing to note is that you are not the only person who will fail; anyone who wishes to take the same path will have to go through the same process. The one advantage you can gain over the competition is the “first-mover advantage”, wherein starting out early will put you ahead.

In the late 90s, when you left Intel to join NextGen, it must have been a difficult step to take. Can you tell us more about that decision?

It was difficult to leave from an emotional point of view. However, I was at a crossroads at that point. Having closely witnessed the rise of Silicon Valley, it was evident that the glamour of California was due to the booming and fast-growing startups in Silicon Valley. At 45, it is somewhat out of the ordinary to try one’s hand at startups. However, I had this nagging feeling that if I didn’t step out now to expose myself to this underground world of startups, I would miss out. So I went ahead and got financial advice. In response to my concerns, my advisor assured me that the decision I made would not adversely affect my prospects for a secure future, regardless of whether the startup was successful. That was my cue to go and do what my heart told me to do, making leaving Intel the second-best thing I had done, the best being joining Intel.

You’ve seen the Indian and the international educational infrastructure very closely. What do you feel is lacking in the Indian education infrastructure?

The biggest drawback of the Indian education system is the inability to provide hands-on training. For example, in VLSI, not only do you have to design a chip, but you also have to fabricate the chip and test it. More learning is accomplished through practical training in laboratories, particularly in fields like physics, electronics, etc.

What do you think motivates you? What is something you’ve learnt from your college experience and is there any advice you would give to anyone who wishes to follow in your footsteps? 

I think what motivates me is to make a difference. It’s like my mind is programmed a certain way - after a few days it starts nagging me to be productive. In view of the accidental nature of our existence, I believe the advice I will offer is to make a difference. That is, make the planet you leave a better place than the planet you came into. If that becomes your aim, as it did for me, the next step is to find that passion that will sustain you for a long time. This is because you will only see the results after a long time. When you find that passion, it goes beyond work, it becomes joy. If you can find yourself in that state, where all work becomes joy, you will also be working 18 hours a day, regardless of age. 

How can the youth of India contribute to developing a more experience-based learning ecosystem?

Since the actual setup of such a system is very capital-intensive, it is difficult for the youth to pull off something of this sort independently. Something which the youth can focus on and that I find lacking in the younger generation is developing a mindset of creativity and innovation. There is a lot of emphasis on knowing things, getting good grades, and passing exams, whereas I believe that sometimes it is okay for the student to fail. In this way, many individuals would be able to venture out of their comfort zones, who might have been confined due to the fear of failure.

biliner:

DTU Times interviewed Varnit Sharma, EP, Class of 2021 who scored a 99.98 percentile in the CAT examination 2022.
body:
'Practice and consistency are key to scoring well on the exam. I used to efficiently balance my time between work, giving mocks, and analysing them.'

DTU Times interviewed Varnit Sharma, EP, Class of 2021 who scored a 99.98 percentile in the CAT examination 2022.

Being an engineer, what do you think was your inspiration behind choosing CAT?

My father knew I would be an engineer long before I did, which is how I landed at DTU. During my college years, I got an opportunity to work with a society now known as DEPTH-DTU. When I joined, the society was dormant, and I was responsible for reviving it. This responsibility kept me up at night and had me roaming the corridors of the BCH Hostel, thinking of ways to get better engagement. Around that time is when I realised that this was something that pushed me to get more done.

To follow this passion, I started taking up similar projects, and eventually, I ended up at Bain Capability Network, which is the closest I could get to my passion after B.Tech. After working at BCN for a couple of years, I decided that I wanted to be involved in a more up-front role in which my work is not just limited to analytics. This was when I decided to go for an MBA.

What was your preparation strategy for the CAT exam?

There are three sections in the CAT paper - namely Verbal Ability & Reading Comprehension (VARC), Data Interpretation and Logical Reasoning (DI & LR), and Quantitative Aptitude. VARC deals with your reading comprehension, the DILR section tests how well you can make decisions in the spur of the moment, and the quant section requires brushing up on the theoretical aspect of quantitative aptitude, which most engineers have in place. I primarily built my concepts by giving mock exams. I gave around 150 mocks in the past two years, analysed where I went wrong in each paper and followed up by studying the topics I lacked. Practice and consistency are key to scoring well on the exam. I used to efficiently balance my time between work, giving mocks, and analysing them. 

What difference do you feel exists between JEE and CAT, in terms of both, preparation and competition?

The biggest difference between JEE and CAT, from my experience, was that CAT had a very small syllabus as compared to JEE. CAT is all about your aptitude, the type of questions are all based on quick thinking ability, logical reasoning and such. It’s all about how quickly the solution comes to you when you’re sitting in the exam hall. 

In terms of competition though, I feel like CAT is trickier than JEE. In JEE, after getting a decent rank, one can safely say he or she will get a college. In CAT, you need to achieve an extraordinarily high percentile just to be eligible for a call from an IIM ABC. That is not to say that CAT is tougher than JEE, I would definitely say that JEE is trickier, but it has a much larger window of opportunity than CAT.

How do you see your career evolving from here? What are your future plans?

It’s always been my dream to be able to give back to those less fortunate than myself and make a meaningful impact. I feel like India as a country could evolve a lot if we could bring education to underprivileged kids, and I would like to, maybe far down the line, be able to bring about that change. Of course, as I said, this is a bit far down the line, but it’s my dream to reach the point where I can eventually make that difference.

title: Interview | Manmeet Dhody, CTO of Paytm
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Manmeet Dhody, CTO of PayTm, during Invictus.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Manmeet Dhody, CTO of PayTm, during Invictus. 

What does a typical day at the PayTm office look like?

Digitizing payments and financial services for all Indians, and we’re working towards making that mission a reality. The majority of people in India don’t have access to credit. We do our jobs and have different roles and are focused on making that vision a reality. Whatever it takes to ensure that every Indian will have access to credit because when you do have access to credit, it allows you to grow your business and start new initiatives, especially for people who don’t get credit like the common person. So, all of us are focused on making that a reality.

PayTm is a household name in India, but other giants like Amazon and Google are now entering the same market. How do you analyze and stay ahead of the competition?

We are focused on customers—India and Indians. 

Our focus is to digitize payments for all Indians and solve all kinds of problems, i.e., providing access to credit, the ability to pay your bills, and accepting payments for you whether you're an online, offline, small, or big merchant. That razor-sharp focus gives us an advantage. We are completely focused on our customers—consumers and merchants.

What gave birth to the idea of a payment voice box?

Once people started accepting payments, you could go to any merchant, scan their QR and make payments. However, sometimes you might show an image that you have made the payment, but it's not very easy to verify. There is a demand  for this - if the merchant could hear that he has received the money and would be assured that money has come into his account. That gave birth to the idea of a payments voice box. PayTm was the first to bring audio-based payment confirmations with the Soundbox. 

What strategies have you adopted to stay up to date with the latest technology?

I am a strong believer in cloud computing. There are no two ways about it, the kind of scale we have where we do millions and millions of transactions every hour, which only increases daily. 

You won’t be able to handle that scale without being on the cloud, which helps you in two ways. Some basics are already built for you, like the ability to scale your transactional systems. Some technologies will do that scaling for you.

Similarly, databases in the cloud can scale to a very, very large scale, which speeds up computing. We ensure that we collaborate with the best cloud computing providers in the country. We also train our technology teams with the latest cloud technologies within PayTm. This helps us to innovate faster because when you spend time building basic blocks, you need to innovate faster.

How did PayTm venture into movie ticketing services?

These are the services people love to have. You can make payments to friends and merchants and transfer money to anyone, and you’ll also want to do additional things in commerce. And for us, we wanted to make a one-stop solution for all these things, and it also helps us get many more consumers through this channel. Today, PayTm is the only Super App in India, which is trusted by millions of Indians.

What would you describe as your biggest passion as CTO?

My biggest passion that I’m trying to fulfill at PayTm is to improve the lives of Indians and make that happen through the availability of credit because the majority do not have access to credit. Either they can't dream of something bigger, or they end up taking credit from pensive sources, and then they have to pay huge amounts of interest on those loans. 

So, what we have been able to do as you look at our latest numbers is that we provided a loan of Rs.3,600 crores approximately in December. These are small loans ranging from Rs.10,000 to Rs. 3 lacs. That kind of microcredit for people is life-changing. That is the biggest achievement for me as the CTO.

Is it the responsibility of private firms like PayTm to provide small micro credits, or should the government be taking it up?

The government definitely has a role in this, but the government also looks at private partnerships to make some of these things happen. That's where we stepped into this. It's where we all work together. Given that people transact on our platform, we can make informed decisions on the amount of credit to provide to them.

How can we ease the small merchants to accept payments through UPI rather than cash?

As the pioneers of QR, PayTm has taken UPI to every nook and corner of the country. Today, even small merchants like fruit or vegetable vendors are very happy to take payments through UPI or wallets because we settle this money instantly in their bank account, which gives them confidence. So that change has happened, in my opinion, in big cities, and in smaller cities, things are moving in that direction. Though some merchants might prefer cash, the majority have already moved towards it, which is good for India.

Recently, we heard that big companies laid-off employees. What strategy would you suggest for engineers or students to stay relevant in the market?

Join PayTm. We don’t mass fire. There were unique events that triggered this. I have never seen such events in my career, and it’s a combination of Covid-19. Some sectors saw a lot of jump in demand at that time, and some companies over-hired beyond their capability. Such a large number of employees probably led to this. 

For students, I would suggest focusing on your courses and subjects. Do your projects well in college. Most importantly, work hard. This combination will allow you to always stay relevant in the market.

Do you believe in hustle culture, or prefer a more laid-back approach while balancing mental health, personal life, and work life?

I don’t differentiate between these two terms. 

If you are passionate and lucky enough to work on something you are passionate about, it's no longer work, which is the key thing. 

Try to find something that you love doing. All of us have to maintain good mental and physical health.

What would you say to students giving up their passion for a high-paying job? What exactly do you look for in SDE roles when recruiting?

In my time, it used to be that most of us first focussed on getting a good-paying job or pursuing higher education, though there were exceptions. Things have changed today and there are a lot more opportunities for people to focus on pursuing their passions. The best combination is when you are passionate about the work you do. Everyone in DTU is smart. I look for people who have done their courses well and do their assignments and projects diligently. Sparks of innovation are always an added plus.

title: Blog | A Walk Towards Hope
biliner: Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies. Read on as Bilal Khan, 2nd Year, MCE, reiterates the strong message that when everything is lost, hope just isn’t. We just need a tread down some road, have our own journey, and “learn and move on”.
body:
Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies. Read on as Bilal Khan, 2nd Year, MCE, reiterates the strong message that when everything is lost, hope just isn’t. We just need a tread down some road, have our own journey, and “learn and move on”.

With blue toes and lost hope, I walk on the cold and obsolete road with moist asphalt rubbing against my coarse sole. Completely lost and gave up on life, backstabbed by the ones I trusted, treachery written all over my destiny. A miserable life, full of regrets and sorrows. I have given up on life, its very meaning and purpose. I am constantly looking for answers to my existence yet failing every single time.

Distressed, defeated, done. I start meandering along the path deflected by rock-hearted humans, bereft of any compassion. Thus, begins an excursion of sorts, a map futile, a reason hostile, going wherever my tired feet drag me towards. A journey I am skeptical about, what good will it do? With a drained and derailed spirit, I start this walk toward hopelessness and zero possibilities.

A joyous seven-year-old who seemed to have no regrets confided in me that she wished she had never met that mean girl who hurt her tender heart. A small yet early experience about human behaviour had the little one sad and silent but with a hope of looking for the good in the future, she smiled at me and said, “I will learn and move on.”

I walked further to meet a boy inching towards the end of his teenage years who had regrets about having flung off school which otherwise could have brought a change in fortunes for him. He wished to have done better but with the moisture of regret yet pulsed hope in his eyes, he lifted his head and stated with determination, “I will learn and move on.”

Then I came across a middle-aged man who shared his remorse for his deceased wife whom he wished to have loved more when she was alive. He wept the loss of his sunshine, his love, his hope. But caressing his infant daughter’s little forehead with his sweaty fingers and giving it a deft kiss, his eyes full, he told me, “I will learn and move on.”

Towards the end of the road, I encounter an old man with aching knees and receding health. He sat over the vast wealth and wisdom he had garnered. He received the reverence and status of a respectable man in society. A life that seemed perfect and complete to me. But there he sat with his wife, both wishing that their children came to see them more often. Clenching his woman’s hands with his creased palms, he looked at me and muttered in a low and shaky voice, “I will learn and move on.”

My feet gained strength, my back became straighter, and a strange, comforting feeling of gratitude sealed the opening in my heart that had been there all this while. Lessons that were known yet far from known, were unravelled to me. The unanswered got answered. A walk down an unknown path brought about some serendipitous discoveries along the way. Hope never dies, it just can’t, look around and you would see people clinging to their lives even after everything seems lost to them. It was the revelation of the truth about our lives, that no matter how desolate and despairing we consider our destiny to be, never give up on hope, never give up on ourselves, never give up on the infinite possibilities, and just keep walking, just step out, just “learn and move on.”

पढ़िए अमन, 2nd Year, MCE की यात्रा और अधूरे प्रेम पर लिखी एक छोटी सी कहानी।
body:
सबसे अच्छी यात्राएं सबसे पहले प्यार की तरह होती हैं जिनमे हम हँसते हैं, रोते हैं, नाचते हैं, गाते हैं और एक दिन उन सभी पलों को यादों के बक्से में समेट कर उस शहर की ओर लौट जाते हैं जहाँ आवाज़ों के नाम पर शोर है, लोगों के नाम पर भीड़ और प्यार के नाम पर दिखावा मात्र से ज़्यादा कुछ नहीं। हमारे लिए हमारा प्यार हमारी सबसे अच्छी यात्रा होनी चाहिए। थोड़ी अधूरी और थोड़ी अनकही यात्रा।

पढ़िए अमन, 2nd Year, MCE की यात्रा और अधूरे प्रेम पर लिखी एक छोटी सी कहानी।                

एक संपूर्ण यात्रा की उम्मीद किसे नहीं होती? एक ऐसी यात्रा जिसमे अधूरेपन का एहसास न हो। जो जितनी संपूर्ण हो, उतनी ही खाली भी हो। वास्तव में पूरा हो जाना या खाली हो जाना एक ही सिक्के के दो पहलू हैं। हमारी जिंदगी इन दोनों सिरों को पा लेने की कोशिश में ही बीत कर रह जाती है। क्या अंत और अनंत एक दूसरे से अलग होकर होकर अधूरे नहीं हैं? क्या इनकी सीमा भी सीमित नहीं है? वैसे जीवन यात्रा के ये अनसुलझे सवाल कभी ख़त्म तो होंगे नहीं। तो आइए पढ़ते हैं मेरी लिखी एक छोटी सी कहानी - एक अधूरा अनंत।

पूस की अंधेरी रात थी। आकाश पर तारे भी ठिठुरते हुए मालूम हो रहे थे। मैं भी दिन-भर की ऊबन और थकान के बाद हीटर जलाकर आग ताप रहा था। जैसे-जैसे समय बीत रहा था, रात शीत को हवा से और धधकाते जा रही थी। फ़ोन भी इस ठंड मे गर्मी का एहसास ले रहा था। दरअसल वह दिन भर की थकान के बाद चार्ज होकर पुनः सेवा देने के लिए उपलब्ध हो रहा था। घंटी धीरे-धीरे तेज़ होने लगी थी और मेरे फ़ोन के अपाहिज होने के कारण मुझे ही अपने तन को चादर की ओट से बाहर लेकर जाना पड़ा। देखा तो कोई अनजान नंबर था सो मैंने मन कचोट कर कॉल काट दिया। परंतु मेरे आराम मे खलल तब पड़ा जब वही कॉल दोबारा आया। मेरे मन में न जाने क्यों संशय बढ़ने लगा पर फिर दिमाग ने कहा कि मुझे फ़ोन लगाएगा हीं कौन? सालों से किसी दोस्त ने मेरे दर पर दस्तक दी नहीं थी और जो देते भी, वो अपने दुखड़े सुनाकर पुरानी बातों का मलाल करने लगते। अरे भाई! अब जो हो गया उसका रोना रोने से क्या होगा। उनको सांत्वना देकर मैं भी फ़ोन जैसे तैसे रख देता। वह कॉल भी अपनी आखिरी साँस लेते हुए कटने ही वाला था कि मैंने दया करके उसे अपने कान के पास जगह दी। तभी एक हेलो ने मानों, इस सर्द रात मे मुझे लेह के बर्फ़ानी पहाड़ों मे वीरान छोड़ दिया। करीब सात साल बाद श्रेया की आवाज सुनकर मैं वैसे हीं थर्रा गया था जैसे बरसों पहले सिहर जाता था। वक़्त मानो थम सा गया था। मैंने हड़बड़ाहट में पूछा- "कौन!" जवाब मे प्रश्न से स्वागत हुआ कि "इतनी जल्दी भूल गए?" जल्दी! क्या सात साल कोई बच्चों का खेल है जो जल्दी बीत गया। शायद आज तक मैं उन कष्टदायी रातों को नहीं भूल पाया था जो उसके अचानक दूर चले जाने पर मुझे मिले थे। खैर! मैंने उससे अचानक अरसों बाद मुझे याद करने का कारण पूछा तो जवाब आया की "नाराज़ लगते हो।" देखिए, अब नाराजगी की कोई बात नहीं है, सिवाय इसके कि मेरे गत सालों के अनगिनत प्रयासों के बावजूद उसका न तो कोई कॉल आया था और न ही कोई मैसेज। सच कहूँ तो मुझे पता भी नहीं था कि वह ज़िंदा भी है या नहीं। मेरे दिमाग में पुरानी यादों का घेरा सा बनना शुरू हो गया था। मुझे याद आया कि करीब सात साल पहले हीं तो मैंने उसे प्रोपोज़ किया था और उसने न हाँ कहा और न ही ना। कितना मनहूस पल था वो भी। शायद क्षितिज के उन अनंत बिंदुओं को भी तलाश होती होगी न किसी प्रामाणिकता की कि क्या आकाश उन तक सीमित है भी या नहीं। शायद मुझे भी उसके जवाब का उतना ही इंतज़ार था। उसकी सादगी की तो क्या ही बात करूँ। आधा स्कूल उसके पीछे पागल था। एक वाक्य में बयान करना हो तो उसका चेहरा मानो गहरी सवालिया आंखें लिए सीधा दिल में झाँकती तस्वीर जैसी था। ​हम स्कूल में काफ़ी अच्छे दोस्त थे। मुझे फोटोग्राफी का बहुत शौक था पर उसे बिल्कुल भी नहीं। "अरे! इधर देखो ना यार।" उसकी तस्वीरें यही कहकर तो खींचता रहता था मैं और वह बार-बार अजीब सी शक्ले बनाकर, आँखे जानबूझकर बड़ी कर के, मुझे तंग करती थी। "मुझे नहीं आता यार ये पोज़ वोज देना। ऐसे ही खींच लो।" उसने चिढ़कर कहा था और फिर मेरे जिद करने पर मेरा कहा मान कर खड़ी हो गई थी। उसकी फोटो मेरी खींची हुई सबसे सुंदर तस्वीर है जो आज भी मेरी पर्स के ऊपरी पॉकेट में सुरक्षित है। अचानक से मेरा हाथ मेरी पर्स की ओर बढ़ा और उसकी तस्वीर निकल कर बाहर आ गई। काफ़ी समय तक पर्स में रहने के बावजूद वह तस्वीर आज भी बिल्कुल वैसी ही थी जैसे आज ही खींची गई हो। वहीं चेहरा और उसपर वहीं कत्थई आँखें जिनमे अल्हयदा से ख्वाब रहा करते थे। वहीं पेशानी और उसपर वहीं शिकन जिसपर न जाने कितने सवाल बसा करते थे। पता नहीं वह अब भी पहले जैसी होगी या नहीं। यह सब सोचते हुए मेरे आँखों में नमी सी आने लगी। मैं उन दिनों अपने कैमरे में सब कुछ कैद कर लेना चाहता था। नदियों की कलकल, वीराने में पसरे सन्नाटे, अंधेरे की गहराइयां, आसमान में उड़ते पंछी, सड़कों पर दौड़ते बच्चे, बेबाक मुस्कुराहटें, रोते हुए चेहरे। हर एक चीज जो आम आँखें नहीं देख पाती। मैं वो सारी तस्वीरें खीचना चाहता था जो सिर्फ तस्वीर होने की सीमा में न बंधकर देखने वाले के मन में गहरे उतर जाएं। मुझे पता ही नहीं लगा कि कब मैं उसकी एक के बाद एक तस्वीर खींचता हुआ अपने ख्यालों में बने फ्रेम को मुकम्मल करने के लिए उसके दिल के इतना करीब पहुँच गया जहाँ से सिर्फ दोस्त बन कर रह पाना मेरे लिए मुश्किल होता जा रहा था। 

मैं उसे पाने की कोशिश में उसकी गहरी दोस्ती से वंचित नहीं होना चाहता था पर उसके चुप हो जाने की वजह से मेरे दिन और रात में एक अलग सी उदासी आ गई थी। अब दुनिया उतनी खूबसूरत नहीं जान पड़ रही थी जितनी कुछ दिन पहले तक थी। मैंने धीरे-धीरे तस्वीरें खींचना बंद कर दी और अपना पूरा ध्यान उसकी यादों से निकलने में लगा दिया। 

पर क्या पुरानी यादों को भुलाना इतना आसान है। उसका वह चेहरा जिसको बयान करने में हर विशेषण फीका है, उसे मन भी न भूल पाने पर विवश था। मैंने उसकी वो हवा में उड़ते किसी दुपट्टे जैसी थी। एकदम बेबाक, और उसकी हंसी तो ऐसी निश्छल जैसे बहता हुआ पानी। उसे छूकर जाने वाली हवाएं खुशबू से भर जाती थी। ऐसा ही कोई खुशबू भरा झोंका उसको छूते हुए पहुंचा था मेरे पास। और मैं खींचा चला गया था उसकी तरफ। खैर श्रेया अपने कॉलेज के नए दोस्तों के साथ कुल्लू यात्रा से वापस हो रही थी। चूँकि बनारस लौटने का रास्ता दिल्ली से होकर गुज़रता था, मैंने उससे दिल्ली में एक मुलाक़ात की अर्ज़ी डाल दी। उसने भी हामी भरकर कहा कि "मुझे द्वारका मेट्रो से रिसीव कर लेना ना।" शायद रोज़ मस्ती करने वाले हम दोस्त बीते सालों में काफ़ी गंभीर हो चुके थे। उसकी आवाज में वह मासूमियत नहीं झलकी जिसका मैं कायल था।

अगली शाम उसकी पसंदीदा नीली रंग की कमीज पहन कर मैं समय से पहले ही मेट्रो पहुंच गया था। एक पास ही के छोटे से हॉटल में मैंने उसकी शाम को यादगार बनाने का इंतज़ाम किया था। सबकुछ वैसा ही था जैसा उसे पसंद था। रंग-बिरंगी मोमबत्तियों की मद्धम रौशनी, सुकून और शोर-सराबे से बिल्कुल दूर एक छोटा सा कैफ़े। मन थोड़ी उधेड़बुन में व्यस्त था कि क्या वह मुझसे अब तक नाराज़ होगी? मुझे समझ ही नहीं आ रहा था कि उससे क्या बातें करूँगा। कहने को तो लाखों बातें हैं पर उसके सामने मैं ठिठक के न रह जाऊँ। वक़्त भी काफ़ी बीत गया। उसे तंज मारकर जो मैं चिढ़ाता रहता था, क्या वह मौसम बदल गया होगा? तभी मुझे ख्याल आया कि मैंने तो उससे कुछ पूछा ही नहीं कि उसकी मेट्रो कब तक पहुंचेगी? कहीं वो भीड़ में गुम न जाए। उसे दिल्ली के भीड़-भाड़ की आदत भी तो नहीं थी। उसके दोस्त हैं उसके साथ पर न जाने एक अजीब सी फ़िक्र तो थी ही। मन की गति बहुत ही तीव्र होती है। एक पल में आसमान समेट लेती है और दूसरे ही पल बिल्कुल खाली। इन्ही उधेड़बुन में मैंने उसे कॉल लगा दिया। उसने कॉल नहीं उठाया। क्या पता घूमते फिरते वक़्त का अंदाजा न लगा हो। अब मैं उसे बार-बार कॉल करके परेशान नहीं करना चाहता था। वो जहाँ भी, जो भी कर रही होगी, मेरे इंतजार से ज्यादा ही जरूरी होगा। मैं इंतज़ार करता रहा। रात घनी होती जा रही थी और स्टेशन पर ख़ामोशी पसरती जा रही थी। पिछले चार-पांच घंटो मे मेरे सामने से गुज़री करीब सौ-सवा सौ मेट्रो मे मैं उसे तीन-चार सौ बार देख चुका था। मेरा भ्रम मेरे दिमाग पर हावी होता जा रहा था। मैं अपने मन में स्कूल की खोयी यादों के बिखरे आशियाने इकट्ठे कर रहा था।

प्यार की खूबसूरती और अहमियत दोनों ही प्यार की गैरमौजूदगी में ज्यादा बेहतर पता लगती है। तब हर दर्द का बस एक ही नाम होता है। एक ही वजह होती है, याद। दिन ढलते ही दिल भारी सा होने लगता है और रातें एक अजीब सा चुभता हुआ अकेलापन लिए हमें खुद में समेट लेना चाहती है। चारों तरफ उस एक चेहरे को ढूँढती हमारी आँखे किसी के पूछ भर लेने से छलक जाती है। इतने सालों बाद भी मेरा मन फिर से मुझे उसी मुकाम पर ले आया था जहाँ सिर्फ काँटों से बिछे मंज़र मेरे दिल के अनंत टुकड़े किए जा रहे थे। रात और अंधेरी होती जा रही थी और उसके साथ ही मेरा दिल भी। मैं क्यों मिलने को बेचैन हुआ जा रहा हूँ? अचानक से मन में उठते एक सवाल ने मुझसे पूछा। वह खुद गई थी न उसे बीच सफर में छोड़कर। अगर प्यार नहीं भी था तो क्या मुझे एक शब्द में मना नहीं कर सकती थी। यूँ तन्हा छोड़ जाने का क्या मतलब हुआ? उसने एक पल को भी कहाँ सोचा था मेरे बारे में। उसने सिर्फ और सिर्फ अपने बारे में सोचा था। उसने एक बार भी नहीं सोचा कि वह लड़का जो उसके छू लेने भर से कांप जाता है, उसके देख लेने भर से जिसकी आँखें डबडबा जाती है, वह कैसे जी पाएगा उसके बिना। इस भागती-दौड़ती जिंदगी में कोई हमारा हाथ थाम ले तो कितना आसान, कितना जायज़ सा लगने लगता है। आँखों में चमकते किसी के प्यार की रौशनी, होठों पर खिलखिलाता किसी का नाम, जैसे हर चीज को मायने मिल जाते हैं। किसी का साथ हो तो जीवन के ऊबड़खाबड़ सड़कों पर चलना भी ऐसा लगता है कि जैसे हर तरफ बस फूल हीं फूल बिखरे हों। उसका साथ ही तो चाहता था न मैं। बस उसका साथ। दिल सिर्फ अपनी तसल्ली के लिए पेड़ों पर सज रहे सुन्दर फूलों को उचक के तोड़ लेना चाहता है। उसकी खुशबू को अपनी सांसों में भरता है। उसे अपने कमरे के गुलदस्ते में सजाता है और फिर कितनी आसानी से उसे परे सरका देता है। शायद उसने भी यही किया था मेरे साथ।

अब और इंतज़ार संभव नहीं था। अचानक से मेरे सब्र का बान टूट गया और मैंने उसे फिर से कॉल लगा दिया। उसकी आवाज़ सुन कर मेरी जान मे जान आई की वह सही सलामत है। मैंने हड़बड़ाते हुए उससे पूछा कि ठीक तो हो न तुम और उसने बड़े बेबाकी से जवाब दिया कि "हाँ अमन! मुझे क्या होगा?" मैंने पूछा की तुम अभी तक आई नहीं। उसके दिए जवाब से मेरा प्यार हार गया। इतना ज़्यादा की इतना तो मैं फिर भी नहीं टूटा था जब वो मुझे सात साल पहले छोड़ के गई थी। उसे हमारा मिलना याद हीं नहीं था और वह बनारस मेल में बैठ कर यात्रा के अगले पड़ाव में प्रवेश भी कर चुकी थी। हमारे धोखे हमेशा धोखे बने रहें तो कितना अच्छा हो ना। कल को सच खुलने पर सब बिखरता हुआ, सब एकदम खाली सा तो न दिखाई दे। उस एक पल में मन जगजीत सिंह जी के गज़लों से ज़्यादा ग़मगीन हो गया। "कोई बात नहीं श्रेया। दिन भर घूमने फिरने के थकान में भूल गई होगी।" उसे यह सब कहते-कहते मेरा गला भर्रा गया। सब रुक गया था मेरे अंदर.. एकदम सन्नाटा.. कोई भी आवाज़ नहीं थी। उसके कहे हुए शब्द अब भी वहीं तैर रहे थे। "मुझे हमारा मिलना याद नहीं रहा अमन…प्लीज़ मुझे माफ़ कर देना। अगली बार पक्का मिलेंगे।"

कुछ पल के सन्नाटे के बाद ये एहसास हुआ की उन सौ-सवा सौ मेट्रो मे जो मुझे चार-पांच सौ बार उसके होने का भ्रम हुआ था, उनमे कोई एक भ्रम वो हकीकत था जिसका अनंत परिदृष्यों में साकार हो पाना संभव न था। वह मेरा अधूरा अनंत बनकर रह गई थी।

body:
"When you start you think you can do many things, but the biggest strength is in realizing what not to do. Pick one or two things, focus on it, do well in it and then move on to others." - Ramit Sawhney

"There is no such defined career path, everyone can do everything. You have to figure out what works best for you, and what you enjoy doing in the end." - Sanyam Bhutani

In an open conversation with DTU Times during Invictus '23, Ramit Sawhney, Engineering Manager, TRC and Sanyam Bhutani, Senior Data Analyst, H20.AI confessed about their entrepreneurial endeavours, coding hacks and upgrowing startup culture in India.

How much, according to you, should a student focus on data structures and algorithms as it is a constant dilemma amongst students?

(Ramit Sawhney) Being from Tower Research, and in the case of every big tech company, whether you like it or not you will have to do DSA. It is better to get accustomed to it at an earlier stage. Maybe it changes in the future, but this year and the next year, there will come a time when every company will have a negative filter which will be the HackerRank test on DSA. So I think if you are looking for an internship or a job you need to focus on that DSA bit. Web Development is an additional great thing to have unless you are going for a niche in that. 

(Sanyam Bhutani) I have a very different opinion on it. I have never done DSA and never prepared for it. I’ve done it for the college course but I didn’t do it after that. In my experience startups are generally open to it. I work at H2O.ai and for Kaggle Grandmaster, these are a few achievements for which you really don’t have to do DSA. But, if you eventually want to work at a large scale company, there is no shortcut to it because that’s the only way they know how to hire effectively and they are looking at fifty thousand people every month, every day. You can’t find a way around DSA but if you do, it would be temporary.

(Ramit Sawhney) I actually spent a lot of time thinking how I can get away from it, from data structures and algorithms or is there any potential that I can get but especially when companies come on campus for students like you and me, like (Sanyam) said there are too many students they have to evaluate so you need to do it. The quicker you accept it, the better it’ll be. It is a filtration process with lots of different students. You need something that everyone knows. It has somehow become the norm now, it has its pros and cons both. Even if you think about Google, I think for the junior level which most of us would be here they only ask about DSA in all the rounds. All DSA rounds and one behavioral round.

Since you’re a grandmaster in Kaggle, we would like to ask how one can reach that level?

(Sanyam Bhutani) I started doing DSA and it was out of my own curiosity because I’ve been interviewing Kagglers primarily. I’ve interviewed researchers and practitioners, but I think I’ve done 160 interviews out of which 90 would be Kagglers. And I’ve been asking the same question and I think that there is no way around it except for passion because all the medals of a grandmaster are a proxy of you being passionate about it. Anyone who says it’s easy puts in at least 20,000 hours. It’s a very unglorified effort.

After college, there are very few people who build a startup and most people go for jobs at other companies. Why do you think that is and how can we promote startup culture?

(Ramit Sawhney) I will give you my personal experience. When you get into a college, the first thing you hear is that I should do DSA and LeetCode because the internship or placement season is coming. That’s the environment you're looking at, then that is what you will automatically get into. Now, with things like Shark Tank, it is a good example. You see people talking about that. So I don’t think that people are not interested, but for most of us we don’t realize that such a route exists. The common route is to take engineering, get into a good college, and get a good job. 

(Sanyam Bhutani) Since I am a fan of fundamental thinking, I would ask questions like why do you want to have a startup? Do you want to solve a problem, do you want to make money or do you find glory in that? You need to know why you are in it. Even if you are exploring it as a career option you have to have an open mind about your product and what problem it is solving. You have to be clear about your motives. 

Since you are an Engineering Manager at Tower Research, could you throw some light at the work culture there?

(Ramit Sawhney) Work culture is usually a function of your team, your environment and your own mental state. In my case, I never found the work-life balance to be extreme or what sometimes people make it out to be. I personally find the right amount of challenge that keeps me interested but never to the point of burnout. I find it extremely supportive. Bottom line is that it all depends on your mental state. 

What is one piece of advice that you would give to a first year student who wishes to explore all domains of development?

(Ramit Sawhney) When you start you think you can do many things, but the biggest strength is in realizing what not to do. Pick one or two things, focus on it, do well in it and then move on to others.

(Sanyam Bhutani) There is no such defined career path, everyone can do everything. You have to figure out what works best for you, and what you enjoy doing in the end. How you do that could be through random exploration and you can be influenced by people who deliver things differently that gets your attention. You won’t be an expert at anything but explore everything and stick to what you enjoy doing the most.

title: Blog | When You’re Bitten by the Travel Bug
biliner: As you thrust your headphones in your ear, you conceal all the negativity and bad words and just await the journey that lies ahead. Read on as Yash Chaturvedi, 1st Year, MCE, reminds everyone of the ecstasy of travel and the sentiments that we undergo before, during and after the vacation.
body:
As you thrust your headphones in your ear, you conceal all the negativity and bad words and just await the journey that lies ahead. Read on as Yash Chaturvedi, 1st Year, MCE, reminds everyone of the ecstasy of travel and the sentiments that we undergo before, during and after the vacation.

Think of films like Dil Dhadakne Do (2015), Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani (2013) and Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara (2011). Apart from being exceptionally directed and being adored by everyone, they share another common aspect- travel. While travelling in a large group of friends or with family, in the breathtaking backdrops of rugged mountains, sandy beaches, the crimson and orange hues of sunsets, blue skies, infinite oceans and shimmering stars at night, I couldn’t help but wonder, what is so special and euphoric about it? Why do we feel the sensation of butterflies scurrying around in our stomach the night before we catch a flight, train or a bus? And most importantly, why do we end up feeling homesick after 3-4 days of the vacation, the one that we so meticulously planned and convinced our parents for?

When you’re bitten by the Travel Bug, the tingling sensation isn’t felt at the exact moment. It festers and slowly grows as you check off the days on the calendar and prepare yourself for that week or days where you’d be in a different place, breathing different air, seeing different skies and eating new food. It’s almost indescribable, because there are so many things on your mind. Do I take this T-shirt? Are these shorts really necessary for the trip? Will security stop me if I carry this bottle of perfume? Will I actually have fun? You ponder the answers of these questions in your mind as if attempting an exam, and try to make a big deal out of it, while in reality it's not that big of a deal. You end up doing this because you want to experience that rush of emotions, the thrill of packing more than you should and the chaos in the morning while getting ready to leave. Planning the itinerary for the day that lies ahead, quarrelling with your family to go to your dream tourist site, everything seems surreal at that moment. The moment where all you can think about is the joy that you will experience and the memories you will make. 

So you’ve reached your destination. After a tiring journey filled with laughter, short naps, munching on chips and biscuits, you’ve finally made it. You step out and breathe in the air with closed eyes, the breeze going over every feature of your face, sunlight spreading itself into every curve of your body, you feel elated and relaxed. Say you’re at the beach, the waves of the ocean immersing themselves in the crevices of your feet, the coarse sand pinching your toes, the seashells lying bare with wet sand in them, the unseen horizon reaching tending to infinity, the curves of the sun reflecting themselves on the water, the cries of people running around, sipping on fresh coconut water and chewing on pineapple. All of a sudden, you’re being twirled around on the pretzeled roads of the mountains. The growing feeling of nausea takes over, so you look out the window and are beheld by nature’s beauty. The trees covering the mountains, with colourful tiny houses filling in the gaps, the fresh air and mist wetting your face as you hug yourself in the rising gelidity. Now you’re in the forest, covered by the canopy of the trees, strolling in their magnificence, the air condensing on your arms, the palpable smell of the humidity and walking on the muddy trail. 

Unexpectedly, you’re lolling on the cosiest hotel bed, with a cup of coffee in your hand, with the smell of brand new bedsheets and curtains reminding you of your solitude away from work. The sheer joy that you derive from being able to jump around the room, using new products and ordering room service is inexplicable. You look out the giant window and see the city in its glory and beauty, or look out the door to see the empty corridor and close it immediately. All these experiences are real and one deserves to live through them. In simple terms, it brings you bliss. As you smile cheek to cheek lying on your bed with your arms spread out, it is just unfiltered happiness. 

Your trip is coming to an end. Unfortunately, you are packing up the deliberate mess you’ve created and you’re thinking backwards. Thinking about your first day, how you tried to explore everything in the first day, how 24 hours felt less as the trip progressed. Then you proceed to remember your second day, a more calm and relaxed attitude, reserving energy for the night that lies ahead, eating more and more. You pack up the souvenirs you bought for your friends and family, and picture their reactions in your mind. You stuff the dirty clothes and socks in a bag and push them as if they don’t deserve to be in your suitcase. While shutting the door, you realise that all those days, months or even years planning that memorable experience was all worth it in the end.

biliner:

As a Grandmaster at Kaggle, her interview is a must-read for anyone interested in the tech industry, as she offers her extensive experience and expertise in the field of technology. body:
“The power of innovation lies in our ability to use data and technology for creating a brighter tomorrow.” 

In an enlightening conversation with DTU Times during Invictus’23, Usha Rengaraju, Chief of Research at Exa Protocol, founder of NeuroAI, and Chief Data Scientist at Polymath, delves into her unique perspective on the evolving startup ecosystem. As a Grandmaster at Kaggle, her interview is a must-read for anyone interested in the tech industry, as she offers her extensive experience and expertise in the field of technology. Don't miss out on this exclusive interview and gain valuable insights from one of the top tech experts in the industry.

The very nature of the tech companies is based on Data Structures and Algorithms rather than Development. There is a constant dilemma in the students on how to balance them well because when someone enters the job, they have to excel more in Development than in DSA. What would be your advice regarding this.

If you are planning to get into the FAANG companies, one must start early. Don’t start your preparation just before the placement starts. Start preparing from first year itself, practicing 20-30 min a day, so by the time you reach your 3rd year, you are already habitual and good with it. You can enjoy what you do. Of course, it is going to take a lot of effort but you can start a revolution to change the system and the process. If you might have noticed, Google used to give puzzles in their interviews. Eventually, people started speaking up and then Google realised and admitted that their way of interviewing people is wrong. So, if something is wrong, it takes a collective group of people to change it. But again, it takes a long time to bring about a change like that. So, if the big companies are your target, just make the process enjoyable for yourself. But most startups don’t have DSA rounds at all. They will generally provide you with a problem statement and a week’s time to solve the problem.

As we all know, you are a Grandmaster at Kaggle, which requires 5 competition medals including 1 solo medal, 15 medals for notebooks and other requirements. How can one plan to go about and be a Grandmaster?

Kaggle is all about doing it religiously and with persistence over a period of time. If you are religiously putting 2 hours every day, then you can reach the level of master or grandmaster in a period of 6-8 months. Doing it the right way and teaming up with a lot of people who have been Kaggling for long helps you learn tricks and can shorten the time even further. If you have good programming skills and a very good GPU, you could easily achieve this goal in 6-8 months. Majority of the problems are NLP and Computer Vision problems; so, if you have access to a good GPU which may be provided by your university, you can crack it if you work diligently.

In engineering colleges, most of the fresh graduates look to bag jobs in big tech companies and very few of the students plan to start a company of their own. Why do you think this is prevalent in the Indian youth especially? Also, what can be a good way to promote the startup culture among the students?

Firstly, there’s a pressure to follow all what your peers are doing. Even if someone is passionate   about a startup, the thought that their friends are placed in companies such as the MAANG while they are still struggling with their own company can be something that keeps them from pursuing it. Some people might also want to try working in a company for 3-4 years and learn the trade. They still don’t know how the corporate world and the entire end to end things works before going for a company of their own. There’s also a lot of risk involved while starting a company; the market, the unsurety of having funding or not; it’s not rosy for all of them. Other circumstances such as family dependency and other issues may also come into play.

What I would like to add is that there are a lot of companies and organisations which are coming up with programs for student entrepreneurs. Since there’s a lot of risk involved, one must watch out for these programs. One such program is by Google itself. They had a mentorship program in 3-4 cities and chose a total of 60 entrepreneurs, gave them initial level of funding, access to all the resources. 

As students you can look through these programs as a lot less skin is involved. They gave you a glimpse into the world of startup, free access to mentorship, free access to cloud resources and top researchers. All of these programs run by various companies can be very beneficial for budding entrepreneurs.

title: ब्लॉग | यात्रा - अंतर्मन से बाह्य जीवन की ओर
biliner:

पढ़िए इसी दिशा में दक्ष खण्डेलवाल, प्रथम वर्ष , ई. ई.  द्वारा लिखित एक लेख  'यात्रा - अंतर्मन से बाह्य जीवन की ओर'।
body:
व्यक्ति बाल्यावस्था से सीखना प्रारंभ करता है। यही सीखने की प्रवृत्ति उसे जिज्ञासु बनाती है। प्रारंभ से ही मनुष्य  की जिज्ञासा, उसकी यात्रा का आधार बनती आई हैं। हम चीजों को व्यावहारिक अनुभव से जानने की कोशिश करते हैं और आसानी से समझ पाते हैं। यात्रा हर व्यक्ति के जीवन में खासा महत्त्व रखती है। हमारा जीवन भी एक यात्रा की भांति ही है जिसका आरम्भ व अंत दोनों ही निश्चित है। प्रत्येक व्यक्ति के जीवन में यात्रा के संदर्भ भिन्न - भिन्न हो सकते हैं, परन्तु यात्रा एक खोज है जो हमारे अंतर्मन से बाह्य मन के अनेक सूक्ष्म व्यवहारों का अवलोकन करती है।

पढ़िए इसी दिशा में दक्ष खण्डेलवाल, प्रथम वर्ष , ई. ई.  द्वारा लिखित एक लेख  'यात्रा - अंतर्मन से बाह्य जीवन की ओर'।

यात्रा क्या है ? यात्री कौन है ? जब इस प्रश्न पर हम विचार करते हैं तो पाते हैं कि जब कोई व्यक्ति समय का सदुपयोग करके व्यावहारिक अनुभव की प्राप्ति करता है, वह यात्रा है | यात्रा हमारी पाँचों इन्द्रियों से जुड़ी अनुभूति है | यात्रा से मिला ज्ञान अवर्णनीय है, जिसको सिर्फ महसूस किया जा सकता है, व्यक्त नही किया जा सकता और न ही वह शिक्षणीय है | यात्रा में प्राप्त ज्ञान को किसी और व्यक्ति के वर्णन द्वारा जानना उसका अंशभर ज्ञान प्राप्त करने जैसा है | इसलिए किसी व्यक्ति के संपूर्ण विकास में यात्रा का बहुत ही विशिष्ट महत्त्व है | यात्राओं से मिला ज्ञान जीवन में काफी प्रभावी होता है | जिस प्रकार प्राचीन भारत के कई साधु-संतो ने भारतीय उपमहाद्वीप में यात्रा करते हुए ज्ञान प्राप्त किया जैसे कबीरदास, मीराबाई, तुकाराम, गुरुनानक देव आदि | इन्होंने इसका प्रचार-प्रसार भी किया |

मनुष्य जीवन में यात्राएं इतनी महत्वपूर्ण कैसे हैं? अगर इस बारे में हम विचार करें तो पाएंगे की आज से हजारों साल पहले मनुष्य की उत्पत्ति के उपरांत जब वह अपने जीवन के  आवश्यकताओं की पूर्ति की खोज में निकला, तब वह पैदल ही यात्रा करते हुए धरती के छोर तक जा पहुँचा | शुरुआत में यह यात्रा सिर्फ प्राकृतिक ज़रूरतों के लिए हीं थी परन्तु जैसे-जैसे मनुष्य जाति का विकास हुआ, यह यात्राएं भौतिक इच्छाओं से लिप्त होती चली गईं और उसका सहायक बना पहिए का अविष्कार जिसने यात्रा की सुविधा को भी जन्म दिया | आज के परिप्रेक्ष्य में यात्रा किसी के लिए रोमांच का साधन है, तो किसी के लिए जीविका का और किसी के लिए यह मजबूरी भी है जैसे युद्धों में विस्थापित लोग, कोरोना काल में प्रवासी मजदूर इत्यादि | अगर हम यात्राओं के सकारात्मक प्रभाव देखें तो हम पाएंगे की यात्रा करने से मनुष्य के जीवन की नीरसता कम होती है, वह मानसिक व शारीरिक रूप से स्वस्थ रहता है, उसके भीतर रचनात्मकता बढ़ती है और  वह नई-नई संस्कृतियों व भाषाओं के बारे में सीखता है | दूसरी तरफ यात्राओं के कुछ नकारात्मक प्रभाव भी हैं जैसे मनुष्यों की यात्राओं की वजह से धरातल व समुद्री जीवन में फैली अशांति, पर्यटन स्थलों में स्थानीय आबादी को होने वाली समस्याएँ, प्रदूषण व कचरा प्रबंधन समस्याएँ, दुर्गम स्थानों पर अतिक्रमण व उससे होने वाली प्राकृतिक आपदाएँ जैसे हाल ही में हुई जोशीमठ की घटना | यात्राओं की यह स्थायी विशेषता है कि वह हम पर खासा प्रभाव छोड़ कर जाती हैं| कुछ यात्राएं तो ऐसी भी हैं जो हमारी सांस्कृतिक विरासत है जैसे धार्मिक यात्राएं, जन आक्रोश को दर्शाती दांडी मार्च और वास्को दा गामा की भारत की खोजपरक यात्रा इत्यादि | 

यात्रा व्यक्ति के प्रारंभिक जीवन से आरम्भ होकर जीवन के अंतिम समय तक चलती रहती है | प्रत्येक व्यक्ति के जीवन में यात्रा के सन्दर्भ भिन्न- भिन्न ज़रूर हो सकते हैं , परन्तु यात्रा एक खोज है जो हमारे अंतर्मन से बाह्य मन के बीच की एक महीन रेखा को पाटने का काम करती है|

व्यक्ति बाल्यावस्था से सीखना प्रारंभ करता है। यही सीखने की प्रवृत्ति उसे जिज्ञासु बनाती है। प्रारंभ से ही मनुष्य  की जिज्ञासा, उसकी यात्रा का आधार बनती आई हैं। हम चीजों को व्यावहारिक अनुभव से जानने की कोशिश करते हैं और आसानी से समझ पाते हैं। यात्रा हर व्यक्ति के जीवन में खासा महत्त्व रखती है। हमारा जीवन भी एक यात्रा की भांति ही है जिसका आरम्भ व अंत दोनों ही निश्चित है। प्रत्येक व्यक्ति के जीवन में यात्रा के संदर्भ भिन्न - भिन्न हो सकते हैं, परन्तु यात्रा एक खोज है जो हमारे अंतर्मन से बाह्य मन के अनेक सूक्ष्म व्यवहारों का अवलोकन करती है।

title: Interview | Kanika Vats
biliner: DTU Times interviewed hon'ble panelist of Yuvaan’23, Kanika Vats, Co-Founder of CosIQ. Read along as she shares her insights about entrepreneurship and life.
body:
"Go for it only if you are passionate about it, or else you won't find the passion and strength to go and work. Don’t do it just because everyone is doing it."

DTU Times interviewed hon'ble panelist of Yuvaan’23, Kanika Vats, Co-Founder of CosIQ. Read along as she shares her insights about entrepreneurship and life.

How did you come up with the idea of building CosIQ?

I was working in manufacturing units for a cluster of brands and at that point of time I realized that there were not many regulations for skin care products in India and people were writing anything and everything on their product labels. So, I thought there was a requirement for a brand which was transparent and worked on the skin as well, and that was when this idea came into picture.

How does CosIQ compete with giants like DermaCo and Minimalist and how are you able to differentiate yourselves?

They are there in the market, and they are doing really well for themselves. We are not copying an international brand; we believe in using minimum ingredients but maximum active ingredients, you can see on our labels that our Vitamin C serums have only 2 ingredients and our retinols have only 4 ingredients, we believe in using active ingredients, we shouldn’t put something on our skin which isn’t needed, in fact, we were the first ones to launch sunscreen in the form of a serum; we are also really transparent with our customers; we include whatever we write on our labels in the said quantity.

What is your day-to-day process of learning new things and growing?

We need to be updated about the new chemicals working out in the market. We read a lot, and we study a lot of technologies, for example- the encapsulation technique. Our sunscreen is double encapsulated, it doesn’t seep into your skin. Sunscreen can cause cancer if it seeps into your skin.

What was the lowest point in your journey and how did you bounce back from it?

The lowest point was when we started CosIQ. It was June 2021. We had gone all in, and at one point of time we were unable to pay our EMIs as well, so that was when we had hit rock-bottom, the bank also took our car away, but that’s the part and parcel of life, you have highs and lows, the very next day we got a call from Shark Tank, so it's good that our car was taken away. (Laughs)

Things changed after that. We were on national television, and it was like an eureka moment for CosIQ. That was when we started to grow, and people loved our products. We have been able to create a community of customers because we don’t push sales; we pull sales, and we want our customers to keep coming back to us.

What has been the biggest change in your life post Shark Tank?

People started to recognize us and our brand, and we saw a massive spike in our sales, we also went out of stock initially due to Shark Tank, which is a very nice feeling, but we were also losing out on orders because we were sold out. We were out of stock for 3 months because we had forecasted our sales incorrectly, but it was a learning opportunity since it came at an early stage, and we are doing really well now.

At times, women entrepreneurs aren't taken very seriously, did you face any discrimination solely because you are a woman?

No, I wouldn’t really say that. See difficulties are there in life at every point, but it all depends on how you move ahead with it. In fact, I don’t understand this woman-entrepreneur term. An entrepreneur is an entrepreneur. This segmentation is similar to the caste system that we have in our society. We live in a patriarchal society, so some people don’t take you seriously unless there is a man standing next to you. I remember an employee not taking me seriously due to his male-ego.

What is the one advice that you would give to budding entrepreneurs?

Go for it only if you are passionate about it, or else you won't find the passion and strength to go and work. Don’t do it just because everyone is doing it.

title: Interview | Geetika Gupta
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Geetika Gupta, Co-founder & Chief Pilot at MOPP Foods during Yuvaan.
body:
“The 3Ps that have helped me in my journey are passion, patience and perseverance. If you are passionate, you would want to work every day." DTU Times interviewed Geetika Gupta, Co-founder & Chief Pilot at MOPP Foods during Yuvaan. 

What all changed for your brand after your Shark Tank episode telecasted?  

The most important impact was the sales. Our sales shot up in just a matter of seconds, and while the episode was being telecasted, our phones did not stop beeping. Our brand is hyper-local, but we received calls from various parts of India. The visibility that Shark Tank gives your brand is amazing. Our brand became popular instantly. Our sales increased by 60% and we got more than 100 calls for franchise opportunities from various parts of the world, even outside India. 

What are the steps you follow for constant growth and learning? 

Know your business! By knowing your business, you will find ways to learn. There are a lot of books, interviews and media available online which can help you to grow. But knowing your business, analysing and reading feedback will give you a lot of insight into your business, which you cannot gain from an external source. I believe in learning from everyone and everything, not just from books or the Internet. If you have an open mind, you can take everything as a learning opportunity. Try to learn something from whatever you do on a daily basis.

What was the lowest moment in your journey and what were your learnings from it? 

Entrepreneurship is like a roller coaster ride. There are highs and lows. There can be moments of happiness, excitement, and sadness. In my journey, I have gone through many stages. The 3Ps that have helped me in my journey are passion, patience and perseverance. I used to go to the mirror and ask myself If I had fulfilled my mission and vision. If you are passionate, you would want to work every day. If you are patient enough to face the ups and downs without giving up, you will eventually achieve success. 

What is the one attribute that college graduates lack, which is required in the industry?  

I have interacted with a lot of GenZ. I feel that they lack patience; they want overnight success, and they need to change their attitude and realize that they won't get all the opportunities laid on a silver spoon.

title: Interview | Hardik Banga
biliner:
"Getting views is rather easy, but building a brand is very difficult."

DTU Times interviewed Hardik Banga, Content Creator and Instagram Influencer with 500K+ followers.
body:
How do you come up with ideas for content, and how do you stay motivated to keep creating?

My content is based on the lives of students and since I am a student myself, my life is my content, so ideas come naturally to me. After building a career from scratch in a span of 2 to 3 years, there is a certain responsibility to maintain that and keep levelling up, so the motivation to do better will always remain there. 

How do you balance sharing your personal experiences while maintaining your privacy? 

Social media has two sides. One is where you have to be public with everyone, but at the same time, a content influencer has another aspect of their life which they do not wish to showcase so we cannot post everything. So finding that balance and to understand the difference between content is important. 

 Everyone has stories, but not all stories are interesting. How do you manage to make your stories worth listening to for your users?

Since I am a 4th year student, I know what students of our age group like to hear and watch. If they don’t appeal to the students, I have to make changes accordingly so that everyone is able to relate to it. So I keep the relatability factor of utmost importance. 

What is your content primarily driven by? Is it focused on content that does well, or does it have more of what you like?

It’s a mixture of both. Content creation does not solely involve the ideas of the creator, one has to think about what will work with respect to numbers. Since we are doing it on a big level now, I have to consider adding an element to the content that I like, which will eventually work in the long run. So I have to connect the two things in such a manner that my audience and I are both happy in the end. 

What are your views on content creation being the new face of marketing?

It definitely is a face of marketing, and it is going to stay for a long time. It will replace a lot of industries, and the competition regarding the same has already increased. One has to stay relevant to continue growing in the business. I ensure that by innovating. If I keep on creating the same content, at one point I have to do something new so that my content remains relatable and I stay relevant. Whether it's inherent or not, I have to bring something new to the table every 3 to 6 months.

What has been the biggest challenge that you’ve faced while making videos?

The biggest challenge was retention. In current times, anyone can create content and for most people, it ends up working. But to retain that ability, building a community and ensuring that my followers genuinely know me is one of the major challenges I face till date. Getting views is rather easy, but building a brand is very difficult. 

Can you share how a social media presence has impacted your life, both positively and negatively?

Mostly it has had a positive impact as it has given me a face for the youth, and to be invited to these events and be felicitated is a great feeling. The negative side remains that there are some things you can’t go public with. One has to keep that phase of their life aside.

How do you balance your work with life and college?

I’m still in my 4th year, and I’m sure you all would know the stress that comes with it! Currently, I don’t have a work-life balance as everything is still in a building stage, and things are scattered here and there, but with time everyone will figure it out. 

You are an Instagram content creator, and we currently have this debate going around whether content on Instagram is good quality content. What is your take on that?

Content on every platform is either good or bad. There is a lot of informative content on Instagram, but at the same time, there is no shortage of cringe content, and both have their separate audiences. I don’t think short-form content is harmful, it all depends on what you watch. Lip-syncing, transitions, comedy and finance are all a part of short-form content, but in the end it totally depends on the consumer. Content is always healthy, it's the algorithm that is unhealthy. It's the platform that causes the addiction.

title: Blog | The It Girl
biliner: Wherever she looks, she finds her own self smiling down at her. Read on as Navya Singh, 1st Year, EE delves into the captivating yet tumultuous world of an "it girl," as she grapples with the toll of fame, beauty standards, and a failed marriage.
body:
Wherever she looks, she finds her own self smiling down at her. Read on as Navya Singh, 1st Year, EE delves into the captivating yet tumultuous world of an "it girl," as she grapples with the toll of fame, beauty standards, and a failed marriage.

A flurry of flashes blinds her as photographers call out her name on the red carpet. She dazzles her trademark smile in return, a scintillating goddess in her own right. She is flogged by producers and actors alike throughout the night of the premiere of her latest movie. She smiles kindly at the praise she receives; how beautiful she looked in the film, and how brilliantly she showcased the complexities of her character.

Wherever she looks, she finds her own self smiling down at her. Her face adorns the enormous posters placed outside the venue, and the advertisement boards on her way show her holding a bottle of perfume, a box of cream, or a can of soda. Even as she leaves, she hears the cries of photographers and fans alike. Cheeks aching, she finally settles down in her car and winces at the sharp pain in her feet, already turning blue from the awful shoes that simply had to be worn tonight. She brushes her hair out of her face; dyed blonde now. She has often wondered what her mother would think of it, or if she would even recognise her daughter. No, her mother has only ever known a brown-haired full faced
girl who loved to play in the mud outside their kitchen. She would not recognise her now, with her straw-like blonde hair and her hollowed cheeks.

She closes her eyes in a moment of dizziness, caused by starving herself for the past two days so she might fit into the dress she has worn tonight. The suffocating smell of cigarettes lingers in her car, another way to make her face look sharper, her shoulders daintier. She looks out the window to yet again see her face smiling back at her. She wants to claw that serpentine smile off the poster. She does not remember the last time she genuinely smiled, does not know if she is even capable of the act anymore.


She thinks of the ending of the movie she has just seen, how happy and in love the two protagonists seemed. She knows a stack of papers finalising the details of her divorce will be waiting on her office desk when she gets home. She wonders if her husband will wait until the high of her new movie has passed before announcing their separation, or if he would steal her spotlight; simply to spite her.
 

The car halts to a stop outside her mansion, as she steps out, careful not to grimace in front of her chauffeur. A woman, plain to look at with ashy brown hair and wide-set eyes, walks with her husband. They recognise her immediately- she is used to the widening of eyes, the slight pause in breath when people see her. She smiles at them, as the couple rush to shake hands with her, telling her how they admire her work, how beautiful she is in person. She smiles and thanks them for their kind words, but as she turns to leave she hears the woman whisper to her husband.


“Oh, how I wish I could be her.”


She smiles sadly to herself as she steps into her house that feels too large, too empty. She
whispers to the too-large foyer.


“So do I.”

title: Interview | Anoop Lather, PRO, DU, former PRO DTU
biliner: In an enlightening conversation with DTU Times, Mr. Anoop Lather, PRO DU, former PRO DTU, shares with us his experience at the two educational institutions. Also, previously as an artist in Haryanvi movies, he describes how he contributed to the promotion of the Haryanvi Culture. Don't miss out on this exclusive interview and gain valuable insights from Mr. Lather's journey.
body:
"Art and Culture refer largely to the widening of the mind and the spirit and technology and science is nothing but, culture and society made durable."


In an enlightening conversation with DTU Times, Mr. Anoop Lather, PRO DU, former PRO DTU, shares with us his experience at the two educational institutions. Also, previously as an artist in Haryanvi movies, he describes how he contributed to the promotion of the Haryanvi Culture. Don't miss out on this exclusive interview and gain valuable insights from Mr. Lather's journey.

Bringing ancient and contemporary Haryanvi culture together, the state-level youth festival, ‘Ratnawali’ is celebrated with immense exuberance. Your contributions to its formation and evolution over the years to become what it is today are unsurpassed. We would like to know more about the journey that Ratnawali, formerly known as Haryana Day, has travelled and your experience as the pioneer of the festival.

As far as Ratnawali is concerned, it all started long ago, in 1985. It started in my mind in 1981, when I got an assignment for a play named ‘Rani Jind’, which was to be in Punjabi while working as a freelancer in theatres after passing out from the Department of Indian Theatre. All the artists in this play were from Punjab, and I was the only non-Punjabi-speaking guy in the whole production. I got the script in Hindi and read it for 2–3 days, and tried speaking the dialogues with not-so-correct pronunciation. So, I asked them to give me a script written in Gurmukhi. After getting the script in Gurmukhi, I bought a Qaida for the Punjabi language and started learning Gurmukhi. Also, I used to spend a lot of time with my Punjabi-speaking friends, like a famous Punjabi poet Amitoj, trying to talk to him in Punjabi and having conversations. As this play was a historical play, and being an inquisitive learner and avid reader, I started spending the rest of my time other than rehearsals in the Punjab University library learning about history during the reign of Maharaja Ranjit Singh. I read all the books available in the Punjab University library. I read books available in the Chandigarh Central Library, and at that time I realised nothing was written about Haryana, not even a single page about its culture, dance, or folk. That made an impact on me to start something in Haryana too. We went to the US and gave 75 performances across different cities. A lot of friends asked me to stay in the US, and though it was very easy for me to stay there, I came back to India and started studying the history and culture of Haryana, and during the study, I got to know that the nucleus of any culture is folk theatre because it contains all the aspects of that particular culture like singing, music, dance, humour, etc. Luckily, we had a theatre known as ‘Saang’ in Haryana. Before that, part of my education was at the convent school and at the Sainik School. So, I didn't have exposure to the culture. 

After coming from the US, I followed Ramkishan Vyas for some time, and in the meantime, I made up my mind by observing, learning, and executing. There were two historical reasons for the degradation of Haryanvi folk. One was the revolt of 1857 because people from this region participated in it, and sponsorship was not given to them, so they migrated to other parts of India. Secondly, after the partition of India and Pakistan in 1947, most of the Haryanavi folk artists were Muslims. So, they migrated to Pakistan. When I realised that we need to work on folk instruments and, for that matter, I applied for the job of Director of Youth and Culture at Kurukshetra University and I got the job. We converted the Haryana Day Evening celebration into Full day celebration and from that time we increased the number of events, subsequently days increased from 1 to 4, and venues increased from 1 to 5. 

I have introduced 30 events as I worked there for 30 years. We wrote to different colleges about this event. Haryana Day was introduced in different colleges of Haryana as a part of their fest. When I was a member of the Cultural Board of the Association of Indian Universities, I gave a presentation to introduce folk instruments to different parts of India to different colleges, as people from tribal areas were also present there. So, for experimentation folk orchestra was introduced in colleges for a year, and now the folk orchestra is an event. Also, we introduced Humour, Poetry, Ghazal, and Haryanavi Pop. I was criticised for introducing Haryanavi Pop. After working on all the aspects, Ratnawali is now so successful. Haryana is the only state in India where Saang is part of the Youth Festival in colleges and schools and that helped us to transfer our folk culture to our younger generation very easily and effectively. Ratnawali has been celebrated every year since 1985 without a single break, which is a great achievement in itself.

Have you ever faced any difficulty/opposition in introducing women to lead or supporting roles in plays?

We have to be very cautious while making any kind of change and have to perceive the problem. I will give you an example. We had started the event and a few girls from a college came to participate. There was a tradition that people used to come on stage to give money to artists as a reward. So, when I got this information, I took the mic and announced, “This is the new beginning because for the first time in the history of Haryana, Girls will be participating. So, whoever comes on stage to give money to artists, remember to consider them as my daughter or their sister.” Surprisingly nobody came. So, you need to find easier ways to do the job. Also, I was trying to expand this festival but people were getting anxious because the workload and crowd were increasing. Sometimes people say there will be a total ruckus. Once the VC of Kurukshetra University refused to permit a celebration, so there I raised my voice through the student union. 

Do you find it difficult to make students interested in folk dance/music and theatre?

I never said that I’m doing it instead I have always said that this is our yaj and we are doing our part of rituals also, I’ve always tried to imbibe one thing in students and that is - they are the saviours and soldiers of folk culture that’s why it is celebrated continuously every year. Sometimes people say who is going to take the responsibility and I have always stood upon to take that responsibility because thousands of people come to visit and enjoy the festival.

You have acted in a couple of movies. Do you think that the current regional and national cinematic creations are doing justice to the diverse cultural identity in the country?

The first thing you need for a film is a story to share. If the story interests you, it will also interest of the audience; secondly, the tools and the technologies also play an important role. Different forms of cinema in different regions offer varied experiences and one can find what one wants to see. The choice belongs to the audience and that choice varies as the audience ages. Either you should be able to deliver what the audience wants, or you should have the ability to cultivate the audience for the type of content you desire to make.  

In Bollywood, characters from different states are generally caricatured and are not represented with sincerity. How do you think that can be overcome? 

Caricaturing the characters is generally an easy way out. A society contains various kinds of people, so it is not very easy to represent all the minute details. This is a very ticklish subject, keeping things in a generalised manner increases acceptability and business opportunities. Some change is being observed nowadays. Now films do not contain many songs and the OTT platform also has some new types of content to offer, but generally, the new types of content are. heavily inspired by the content available abroad. They generally follow the same pattern and flow of progression of the storyline. We have 4-5 sorts of emotions, and we generally cash in on that. 

Tell us something about your latest book ‘काल और ताल’ which was launched at the New Delhi World Book Fair, 2023.

All my life, my main motto has been the preservation, promotion, and documentation of the culture of different states. Nowadays we have been detached from the traditions and cultures of the past. I could feel that as our culture was vanishing, our music was also vanishing, so I went to various villages and started recording the tunes. I made sure to include the notation of the songs alongside so that my future generations could reciprocate the songs in a similar way to the original. It would be like a collection of my heritage. The book contains songs ranging from events of birth to marriage to death. We have a tradition to celebrate the death of people who are close to the age of 100 since they have lived life in its truest sense, I have recorded those songs as well.  

Nowadays, families are shifting to urban areas for job opportunities and education. How can we preserve our own culture and preserve that?  

I feel that in another 30 years, 70 percent of the population will be urbanised. Even the way a normal conversation is carried out in urban areas is different from rural areas. I feel culture is transitional, and the sense of fashion also keeps on changing. These things go around in a circle. We still see traditional, ethnic dresses in fashion shows, movies, and weddings, since these styles have been documented and preserved. However, I would be the last person to stop youngsters from progressing to newer trends. There was a time when I enjoyed listening to The Beatles, then there was also a time when I used to go gaga over Rasputin’s music, so just like a flowing arrow we cannot stop the generation from progressing else they will get diverted.  

How has your journey been over the years in terms of the responsibilities you’ve taken and the challenges you’ve faced?  

Presently, I am working as the Chairperson of the Cultural Council and PRO of the University of Delhi. Back in the day, there was a difference. I had to do a lot of things on my own; I had to create my team of youngsters, and I used to conduct training programs for them. When I came to DTU, I realised that I had to generate work and relevancy for myself. I remember being closely involved in organising the EngiFest. I wanted the team over here to grow, and I closely listened to the problems they faced. It's important to have faith in the students when they list their monetary demands for organising the fest. I made sure that the money was being handled and utilised properly, and I saw the grandeur of the fest grow over the years. At DTU, the students have always exceeded my expectations in every regard, unlike the places I've worked in the past. I remember DTU Times being very unorganised when I first came here; we decided to divide the team into various subdivisions. I had done the same during my time at Kurukshetra University during the Ratnawali festival. Gradually we increased the amount and quality of content we were delivering at DTU Times. DTU gives you an opportunity to rediscover yourself. I know about many such students who have ventured into various diverse fields since the students over here have a lot of potential.
