title: Interview | Aditi Bhutia Madan
biliner:
Interview | Aditi Bhutia Madan, Founder of BluePine Foods and Yangkiez

"Why we push on handcrafted is because it generates more opportunities for the unprivileged. There are single mothers, divorced, and orphans. There are many such employees from different parts of the country who believe in us. It’s a beautiful confluence which has been conspired to be."

DTU Times interviewed Aditi Bhutia Madan, Founder of BluePine Foods and Yangkiez, Opener Shark Tank Season 1, MasterChef India Season 3 Top 6, during Yuvaan. Read on as she shares her highly inspiring entrepreneurial journey and talks about the joy of popularly being called the "Momo Mami".
body:
Interview | Aditi Bhutia Madan, Founder of BluePine Foods and Yangkiez

"Why we push on handcrafted is because it generates more opportunities for the unprivileged. There are single mothers, divorced, and orphans. There are many such employees from different parts of the country who believe in us. It’s a beautiful confluence which has been conspired to be."

DTU Times interviewed Aditi Bhutia Madan, Founder of BluePine Foods and Yangkiez, Opener Shark Tank Season 1, MasterChef India Season 3 Top 6, during Yuvaan. Read on as she shares her highly inspiring entrepreneurial journey and talks about the joy of popularly being called the "Momo Mami".

How does it feel to become a household name in India? 

Being crowned Momo Mami is a validation that my journey, vision, and purpose are on the right path. As someone from the Himalayas, I understand the importance of authenticity and handcrafted momos made with love, care, healthy, and hygienic ingredients. It's a validation from the right person that we're able to create awareness and deliver authentic momos to our customers. Handcrafted momos generate opportunities for the unprivileged, including single mothers, divorced, and orphans. This journey from MasterChef to SharkTank has been amazing, and I'm grateful for the beautiful confluence that brought us here. To anyone selling momos, my message is to make them handcrafted with love and care, and the right ingredients.

Do you think being a male would help you better?

As a female entrepreneur, I believe my brand and product are best suited to me. If a male were in my position, it would be more difficult and unjust as women put more love and care into everything. Just as mothers and sisters prepare food with good intentions and nutrients, I want to pass on that same thought and feeling to my employees, making momos with love and care.

What did you learn during your Masterchef journey?

MasterChef taught me that food should be prepared with love and care, rather than complicated dishes with layers of cooking that look fancy but are not healthy. Innovation in food should bring something new while keeping it simple. Basic and simple foods are now more valuable as people are going back to their roots and rediscovering sustainable clothing, pottery, and locally available ingredients like millet and ragi. However, I am concerned that these once thought of as poor man's foods are becoming a rich man's diet, leaving the poor behind. MasterChef has taught me the value of basic cooking techniques and using locally available resources.

What are the most influential people that you have come across in your career and how have they inspired you?

I draw inspiration from a variety of people, including actors like Akshay Kumar, who exemplifies discipline and a balanced lifestyle. His boundless energy is infectious. Another source of inspiration for me is chef Vikas Khanna, who has taken Indian cuisine to the world and was one of the first Michelin star chefs. I'm proud to have contributed to the journey of bringing momos to the country in a way that values and respects the cuisine. My husband has also been a significant inspiration. He has taught me to respect all cultures, and his guidance has been invaluable to me in times of confusion. Additionally, my IIM Ahmedabad professor Sunil Handa has been a mentor to me in business. He is a humble, grounded, and supportive guide for entrepreneurs.

What are your thoughts on food wastage as an entrepreneur?

Blue Pine's core purpose is to reduce agro-produce wastage by converting it into products that have a longer shelf life. As a farmer's daughter-in-law, I understand the effects of agro-produce waste, pesticide use, and climate change on crop growth. Startups and entrepreneurs must take action to find solutions to prevent food shortages. We should also consume food responsibly and avoid overeating. I do not support meat replacement products, which can bring more diseases. We must generate awareness among our parents and communities to prevent wastage of agro-produce. Fashion food should be avoided, as it destroys a lot of agro-produce and grains. Instead, we should consume natural food from the soil. We must act now to correct our actions and prevent future food shortages.

What would you say to a momo lover?

Please have Yangkiez momos by Momo Mami! I'm associated with GoldenEye as a jury from where we try to give more opportunities to blind people. They actually do amazing cooking. So by having Yangkiez momos, you’re supporting the cause and venture of their employees.

title: Interview | Varun Alagh, Co-Founder & CEO, Mamaearth
biliner: In an open conversation with DTU Times during Invictus'23, Varun Alagh, Co-founder and CEO of Mamaearth delves into the compelling origins of Mamaearth, driven by the vision to provide toxin-free products.Read on as he unveils their successful expansion into the beauty industry, along with the powerful message that skincare is essential for all individuals, transcending gender norms.
body:
"For us, beauty is not a noun. It’s a verb. And that’s the biggest difference, right? Beauty for a lot of companies
has been about how you look. But for us, it’s about what you do that makes you beautiful."

In an open conversation with DTU Times during Invictus'23, Varun Alagh, Co-founder and CEO of Mamaearth delves into the compelling origins of Mamaearth, driven by the vision to provide toxin-free products.

Read on as he unveils their successful expansion into the beauty industry, along with the powerful message that skincare is essential for all individuals, transcending gender norms.

How does it feel to be back on campus after so long?

It feels fantastic. This is where I started my professional learning path. Coming back to space and watching it expand so much is incredible. The infrastructure is substantially better and larger from what we had to what you have. The enthusiasm and passion that we had to make a difference will help you develop a name for your college. We were the first group to construct the racing car that was chosen. Other things were going on at the time. The desire for building something new and developing something new, which puts your name and the college's name on the map, is still present and, you know, similarly high. But I'm overjoyed to be here.


What was the idea behind MamaEarth? And who do you aim to target with this product? What were the turning points in your journey?

The idea started with our own son. We couldn't find the right chemical-free natural products for him, which pained us to order stuff from the USA or UK. Asking relatives to bring in was always a hassle. Just telling them, "Please, ye le ana, wo le ana," it's just painful. Because not everyone is willing to adjust to those requests that you have. Right. And you're already so stressed as a parent that these things make you feel here. I wish there was a better way. And that inspired us to think, can this be done in India? And when we started researching, when we started thinking is when we realized that, yes, it was possible. It needed someone to take that mantle and do something about it, which is what we then started doing. We quit our jobs and started working on building a brand that will stand for toxin-free, clean, labeled natural products and build that for India because Indians deserve better personal care. And that's how we started, and here's where we are.

Starting your journey is the most crucial turning point that we can all make. Along the path, I experienced a lot of ups and downs, which you must manage. Thank goodness for my wife, co-founder, and some Black Label. We put in the effort. Things will improve the next day, you know. Having adult categories, having a celebrity on board, taking capital at the proper time, and acting aggressively while everyone else was passive during Covid-19. All of that has been inflecting points.

At what point did you realize that your product can cater to adults who want more toxin-free products?

Yeah. Finally, keeping your focus on the consumer is beneficial. Finally, they keep telling you what they require; if you keep reading that, your path keeps forming. So we just kept listening to our customers because kids don't buy items directly; their parents do. They assured us that we, too, would like to have stuff for ourselves. This is something with which we can identify. So when we heard that, we started concept testing and asked them if they would be interested in launching anything similar. And the response was emphatic yes. As a result, we began with a tiny project. We started in hair care with something in the hair fall area because our mums were buying us. And that received a very great response. And with that, we didn't stop. We continued to grow and to listen.

Within marketing, how do you differentiate yourself from a brand like Johnson's and Johnson's, which has been there since our childhood?

The largest difference for us was, first and foremost, functional, that we were toxin free rather than just stating it, but claiming it yourself will not win people's faith. We needed someone impartial and external to back it up for us. Right. That is why we tested with MadeSafe and received certification as Asia's first Made Safe certified brand. And that merely added to its popularity among consumers. This is a Certified Safe brand that helps us break through with customers. This is what makes this unique. Then, emotionally, we were always concerned with internal sustainability and virtue. When you order a product from our website, you will plant a tree, and the geolocation of the tree will be displayed. The picture of that tree makes you believe that you're not just doing good for yourself by choosing the natural product, but also for your Earth and your community. And the blend of emotional and utilitarian helps us differentiate.

Do you think becoming plastic-positive is a real goal for many people, or do people do it more as a publicity stunt?

That depends on the organization. For some, it is a CSR agenda. For others, it is a firm belief that as part of establishing your company's brand, this is how you will differentiate. It is a component of our brand building and part of how the company lives. So there isn't just one agenda. So far, we have recycled almost 3000 metric tonnes of plastic, which continues to climb as we grow older.

Similarly, we have a “Water For All” campaign on our other brands, such as Aqua Logica. We have a little scientist program, Dermaco. As a result, each brand has its own program that relates to life and how it contributes to society. Because we send you a message with a community where we put a water plant and you can see the family who got clean water. As a result, you actually get to witness this whole thing come to life. So it is a way of life for us, which is the major distinction between us and others.

Is it something small brands can aim to do as well? 

We, of course, began it. When you're young, it's not so much about your size as your intent. Even if we ignore the brand component, what you believe in as an individual is the most important. We recycled more plastic than we anticipated. That philosophy may also be applied to individuals. To seek more.

Are your products something that can expand into the beauty industry as well? For people more focused on their looks? 

Sure, of course. We just got into color cosmetics last year. So we now have lipsticks and foundations. Everything, right? Liquid lipsticks, concealers, kajals, you name it. And they are all certified to be safe. Toxin-free in the end, they're doing amazingly well because people are obviously seeking solutions where even in Beauty, which gets put the whole day on your face, on your lips, you want something that's not poisonous and that's hazardous chemical free, and yeah, we're getting there. We see a lot of bright futures in that field in the long run.

What is your concept of “beauty” as a natural product brand?

For us, beauty is not a noun. It's a verb. And that's the biggest difference, right? Beauty for a lot of companies has been about how you look. But for us, it's about what you do that makes you beautiful. 

Students, especially males, don't focus on skincare, thinking it's feminine. How can they be convinced to focus on skincare too? 

This is an ever-changing sector—can you believe toothpaste didn't exist until 70 years ago? We can't imagine now that it's a necessary aspect of basic hygiene. Similar to sunscreen, evolution, cultural, and behavioral changes will eventually occur.

title: साक्षात्कार | रजत चौहान, कॉमेडियन
biliner: डी•टी•यू  टाइम्स के द्वारा साहित्य एवं फिल्म समारोह ‘युवान’ के अवसर पर मशहूर कॉमेडियन रजत चौहान का साक्षात्कार लिया गया । साक्षात्कार में रजत चौहान से वीडियो रील्स, यूट्यूब एवं वतर्मान समय में  कलाकारों पर हो रहे मुकदमों इत्यादि जैसे विषयों पर वार्ता हुई |
body:
“मैं तो कल भी मुस्कुरा रहा था, मैं आज भी मुस्कुरा ही रहा हूँ 

और मैं आने वाले कल भी मुस्कुराता ही रहूँगा,

क्योंकि किसी चीज़ पर रोने के लिए ज़िन्दगी बहुत छोटी है”

डी•टी•यू  टाइम्स के द्वारा साहित्य एवं फिल्म समारोह ‘युवान’ के अवसर पर मशहूर कॉमेडियन रजत चौहान का साक्षात्कार लिया गया । साक्षात्कार में रजत चौहान से वीडियो रील्स, यूट्यूब एवं वतर्मान समय में  कलाकारों पर हो रहे मुकदमों इत्यादि जैसे विषयों पर वार्ता हुई | 

क्या आप अपने लाइव शो के दौरान हुए किसी अनोखे किस्से को हमारे संस्करण के माध्यम से साझा करना चाहते हैं?

मेरे हिसाब से हर शो कुछ न कुछ नया सिखाकर ही जाता है। मेरी यह ख़ास आदत है कि मैं छोटी-बड़ी चीज़ों पर बारीकी से गौर करने में यकीन रखता हूँ। मैं आज भी अपने नए-नए प्रयोगों से सीख ही रहा हूँ। चाहे वह कोई भी शो हो - कॉर्पोरेट शो, कॉलेज शो या अन्य छोटे-बड़े प्रदर्शन, हरेक अवसर खुद में विशेष है और उन सभी का अपना एक मज़ा है। हर जगह कुछ न कुछ नया सीख ही रहे हैं। अब आप पूछेंगे कि क्या नया सीख रहा हूँ, तो मेरा जवाब होगा कि अगर बड़ा थिएटर शो कर रहा होता हूँ तो कॉमेडी के साथ साथ थोड़ी एक्टिंग भी करनी होती है और अगर बड़े रूम के बाद कभी छोटे रूम में परफॉर्म कर रहे होते हैं तो लगता है कि “मैं इतना चिल्ला क्यों रहा हूँ?” (हास्यास्पद)

कुछ चंद लम्हों पहले ही मेरे सामने गिनती के लोग थे और अकस्मात दर्शकों की भीड़, जिस भीड़ को देखकर मैं आज भी पसीज जाता हूँ। दोनों स्थितियों की तैयारी पूर्णतः भिन्न है। कभी-कभार तो शो ख़तम होने के बाद एहसास होता है कि कितनी सारी चीज़ें तो मेरी योजना में भी नहीं थी। ये सब चीज़ें मेरे जीवन का अभिन्न अंग बन चुकी हैं।

कॉमेडियन के रूप में आप अलग-अलग मंचों पर प्रदर्शन करते हैं, परिणामस्वरूप आपके शो कि छोटी-बड़ी वीडियो रील्स एवं यूट्यूब के माध्यम से आपके चैनल पर उपलब्ध है। आप इन दोनों प्रारूपों में से किसे अधिक तवज्जो देते हैं?

मेरे विचार से स्टैंड-अप एक लम्बे समय का प्रारूप है। रील्स एक तरह का फ़ास्ट फ़ूड है जो लोगों को कुछ सीमित पल के लिए आनंदित तो कर सकता है परन्तु अंत में एक लम्बा प्रारूप ही किसी विशेष के मन को जीतने की एकमात्र प्रक्रिया है। मैं पॉडकास्ट का बहुत बड़ा प्रसंशक हूँ। मुझे नहीं पता कि इस उभरते विधा में आप लोग ज़्यादा रूचि रखते हैं या नहीं परन्तु मेरे विचार से पंद्रह सेकेंड में किसी कथन से मन पर गहरा असर नहीं डाला जा सकता। मुझे नहीं लगता कि इतने कम लम्हों में मैं किसी का मनोरंजन कर सकता हूँ। मेरे हिसाब से यूट्यूब एक लम्बा प्रारूप है और मेरी कोशिश है कि मैं उस पर रहते हुए ही आपको ज़्यादा से ज़्यादा हँसा सकूँ।

क्या आपको लगता है की रील्स वगैरह एक आर्ट फॉर्म की तरह माने जा सकते हैं?

मुझे तो लगता है कि काफ़ी लोग इसे पहले से ही एक आर्ट फॉर्म मान चुके हैं। कुछ लोग पंद्रह सेकेंड में अपनी बात कह सकते हैं जिनके लिए यह फॉर्मेट एक वरदान की तरह है। वास्तव में स्टैंड-अप का उद्देश्य लोगों को हँसाना है चाहे वह छोटे-बड़े किसी भी प्रारूप के माध्यम से संभव हो। मेरी कोशिश होती है कि मैं उन सभी लोगों की आवाज़ बन सकूँ जो अपने मन की बात सहजता से नहीं बोल पाते। जैसे आप रील्स साझा करते हैं तो इसका कारण यही है न कि वह आपको आपके दोस्तों से जोड़ती हैं । ख़राब रील्स और भी ज़्यादा वायरल होती है क्योंकि लोग अपना समय बर्बाद होता देखकर दूसरों का समय भी बर्बाद कर देना चाहते हैं। (हास्य)

सकारात्मकता यही है कि सौभाग्य से सभी के घर में आज स्मार्टफोन है जिसके परिणामस्वरूप आज हर दूसरे घर में क्रिएटर है जो पंद्रह बीस-सेकेंड में अलग-अलग प्लेटफार्म से पैसे कमा पा रहा है।

आपके हिसाब से क्या आज के दौर में रील्स बनाना कॉमेडियन्स के गुणों को प्रदर्शित करने का सही माध्यम है या नहीं?

मेरे अनुसार, जो दिखता है, वही बिकता है। जिसके पास क्षमता होगी, उसे पहचान मिलने से कोई नहीं रोक सकता। अगर आपका काम सही है तो लोग आपको देखना पसंद करेंगे, अन्यथा नहीं। घूम फिरकर बात यही है कि चाहे वीडियो बनाने के बहुत से प्रारूप हो, प्रमुख यह है कि लोगों को वह पसंद आ रहे हैं या नहीं। अंततः आपको एक शानदार अनुभव ही पसंद होगा। शायद आपको मेरी दस मिनट की वीडियो देखने का समय न हो तो आप उस समय पर उसे देखना पसंद नहीं करेंगे। आपको यह एहसास होगा कि मैं अभी पंद्रह सेकेंड का क्विक-बाइट लेने के लिए ज्यादा तैयार हूँ, इसलिए मैं अभी वही देख लेता हूँ। इसका एक नुकसान यह भी हुआ है कि आपकी ध्यान अवधि काफी कम हो चुकी है। अब लोग बहुत जल्दी चीजों से ऊबने लगे हैं। उन्हें कुछ पल का समय भी अब बहुत अधिक जान पड़ता है। अब मैं तो इस इंडस्ट्री से आता हूँ इसलिए मुझे खबर है कि रील्स जैसे छोटे फॉर्मेट में भी क्वालिटी सबसे ज़रूरी होती है। पंद्रह सेकेंड के क्लिप के लिए भी कितने ही बहुतेरे एंगल शिफ्ट लेने पड़ते हैं ताकि आप किसी दूसरी वीडियो पर जल्दी स्वाइप न कर सके।

आप बहुत से प्रोजेक्ट्स में व्यस्त रहते हैं, जैसे इंडिया टूर, ऑफिस टूर, मिनी शो आदि। इस क्रम में आप लगातार अलग-अलग कंटेंट बनाने को मजबूर हैं। समय के साथ-साथ, जब आपकी लोकप्रियता इतनी बढ़ चुकी है, तो अपनी कॉमेडी के कुछ मुख्य तत्वों को हर एक लाइव शो में शामिल करना कितना मुश्किल हो जाता है?

भाई मुश्किल तो है पर यही मेरा काम है, मेरी रोज़ी-रोटी है। पहले बहुत परेशानी होती थी पर अब आदत हो चुकी है। इस क्षेत्र में शुरुआत में तो काफी समय तक कुछ समझ नहीं आता था। स्टैंड-अप का प्रारूप भी नया था, इसलिए कुछ समय तो पैर जमाने में लग गए पर मैंने धैर्य का साथ कभी नहीं छोड़ा और आगे बढ़ता गया। अगर आपके मन में किसी उद्देश्य के प्रति सच्ची लगन और पूर्ण आत्मविश्वास है तो आप असंभव प्रतीत होने वाली कठिनाइयों से भी जूझ सकते हैं। आपके भी कुछ लक्ष्य होंगे जैसे कि किसी को एक अच्छा व्यवसाय करना होगा या किसी को विदेश में पढ़ाई करनी होगी। उसी प्रकार मेरा भी लोगों को हँसाने का एक छोटा सा उद्देश्य था जिसमें शायद मैं सक्षम रहा हूँ। आप कभी भी किसी कला में पूरी तरह से निपुण नहीं हो सकते, समय आपको कुछ न कुछ सिखाता ही रहताहै। अगर मैं मानूँ कि मुझे वीडियो बनाते हुए पाँच साल हो गए हैं तो शायद उस समय आप स्कूल में थे। अगर मैं स्कूल के समय से आजतक आप सब के मनोरंजन का साधन रहा हूँ तो वास्तव में यह मेरे लिए बड़ी उपलब्धि है क्योंकि आपके बड़े होने के साथ-साथ मैं भी अनुभवी होता रहा हूँ। हमारे स्कूल में उद्देश्य अलग होते है जैसे कि दोस्त बनाना, परीक्षा में अच्छे अंक लाना इत्यादि पर जीवन इतना सुगम नहीं है। हर समय मुश्किलों से सामना करना और उनसे सीखना ही इसे मनोरंजक बनाए रखता है। आपको ज़्यादा परेशान होकर जीवन को भार नहीं बनाना है। प्रतिकूल परिस्थितियों के अनुभव से स्वयं को नई सीख देते रहना ही मेरे हिसाब से सबसे ज़रूरी है और हमें बस इसका ख़्याल रखते हुए आगे बढ़ते रहना चाहिए।

आप अपने शो में क्लीन कॉमेडी पर ज्यादा ध्यान देते हैं जबकि आजकल फूहड़ता इत्यादि के प्रयोग से युवाओं में किसी भी प्रकार के कंटेंट को बड़ी सहजता से बनाने का एक चलन बन गया है। इसपर आप क्या कहने चाहेंगे?

यह आपका निजी चयन है। मैंने कभी नहीं कहा कि मैं केवल साफ़-सुथरी कॉमेडी करूँगा या मेरे शो में फूहड़ता के लिए कोई स्थान नहीं है। बात केवल इतनी है कि मुझे उसे प्रयोग में लाने की आवश्यकता नहीं पड़ी और लोग उसके बगैर ही जुड़ते चले गए जो मेरे लिए बहुत बड़ी बात है। हरेक प्रकार के लोग हैं और उसी मुताबिक भिन्न-भिन्न तरह की ज़रूरतें भी हैं।  मैं अपने प्रदर्शन के समय अपने दर्शकों को देखकर समझ जाता हूँ कि उन्हें मेरी बातों में दिलचस्पी आ रही है या नहीं, ताकि मैं अपने शो को बेहतर बना सकूँ। अब उस कॉमेडी में वेज कंटेंट था या नॉन वेज, इससे कोई फ़र्क नहीं पड़ता। इसलिए किसी प्रकार की तुलना करने की आवश्यकता नहीं है कि किसका काम बेहतर है और किसका नहीं। जब तक उनका कोई भी काम आपको हँसा सकता है तब तक सब ठीक है।

आजकल कॉमेडी में अक्सर देखा जाता है कि कॉमेडियन्स कुछ ऐसा कर जाते हैं जिससे लोग रोष में आ जाते हैं और कलाकारों को केस मुकदमो से होकर गुज़रना पड़ता है। इसपर आपका क्या मत है?

किसी न किसी बात पर लोग आक्रामक तो होते ही रहते हैं। सबकुछ इस बात पर निर्भर करता है कि जिसे आपकी बात बुरी लगी है, उसमें सामर्थ्य कितना है। कोई भी व्यक्ति चिल्लाता उसी पर है जो उसे स्वयं से छोटा जान पड़ता है। आप कभी भी अपने से बड़े ओहदे के लोगों पर नहीं चिल्लाते क्योंकि वो आपको सीधा जवाब दे सकते हैं या आपके जीवन को काफी हद तक प्रभावित कर सकते हैं। आप एक रिक्शेवाले पर चीखना अपने मालिक पर चीखने से अधिक सरल महसूस करते है क्योंकि पदासीन लोगों पर चीखने के कई बुरे परिणाम हो सकते हैं परन्तु एक रिक्शावाला जो अपनी अनंत समस्याओं से पीड़ित है, वह आपके गुस्से का आसान शिकार बन जाता है।

तो क्या आप यह कहना चाहते हैं कि जिन संगठन अथवा व्यक्ति विशेष को ज्यादा दबा हुआ महसूस होता है, उनपर लोग आसानी से अपना वर्चस्व स्थापित कर लेते हैं?

भारत में प्रजातंत्र है और सबको अपनी बात बोलने की खुली छूट है। घूम फिर कर बात वहीं आ जाती है कि जो लोग शक्तिशाली होते हैं, वह अपना दम-ख़म दिखाने में कोई कसर नहीं छोड़ते। हमारे घर में भी इसका एक साधारण सा उदाहरण है। घर में सबसे ज़्यादा इज़्ज़त उनकी ही होती है जो पैसे इत्यादि संसाधनों का प्रमुख स्रोत होते हैं। हम जानते हैं कि उनका होना हमारे परिवार की आजीविकाओं को चलाने के लिए बहुत आवश्यक है। शायद इसीलिए घर चलाने वाले लोग हमारे समाज में विशिष्ट नज़रों से देखे जाते हैं।

चूंकि हमारे पास अब बहुत थोड़ा समय बचा है और आप भी अपनी परफ़ॉर्मेंस को लेकर काफ़ी उत्साहित हैं तो मेरा आख़िरी सवाल आपसे यह है कि आप तो लाखों लोगों की मुस्कान की वजह बने हुए हैं, पर ऐसी कौन सी चीज है जो आपको हँसाती है?

लोग जिन बातों पर ठहाके लगा कर हँसते हैं, वह बात मुझे कुछ खास नहीं लगती है। अच्छी से अच्छी हास्यास्पद बातें जो लोगों को काफ़ी पसंद आती है, वह मुझे उबाऊ जान पड़ती है। अब मैं इसमें कुछ कर भी नहीं सकता क्योंकि यह मेरी उम्र के साथ-साथ आदत में बदल चुका है। मेरा काम बहुत विस्तृत है जिससे मैं मुँह भी नहीं फेर सकता। फिर भी कुछ मुट्ठीभर चीज़ें हैं जो मुझे भी हँसाती है, वरना जीवन जीना कठिन हो जाएगा। अभी हाल ही में एक तमिल फिल्म 'जय जय हो' आयी थी। मैं चाहूँगा कि आप कुछ अनोखी प्रकार की सिनेमा का भी अनुभव करें। इस फ़िल्म का मुख्य केंद्र घरेलू हिंसा है पर आप इसे बार-बार देखने के लिए विवश हो जाएँगे। 'हॉटस्टार' प्लेटफार्म पर वह हिंदी भाषा में उपलब्ध है। यह फिल्म आपके जीवन में एक खास चीज पर सोचने के नजरिये को बदल देगी। शायद आपने एक पुरानी फिल्म 'भेजा फ्राई' भी देखी होगी। यह सारी फिल्में जीवन के आयाम तय करती हैं जो सैकड़ो अद्भुत विषयों से हो कर आपके जीवन जीने की खूबसूरती में निरंतर बढ़ोढ़ती करती है। यहीं कुछ मनोरंजन के साधन हैं जो मुझे हँसाते रहते हैं और जिनके जरिए मैं ख़ुशी के दो पल लोगों के बीच बाँट पाने में सक्षम हो पाता हूँ। कहते हैं न कि हलवाई अपनी मिठाई खुद नहीं खाता। कुछ वैसा ही मैं भी हूँ।
meta_description: डी•टी•यू  टाइम्स के द्वारा साहित्य एवं फिल्म समारोह ‘युवान’ के अवसर पर मशहूर कॉमेडियन रजत चौहान का साक्षात्कार लिया गया । साक्षात्कार में रजत चौहान से वीडियो रील्स, यूट्यूब एवं वतर्मान समय में  कलाकारों पर हो रहे मुकदमों इत्यादि जैसे विषयों पर वार्ता हुई |

title: Interview | Rajat Sood

body:
“This discussion of art, you cannot do it with everybody. You need to find the right people. That is what I believe is the function of societies. This is their work. It gives you a platform where you can go and announce, ‘Arz kiya hai’.”

Amidst the electric atmosphere during Yuvaan’23, DTU Times seized the opportunity to sit down with comedic genius, Rajat Sood, for a captivating interview. Read on as he shares with us uproarious tales from his college trips and how college life shaped him as a superstar comedian.

How does it feel to be back in your college?

It’s thrilling. As I roam these streets, I get this feeling—this is where I  generated all my content. I have a memory associated with everything. For example, I remember that here only a friend of mine proposed to someone; or a fight happened there when we found out we got a ‘back’ in a subject; that was where we were laughing and all sorts of things. Plus, when you get so much love from here, it just makes your day.

Did joining college societies help you in any way in creating this new art form of comedy?

Obviously, everything helps you. Every experience you gain helps you as a whole and I believe societies like Sahitya provide you with a cultural atmosphere that is very essential in a college and you should be surrounded by it. For example, if you write well and you are meeting four people, then you all will grow together. That is what I believe is the function of societies. This is their work. It gives you a platform where you can go and announce, ‘Arz kiya hai’. If I would have said this in the hostel, I would have been hushed. Now there (in Sahitya) you can say, ‘Arz kiya hai’, a second person also comes along and says, ‘Maine bhi arz kiya hai’ and this, in turn, makes a mehfil. The same goes for Madhurima when someone discovers a new song, soon enough everybody starts analyzing it, wondering what is the music in it. This discussion of art, you cannot do it with everybody. You need to find the right people. They can be your friends or family or society. So that way, it was immensely beneficial.

How would you describe DTU’s culture and how has it helped you, considering all your sketches and your works of today have been derived from it?

The best thing that I think of DTU, and of every other engineering college in general, in which DTU provides a lot, is that there is nothing as ‘just study’ here. You sometimes come out better in extra-curricular activities. You get refined and you learn new things. You realize that studying is something that everyone is doing and that is mandatory. You can’t say that you are not doing 5th semester. That is not an option. But you can learn other things like how to organize a fest, how to market a product, and how to work in hospitality. I have learned all these things. Like in hospitality, I learned what is the requirement of a celebrity. Maybe he wants black tea, so where can we get it? That is how you learn how to cope with real-life problems and you become a better person in social dealings. Then you learn the etiquette to converse, you build strong associations similar to how most of the start-ups are. From my college, we were able to take off not because I knew their skill but because I had a good time with them at the hostel. Then we both discussed an idea and developed that skill, then we started the ‘start-up’. Once your vibes match then you feel like, ‘Let’s do something together.’

Did you try to travel while you were in college?

We roamed a lot during our time in college. Manali. Kasol. Otherwise, we were just loitering around the hostel. Someone would say let us go to Rishikesh, and then we would go to Rishikesh. Traveling is very necessary. And I would like to tell you this as well - do this (traveling) at this age. It’s better. Once you get into a corporation, you would have a lot of money. Transactions of 1.5 lakhs, on the 1st day of every month, and you will feel like you’re a queen, and then the manager ends up saying that you cannot take any leave for three months, saying “This is a project from America”. So, you won’t be able to do this, then. Try to get as many experiences as you can from this college.

How has life been after you won that competition? Is it in any way different from what you expected?

Every day, I feel very overwhelmed. I feel very grateful for the kind of life I’m living because this was a dream. I always used to think that all these big artists live like this, they travel a lot, tour India, and do international shows. Now I feel very blessed to live this life. I’m very thankful. Also, there is a bit of motivation that one gets, there is gratitude and you wonder, “How can this life be so ethereal?”. I feel amazed every day. Earlier I used to feel I had a good day, this will be in my memory for a long time. And then I realized that my whole week was great and that I might remember it my whole life. Which is impractical. It may not be possible. But in the last four-six months that I’ve lived, I feel every day that I will remember it for my lifetime. I cannot imagine a better day. And with God’s grace, I might progress further.

What has been one of the most defining moments of your career?

A career-defining moment for me has to be when I left my job. It wasn’t one practically. But internally, it was career-defining. Because once you have a backup plan you rely on that. You get your salary, and you feel great. You feel life is great. You can buy anything. You can go shopping. You can go wherever you want to go. But once you stop that option and consider that there is no Plan B, you challenge yourself and push your boundaries. And for me, that happened just before the lockdown. I got a very good show and it was paying me well. So I realized that if I can earn this much in one day, that my art has so much power in it that it can sort my life in a day or two instead of working for a month then why should I not work on it (art) for the rest of the 28 days as well? The result might be better. I am not talking about the finances but if you can get, in just two days, so much love or recognition and other terrific things like knowledge, and you give the rest 28 days to it as well, then it can bring you a lot on a large scale. All these things would be multi-folded. That was when I felt that this was the right decision for me. So I spent my entire lockdown reading and consuming art. “What kind of art has been created in the world? What have the legends written? Why are they legends? Then I analyzed their art form and then I realized, so this all has happened. Now, what can I do? We can do comedy. This is new for the nation.” So, I think that was my career-defining moment. From there, it was, let us learn, and when you learn a lot you realize what has been circulating in the market and what is not and that is what you can provide. That is how you can become exclusive. I guess that is what can be said about start-ups as well. For example, even Myntra is selling only clothes and so is every other app. But wait till a new app comes. Uber offers you cab rides. Ola offers you cab rides. Maybe there’s a new app that I believe gives discounts and is open to bargain and negotiation. It is a very small change, but now they are exclusive in the market. You need to find that space. “Why am I necessary in this field? Why do they need me?”. When I realized that, that was my career-defining moment.

When you made that decision, were you afraid?

I think it’s absolutely normal to be afraid. You get all sorts of thoughts in your mind, I won’t call it fear. But I am a very optimistic person in life. It’s to such an extent that even if I meet with a car accident then I’ll be happy thinking, it wasn’t a truck. I won’t be thinking that it’s an accident. And I knew from the start that I could do it. But I didn’t know the timeline. Might be in six years. So, I had this in my mind, that I might struggle for six years and I don't have money and my peers are growing and I’m not growing. I mean in terms of stature and a life point of view, but I was ready for that. So that was why I wasn’t afraid. You feel fear when you are uncertain. What can be the worst? I knew it could be sleeping on the streets. Because you’ve grown up listening to all these struggle stories and I thought it might be even better if I sleep on the streets. So, I was always ready. And I had good support from my friends and family at DTU. Inshallah, the people were very nice. Whoever I met was supportive. And I think if you are able to find even two people like these then I think your career or your life is made. There were others who, when I was growing up, said I can do this, and I kept doing it. And then it gets into you. So, I wasn’t afraid. No. The main thing was that I was ready for it even if it leads to failure, I’ll cherish it. But eventually, I will make it happen. I don’t know why I believed so much in that. 

Any final advice for the students?

Advice is to just live your life. I think it’s extremely important. I think the culture that is here now asks you to get a 20 lakh package, just after college. I say, if you get a package of 20 lakhs at 22 then what would you do at 30? I am not saying don’t earn but all I'm saying is if that money is limiting your experiences then take your time. Earn 20 lakhs next year. But just live life simultaneously. I once wrote a sher that followed the lines of - 

‘Jahan mein ek din aval banoonga

Magar tum aaj choro, kal banoonga

Abhi khamosh baitha dekhta hoo

Kisi din sheher ki halchal banoonga.’

title: Edition 59 | Souvenir Scheherazade
biliner: Situations are the unpremeditated storms of our life. This do or die situation tests our mindful decisions thus shaping the story of our life. Read on as Tejasv Mohan, Head of Illustrations, DTU Times, 2022-23, brings out the conviction of success in the wildest of situations.
body:
Situations are the unpremeditated storms of our life. This do or die situation tests our mindful decisions thus shaping the story of our life. Read on as Tejasv Mohan, Head of Illustrations, DTU Times, 2022-23, brings out the conviction of success in the wildest of situations.

For most people out there, the 'University Phase' is the most eventful phase of early adulthood. A phase that is known to be quite eventful despite its short span; a fact that most of us knew already, even before completing the earlier phases of middle and high school. This leads to a staircase where, at every step, we expect and imagine building memories of our college lives, similar to a kid playing with Lego blocks. One at a time, slowly connecting blocks piece by piece, we create something fruitful to be mesmerized by. Even so, there are a few bigger, stronger, unbeatable events that can effortlessly derail the formative years of adulthood. And, as a member of the COVID batch, I can attest to the immense sense of loss we have felt over the past two years quite heavily. It took an unprecedented pandemic, as mad as a March hare, that no one in their right mind anticipated, to rob us of the college experience we had dreamed of for years prior.

We were the Scheherazades of our time, desperately trying to hold onto the memories of what college life could have been. We created makeshift traditions and rituals, trying to make the most of what little time we had together. We held virtual events, Zoom parties, and online games, trying to connect with each other through screens and pixels. It was never enough, and the desperation for college memories only grew stronger as the months went by. We watched as our peers from previous years reminisced about their wild adventures and crazy stories. Meanwhile, we sat at home, finishing our coursework in our pajamas.

We longed for the late-night conversations in hostels, the spontaneous road trips, the crowded fests, and the deep conversations about life near OAT. We missed the feeling of being surrounded by people who were going through the same things as us, those who understood the struggle of balancing academics and social life.

But most of all, we missed the sense of belonging that came with being part of a college community as a whole. The feeling that we were all in this world and youth together, that we were building something bigger than ourselves. And yet, despite all of this, we refused to give up. We held onto the hope that someday, somehow, we would get to experience all of those things that we had missed out on. We clung to the idea that our college memories were not lost forever, that we would make new memories, even if they were not the ones we had originally envisioned. This led to a spiral where we tried to make memories out of anything possible, even if it meant lying to ourselves for the sake of it. To my fellow batchmates who are graduating this year, please do not fall into this mentally tolling spiral of making souvenirs out of everything. Let’s not lose our hope. Let’s continue to hold onto the memories we have, and let us make new memories wherever we can. Let us be the Scheherazades of our time, telling stories of resilience and perseverance in the face of adversity.

Our college experience may not have been what we expected, but that does not mean it was not valuable. We have learned to adapt, to be creative, and to never take for granted the moments we spend together. And who knows? Maybe someday, when we are all old and grey, we will look back on these years with a sense of fondness and nostalgia, remembering the time when we were forced to be apart but still managed to find a way to come together. And, on a final note of importance — we’re all going to make it. Trust the process and trust yourself.

body:
"An 18-year old filled with glee at the sight of the iconic OAT- 4 years away there I was, on first day at DTU. Cut to 2022- after 3 years of Google Classroom, we find ourselves standing at the edge of OAT once again. A lot had changed, but the will was right there- intact as ever." 

Read on as Hemang Sinha, Associate Designer, puts into words an inimitable say on the TIMES of his life. 

Written by Hemang Sinha, Associate Designer, DTU Times, 2022-23 and Saujanya Sood, 3rd Year, IT.

An 18-year-old filled with glee at the sight of the iconic OAT - here I was, on my first day at DTU. I was overwhelmed by the sheer scale of the campus. The first few days were spent catching up with school friends who ended up here, just to share the delight of it. As time passed, my clock started revolving around the idea of societies and roaming the campus with batchmates turned friends. I’d turn up pretty much anywhere that offered me an opportunity to learn something - anything.

I spent months getting accustomed to the culture here - from society meetings, to drawing up ED sheets with my friends, all the way up to slogging “one-week-before-the-mid-sems”. Late-night calls meant to complete lab files turned into cherished conversations with friends. 

But before I could go ahead with my adrenaline-filled first-year self, the pandemic struck. It was pinching at first, but slowly, acceptance took over uncertainty. I found myself more involved in college clubs, which no longer held only professional significance for me, but also served as my second family. Despite the rather abrupt transition from SPSs and Mic-Mac to Google Meet, we eventually found solace in calling up our friends late in the nights saying, “Meet aaja yaar”. 

Notably, this is when I truly discovered my role at a college society I proudly call my own - IEEE DTU. During my relentless struggle to figure out what I wanted to do in life, I was indeed blessed with seniors who were somehow always open to my endless ramblings, making IEEE not just a group, but a community.This was also around when I discovered Times. I never thought I would go from filing a “Recruiting Designers” form to compiling a whole edition of my university newsletter. The team went through its ups and downs, but Times was always close to my heart - something that would open the gates to my “yaadon ka pitara” even fifteen years from now.

A year into the pandemic, we started settling into the culture of surprise tests and online movie nights. Carrying forward what I had learnt, I made my pre-final year more about giving. I wanted to help everyone I could with what little I had accumulated over the years. I was hit by a sense of disappointment attached to the internship season that had just gone by, but I knew in my heart that something larger was in line for me - and I started working on something that forms part of their bucket list for many - my startup. I spent days and nights relentlessly trying to “create” something. We went from an idea on a call, to a tangible prototype, to incubation at the IIF.

Cut to 2022 - after 3 semesters of Google Classroom, we find ourselves standing at the edge of OAT once again. A lot had changed, but the will was right there - intact as ever.The offline part of college seemed to go by in a blink as I was about to go into my last semester. We were all ready to pack our bags in another six months and leave for our corporate offices. Any chances of finding something new seemed rather minuscule until I found myself on a trip with 5 people to a fest that we had all been eagerly waiting for - Mood Indigo. I never expected to find, on a trip to a new city in my final year, some of the most adored friendships of my college life. I did everything from observing sunsets to dancing at concerts with people I had always known but never felt connected to until just now.We enter college with bated breath - wondering what to expect from this seemingly alien yet homely place. Our image of what we wish to become is often markedly different from what we end up becoming. But somehow, on the day of the batch photograph, meeting acquaintances and friends, it feels as though everything has fallen into place. It’s not an all-happy album that we take away. But in the end, it all seems to have worked out for the best.

biliner:

As they embark on a new journey, the storyteller within them would make sure that the stories that shaped them, the cherished memories in the most remote spots of the campus, stay with them forever.

Written by Pranjal Srivastava, columnist, DTU Times, 2022-23.
body:
"Even when the world outside is harsh and unforgiving, I take comfort in the memories of the tranquil sunsets at the OAT that never failed to lift my spirits."

As they embark on a new journey, the storyteller within them would make sure that the stories that shaped them, the cherished memories in the most remote spots of the campus, stay with them forever.

Read on as Pranjal Srivastava, columnist, reminisces the very minute yet meaningful memories that he would look back at with a smile.

Do you appreciate the art of storytelling? 

You should, for there are no bad stories, only bad storytellers. To me, there is nothing more alive than sharing glimpses of the vast human experience and leaving others with their own stories to cherish. I have one such storyteller for you, one that has accompanied us through the most formative years of our lives–our college, DTU. As we prepare to bid farewell, I am struck by the countless tales of friendship, love, laughter, and learning that its walls have been privy to more than ever before. The campus holds a plethora of secrets that gradually reveal themselves to you over time. You learn how to navigate the paths that once had you lost and fatigued. You discover your own little havens amidst the bustling crowd. You befriend the campus dogs and maybe even give them names. You know exactly where to find a cool spot in the library and when to head to the MechC for piping hot samosas. You imbibe the vibrant vibes of DTU, carrying it with you as you step out into the world beyond its walls. 

In your final year, you might spend less time on campus and the nostalgia of your time at DTU washes over you, making you keenly aware of how it has shaped you and the idiosyncrasies that it has left you with. Even when the world outside is harsh and unforgiving, I take comfort in the memories of the tranquil sunsets at the OAT that never failed to lift my spirits. And when someone is rude to me, I think back to the time I relentlessly pestered Chandan Bhaiya for my order of Maggi, and it puts things into perspective. Even a simple sip of tea can transport me back to the warm, cardamom-infused tea I savored on cold evenings at Nescafe. Though I may feel lost in the crowd at times, I cherish the memories of how I found my people amidst the thousands and had the time of my life with them over four unforgettable years. DTU will have a fascinating way of accompanying you throughout your life. I still remember the sense of wonder I felt when I first stepped into college, unsure of what the future held. Today, as I prepare to leave, I find myself standing at a similar crossroads, with the vast world waiting for me. But my time at DTU leaves me filled with hope and eagerness for what awaits me. And I am sure such is the case for all my fellow DTU’23 batchmates. So if you ever find yourself in the company of a DTU graduate, don't hesitate to ask them about their college days. For with the stories that live with us, we carry a piece of DTU, and the storyteller lives on.

title: Edition 59 | After Slaying the Dragon
biliner: Read on as Ritvik Nair, Managing Editor, DTU Times, reminds us that bidding farewell is never easy, however it may seem to be and that there is just something about bidding adieu, that makes it difficult to even digest the idea of it.
body:
College is hard. There are way too many people, way too many memories to make and forget, and way too many grades to secure in this tumultuous journey of 4 years. But after doing it all, all we’re left with is the moments we make after pushing through every day of the 1460 we’re supposed to. As one makes their way to the college gate at the end of the day, there’s just one sensation in our heads- the feeling of toiling throughout the day, yet emerging victorious to be able to go for it the next time. Some days are so bad that you feel like disappearing into thin air, into  something that isn’t palpable anymore, yet some days are so good that you wish to remain in the moment- be it receiving a good grade, having the best food at the canteen, or just good weather. But when we wake up, we choose to have a day. A day that takes us in whatever way it’s supposed to.

Read on as Ritvik Nair, Managing Editor, DTU Times, reminds us that bidding farewell is never easy, however it may seem to be and that there is just something about bidding adieu, that makes it difficult to even digest the idea of it.

The young squire stared deep into the dragon’s ruby eyes. Even as flames within its eyes were snuffed out, the dragon struggled, trying to lash out at the squire with its long man-sized claws. Its efforts were fruitless however, for the squire had already dealt a fatal blow and a grim crimson oozed out of the hole on the dragon his sword had left.

Soon, the dragon fell, shaking the ground as a final rebellion against his fate. Upon confirming the dragon’s demise, the now knight stuck his sword on the ground and leaned against it. A shaky yet wide grin plastered on his face. His vision clouded as tears started flowing out of his eyes. Tears dropped onto the hilt of his sword, flowing down onto the ground and making streaks on the dragon’s blood that clung to the blade.

The young knight dragged his feet to his foe’s corpse. He ran his fingers over its brilliant red scales. Suddenly, his legs gave and he tumbled onto his buttocks. He looked up at the clear blue sky and laughed, tears still streaming down his messy face.

After sitting beside his foe for a while, the knight wiped his face on his sleeves. He then stood up and retrieved his sword. It was finally over. Four years of intensive preparation, training, and planning had finally paid off. With a smile on his face, he pointed his sword at the felled foe.

“Farewell,” he said, “old friend.”

Then, he was off. Soon, he would be officially knighted. Yet, he anticipated more of what was to come after. For becoming a knight was only just the beginning. The beginning of many adventures to come.

title: Edition 59 | And Welcome to Fight Club
biliner: Read on as Shikhar Rana, Head of Design, DTU Times tells about the stressful and emotionless corporate life and Tyler Durden's way of getting rid of this system
body:
Read on as Shikhar Rana, Head of Design, DTU Times tells about the stressful and emotionless corporate life and Tyler Durden's way of getting rid of this system

You see, I’m sick and tired of the way things are in this world. People are living their lives like zombies, slaves to their jobs, their possessions, and their status symbols. Often feels like we are all just cogs in a machine, endlessly churning away at our jobs, day in and day out. The 9-to-5 grind has become the norm, and seems like everyone is expected to give it all, just to keep up.

But at what cost?

The truth is that society is manufacturing 9-to-5 slaves every day. From a young age, you are conditioned to follow a descending path: “go to school, get good grades, go to college, and get a job”. A one-size-fits-all model that doesn’t give a damn about your skills and passion. And once in the workforce, you have to put in long hours, be available 24/7, and sacrifice your personal life for the sake of your job. And for what? To climb the corporate ladder, to earn a bigger paycheck, to keep up with our peers?

It’s a vicious cycle that leads to burnout, stress, emptiness, and disconnection. So, I started a place where men can come together and resist the system, resist the establishment that’s keeping us all down. It’s a way to wake people up, to get them to feel alive again.

And as this place grows, so does my mission. The only way to escape this existential emptiness is to reject the status quo and embrace chaos and destruction. We’re going to sabotage corporate offices, cause disorder in the city, and show people that there’s another way to live. 

Now, I know this all sounds crazy to some people. But that’s the point. We need to shake things up, to challenge the status quo. Because if we don’t, we’re just going to keep living our lives like mindless drones.

 So, that’s my mission. It’s bold, it’s ambitious, and it’s not without its risks. But I truly believe that it’s worth it, that we can make a difference in this world if we just have the courage to try. My name is Tyler Durden

title: Edition 59 | ABCs of Music
biliner: From the struggle to find a decent melody to the relentless refining of chords, phrasing, and percussion, musicians endure the arduous journey of creating music. Through practice, camaraderie, and unwavering passion, they triumphantly grace the stage, leaving behind a bittersweet farewell as they close the door of the jam room, carrying the weight of their guitar case and the memories of the creative process.
body:
From the struggle to find a decent melody to the relentless refining of chords, phrasing, and percussion, musicians endure the arduous journey of creating music. Through practice, camaraderie, and unwavering passion, they triumphantly grace the stage, leaving behind a bittersweet farewell as they close the door of the jam room, carrying the weight of their guitar case and the memories of the creative process.

Read on as, amidst the trials of crafting music, Ishaan Kaul, Head of Development, DTU Times, 2022-23 and Abhimanyu Dayal, 2nd Year, IT, explore the symphony of dedication, collaboration, and unwavering passion, where the jam room becomes a sanctuary of creation, culminating in the crescendo of live performances and the poignant farewell that resonates with the weight of memories and the closing of a transformative chapter.

Producing decent music is tough. Heavy stress on “decent”.

Good music — music that gets your head bobbing and your feet tapping — doesn’t just come into existence, it needs to be worked upon. Constantly. Painfully. At its peak, the 10 x 10 jamroom above MechC will become your home, and the soreness in your fingers will become your constant. 

The first step is the melody. Sometimes it comes to you naturally, but most times you’re pressed, and you have to force it out. You’ll get your phone out, and you’ll record yourself humming — twice, thrice, five times, seventy three times before it feels right. You’ll get it down on a guitar, and, if you can get your mates to approve it, you’ll move on happily to step two.

This next step is easy — chords. Music 101. Your ear’s trained by now, and you know instinctively what will and won’t work. You keep throwing until something sticks and usually, it sticks. 

It’s break time now. You have — not technically a song — but something that sounds good. The music runs through your head for the rest of the day — through Data Structures, the song is fast, upbeat; through DBMS it’s slow and calm. By the time you hit the jam room again, you find you’ve already decided what works best, and the rhythm is set. 

Next you add the phrasing and the percussion. For the non musicians, percussion is the beats, the rhythm, the drums, the bop, the phrasing means the notes you play in a certain way to convey a message. Again, easy — trial and error. 

You’re ready! Oh sure, you have the lyrics left, and the title, but you don’t focus on them — they’re icing. No, your focus is on the hardest part — Practice! Practice! Practice! How do you get through it? Friends, obviously! You play John Cena’s entrance, and the room has to get up and salute. You compete, you trash talk, you joke, you laugh, you scream and the music plays on. 

Your day has come — Homecoming fest, and the stadium is full. You walk in, and the crowd screams. Nervous? Nah. You dyed your hair blue for this! You walk out there, and the world turns upside down. Suddenly, all your sweat, blood and tears make sense. They love you, and you love them, and there’s nowhere else on Earth you would rather be.

Hold on — there’s one more step.

You’ll leave the jam room for the last time, and that smell will linger just a little as you turn to leave. In that moment, you’ll remember all the good times you had in this room, all the beauty you helped create, all the people you created it with. You might say a quiet last word or you might remain silent, but eventually you’ll turn around and close the door, your guitar case suddenly heavy.

title: Edition 59 | Savouring the Solitude
biliner:
“I clutch the straps of my backpack, cock my head back and look up at the beautiful evening sky. My smile slowly widens, and my eyes instinctively close, embracing the serene beauty in that blissful moment of solitude.”

As silence wraps up the warm blanket of peace and tranquility, our enshrouded selves reveal themselves.  In the depths of immense quietness, the inner being frolics in exuberance to the melodic sound of silence. 

Read on, as Neha Goyal, Head of Development, DTU Times, 2022-23, and Ritwij Kashyap, 2nd Year, IT vividly paint the delightful intricacies one enjoys alone at the University Campus, and how one cherishes these beatific moments, where euphoria pervades the senses.
body:
“I clutch the straps of my backpack, cock my head back and look up at the beautiful evening sky. My smile slowly widens, and my eyes instinctively close, embracing the serene beauty in that blissful moment of solitude.” 

As silence wraps up the warm blanket of peace and tranquility, our enshrouded selves reveal themselves.  In the depths of immense quietness, the inner being frolics in exuberance to the melodic sound of silence.  

Read on, as Neha Goyal, Head of Development, DTU Times, 2022-23, and Ritwij Kashyap, 2nd Year, IT vividly paint the delightful intricacies one enjoys alone at the University Campus, and how one cherishes these beatific moments, where euphoria pervades the senses.

"I should really get going; we've been loitering around for hours now."

"Yeah, it's getting pretty late. I'll head back too. See you tomorrow!"

"Bye-bye!"

I bid my friends adieu and started walking towards my hostel, which happened to be on the opposite side of the campus. A smile makes its way onto my face as I realise the long walk means more time for myself. I clutch the straps of my backpack, cock my head back and look up at the beautiful evening sky. My smile slowly widens, and my eyes instinctively close, embracing the serene beauty in that blissful moment of solitude.

Don't get me wrong, the time I spend with people I'm fond of is precious, and I wouldn't give that up for anything. However, sometimes, one just needs to unplug from the noise of college life. For an introvert, college can often feel like a whirlwind of activity and stimulation. As an introvert, I constantly sought respite amidst the frenzied chaos of college life. The never-ending flow of people, events, and information became overwhelming at times, and I often retreated to my own world to find balance and recharge. As I started on my way, I put on my headphones almost as if it was second nature and queued up my favourite playlist as I readied myself to relish the peace and quiet on the walk back.

I see the library to my side, and a wave of memories from the last four years flash in front of me as I reminisce the countless hours of precious me-time I spent there. A library may seem like an unconventional place to attach one's core memories to, but for someone who cherishes a moment away from the hustle and bustle simply to savour the solitude - the library serves as the perfect abode. Nothing pleased me more than finding a secluded corner where I could lose myself in a book or work on an assignment in my own little zone. I feel a deep sense of calm and contentment in these moments, my worries and anxieties melting away like snowflakes on a warm spring day.

I make my way towards the OAT, where all the colours of the college are on display. The people huddled up on the stairs for society meets, benches flocked with groups of friends, sparsely scattered people sitting by themselves, engrossed in their own little amusements - the OAT manages to capture a diverse yet homogenous image of the college culture. Being a spectator to this familiar yet serene scene grants me an immense sense of tranquillity. Witnessing the quintessential DTU evening takes me back to the evenings I spent on the lawns, under the twilight sky, with a book and a puppy nestled up to my side. I end up incessantly romanticising these moments because these cherishable fragments of time are what I look back at with immense fondness. These moments are like oases in the desert of college life, where I can pause and reflect.

As I make my way towards the girls' hostel, a bittersweet realisation dawns on me - the precious 'me-time' I had savoured along the way was coming to an end. These moments of stillness are not a luxury, but a necessity, a lifeline that sustains me and gives me the strength to navigate the ever-changing waters of college life. I come to terms with the fact that with my chapter at DTU coming to a close, I didn't have many campus walks left to add to my piggybank of cherishable memories.

I turn around, queue my playlist and cock my head back to take in the mesmerising evening sky once again. The vivid canvas of the shades of dusk looks even more inviting, causing a subconscious smile to appear on my face once again as I begin another campus walk.

title: Edition 59 | Choppy Waters
biliner:
As the transformative college journey nears its culmination, a cascade of reflections emerges, centered around the aspirations held dear by the 18-year-old self: the yearning for popularity, confidence, and sophistication. College unravels as a whimsical tapestry of comedic errors, illuminating the profound lesson that, even amidst moments of self-doubt, an unwavering sense of inherent worth resides within. With tenacity, uncertainties are conquered, and profound, supportive friendships are fostered, all while embracing one's unique quirks.

Join Ananya Kapoor, Editor-in-Chief, DTU Times, 2022-23, as she shares her introspective tale of transformation from a wallflower to an unexpected protagonist. Delve into her reflections on the lingering desires for greater achievements and the unwilling conviction that, if granted the opportunity to relive those extraordinary days, not a single thing would be changed.
body:
As the transformative college journey nears its culmination, a cascade of reflections emerges, centered around the aspirations held dear by the 18-year-old self: the yearning for popularity, confidence, and sophistication. College unravels as a whimsical tapestry of comedic errors, illuminating the profound lesson that, even amidst moments of self-doubt, an unwavering sense of inherent worth resides within. With tenacity, uncertainties are conquered, and profound, supportive friendships are fostered, all while embracing one's unique quirks.

Join Ananya Kapoor, Editor-in-Chief, DTU Times, 2022-23, as she shares her introspective tale of transformation from a wallflower to an unexpected protagonist. Delve into her reflections on the lingering desires for greater achievements and the unwilling conviction that, if granted the opportunity to relive those extraordinary days, not a single thing would be changed.

Over the past few months, as I have inexorably moved towards the finish line that marks the end of my college journey, my thoughts seem to be increasingly occupied with a certain ‘mental checklist’ my 18-year-old self had created before she first entered the arched gates of DTU. After spending the majority of my school life as a wallflower, I had vowed to be more popular, confident, and sophisticated by the time I graduated—things I hadn’t the gall to aspire to in the past. What I hadn’t counted on, however, was that instead of being the gateway to fantasyland I had imagined it to be, college has been far more reminiscent of a comedy of errors, with me as an unwilling protagonist. 

It all started the day I entered the campus for the first time; as my eyes wandered uneasily over the sheer magnitude of the DTU student body, I wondered how impossible it would be to stand out in a crowd like this. This dread became even more pronounced as the days went by; as my grip on academics slipped and I struggled to find my niche in this gifted crowd, the only thing that gave me some measure of comfort was the fact that I still had a lot of time to turn things around. I suppose the final nail in the coffin of my ambitions was driven by the pandemic which, in my mind, cheated me of the quintessential college experience I deserved and in turn, prevented the metamorphosis I had so dearly wished for. Perhaps the only thing I had going for me was that I was a part of the illustrious DTU Times team but here too, I’ve spent so much of my time plagued with insecurities regarding everything from my writing to my ability to lead. I suppose it is only fair to say that an unbiased appraisal of my trajectory over the past four years can only yield disappointment. 

Why then, do I find myself clutching at the last vestiges of my time here, unwilling, or perhaps, incapable of letting go? Equally puzzling is the revelation that despite failing to achieve the goals I had set for myself earlier, I have moved further along the road to self-acceptance than I had ever imagined possible. It is true that on the face of it, nothing seems to have changed; my annoying trait of blending into the wallpaper remains as pronounced as ever and I’m probably the least self-assured senior I know. Perhaps the only thing that has changed is the way that I perceive my flaws–not as chinks in my armour but as a set of unique quirks that make me who I am. 

As I have achieved things I had never thought possible–bagging an internship offer when I had absolutely no hope of making it, receiving the great honour of leading the DTU Times team despite the first-year me being so sure that she wouldn’t survive a single month here and even managing to build fulfilling and supportive friendships despite my many eccentricities–the one thing I have learned through it all is this—hat even in times when I find myself crippled with self-doubt, I am and will always be enough. Though I may still stammer my way through a conversation and panic at the thought of making important decisions, I now know that these imperfections can no longer act as impediments to my progress. Do I sometimes wish that I had achieved more during my time here? Yes, of course, but even in those moments of doubt, in my heart of hearts, I know that if I were to relive these days again, I wouldn’t change a thing.

title: एडिशन ५९ | अति का भला न सोचना
biliner: सत्य और सार्थक की ओर इंगित अनुसन्धान स्तर पर रोचक लगते ज़रूर हैं पर अंत में जब आपके पास उत्तरों से ज़्यादा प्रश्न हों तो क्या वह एक सफल अनुसन्धान था? पढ़िए इसके और समान प्रश्नों के उत्तर खोजने का प्रयास करते कपिल शर्मा, प्रमुख संपादक, 2022-23 के विचारों का सार इस अंतर्मुखी रचना में।
body:
सत्य और सार्थक की ओर इंगित अनुसन्धान स्तर पर रोचक लगते ज़रूर हैं पर अंत में जब आपके पास उत्तरों से ज़्यादा प्रश्न हों तो क्या वह एक सफल अनुसन्धान था? पढ़िए इसके और समान प्रश्नों के उत्तर खोजने का प्रयास करते कपिल शर्मा, प्रमुख संपादक, 2022-23 के विचारों का सार इस अंतर्मुखी रचना में।

चन्द्रमा की कलाएँ रात्रि नभ को भेदती हुईं निरंतर, लहरों का द्विचर गति में आरोह-अवरोह और उन्हीं जाने पहचाने विचार सूत्रों से टकराता मैं। रह रह कर मैं इसी निष्कर्ष पर पहुँचता हूँ कि जग में कहीं छाँह है नहीं, व्यक्ति के खुद के मस्तिष्क के सिवाय। पूर्ण क्लांति के स्तर की उपेक्षा कहीं से ओट यदि मिल सकती है तो वह अपने ही बुद्धि-वृक्ष के नीचे है। वो जर्जर हो या न हो, फल-फूल रत हो या न हो, कंटकों का क्रीड़ास्थल हो या न हो, वही है, जो है।

पर जो है वो क्या है? रूपकों के परे हम जानते हैं कि हमारे और (आशा है) सभी के कपाल के पीछे एक लोथड़ा है जो हमें पुरुष(अहम्) और प्रकृति दोनों का बोध देता है। फिर भी चेतना का ये आधार स्वयं ही स्वयं के लिए पारदर्शी नहीं है और चाहे आप कितना भी आत्मनिरीक्षण या अंतर्दर्शन कर लीजिए इस परिस्थिति में कोई बदलाव नहीं आएगा।

बहरहाल, हम प्रयास करते हैं प्रकृति और पुरुष दोनों को ही साँचों में ढालने का, प्रभावों के मानसिक कारण खोजने का और ब्रह्माण्ड को मानव के इर्द गिर्द मोड़ कर इस प्रक्रिया में सार्थकता तराशने का। इस विश्लेषण का जो भाग अचेतन होता है उसका तो कुछ किया नहीं जा सकता, पर प्रायः अपनी बुद्धि के साथ अकेले बैठे हुए एक फ़ीकी ग्लानि की धुंध घिर आती है और मैं विचार करता हूँ कि जो भाग चेतन था, जो स्वैच्छिक चेष्टा का फल था, क्या वो वर्थ इट था?

खोद डालीं नींव ही

उखाड़ दीं जड़ें सभी

दूर की और पास की

प्रेम और विश्वास की

खोद और और घना

और और कीच में सना

असत्य और तथ्य की।

लिए अतृप्त लालसा कि

ज्ञान सब देख लूँ

खोल सब भेद लूँ

ये ज्ञान जो बखानता

स्वयं की ही अधीरता,

(अब हूँ जानता) मलीन है।

स्यात अब कुछ सत्य को पहचानता,

हाय! प्रेम ही क्या सत्य है?

वही जड़ासीन प्रेम जिसके

रक्त में हूँ मैं सना?

क्लांत और अनमना

हूँ खोदता तदापि निरंतर

लिए वही अशमित अतृप्त लालसा

सोचता कि भविष्य में कहीं

शायद पुनः अतीत हो, नवीन हो।

पर बोझ सा बना

कण-कण में तना

अतीत ही तो एक सत्य अतीत है,

प्रतीत है!

वर्षों की आत्म-आलोचना से मैंने जो भी सीखा है उसका संक्षेप यही है कि कोई भी सिद्धांत अक्षय नहीं होता। दुनिया में कुछ भी ऐसा नहीं जिसे आप तर्क-वेदी पर फेंक कर मारेंगे और उसमें चोट नहीं आएगी, अतः आपको सावधानी से चयन करना चाहिए कि आप आलोचना के दूसरे छोर पर किसे रख रहे हैं। हमारे प्रतिपल बदलते परिवेश में उपस्थित स्फूर्त जन-मंडल के साथ हमारी परस्पर क्रिया-प्रतिक्रिया आत्मपरक विषयवस्तुओं को जन्म देती है, और उनके बारे में सोचना स्वाभाविक भी है। पर यह लाज़िमी है कि इस अनंत सूची में कुछ ऐसा रहे जो बुद्धि के प्रहार से संरक्षित उसकी ही नींव बन सके।

सत्य और सार्थक की ओर इंगित अनुसन्धान स्तर पर रोचक लगते ज़रूर हैं पर अंत में जब आपके पास उत्तरों से ज़्यादा प्रश्न हों तो क्या वह एक सफल अनुसन्धान था? अंतर्मुखी होना और विश्लेषण करना मूल्यवान गुण हैं लेकिन यह भी आवश्यक है कि हम अपनी अविरल फैलती विचार श्रृंखला (ब्रह्माण्ड की तरह) की सीमाओं की सम्भावना का बोध रखें। तभी हम अपने अंदर एक मज़बूत और प्रतिरक्षी आधार स्थापित कर सकते हैं जो जीवन की उथल-पुथल से हमें सुरक्षित रखे। एक सदृण बुद्धि-वृक्ष जो हमें जीवन की विषम धूप से छाया प्रदान कर सके।

title: Edition 59 | The Eye of the Tiger
biliner:
"Picking yourself up in the tough times, diligently observing your own actions, being strong enough to accept what is wrong and not falling into the labyrinth of being right every time is the only way forward. Always look at your inner self from the eye of a tiger."

The unwavering gaze of the tiger serves as a reminder to trust one's instincts, face challenges with determination, and persevere, embodying the indomitable spirit that resides within each of us.

Read on as N. Krithika, Student Head, DTU Times, 2022-23, embraces her inner power and fearlessly peers into the Eye of the Tiger, discovering her true strengths.
body:
"Picking yourself up in the tough times, diligently observing your own actions, being strong enough to accept what is wrong and not falling into the labyrinth of being right every time is the only way forward. Always look at your inner self from the eye of a tiger." The unwavering gaze of the tiger serves as a reminder to trust one's instincts, face challenges with determination, and persevere, embodying the indomitable spirit that resides within each of us. Read on as N. Krithika, Student Head, DTU Times, 2022-23, embraces her inner power and fearlessly peers into the Eye of the Tiger, discovering her true strengths

The Eye of the Tiger is synonymous with strength, determination, and resilience. It signifies the fierce and unflinching spirit that drives individuals to achieve their goals, irrespective of the hardships that come. This phrase is mainly associated with the world of sports, where athletes strive to cultivate the same spirit of determination and strength that is represented by the tiger's eye. However, for me, the phrase holds an essentially different meaning. For me, it means the clarity of thought in the minds of people these days and how one can’t get away from one's eye after committing a wrong deed. “The Eye of the Tiger” signifies that you will always be watched by someone and it is very important to do the right thing to have a clear conscience. 

There is something about the tiger, a poem of the liberty of pure genes which is meant to roam freely in its wild spirit and majestic demeanour. My fascination for tigers emerged when I went for my first-ever safari with my family in the hope of citing the mighty cat. We paved our way amidst the dense forest with the leaves dancing to a mysterious beat as if whispering their song to the wind in the arboreal air. We saw monkeys swinging by the trees, a herd of deers crossing the road, and thousands of birds chirping and enjoying the chilly breeze. To our surprise, we received a call that a tiger was sighted near the river. We rushed there just to witness the magnificence of the majestic animal. I could see its lustrous coat gleaming with pride, panting and silently growling, looking at me - eye to eye. Remember how it was a windy day? Well, the trees stopped swaying for me at that very instance. 

I would never forget the moment - my first encounter with a tiger. It got me thinking, is it only me or are all humans this weak that a stare-down could alter our lives altogether? It felt like the tiger could see right through me - my past, present and future. I believe that the eye of the tiger always exists. Someone somewhere is always watching us, monitoring our actions and observing our deeds, good or bad. One can never comprehend how a small action can lead to bigger consequences. This can also be related to what people call the “Butterfly Effect''.

Tigers are the living embodiment of fortitude and brilliance. Just like them, one should never hesitate to trust their instincts and let their brilliance shine. With this hope, our batch entered the placement season which offers abundant opportunities to learn, grow and make mistakes, most certainly being a difficult path to tread. There was a time when I reached an impasse, getting rejected in the very last round of a firm which I had coveted for a long time. I was devastated but I realized this was the time to be the strongest version of myself and be bold enough to go through the process of learning, unlearning and relearning without making excuses for my failures. 

One should never be delusional about reality and be honest with oneself. Picking yourself up in the tough times, diligently observing your own actions, being strong enough to accept what is wrong and not falling into the labyrinth of being right every time is the only way forward. Always look at your inner self from the eye of a tiger.

title: Edition 59 | College Chronicles: From Orientation to Graduation
biliner:
“And even when our paths diverge with some and we grow apart, I know that the memories we made together will always be a cherished part of my college experience.” Behind every bittersweet goodbye, there are a million memories waiting to be relived and a million more waiting to be made. 
Friendships mold us into the individuals we become, as they accompany us through moments of joy and sorrow, solitary reflection, and emotional setbacks. Read on as Saatvik Agarwal, Head of Design, DTU Times, reflects on the magic and madness of friendship, of the love and hope and understanding which is woven together in the strangest way possible.
body:
“And even when our paths diverge with some and we grow apart, I know that the memories we made together will always be a cherished part of my college experience.” Behind every bittersweet goodbye, there are a million memories waiting to be relived and a million more waiting to be made.

Friendships mold us into the individuals we become, as they accompany us through moments of joy and sorrow, solitary reflection, and emotional setbacks. Read on as Saatvik Agarwal, Head of Design, DTU Times, reflects on the magic and madness of friendship, of the love and hope and understanding which is woven together in the strangest way possible.

Being someone who shifted around a lot, I’ve constantly had to meet new people and be part of different & exciting experiences and interactions. The times I’ve had, man! Take it from a guy who was in more than 5 schools in just the last 3 years of his school life, life is like a box of chocolates. You never know what unexpected lesson you may get in what phase of your life. One such phase is college life.

College is a time of growth and exploration, a period of our lives where we transition from adolescence into adulthood. During this time, we forge friendships and relationships that can shape our lives for years to come. As a graduating student, I can say without hesitation that some of the best memories I’ve made in college have been with my friends. From late night brainstorming sessions to weekend adventures, my college friendships have been an essential part of my growth and development.

One of my fondest memories was during my junior (third) year, when my friends and I decided to take an impromptu bus trip to Rishikesh. Packed into a double-decker bus, we embarked on a journey filled with deep conversations. We stayed in a traveller hostel where we met a ton of strangers, coincidentally, even our super seniors from college and we took some of them along to explore the city on our rented scooties. We even befriended a group of girls who we invited to come along with us on possibly one of the most beautiful routes a person can travel on by a 2 wheeler to add to our ultimate bollywood vacation.

But it wasn’t just the fun times that made my college friendships so meaningful. We also shared some tough moments together. One of the hardest parts of navigating college friendships is when people change and grow apart, leading to feelings of betrayal and loneliness. It took me a long time to process what had happened and to come to terms with the fact that sometimes friendships just don’t last forever. But in that difficult time, I also learned a lot about controlling my emotions and resilience, and that even though it may seem like it, we are not alone. I learned that it’s important to communicate openly and honestly in any relationship and that it’s okay to let go of relationships that are no longer serving us, even if it may hurt us the most doing so.

Despite the challenges, my college friendships have been some of the most rewarding and fulfilling relationships I’ve had. Whether we were laughing over coffee in our PG or crying together after a tough week of work, my friends have been there for me through it all, offering support and encouragement and reminding each other of our strength and resilience. And even when our paths diverge with some and we grow apart, I know that the memories we’ve made together will always be a cherished part of my college experience.

So, to all the college students out there, cherish your friendships and hold them close. They may not last forever, but they have the power to shape who you become. Challenges are inevitable, but how we navigate them defines our growth. As I prepare to graduate and move on to the next phase of my life, I know that I’ll always look back on my college friendships with fondness and gratitude.

The campus size that scares you in the beginning would eventually shrink in comparison to the memories you make in it because frankly, there is no part of college that won’t bring up a wonderful memory for me and those memories weren’t made alone.
