title: Placement Journey | Google, Tower Research Capital, QuadEye
biliner:
"I know it’s easier said than done. Just work on your skills, have fun and try not to worry about the results."

DTU Times interviewed Shrey Dubey, COE, 2023 who received offers from Google, Tower Research Capital and QuadEye for an SWE profile.

Read the complete interview on our blog. Link is in the bio!

Use #dtutimes to get featured!
#placement #college #dtu #times #journey #college #corporate #sde #news #interview #recruitment #career
body:
DTU Times interviewed Shrey Dubey, COE, Class of ’23 who got offers from Tower Research Capital and Google for the Software Development profile. 

Can you share with us your placement journey?

I was mainly interested in problem-solving so I started doing competitive programming in the fourth semester. I held a pretty good ranking, I remember I stood second in the college. 

During the internship season, Google came first. I gave the test and was pretty confident with the DSA part, I didn't have many issues there. I was selected for the Google interviews but they were scheduled for a month later. 

In the meantime, Sprinklr conducted an online test which I cleared. My first interview was around 8 AM. I generally wake up at 2 PM, so, at first I had difficulty waking up and I was very sleepy once the interview started. They gave me easy problems but I think I didn’t communicate properly. Still, I thought I had done well and I was waiting for the next interview round, but then I was told they are not continuing with my process. I was shocked. 

I reassured myself that at least there was Google’s interview remaining. I practiced my communication skills for that, and did a few mock interviews as well, to communicate my ideas in a more structured way. The interview timings suited me— I wasn’t sleepy this time! They asked pretty straightforward and easy questions. By the end of the day, the results came and I was selected, so I was really happy. 

My internship was quite decent. The projects I was given weren't as tough as imagined. Once they were done, I was working on the documentation and presentation. I finally got the PPO from Google then so I didn’t sit in the placements at all. 

What advice would you give to juniors preparing for SDE roles at top product firms?

For people who are trying to crack big companies such as Google, I’d advise them to focus on problem-solving along with their core subject. You should have a decent enough CGPA and good problem-solving skills because, in the coding round of interviews, the questions are a bit challenging. Coding is a part of the only test, so once that is cleared it all comes down to your communication skills. 

I think most people do badly at interviews because of stress, so I’d say don’t think about it too much. I know it’s easier said than done. Just work on your skills, have fun and try not to worry about the results. 

What works and doesn’t work for an SDE resume?

From what I’ve seen when companies come to college; if you have 1-2 good projects to put on your resume and your GPA is good, I think that is just enough. They will shortlist you for the coding test. As far as resumes are concerned I believe it is better to have a good project or two which you have a clear idea about, that’s the main thing. 

You should have good problem-solving skills. Every company requires Python and Database skills in some way. You can learn Linux and put that down too. If you put something on your resume you should know about it.

 Also one should understand that having one resume for different companies is not always the key. We can’t apply to every company with the same resume. When I applied for Tower Research I tweaked my resume a little to highlight the skills that were relevant to that role. Just play to your strengths.

title: Placement Journeys | McKinsey & Company
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Aadya Bansal, BT, DTU’23 who has received an offer from McKinsey & Company for the Analyst profile.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Aadya Bansal, BT, DTU’23 who has received an offer from McKinsey & Company for the Analyst profile.

Can you tell us about your preparation journey of being placed at McKinsey?

In my four years of college, I have tried my hands at every field - coding, core subjects etc. I think the perfect fit for me was analytics and consulting. Also, the preparation for this was not very tedious. Your resume should be on point. It should be in the correct format and well-structured.

Was there any specific technical skill on which you have worked on for this role?

For non-tech placements, there is a set of skills that enhance your resume, but there is no specific skill that you really need. In technical skills, you have SQL, MS Excel, etc. They add to your resume but they are not the deciding factor.

What are the skills that are required to work in multinational corporations?

The first thing I learned is that your body language and confidence plays a major role. The second thing they notice is how you communicate.

Focus on the soft skills. Your introduction in the interviews is very significant. People do say that placements are based on luck but I think it's your soft skills that makes a difference.

What do the recruiters consider while interviewing any candidate?

The employers don't just look for technical skills. They look for people who can easily adjust in their company or organization. Read about the organization before giving your interviews. They are not looking for people who are completely study-oriented. They look for an overall personality.

What are your future goals as you have been placed in one of the most prestigious companies?

I plan to work for some time at McKinsey. Then I plan to go for higher studies because that will give me an upper edge. Then I will see where it takes me. There is no set plan as of yet.

title: Placement Journeys | Google
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Digant Rastogi, EE, Class of 2023, who got an offer from Google in their Hardware vertical.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Digant Rastogi, EE, Class of 2023, who got an offer from Google in their Hardware vertical. 

Tell us a bit about your placement journey. How did you come to the decision that you would be choosing a hardware-related role? How did you prepare for such a job opportunity? 

During my first year, it became quite clear to me that there were three ways I could go—tech, non-tech or core. Most people tend to go for tech as it is quite popular these days, but it was always clear to me that I wanted to get into core electrical related jobs. During our second year, we studied digital electronics and analog electronics. These subjects fascinated me a lot and the whole topic of VLSI really got me interested. I’d say you can get about 60% of your preparation out of the way just by paying attention in college and covering the three topics of digital electronics, analog electronics and network analysis since these are the topics interviewers ask most questions from. So, I’d say college is incredibly crucial for people looking to go into core electronics or core electrical. 

What was your interview experience like? Was Google your first choice since you must have had many other interviews? 

I haven't given many interviews since i got selected in my very first in both internship season and placement season. But, what I’ve felt is that interviewers seldom test your knowledge during the interview. Rather, they look for how exactly you approach a problem presented to you and how you deal with situations wherein you do not know the answer. So, you need to be fairly expressive about how you’re thinking about approaching the problem and whether you’d like to try answering the question despite not knowing the exact answer. 

What advice do you have for someone who’s looking to get into a hardware related job with respect to how they should prepare for their interview? Take us through how your Google interview was like. 

The Google interview had 3 rounds, with every round getting progressively harder. As I said, they’re not as focused on you knowing the answer as they are on finding out more about how you present your answers and how you approach the given problem. Moreover, even when we sometimes know the correct answer, we’re not able to present it well enough. So that is another thing that we must work on bettering. The most difficult part of my interview was the HR questions since there were no simple yes/no questions. Each question presented a unique situation where they expect an appropriate response from you. 

Many students feel that they need to give up their personal time with friends and family to prepare for their placements. Do you agree with this notion or do you think that academics and personal life can be balanced? 

There are 2000 kids in every batch, so it's not very practical to compare yourself to others because everyone has different aspirations. Some wish to go for higher studies while some wish to get a good placement so you cannot compare the amount of time you are devoting to studies with others since they might have an entirely different goal altogether. You can definitely balance out the fun with academics since I  personally do not feel that I missed out on anything.  

Did you have any setbacks during your time at college and if so how did you bounce back to where you are right now? 

I had my fair share of setbacks and I did not bounce back immediately from them. But one thing I love about this college is that there are so many opportunities to redeem yourself. Even if you’ve missed out on a placement or an internship there’s always some or the other message on whatsapp groups presenting you with new opportunities. Especially in terms of placement, even if you don't get placed in the first one or two months there’s plenty of companies to come and I’m sure that most students would get decent placements.  

What unique qualities would you say sets a student apart from the rest of the field? 

A well-written resume is incredibly important in my opinion, since your resume speaks for you. Another crucial thing would be having a good GPA. Lastly and perhaps most importantly would be communications skills. There’s no point having a good resume and a decent GPA if you’re not able to communicate to the interviewer why exactly you’d be perfect for the job.  

What advice would you give to juniors looking to get decent placements? 

Firstly, get your resumes looked at by a senior since you can't find the mistakes that your seniors would probably recognise quite easily. Another thing you can do is get some sample resumes from your seniors. Give as many mock interviews as you can for further improving your communication skills. Study regularly for exams and maintain a good GPA. 

Do you feel like you’re leaving a part of yourself behind as you transition from a student to an employee? 

There’s definitely many quirks of being a student; you can make mistakes and not expect there to be too many consequences, so there’s more freedom to try new things and learn from them. So I’ll miss the opportunities and flexibility of changing your mind about what you wish to do and of course meeting people from different backgrounds with different aspirations.

title: Placement Journeys | Homecentre - Landmark Group
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Harsh Gupta, ME, Class of 2023, who got an offer from Homecentre - Landmark Group for the Business Analyst profile in Dubai.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Harsh Gupta, ME, Class of 2023, who got an offer from Homecentre - Landmark Group for the Business Analyst profile in Dubai.  

Can you tell us briefly about your placement journey?  

In the first year, I explored all my options. But I knew my interest lies in non-tech. Initially, I tried doing coding-related projects but mechanical felt like the right path for me, so I shifted my trajectory to pursue it. I applied to mechanics-related roles and did 6-7 internships in the last three years. I worked at MakeMyTrip as a Product Manager, before that I had an on-campus internship at PwC as a Technology Consultant. 

From the second year, I started building my profile—PoRs, recognitions, achievements, and internships. As the placement season came closer, I studied case studies. I practiced them on my own on weekdays and then on weekends I had a friend over. My senior took mock interviews for me and based on those, I made changes and checked if my approach was working. Basically, I opted for the most streamlined approach to solving any case study. 

How was your interview experience? If you got any rejection post-interview, was that a learning experience in your journey toward your final interview with Landmark? 

Based on my profile, I was sure that  I would get placed in a month or two. But, for some reason, I was not placed till November. I got called for interviews and performed well. I reached the final stage but after that, my name didn’t appear on the list. This happened to me in almost every company I applied for.  

When Landmark came, I was not very keen on applying there because it is in Dubai. They conducted five offline rounds. The first was resume shortlisting. First, we had an aptitude test followed by group discussions. There were 15-20 candidates in front of two interviewers. Group discussion majorly involves agreeing with their points and quickly saying what you want to say before you miss the cue.  

The next round was quite stressful. They asked if I am willing to relocate to Dubai, why this role, why risk it for a country I’ve never been to, why I wasn’t placed yet. In the next round, they gave me five case studies. After I solved all of them and walked out of the interview, I felt confident that I have done my best and that maybe this is the place where all this will end. 

By then, it was almost 11:30 PM, we had been there since 7 AM. A friend of mine came from the hostel, and he was worried. I simply smiled and said, “This is it.” Within ten minutes, they handed us the shortlist and I was in it. 

Do you have some awkward or light-hearted moments during this time? 

Oh. definitely. In one, I was in the last round and they had a camera on the top of my head through which they were seeing and listening to whatever I was saying.  And they did not care whatsoever. I am saying something and one of them casually goes to fill his glass of water. One of them completely disappeared and so I stopped but then his voice came from another room saying, “Keep Speaking.” 

Then in another, my first round was flawless. Or I thought so because very quickly they rejected me and instead recruited forty-something people. After this setback, I took a vacation to Mussoorie and even there I had an online interview that went smoothly. The panelists were asking me where I have been vacationing, I showed them the view and we were laughing and having a good time. And then, the list came and I was not selected. Imagine, laughing and discussing the weather, and still, they don’t take you. 

So considering it took you six months you must have had that one moment looking back at which you must think, this has been my rock bottom. How did you bounce back from that to bagging this placement at Landmark? 

My rock bottom must have been the time when this company recruited forty-something people. After that, I just thought, “Whatever is to happen, will happen.” Because nothing was in my hands. I had a good resume, I was giving my best in all the interviews. I was clearing all the aptitude tests. I wasn't disagreeing with anything even when some company said, will you relocate or will you do this or that? I never disagreed. So all I had in my hand was to keep applying. And that I did, till November which was still three months ahead at that time. 

How do you feel about this transition from a student to an employee? Do you have any future goals and plans? 

Definitely, life is becoming more streamlined. Now you might not have time to pursue a number of things. You would be committing to a single work profile for the foreseeable future. 

I am planning for MBA and I was preparing for GMAT but due to some personal reasons I haven’t been able to study and so I won’t be applying this year. I wanted to give it before I go to Dubai but now I don’t think that’s feasible. 
 
What advice would you give to a junior aspiring for similar roles? 

Keep struggling. There is a little bit of luck factor that also comes into play. When a lot of people around you are getting placed and you just think, “he must have had luck because he had no achievements whatsoever”. So I would just say that keep struggling because luck favors the one who struggles. 

Do as many internships as you can. Don’t worry if your profile is up to it or not. Even if you are prepared, rejection is never in your hand. So just apply. 

Be patient. Be confident. Never lose hope. And don’t listen to others. Always listen to what you think is best for you. Because in the end, only you know what is best for you. Only you.

title: Placement Journeys | Bosch
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Anshuman Pandey, B. Des, Class of 2023 who was offered the role of Industrial Designer at Bosch.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Anshuman Pandey, B. Des, Class of 2023 who was offered the role of Industrial Designer at Bosch. 

Please tell us about your Internship and placement journey. When did you decide you wanted to apply at Bosch? How did you get the internship at Bosch? How did it turn into a placement?

When it comes to design placements, it's a different ball game for industrial designers compared to engineering students in our college. Industrial design placements don't follow the same structured process as engineering placements. For us, our portfolio is our best asset.

You have to work hard to be above average. Only 20% of industrial design students in India get placed. Only 2- 4% of them will have their dream jobs. The industry doesn't have a high demand for industrial designers, and design studios are usually closely knit. I realized these realities from my first year of college onwards. I understood what the industry demands and what it's all about. I knew I wanted to pursue industrial design and nothing else. I focused solely on industrial design and didn't waste my time on other subjects. Instead, I dedicated myself to product design, creating physical objects and prototypes. I studied the works of the best industrial designers in India and beyond, trying to match their portfolios and understand what they did during their college years. I built my own portfolio, even though at that time, I had only one project while others had three or four. But with that portfolio, I applied to Tata Elexsi, and luckily, I got an internship there. It was a great starting point for me, and I'm still in touch with my Tata Elexsi mentor.

During my internship, I gained real-world experience and learned how the industry works. I understood what it takes to succeed and what doesn't work. I made significant changes to my portfolio, aligning it with industry expectations. I took a break for six months after Tata Elexsi, during which I focused on personal projects and enhancing my skills. I also won several awards, including some international recognition, which helped me gain visibility.

One key factor in this industry is that the industry doesn't come to you; you have to reach out to them. You can't rely on job portals; you need to personally contact people in design studios. You have to introduce yourself, share your portfolio, and ask for a portfolio review. If they like your work, they may offer you a job or an interview. It's simple and straightforward, but also quite challenging because most of your emails may go unanswered. But persistence is key. I extensively used LinkedIn to find professionals working in companies like Bosch, Ether, Frog Design, Samsung, and more. I must have sent over 800 cold emails, introducing myself and sharing my work. Out of those, I received around 20 to 22 replies, which is a good response rate. I had interviews with those who replied, and I managed to secure internships and job opportunities through these connections.

For most of these interviews, it didn't feel like a typical interview. They were more interested in getting to know me and my capabilities rather than grilling me with questions. I believe it was because they had already seen my work and knew me through the design community. So, it was just a matter of reaching out to them and expressing my need for an internship or job.

Networking is crucial in this industry. You need to join design communities like Young Designers India and engage with other designers. Attend design events and conferences, and make connections. It's all about being confident and showcasing your professionalism. Your portfolio should speak for itself and reflect all the hard work you've put into it.

In addition to the internship at Bosch, I received a full-time scholarship for an industrial design cohort called Offsite, conducted by an American design agency called Advanced Design. I managed to balance my internship at bosch during the day and Offsite classes during the night, applying the knowledge gained from the course to my internship projects

Lastly, I want to emphasise that internships in design are not like typical internships. When you join as an intern, they give you substantial responsibilities and expect you to take ownership of projects. You'll be treated as a professional, not just an intern. So, it's important to be prepared and showcase your skills and willingness to learn.

That's pretty much my journey and what I learned throughout the placement process. It's competitive, but with the right mindset, a killer portfolio, and a proactive approach to networking, you can increase your chances of success.

Did you have any amusing rejections during your placement journey? How did you bounce back from those moments?

Yes, I faced several setbacks during my placement journey as a designer. In interviews, some people simply didn't like my work without any explanation. It was a matter of personal taste. I couldn't defend my design decisions effectively, and that's where I went wrong.

There was a lot of uncertainty and anxiety when choosing between multiple job offers. I had to weigh different factors like pay and workplace environment. I had zero professional experience and wanted to make a good start in the industry. I applied to many European design studios through cold mailing, and I received responses from some of them, including Teams Design, a renowned design agency in Germany. However, due to bureaucracy and visa issues, I couldn't accept their offer.

Another disappointment came from BSH (Bosch Siemens Home Appliances). After interning with Bosch, I applied to BSH and surprisingly received replies from all three designers I contacted. They were impressed with my work but wanted to know more about my design decisions. Unfortunately, the visa process became a major obstacle, and despite multiple attempts, I couldn't secure the necessary documentation.

Although I had a job offer from Bosch, I continued searching for better opportunities. It was challenging to deal with these rejections, especially when circumstances were beyond my control. I felt helpless because I knew I deserved to be there, but I couldn't overcome the bureaucratic hurdles.

To cope with the disappointments, I reached out to my connections and received internship offers from Samsung Design Delhi and Frog, a global design agency with a studio in India. However, I realised that these opportunities didn't align with my ambitious goals for my graduation project. Ultimately, I decided to intern at Ather, a dynamic company where I felt a strong connection and energy.

Currently, I have a job offer from Bosch, which is highly lucrative and exciting. However, I'm still looking for something that truly resonates with me. If everything goes as planned, I'll be in Munich soon. Otherwise, I'll start my job with Bosch in Bangalore, which is also a great opportunity. These disappointments are a part of my journey, but they fuel my determination to find the right path for myself.

What are the biggest learnings that you have applied to your design practice? And what advice would you give to aspiring designers?

One of the major learnings I gained from my internships is the importance of approaching challenges with honesty, naivety, and optimism. Each designer in my batch had their own unique ideas and ways of thinking, so it's crucial to find your own approach while also following a structured and linear process.

I faced a technical issue during a client presentation when my internet was unreliable. My mentor had to step in and handle the situation. From that experience, I learned the significance of double-checking everything, from your internet connection to your tools, to avoid any embarrassing or setback-inducing situations. Taking proactive measures to ensure your systems are running smoothly can save you a lot of trouble.

Another lesson I learned was the value of saying no to projects. As designers, we tend to be eager to take on multiple projects simultaneously. However, it's essential to assess each project's potential value and impact on your portfolio and creative bandwidth. Learning to decline projects that won't contribute significantly allows you to focus on delivering quality work and achieving better outcomes.

Note-taking is another critical aspect that I realized during my internships. Initially, I thought I could rely on my memory, but working on multiple projects made it evident that details can slip away easily. Taking comprehensive notes during meetings, client discussions, and interviews became a habit that helped me stay organized and prevented me from forgetting important information.

Improving my interpersonal skills was a significant area of growth for me. As an introvert, initiating conversations and engaging with colleagues didn't come naturally. However, I soon realised the importance of building relationships and effective communication in a design studio. Taking the initiative to connect with others, sharing more about myself, and showing genuine interest in their lives helped me develop stronger connections and created a more collaborative environment.

Utilising weekends for personal projects was something I discovered during my internships. Many companies are open to allowing interns to use their resources for personal projects. I took advantage of this opportunity and worked on my own ideas during weekends. It not only allowed me to explore new concepts but also garnered interest from colleagues and mentors who provided valuable guidance and mentorship.

Speaking of mentors, learning from experienced designers was invaluable. I actively sought guidance, participated in projects, and observed their techniques. Building a strong relationship with my mentors provided additional learning experiences and helped me grow as a designer.

Finally, I learned the importance of learning about people in a design studio. Each person has their unique passions and hobbies. By connecting with colleagues and finding common ground, I could learn from their interests and build stronger relationships. This opened up avenues for knowledge sharing and collaboration.

So, my advice to aspiring designers would be to approach challenges with honesty, embrace naivety and optimism, double-check technical aspects, learn to say no to projects that don't align with your goals, take comprehensive notes, work on personal projects during weekends if possible, actively seek guidance from mentors, improve interpersonal skills, and learn from the diverse passions of colleagues. By applying these learnings, aspiring designers can enhance their design practice and make the most of their internships

Which skills helped you succeed as a designer?

Industrial design is very hands-on, so in my portfolio, you'll see a lot of renderings and action prototypes. I've always been inclined towards physically building things, so I emphasise the importance of prototyping skills. From the beginning of college, I started building things by hand. Even without proper tools, I learned a lot from YouTube videos, like those from Adam Savage on Tested. I watched these videos to learn how to use different tools and make things work. As I gained access to resources during internships and college, I mastered the tools required for prototyping. So, keeping your prototyping skills strong is crucial.

Knowing materials is another valuable skill. I've always had a passion for learning and crafting, so I realized you can create amazing prototypes using materials that are readily available, even waste materials. For example, a shampoo bottle at home can become a good grip for a drill machine. So, I encourage aspiring designers to try quick and dirty prototyping and make the most of the resources around them.

Being a good reader is essential too. You don't have to be a nerdy kid like me, but you should keep yourself updated and aware of what's happening in the industry. The field of design is constantly evolving, and you need to adapt to different user demographics, use cases, and product types. While you can specialise in certain areas like medical product design or automotive industrial design, it's important to remain flexible and have a broad awareness of the industry. There are plenty of online blogs, YouTube videos, and LinkedIn posts by experienced designers that you can learn from and stay updated.

Knowing your software tools is also crucial, but you don't have to learn every single software out there. In my case, I focused on mastering Fusion 360 for 3D modelling, Photoshop for post-processing, and KeyShot for rendering. These are the digital software tools that are relevant to my work. You should identify the essential software tools for your area of specialisation and become proficient in using them. You don't need to know ten different software programs; just focus on mastering a few.

Sketching is another skill that I highly recommend. In the early years of college, I didn't think sketching was important, but I was wrong. You don't have to create fancy, Instagram-worthy sketches. Simple doodles and line drawings are enough to communicate your ideas effectively. Sketching helps you visualise and convey your thoughts and is an essential part of the design thinking process. Start with simple sketches and gradually develop your sketching skills.

Lastly, even if you're an introvert, it's important to learn how to present yourself and communicate your ideas. Developing a strong personality and improving your presentation skills will help you advocate for your designs and get your ideas across effectively. Seek feedback from others and work on refining your presentation style. Remember, the industry pays you for your skills initially, so keep practising and honing your skills. As you progress in your career, you'll also be paid for your ability to think strategically and come up with innovative ideas.

We've noticed a growing trend of design students shifting towards interaction design. Why do you think that is? And how have you managed to stick with product design and excel in it?

Well, when I started at DTU, there were about 15 to 18 people interested in industrial design. By the end of the first year, that number had decreased to around 12. And now, in my fourth year, there are only four or five of us working as industrial designers. The rest have shifted to other fields. The reason behind this decline is that industrial design is demanding and challenging.

To succeed in industrial design, you need a wide range of skills. It starts with identifying the right problem and understanding the needs of the users. The entire journey can be mentally and physically exhausting if you're not passionate about it. It requires dedication and the willingness to give it your all. You might have to work over weekends and push yourself to the limits. Industrial design demands a lot from you, from hands-on work like prototyping and testing to maintaining creative rigour and generating fresh ideas consistently.

It's not a job for everyone. It's like biking—some people are content with a regular scooter for their everyday needs, while others crave the thrill of riding a high-performance superbike. It all comes down to passion. Some designers pursue industrial design purely out of passion, while others love the process of building and managing projects. They become skilled designers who also excel at leading and coordinating teams.

Regarding interaction design, from what I've observed, many people mistakenly associate interaction design with designing screens for mobile phones or other devices. But interaction design is much broader than that. It involves the interaction between the human senses and something physical or virtual, regardless of screen size. For example, interacting with the exterior of a car or using a unique typewriter merged with digital technology.

Unfortunately, many individuals in the field of interaction design lack a deep understanding of what it truly entails. Only a small percentage of them truly grasp the essence of interaction design and produce exceptional work. I have great respect for those who excel in this field.

Now, to address why more students are shifting towards interaction design, I believe there are several factors at play. Firstly, interaction design offers a more predictable and structured career path. The tools and patterns are well-established, making it easier to make an impact. Secondly, India is predominantly a software economy, so there is a greater demand for software designers. Job opportunities in interaction design are abundant compared to industrial design, especially for fresh graduates. Lastly, there is the allure of higher-paying jobs in the interaction design field.

However, it's important to note that if you excel in industrial design and produce outstanding work, you can also enjoy equal or even better remuneration. The key is to showcase your best work and stand out from the competition.

Ultimately, it's a personal choice. Shifting to interaction design is perfectly fine if you feel it suits you better or if you're drawn to its advantages. I have chosen to stick with product design because I'm passionate about it and find fulfilment in this field. My motivation lies in creating meaningful physical products, and I'm content with my decision.

How was your experience publishing a research paper in your second year? 

Well, it's interesting because publishing a research paper in my second year of college was quite an achievement. However, as someone who has been working in the industry for a while now, I wouldn't prioritise it as much. But yes, I'm still quite passionate about reading and writing. I have written several articles and research papers that I haven't published yet, but I enjoy the process.

Actually, my first research paper was not in college but back in ninth grade. It was for the Indian International Science Festival organised by the Ministry of Scientists. The event was open to everyone, from school kids to PhD students and researchers. I always had a keen interest in science and wanted to work in scientific fields, although my maths skills weren't strong enough to pursue a scientific career. However, my school mentor, who had a strong academic background and had previously worked as a research scientist, motivated me to participate in the festival. He guided me through the process, and I ended up writing and submitting a paper. Looking back, it may not have had much value, but it was a significant accomplishment for me at the time.

When I entered college, I was determined to become a college professor and teach industrial design. I was very research-oriented and still am. I always keep myself updated by reading a lot of research papers regularly. It's like how some people read manga or comic books—I find reading research papers fascinating. Even in the field of industrial design, there are many research papers that provide valuable insights and methods. Institutions like MIT Media Lab and Technical University offer excellent research in design. So my advice would be to read a lot of research papers and familiarise yourself with the work of other researchers. This will help you distinguish between good and bad research, just like how watching many movies allows you to judge their quality.

If you aspire to publish a research paper, my recommendation would be to look for existing research on the topic you're interested in. Chances are, someone else has already explored it. Reach out to college seniors or search for content online to see if others have encountered similar problems or have valuable insights. Learn from other people's work and develop your own perspective based on that foundation.

For design research specifically, it's important to understand how it differs from research in other fields like engineering or physical sciences. Look for the best design researchers in the field, both in India and internationally. Manchu Bhagavad is one prominent researcher I can recommend. Also, explore the work of designers who combine research with industry practice, such as Arvin Sanjeev. By studying their papers, you can gain a better understanding of how to approach research as a designer and add your own unique perspective to the traditional research paper format.

What upcoming fields can designers work on to gain an advantage in their careers?

I once asked an influential person the same question, expressing concerns about industrial designers moving towards interaction design and whether it's something to worry about. He assured me that as long as people need physical products like toilet seats and spoons, there will always be a demand for industrial designers. The introduction of AI doesn't eliminate jobs but rather creates new opportunities. For example, knowing how to use a smartphone or a computer used to be a valuable skill, but now it's commonplace. So, you need to constantly upgrade your skills to stay ahead.

One field to explore is digital interfaces, as the convergence of physical and digital experiences is becoming more prevalent. It's not enough to just claim to be an interdisciplinary designer; you should showcase your abilities through a diverse portfolio that includes both physical and digital projects. Traditional design disciplines like visual design, interaction design, and industrial design still have value, but it's important to prepare for the future. Consider the interfaces we'll need in the next 20 or 30 years and focus on that.

Medical design is an emerging field that many companies are shifting towards. For example, Philips, known for consumer products like trimmers and homogenizers, generates less than 20% of its revenue from those products. They are investing more in healthcare devices, medical equipment, and software. Even Bosch, a hardware manufacturer, is transitioning towards software and embedded systems. As an interaction designer, upgrading your skills to specialise in industrial applications of interaction design could be a strategic move.

Observing industry trends is also crucial. Analyse platforms like the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) over the years to understand the product evolution and where the industry is headed. You'll notice a focus on medical products, the digital economy, and companies integrating software into their operations. It's not just about screens but about managing entire systems through software, such as fleet management or workforce coordination.

In summary, upcoming fields to explore include medical design and the integration of software in traditionally hardware-focused industries. Stay updated with industry trends and position yourself for the future by upgrading your skills accordingly.

What are your future goals, considering your successful placement and current work?

I have both short-term and long-term goals. In the long term, I see myself teaching industrial design to students. However, that will happen around ten to fifteen years from now, once I have gained more industry experience. I enjoy sharing my knowledge and tricks with others, so I already mentor students occasionally. But actively teaching would be my focus in the future.

In the short term, I have a goal to visit Europe and Japan. These two places are known for their design excellence, especially in industrial design. Brands like Sony from Japan and companies like Braun from Germany have iconic products that are often featured in textbooks. So, I want to experience the design culture there and learn what sets them apart. I believe it will broaden my perspective and expose me to more mature and defined design practices. Learning German and Japanese would also be beneficial for an industrial designer.

Once I have gathered these experiences, my plan is to return to India and work for an Indian brand. That's my short-term goal. Additionally, I have a personal aspiration to pursue a master's degree. I have always wanted to do it even before entering this field. In the short term, I aim to work for a design studio or apprentice under a European, Canadian, or Japanese designer to further enhance my skills.

So, in summary, my dream job is to become a college professor in the long term, while in the short term, I want to gain international exposure, work for an Indian brand, and pursue a master's degree.

title: Placement Journeys | Uber
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Kartik Tomar, COE, Class of 2023 who has received an offer from Uber for a Software Development role.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Kartik Tomar, COE, Class of 2023 who has received an offer from Uber for a Software Development role.  

When did you decide that you wanted to apply for an SDE role and when did you start preparing?

Around the 2nd semester of the first year, I found out that DSA is a major requirement for the SDE roles, which most people go for, so I started doing DSA, going from easy to harder problems. I achieved about 6 stars on HackerRank, I then moved onto doing LeetCode questions and solving questions on Codeforces. In the start I wasn’t even able to solve a single problem, but I kept solving and revising. From the start of 2nd year, I started giving contests on CodeChef with focus also on LeetCode. I think around the end of 2nd year I started doing LeetCode contests as well. Rather than first studying the concepts I would start with the problem and if I faced any difficulty then I just revise the concept. You have to majorly solve problems and give contests as well.

Can you walk us through your internship application and interview journey? What advice would you like to give to students who are preparing for their intern interviews right now?

I applied through an off-campus opportunity. I already had an intern offer from CureFit but I was not satisfied with it. In the first week of January 2022, I found a job posting on LinkedIn. At that time, I was not expecting to get any interview call or get shortlisted. After 1 week I got the online assessment link, and then subsequently I got the interview notification. I had 3 interviews, all of them were scheduled on the same day. The first 2 interviews were technical, and the 3rd was managerial. In the technical rounds I was asked questions surrounding brute force solutions with follow up questions. The interviewers help you a lot, you are not alone. It was the first time I was given questions on low-level designing, but they gave hints to follow up on.

The advice I would like to give is, nervousness is ok, but you are not alone, the interviewer will help you, follow the tips they are giving, and communicate your thinking process properly. Whenever you find an off-campus opportunity, try to ask for a referral but apply as soon as possible as some companies just take an X amount of people who applied first.

Were there any hilarious or unforgettable moments during your preparation?

I lived in a PG at the end of first year, my roommate also wanted to crack a SDE job, so we started with HackerRank. We jumped to CodeChef and opened a graph problem without even knowing what it is. Forget about solving it, we didn’t even know what it was. So, we started studying graphs and doing various problems. But we got so demotivated because we couldn’t understand it at all, and we left DSA for 1 month. It’s not exactly hilarious but it’s something I remember.

You mentioned that you did not have any referral while applying for an off-campus opportunity, what was the highlight in your resume?

According to me there wasn’t anything specifically exceptional highlighted on my resume, but I feel like I had decent projects and some good experience, what I think most companies do is that they just take the X number of candidates who applied the earliest. If you do 2-3 decent projects and some internships, it gives you an upper hand.

You may have faced some setbacks and been rejected, would you like to share some of those with us and how you overcame them?

D.E. Shaw was the first interview I gave, but after 1 round I was rejected as they asked questions about OOPS which I couldn’t answer. After that I felt very demotivated, but then realized I could either cry or start preparing for the next rounds. After that I had my Sprinklr interviews, I gave 2 rounds, but I wasn’t even told about my rejection, so I felt very demotivated after this as well. After was the interview for Microsoft, but even after 3 rounds I wasn’t shortlisted. I was able to crack the CureFit interview. What happens is that if you are shortlisted in a company and if you have worked hard, you will get what you deserve. Don’t fear setbacks or rejections, life happens. But even after CureFit I wasn’t satisfied, so I applied for Uber. I was very happy at the end, and I didn’t even remember everything that happened because even if I cracked the previous interviews, I would’ve left them for Uber as well. 

What general advice would you like to give to your juniors to ace their placement preparation?

The first thing would be to focus on your CGPA, don’t focus too much so that you are only studying for college. Many a time CGPA is the shortlisting criteria, try to aim for a good CGPA of 9 or above. The next thing I would suggest is to try to give contests regularly, don’t worry about decreasing rankings because what matters is your skill, the interviewer will not shortlist you on your ranking but rather on your skillset. Keep doing DSA regularly, you will not be a master of DSA at any point of time, it is a long process, and you have to continuously practice. Solving problems and doing contests regularly is a good habit.

What unique skills or qualities make a candidate stand out to the employer? Could you give some examples from your own case?

The first thing is you should be able to take feedback, be open to whatever your interviewer or colleague is telling you. The next thing is to always keep learning, you can always learn something from someone. And especially for the interview, always communicate what you are writing or thinking so that the interviewer can help you out.

title: Placement Journeys | Codenation and VISA
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Shashank Parmar, SE, Class of 2023, who got offers from Codenation and Visa for a Software Developer position.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Shashank Parmar, SE, Class of 2023, who got offers from Codenation and Visa for a Software Developer position. 

What was your approach to placement preparation?

My preparation for placements began with focus close to the end of my first year. While I was in my first year, I gained some knowledge in web development and actively participated in various societies, although I eventually left most of them. However, it was towards the end of the first year that I started my actual preparation for data structures and algorithms. Fortunately, since both opportunities were on campus, I didn't have to go through a job portal. We had a convenient DTU RM app where we could apply to different companies. Unfortunately, I made a mistake by solely focusing on projects, data structures, and algorithms, neglecting important subjects like operating systems, object-oriented programming, and computer networks. This oversight cost me several opportunities, such as cracking interviews with companies like Sprinklr, Intuit, and Atlassian, as I wasn't proficient in those subjects.

What advice would you give to candidates preparing for placement interviews?

I believe it's crucial for candidates preparing for interviews to strike a healthy balance between developing their resume, studying algorithms, and covering the course curriculum. Each aspect deserves equal attention. 

Furthermore, I'd like to share a humorous incident related to projects. During the second half of my first year, I focused primarily on projects. However, as I progressed, I shifted my focus solely to algorithms and data structures. This approach posed a challenge when I was in interviews and completely forgot about my web development experience, despite mentioning it on my resume. In an interview with Sprinklr, the interviewer, who happened to be a front-end developer, noticed the project section on my resume. He started questioning me about it, and even though I had worked on those projects myself, I had forgotten the intricate details. He even asked if I had copied them from the internet. It was an embarrassing situation, and I couldn't make the most of those projects. This experience taught me the importance of continuous studying as a means to bounce back from such setbacks.

Can you share an instance where you successfully overcame a lack of proficiency in certain subjects?

There was a point when I realised I had made mistakes in operating systems and DBMS. To rectify this, I dedicated myself to studying those subjects thoroughly and reappeared for interviews. This effort paid off, as I was able to successfully pass those interviews. Through this process, I developed a strong grasp of data structures and algorithms. Additionally, I realised the significance of understanding the underlying concepts and technologies when working on projects in any field. Interviewers often delve deep into project details, so it's crucial to have a deep understanding of the chosen tech stack. Alongside this, studying subjects taught in college, such as DBMS, operating systems, computer networks, and object-oriented programming, proved to be instrumental not only for interviews but also for becoming a well-rounded software engineer.

What qualities do you believe set a candidate apart during interviews?

The ability to effectively express projects, ideas, and solutions is vital. While many candidates may have impressive projects and a strong understanding of algorithms, what truly matters is how well they can communicate their thought process to the interviewer. Effective communication is key. Even if a candidate doesn't arrive at the correct solution, the clarity and coherence with which they convey their thought process can make them stand out. Let me share an incident from my interview at Uber. During the data structures and algorithms round, I couldn't solve the entire problem. However, I was able to progress to the next round because I presented a rudimentary solution and effectively communicated my approach. Although it wasn't the ideal solution, my strong communication skills played a significant role in advancing me to the next stage.

What sparked your fascination with machine learning and deep learning?

Over the past year, I've developed a profound fascination with the field of machine learning and deep learning. Currently, I'm working on several research projects and have a strong desire to pursue this field as a career. The combination of mathematics and algorithms involved in machine learning is what captivates me. Unlike traditional data structures and algorithms problems, where an exact solution is sought, machine learning offers constant room for improvement through mathematical skills and algorithmic thinking. There's always the opportunity to enhance solutions, and there isn't a single correct answer. This dynamic aspect of machine learning truly intrigues me.

Considering your interest in machine learning, how do you envision incorporating it into your future career?

While I'm deeply passionate about machine learning and deep learning, I haven't made a concrete decision about how I'll incorporate them into my future career. Currently, my plan is to continue my job and simultaneously explore opportunities in this field. I'm open to the possibility of pursuing a Master's degree in order to further develop my expertise. The combination of mathematics and algorithms in machine learning aligns perfectly with my interests. The fact that there's no single correct answer and that continuous improvement is possible through mathematical skills and algorithmic thinking is what excites me the most. As I explore more possibilities, I'll make a more informed decision regarding my future path.

title: Placement Journeys | Qualcomm
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Abhigyan Adarsh, EE, Class of 2023 who has received an offer from Qualcomm for a Hardware profile.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Abhigyan Adarsh, EE, Class of 2023, who got an offer from Qualcomm in their Hardware vertical.

 

How did you decide on applying for hardware-related roles? Did you face any setbacks? 

It was from the end of the second year when I committed myself toward this by learning the skills and the test experiences of my seniors. I got this inspiration from my seniors. I worked in a technical team, IEEE DTU, and also with Inferno where my seniors are doing internships in hardware companies. I also got intrigued with these roles as they do not require much coding which I was bad at but more electrical and electronics background. I was enthusiastic about electronics and I wanted to pursue it. That's why I chose this option and took on the preparation for the hardware roles in general for the placement as well as an internship at the end of the second year. 

For the initial phase during my internship season, I was not able to clear the interviews of companies because of the lack of practice so I couldn't compete in those scenarios. I was sure of these things in placement seasons where I was very focused on practising and clearing the concepts and also sharing questions that are designed and shared by our seniors with us. These setbacks of not clearing the tests brought a kind of practice environment for me where I can learn from my past and bounce back in the placement season where I could clear more tests than internship season. During the first interview experience, I got to know how the interview process works in real life and I was sure of these mistakes that I made in the past and could rectify them in the second opportunity I got with Qualcomm.

How was your interview experience with Google and Qualcomm for Hardware roles? 

During the placement season, I was able to crack Google's hardware test. We had 3 interview rounds. The first round was coding. The second one was core electronics and some logical questions. Then the third round was a ramp-up round with HR questions mixed with technical questions. It was basically a domain-specific interview. The interviewer was eager to know whether I was inclined towards analog or digital. Unfortunately, I couldn't go through the final selection. 

Next, I gave the interviews for Qualcomm. There were just 2 rounds. The first one was about digital electronics and logical reasoning puzzles. The second round was about Verilog, resume and HR-related questions. Finally, I got a call from HR and they asked me what I wanted to pursue in the future and how long I would be able to dedicate myself to the company.

What advice do you have for students looking to get into a hardware-related job?

Google requires good work experience, either in the project domain or internships. They get to know your skills from that. For other companies, they look into your projects and skills which you gain throughout your college years. They are more concerned with your academics. You need to maintain a good CGPA. Focus on Verilog, digital electronics and also practise puzzles for the academic side. For the resume, except for Google, you need to have a pretty standard resume with a Verilog project to be a must, for Google specific you should have some good experience with projects. 

For the non-academic side of things, you need to have good communication skills and the ability to propagate your idea to others properly. Co-curricular activities are an important part of your overall development, so you should have a good co-curricular life as well where you can participate in things be it a society or a tech team. 

The interviews are pretty standard; they just focus on your good understanding. All of the tests are hardcore digital and analog questions that you need to practise from the second year when you learn them in college. The second thing would be during the interview process, they just need to know how good you are at the things you practised for the test. They actually ask questions from your academics and they see the understanding of basics. So, you need to have good practice and the basics should be clear. You need to be focused just for 2-3 months to practise and to clear your concepts. If you practise, focus, and study for 3-4 months as we did in our JEE days, that's enough. 

 

Who do you think played a major role in your success with placements?  

I greatly respect my seniors for all the efforts which they put into training us. Right from the second year, our seniors were really helpful in answering any questions or taking sessions in fact for us in the placements and internship opportunities and also taught us about industry standards and what all the companies wanted. I would greatly thank my seniors for their support in this journey of 1.5 years where they supported us throughout the internship as well as placement season.

What are your future goals?

I would surely love to explore this corporate world. The chalta hai attitude does not really work in the corporate world. In college, delaying work is not a big problem. But in a company, if you are assigned a task, you need to do it. If someone asks about your progress, you can’t delay the reply if you haven't done it. If you're running a delay, you should be transparent. 

My immediate goal is to learn more in hardware—chip designing, robotics, analog and digital stuff. When we were in college, it was just “hardware or software”, but here, hardware is very diverse.

title: Placement Journeys | BlackRock
biliner: DTU Times interviewed Anusha Barman, EE, Class of 2023, who got an offer from BlackRock for the Analyst profile.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Anusha Barman, EE, Class of 2023, who got an offer from BlackRock for the Analyst profile. 

Please tell us about your placement journey and how you prepared. 

Since this offer is in the non-tech domain, there are certain topics you need to prepare yourself with. I had started preparing Python and pandas about a year prior to my placement season in order to establish a base. Then in the last two months before placement season, I started to really catch up and polish my resume. I made some standard projects which are required for entering non-tech domains, for example, exploratory data analysis. I also studied the basics of ML.  

Please tell us about your recruitment experience with Blackrock.  

BlackRock conducted a resume screening test and then an interview. In my resume, I had mentioned taking up a course called Financial Statement Analysis in my 2nd year which covered the fundamental aspects of finance. I think that helped my resume get shortlisted and also helped me in my interview. 

In the interview round, the panellists were really warm, so, I guess I was a bit lucky in that sense, since some people get really rude interviewers. In an interview, it is really important to be yourself. Your unique experiences and skill sets distinguish you from the other candidates. To be honest, most of the questions that they had asked me were really standard. I was just being honest to them and not exaggerating any of my skills. 

Were you sure of which companies you wanted to target? How did you bounce back from the rejections prior to getting into BlackRock? 


I was really particular about the companies I wanted to sit for. I had an Excel sheet that included the names of the Big4, American Express, BlackRock and others. I had initially decided to target these companies and I had planned to lower the bar if that plan would not have worked out. 

To deal with rejections, I had tried to instil some faith in myself since I knew there were still more companies. It wouldn't have made sense to feel dejected before September since that would've just hampered my progress and prevented me from getting into the companies I had targeted. 

What advice would you give to students preparing for similar roles? 

Practise your communication skills in front of the mirror—that would help to present your ideas more freely. In the non-tech domain, the most popular questions are generally about walking through your resume and telling about yourself. So you must make sure you are well versed with all the details of your resume and you are ready for these questions before-hand. Also, you must highlight the keywords in your resume. 

Do you have any hilarious anecdotes or weird pre-interview rituals? 

I remember the initial few companies were the renowned tech giants like Google and Microsoft and I didn't sit for the placement rounds of any of them, my friends were like “Anusha, why don't you sit for tech companies? It is easier for girls”. I felt that it might be easy for girls who have a good amount of technical knowledge and skills, but that was not me! I am not interested in coding [laughs].  

Before every interview, I liked to make sure that I was happy with the way I looked. I used to spend a good amount of time taking a bath, drying my hair and getting ready for the interview. I remember I had a really good hair day at the time of my interview, being at my best helped me to focus entirely on the interview and not on the external factors. 
 
During your company visit, what did you find the culture of BlackRock to be like? Is it like a LoFi song or is it like a loud orchestra? 

I think it is inclined more towards the LoFi side. All the panellists I had spoken to were very knowledgeable yet also very respectful. They were welcoming and eager to have me on board. The experiences of others that I have read about online also seem really good. 

What are your future plans? 

My end goal is to either work independently or have my own firm. I feel like I am really good at managing money and helping people with their finances, but before that, I suppose I need to create impact and that is what I am looking to do in the next few years.

title: Edition 60 | Interview - Prof. Anu Singh Lather, Vice-Chancellor, Ambedkar University, Delhi
biliner:
“I think that leaders need to be more tech-savvy and their agendas must be related to the practicality of the world. We are faced with a diverse set of issues, be it the sensitive ones regarding the social fabric of society or simply the need to include the marginalised communities. So, even leaders need to develop a broad mind set along the way as well as connect to the people at grassroot level.”

DTU Times interviewed Anu Singh Lather, Vice-Chancellor, Ambedkar University, Delhi. Read on as she shares her highly inspirational and impactful journey and talks about how to blend technology and leadership together to bear the best results.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Anu Singh Lather, Vice-Chancellor, Ambedkar University, Delhi. Read on as she shares her highly inspirational and impactful journey and talks about how to blend technology and leadership together to bear the best results. 

You have been affiliated with a number of prestigious institutes across the country and each role is a testament to your leadership ability and administrative expertise. Based on your experiences, what characteristics do you think set a leader apart?

Furthermore, I think that leaders need to be more tech-savvy and their agendas must be related to the practicality of the world. We are faced with a diverse set of issues, be it the sensitive ones regarding the social fabric of society or simply the need to include the marginalised communities. So, even leaders need to develop a broad mind set along the way as well as connect to the people at grassroot level. 

What hallmarks of an institute in your opinion makes it a more distinguished and exceptional institution as compared to other institutions of the country and the world?

Contemporary pedagogy should be field based i.e. you have to be connected with the field and the community. Moreover, an institution can play an even more significant role in society by providing financial help to the students in need along with sharing resources and facilities with neighbouring universities.

Talking about Internationalisation of Education, how do you feel student exchange programs and academic partnerships with foreign universities can also benefit us?

Also, these MOUs are very important in the upcoming times for India as a nation and we, as leaders, are also trying to emphasise this as much as possible. For instance, ICCR is giving a big platform to economically backward nations to send their students here and that too almost on a freeship. In return, Indian students also get to travel at a very subsidised amount across the world and that has brought about a big difference.

While the majority of teachers in our schools are female, the picture of Higher Education is strikingly opposite. What are the causes behind this situation and what shall be done to improve this ratio?

Another concerning factor is the female dropout rate in our country which ultimately prevents more female students from pursuing higher education. This also needs to be taken care of more seriously, especially at the school level. 

It has been observed that research in educational institutions is still limited to research papers, citations and journals, which in turn obscures their potential applications in the industry. What steps shall be taken to ensure that the outcomes of these possible practical applications and the research, that is conducted in these institutions, reaches industries and other organisations, be it government or private, more effectively?

Furthermore, I believe that the connection to the community is also very important otherwise your curriculum and follow up research will make no sense. To deal with this issue more pragmatically, what we can possibly do is we should take up the research projects coming from the industry, so that their relevance is guaranteed. But for this to happen, the industry should open up first. I hope that since the New Education Policy (NEP)  has been introduced by the government with a lot of deliberation, it might make some difference in the domain of research as well. 

Talking about industrial application, entrepreneurship is something that cannot be taught in classrooms. You played a pivotal role in establishing the DTU’s East Campus i.e. University School of Management and Entrepreneurship. How does U.S.M.E facilitate entrepreneurship? 

We also decided to introduce a 2-year MBA in Family Business which, at that time, was being offered only as a diploma or an elective course in other institutions. The main reason behind that was to connect people from small and middle-class industrial belts with the institution. 

For a long time, we wanted to start a B-School in Eastern Delhi which also received support from the government. After all, entrepreneurship is the future of our country, so it made sense to have a school that completely focussed on that. While setting up the institution and deciding upon the curriculum that was to be taught, we connected with those in the relevant industries and had marathon meetings with them regarding college’s programs. 

This is a case as seen in our nation and in other developing nations where the researches are more theoretical in nature or they just present repetitive kinds of work. This sort of poor orientation comes from the fact that we introduce research much later in the life of the scholar than it should have been introduced. To change that, we did the experiment, in DTU itself, with the introduction of the research project work at UG levels and that made a difference in terms of their publications, etc. 
When you look at the female representation in the social sciences domain, you will find that the number is very encouraging. In my university itself, we have about 64 percent female students and almost 50 percent female faculty. But these numbers also depend on the nature of the courses offered at an institute. For example, in technological institutes, we will always find a dearth of girls subscribing to technology-based programs. 

Since I have had the experience of leading the International Affairs office in my parent university, I believe that resources will always be limited so we need to develop mechanisms to optimally use them. That’s why international exposure and student exchanges are happening across the globe wherein good universities approach each other and sign MOUs for student exchange for a period of time. Undoubtedly,  students get the most benefits through such programs as they do not have to pay from their pockets while travelling and staying at other institutions.

First and foremost, it’s the quality of students, who are taking admissions in these institutions, that makes all the difference. This is because their expectations from the system, their contributions to the society, and their awareness about the changes and transformations in their surroundings are the factors that drive institutions towards greatness. Furthermore, an institutions’ prestige is also measured by its faculty and its quality in terms of their profile. Nevertheless, in today’s time, the profile is not about degrees they have acquired, it's about how they can teach their students by depicting the connection between reality, conflicts, and the challenges.

I believe we are in a transition from the previous traditional systems to a more technology-driven society, so leadership has definitely become far more challenging these days. However, I firmly believe that the social and emotional skills that drove the leaders in the past will still drive them in the future. After all, to avoid becoming irrelevant as a leader, you need to evolve in every aspect and in order to do so, one would always need traditional skills and competence.
