title: Edition 60| Interview- Prof. Madhusudan Singh, Registrar, DTU
biliner:
“One should develop their career profile at an early stage of study. As engineering is a professional career, if you want to excel in a profession you should plan it and put your efforts into achievement. You have a multifaceted scope of growth impact in the engineering profession”
Prof. Madhusudan Singh, Registrar, DTU, unveils the Registrar's office impact on educational reform and shares insights from years at the University in an exclusive interview with DTU Times.
body:
“One should develop their career profile at an early stage of study. As engineering is a professional career, if you want to excel in a profession you should plan it and put your efforts into achievement. You have a multifaceted scope of growth impact in the engineering profession”

Prof. Madhusudan Singh, Registrar, DTU, unveils the Registrar's office impact on educational reform and shares insights from years at the University in an exclusive interview with DTU Times.

Can you describe your vision for the future of engineering education in India and how DTU is working to achieve that?

In my opinion, the Indian engineering education system is going through a major transformation after the implementation of the new education policy in 2020, which emphasizes mainly on multidisciplinary education systems. That's why most of the reputed engineering and other institutions are orienting themselves towards multidisciplinary nature. If you have noticed, even Delhi Technological University (DTU) in the past six to seven years has started programs in other disciplines, other than engineering, such as Bachelor of Design, other management programs, and allied areas like BA Economics, BBA programs. This is an effort to create a comprehensive university where all kinds of studies are offered, giving students the opportunity to study other areas as well, apart from their own discipline, which is usually called a major. The discipline in which you are admitted is your major, and if you want to study a discipline other than your major, you can opt for those courses through a minor area of study. DTU has already introduced this provision of a minor in 2020, even before the announcement of NEP 2020. The first batch with a minor specialization is going to graduate this year. Some provisions of NEP are already implemented in DTU, and we are trying to implement the remaining provisions through our new curriculum, which has already been designed and approved by our academic council for the forthcoming B.Tech batch. This broadly outlines the future of engineering education, and there are many provisions in NEP that we are working on implementing in a phased manner. One provision, as I mentioned, is multidisciplinary education, for which the minor will be helpful. Another provision is for multiple entry and multiple exit. In a four-year program, there must be ways to enter the system at different levels and plan for different exit points with certifications and degrees. These provisions are already made in our new curriculum, which is going to be implemented from the upcoming session in 2023.

DTU has a huge faculty base. How do you ensure that all the faculty members remain up to date and engage with the latest developments in their respective fields of study?

Keeping knowledge updated is a regular requirement for the teaching profession. The university encourages all faculty members to attend faculty development programs organized in different domains to learn about recent developments. We find that most of our faculties attend these programs from time to time and update their knowledge. In addition to that, research is another activity through which faculty members regularly update themselves. To promote research among faculties, the university has already introduced a Research Excellence Award for faculty members and research scholars. This award provides financial and academic benefits to the faculty members. Therefore, I believe that through these measures, everyone is actively seeking the most up-to-date knowledge in their field.

As a professor, can you describe your teaching philosophy and how you engage with students?

Teaching philosophy is a very broad term. It includes the pedagogy you use to teach your curriculum. The ultimate task is to impart quality knowledge through your subject and help your students understand the content. To understand a particular topic, it not only depends on the pedagogy but also on the class you have and the students and their interests you are dealing with. Many times, we find that depending on the class size and the students' maturity level, we adopt different teaching philosophies. For example, in a master class, we may use digital tools like PPT, animations, and online demonstrations to make the subject more attractive. But in a large undergraduate class for beginners, where the class size is usually large, the content is delivered through traditional classroom teaching mainly through physical contact. Additionally, laboratories and project work are other learning tools through which the subject matter is made understandable to the class.

What initiatives or programs has DTU recently launched to promote innovation and entrepreneurship among students?

The concept of entrepreneurship and startups is gaining momentum, especially in engineering institutions. In line with that, DTU has established a Technology Business Incubation Center known as TBI under the name DTU Incubation and Innovation Foundation (DTU-IIF), a Section 8 company established in 2016. This incubation center provides mentorship and necessary infrastructure for startups and entrepreneurs to launch their businesses. Through this center, we not only provide mentorship but also offer infrastructure support to foster innovation and entrepreneurship among our students.

In your opinion, what are some of the emerging fields of study DTU should consider promoting or introducing in the institution?

Depending on the discipline, there is quite a good number of emerging areas of studies in engineering. There is a provision for interdisciplinary study through minors and for the implementation of minors the university has already introduced 45 different varieties of minor areas of study. For example, in computer science, you have minors in machine learning, data science or similarly you have minors on IOT’s, in electronics you have minors on VLSI design and other emerging areas of communication. All the disciplines have already introduced their minor areas of study where the students of other disciplines will opt for those mainly to widen their origin and increase their employability.

Can you share with us your journey from a professor to holding one of the highest administrative position in the university?

I am a professor of electrical engineering and presently looking after the task of Registrar which is a purely administrative position. I joined this University in 1999, at the time it was Delhi College of Engineering, as an assistant professor of electrical engineering. In 2007 I became a professor. It has been almost 15 years since I have been in service as a professor in this prestigious University. During the entire 24-year span of my stay I have gotten the opportunities to work at almost all the academic and administrative positions. For example, I have been head of department for more than 6 years, I was Dean Academic for almost 6-7 years, I have also worked as the controller of examination, chief warden. Whatever task the University assigned from time to time I tried to give my fullest commitment to those assignments which the University has assigned from time to time and have done all the work with my full potential and honesty. I always consider this university close to my heart, my belongingness to this university is at a very deep level. That’s the reason why during the entire 4 years of my stay I was involved in the administration deeply and due to all the trust and faith of the administration I got important opportunities and I tried to discharge my duties with my fullest commitment. 

How does the registrar's office contribute to maintaining DTU's position as the top technological university of India?

Registrar office is an office which extends services and support to all academic departments and administrative branches of university. The role of registrar is to ensure that all the policy and regulation that are framed by university authority and bodies are implemented in true sense. We always try our best to give all kinds of help and support for the overall functioning of administrative departments as well as other administrative functions of the university. We have some challenges because the university is in expanding mode. The student strength is increasing, currently we have 15000 students in the campus including our east delhi campus. So the requirements of manpower to carry out these academic activities smoothly and at ease at all levels. Where there is a requirement of faculty members or requirements of supporting staff university is putting its best effort to recruit qualified faculty members and also supporting staff but due to some administrative reasons sometimes recruitments are not done timely and because of that we are short of faculty members but any way we are managing through temporary staff.

What advice do you give to the students who are planning to study at DTU?

Those are planning to join this university have collected feedback about this place. So I simply convey my congratulations to them. I assure that once they join this place it is their wise decision to be here and they should also be proud of being associated with Delhi Technological University, they should be passionate about their discipline of study and must develop attitudes for academic not only attitude but also maintain academic credentials. Second thing is once you join university, university culture is different from school. In school you're in a very protective environment. Most of the time your parents are there to look after you. When you join university you have freedom, you have to take care of your academics, you have to take care of your personal belongings and your health also. So I advise everyone who is associated with this university to maintain good health by eating healthy food and following a healthy lifestyle. Every student should join a sports or other physical activities which are developed in the college like gymnasium. Apart from this one should also develop their career profile at an earlier stage of study. As engineering is a professional career and if you want to excel in a profession you should plan it and put your efforts into achievement. You have a multifaceted scope of growth impact in the engineering profession. You can go into the core technology sector, you may go into management, you may start your own business or you may join an administrative environment job as well. One should always plan at an early stage to which domain should I take over and plan your career and I think that way maintaining your good academic records and maintaining good health. You will surely get success.

title: Edition 60| Interview- Placement Coordinators। Batch of 2023
biliner:
"Being a placement coordinator, we are exposed to innumerable queries of the students and HRs and we learn about the viewpoints and perspectives. It builds confidence in our personality and develops our personality wholly. Further, you learn how to tackle problems in a corporate world and gain experience for that."
DTU Times interviewed Placement Coordinators for the batch of 2023, Delhi Technological University, Delhi. Read on as they share their highly inspirational and impactful journey and talk about how to blend technology and leadership together to bear the best results.
body:
"Being a placement coordinator, we are exposed to innumerable queries of the students and HRs and we learn about the viewpoints and perspectives. It builds confidence in our personality and develops our personality wholly. Further, you learn how to tackle problems in a corporate world and gain experience for that."

DTU Times interviewed Placement Coordinators for the batch of 2023, Delhi Technological University, Delhi. Read on as they share their highly inspirational and impactful journey and talk about how to blend technology and leadership together to bear the best results.

 

You're the cohort of placement coordinators who have witnessed the shift of online to offline mode in a very pronounced manner. Has this adjustment influenced your approach to carrying out a PC's responsibilities? What are the advantages and disadvantages of each mode?

It was definitely easier managing a large group of students in the online mode, since in the offline mode we sometimes had to manage 400-500 students in the campus, which was obviously quite difficult. But, as we’ve seen many people use unfair means in online assessments, so that obviously caused many problems. Moreover, another huge problem we face in online mode is technical issues. Links of meetings not working, Faulty internet connections are just a few of many problems faced by students that we must manage. Other than that, there are of course advantages; for instance, it's easier to take presentations in online mode as we can include as many as 400 students in one meet; whereas in the presentation hall, it is only possible to have about 200 students at a time. So, we’d say that online mode had a lot of hassles in terms of technical issues and regardless of the advantages of online mode, we were glad to have everyone back on campus for offline placements.

Owing to the recent boom of technology and automation in every industry; placements in core branches and non-technical domains have become increasingly competitive. Do you think a technical prerequisite is necessary for the preparation of non-technical domains also?

Coding is an absolute necessity for non-tech students now. We’d say that a fairly decent amount of coding knowledge is required for a good tech placement; little knowledge or the basics would not be enough. And yes, with the technology boom, the roles for core branches are decreasing as they are slowly being transferred over to AI. So, we’re getting more and more tech-related roles in this day and age. In fact, non-tech students should look out for opportunities that enable the tech team to do non-tech work as well. So, the core branch students should learn the aspects of tech that are unique to their core branch as well so they can present a uniquely identifiable skillset.

How does the choice of electives affect one's placement? For example, does a minor in software engineering assist a student from a core branch to stand out from peers who do not have such a minor?

We’ve been in talks with the companies and the faculties about this, and we do keep a database of the students pursuing a minor in software or COE who are in core branches. So, in future, it might help the students as they are considered fit for a tech placement by companies. That being said, one should only choose a tech-related elective if one wishes to aim for a tech placement; if not, maintaining your GPA is equally crucial and the choice of an easier elective can give your GPA the boost it needs.

There is always a debate over interning in two ways: interning at a startup for more flexible learning or interning at an established organisation with predetermined corporate rules. What are your thoughts on this?

In a startup, there are more opportunities to learn about every position inside the organisation and you obtain a comprehensive understanding of how a firm truly operates. Understanding corporate behaviour is also very important, as you never know where you might end up post graduation; so understanding how both of these organisations work is crucial. Given the numerous layoffs and company failures, it is safe to assume that large corporations are a safer choice to startups. Therefore, for campus placements, we advise choosing either large MNCs or startups that have already achieved unicorn status.

We’ve seen entrepreneurship gaining momentum steadily; How would you say startups are supposed to recruit their workforce when entrepreneurship is on such a steep rise?

Most startups in their early stages, hire students in off-campus placements. Such startups look for a very specific skill set, and as we’ve seen in our college, most candidates only have basic coding knowledge and know very little about development. So that is where the college students lack in terms of specialisation of their skills; so such startups tend to hire in off-campus placements. Whereas for entrepreneurship, DTU offers the students IIF where students are allowed to take extended breaks to develop their idea further. Given that the idea is not a fluke, and is unique in its terms. If you think your idea is unique and cannot be replicated by big MNCs easily, go for it.

Many students believe that, despite having a competitive profile on par with their peers, they have difficulty being shortlisted for an interview. Is there anything specific that employers look for on our CVs?

Companies tend to shortlist resumes in which they tend to look for GPA, sometimes 10th and 12th Board percentages, the projects you’ve worked on during your time at college and they also have an AI software that compares your resume to the job description offered by the company. So, students are advised to structure their CVs in such a manner that it aligns as best as it can with the company’s job description. 

What are the mistakes that students tend to make that endanger their chances of getting placed or getting an internship?

As for the mistakes that students tend to make, it is important to mention how students focus less on the core parts. For example, when people sit for tech placements or internships, they tend to ignore the core subjects like OOPs, OS and DBMS. Interviews depend 25% on these core subjects and can determine majorly whether or not you fare well in the interview. The next mistake would be how people are helplessly over-confident for the HR rounds, considering it to be a piece of cake. However, they miss out on knowing details about the company they are applying for and that might as well turn the tables for them. Ence, students must be aware about the company, their policies, work culture etc.

Further, for a non-tech company, your attitude and personality matters a lot. Therefore, those applying for non-tech roles should keep this in mind.

Do previously cleared backs impact a person’s chance of getting placed?

We do not share the data for any previous backlogs. Only data pertaining to the current backlogs is shared. So, there won’t arise any hindrance due to previously cleared backlogs.

Do the achievements from school hold any relevance in a person’s resume for internship or placement?

You are required to  mention college achievements, of course. However, if you don’t haven't had any in college, it’s better to mention the school achievements, than leaving the section blank. The personality development on the other hand, comes in handy, whether developed in school or college.

Also, when it comes to interviews, your communication skills matter a lot. Most of the student at the university lack such skills. Hence, they lag back in the GD rounds and interviews.

Also, if you don’t happen to have any college achievements, you can mention the events you had participated in.

The current economic down turn has had an impact on the company recruitments. So how are the Placement Coordinators dealing with this scenario in order to maximise the benefit for DTU Students? What would be your recommendations to students to endure this downturn.

We understand that the market conditions are not good. But even this year, we have achieved placement stats are the previous years. If I were to advise students about this scenario, my sole word of advice would be that students should apply off-campus as well. Also, upon deliberations with seniors, I have brought to my attention that Q3 might be a determining point and companies might begin to recruit like before after this point. This placement season, as recession was almost on board to hit us, we asked the companies to offer more profiles for DTU Students. Like Google came for 2 profiles and Microsoft offered 3 to 4 profiles. DTU is trying its best to call new companies. Further, students must be clear which profile they want to go for in the FTE. There are enough opportunities in the university to cater to every profile and interest. One should single-mindedly move in one direction. We are trying our best to ensure all the students seeking placements get one. We still have companies coming for the previous batches.

You must interact with a lot of students regarding the internship and placements. So what do you think students have the most queries about?

DTU students are more focused when the internship or placement season starts. They are focussed on what to put on their resume.The most asked question is that if the student is in the middle of a project can he mention it in the resume. Further, students are concerned about the percentage and CGPA Criteria for the internship and placement. We are planning to hold a meet for this purpose.

How damaging are the active backlogs to a student’s reputation and personality?

Many companies have criteria for the internship. Some companies do allow students with active backlogs to sit for interviews.

How being a placement coordinator helped you develop the personality that you possess currently?

It gives us confidence to communicate with HRs and students. You have to communicate the HRs message to the students in a simple language. We do understand what topic of discussion interests both the parties. Through the pre-described process, one does develop confidence. Furthermore, being a placement coordinator, we are exposed to innumerable queries of the students and HRs and we learn about the view points and perspectives. It builds confidence in our personality and develops our personality wholly. Further, you learn how to tackle problems in a corporate world and gain experience for that.

title: Edition 60| Interview- Ms. Laghima Tiwari, AIR 19, UPSC Civil Services Examination 2022
biliner:
“In the end, even if my result had not been favourable, I still would have had the satisfaction that the decision was mine and it had not been imposed by someone else over me.”

DTU Times interviewed Ms. Laghima Tiwari, AIR 19, UPSC Civil Services Examination 2022. Read on as she elucidates her inspiring rise to success and the importance of working undeterred towards one’s goal.
body:
“In the end, even if my result had not been favourable, I still would have had the satisfaction that the decision was mine and it had not been imposed by someone else over me.”

DTU Times interviewed Ms. Laghima Tiwari, AIR 19, UPSC Civil Services Examination 2022. Read on as she elucidates her inspiring rise to success and the importance of working undeterred towards one’s goal.

How has your life changed since securing AIR 19 in UPSC CSE 2022?  

My life has changed a lot, majorly for good. There are new and exciting things coming. It’s a huge achievement and we don’t realise it ourselves but when we meet others especially people from rural backgrounds, they consider it a significant achievement. So, life has changed, and more people are talking about me, wanting guidance from me, and interested in knowing my strategy. The most important part is I’m looking forward to the exciting phase of upcoming training and the job part because it will be exciting to work and will be a journey full of learning.

Since it was your first attempt, are you excited or nervous about how your work life would be?

As you said rightly it was my first attempt but I was not nervous because the training program is the same irrespective of whether you have prior experience in some other field or not. So, in those terms, it is a level playing field and I’ll have more excitement than nervousness which will only be around 5-10 %.

As a successful UPSC aspirant, what according to you is the ideal time to start preparation? Did you feel at any time in your preparation that you should have perhaps begun studying earlier?

I already knew from the beginning what I wanted to do and when to start my preparation when I finish college. I took a drop year which was a very conscious decision on my part. I also had a placement opportunity but I turned it down. The reason was that my branch was ECE and my aggregate CGPA was 9.14. ECE in itself is a challenging and demanding branch. So, for the four years of college, I dedicated my time to my subjects without any compromises. The second reason would be that I was part of Enactus DTU, an active society at that time. I was also thinking, what if I don’t clear the exam even after sacrificing years of college preparing for this exam? There would be no fun part. So, I was very clear that if someone feels the need to start preparation during college in my opinion they can start in the 4th year to research about UPSC, their optional subject, and strategy but not before that because they will be having an ample amount of time and will eventually lose focus.

Did you feel that your participation in society helped you while preparing for the written examination and interview?

I was part of Enactus DTU which provided a lot of exposure at that time. It helped in networking across with juniors and seniors and gave exposure in terms of working on the field and interacting with people from different areas like administration and corporate. So, it was a very all-rounded exposure for a student who has just come out of school and in that way, it did help me.

Which subject would you say turned out to be the decisive factor in your rise to success? How has it helped you grow as an individual?

Based on my mark sheet, I have very good marks in Anthropology, even in my GS subjects and also my interview score is decent. If I have to talk about one then surely it would be my optional subject, Anthropology. It has imbibed a sense of tolerance, and understanding towards the different cultures and societies of India because you get to study a lot of tribes and cultures of different societies. So, we naturally get tolerant towards them while getting to know why a particular state & their people are following a particular tradition and we try to think about it more scientifically. So, it has made me a more tolerant person.

How did your college life in DTU influence your decision to give UPSC? Would you have preferred to be an Arts student, since your course would have had some topics similar to your syllabus for UPSC, or was the DTU environment comfortable for you and was the competitive nature of students even helpful in a way to aid your preparation?

It might seem to some that the syllabus is arts-heavy but in my opinion the syllabus of UPSC CSE has a  very level playing field for all the people coming from all the branches and even some people complain that engineers tend to do well in UPSC. CSAT exam has a lot of maths-oriented questions but all the allegations rather I would say assumptions do not hold much ground. As all the aspirants come from different streams be it science, arts or even commerce and have to study the same material. So, there are no biases. As an engineering student from DTU one can get a lot of advantages from the distinguished set of alumni who have cleared the UPSC CSE with such good ranks in the past. So, people took inspiration from them and it’s moving to see that people from the same environment, lived in the same conditions as you and studied the same courses are doing it. Being an aspirant you get motivated by it. It is easier to reach out to people for example there have been previous toppers who have secured rank in the top 6, top 3 and it is motivating and there are no biases towards any branch in DTU 

There is one competitive exam that you and every other student in DTU or any other engineering college have in common, which is JEE. Did your JEE preparation at all resemble your preparation for UPSC? What did you find different about UPSC as compared to JEE? 

JEE and UPSC CSE are 2 different exams and the demands of these 2 exams are also very different. In JEE you just have a test of your intellect in terms of mathematical aptitude. You have your objective papers in JEE but in UPSC CSE there are 3 rounds that are objective (prelims), subjective (mains)  and interview. So, UPSC analyzes your overall personality, not just your intellectual aptitude but also your moral and social aptitude as well. So, that's a significant difference and even preparation for these two exams is very different, the syllabus is different, that is one thing and you have to cater to the demands of these exams. In UPSC, you have to write subjective answers which is a slight difference too but one thing among both the exams is how smart and hard-working, determined and disciplined you are. These are the qualities that will definitely be going to help you in whatever state of life you are.

It was a sizable risk- rejecting the safety of an on-campus placement and preparing for what is arguably the toughest exam in India. Was your family supportive of this decision and more importantly were you at peace with yourself with such a commitment? If yes, how did you manage to convince yourself to take that risk? 

I took my placement offer just because my family wanted me to and my family was very supportive so I consider myself privileged in this regard not everyone is privileged to turn down the on-campus placement opportunity. My family was supportive of my decision. Also, I was able to convince them that I needed a full cycle without any distractions and I was at peace with myself because ultimately it was the decision of my choice. All over the 2 years that passed, I graduated in 2021 and the result came in 2023. So, in these 2 years, I was very content and satisfied because I was doing what I wanted to do. Since I have taken this decision, I was putting in extra hours because it was a conscious decision on my part but in the end even if my result would not come. I would have the satisfaction that the decision was mine and it was not imposed by someone else either from my family or my friends over me. So, I would suggest if you are taking any decision in life whether it is related to UPSC or related to your career. It is important to listen to people around you because you can always learn from their experience but ultimately you have to make your own choice. Once you make the choice stick to it for that duration you have thought for and even if the result doesn’t come at least you’ll have a sense of self-satisfaction of giving your 100%. As I said, even if my result would not have come positive. I would have thought of some other plan either joining the corporate or giving some other exam. So, I think that it is important you have clarity of mind and know what you are doing because if you have that you’ll easily convince others too.

In our daily lives, especially in Indian culture, many family and friends raise questions regarding our decisions in life. How did you deal with those questions?

Fortunately, my family and friend circle are very good. My friends were very supportive from the start, they were confident in me and gave me constant motivation. If your close family is supporting you, then you should ignore the other voices because people will always talk. So, it’s not important to listen to every voice. You don’t have to convince everyone else. But you also have to be a little ignorant in this aspect too, like how the saying goes ‘ignorance is bliss’. Sometimes people’s comments may come true after 2 years but what are you losing? But at least 20 years down the line I would not have the regret of not taking that decision. Being practical and having a backup plan is also necessary.

The interview stage is one where many candidates are heartbroken after coming tantalizingly close, but just missing out on their goal. About a few months before today’s interview, you gave the interview of your life; tell us a bit about how you prepared for that and what the experience of giving that interview was like.   

The marks distribution in UPSC is such that although the interview is a very important stage, it holds just 270 marks and a major chunk of 1750 marks is the mains marks which is the subjective test. In the interview, the questions revolve mainly around two areas, which are the current happenings and events of national and international importance and the 2nd part is your personal background. The questions generally revolve around personal areas such as your hobbies, what you studied during school and college and so on. Preparing for the interview process is mainly just knowing yourself very well. You must be adequately confident about your answers because it’s a personality test rather than an interview. They don’t judge your aptitude, they judge your overall personality. Even if you don’t know an answer, what matters is how politely you can say that you don’t know the answer and how willing you are to learn. Overall, it’s a very fun stage and you get to know yourself. Enjoy that stage if you get to reach there, it’s a big achievement.

You chose not to opt for any coaching institute for your preparation; Did the lack of deadlines and the pressure of teachers bearing down on you make the process easier for you? Or would you have preferred a classroom-like environment, with fellow aspirants alongside you and the guidance of teachers to help you along? 

I did not opt for classroom coaching but I did take a test series and mock interviews. If I had to go back, I wouldn’t change my decision, I’m very happy with it. I have some acquaintances and friends who opted for coaching. There’s a stage when you’re very confused about opting for coaching or not. I ultimately decided not to but some of my friends decided to. Now when I talk to them, they all regret their decision, as the coaching they opted for either did not complete the syllabus or they did not gain much from it. They ultimately had to study it by themselves. Coaching can do wonders for many people, especially for those who need some external guidance or nudging. But if you can do that exercise on your own, it’s good for you. It can go either way depending on different people, their own strengths, and their weaknesses. It worked for me, but it might not work for others.

A lot of undergrads in DTU wish to go for UPSC, can you give a piece of advice to all the UPSC aspirants? 

While in college do not focus completely on your UPSC preparation, also focus on your personality development because these are the four years where your personality grooms and develops. Ultimately when you reach the interview stage your overall personality will also be judged in addition to your intellect and aptitude. Divide your time adequately. Don’t lose out on your academics, they are equally important. But if you want to start the preparation for UPSC, you should enter with a clear mind as to why you want to do it. It is very important to search for the answer to that because it is a very long journey. Even if you are expecting to clear the exam in your first attempt it will take at least two years as one year goes towards the preparation and the exam cycle is itself of one year. If you do not have an answer to that why you might continuously feel demotivated. Also, be very clear about which strategy you will be adopting. You will learn many things but having a clear strategy will ensure that you do not get distracted and diverted. Keep some flexibility also. Do repeated revision and lots of practice.

title: Edition 60 | Interview- Placement Coordinators। Batch of 2023
biliner:
"Being a placement coordinator, we are exposed to innumerable queries of the students and HRs and we learn about the viewpoints and perspectives. It builds confidence in our personality and develops our personality wholly. Further, you learn how to tackle problems in a corporate world and gain experience for that."
DTU Times interviewed Placement Coordinators for the batch of 2023, Delhi Technological University, Delhi. Read on as they share their highly inspirational and impactful journey and talk about how to blend technology and leadership together to bear the best results.
body:
"Being a Placement Coordinator, we are exposed to innumerable queries of the students and HRs and we learn about the viewpoints and perspectives. It builds confidence in our personality and develops our personality wholly. Further, you learn how to tackle problems in a corporate world and gain experience for that."

DTU Times interviewed Placement Coordinators for the Batch of 2023. Read on as they share their journey and talk about how to blend technology and leadership together to bear the best results.

As the cohort of Placement Coordinators who have witnessed the shift of online to offline mode in a very pronounced manner, has this adjustment influenced your approach to carrying out a PC's responsibilities? What are the advantages and disadvantages of each mode?

It was definitely easier managing a large group of students in the online mode, since in the offline mode we sometimes had to manage 400-500 students in the campus, which was obviously quite difficult. But, as we’ve seen many people use unfair means in online assessments, so that obviously caused many problems. Moreover, another huge problem we face in online mode is technical issues. Links of meetings not working, Faulty internet connections are just a few of many problems faced by students that we must manage. Other than that, there are of course advantages; for instance, it's easier to take presentations in online mode as we can include as many as 400 students in one meet; whereas in the presentation hall, it is only possible to have about 200 students at a time. So, we’d say that online mode had a lot of hassles in terms of technical issues and regardless of the advantages of online mode, we were glad to have everyone back on campus for offline placements.

Owing to the recent boom of technology and automation in every industry, placements in core branches and non-technical domains have become increasingly competitive. Do you think a technical prerequisite is necessary for the preparation of non-technical domains also?

Coding is an absolute necessity for non-tech students now. We’d say that a fairly decent amount of coding knowledge is required for a good tech placement; little knowledge or the basics would not be enough. And yes, with the technology boom, the roles for core branches are decreasing as they are slowly being transferred over to AI. So, we’re getting more and more tech-related roles in this day and age. In fact, non-tech students should look out for opportunities that enable the tech team to do non-tech work as well. So, the core branch students should learn the aspects of tech that are unique to their core branch as well so they can present a uniquely identifiable skillset.

How does the choice of electives affect one's placement? For example, does a minor in software engineering assist a student from a core branch to stand out from peers who do not have such a minor?

We’ve been in talks with the companies and the faculties about this, and we do keep a database of the students pursuing a minor in software or COE who are in core branches. So, in future, it might help the students as they are considered fit for a tech placement by companies. That being said, one should only choose a tech-related elective if one wishes to aim for a tech placement; if not, maintaining your GPA is equally crucial and the choice of an easier elective can give your GPA the boost it needs.

There is always a debate over interning in two ways: interning at a startup for more flexible learning or interning at an established organisation with predetermined corporate rules. What are your thoughts on this?

In a startup, there are more opportunities to learn about every position inside the organisation and you obtain a comprehensive understanding of how a firm truly operates. Understanding corporate behaviour is also very important, as you never know where you might end up post graduation; so understanding how both of these organisations work is crucial. Given the numerous layoffs and company failures, it is safe to assume that large corporations are a safer choice to startups. Therefore, for campus placements, we advise choosing either large MNCs or startups that have already achieved unicorn status.

Entrepreneurship has been gaining momentum steadily. How would you say startups are supposed to recruit their workforce when entrepreneurship is on such a steep rise?

Most startups in their early stages, hire students in off-campus placements. Such startups look for a very specific skill set, and as we’ve seen in our college, most candidates only have basic coding knowledge and know very little about development. So that is where the college students lack in terms of specialisation of their skills; so such startups tend to hire in off-campus placements. Whereas for entrepreneurship, DTU offers the students IIF where students are allowed to take extended breaks to develop their idea further. Given that the idea is not a fluke, and is unique in its terms. If you think your idea is unique and cannot be replicated by big MNCs easily, go for it.

Many students believe that, despite having a competitive profile on par with their peers, they have difficulty being shortlisted for an interview. Is there anything specific that employers look for on our CVs?

Companies tend to shortlist resumes in which they tend to look for GPA, sometimes 10th and 12th Board percentages, the projects you’ve worked on during your time at college and they also have an AI software that compares your resume to the job description offered by the company. So, students are advised to structure their CVs in such a manner that it aligns as best as it can with the company’s job description. 

What are the mistakes that students tend to make that endanger their chances of getting placed or getting an internship?

As for the mistakes that students tend to make, it is important to mention how students focus less on the core parts. For example, when people sit for tech placements or internships, they tend to ignore the core subjects like OOPs, OS and DBMS. Interviews depend 25% on these core subjects and can determine majorly whether or not you fare well in the interview. The next mistake would be how people are helplessly over-confident for the HR rounds, considering it to be a piece of cake. However, they miss out on knowing details about the company they are applying for and that might as well turn the tables for them. Ence, students must be aware about the company, their policies, work culture etc.

Further, for a non-tech company, your attitude and personality matters a lot. Therefore, those applying for non-tech roles should keep this in mind.

Do previously cleared backs impact a person’s chance of getting placed?

We do not share the data for any previous backlogs. Only data pertaining to the current backlogs is shared. So, there won’t arise any hindrance due to previously cleared backlogs.

Do the achievements from school hold any relevance in a person’s resume for internship or placement?

You are required to  mention college achievements, of course. However, if you don’t haven't had any in college, it’s better to mention the school achievements, than leaving the section blank. The personality development on the other hand, comes in handy, whether developed in school or college.

Also, when it comes to interviews, your communication skills matter a lot. Most of the student at the university lack such skills. Hence, they lag back in the GD rounds and interviews.

Also, if you don’t happen to have any college achievements, you can mention the events you had participated in.

The current economic down turn has had an impact on the company recruitments. So how are the Placement Coordinators dealing with this scenario in order to maximise the benefit for DTU Students? What would be your recommendations to students to endure this downturn.

We understand that the market conditions are not good. But even this year, we have achieved placement stats are the previous years. If I were to advise students about this scenario, my sole word of advice would be that students should apply off-campus as well. Also, upon deliberations with seniors, I have brought to my attention that Q3 might be a determining point and companies might begin to recruit like before after this point. This placement season, as recession was almost on board to hit us, we asked the companies to offer more profiles for DTU Students. Like Google came for 2 profiles and Microsoft offered 3 to 4 profiles. DTU is trying its best to call new companies. Further, students must be clear which profile they want to go for in the FTE. There are enough opportunities in the university to cater to every profile and interest. One should single-mindedly move in one direction. We are trying our best to ensure all the students seeking placements get one. We still have companies coming for the previous batches.

You must interact with a lot of students regarding the internship and placements. So what do you think students have the most queries about?

DTU students are more focused when the internship or placement season starts. They are focussed on what to put on their resume.The most asked question is that if the student is in the middle of a project can he mention it in the resume. Further, students are concerned about the percentage and CGPA Criteria for the internship and placement. We are planning to hold a meet for this purpose.

How damaging are the active backlogs to a student’s reputation and personality?

Many companies have criteria for the internship. Some companies do allow students with active backlogs to sit for interviews.

How being a placement coordinator helped you develop the personality that you possess currently?

It gives us confidence to communicate with HRs and students. You have to communicate the HRs message to the students in a simple language. We do understand what topic of discussion interests both the parties. Through the pre-described process, one does develop confidence. Furthermore, being a placement coordinator, we are exposed to innumerable queries of the students and HRs and we learn about the view points and perspectives. It builds confidence in our personality and develops our personality wholly. Further, you learn how to tackle problems in a corporate world and gain experience for that.

title: Edition 60 | A Day In The Life Of A Day Scholar
biliner:
The challenge of an hour-and-a-half commute back home lingers in the back of the mind, but is momentarily forgotten in the pleasant distraction of the lush college campus. Despite the lure of home-cooked food and a personal bed, the charm of college life urges one to linger. 

Read On as Yash Chaturvedi, a 2nd year MCE student describes what it’s like to be a day scholar in DTU and how it can be both challenging yet fulfilling to fight against all forces and come to the campus on a daily basis
body:
The challenge of an hour-and-a-half commute back home lingers in the back of the mind, but is momentarily forgotten in the pleasant distraction of the lush college campus. Despite the lure of home-cooked food and a personal bed, the charm of college life urges one to linger. 

Read On as Yash Chaturvedi, a 2nd year MCE student describes what it’s like to be a day scholar in DTU and how it can be both challenging yet fulfilling to fight against all forces and come to the campus on a daily basis

The daily routine of a college day scholar begins with the shock of leaving the cozy, dark comfort of one's room to face a bustling household bathed in sunlight. This transition to the chaos of the day never feels heroic, but rather a battle against societal and educational expectations. This battle continues in the oppressive summer heat that feels like a punishment, as one heads to the metro station for a 28-station journey to Samaypur Badli. 

The metro ride, although never empty, offers a moment of respite as it signifies conquering 30% of the looming day. Amidst the constant shuffle of passengers boarding and alighting, finding a seat becomes a victory against being pushed around. The journey is shared with fellow workers, students, and travellers, creating an atmosphere of familiarity and silent camaraderie. 

After enduring a sweltering e-rickshaw ride from the metro station to college, four hours of classes follow. Emerging into the Delhi air, brief exchanges with acquaintances occur before the routine moves to the open-air theatre (OAT) where students gather for refreshments and casual conversation. The challenge of an hour-and-a-half commute back home lingers in the back of the mind, but is momentarily forgotten in the pleasant distraction of the lush college campus. 

Despite the lure of home-cooked food and a personal bed, the charm of college life urges one to linger. As the day ends, students return to the metro, sharing stories about their day, creating a reservoir of infinite conversations. Each day, though tiring, has its unique happenings which make it interesting. Being a day scholar is challenging, but far from monotonous, painting vivid colours of adventure and growth into daily life.

Illustration by Ayan Khajuria, 2nd Year, MCE

title: Edition 60 | अभय उड़ान
biliner:
घर की यादों को पीछे छोड़ छात्रावास के वातावरण में स्थिर होने में विद्यार्थियों को काफी समय लग जाता है परन्तु चार साल पूरे होते-होते यह छात्रावास ही घर जैसा लगने लगता है और उसके निवासी एक परिवार जिसकी नींव विश्वास,भाइचारा और स्नेह होती है। 

पढ़िए इसी दिशा में राहुल देव, द्वितीय वर्ष, ई. ई. द्वारा लिखित एक लेख 'अभय उड़ान' जो अपने रचनात्मक विचारों से छात्रावास और कॉलेज के जीवन को प्रतिबिंबित करता है |
body:
घर की यादों को पीछे छोड़ छात्रावास के वातावरण में स्थिर होने में विद्यार्थियों को काफी समय लग जाता है परन्तु चार साल पूरे होते-होते यह छात्रावास ही घर जैसा लगने लगता है और उसके निवासी एक परिवार जिसकी नींव विश्वास,भाइचारा और स्नेह होती है।

पढ़िए इसी दिशा में राहुल देव, द्वितीय वर्ष, ई. ई. द्वारा लिखित एक लेख 'अभय उड़ान ' जो अपने रचनात्मक विचारों से छात्रावास और कॉलेज के जीवन को प्रतिबिंबित करता है |

एक प्रतिस्पर्धा मेरी उड़ान और असीमित आकाश के छोर में डूबते सूर्य की लालिमा के बीच है और दूसरी मेरे अंतर्मन की भावनाओं से  है। भावनाएँ जिन्होंने मुझे भीतर तक झकझोर कर यह सोचने पर विवश कर दिया कि चार साल बड़ा या चार पल ? यह कितना सरल प्रश्न है।

 सभी भावनाएँ, प्रश्नोत्तर और यह अंतर्मन की प्रतिस्पर्धा पेड़ की छाँव में शांत किन्तु व्याकुल व उदास खड़े हिरण को देखने के बाद शुरू हुई है। छात्रावास में पहला दिन होने के कारण हिरण भी व्याकुल एवं उदास था। उसे देख उन चार वर्षों की सभी यादें चार पलों के लिए मेरे समक्ष आ गईं। छात्रावास में रहने की ख़ुशी तो घर से दूर होने की उदासी भी थी। 

पेड़ की टहनी पर विश्राम करते हुए मेरा प्रथम मित्र जग्गू बन्दर बना था। वह चंचल और चतुर था । हम सभी हमेशा उसकी शरारतों की वजह से खुश रहते थे। जंबो, बघीरा, भालू, चींटी और जिराफ़ जैसे मेरे और भी दोस्त थें।  बघीरा की स्फूर्ति का कोई अंत नहीं था। भालू जितना आलसी और चींटी जैसा मेहनती कोई नहीं। चींटी देखने में तन से कमज़ोर लेकिन मनोबल में परिपूर्ण थी। जिराफ़ शांत जैसे की गहरा स्थिर पानी  हो। इन चार वर्षों में सिम्बा से मेरी घनिष्ठ मित्रता हो गई जो विवाद से शुरु हुई थी । सिम्बा गंभीर, साहसी और परिपक्व होने के साथ ही एक आदर्श अग्रणी की भांति सबका ख्याल रखता था।

 लड़कपन से परिपक्वता तक इन्हीं के साथ रहते हुए मैंने खुद को संवारा और जिन्दगी का तरीक़ा सीखा। परिसर में विभिन्न जगहों पर सबका एक साथ बैठ कर कभी हँसी- मजाक या द्वंद्व करना और कभी दौड़ लगाना। किसी के साथ कुछ बुरा होने पर परिवार की भांति हम एक जुट खड़े हो जाते थे। इनके सहयोग से ही मैंने खुद को पहचाना की मैं केवल एक गरुड़ ही नहीं बल्कि हदिति  हूँ। 

छात्रावास एक घर है और निवासी एक परिवार जिसकी नींव विश्वास,भाइचारा और स्नेह होती  है। जिस प्रकार मेरा परिवार बन गया था ठीक उसी प्रकार प्रकार उस हिरण का भी बन जाएगा इसी कामना के साथ संपूर्ण चार वर्षों को उन चार पलों में जीने के बाद चेहरे पर मुस्कान लिए मैं खिन्नता के भाव से बाहर आ गया और अपने अंतर्मन की प्रतिस्पर्धा को त्याग कर अस्त होते सूर्य की लालिमा और मेरी उड़ान वाली प्रतिस्पर्धा को जारी रखा…

Illustration by Saurabh Sharma, 4th Year, B.Des

title: Edition 60 | Identifying Ithaca
biliner:
"The enormity becomes less scary when you walk these halls with interlocked arms, or a sense of achievement when you are able to reach your classroom without asking anyone."

Read on as Siddarth Malik, 3rd Year, BT, describes how the overwhelming facets of university life gradually mold into a solitude that one ends up having an unexpected liking for.
body:
"The enormity becomes less scary when you walk these halls with interlocked arms, or a sense of achievement when you are able to reach your classroom without asking anyone." 

Read on as Siddarth Malik, 3rd Year, BT, describes how the overwhelming facets of university life gradually mold into a solitude that one ends up having an unexpected liking for.

There is more than one way to say this, but none that might convey this simple matter-of-fact thought  I had the first time I visited DTU. This place was soulless. Everything felt extreme — trying to convey the monstrosity of university life by the colossal sheerness of the buildings, by their lifeless limbs gouged into boxes with iron-framed windows, by the circularity of every road which always looked clean-licked, recently tarred but at the same time barricaded, making a mockery of our walking feet. It felt like I was an isolated cotton plug bouncing off the surface of an uncleaned ashtray. I felt something was amiss, like an essential organ, that due to a strange subconscious law, it must have, yet it lacked at its very core.

But that’s when you hear that one soft, gentle thud. You look to your side to the person next to you who has just banged his head against the desk, partly from boredom and partly from being confined to sitting for too long for a long lecture. And somehow, it’s not an intrusion, but a welcoming distraction. The view alters when no amount of concrete could ever possibly make you not pet a cat on the staircase or stop a burst of laughter. The enormity becomes less scary when you walk these halls with interlocked arms, or a sense of achievement when you are able to reach your classroom without asking anyone. The coin starts to fade. It gives way.

Looking back I think I was the one who misinterpreted the solitude of DTU as something empty and soulless. It was never soulless. Instead, it was unique how you can easily disassociate yourself, set boundaries, give as much as you want, when you want, and take as little as you like. There is a line between being isolated and being individualistic. And it took me some time to realize that whatever was happening, all this exhaustion and fear, was encouraging me to be an individual, to stand on my own two feet. The emptiness around me became rather a place of my own, to build my own path, to gather my own thoughts, and to live on my own terms.  And somewhere down the line, I began to like it.

title: Edition 60 | Shades of Hope and Apology
biliner:
“One day you’re sixteen, diligently solving your 100th daily sheet problem; H. C. Verma is both the bane and saviour of your existence and then in the blink of an eye, you’re eighteen, the protective cover of your JEE days long gone, opening to a realm of boundless possibilities.”
Read on as Charvi Solanki, 3rd Year, MCE and Dhruv Rahuja, 2nd Year, COE dive into the dilemmas faced by a fresher upon crossing the threshold of childhood and being faced with the emotional calamities of the real world.
body:
“One day you’re sixteen, diligently solving your 100th daily sheet problem; H. C. Verma is both the bane and saviour of your existence and then in the blink of an eye, you’re eighteen, the protective cover of your JEE days long gone, opening to a realm of boundless possibilities.”

Read on as Charvi Solanki, 3rd Year, MCE and Dhruv Rahuja, 2nd Year, COE dive into the dilemmas faced by a fresher upon crossing the threshold of childhood and being faced with the emotional calamities of the real world.

One day you’re sixteen, diligently solving your 100th daily sheet problem; H. C. Verma is both the bane and saviour of your existence and then in the blink of an eye, you’re eighteen, the protective cover of your JEE days long gone, opening to a realm of boundless possibilities. When I was about to get admitted into college, I had envisioned my life to become an idealistic version of its former self and formed many unrealistic expectations along the way—from myself and my college life. But it quickly turned into this:

You’re inspired and motivated for the life ahead, but wait, what did you ever do to deserve all of this, but you also deserve more, and why is the time passing by so quickly? I thought there was more to this, more to me. There used to be beauty in the mayhem of it all but now there’s just a lingering regret of your naivety, grief of what should’ve been but never was, of who you should’ve been but never were. One by one your expectations come crashing down. The test scores keep getting lower. Your peers keep moving higher. And no comments on your social life, please! You’re all grown up now but you agree with Jo from Little Women when she says "I can't believe childhood is over". The ghosts of your eleven, fifteen, or even seventeen-year-old self are nowhere to be found, while you try desperately to hold onto wisps of a time when ambition didn't have to be forced and hope was your next-door neighbour.

Slowly I've learned that instead of chasing the illusion of a picture-perfect college experience, there's so much beauty to be appreciated in the everyday moments, the ups and downs, and the valuable lessons learned along the way. College is not solely about attending classes and passing exams; it's a journey of personal growth and self-discovery. It’s not just about going from one deadline to another; it’s the impromptu 2 AM discussions that teach you more than your classes ever will, it’s the tacit understanding of having each other’s backs, it’s my friend sharing his tiffin with me because he knows how much I (and everyone) hate the mess food. It’s about the 100 mistakes you make but not letting them hold you back.

In Bollywood movies, we are frequently made to believe that college life is a paradise-like experience consisting of perfect friendships, stress-free exams, and fun found around every corner. While these portrayals make for entertaining cinema, they often fail to capture the real-life experiences of college students. There's heartbreak and loss, a never-ending confusion, bitterness, and jealousy that come with every lost opportunity. But there's also love and friendship to be found everywhere if you just look closely.

It's okay if you're not who you thought you'd be. Don't constrict yourself to a checkbox of personality traits. After all, there's more to life than trying to fit into a rigid mould.

title: Edition 60 | Soliloquy
biliner:
There’s a part of me which will never come back, I know it, I understand it but for some reason I  keep checking the night stand, my childhood closet, notebooks of days long gone - over and over again I search for it, deluding myself into deciding I actually need this part of me back, when all I need is the warm embrace of kindness and grace.

Join Navya Singh, 2nd Year, EE in the epiphany of realising that even when the weight of our own callous words grind us down, even when we scream a million silent confessions in our head, even amidst the echo of unmet expectations, there is still the tender art of being kind to ourselves.
body:
There’s a part of me which will never come back, I know it, I understand it but for some reason I  keep checking the night stand, my childhood closet, notebooks of days long gone - over and over again I search for it, deluding myself into deciding I actually need this part of me back, when all I need is the warm embrace of kindness and grace. 
 


Join Navya Singh, 2nd Year, EE in the epiphany of realising that even when the weight of our own callous words grind us down, even when we scream a million silent confessions in our head, even amidst the echo of unmet expectations, there is still the tender art of being kind to ourselves. 

 

“What are you doing?”

I turn to look at my own face, slightly haggard and naïve, wearing an expression of shock on her face.

“Copying some kind soul’s assignment” I answer flatly.

She stares at the datesheet of my upcoming midsems stuck on my table and  furrows her brows, “Don’t you have your exams in two weeks?”

“Yup”

“How many times have you completed your revision?” 

“Well, I’ll start studying once I know what the syllabus is”

Her eyes look like they might pop out of their sockets. “You don’t even know your syllabus yet? Do you even study anymore?” 

I frown at her disapproval, “Hey, just ‘cause you’re studying all day doesn’t make you more responsible than me; guess which one of us is actually in DTU?” I ask, wiggling my brows at her.

Multiple emotions pass over her face; shock, admiration, anger and… was that a hint of happiness?

“W-we did it?” 

“Yup, we did. Now shut up and let me copy this assignment”

She’s quiet for a while before she chirps up again, “What do you even do all day?”

I don’t really have an answer to that.

“You’ve got enough free time now to read all the books you wanted to read, clearly.” She says with a pointed expression towards my shameless copying of someone’s assignment, “Do you read?”

I try not to meet her eyes. The light that had lit her eyes when I told her of my college is slightly dimmed by my silence.

“What about painting? Surely you must paint. And our school friends? You guys still talk right?”

 I scramble to find words to soothe the disappointment starting to cloud her face but fail. Truth is I don't know why I’m unable to finally be kinder to myself after those two herculean years of preparing for JEE. All that effort did get me into the college I always wished for, but it inevitably took some irreplaceable pieces of my being from me.

I can’t tell her the truth of how big of a daedalian web human emotions can spin. I can’t tell her that the things she hopes getting into DTU will help her achieve are practically unattainable. What I can do, however, is promise to be nicer to myself.

title: Edition 60|Enjoy While You Are At It
biliner:
“From day 1, freshers get confused about whether to take the easiest FEC to score in or the one chosen by most of their friends. From selecting the right clothes for Engifest to finding the most appealing item on the canteen's menu, the list goes on and on.
”Embark on this insightful journey with Sameeksha, 2nd Year, MCE, as she unravels the tapestry of college dilemmas and the wisdom they bestow while guiding us to embrace our decisions.
body:
“From day 1, freshers get confused about whether to take the easiest FEC to score in or the one chosen by most of their friends. From selecting the right clothes for Engifest to finding the most appealing item on the canteen's menu, the list goes on and on.”

Embark on this insightful journey with Sameeksha, 2nd Year, MCE, as she unravels the tapestry of college dilemmas and the wisdom they bestow while guiding us to embrace our decisions.

On a quest to find the perfect show to binge but only to end up scrolling through the platform's library for hours? Well, it is rightly said that "Too much analysis can induce paralysis". Sometimes, being presented with too many choices may land us in such a dilemma that we end up doing nothing. 

Moreover, this ironic situation manifests even more dramatically in the lives of students with the newly adorned 'college freshers' tag. After spending a long time amidst inanimate books and rigorous coaching classes, getting bombarded with options at every step can overwhelm anyone. From day 1, freshers get confused about whether to take the easiest FEC to score in or the one chosen by most of their friends. From selecting the right clothes for Engifest to finding the most appealing item on the canteen's menu, the list goes on and on. 

So, hardly anyone can deny that the only ubiquitous situation experienced by everyone in college is choosing one option over multiple others. Is that a problem? Maybe not! Biting more than what you can chew is an inevitable and sometimes fun part of being in college. Instead of feeling swamped by possibilities, you should go for the one that makes the most sense (without landing you in trouble, of course) and make the most out of it. After all, no matter what you choose, the mere reminiscence of those days is exactly what's going to help you sail past the more gloomy ones. 

Hence, rather than worrying about the road not taken, enjoy the one you are traversing on!

title: एडिशन ६० | कॉलेज परिवेश
biliner:
प्रत्येक विद्यार्थी के लिए कॉलेज में प्रवेश के उपरान्त उसके परिवेश को समझना अत्यंत ही आवश्यक हो जाता है। कॉलेज हम सभी को स्वतंत्रता, संतुलित दृष्टिकोण, जागरूकता, सामाजिक कौशल एवं व्यक्तिगत विकास के अनगिनत अवसर प्रदान करता है। साथ ही यह आत्मा-अनुशासन एवं सशक्त मनोबल की मांग भी करता है। 

इसी नए परिवेश से खुद को अवगत कराने के लिए पढ़िए आद्यन्त, तृतीय संज्ञार्थ, बी• डिज़ाइन• द्वारा लिखित एक संक्षिप्त लेख ‘कॉलेज परिवेश’।
body:
प्रत्येक विद्यार्थी के लिए कॉलेज में प्रवेश के उपरान्त उसके परिवेश को समझना अत्यंत ही आवश्यक हो जाता है। कॉलेज हम सभी को स्वतंत्रता, संतुलित दृष्टिकोण, जागरूकता, सामाजिक कौशल एवं व्यक्तिगत विकास के अनगिनत अवसर प्रदान करता है। साथ ही यह आत्मा-अनुशासन एवं सशक्त मनोबल की मांग भी करता है। 

इसी नए परिवेश से खुद को अवगत कराने के लिए पढ़िए आद्यन्त, तृतीय संज्ञार्थ, बी• डिज़ाइन• द्वारा लिखित एक संक्षिप्त लेख ‘कॉलेज परिवेश’।

विश्वविद्यालय के जीवन की गति अक्सर स्वतंत्रता, आत्म-अन्वेषण और असीम अवसरों से बढ़ती है। विश्वविद्यालय का जीवन अनुकूल और प्रतिकूल पहलुओं पर प्रकाश डालना एवं एक संतुलित दृष्टिकोण प्रदान करने के साथ-साथ छात्रों को जागरूकता एवं तैयारी के साथ अपनी यात्रा को गति प्रदान करने में मदद कर सकता है। विश्वविद्यालय एक ऐसा वातावरण प्रदान करता है जहाँ छात्र अपनी स्वतंत्रता का विकास कर सकते हैं और अपने जीवन का प्रभार ले सकते हैं। यह रुचि के विषयों में गहराई तक जाने, नए विषयों का पता लगाने और भावुक प्रोफेसरों एवं सहपाठियों के साथ जुड़ने का अवसर प्रस्तुत करता है। इस विविध समुदाय के साथ जुड़ना किसी के विश्वदृष्टि को व्यापक बना सकता है। सामाजिक कौशल को बढ़ा सकता है एवं पेशेवर संपर्क स्थापित कर सकता है। कॉलेज पिछले शैक्षिक चरणों की तुलना में उच्च स्तर की अकादमिक कठोरता और आत्म-अनुशासन की मांग करता है। यदि प्रभावी ढंग से प्रबंधित नहीं किया जाए तो कोर्सवर्क, परीक्षा और असाइनमेंट को संतुलित करने से तनाव, चिंता एवं बर्नआउट हो सकता है। कॉलेज शिक्षा अक्सर महत्वपूर्ण वित्तीय दायित्वों के साथ आती है। कॉलेज फीस, छात्रावास, पाठ्यपुस्तकें और अन्य खर्च छात्रों के बजट को प्रभावित कर सकते हैं। इन मांगों के बीच संतुलन का भारी पड़ सकना साधारण है।

जब हम स्वयं को दूसरों से प्रतिभा और कौशल के आधार पर आँकते हैं तो स्वयं को सूक्ष्म और नाकारा मान लेते हैं। कठिन कार्य को भी आत्म-विश्वास के बल पर ही सरल बनाया जा सकता है चाहे वह सफलता की ऊँची छलांग हो, अतीत पर अफ़सोस या भविष्य की चिंता किए बिना वर्तमान में खुलकर जीने की बात हो। अनेकों महापुरुषों ने भी इसी बात पर ज़ोर दिया है। अतः  

“अपने कॉलेज के दिनों का भरपूर आनंद उठाइए और वो सब कीजिए जो आप तैयारी के दबाव में अब तक नहीं कर पाए थे । आप सभी एक अंतर्निहित सितारे की भांति हैं जो भले ही बादलों की चादर में गुम हो पर मौजूद हरदम है।”

इसी दिशा में अमन, तृतीय वर्ष, एम. सी. ई. द्वारा लिखित प्रेरित करने वाले इस लेख ‘अंतर्निहित सितारा’ को पढ़िए।

'अहम् ब्रह्मास्मि' - स्वामी विवेकानन्द प्रायः उपनिषद् के इस मंत्र का उल्लेख किया करते थे। वे कहते थे कि "प्रत्येक व्यक्ति ईश्वर का ही प्रकटीकरण है।" या यूँ कहें कि वह स्वयं ईश्वर है। हर एक में अनंत सम्भावनाएँ छुपी हुई हैं। कॉलेज में यह अत्यंत आवश्यक हो जाता है कि आप प्रतिदिन अपने इस वास्तविक स्वरूप का स्मरण करें। आप कॉलेज में कई तरह के लोगों से मिलेंगे। संभव है कि आप इन सभी भिन्न प्रतिभाओं के बीच स्वयं को सूक्ष्म और नाकारा मानने लगे। क्या आपने गोताखोरों को देखा है? जब वे पानी में ऊँचाई से छलांग लगाते हैं तो अपने आत्म-विश्वास के बलबूते पर लगाते हैं न कि इस उम्मीद से की नीचे कोई उन्हें थाम लेगा। कठिन पथ प्रशस्त करने हेतु खुद पर विश्वास बनाए रखना बहुत अनिवार्य है।

कुछ लोग सदैव ही अपनी सफलता के बजाय अपनी विफलता पर रोते रहते हैं। मैंने कैंपस में आई•आई•टी में एडमिशन न पा पाने के कारणवश बहुत से लोगों को अपने पुराने दिनों की गलतियों पर अफ़सोस करते और अपने वर्तमान को नकारते देखा है। प्रायः ऐसा होता है कि लोग या तो अतीत में उलझे रहते हैं या फिर भविष्य के सपनों में, आशंकाओं में डूबे रहते हैं। वे वर्तमान में जीना ही भूल जाते हैं। यहाँ मुझे महान खिलाड़ी सचिन तेंदुलकर द्वारा कही गई बात याद आती है कि "जब आप क्रिकेट खिलते हैं, तब क्या आप उस गेंद के बारे में सोचते हैं, जिसे आप पहले खेल चुके हैं या उस गेंद के बारे में सोचते हैं, जो आप आगे खेलेंगे? उस समय आप सिर्फ उसी गेंद पर ध्यान केंद्रित करते हैं, जो उस समय आने वाली है। अगर आप पिछली गेंद या अगली गेंद के बारे में सोचते रहेंगे तो उस गेंद का सामना कैसे करेंगे जो अब आपके सामने फेंकी गई है।"

आखिरी में बस इतना कहूँगा कि अपने कॉलेज के दिनों का भरपूर आनंद उठाइए और वो सब कीजिए जो आप तैयारी के दबाव में अब तक नहीं कर पाए थे। आप सभी एक अंतर्निहित सितारे की भांति हैं जो भले ही बादलों की चादर में गुम हो पर मौजूद हरदम है।

title: Edition 60 | The Emotional Rollercoaster
biliner:
"The moment I reached my college campus, a medley of emotions danced upon my quivering lips. Anxiety, anticipation, and a hint of bewildered excitement. My heart fluttered like a trapped bird"

Read on as Gurashima Kaur, 2nd year, B.Des., navigates the maze of freshman emotions and academic beginnings, while capturing the essence of camaraderie, uncertainty, and the grand adventure that awaits.
body:
"The moment I reached my college campus, a medley of emotions danced upon my quivering lips. Anxiety, anticipation, and a hint of bewildered excitement. My heart fluttered like a trapped bird"

Read on as Gurashima Kaur, 2nd year, B.Des., navigates the maze of freshman emotions and academic beginnings, while capturing the essence of camaraderie, uncertainty, and the grand adventure that awaits. 

As I opened my eyes and saw the bright sunlight streaming through my window, it hit me like a ton of bricks: I was no longer a school student. 

I peeled myself out of bed and found my mind in a state of frenzied chaos. I was darting between my thoughts of elation, apprehension, and a persistent need to check and recheck my course schedule. Will I be able to find my classes? Will I make friends or find myself languishing in a sea of socially inept students? The possibilities were endless, and not exactly comforting. These thoughts buzzed about my head like a swarm of bees, each competing for my attention and causing me to feel simultaneously giddy and overwhelmed.

As I got dressed, the true dilemma emerged: what on earth should I wear? I rummaged through my closet, trying on different combinations of clothes as if I was writing a computer code. I finally settled on a perfect ensemble. Clutching my backpack, I decided to venture out and conquer my fears.

The moment I reached my college campus, a medley of emotions danced upon my quivering lips. Anxiety, anticipation, and a hint of bewildered excitement. My heart fluttered like a trapped bird. I trudged towards the entrance gates, each step a precipice leading me further into the abyss of academia. My nerves played a frenetic symphony within me. 

I had a mental picture of myself wandering around campus, muttering "left, right, no, wait, left," like some kind of dyslexic marching band. But as I glanced around, I saw a sea of anxious faces. I couldn't help but feel a sense of camaraderie. The tumultuous swirl of emotions was drowned out by the sound of hundreds of other freshers, all experiencing the same flurry of emotions.

I stood there for a moment to wonder about today. This instant, I embark upon a journey, a rite of passage, one that would either shape me into an erudite scholar or leave me lost amidst a labyrinth of textbooks and bad canteen food. What grand spectacle awaited me in this academic extravaganza?

title: Edition 60 | The Ultimate Guide to Approach New People in University
biliner:
“Initiate the conversation by discussing shared experiences like attending an event or class. Ask for opinions or thoughts.”

Read on as Sara Sanwal, 3rd year, B. Des (@sarasanwal) capsulizes the hefty task of approaching new people in the university into a resourceful guide offering invaluable insights that might manifold a person’s social abilities.
body:
Meeting new people can be both exciting and nerve-wracking. Whether you're starting college or attending a social event, initiating conversations is a crucial step towards building connections. This blog post explores two effective strategies to strike up conversations with new acquaintances.

YOU MEET SOMEONE NEW

Strategy one: Induced Conversation

1. TAREEFAN:Initiate conversation by genuinely complimenting something you admire about the person. For example, if you notice a unique necklace, say, "Cool sneakers man! It has such a stylish vibe, Where did you find it?" This approach can be used for clothing, hairstyle, or any item.

2. CLASSES?:Initiate conversation by discussing shared experiences like attending an event or class. Ask for opinions or thoughts. For example, after a lecture, say, "Insightful talk, right? Speaker was unusual though." Observe their reaction to engage further, as it can spark a conversation.

3. SAME PINCH: Spot someone with similar interests or hobbies, and use it as a conversation starter. For example, if you see someone reading a book by your favorite author, approach them and say, "I love that author too! Have you read any other books by them?"

4. GC PAR ATMA KATHA: Share an interesting or funny story related to the topic to encourage others to share their own experiences and create a connection. For example, in a group discussion about traveling, share a funny travel mishap and add some humorous stickers/memes/gifs to make it even more engaging.

Strategy two: On Cue Conversation

1. YOU AND ME AND STEVE: If you have a mutual friend, ask them to introduce you to the person you want to approach. This can help break the ice and make the introduction more comfortable.

2. AAS PAAS DEKHO: Comment on the surroundings or a whimsical situation nearby. Make a humorous remark to a nearby person, saying, "Can you believe what we're seeing? Any thoughts on what's going on there?", create a light-hearted moment together.

3. IIT BAWANA KI AMENITIES: Engage in conversation about the current environment, like a café, park, or library. Ask for recommendations or opinions about the place. For example, if you're at nescafé/hpmc/micmac/canteen, ask people nearby about their favourite items on the menu or what they think the place serves best.

4. IMPROMPTU DILLI DARSHAN OFFER: If you're in a new city or town, discuss local attractions, restaurants, or landmarks. Ask for suggestions or share your own experiences.Especially if you are from outside of Delhi and exploring this new city. Approach a classmate from Delhi and say, "I'm new in town. Do you have any recommendations for the best places to eat around here? Any hidden gems?"

Illustration by Joshna Lohaan, 2nd Year, B.Des.

title: Edition 60 | If These Benches Could Talk
biliner:
An encounter on an ordinary bench at the OAT can lead to an extraordinary story thereafter. A boy in despair comes across his classmate and shares his melancholy about a messed up test. A short conversation was sufficient for something special to brew between the two. 

College is an infinite reservoir of such encounters which lead to some beautiful "how I met your mother" moments. It keeps collecting these memories and words and stores them in its Pandora’s Box. The OAT benches are an example of those boxes which keep holding onto the whispers and susurrations that it hears. 

Read on as Bilal Khan, 3rd Year, MCE and Dheeresh Chandra, 3rd Year, MCE talk about one such instance where they wished that the benches could talk.
body:
An encounter on an ordinary bench at the OAT can lead to an extraordinary story thereafter. A boy in despair comes across his classmate and shares his melancholy about a messed up test. A short conversation was sufficient for something special to brew between the two.

College is an infinite reservoir of such encounters which lead to some beautiful "how I met your mother" moments. It keeps collecting these memories and words and stores them in its Pandora’s Box. The OAT benches are an example of those boxes which keep holding onto the whispers and susurrations that it hears.

Read on as Bilal Khan, 3rd Year, MCE and Dheeresh Chandra, 3rd Year, MCE talk about one such instance where they wished that the benches could talk.

As the clock tower looked down on the shimmering fountain waters, he ran across the OAT, hurriedly climbing up the steep stairs of the mega structure towards a bench to wrap things up. Having two humongous assignments to submit before 3 o'clock, and the May sun to battle with, he could have kept from this peril if not for listening to just one more song. And yet he was, still humming this absolute rocker from Survivor, which was more relevant now than ever, ‘just a man and his will to survive’. Solving the 20 questions was beyond an option, as he copied the solutions, convincing himself that he would practise them later. 

Taking out time for looking around was not an option but as he scribbled with all his might, he realised that there were two sounds of pens scratching the papyrus. 

      This girl, of the same class as him, who would win over all with her grades was right there, facing the same trouble that plagued him. “Was she also listening to ‘Eye of the Tiger’ last night?”, he jokingly thought. They exchanged solutions before finally remembering to exchange pleasantries as well. “I’m so glad that you were here next to me or I’d have surely got a B”, he said. “It’s really mutual”, she said with a smile, “I wouldn’t have really got anything better.” He said, “Let me know how it went after you’re done; right here at this bench?” She gleefully nodded.

The enduring hour went by. He walked out of the room with cold feet, his sleep-deprived eyes barely staying open, and the song still playing in his head louder than ever. After a terrible viva, the little hope he had of securing a decent grade was gone. He got himself seated on the bench, as he had promised. He questioned him sitting there as she would have fared far better.

 He shook his head, gave a sigh of disappointment, and just as he was getting up, “Hey, how did it go?”, the beaming voice stopped him. He looked back, “It’d be good if I don’t talk about it.” She paused to realise what had transpired, and said, “Hmm, same here. It just could not have gone any worse”, as she lied, after having performed better than anyone could. “Perhaps blowing the steam off a coffee would help, don’t you think?”, she said with an endearing smile, as his eyes met hers...
