title: Edition 60 | The Ordered Mess
biliner:
कॉलेज के ये तीन-चार साल वह समय है जिसमें आप लापरवाह बचपन की अवधि से गुजरते हुए अधिक सुव्यवस्थित वयस्कता में प्रवेश करते हैं। इस समय के अन्तराल में गलतियाँ करना व उनसे सीखना ही हमारा मुख्य उद्देश्य होना चाहिए न कि हतोत्साहित होना और अपने आप को कमतर आंकना। अगर हम मौज-मस्ती करते हुए नई-नई चीजों को सिखने का आनंद उठाएँगे तो आगामी जीवन में अपने आप को और अधिक उत्साहित महसूस करेंगे। डीटीयू आपके जीवन के इस समय का आनंद लेने के लिए आपका हार्दिक स्वागत करता है।

Read on as Anshita Garg, 3rd Year, COE, and Daksh Khandelwal, 2nd Year, ECE, your seniors at college, tell you about how much you are going to love the ‘ordered mess’ at DTU.
body:
कॉलेज के ये तीन-चार साल वह समय है जिसमें आप लापरवाह बचपन की अवधि से गुजरते हुए अधिक सुव्यवस्थित वयस्कता में प्रवेश करते हैं। इस समय के अन्तराल में गलतियाँ करना व उनसे सीखना ही हमारा मुख्य उद्देश्य होना चाहिए न कि हतोत्साहित होना और अपने आप को कमतर आंकना। अगर हम मौज-मस्ती करते हुए नई-नई चीजों को सिखने का आनंद उठाएँगे तो आगामी जीवन में अपने आप को और अधिक उत्साहित महसूस करेंगे। डीटीयू आपके जीवन के इस समय का आनंद लेने के लिए आपका हार्दिक स्वागत करता है।

Read on as Anshita Garg, 3rd Year, COE, and Daksh Khandelwal, 2nd Year, ECE, your seniors at college, tell you about how much you are going to love the ‘ordered mess’ at DTU.

Life is what we make of it. On one of the most defining crossroads of your life, here you stand today; having budded from what you were, into what you desire to become. Innumerable paths and checkpoints are yet to come, better with every level. The crossroads you’re at, friends, is what they call ‘the golden days of college life’.

Sprouting out energetically from the shell of childhood, you feel liberated from all control and supervision. To a very large extent nevertheless, it is not now that you’d become the master of your destiny. There’s still a long way to go through the journey called life.

विद्यालय शिक्षा का समापन व कॉलेज जीवन में प्रवेश विधार्थी जीवन का काफी महत्तवपूर्ण परिवर्तन साबित होता है | जीवन के इस अन्तराल में विद्यार्थी अपने युवावस्था के उत्साह से परिपूर्ण है, परन्तु दूसरी ही तरफ उसका मन विचलित और असमंजस की स्थिति में है | रणभूमि में खड़े अर्जुन की भांति ही उसका मन भयभीत हैं | वह भूत-भविष्य की फ़िक्र व जीवन की अनिश्चितताओं से विचलित हैं | कॉलेज की शुरुआत में विद्यार्थी काफी सहमा हुआ होता है और अपने हर कार्य में त्रुटियों का भंडार लगाता जाता हैं | वह अभिमन्यु की भांति अपने आप को चक्रव्यूह में फंसा हुआ पाता हैं | जिसकी वजह से उसे कई बार परेशानियों का भी सामना करना पड़ता है परन्तु 

“करत-करत अभ्यास के जड़मति होत सुजान, रसरी आवत जात ते सिल पर परत निशान” 

कबीर जी की इन प्रस्तुत पंक्तियों को सिद्ध करते हुए और परिश्रम के साथ वह अपने पथ के प्रति और सजग होता चला जाता हैं | जिस तरह महाभारत में अर्जुन के मार्गदर्शन के लिए श्री कृष्ण उपलब्ध थे, उसी तरह कॉलेज में विद्यार्थी के पथ निर्माण में सीनियर्स, शिक्षकगण व मित्रों का खासा सहयोग रहता हैं | धीरे-धीरे समय के साथ विद्यार्थी के भीतर घबराहट कम होने लगती है और आत्मविश्वास बढ़ने लगता है जिसमें व्यक्तित्व विकास को प्रेरित करती ‘सोसाइटीस’ का भी खासा महत्त्व है |

You come to college to not only learn, but to satisfy your creative thirst. You’ve had been learning that all your school life, haven’t you? Now it's time to widen your horizon. The setting is brighter when you hop on the wagon called college societies and tread the path with like-minded people. Seniors, juniors, all alike. You’ve made it to here, it’s now time to cut yourself some slack, catch a break and enjoy with your interests and academics, all balanced out. And trust me, when you join one, you’re not gonna regret it.

The canvas of life you’re recklessly doodling on, now seeks to orient itself in a definite order; more diligently carved and precariously taken care of. As you steer clear through a period of reckless childhood to enter into a more ordered adulthood, DTU welcomes you to rejoice this time of your life, that they dearly refer to as the ‘ordered mess’. 

With things falling apart and some other falling right into place, you’ll learn how to put it all together. With pending assignments day in and day out and exams always around the corner, you’ll learn to get it done, with time. After all, you can trust when your seniors would say that you are gonna love the ‘ordered mess’ at DTU.

title: Foreign Admissions | University of Pennsylvania
biliner:
“Don't be afraid to be different. Don't be afraid that there are not a lot of people who are applying for a master's. Do what you love and love what you do. I think that's the way to do it. If you don't like what you are doing you are not in the right direction.”

DTU Times interviewed Shubhodeep Shiv Aditya, ME, Class of 2023, who received admits from University of Pennsylvania (School of Engineering and Applied Sciences) for MS. in Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics (Robotics Concentration) and Johns Hopkins University, Carnegie Mellon University and Northwestern University for MS in ME and will be joining the former.
body:
“Don't be afraid to be different. Don't be afraid that there are not a lot of people who are applying for a master's. Do what you love and love what you do. I think that's the way to do it. If you don't like what you are doing you are not in the right direction.”

DTU Times interviewed Shubhodeep Shiv Aditya, ME, Class of 2023, who received admits from University of Pennsylvania (School of Engineering and Applied Sciences) for MS. in Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics (Robotics Concentration) and Johns Hopkins University, Carnegie Mellon University and Northwestern University for MS in ME and will be joining the former. 

What is going to be your field of study and the prospects that follow?

I am going for a Masters in Science and Engineering in Mechanical and applied mechanics. I have applied for the robotics concentration so the focus will be on robotics and electronic applications. As far as applications and the prospects go, robotics is one of the most upcoming branches in engineering. After a master’s, you can either go for Ph.D. or apply for a job after a bachelor's. There are not a lot of jobs in robotics if you compare it with software development, however, after masters, there are a lot of opportunities that open up. In the future, I plan to go for a job after my master's but I have not completely decided on this.

Most engineering students incline toward the software domain. What was your motivation for going on the less typical path?

I was not greatly interested in computer science. I am usually inclined towards the mechanical side of robotics. So applied mechanics is the field that interested me the most but of course, in today's world, you can't ignore computer applications because robotics also needs technology. Even before entering college it was clear to me that I don't want to go into software. I am not the kind of person who could sit and work on a coding problem for too long. I was very interested in aviation and stuff so that's how I joined UAS in my first year. From there I got a keen interest in drones and gradually towards robotics in general. Mechanical engineering was my first priority at the time of counselling, which people usually don't take up nowadays. So it was mainly out of interest and I think that's how it should be. I know that the software domain has a lot of money. My friends are making a good amount whereas I will be spending more than them here but I will be doing something I like to do, something that I am actually interested in. Even if I would have gone for SDE I wouldn't have liked it much because it is not my thing and never has been.

In your opinion, do Indian universities fail to provide the same kind of research facilities and career opportunities as compared to foreign universities for higher studies?

Yes to a very large extent. We are behind the US at this point in time, and education in India is too focused on the theoretical aspect. All of us pursuing B.Tech here are only studying to get good marks without any understanding of the practical applications of it. I personally don't have an idea about 50% of my subjects in mechanical engineering and I think that's true for a large number of people, not just in DTU but almost in all colleges because our education system is backward. Research takes a lot of money. Our colleges are trying to promote research and specifically DTU. A lot of projects in science and technology are coming in. We're moving in the right direction but the progress is slow. I think with time Indian universities will catch up. We need to move away from this rote learning mode although there is no comparison at this moment.

What were your biggest learnings in your journey so far from the mistakes you made? 

The biggest learning is whatever you want to do, start early. Explore what you want to do and try to grasp one of the things you like as early as possible. The earlier you start the more time you will have to build upon. Don't be afraid to be different. Don't be afraid that there are not a lot of people who are applying for a master's. Do what you love and love what you do. I think that's the way to do it. If you don't like what you are doing you are not in the right direction.

What advice would you give to the students of core branches who feel there is a lack of opportunities for them because of their branch?

One of the reasons why I am going for a master's is because you don't get opportunities immediately for a job in robotics. If I had the option for a job and then go for a master's degree that would have been much better. When there are fewer opportunities, there is always a way around. Going for a master's is one of them. I don't expect SDE to be such a big thing in 10 years. Things keep changing. I think if there is an overlap in the requirement and your interest, identify it and go forward.

Tell us about your admission procedure. How was the support from the college professors?

The application procedure starts sometime around September-October and the deadlines are from November to the end of January. All colleges have different application procedures so that's a tedious process. In the application, they mostly ask for a statement of purpose about what all you have done in that field, why you want to go for it, what all work you have done, your research work, and basically a summary of why you want to go for that course. Apart from that there are letters of recommendation from professors, which are very important. That's a very opaque process and not very transparent. One mistake that people tend to make is that they start very late. I have juniors in 3rd year asking me how to start now. If you are starting  late you won't be able to do justice to the work that you are doing. You have to give it time, it's not immediate. That being said, if you  work hard you can do it somehow. It always depends on the individual.

In my process, college professors were very helpful. The Faculty Advisor, Raghav Sir, ECE Department, Indu Ma’am, my B.Tech project supervisor, Mr. Atul Agarwal, Mechanical Department have been there throughout. They were very helpful and supportive. They gave me my LORs. I would say that if you continue to work under your professors for 6 months or a year or two, you build a relationship with them. If you diligently work, they identify your worth. You need to make them understand what your goals are and how they can help you. Go out as early as possible. If you ask a professor 2 months before your application for a LOR, there are very few  chances for you to receive it. 

How did the initial interest in aerospace develop?

I was very interested in aircraft and aviation from school time. Robotics was a lot later. It's very funny to think that like a child I still look up and try to identify which aircraft it is; that child in me is still there. My interest in robotics arose in college when I joined UAS. I shifted from aircraft to robots in general so that was a transition over the two three years. I had initially planned to go into aerospace but the scope in that industry has recently become less as it is  mainly focused on defence applications. Being an Indian I can't work in the US in defence applications. It’s very difficult to get into that segment but robotics is rightly the more generalised field so that has a broader scope.

title: Foreign Admissions | University of Padova
biliner:
“It is the mysteries of the electromagnetic spectrum that interest me. They are pretty intriguing to me, how they interact and what are the dynamics between them.  I knew I wanted to do research and for that, I tried multiple domains, physics, material sciences, plasma physics as well as astrophysics. This is what stuck and this is what I decided to pursue.”


 DTU Times interviewed Mr. Anish Kalsi, Aspiring Astrophysicist who has been  accepted for MS in Astrophysics and Cosmology at University of Padova, Italy.
body:
“It is the mysteries of the electromagnetic spectrum that interest me. They are pretty intriguing to me, how they interact and what are the dynamics between them.  I knew I wanted to do research and for that, I tried multiple domains, physics, material sciences, plasma physics as well as astrophysics. This is what stuck and this is what I decided to pursue.”

 DTU Times interviewed Mr. Anish Kalsi, Aspiring Astrophysicist who has been  accepted for MS in Astrophysics and Cosmology at University of Padova, Italy.

What sparked your interest in astrophysics and cosmology?

I don’t think I can answer it in a way that is not cliche. Everyone starts with I loved space sciences from my childhood and I am one of those people. What I feel is different for me is this is what I want to do. I have tried everything else. I knew I wanted to do research and for that, I tried multiple domains, physics, material sciences, plasma physics as well as astrophysics. This is what stuck and this is what I decided to pursue.

Can you walk us through your application process including any challenges that you may have faced and how you overcame them?

It is always challenging to apply abroad. I got admission to a university in Italy but that wasn’t Plan A. Plan A was to get a direct Ph.D. from a country like the USA or Canada but I couldn’t ace that. Plan B was to go to Germany, but Germany started taking extra certificates like APS which is mandatory for the visa, and the application which takes about four to five months and you can’t apply for it unless you’ve got your degree and on those terms I didn’t have my degree yet, I just graduated. Italy was Plan C. So I applied there and I got my acceptance letter within a week of it. The biggest challenges are, I would say, the LORs. Anywhere you apply you would need a letter of recommendation from your professors and your supervisors. Writing the statement of purpose is also tedious work, you have to start writing it months before you actually apply. Then of course you have to give various exams like GRE, IELTS depending on the course you’re applying to and where. 

Walk us through how your childhood interests helped you develop a liking for astrophysics.

I was an average student with teachers always suggesting that I can do better at every parent-teacher meeting! But if you want me to specify, I always had an interest in math and science. Regarding astrophysics, I relished the field and everything it had to offer. So, I have a bit of a curious mind. I need to know how and why everything that happens, happens. This is something that you cannot just know. It’s based on curiosity only and space sciences offers you a lot. You cannot just go there and ask and expect to get direct answers. I think this is why I’ve been a little here and a little there because I need answers and there are none.  

What are some of your personal and professional goals you wish to achieve during the tenure of your Master's degree?

It's just for two years so I don't think I'll get enough time to devote to other things. For now, I have planned out to have a couple of research papers and get a good research experience along with connectivity of course. People talk a lot about it in the research field only because you need connections to go further from where you are. 

Talking about research, what specific interests do you wish to explore in astrophysics?

I am particularly in astrophysics and astronomy and that too observational, modeling, and inferring information. I have worked on gamma-ray bursts. Right now I am working on X-ray binaries and fast radio bursts. These are some of the mysteries of the electromagnetic spectrum. Beyond this, I want to work on satellite galaxies. They are pretty intriguing to me, how they interact and what are the dynamics between them. So this is something that I want to explore, in my master's or if I get a chance, in my Ph.D. 

 Which internship would you say has been the most fruitful and fulfilling research experience for you?

There are some local conferences that I did in my first year. It comprised of a theoretical portion, modeling etc. So, that was pretty satisfying. Currently, I am inclined towards simulation work; you need to visualize stuff to yield results and draw inferences. Everything is what I’ve always wanted to do. Mini projects like the one at IIT Bombay offered a pretty good exposure.

Walk us through how your interest in astronomy has helped in your personality development.

“Asking an engineer how to develop a good personality is pretty ironic. I have a personality of a potato.”

I got interviews in summer school in Nainital. There, I met 40 other people with l with same interests and goals and yet very different. This experience added way more to my personality than any other experience that I have had so far. Other international interns also belong in the same league.

With your internship at APC Lab how would you say you manage time between academics and the internship?

I would just say that it just takes time to become familiar with something new. After that, everything seems to fall in its right place.

How do you plan to adapt to life abroad?

There do exist cultural experiences,  Language will be a barrier but, most of the people that I would be communicating with will most probably be Indians and would know English.  Further, as I said it takes time to adapt to any change and I am pretty sure I would adapt to any such change with time.

title: Foreign Admissions | Stanford University
biliner:
“Your application should tell a compelling story that showcases your motivations and aspirations. In my personal statement, I emphasized the unique challenges faced by women in STEM, particularly in a lower-ranked branch.”
DTU Times interviewed Shambavi Rathore, ENE, Class of 2023, who received acceptances from Stanford University and Texas A&M University for MS. in Environmental Engineering; Carnegie Mellon University, UC Berkeley and University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign for MS. in Civil and Environmental Engineering; University of Michigan for Master’s in Environment and Sustainability and University of Toronto, Wageningen University & Research for Master’s of Environment Science.
body:
“Your application should tell a compelling story that showcases your motivations and aspirations. In my personal statement, I emphasized the unique challenges faced by women in STEM, particularly in a lower-ranked branch.”

DTU Times interviewed Shambavi Rathore, ENE, Class of 2023, who received acceptances from Stanford University and Texas A&M University for MS. in Environmental Engineering; Carnegie Mellon University, UC Berkeley and University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign for MS. in Civil and Environmental Engineering; University of Michigan for Master’s in Environment and Sustainability and University of Toronto, Wageningen University & Research for Master’s of Environment Science.

Looking back on your college years, what do you believe were some of the decisions, specific resources or strategies  you made that led you to where you are now? 

To be completely honest, pursuing a master's degree wasn't initially on my radar when I joined DTU. I was unsure and lacked a concrete plan. My initial inclination was towards pursuing an MBA, as that seemed to be the common path for engineering graduates. I hadn't considered the field of environmental sustainability as a potential career choice. However, during the COVID-19 pandemic, I found myself with a surplus of time in my second semester. This gave me an opportunity to explore different subjects and gain clarity. It was during this time that I enrolled in a sustainability course offered by the University of Illinois on Coursera. The experience was transformative, and I became engrossed in the subject matter. Consequently, I found myself subscribing to numerous courses, journals, and actively seeking to expand my knowledge in this field. By a stroke of luck, everything fell into place, and I discovered my passion. It was a turning point that led me to actively pursue internships and delve deeper into the subject. 

What advice would you give to the students of your branch who feel there is a lack of opportunities for them because of their branch? And how to choose between programs in environmental engineering which have a lot of options?

Throughout the four years of my study here, I happened to encounter countless instances where I had to explain my branch choice to people. There seems to be a prevailing perception that I settled for this field because I hadn’t secured a good rank and simply wanted to secure admission at DTU. However, the truth is that this perception is largely based on people's lack of awareness about the immense potential and opportunities that my branch offers. It is disheartening to see that many individuals choose not to make an effort to understand this field. In terms of opportunities, this field is the need of the hour and experiencing rapid growth. It is essential for every sector to consider the environment and adopt sustainable practices to ensure their continued functioning. If we don't have professionals who specialize in this area, who else will drive the necessary change? It is crucial to delve into this field to realize its scope and importance. We need experts who have a background in civil or mechanical engineering but with a specific focus on environmental concerns. We are the ones who can make a significant impact. While the traditional top branches were important in the past, the current scenario demands a shift in perspective. We need to prioritize sustainability and address the pressing environmental challenges we face. The job market will respond accordingly, with an increasing number of projects inherently incorporating sustainable practices. Governments will require impact analysis, and the demand for professionals in this field will rise. There will be a boom, and we are already witnessing the emergence of dedicated sustainability divisions in prominent companies such as the Boston Consulting Group.

Could you share some details about the application and interview processes for the programmes into which you were accepted? particularly Stanford

The programs I applied for did not require interviews. However, I attended a session by Aviral sir, who had successfully gained admission to Stanford. One valuable lesson I learned from others is that the master's application process is highly demanding and time-consuming. It cannot be accomplished within a month; it typically requires several months of preparation. Moreover, you need to have a clear understanding of why you want to pursue a master's degree. It's a process that demands significant effort, including collecting documents such as letters of recommendation and certificates. The application process may seem straightforward in theory, taking no more than 30 minutes if you have all the necessary documents. You need to craft a well-written Statement of Purpose (SOP) that explains why you chose their program. Describe how your academic or internship journey led you there and an essay highlighting what you can bring to their diverse environment. In my SOP, I made a point to mention specific faculty members I was excited to work with. I invested time in efficient research about their work by exploring their websites and understanding their areas of expertise. Since they receive numerous applications, it's important to demonstrate that you have a genuine interest and align with their research. Your application should tell a compelling story that showcases your motivations and aspirations. In my personal statement, I emphasized the unique challenges faced by women in STEM, particularly in a lower-ranked branch. It can be tough dealing with stereotypes and jokes, even within the classroom. The perception of education in India as a means to secure marriage for women often influences how society views female students. I felt it was important to address these issues and share my experiences. Naturally, each personal statement should be different and reflect the individual's journey. Something my mother advised me was to highlight the efforts I have made to create a better space for myself to function. This aspect was crucial to me, and I included it in my application.

Can you shed some light on the program's monetary vacuum, and how difficult it is to finance or self-fund an MS degree? 

Stanford University, unfortunately, does not offer financial aid. However, I consider myself fortunate to have a father who is a financial consultant. Through his guidance, we made the necessary investments to support my education. To gather information about funding options, I reached out to my seniors who had already gone through the process. They informed me about positions available as research assistants or teaching assistants, which provide a stipend. A portion of this stipend is allocated towards tuition, while the remainder is received as income. Broadly, different colleges and universities have their own programs for providing financial aid to students.

How do you plan to leverage your MS in environmental engineering? 

I anticipate completing my studies within the next 1-2 years, and I do not plan to pursue a PhD at this time. Instead, I am interested in working with a research institute or engaging in consulting work. I would like to be involved in client projects with government organizations, particularly those that align with sustainable goals and have a real-life impact. One example of such an organization is the Delhi Research Institute, which offers opportunities to work on projects that contribute to sustainability and address pressing societal issues. While I don't have a definitive plan yet, this is the general direction I am considering for my future career.

title: Foreign Admissions | University of Bonn
biliner:
"You should be very clear about what you want to pursue to avoid rejections and you have to be aware of the eligibility criteria, and the required CGPA."

DTU Times interviewed Jasmeer Singh Kalra, BT, Class of 2023, who received acceptances from University of Bonn and RWTH Aachen in cooperation with the Fraunhofer Institutes Sankt Augustin, Germany Carnegie for MSc in Life Sciences Informatics; National University of Singapore for MSc in Biomedical Informatics; University of Liverpool and University of Glasgow for MSc in Bioinformatics; University of Greenwich for MSc in Big Data and Business Intelligence and University of Sheffield for MSc in Genomic Approaches to Drug Discovery.
body:
DTU Times interviewed Jasmeer Singh Kalra, BT, Class of 2023, who received acceptances from University of Bonn and RWTH Aachen in cooperation with the Fraunhofer Institutes Sankt Augustin, Germany Carnegie for MSc in Life Sciences Informatics; National University of Singapore for MSc in Biomedical Informatics; University of Liverpool and University of Glasgow for MSc in Bioinformatics; University of Greenwich for MSc in Big Data and Business Intelligence and University of Sheffield for MSc in Genomic Approaches to Drug Discovery.
 

You worked as a Project Intern at Ashoka University and also did an internship with CSIR. How has your work experience helped you in your master's journey?

When I was preparing for my Masters, I had two things on my mind. First, I wanted to do a Masters in the field of Biology, Data Science, and related fields. So I approached Dr. Anshu Bharadwaj from CSIR Chandigarh for an internship position in her lab because the lab aligned with my interests and subjects. When I approached her I didn't get a follow back reply immediately. I mailed her in January 2021, after which she gave me a follow-up 6 months later. Soon, she gave me two projects to begin with. One of them was related to my field and the other was related to SciComm. My first project was an incomplete project from her lab which was previously assigned to a Ph.D student. I had to automate everything and I used an ML algorithm on the data. I finally completed the project in two months and I published a research paper with a good impact factor. This was the start of my foreign master's journey. I contacted more professors for a research position in their lab which aligned with the subjects for my Master's degree. I contacted Dr. Rintu Kuntum from Ashoka University. He assessed me from the interview and then we started working. We are currently doing a project that is still under preparation and will be published soon. My interest is in NLP. It is a field that is exclusively working on genomic data and I plan to work on that after my Master's. I plan to do a PhD in that field.

We can observe that your acceptances entail a variety of domains, including bioinformatics, life sciences, and data science. We have two questions in my mind; Why such a variety? And second, how did you finally choose your master's field?

This started in 2017 when I completed my 10th standard. I'm a lateral entry student at DTU. I have a diploma in computer engineering. After that, I had two options; to join DTU or IP University. I was getting Biotechnology at DTU, so I selected that as I had an interest in biology. I knew that I had to pursue a Master's degree, so I planned to do the same in a field combining computer engineering and biotechnology. 

You've been into fields which hold very vast practical and emerging applications, what's your take on the maturity of such courses in India?

Currently, these courses do not hold much value in India, and the research is still in progress. For a person who wishes to stay in India, I don't recommend this side of academics because it is still in progress and I don't know what is going to be the scenario after 3 or 5 years. That is why I decided to go to Germany since they have companies that are doing great in this field. 

What do you think research-inclined students opt for foreign universities when there is ample space for the same in India as well?

The easiest answer to this would be that people don't value research here. In India’s scenario, when you pursue a Ph.D. you get a stipend of 33k-35k as a JRF or SRF, which is nothing as compared to what a B.Tech student would get after his/her degree and further go into core, non-tech, or tech field. So research is not valued in India, at least till now. It is changing, and eventually, it will change. It is also an easy option for people to get more money, thus people prefer going outside. 

When did you decide you wanted to pursue a Master's, and how did you shortlist the courses you'd be applying to? 

It was in my second year when I joined DTU that I got to know that most of my subjects are not related to IT or CSE. I was sure that I would only do a job that would have both Biology and IT in it, so I decided to go for a Master's and not opt for a job.

When did you decide in what field you wanted to pursue your Master's?

I joined DTU in my second year. I found out that most of my subjects are not related to IT or computer engineering, but I was sure that I had to get a job in a field that has both IT and Biology. So, for that, I knew I had to do a Master's and not focus on the placements. So, I didn’t apply for placements at all.

What will be the new career opportunities that will be available to you after your Master's?

The eligibility criteria is a Bachelor’s degree in IT, Biomedical Informatics, or Life Sciences Informatics. I’ll be doing industrial research after completing my Masters. 

What are the specific domains you would explore after doing M.Sc?

I’m going to do a minor in NLP ( Natural Language Processing) which includes large language models or GPT models. Research in that field is very vast by using data in the fields of biotechnology and biomedical informatics.

What are the various stages of different exams and how can one clear those stages easily?

First, select which country you want to go to. During the decision process of the same, I made a mistake. Initially, I wanted to go to the US. The UK has good research opportunities but it is a bit expensive. Also, the US doesn’t value international students that much. So, I didn’t apply there. I applied to the UK for the sake of it. I had two options after this; Singapore or Germany. So, I researched which was better for me and I learned that Germany values international students very much and it’s easy to earn there. So, you should prepare for GRE as it is mandatory in almost all universities but it’s not the case with IELTS or TOEFL. I appeared for TOEFL initially because it was required for the US. I appeared for GRE as it was required in Germany.

What is the financial aid process for the universities you've applied for?

They do not give much financial aid in the US or UK for Master’s students but they do give financial aid for Bachelor’s students as the course is not that expensive compared to M.Sc, and the same applies for Singapore. They give scholarships to students who sign a bond with them. The bond states that students have to work there for 3 years after completing their Master’s but in Germany education is free and the cost of living is not that high. As Germany is not that expensive compared to the UK, US, or Singapore, the research facilities and salaries are good, so I finally chose Germany.

What is the application process for most of the universities?

The application process starts one year before the year in which you’re aspiring to get admitted into any university. German universities open their applications in March. The application has several steps. The first step is acquiring the transcript from college. Then you have to write a SOP (Statement of Purpose). SOP has the most weightage in any application, so one is advised to devote a good amount of time to writing it. Some of the courses require a Personal History Statement(PHS) and then prepare for IELTS/TOEFL and your interview.

What advice would you like to give the students who want to pursue their interests abroad or in India?

You should be very clear about what you want to pursue to avoid rejections and you have to be aware of the eligibility criteria, and the required CGPA. A CGPA of more than 9 is sufficient. Do thorough research about the field you want to pursue. Some courses require GRE, so it's best to prepare for that as well.

DTU Times interviewed Ms. Yati Sharma, B. Des., Class of 2023, who has been accepted for Master of Fine Arts at the Royal College of Art, London.
body:
“This is more like I want to follow my passion. It's not like I want that degree because in this field the main matter is the goal you have. So I just want to get a formal education in art.”

DTU Times interviewed Ms. Yati Sharma, B. Des., Class of 2023, who has been accepted for Master of Fine Arts at the Royal College of Art, London.

These four years of college sure feel like a roller coaster ride and now that you are done, you must be feeling relaxed. So before diving into the next years of your life can you please walk us through what the period at college has been like for you?

So these four years were not very stable. Design as a subject I had no idea what it was going to be and about DTU itself, I had no idea before. I have explored a lot of things, have been a part of a lot of societies, have worked with teams, and research projects, attended many conferences, and made many friends and it was a very wholesome experience.

The decision to do a Master's especially abroad wouldn't have been easy so now you have decided to pursue it and this time you took to convince yourself and your parents.

So I am going for a Masters in fine arts with a specialization in visual communication. This is more like I want to follow my passion. It's not like I want that degree because in this field the main matter is the goal you have. So I just want to get a formal education in art. I want to switch fields from design to art so that's why I am going for a Master's. So it was very difficult to convince my parents for this because before it was very difficult to convince them for design and now telling them that I am going towards art. Basically, there was no job in art so it was very difficult but then I told them about my plans and goals and they are confident now.

In contemporary times, when everybody searches for a good placement right after the degree, studying abroad can be a lonely experience. So how did you look ahead to manage the stress and overcome the dilemma of executing your decision?

It was very difficult, like the entire accumulation process, and those months like from September to January was the most difficult part of my college life. Everyone else was going for placement, and I was planning to study ahead. It is a very long process even now I have applied to four universities. That was a very long process already because you devoted all your time to building a Portfolio in that direction. So it was from July onwards only that I started working towards internship and placements but I was more comfortable towards the academic side than corporate.

Can you explain more about a portfolio? Is it the same as a CV or building a Portfolio is something different in design or art? 

So for art and design courses, the only thing that matters is your portfolio. It portrays your art, whatever you are doing and your journey. SOPs and letters of recommendation are also important but a portfolio is the thing that supports you and what you want to do in the future. It's a compilation of all your work, your journey whatever you have done.

Why did you choose the Royal College of Art, London as your institute for MFA? How does it distinguish itself from the rest of the institutions in India and abroad?

It was always a  dream to enter the Royal College of Arts, London, and the first reason to choose it is that it is situated in London and London is a very mature City, especially for arts it's a very major factor. It has all the museums and it also has a very strong alumni trait and it is the reason a lot of renowned designers and artists have studied there. I was also in touch with a few professors from there and I took mentorship from them. And as a result, I was inspired to take admission there.

How did the faculty at the Department of Design, DTU help you to study and prepare for your Master's? Do you think mentorship in subjective feel like art and design is necessary?

The professors helped us a lot. We have many professors from the fine arts background only. They helped me in the process because I had no idea about this field so they initially warned me about the situation of art, but then they wholeheartedly supported me. Usually, people say that faculty doesn't help you in getting jobs and placement, but in academics, if you're going to higher studies you should consult them because they have gone through all these processes and no one can help you better. A few of my professors helped me in writing my SOPs, and portfolio and also guided me for my projects. They helped me in making my portfolio and projects more academically professional than corporate-oriented.

How do you feel mentorship in a subjective field like design and art helps you?

Yes, it helps a lot as there is not much material available in this field. You don't study from books or online lectures for design because it's a very subjective field. So mentorship is the only thing that keeps you on track and validates what you're doing. It is rather important, especially in your academic years. 

What would you advise to your design juniors who are passionate and want to start a career in this field?

Go out and experience a lot of things. Capture whatever you experience, and not just visually. Whatever you are doing, put it in your portfolio constantly because most people decide to build a portfolio at the very end moment. Present your work in the form of a story. Do collaborations, do freelancing a lot because that's only how you can get a lot of exposure. Also, I think internships aren’t that helpful for communication especially because in India visual communication is just graphic designing so if you are into product design go for an internship but if you want to explore other fields of design like animation, collaborate with people, and professors from other universities and explore different fields.

What would you like to tell readers about art and design, especially your work domain?

During lockdown, I observed other creatures, like birds and animals, interact with each other. I discovered a distinct sense of smell. I saw animals interact using this sense of smell. I thought that it would be an artful idea to use the sense of smell to capture experiences. My first project was capturing the experience of rain using smells because once I was having this discussion with my mom about what the smell of rain would be, what would the experience be, and what it feels like. So everything is about that specific smell which can be used to communicate that experience but until now you don't have any medium to communicate this. For the past two years, I have been working to come up with a medium to communicate those experiences. In our last semester in design, we had to do a major project in collaboration with some industry. I collaborated with the Japanese artist Akiota who has been in olfactory art for around 20 years now. She has been working towards the same goal, to develop new modes of communication. So I collaborated with her and worked on communicating emotions through smells, how different smells can trigger nostalgia and others can trigger other experiences. In general, such communication can have multiple uses, for example in the tourist industry it can be used as a form of communication. People get to experience different emotions not just visually but also on an olfactory basis.

What have been your major learnings from your time at DTU?

DTU has given me a lot of freedom, especially in the department of design. They provided the tools for exploring and gave me the freedom to do whatever I wanted to do. This was one of the factors that attracted me to design. Also, there was a very mixed atmosphere here, we have designers, engineers, and business students. You get a lot of exposure in college through internship opportunities and societies which helped everyone in building a network, socialize with people, and build personality.

body:
“Working within a team helps you as an individual. You can work on your soft skills and communication skills, which can't quite be replicated in a classroom. Working in a society introduces you to a lot of people from different branches and different academic backgrounds which further enhances your outlook. So, collaborating with such a mix of individuals in a college society helps you grow, communicate and be more expressive.”

DTU Times interviewed Parangat Mittal, ECE, Class of 2021, who has been accepted for Masters in Electronics and Communication at the University of California, Los Angeles.

You worked as a Physical Design Engineer at Qualcomm and also did an internship with DRDO. How has your work experience helped you in your master's journey?

The DRDO internship gave me an insight into how research labs work in the real world, outside of college. I worked with the Defence Lab in Jodhpur, in the domain of Desert Environment Science. I worked on the up and coming stealth technology for defence aircrafts, which gave me a lot to learn. 

Qualcomm has been one of the highlights of my career; I worked there for the past two years. It started with a two-month-long remote internship during  the pandemic, which was a good starting point for my corporate journey. I got a PPO in the same team I interned in, which I joined right after graduation in ‘21. I worked as a Physical Design engineer at Qualcomm, which was very rewarding to me considering that the work we specialised in aligned well with the specialisation I’m aiming for in my MS. So, it has been a fairly decent experience at Qualcomm.

When did you decide to pursue a master's, and how did you shortlist the courses you'd be applying to?

I had made up my mind about pursuing a master's degree while I was pursuing B. Tech at DTU. My interest in electronics grew during the 4th semester when we had more electronics-oriented subjects in our curriculum. As I worked on more and more projects and subsequent internships, it became quite clear to me that I wanted to pursue my master's in the same industry. The publishing of my first research paper was the biggest motivating factor in my decision to pursue this discipline further. After one year of working at Qualcomm, I was introduced to many different teams working on the same project but with different tasks. So while I’m currently working in back-end VLSI design, I wish to get into front-end digital design and the ideal way to go about that would be through a master's program. So, that’s what motivated me to go for a master's degree.

You were the editor-in-chief of DTU Times. How do you think the role helped you in your applications, and how important are college societies when it comes to master's applications?

Speaking of college societies in general, working within a team helps you as an individual. You can work on your soft skills and communication skills, which can't quite be replicated in a classroom. Working in a society introduces you to a lot of people from different branches and different academic backgrounds which further enhances your outlook. So, collaborating with such a mix of individuals in a college society helps you grow, communicate and be more expressive. It’s very helpful for job interviews, adjusting within a team and working in different organisations. 

Speaking of DTU Times specifically, it was the biggest factor that helped me write all my application essays. The command  I got over language by writing articles,  interacting with seniors, taking interviews and working on editions was extremely helpful.

How do you think an MS is different from an M.Tech?

The institutions abroad generally don't have an MTech degree, so the MS degree over there is somewhat similar to the MTech degree we have in India. In both the degrees you have to choose a specialisation, since the kind of roles I wanted to take up were mostly centred in the US and the kind of research facilities I am looking for were available in the US schools, I went for an MS degree instead. In terms of curriculum, they both are essentially the same. The MTech is the Indian counterpart of the  Masters degree in Engineering (aka MS in Engineering). 

It is commonly said that an MS is more inclined towards research than MTech. What are your views on that?

Not really, there are multiple options in MS, there is a research track where you are supposed to publish a thesis report, there is a project track in which you have to submit a capstone project and then there is a courses track in which you just study the required courses and can go for a job after that. Even in MTech, many people convert their degree to a PhD, since they are pursuing full-time research. They also work as JRFs and RAs under different professors, so I feel that it all depends on the individual instead.

Where does your major interest lie, what are your career goals?

My interest mainly lies in R&D, research and development, it is a mix of both academic research and a corporate job. My career goal would be to get an R&D role in an organisation. My specialisation is Computer Architecture, which is something that I have been studying since my second year. I have actively been following different professors and research work for the last four years, which is why I chose this particular specialisation.

Why do you think research-inclined students opt for foreign universities when there are ample opportunities in India as well?

I can't comment on the general trend, but I can speak for myself, I feel like the kind of research infrastructure and facilities I was looking for aligned better with foreign universities. I had spent a decent amount of time researching the options that I had; I researched about the institutes, their research facilities, their professors, and the kind of work being done. After a thorough analysis of all the aspects of various universities, in India as well as abroad, I concluded that I wanted to pursue an MS from a foreign university.

What are the major stages of the application process, and what should be kept in mind for each? 

The application process is really tedious. Firstly you need to make up your mind that you want to do an MS, then you finalise your desired universities, and you should thoroughly research the program specifics, faculties and the schools which you aim to join. You must document all the required information for the list of universities you wish to apply to (It becomes really helpful at a later stage). You should keep the estimated fee structure in mind as well and check if you can afford it.

Some universities require you to appear for an English proficiency test like IELTS and a general aptitude test like GMAT. You might also need to appear for TOEFL and GRE, these exams have their specific preparation processes and you need to keep a buffer period for preparing for these exams. Once you are done with the exams, start preparing your application material, which includes a statement of purpose that highlights all your key academic and professional achievements, and why you wish to pursue that specific degree. Then you need to get letters of recommendation from your professors or employers and submit all the material before the deadline which is generally in December.

What would you suggest to other students who want to pursue higher studies abroad like the US?

The main question that I faced was, whether I should apply to the Computer Science (CS) Department or the Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Department because the courses and curriculum overlap for both of these departments in many universities and sometimes even professors teaching in both departments are the same. Students are doing their research from both the departments. So, first of all, You have to decide whether you want to apply to the ECE department or the CS department. Secondly, if you wish for a job after your master's, you need to check what the job market looks like in the country where you’re applying, specifically in your domain. You need to check for roles that are currently open. In India, there are roles that are only open for ECE graduates and some are open only for CS graduates but this is not the case everywhere. So, make sure that the job you’re looking for would be satisfied by the degree you're pursuing.  While preparing your application materials like a CV, Letter of Recommendation, and SOP, you should highlight all those parts of your professional experiences and academics that support your application towards your domain. If someone wants to work in the field of AI then they should highlight AI projects in their application. 

What specific domain do you plan to go for during your period in MS?

It was very tough to decide whether I want to apply to CS or ECE and some universities have Computer Engineering which comes between CS and ECE. So, I’ll be pursuing Computer  Architecture and VLSI which is an overlap of both the departments, CS and ECE.

Are there any domains related/remotely related to Computer Architecture that you may want to explore?

Yes, definitely. I will have options to explore Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning in Computer  Science and Embedded Systems and Digital Design in Electrical. Apart from this, there is a newly emerging field of Human-Computer Interaction, which I would also like to explore during my master’s.

What is the financial aid process for the universities you've applied for? 

Financial aid is different for different countries. In the US, financial aid is different from state to state and school-to-school. Some schools provide various scholarships to students based on their previous academic records, some states give you an opportunity to pay the in-state tuition fee which is a lot cheaper than the foreign tuition fee. Sometimes, professors can make recommendations to the university to give you a tuition waiver or some sort of financial aid. There are different third-party scholarships that you can apply for, during your application or after getting admission. They have their own test and interviews before giving you the scholarships. It’s not always feasible for universities to provide all students with a scholarship. So, some students have to pay their whole fee by themselves but once you start your studies abroad there are various opportunities for you to earn money and pay for your expenses.

title: ब्लॉग | संगीत : स्वयं से संवाद
biliner:
हम सभी के जीवन में एक ऐसे व्यक्ति की दरकार होती है जो सुख-दुःख, यश-कीर्ति के समय ही नहीं बल्कि संघर्ष में भी हमारे साथ खड़ा रहे और वह व्यक्ति हमारे भाई, बहन, माता-पिता या दोस्त कोई भी हो सकता हैं। निराशा के उस समय में उनके साथ हुए संवाद कि उतनी ही अहमियत होती है जितनी उस व्यक्ति की होती है। 

“क्योंकि तुम्हारा साथ ना मैं कभी छोडूंगा और ना ही कभी यह संगीत छोड़ेगा।”

इसी दिशा में राहुल देव, द्वितीय संज्ञार्थ, ई.ई. द्वारा रचित एक रोचक संवाद को पढ़िए एवं यह पता लगाइये की उस रात जिस व्यक्ति से उस संगीतकार ने संवाद किया था। वह कौन था ?
body:
हम सभी के जीवन में एक ऐसे व्यक्ति की दरकार होती है जो सुख-दुःख, यश-कीर्ति के समय ही नहीं बल्कि संघर्ष में भी हमारे साथ खड़ा रहे और वह व्यक्ति हमारे भाई, बहन, माता-पिता या दोस्त कोई भी हो सकता हैं। निराशा के उस समय में उनके साथ हुए संवाद कि उतनी ही अहमियत होती है जितनी उस व्यक्ति की होती है।

“क्योंकि तुम्हारा साथ ना मैं कभी छोडूंगा और ना ही कभी यह संगीत छोड़ेगा।”

इसी दिशा में राहुल देव, द्वितीय संज्ञार्थ, ई.ई. द्वारा रचित एक रोचक संवाद को पढ़िए एवं यह पता लगाइये की उस रात जिस व्यक्ति से उस संगीतकार ने संवाद किया था। वह कौन था ?

अंधेरी स्याह रात थी। थकान इतनी की मैं सो तो रहा था लेकिन मेरी सांसें थम सी गईं थीं। नींद की गहराई मे मैं अपने जीवन के लिए यमदूतों से लड़ते-लड़ते कमज़ोर पड़ने लगा। मैं उनसे कभी न ख़त्म होने वाली इस लड़ाई के बीच में ही था, तभी दूर से आती हुई किसी ध्वनि ने मानो मेरे बल को बढ़ा दिया। उनसे ये द्वंद्व जीत कर, मैं उस ध्वनि की ओर खींचा चला जा रहा था। मेरी नींद अचानक टूट गयी लेकिन यह ध्वनि बंद नहीं हुई बल्कि इसका शोर अब बढ़ता ही चला जा रहा था मानो उस शोर का कोई विशेष उद्देश्य था। जैसे की वह शोर केवल एक शोर नही बल्कि एक आवाज़ थी जो मुझसे कुछ कहना चाहती थी। मैं डर से सो नहीं पा रहा था। सोने के प्रयास मे कुछ देर तक करवट बदलने के बाद इस ध्वनि का शोर तो कम हो गया लेकिन यह ध्वनि मुझे खींचकर कुछ महीनों से बंद पड़े कमरे की ओर ले गयी। मैंने डरते हुए उस कमरे के दरवाजे को खोला, अंधेरे के कारण मुझे कुछ नहीं दिख रहा था। स्विच दबाने पर बिजली ने झट-पट रोशनी की, तब धूल लगे मेरे पुरस्कार दिखे, धूल खाते हुए मेरे सभी वाद्य यन्त्र दिखे, यह सब देखकर मेरा पूरा जीवन क्षण भर के लिए मेरे समक्ष आकर खड़ा हो गया। उस कमरे में पड़े प्रत्येक यन्त्र और पुरस्कार ने मुझसे केवल एक ही सवाल पूछा “हमारी क्या गलती थी ? जो हम से रिश्ता तोड़ लिया, ऐसे अंधेरे कमरे में धूल खाने को छोड़ दिया ?” मुझे ऐसा लगा की मैं गूंगा हो चूका हूँ, ना मेरे पास शब्द थे और ना ही उनके सवाल का जवाब था। वहाँ से भागने के लिए मैं पीछे मुड़ा ही था की किसी ने मुझको रोक लिया और मुझसे यह कहा

“कहाँ और कब तक भागते रहोगे?

और कितनी रातें ऐसे परेशान होकर जागते रहोगे?

कभी ना कभी तो इनसे भी सामना करना ही होगा। 

भागने की बजाय डट कर लड़ना ही होगा।  

केवल यह नहीं बल्कि इस पर भी विचार करो की,

तुमने क्यों सब कुछ शुरू किया था ?” 

मैं किसी से भाग नही रहा हूँ और ना ही मुझमे किसी से लड़ने की क्षमता बची है। यह भी नहीं जानता हूं की मैं क्यों रातों को जगता हूँ। मैंने ये शुरू किया था क्योंकि मुझे हर कण में एक मधुर ध्वनि सुनाई देती थी। करीबियों में सबसे ज्यादा भावनाएं मुझे समझ आती थी। मुझे कभी पैसे,यश, कीर्ति इन सब की भूख नहीं थी। मेरे लिए हमेशा से ही संगीत एक जुनून था, मुझे केवल इसी से मिलता सुकून था। परन्तु इस समाज के तिरस्कार और कड़वे-कठोर शब्दों के मार ने मुझे अंदर से तोड़ दिया था इसलिए मैंने संगीत का ही दामन छोड़ दिया था। 

तुम यह सब क्यों मुझसे पूछने आए हो? यह पूछकर मुझे एक बार फिर सबकुछ याद दिलाने आए हो। कैसे और कितनी मेहनत,अनुशाशन से मैंने खुद को इस काबिल बनाया था। मैंने माँ-बाबा को चंद लम्हों में नहीं बल्कि महीनों में मनाया था। बचपन से मैंने बस एक सपना देखा था, उसी  सपने को हासिल करने का अरमान लिए मुंबई आया था लेकिन मेरे सभी अरमानों को लोगों के पक्षपात ने तोड़ दिया। मुझको वह सब फिर से याद नहीं करना, मेरा हृदय पहले से ही बहुत खंडित है, उसे और नहीं तोडना है। मुझे यह बताओ इसके पीछे तुम्हारा उद्देश्य क्या है? तुम कैसे इस कमरे के अंदर आ गए ? बस मेरे इन्ही कुछ प्रश्नों के उत्तर दो। 

कमरे के अंधेरे कोने में खड़े उस साये ने जवाब दिया - “मैं तुम्हारे बारे में सबकुछ जानता हूँ, मुझसे  कुछ भी छिपा नहीं है। मैं हर घड़ी तुम्हारे शरीर के एक अभिन्न अंग की तरह रहा हूँ, कभी साथ तो कभी पीछे चला हूँ। तुम्हारी संगीत सीखने की वह पहली क्लास हो या बाबा ने जब तुम्हें पहली बार बांसुरी दिलाई थी,तुमने पहली धुन बनाकर माँ को ही तो सुनाई थी। ट्रेन तक माँ-बाबा दोनों छोड़ने आये थें। तुमने अपने मित्र रजत के ही हाथों किसी को खत भी भिजवाए थे | तुम्हारे हाथ से उसने किस तरह अपने हाथ छुड़ाए थे। तुमने जो बातें किसी को नहीं बताई वह सब बातें भी मैं जानता हूँ केवल बाहर ही नहीं तुम्हारे अंतर्मन तक मैं तुम्हें पहचानता हूँ। क्योंकि तुम्हारा साथ ना मैं कभी छोडूंगा और ना ही कभी यह संगीत छोड़ेगा।”

आखिर कौन हो तुम ? इतना सब कुछ कैसे जानते हो? मैंने जो अभी तक किसी को नहीं बताया वह सब कुछ भी कैसे जानते हो ? आत्मा हो या कोई तांत्रिक हो ? अब तुमसे जब कुछ छुपा नहीं है तो बताओ मुझे मैं क्या करूं जिस से सब कुछ ठीक हो जाये ? माँ-बाबा ही नहीं जो भी मुझसे दूर चले गए हैं वह भी मेरे पास वापस आ जाये ? कभी-कभी सोचता हूँ कि कहीं यह संगीत भी मेरा साथ छोड़ ना जाए। चुप मत रहो ! कुछ तो बोलो, मेरी बंद आंखें तो खोलो। मुझे अपना चेहरा तो दिखाओ, बस एक बार रौशनी मे तो आओ।  

उस साये ने लम्बी सांस ली और कहा - “मैं अब प्रश्नों के उत्तर नहीं दूंगा क्योंकि हमारे पास कुछ क्षण का ही समय है। बस इतना कहूँगा कि चाहे कुछ भी हो जाए कभी हार मत मानना। पूरे जी जान से फिर एक नई शुरुआत करो, एक बार फिर मुझ पर और खुद पर भी थोड़ा तो विश्वास करो। बस इतना कहकर वह रौशनी में आया। उसे देखकर मैं डर से काँप गया | वह थोड़ा आगे बढ़ने लगा और मैं उलटे पांव पीछे  चलने लगा, धीरे- धीरे हम दोनों की चाल बढ़ने लगी और फिर अचानक वह किसी भयावह आत्मा की भांति मेरे अंदर समा गया। मेरी नींद डर से टूटी और आंखें खुली की खुली रह गई क्योंकि सपने में मैंने जिसको देखा वह साया कोई और नहीं बल्कि स्वयं मैं ही था।

title: Blog | Growing Up with Bollywood
biliner:

Read on as Dhruv Rahuja, 2nd Year, COE takes us on a trip down memory lane and explores the evolution of Bollywood from the 1990s to the present day.
body:
“I remember the time when standing in long queues for movie tickets was the norm and the excitement for new releases was palpable. The anticipation for a movie release was at an all-time high and the hype surrounding it was infectious.” 

Read on as Dhruv Rahuja, 2nd Year, COE takes us on a trip down memory lane and explores the evolution of Bollywood from the 1990s to the present day.    

Have you grown up watching Bollywood movies? If yes, you're not alone! Many of us have fond memories of watching movies with family and friends, enjoying the larger-than-life characters, addictive music, and captivating stories that Bollywood movies offer. Let's take a trip down memory lane and explore the evolution of Bollywood from the 1990s to the present day.   

I remember the time when standing in long queues for movie tickets was the norm and the excitement for new releases was palpable. The anticipation for a movie release was at an all-time high and the hype surrounding it was infectious. The atmosphere inside the cinema was electric, with the audience cheering and clapping. These memories remain etched in my heart and continue to bring a smile to my face.

The 1990s marked a significant era in Bollywood, where the industry witnessed the emergence of various new genres. Movies like "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" and, "Kuch Kuch Hota Hai" captured our hearts with their unforgettable characters and catchy songs which we still remember and adore. Although most of you probably weren't born at the time, I am sure all of us have watched many films from that era on those “box-type televisions" with our families.

Just like many of you, the Bollywood movies from the 2000s were an integral part of my childhood. I grew up watching movies, dancing to their catchy tunes, and memorizing their dialogues. In addition to the conventional Bollywood-style light-hearted movies, I was intrigued by the new wave of experimental filmmakers. Movies like "Rang De Basanti" and, "Taare Zameen Par" which were a departure from the traditional Bollywood formula, fascinated me while growing up. 

The 2010s era was the time when I had matured enough to properly understand the movies. Movies like “Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani” and “Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara” awakened my inner wanderlust and imparted valuable lessons on the significance of friendships and relationships which still hold. While romantic comedies and family dramas remained a part of the scene, Bollywood in the 2010s saw a rise in content-driven films, like "Dear Zindagi" addressing mental health and "Dangal" focusing on women's empowerment. These films played a significant role in shaping the perspectives of our generation.

I have been fortunate enough to see Bollywood transition from one era to another. As I look back to those times, I feel a sense of nostalgia for the movies, the music, and the memories. Bollywood will always hold a special place in my heart, and I will continue to cherish these memories for years to come.

title: Blog | Lights, Camera, Beats: Why Movie Soundtracks Are the Sound of Our Generation
biliner:
“The enchanting marriage of music and imagery is the catalyst that infuses storytelling with renewed vitality. Such a feat can only be accomplished by the masterful creation of music, which holds the power to shape cultural trends and influence pop culture at large.”

Read on as Sara Sanwal, 3rd Year, B.Des explores the enchanting world of film music and its transformative impact on storytelling and society.
body:
“The enchanting marriage of music and imagery is the catalyst that infuses storytelling with renewed vitality. Such a feat can only be accomplished by the masterful creation of music, which holds the power to shape cultural trends and influence pop culture at large.” Read on as Sara Sanwal, 3rd Year, B.Des. explores the enchanting world of film music and its transformative impact on storytelling and society.

Music has always been an important aspect of the cinematic experience.  Throughout the evolution of cinema, music has remained a quintessential element in shaping the emotional impact of visual storytelling. From the days of silent films, where live musicians would provide accompaniment to enhance the imagery, to the contemporary era of blockbuster films featuring grandiose orchestral compositions and infectiously catchy pop singles, the power of music to captivate and move us has only grown stronger. The role of music in creating a sense of time and place, as well as eliciting emotional responses from the audience, cannot be overstated. To create memorable musical accompaniments to visual storytelling, composers and filmmakers must work together to create effective movie soundtracks. Successful movie soundtrack examples can shed light on the techniques and strategies used to capture the essence of a film. Leitmotifs, or musical themes associated with specific characters or ideas, can help to maintain continuity across a film series.

Movie soundtracks aren't just for the big screen. They have the ability to influence popular culture beyond the confines of their respective films, as evidenced by the inclusion of pop songs in movie trailers and the creation of standalone soundtrack albums.The enthralling world of film music combines sound and vision to create something magical. 

Let's start with my own two favorite music compositions for films as examples.

"Interstellar," Christopher Nolan's 2014 space epic, is a masterpiece of cinema that immerses audiences in a breathtaking journey through time and space. At the heart of this incredible film is the stunning score by composer Hans Zimmer, which perfectly captures the grandeur of the story and the emotions of the characters. One of the standout tracks on the "Interstellar" soundtrack, "Cornfield Chase," evokes a feeling of weightlessness and wonder. With a haunting piano melody that sets the tone for the track, the music becomes more intense as strings and percussion join in, building to a thrilling and awe-inspiring crescendo. Zimmer's ability to elicit strong emotions in the listener is evident in this piece, as it captures the sense of adventure and longing at the core of "Interstellar." Luca Guadagnino's 2017 romantic drama "Call Me by Your Name" is a cinematic gem that takes viewers on an emotional journey of self-discovery and love. The stunning soundtrack, which perfectly captures the emotions of the characters and the film's setting, is at the heart of this beautiful film. Sufjan Stevens' "Mystery of Love" is a standout track that captures the bittersweet feeling of first love with gentle guitar strumming and soft, melancholy vocals. "Visions of Gideon," another highlight, features Stevens' haunting falsetto vocals and delicate piano melodies that perfectly capture the raw emotions of heartbreak and loss. The soundtrack also includes throwback songs that transport viewers to the early 1980s and the film's Italian countryside setting. Giorgio Moroder's "Lady Lady Lady '' and F.R. David's "Words" are perfect examples of this with their nostalgic synth-pop sound. Overall, the "Call Me by Your Name" soundtrack is a beautiful and evocative work of art that perfectly captures the film's themes and emotions.

The use of music background scores in films has had a significant impact on how audiences perceive and relate to the characters on screen. One prominent example is the use of iconic music pieces such as Ennio Morricone's iconic whistle in Kill Bill is a hauntingly beautiful melody that has become synonymous with Uma Thurman's character, The Bride. It symbolizes her unwavering strength and determination, making it one of the most recognizable pieces of music in modern cinema. It evokes a sense of empowerment and determination, reflecting the character's fierce spirit and relentless pursuit of justice.

In recent years, the use of music background scores in films has grown in popularity, particularly on social media platforms such as Instagram Reels. This trend has had a significant impact on how people perceive and present themselves online, causing the main character syndrome to resurface. Generation Z can feel empowered and in control of their lives for a few moments by playing the roles of strong and confident characters.

The enchanting marriage of music and imagery is the catalyst that infuses storytelling with renewed vitality. Such a feat can only be accomplished by the masterful creation of music, which holds the power to shape cultural trends and influence pop culture at large. Indeed, the incredible influence of music is a testament to its boundless potential.

title: Blog | The Quota of Intangibles
biliner:
“The takeaway from all this is to be selfish at times - to know when to stop, step back, and take a prudent look at your treatment of not just others, but yourself too.”

Often tricked by the popular preachings of spreading love and being kind, people tend to relentlessly pour their hearts out in spite of the absence of reciprocation. Read on as Ritwij Kashyap, 3rd Year, IT, weaves a quantitative analogy for the intangible abstracts in an attempt to emphasize the importance of self-love.
body:
“The takeaway from all this is to be selfish at times - to know when to stop, step back, and take a prudent look at your treatment of not just others, but yourself too.”

Often tricked by the popular preachings of spreading love and being kind, people tend to relentlessly pour their hearts out in spite of the absence of reciprocation. Read on as Ritwij Kashyap, 3rd Year, IT, weaves a quantitative analogy for the intangible abstracts in an attempt to emphasize the importance of self-love.

As much as one would like to believe, there is no such thing as limitlessness. Kindness, love, gratitude, hatred, evil, and conceitedness are all intangible, making it harder to come to terms with the concept of their limits. Society preaches that one should be kind, one should be loving, and one should appreciate others - unconditionally.

At the risk of sounding nihilistic, I fear these intangibles have a quota. A quota which is replenished upon reciprocation. Hate fuels hate, kindness begets kindness, and love attracts love. If spent unconditionally, they are bound to run out. This ideology does not encourage incessantly putting out negativity in the hopes of getting rid of its quota, for one may end up with more than one started out with. After all, the cruel truth is that negativity is much more likely to be reciprocated than positivity.

Being unconditionally kind to others may put one in a position where they’re left with very little kindness for themselves. I believe unreciprocated goodness is often followed by self-loathing and self-doubt. One begins to come up with justifications for what is morally unjust by taking upon themselves all the blame. The compromises one begins to make on themselves have extremely detrimental repercussions. This unkind behaviour towards oneself can be seen as a direct consequence of running out of the kindness quota,

It may sound absurd to quantify something so abstract, but for someone who has trouble grasping abstract concepts, this arithmetic analogy serves as a helpful metric to gauge how well I’m treating myself. This is not to say that you should not be kind; on the contrary, my analogy urges everyone to be kind. Reciprocation is the key to achieving practical limitlessness; if everyone mirrors the good they receive, the quota keeps refilling, and a desirable abundance is accomplished. 

The takeaway from all this is to be selfish at times - to know when to stop, step back, and take a prudent look at your treatment of not just others, but yourself too. If you find an imbalance, pour more wherever necessary. Rest assured, all else will be taken care of by the quota of intangibles.

title: Blog | Be Kind To The Mind, let’s cut it some slack
biliner: “When you can identify discomforts within yourself early and act to relieve them, you can prevent them from escalating further into pain.”  Read on as Anshita Garg, (@anshita3) 3rd Year, COE, describes how catching regular breaks can translate into a more calm and peaceful lifestyle for all of us.
body:
“When you can identify discomforts within yourself early and act to relieve them, you can prevent them from escalating further into pain.”

As the idea of mental health has gained enough momentum to invite all eyes and ears, it has become equally imperative for everyone to deal and heal with it on personal levels. In the past, many people weren’t open to the discussion of mental health and weren’t proud of their journey with it. Even now, this topic of discussion is deemed as taboo and individuals avoid getting stuck in its discourse. 

A more popular opinion suggests that people do regard whatever is visible, as more plausible and obvious. Hence, physical breakdowns are given appropriate attention to, however mental breakdowns run short of apparent and appropriate evidence and response.

Thus, it is high time that we talk about how to be KIND TO THE MIND.

Our mind, brain more so, is essentially the one thing in the human body system that everything is pivoted around. And as it is well understood and easily come to terms with, it is as true and undebatable that catching a break is as important as it is to do work. After a long and hectic day's work, it is fairly important to take some time out and catch leisure time doing relaxing activities, some, if not all, in order to strike a balance between activities in solitude and social and productive activities. 

Further, it is truly said and easily understood that most activities in solitude help your mind to ease off and settle in place after a long day's work. Reading, listening to music, and writing are some activities that help achieve the task of vegging out at hand. 

Of all, the best way to alleviate the inevitable measures of stress is to get one's head down, maybe snatch forty winks once in a while. Not only because it's scientifically proven to take the edge off the levels of stress and anxiety, but, following a regular sleep routine calms and restores the body, improves concentration, regulates mood, and sharpens judgment and decision-making.

With the world changing and new ideas being put forward, the human mind is more at work than ever. And therefore, it is high time to cut it some slack and let it get enough rest and rejuvenate.

title: Blog|Of Kyn, On Kyn
biliner:
'Kyndness' harks back to the Old English for “nation” – and has roots in the word 'kin', as in one's family, race or relations. Join us as we journey through the verses, where time momentarily stands still, and unity emerges beyond lines and trying times. Delve into a world where the moon and the sun share their wisdom, and eyes filled with stories and dreams paint the canvas of human existence.
Read on, as Dheeresh Chandra, 3rd Year, MCE pens the entrenched yet healing conversation between the very forces that frame our night and day.
body:
'Kyndness' harks back to the Old English for “nation” – and has roots in the word 'kin', as in one's family, race or relations. Join us as we journey through the verses, where time momentarily stands still, and unity emerges beyond lines and trying times. Delve into a world where the moon and the sun share their wisdom, and eyes filled with stories and dreams paint the canvas of human existence. 

Read on, as Dheeresh Chandra, 3rd Year, MCE pens the entrenched yet healing conversation between the very forces that frame our night and day.

In a world of wailing babies and lost innocence

Where the loud thuds don’t stop

When the darkness seems to engulf on all ends

When the rivers turn dry with waters reddened

 

On one such dusk, the moon met the sun in the sky,

Each off to its own daily circadian rhythm

The moon was thinking of putting on a new face

The sun just steaming off from its spin

 

Each had its own thought but no pennies to give

Who would be the kind heeder?

The sun roared with the wisdom of the skies,

‘Perhaps some days in the barracks won’t be so bad.’

 

They say it is to save lives

Of the very Nature that we serve

For who will put up a fight

If not trained in the menace of the gun?

 

We are not the first to witness it

Generations have sacredly partaken

My father and yours, my grandpa and yours too

The conscription brings peace, stability and freedom

It ensures that the weak are protected 

and the enemy stay beyond the chicken fence.

 

The moon gently smiled and looked on

After all the sun was said to be the wisest one of all

It had seen the toil and the grind

It had seen the shadow and its crimes

 

Of the boy shot twice in the head for knocking on the wrong door

Of the children running towards the bunkers under screeching boars

Of the loitering eyes and whetted gloats

Of civilized chains and damaged souls

 

The moon wasn’t blissfully benighted

A foolish brute in the face of time

It too had seen the unseeable

The grub, the grunge, the grime

 

But maybe for it shined with the light of the sun

Its beam was radiant and peacefully benign

Like calming the roaring tide

Both of water and the mind

 

It had seen love, in the eyes that looked up at it

It had seen its reflection unjudged

It had seen countless faces and phases in those eyes

Of remembrance and recollection not budged.

 

Those eyes deep like the ocean

Whose tides were at mere mercy of the moon

Those eyes deeper than the sky

In which the sun, the moon, the stars all shone  

 

Those eyes  of different colors

It changed with the emotion and their hues

Of green and black and blue

Sometimes there were red rings too

 

But each night that the eyes looked up at it

They didn’t look for  storms to unfurl

They only wanted bliss and forgiveness

On themselves and on others

 

The moon had seen love in those eyes

Those eyes that had seen all

They had seen the sun the moon the stars

They had also seen the children, the wailings and the bars

 

Those eyes that spoke of remembrance of sacrifices made yore

Those eyes that recollected stories of kindness big and small

Those eyes that recalled dreams for a better world for all

Those eyes that truly had seen all

 

The moon had learned its lesson

It sat quietly with the sun and held on

On the precipice beyond the world

As the heat of the sun waned off

 

The moon calmed the sun to the twilight

It knew it was time to go

Afterall after each passing day

A starry night enthralled.

 

And time stood still as the hands collided

For a brief moment, it traversed beyond

The understanding of lines, vines and trying times

Where all was kin and kin was all.
