title: Blog | Kafkaesque
biliner:
“No one asked for my opinion but I’m going to give it anyway. We have all, at least at times, experienced the Kafkaesque. The uneasiness that you can't escape, entangled anxiety and paranoia, which doesn't allow you to make sense of your surroundings, emotions or feelings.”

Read on as Ishita Mehta (@ishitaaa028), 4th year, SE, attempts to escape the existential dread and metamorphose it into something more appealing.
body:
No one asked for my opinion but I’m going to give it anyway.

We have all, at least at times, experienced the Kafkaesque. The uneasiness that you can't escape, entangled anxiety and paranoia, which doesn't allow you to make sense of your surroundings, emotions or feelings. 

Understanding your own emotions is a long winding, complex and unclear process. But I believe that as complicated, confusing and intriguing emotions are, there is a certain beauty attached to it. I was told to write something on beauty and that led me to think who even decides what is beautiful? It is a social construct after all and anything deemed “desirable” is correlated with beauty.  Emotions can be beautiful too. Happiness and calmness may be beautiful but why not sadness and grief too? As disorienting as they are, they do have a strange familiarity to them. Same with fear, despair and anxiety. By no means am I asking you to romanticise sadness, but the blanket of uneasiness that you carry around with you that allows you to dwell in it, and truly appreciate happiness when it comes. A cup of hot coffee on a cold wintry day and the sublime sun rays permeating a dark room are complementary. So are feelings.

Anger is the fire that, when carefully tended, can forge the tools of change and illuminate the path to a more just and beautiful world. Sadness and grief are the rain that waters the seeds of empathy and understanding, nurturing the roots of compassion that bloom into the gardens of resilience and healing. Envy is the mirror that reflects our aspirations, reminding us of our desires and the potential for growth. It's the spark that, when tempered with self-awareness and motivation, can ignite the flames of determination, driving us to reach for our own stars. Anxiety is the wind that, when harnessed, can set sail on uncharted seas of personal growth and discovery, navigating the turbulent waters of uncertainty to find hidden treasures of strength and resilience.

Humans aren't any way designed to be happy, the matrix made sure of it. But instead of dwelling on it, realise that they are there. Feelings just are. Maybe appreciate them a little more? 

Illustration Credits: Idhika, 1st year, B. Des.

title: Texas Instruments | Internship Experience
biliner:
“After my internship, for my review, my manager expressed his appreciation for how well I gelled with my colleagues and how I was not afraid to ask for help. I was also told that he would put my name for the PPO, and I was delighted when I heard that.” 

Read on as Sidakpreet Singh, EE, Class of 2024, shares his internship experience at Texas Instruments, Inc as an analog EDA (Digital Design) Intern.
body:
“After my internship, for my review, my manager expressed his appreciation for how well I gelled with my colleagues and how I was not afraid to ask for help. I was also told that he would be putting my name for the PPO, and I was delighted when I heard that.”  

Read on as Sidakpreet Singh, EE, Class of 2024, shares his internship experience at Texas Instruments, Inc as an analog EDA (Digital Design) Intern. 

My Preparation Journey

I always strived to do something different and not go with the masses. During my third semester, I gave coding a try, but it never really appealed to me. My senior, Ritik Bhaiya was my key mentor throughout the process. With his guidance, I was able to delve very deep into the world of digital electronics. In the 2 month break after 4th semester, I opted to develop my skills instead of doing an internship. 

Bagging the Internship

I managed to get to the interview round at Texas Instruments fairly early during the internship season.

The interview lasted for almost 2 hours. It began with basic personal questions and gradually progressed into subject-specific questions, to which I responded confidently. However, towards the end, they presented questions related to CMOS, a topic I had limited knowledge of at the time. The relentless questioning about CMOS left me in tears. It was an emotional experience for me, and by the end, I was too drained to ask questions in return. 

I received a call from TI that evening where they asked a few HR questions and asked me whether I would be willing to revise the topics I struggled with during the interview and I eagerly agreed. After the call, my friends were thrilled, but I remained a little sceptical. 

When I received confirmation of my selection the next morning, I was filled with an immense and profound sense of happiness and joy.

I do believe that luck played an important role in my selection. Our classes were mostly online, due to which I could focus on enhancing my skills.

My Experience at Texas Instruments

I had received my offer letter at the beginning of my third year and I joined TI as an analog EDA Intern at the end of my third year. 

My team was called EDA (Electronic Design Automation). It was responsible for designing the software which would facilitate the work of all the other teams.

In the initial days, since I hadn't been allotted a cubicle, I had to share a cubicle with my buddy Pranay who had been working in TI for around 5 years. He was a great guy and I loved sharing a cubicle with him. After a while, the EDA team shifted to another building in the same Techpark where I got my own cubicle. Since this building lacked a proper canteen, we took buses to the main canteen. The entire EDA team would get tea and hang out on the roof for a while sometimes. After lunch, we would walk back from the canteen.

Half of my office floor was occupied by my EDA team, split into development and applications teams. I was part of the applications team, focusing on the backend. 

Initially, for every doubt, I went to my manager. But over time I developed better relationships with my colleagues. With time, I gained an understanding of each person's role and whom to approach for specific doubts. A DTU alumnus was also a part of my team, so it helped me gel with the team easily.

I developed a strong work ethic there and became very punctual. While there were not any fixed hours of work, I worked for many hours in my initial days to prove myself.

During the Internship.

On my first day at Texas Instruments, there was an induction ceremony, and I was introduced to my team. 

My first week was all about getting a brief on the overall flow of things and what was expected of me. I was also instructed to learn about CMOS and learn Python, Perl, and Tshell. A lot of my work had to do with data handling and pattern recognition in data.

In my second week, I was introduced to ICT files. ICT files are used for electromigration analysis for a technology stack. Understanding the data in these files is crucial to ensure the long-term reliability of electronic devices in the long-term.

My first project was to design software that could work on any ICT file of any different type. They were being made manually which took about 1-2 hours each. For each technology, more than 100 ICT files were to be made. My automated code created these 100s of files in 21 seconds. This took me around 1.5 months. My manager was also quite happy with my work in the mid-term review.

My second project was converting .dat to an ICT file. These .dat files were last modified in 2001 and had to be converted. Since the ICT file would only be generated once, I hardcoded it and finished it during the remainder of my tenure at TI.

After my internship, for my review, my manager expressed his appreciation for how well I gelled with my colleagues and how I wasn’t afraid to ask for help. I was also told that he would be putting my name for the PPO, and I was delighted when I heard that. 

During these two months, I learned many valuable lessons. I learned the importance of diversifying one's skill set. Merely focusing on coding or DSA is not sufficient, nor is concentrating solely on hardware. Corporate life taught me the importance of adaptability and the need to embrace the tasks assigned, even if they don't align perfectly with one's initial expectations. 

Some Advice for Juniors:

1. Avoid comparing yourself to others. Everybody’s journey and struggles are different.

2. Don’t simply follow the crowd. During the first few semesters, explore all the different opportunities and discover your own path.

3. Learn Python. It is an excellent language to learn for automation.

4. CGPA is a very important factor and matters a lot. Try to maintain a 9+ CGPA. I know it may seem very difficult, especially for core branches but not unachievable. Basically, grind hard to get the best results!

title: National Taiwan Ocean University | Internship Experience
biliner:
“The best part of my internship was the field trip to marine shrimp aquaculture farms. The interactions with local farmers and hearing how our work positively impacted their lives made it a truly fulfilling experience and one of my most prized memories of the internship. I was surprised by the respect and admiration they held for us and our work.”  
Lakshay Sachdeva, ENE, Class of 2024, shares his internship experience at National Taiwan Ocean University as a core environmental research Intern.
body:
“The best part of my internship was the field trip to marine shrimp aquaculture farms. The interactions with local farmers and hearing how our work positively impacted their lives made it a truly fulfilling experience and one of my most prized memories of the internship. I was surprised by the respect and admiration they held for us and our work.” 

Lakshay Sachdeva, ENE, Class of 2024, shares his internship experience at National Taiwan Ocean University as a core environmental research Intern. 

The Preparation

My journey towards this opportunity had begun long before I had applied for it. Foreign research internships generally require you to have prior research experience in the field you're applying for. I had done 3 research internships during the previous summer and winter breaks in different domains of environmental engineering. Additionally, I was engaged in a couple of research projects under the guidance of several professors. Lastly, I made it my priority to maintain a high CGPA as I believe it can prove to be a differentiating factor. 

The Selection Process

I applied for this internship through the Taiwan Experience Education Program (TEEP) website. There are projects from various disciplines of engineering listed on the website. One must apply directly to the professor in charge of the project via email. Typically, the professors review the student's CV and transcript, followed by an interview to see if they are a right fit for the program or not. Following the submission of the required documents to Professor Tseng, I was interviewed for the position. I got the invitation letter to join as a research intern in Professor Tseng’s lab at National Taiwan Ocean University a week later.

The Onsite Experience

Embarking on this journey initially seemed intimidating, but it was an amazing experience to visit Taiwan for my summer internship. I was fortunate to be accompanied by Omair and Yasa, my batchmates from DTU as fellow interns. Having familiar faces around made it relatively easier to settle in. Despite occasionally encountering language barriers, both the faculty and students I met were consistently eager to help. They very often went above and beyond to make sure I had everything necessary to carry out my responsibilities. The lab members always involved me in discussions and valued my input. 

The Taiwanese people were very warm and welcoming, to the point that it seemed too good to be true sometimes. Even though Taiwan is a small country in terms of landmass, it was baffling to see how much it has to offer. Exploring Taipei, renowned as one of the cleanest and most well-planned cities globally, was a delight.  I loved exploring the nature, lakes, beaches and waterfalls around Taiwan.

The Internship: Highlights, Challenges and Everything in Between

In Professor Tseng's lab, my research centred around performing a comparative study between the YSI ProDSS probe and fluorometric technique for chlorophyll measurement in seawater. I contributed to collecting seawater samples and their on-site analysis from marine shrimp aquaculture farms on Taiwan's eastern coast. I was also responsible for conducting a 3-day lab experiment for gauging the amount of chlorophyll pigment using the fluorophotometer. This study culminated in me making an in-depth report, entailing a review of literature. I also created a research poster for a competition conducted by the University wherein I secured second place.

The best part of my internship was the field trip to marine shrimp aquaculture farms. Professor Tseng rented cars and arranged our accommodations, as that the sampling locations were quite distant. Despite enduring over 12 hours of fieldwork daily in scorching heat, it proved to be a valuable learning experience. I gained insights into the intricacies of sample collection, analysis, and storage during this trip. The interactions with local farmers and hearing how our work positively impacted their lives made it a truly fulfilling experience and one of my most prized memories of the internship. I was surprised by the respect and admiration they held for us and our work.

Professor Tseng played a pivotal role during my time at National Taiwan Ocean University. She went the extra mile to make it easy for me to adjust in the beginning. She was extremely supportive and was available to always answer my queries, ensuring that I had the best learning experience during my time under her guidance. Despite her demanding schedule, she made time to monitor my progress and offer valuable suggestions.

My experience and that of my seniors who did their internships in India were poles apart. This opportunity allowed me to work on a project with a very visible and direct impact on the society and environment.

My Key Takeaway

This internship instilled in me the resilience to remain undeterred by challenges. I had to constantly push my limits in the face of a fast-paced research environment. The final week was super hectic, characterized by mostly sleepless nights, preparing the report and research poster. Nonetheless, this relentless effort paid off, as Professor Tseng was impressed with the quality of my report and presentation. I also secured second place and received a cash prize of 1000 Taiwan dollars in the poster competition. This experience is bound to enhance my prospects of gaining admission to a prestigious institution for higher education.

Advice for Juniors

1. Always be truthful in the interview and never portray yourself as someone you're not. Authenticity is key.

2.Try to gain relevant research experience by working on academic projects and doing internships. Engaging in extracurricular activities and being active in college societies can help create a well-rounded profile.

3. Work hard right from the beginning. CGPA is the key differentiating factor in bagging foreign internships. Try to keep a 9+ CGPA to enhance your chances.

It was a small deliverable, yet it required considerable effort, and I had to work with multiple stakeholders for it. Completing that task and marking it as complete really filled me with joy and a sense of accomplishment.” Abhinav Sharma, CE, Batch of ‘24, shares his experience as a Product Analyst intern at American Express.


Endeavoring for the internship

Throughout the first two years of college, I focused on building a comprehensive profile; thus, I tried to balance academics, extracurriculars, and internships. I feel I am what we call a jack of all trades. I always believed in having spikes in my CV and thus had a plan set in mind to gain those spikes. 

To ensure that my CV got shortlisted for almost all companies, I have maintained a 9+ CGPA over the course of 7 semesters, which became my first spike. 

My second spike — the one I feel was most crucial, were my internships. My internships helped me work on my soft skills as well as sharpen my technical skill set. The exposure and experience I got while working on projects during my internships helped me gain familiarity with the different tools, which became the talking point during my interviews. 

My third spike was my involvement in extracurriculars. I was an active member of two societies, focusing on finance and consulting and helping in positions at both. My role here showcased my leadership skills and how I worked within a team. To sum it up, a well-rounded profile with relevant work experience allowed me to have great interviews with the recruiter, who showed great interest in my resume. 

Into the Internship

I was a part of the CFR CoE at American Express, working with the New Accounts Credit Risk team. Any applicant who wishes to apply for an Amex card has to open a new account. Once the application is submitted, a series of credit and fraud risk checks are performed to assess the creditworthiness of the applicant and decide on card approval. My team essentially worked on the backend of this process and the implementation and authoring of risk rules against which an application was tested for all global markets.

There were four rounds in total, of which three were in-person rounds. The first round was CV shortlisting. Next, we had a GD in round 2. Post-round, I was unsure of my qualification chances, as I felt that I didn't grab enough opportunities to speak. However, ultimately, remaining calm during the round, maintaining a positive demeanour towards the recruiters, and putting forward my points in a crisp and concise manner helped. Following this, we had an interview in round 3, where the recruiter asked us about the things mentioned in our resume, our technical skills, knowledge of guesstimates and case studies. Finally, the last round was a short HR interview round. The overall interview experience was smooth, and I feel all candidates were interviewed in great detail.

The project I worked on had a high business impact and was all done in real time. Working on an actual project and impacting thousands of customers made it an enriching experience for me.

 

The Amex experience and takeaways

My experience working at American Express was truly delightful, and I’d say Amex really lived up to my expectations. All employees, including interns, were provided with perks like free food, pick-up and drop-off facilities, and the ability to work from home. As a standard, all teams would come to the office twice a week, where I’d meet my team members as well as my managers and other leaders.

The most memorable moment for me was when I was able to successfully complete my first official project deliverable after almost a month of training and shadow projects. It was a small deliverable, yet it required considerable effort, and I had to work with multiple stakeholders for it. Finishing that task and marking it as complete filled me with joy and a sense of accomplishment.

The best thing about Amex were the people I got to work with — everyone was so helpful and welcoming. Everyone supported me throughout my 8-week journey and cleared any and every doubt I had. I was entrusted with key deliverables, allowing me to gain confidence. At the end of my internship, when I was asked why I’d want to come back, the reason I gave was the kind of people I met here and the work culture.

My overall takeaway would be to not be overwhelmed when stepping out of your comfort zone. During my initial weeks, I was completely perplexed by the nature of the work I was assigned, and it was something entirely different from what I had expected it to be. Knowing that it wasn’t something I had experience in or how I would move from there to the roles I fancied, it all seemed like an impossible nut to crack. However, soon I remembered an important thing that I had learned through a TEDx talk, which said that you should always be open to grabbing new opportunities, no matter how difficult they may seem at the beginning, as you never know where they may take you.

 

Advice for the aspirers

My advice to everyone seeking placements would be to always plan for things in advance. I feel that everyone should plan for their goals and have a rough idea in mind as to what they wish to achieve and what steps are to be taken for the same in a given timeframe. Proper planning ensures that you do not waste time doing things haphazardly, which are often irrelevant to your goals. I planned my college journey right from year one; the effort I put in my first two years paid off in the final two, where I was pretty relaxed and did not have to take stress or scramble for internships and placements. So always have a plan, tick off things that get done along the way, and be laser-focused on your goals.

title: Microsoft | Internship Experience
biliner:
“In the initial weeks, I admit, I had some doubts. I was anxious and not entirely sure if I could meet the requirements. To address this uncertainty, I committed myself to rigorous study, dedicating nearly 10 hours a day to understanding the project's nuances. I began my work days early, arriving at the office at 8 AM and often returning home well past 10 or 11 PM.  While it might seem like a grueling schedule, I did not take it as a con, instead I reveled in the fact that I had gotten an opportunity to work hard, and to be a part of a team making a real difference”. 
Mehak Garg, IT, Class of 2024, shares her internship experience at Microsoft as a Software Developer Intern.
body:
“In the initial weeks, I admit, I had some doubts. I was anxious and not entirely sure if I could meet the requirements. To address this uncertainty, I committed myself to rigorous study, dedicating nearly 10 hours a day to understanding the project's nuances. I began my work days early, arriving at the office at 8 AM and often returning home well past 10 or 11 PM.  While it might seem like a gruelling schedule, I did not take it as a con, instead, I revelled in the fact that I had gotten an opportunity to work hard, and to be a part of a team making a real difference”

Mehak Garg, IT, Class of 2024, shares her internship experience at Microsoft as a Software Developer Intern.

MY PREPARATION JOURNEY

I began my journey with a straightforward plan: "Daily consistency", and although it just started with a "for and while" loop, I was solving one coding question every day till I secured the internship offer.

1. Build your interest: I think that a passion for technology is not  present from the very beginning;it is nurtured as we do more and more questions every day. For me, it was the moment when those red lines started turning into green; "Accepted" – that was the moment when I truly began to cultivate what we call "interest."

2. Daily Coding Practice: I made it a habit to engage in some form of coding daily, even if it was just an easy gig question or a mere YouTube lecture.

3. DSA: After learning the basics, I advanced to Data Structures and Algorithms, following Love Babbar's sheet, and combining it with LeetCode and GeeksforGeeks questions.

4. Projects: After this, my focus shifted to having at least two projects, the kind where I could explain every line of code even if it's not mine. It's not about creating a huge project from scratch.

5. Advice from seniors: Listening to experienced seniors should be a must in anyone's journey. I showed my seniors my resume and gathered countless feedback from each of them in an attempt to refine my resume.

6. Mock Interviews: In the final stages, I underwent 2-3 mock interviews which were taken by my friends. This helped me fine-tune my interview skills and bolstered my confidence. If you ever find yourself struggling with English, just jot down everything you have to say, repeat it once a day, and you'll make great strides in no time.

Remember whether your preparation comes to fruition or not; whether you get the internship or not, just don't give up, until it's over.


THE APPLICATION PROCESS

The process for getting selected for the internship at Microsoft was an extensive journey that spanned over two months. Here's a brief:

1. Resume Shortlisting: The process initiated with the initial resume screening, where Microsoft assessed the qualifications and experiences of applicants.

2. Two Coding Rounds: Following the resume shortlisting, I faced two coding rounds. These rounds typically included questions of easy to moderate difficulty.

3. Mentorship (ML-Based Project): After progressing through the coding rounds, I was fortunate to embark on a mentorship journey. I was given 21 days for a Machine learning-based project, learning everything from scratch to present a real-time demonstration. This experience taught me how everything is possible even in a limited time frame and one has to give everything they have got.

4. Final Technical Interview: Upon successful completion of the ML-based project, my project was selected, leading to the final technical interview. This round encompassed Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA), questions on Object-Oriented Programming (OOP), Operating Systems (OS), and Database Management Systems (DBMS). Clear and effective communication was imperative during this stage, as it makes you more credible as a candidate.

After successfully navigating these rounds, the heartwarming moment arrived when I received a congratulations email, marking the end of the 2-month selection process.


THE INTERVIEW

Before the interview, there was a mix of excitement and apprehension. I knew that I had put in the effort to prepare for the process. While I had confidence in my preparation, the unknown factor of how the interviews would unfold naturally brought a touch of nervousness.

However, the moment I found myself in the virtual meeting room with the interviewer, a certain warmth was established. I got to know that the interviewers are not intimidating figures, but rather are very kind and simple.

One valuable perspective that I strongly believe is the realization that the company has intentions to hire me. So, it wasn't an obligation on their part, that they are offering me a job; rather, it's them who are looking for real and rare skills and talents. This mindset shift, understanding that you have something valuable to offer, is something I believe you should inculcate to boost your confidence.

So, during the interview rounds, I encountered a balanced mix of questions. These included one easy and one medium-level LeetCode question, testing my problem-solving and coding abilities. Furthermore, the deep dive into my projects allowed them to evaluate how well I could think when I was trying to solve something impromptu on the spot. Additionally, questions from Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) and Database Management Systems (DBMS) were asked to test my knowledge in these essential tech subjects.

It's perfectly normal to feel a bit nervous before the interview. However, once you're face-to-face with the interviewers, let go of fear and embrace the perspective that it's you who is offering your skills and talents. If you've prepared diligently, those initial nerves will vanish in mere moments. In fact, you'll find yourself eagerly awaiting more questions, wanting to showcase how well you've prepared, and eager for the opportunity to demonstrate your capabilities.

MY INTERNSHIP JOURNEY

My journey at Microsoft was an experience, marked by invaluable learning, incredible mentors, and a lot of support from my manager. From the very beginning, I was surrounded by helpful individuals who made me feel at home there.

On the first day, I was filled with excitement but was extremely nervous. I was introduced to my team, and as I looked around, I realized that we were part of one of the thousands of teams working together to make an impact.

The first day at Microsoft left me in awe of the beautiful campus and the high scale of its operations. The sights of golf carts to travel between buildings, nap rooms, phone rooms, and the striking interior design were just the beginning of what Microsoft had to offer.

One remarkable aspect of the Microsoft Office place where I worked was the freedom and flexibility it offered. You could stay back at the office if needed, and there were nap rooms available. So, when I was working on my final presentation, I stayed back at the office without any restrictions. The office space felt like a safe and comfortable home, and you had the complete freedom to choose where to work, what to do, and how long to stay.

Moreover, the Microsoft Office was a sight to behold at night. The office had a beautiful ambience, and the views from the top floor were picturesque, which made me feel extremely peaceful and relaxed.

In the initial weeks, I admit, I had some doubts. I was anxious and not entirely sure if I could meet the requirements. To address this uncertainty, I committed myself to rigorous study, dedicating nearly 10 hours a day to understanding the project's nuances. I began my work days early, arriving at the office at 8 AM and often returning home well past 10 or 11 PM.

While it might seem like a gruelling schedule, I did not take it as a con, instead, I revelled in the fact that I had gotten an opportunity to work hard and to be a part of a team making a real difference.

So, in the 4th week, the project gradually began to take shape and make progress. The journey was a transformation, and my last day was filled with numerous learnings, emotional moments, and cherished memories. It was a chapter I will never be able to forget throughout my life.

MY ROLE, RESPONSIBILITIES AND GETTING TO WORK WITH NEW TECHNOLOGY

As an intern at Microsoft, I had the opportunity to work on an intriguing project within the expansive realm of Microsoft's Hyderabad location. In my case, I was assigned to collaborate with the SAP developers within the team called "Commerce Plus Ecosystem, Commercial Financial Services, Cloud + AI,"

My role primarily revolved around utilizing Python and Azure cloud services to streamline and optimize the daily operations of SAP developers. This involved a significant learning curve, as I was relatively new to the domain of cloud computing. To bridge this knowledge gap, I delved into the numerous documentation and resources provided by Microsoft,

To give a gist, my responsibilities were to develop automation solutions that would enhance the efficiency of SAP developers. This entailed automating the process of generating ABAP code, segmenting it into logical sections, deciphering its pseudocode, and documenting it at the push of a trigger. Furthermore, I worked on automating the process of updating the documentation whenever changes occurred in the original code, integrating it with Azure DevOps for production.

Initially, the project posed significant challenges, and I was met with moments of doubt. However, the key to surmounting such difficulties lies in studying as much as you can.


WORK CULTURE AT MICROSOFT

The work culture at Microsoft, during my internship, was quite flexible. You could choose when and how long you worked. Full-time employees usually worked from 10 to 5, but interns like me often worked late. There was no pressure from managers or mentors; they encouraged us to take breaks, make friends, and go home early. We had a manageable workload, and we could ask for more work if we wanted. Overall, it was a balanced and supportive environment.

I also made great connections with fellow interns from colleges across India. We all got along well and had a cheerful experience working together.

SETBACKS, CHALLENGES AND PUSHING FORWARD

My intern experience was quite different from what my seniors had described. In the second week of my internship, I contracted dengue fever, which was a major setback. I was in a new city where I didn't know anyone, and falling ill at such a crucial time was challenging. I had to be admitted to the hospital, and I remained sick for a complete two weeks. I eventually flew back home and started working from home. After recovering, I went back to Hyderabad to continue my internship.

This experience taught me some valuable lessons. It reinforced the importance of not giving up, even in the face of adversity. It showed me the significance of persisting through difficult times. When you're determined to make things right, even in challenging situations, you can overcome them. I managed to complete the day-one requirements of my project on time, and I received immense support from my team during this challenging phase. I even had the best presentation on the floor.

My internship was a rollercoaster of highs and lows, and I faced some tough times, but I didn't lose hope. In the end, things turned out well, and I learned that perseverance and determination can help you overcome even the most challenging obstacles.

ADVICE FOR JUNIORS

"We have to make a determination and take action. Unless we do so, our environment will not change in the least, though 5 or 10 years may pass, "that time" will never arrive.
"That time" is the moment you resolve from the depths of your heart,
"Now I will stand up and fight!"
From that instant, your destiny changes. Your life develops. History begins."

This quote has been a steadfast beacon of inspiration in my life and it resounds in my mind, especially during moments of doubt and despair. It's the reminder that "that time" is not a distant event but a moment of inner resolve, a commitment etched in the very depths of the heart, to boldly declare, "Now, I will stand up and give everything I have got!".

For those who are now reading my story, my fundamental philosophy regarding the commencement of preparation is simple: take that first step, no matter how small. Just start, perhaps with one question a day, or one documentation task daily. Then, gradually amplify your efforts, pushing yourself to tackle two, three, or more questions each day. It's the act of taking that initial action that sets the wheels of progress.

At first it was an adjustment for me since it was my first corporate job. I wasn't sure if I could just talk to people or ask questions. But everyone was very friendly. They treated me like family even though I was much younger. I ended up becoming the only intern who was given a very good farewell party.”

 

Sanyam Maheshwari, IT, Class of 2024, shares his internship experience at Walmart Global Tech as a Software Developer Intern. 

MY PREPARATION JOURNEY

Basically the preparation is all about two things: You have to go through all the DSA concepts and questions along with preparation for the Core. 

For DSA, I did a lot of questions on LeetCode and CodeForces. For Core, I just went through YouTube videos, lectures and guides.The selection process started off with an online assessment. So in the online assessment there were a few questions based exactly on the core topics such as OS, DBMS etc. So working on that is really important. Also solving problems on LeetCode is very important as well.

INTERNSHIP SELECTION PROCESS

To get an internship at Walmart, you have to go through three rounds where they select 150 people. The rounds were mainly focused around the online assessments. While Walmart doesn't directly recruit on campus, they have partnerships with about 15 schools across India. Students from those schools can participate in the online assessment. The three rounds include a multiple choice question round and two coding challenges. Once you complete those rounds, you'll get the internship. From DTU, about 30 students were chosen. 

Once you start the internship, it's a two and a half month program located in Bangalore at Walmart Global Tech. Then if you want a full-time job, you'll have internal interviews. They don't actually do interviews at the beginning of the internship to give you the role. Instead, interviews are conducted at the end of the internship period. During that time, they'll assign you some problems to work on as well as development work. The interviews will also include data structure and algorithms questions. 

For me, there was only one round of interviews, but the number can vary depending on your manager's review.

THOUGHTS AFTER GETTING SELECTED:

When I got the internship, I was relaxed. I wasn't doing any DSA after that. I did do more CP after some time because in my mind I was too focused on getting a full-time offer. The internship was just for two months, it wasn't a long term goal. I got the internship in September. For two months I had nothing to do, so I was just relaxing, because I had done a lot of work before getting the internship. 

The season we're in now is very uncertain. People aren't getting many job opportunities. It was quite clear from the start that big companies and many companies weren't hiring people. There was a bit of fear I think among all of us. I would wake up at around 9 and go to the office till 5, then come back to my PG and study DSA for 2-3 hours. After that I would rest again and study more DSA. So those 2-3 months were a real struggle. But it worked out pretty well for me in the end.

MY FIRST DAY AT WALMART

So my first day as an intern was really memorable. As I mentioned, my manager had never had an intern before. He was used to only having full-time employees working with him. So on the first day, all the other managers were calling their interns to check in, and get to know them. I was sitting in the room hoping I'd get a call soon. They said calls would start around 3, but it was 3:45 and I hadn't heard anything. 

I was officially assigned a team lead, but two days went by and I still hadn't connected with them. Finally on the third day, my manager realized what was happening around. He said "Oh, I was looking for you but I didn't have your contact info."  We both had a good laugh about it later, and it made for an interesting start to my internship for sure!

GETTING SETTLED IN

At Walmart I was there with a team which was very experienced. My manager had been with the company for a long time, since they first started in India. He had a team of 40 people who were all very experienced, in their 40s and 50s. 

At first, it was an adjustment for me since it was my first corporate job experience. I wasn't very sure if I could just talk to people or ask questions. But everyone was very friendly. They treated me like family even though I was much younger. I ended up becoming the  only intern who was given a very good farewell party.

It also took some getting used to living in a hotel by myself and in no time I began feeling homesick. 

Work became my escape. I'd look forward to going into the office each day from 9 to 5. Once everyone left at the end of the day, it was tough. I'd just be waiting around, not wanting to go back to the hotel.

The Walmart office holds special memories for me in this regard. It was a refuge when I needed to get away from the loneliness of the hotel. I really cherished the time there with my colleagues each day. It provided me great comfort during a difficult time away from home. Work became more than just a job - it was a place I could go to feel less isolated and be more around people who respected and supported me. The Walmart office will always remind me of that period. It became a home away from home. 

The team really came through with helping me adjust and made me feel more included. They gave me a lot of opportunities as well. One time, a head from the American setup of Walmart visited. I was the only intern who got to present my ideas to her and discuss them. She was very interested in what I had to say, and even invited me out for lunch to talk more about them. I felt like my ideas were given importance.

INNOVATION, RESPONSIBILITIES AND NEW IDEAS

So in my role at Walmart Global Tech, I was responsible for the Global Tech Platform, or GTP. As you may know, Walmart is an enormous company with annual revenue of around $663 billion. Even a brief outage of their website can result in losses of millions of dollars very quickly. My team's job was to help prevent those outages and save Walmart a lot of money. 

Within GTP, I focused on site reliability engineering. The goal of that team is to reduce technical debt at Walmart by identifying issues that could lead to vulnerabilities if not addressed. A big part of my job was reporting "artifact violations".  An artifact is basically any software or application deployed on Walmart's servers.

I had to find all instances where an older version of an artifact was being used when a newer version was available. Keeping software updated is important both for performance and security. Outdated versions can have known issues or vulnerabilities that have been fixed in subsequent releases. If Walmart was still using an older version, it could potentially expose them to risks down the line. 

To report these violations, I automated a process to make it more efficient. I would search GitHub repositories for the artifacts and identify who the largest contributor was. From there, I could find their manager in Walmart's HR database. The system would then create a ticket that was assigned to that manager, notifying them of the violation. 

This was a big improvement because previously identifying and assigning responsibility for these issues was a manual process that had been bottlenecked for years. By automating the workflow, my work helped Walmart significantly reduce technical debt and vulnerabilities, potentially saving millions in avoided costs from preventing even brief outages. Even saving seconds of downtime could translate to huge savings for a company the size of Walmart. So my technology ended up being very useful to them.

CORPORATE WORLD: TAKEAWAYS FOR THE FUTURE

The most important thing I learned would be to understand that everyone is just human. It's easy to get caught up in thinking of a big corporation as some intimidating machine, but at the end of the day it's really just made up of people. As long as you treat everyone with respect, you'll find that the environment can be pretty relaxed. 

My team made me feel really welcome during my internship. I think that's because I made an effort to respect everyone, no matter their role or experience level. I listened to their ideas, and the same gesture was reciprocated, even though many of them had been in the industry way longer than me.

It really comes down to this - we're all people. We all have lives and feelings outside of work. As long as you approach everyone with that understanding and respect their humanity, you'll do just fine navigating any corporate environment. The relationships you build will make your job much more enjoyable too.

title: Ayra: An Innovative Venture to Bolster Menstrual Hygiene
biliner:
"Currently, there is a taboo in most households, but I think this has moved forward to an extent. College students nowadays do not shy away from talking about this. Some families still have this taboo. I recently saw someone celebrating their daughter’s first period in Uttarakhand, so I guess it is changing, but it still is a bit slow."
In her interview with DTU Times, Ira Jhakar, founder of Ayra, an innovative venture to bolster menstrual hygiene, talks about how she aims to make a positive impact with her product.
body:
What is your start-up about? 

Ayra is India's first menstrual marketplace offering a one-stop shop for all menstrual products.

Our mission is to build a niche menstrual marketplace, provide a larger product portfolio, provide accessibility and offer a personalised solution catering to real world issues around women's wellness.

How did you start your product? 

I once participated in an event called Techstars Startup Event where we had to come up with an idea in 72 hours. It was there that I initiated this idea. When I received good reviews for it, I took it forward to the DTU professors and started working on it from my first year onwards. 

What sets you apart from the already available sanitary pads? 

Firstly, our pads are 100% organic and biodegradable. The main thing that sets us apart is the anion chip technology in our sanitary pads. The anion chip technology releases negative ions that help in removing the odour from the menstrual discharge. It also helps in blood circulation and overall well-being during menstruation. 

How did you present your idea to the DTU IIF? 

We had the support of Pushpendra Sir, who managed all the incubations in the East Campus. I don’t even remember how I approached him, but after discussing the idea with him, he liked it a lot, and took care of all further processes. 

Since the target consumer is female, is it the case that there are more females in the workforce?

No, it is not like that. Most of my interns and team members are males. You need to sit with them and explain things to them. Eventually, it ends up working quite well.

What kind of tips do you give on Instagram? 

For giving suggestions or tips, you need to build a community of people who trust you, listen to you and don’t feel shy in talking to you. We are building that community and giving general health tips, for example, spreading menstrual hygiene awareness, giving advice on how one should talk to their daughter about her first period, etc. 

Do you feel there is a taboo in society about this topic?

Yes, currently, there is a taboo in most households, but I think this has moved forward to an extent. College students nowadays do not shy away from talking about this. Some families still have this taboo. I recently saw someone celebrating their daughter’s first period in Uttarakhand, so I guess it is changing, but it still is a bit slow. 

Where do you see Ayra in ten years from now?

I want to see Ayra as one menstrual brand which caters to all tiers of the society. We are currently focusing on the first and second tier, but going forward we will be looking towards making organic and sustainable products for the third and fourth tier as well.

title: Edition 61 | Interview- Prof. S. Indu, Former Vice-chancellor, DTU
biliner:
“Bringing a smile to the faces of those I talk to feels like one of my biggest achievements for the day. I hope to continue working here with the same enthusiasm and optimism despite the formal restrictions of my office.”
In a recent interview, DTU Times spoke to Prof. S. Indu regarding her role as an interim vice-chancellor, women in STEM and student entrepreneurship amongst many other things.
body:
Being appointed as the Vice Chancellor of our university, what have been the subtle changes in your life post this achievement?

Being the vice chancellor of such a prestigious institution is a huge responsibility. At first, I felt unsure about whether I would be able to do justice to this demanding role despite my prior experiences in administration. However, because this is my university and I know the grassroot problems, I could understand and deal with the challenges of this position and adjust well with the support of my peers and fellow professors. 

You have had an incredible career advancement — from Head of Department, ECE, to Dean of Student Welfare, and now the Vice Chancellor. What are your expectations from this role?

Many people believe in the saying— “Aim for the moon, and you'll land amongst the stars”. Personally, however, I am not like that. I believe in setting realistic, achievable goals for myself and giving my hundred per cent for them. I don't believe in planning or thinking much about the future. Instead, I believe things keep falling into place as you work upon them in the present. As an example, I never thought I would reach this position when I joined as a lecturer here initially. Therefore, I'm really content with where I am in life right now.

 What are your primary goals and priorities now that you are in office?

The priority for us is kick-starting the Career Advancement Incentives to the faculty members, which were up to date and regular at the time of Prof. Yogesh Singh. Such programmes, however, remained pending and unattended in the previous two years. By resuming these once again, I hope the faculty members are satisfied with getting what is due to them, and things keep progressing smoothly in the future.

Improving the university infrastructure is also a priority for me. Through my previous experience as Dean of Student Welfare, I am aware of the problems faced by the students and the staff members, especially in the hostels. With this office, I hope to address and resolve these concerns for the benefit of all.

You have been very popular amongst the students as the Dean of Student Welfare. What have been your key learnings from this post?

Bringing a smile to the faces of those I talk to feels like one of my biggest achievements for the day. I hope to continue working here with the same enthusiasm and optimism despite the formal restrictions of my office.

As the first female vice-chancellor of the university, you bring a fresh perspective to its administration. What steps would you take to empower the female students?

I feel that community engagement is paramount to students' development, and plans are already in motion to allot female students common rooms in departments to foster such engagement, which I had earlier found lacking. Further, crèche facilities for female staff members, initiated under Prof. Yogesh Singh are being improved and reimplemented for their betterment. Such plans were heavily impacted during the COVID-19 years due to lack of access and funding. I hope to launch more such projects in the future as well.

In elementary education, female educators dominate, but this trend diminishes as one progresses towards higher education, particularly in STEM institutions. How do you wish to address this?

The number of women in STEM schools is considerably less than that of men, which translates to a lack of representation in leadership and teaching roles in these environments. Perhaps reservations up to 10% can be increased for women staff members to level the playing field. Bias against women remains in STEM fields, which is not beneficial for the development of society in general. Outreach activities can also be conducted at school level to encourage girls to become engineers and scientists.

Do you have any role models in your life?

Two people have had a great impact on my life, the first being my doctorate guide, Prof. Shantanu Chaudhary. He is a very humble and down-to-earth person. A perfectionist, he not only pushed us to achieve our best but also inspired us to motivate our students to reach their full potential as well.

Prof. Yogesh Singh is a great source of inspiration for me. During his time in office, he worked tirelessly for the advancement and upliftment of our university, and it is only now that we are enjoying the fruits of his labour.

How do you plan on encouraging entrepreneurship amongst the students in the university?

The Incubation Centre has been launched previously with such an intention in mind and receives funding to support the students with grants. Further, facilities are also in place for students to take a break from their degree to pursue and develop such projects and then continue their studies again. Such measures, with regular and enthusiastic implementation, can greatly foster entrepreneurial spirit in the university.

title: Edition 61 | Interview - Nirmal Yadav
biliner:
“Solar energy can be exploited exceedingly well in India. We live in the subtropical zone - the solar radiance here is much higher than in many countries. I think that is an advantage we should capitalise on.” 

In his interview with DTU Times, Nirmal Yadav, founder of Ezinore, a venture focusing on sustainable energy, talks about using data from sunlight, weather, and user habits to make solar power more efficient.
body:
Walk us through the whole concept and development of your start-up.

The name of our company is Ezinore Pvt. Ltd. We are involved in the sustainable energy generation sector and develop storage management systems. We take data from different factors like solar radiance, weather conditions, and usage patterns to analyse and predict user consumption patterns to maximise the efficiency produced by the solar panels and the energy stored at any particular time in the system. 

Is your start-up restricted to solar energy?

Currently, yes, but we plan to extend it to wind energy as well.

What motivated you to enter this field?

I always had this determination to start my venture. I joined Enactus, which deals with sustainability and renewable energy. After that, I joined Eythor Pvt. Ltd., a solar panel-oriented start-up. There, I explored and identified the gaps between renewable energy integration into the normal grid system at residential as well as commercial levels. That’s how I came up with this idea. I am still exploring more about the problems that a user faces at the residential or commercial level in terms of energy management, energy generation, and energy storage.

You use AI in your venture to increase the efficiency of it all. What is its role in it?

We are using AI to analyse the data we obtain from previous usage patterns, including solar irradiance and weather conditions in that area. After analysing the data, the AI will predict the user pattern such as at what particular time the user will be consuming how much power, and how much is the requirement, and based on all these data points, it will manage the energy distribution to fulfil that load.

How do you receive your data?

We are partnering with the Ministry of Power and getting data from smart meters at residential and commercial levels. At the end of the AI procedure, we will be able to implement our systems in any household. It will take around eight weeks to analyse the data and train our AI algorithm according to that household or commercial unit. Thus, we will have our AI working in the implementation process as well.

Would you call it an AI-based venture? Or do you also provide the materials like solar panels?

AI is used only in terms of the product development aspect. However, after that is completed, we will focus more on energy storage and generation systems. So, we will be providing renewable energy generation-related equipment and infrastructure. We will be open to its implementation as well. If the user has it implemented already, we will help them integrate tech connectivity with it.

There is already a huge non-renewable energy market. How do you think you will compete?

The word ‘non-renewable’ is very self-explanatory. You cannot replace it. At this time, it is almost crucial and imminent that you convert your lifestyle from conventional to renewable energy generation sources. Alternatives have been discovered and made commercial. It is only a matter of implementation. We have progressed a lot. We need to gear up the practical usage of this. Solar energy can be exploited exceedingly well in India. We live in the subtropical zone - the solar radiance here is much higher than in many countries. I think that is an advantage we should capitalise on.

What do you have to say about the growing competition in the renewable energy generation market? How can you make yourself stand out?

Most of those companies are investing in building giant power plants. They are supplying energy directly to the DISCOMs. The main problem we are catering to is that the rate of production of solar energy is Rs. 2 per unit, but the user gets it at around Rs. 6.5 per unit. This difference creates a gap between energy production and user consumption, thus affecting prices. We are a more accessible, more on-the-ground type of venture. As for cost-friendly, what is there for us to compete against?

How did you manage your academics alongside managing a start-up?

I think the university provides an atmosphere as well as a very comfortable academic calendar, which makes it easy to manage both.

Is your family supportive of your start-up?

Initially, my family wasn’t very supportive, but I explained everything and gave them time to understand my idea, and expressed how valuable their support would be to me. My family has no relation to business or being risk-takers. So I had to dismantle their ‘playing-safe’ mentality and get them on a ‘gambler’s path’.

How did you formulate your idea into a venture? How did you prepare a workforce?

I had the idea in my mind for a long time; I just never had the time to think more about it. But in university, I got the time. My first step was research - I studied the generation, consumption, implementation, and capitalisation of these energy sources, the investors, and the top companies in this domain. After that, I got the USIP internship where we did some work in preparing a pitch and presenting it in competitions. We won some cash prizes. Then, Rohit came along, our head designer, who took care of all the design aspects. Now, we’re a funded venture, which allows us to maintain a team of twelve. There are divisions in our company as well: the design division, headed by Rohit, the hardware division, led by Ishan, and the app development division, headed by Gopal.

Where do you see your start-up ten years from now?

I want to expand my venture in the Middle East and other ASEAN countries. I believe we will do well, fingers crossed. As for my team, we are constantly expanding it. The intricacies of running a start-up are becoming complex, which requires more people. But as I always say, making a team is always easier than retaining a team. I want this to become an Engineering Procurement and Construction (EPC) Company.

Any advice you'd like to give to students who wish to become an entrepreneur?

Explore - get all the knowledge on your field of interest. Follow that with dedication. Immerse yourself. Completely and wholeheartedly.

In her interview with DTU Times, Ira Jakhar, founder of Ayra, an innovative venture to bolster menstrual hygiene, talks about how she aims to make a positive impact with her product.
body:
What is your start-up about? 

Ayra is India's first menstrual marketplace offering a one-stop shop for all menstrual products.

Our mission is to build a niche menstrual marketplace, provide a larger product portfolio, provide accessibility and offer a personalised solution catering to real world issues around women's wellness.

How did you start your product? 

I once participated in an event called Techstars Startup Event where we had to come up with an idea in 72 hours. It was there that I initiated this idea. When I received good reviews for it, I took it forward to the DTU professors and started working on it from my first year onwards. 

What sets you apart from the already available sanitary pads? 

Firstly, our pads are 100% organic and biodegradable. The main thing that sets us apart is the anion chip technology in our sanitary pads. The anion chip technology releases negative ions that help in removing the odour from the menstrual discharge. It also helps in blood circulation and overall well-being during menstruation. 

How did you present your idea to the DTU IIF? 

We had the support of Pushpendra Sir, who managed all the incubations in the East Campus. I don’t even remember how I approached him, but after discussing the idea with him, he liked it a lot, and took care of all further processes. 

Since the target consumer is female, is it the case that there are more females in the workforce?

No, it is not like that. Most of my interns and team members are males. You need to sit with them and explain things to them. Eventually, it ends up working quite well.

What kind of tips do you give on Instagram? 

For giving suggestions or tips, you need to build a community of people who trust you, listen to you and don’t feel shy in talking to you. We are building that community and giving general health tips, for example, spreading menstrual hygiene awareness, giving advice on how one should talk to their daughter about her first period, etc.

Yes, currently, there is a taboo in most households, but I think this has moved forward to an extent. College students nowadays do not shy away from talking about this. title: Edition 61 | Interview - Ananya Mittal
biliner: “My basic motivation is serving the public. The nature of the job is also something that excites me, every day is a new challenge.” DTU Times interviewed Mr. Ananya Mittal, IAS officer. Read on as he illuminates his motivation to keep excelling and what led him there.
body:
After completing your bachelor's from DTU in Mechanical Engineering, you pursued an M.A. in Public Management from JNU. What made you take this step in building your career in the long run? 

I appeared for civil services straight after my B. Tech. and during my two-year training at LBSNAA, I completed my M.A. which is a course requirement at LBSNAA. It’s a valuable asset considering that is what we do here in services. It teaches us how to manage human resources even when we are faced with a lack of manpower and a shortage of resources. I’ve used such qualities from the very first day of my posting, so I’m sure that an M.A. in public management has helped me more than my B. Tech. from DTU.

People who clear the UPSC examination are a cut above the rest of the student demographic in India. When and why did you wish to go towards the prospects of being an IAS officer, and how did you prepare for it?

I come from a business background; my father is a businessman and my family has always been a huge factor in my push towards a stellar education. I’d heard about IAS officers in school and college from friends and family alike, and during my B. Tech., I realised I did not want to go for a career as an engineer. The only idea that remained in my head was UPSC. Business was always a fallback option, but I did not want to pursue business either. I wanted to make a greater impact, and civil services would’ve provided me with that system. As I started preparing, I realised that there was a large portion of our history and culture that got neglected. The study of general knowledge truly widened my horizons about all sorts of information. 

What was the role of your family while you were preparing for UPSC?

My family’s support was very important. They never restricted me in any way, rather they motivated me to achieve the end goal. Whenever I was unhappy with my preparation, they moved around with me and tried to look for a solution along with me. For me, personally having the luxury of a family business to fall back on was also a huge relief. 

Tell us more about life in Jharkhand and how you rose from the position of Sub-Divisional Magistrate to the District Collector.

Jharkhand is a place that offers me immense opportunities, it is an aspirational area. There are primarily tribal-dominated areas, under-developed areas and even a few naxal-hit areas. These sorts of places are ones where civil services can make a difference. My first posting was in Dhanbad, as SDM. In Dhanbad, I was fascinated by Wasseypur at the time. The role of the SDM is mainly regulatory, and during my time there, it allowed me to understand the nature of the work I’d be doing and it helped me grasp the basics of the work. Later on, I was posted in the city of Simdega. A place with a mere 6 lakh people population to its name at the time, Simdega was an entirely different world from the bustling city life I had grown up in and become accustomed to. It was a tribal-dominated area, with many first-generational learners. There was no electricity in the area, most villagers did not own a cellphone and there were also no internet provisions in the place at the time. It was there I learnt about the importance of civil servants in such a place. 

How did it feel to be lauded and recognised by the country when you received the Bhoomi Samman Award? 

I’m honoured to receive such a prestigious award, it's very encouraging. We worked on the digitisation of land records so that they can be easily accessible to all. Land is a complicated subject for the public; knowing which land is restricted, which land is government land, which land is private- all these queries can now be answered on a digital platform which is accessible to the general public. 

What motivates you to keep excelling in your job? 

My basic motivation is serving the public. The nature of the job is also something that excites me, every day is a new challenge. One gets to hold various posts and thus learn different things owing to the nature of the work the respective post demands. And of course, the encouragement from your seniors, the people working in your department, and ceremonies where all your good work is lauded is also a source of motivation.

A lot of students are astray when it comes to preparing for the civil services. What piece of advice would you give to the same, and enlighten us on the tips and tricks? 

UPSC as we know is arguably one of the toughest exams in India. Sincerity and hard work are invaluable qualities in one’s preparation. It is very important to understand the complete syllabus and decide what one needs to study. Reading newspapers and garnering more and more information about anything and everything is crucial.

Are there any similarities between preparing for UPSC and preparing for JEE?

One basic difference is that JEE is an analytical-type exam, with mathematics and logical reasoning-type questions. UPSC involves a basic understanding of any particular issue. The subjects are entirely different of course. One has Arts-oriented subjects and one has scientific and mathematically oriented subjects. The similarity lies in the hard work and sincerity aspect of preparation. The biggest difference, I’d say, is that you can expect a certain set of questions in JEE, there is an element of predictability in the manner of questions. But in UPSC, every question, every year is different. The syllabus is expanding every year, it is a very dynamic exam compared to the static JEE exam.

How can a civilian help in the development of the nation without joining the services?

I think the scope of citizens has expanded. We too take help from many organisations in our work, including NGOs, and civil society organisations. Even private organisations have been actively participating through CSR. Each and every citizen is a contributor. Earlier, the services had been regulatory, but now we have evolved into a facilitator. As a facilitator, you have to bring together various organisations and provide leadership so that we can all collectively work together for the betterment of the nation.

title: Edition 61 | Lex Talionis
biliner:
“I calm my body and tread the smothering waters gently. I have struggled against the dark waters for so long, screamed myself hoarse, all in the hopes that someone above the surface would hear me. Maybe they won’t. No - maybe I don’t need them to.”

Read on as Charvi Solanki, 3rd Year, MCE and Navya Singh, 2nd Year, EE paints a vivid picture of drowning in a sea of choices and coping with academic struggles.
body:
“I calm my body and tread the smothering waters gently. I have struggled against the dark waters for so long, screamed myself hoarse, all in the hopes that someone above the surface would hear me. Maybe they won’t. No - maybe I don’t need them to.”

Read on as Charvi Solanki, 3rd Year, MCE and Navya Singh, 2nd Year, EE paints a vivid picture of drowning in a sea of choices and coping with academic struggles.

I have forgotten when exactly I waded into the waters that have now become my prison. The depths are dark, they’re cruel - they taunt my rigid, flailing body with reminders of my past failures and questions about my future.

Somewhere in a childhood haze, my mother once scolded me for being afraid of the vast ocean waves. She spoke of how one day, I'd be like a wave in the currents of my dreams and aspirations, how like the ocean I’d be vast and uncontainable. Younger days, naïve days. How do I explain to my mother that instead of thriving in the vivid world she broke her back trying to create for me, her daughter is buried by all the versions of herself she could’ve been? How am I supposed to tell her how mortifying it is to be the one drowning in the sea of know-it-all’s and competitive coaching addicts?

I came to college with a suitcase full of dreams, expectations, hopes. I came to college with bright eyes, and the light was dead before I could set the suitcase down.

For all their premeditated actions, at least most of the people in DTU knew what their calling was. I watch through the ripples, looking from beneath the surface of water, as seniors trickle out of TnP, wearing their starched blue shirts, smiling at each other nervously. There were exceptions - confident grins - ones who had no doubt done well in their interviews. I often imagine what it would be like if I could just manage to break the surface and join my friends in their quest to conquer the mountain that I could not see. Would I know what I'm meant to do? Would I be staring blankly at a screen with words and punctuation marks scattered haphazardly throughout the script that had no meaning? Or would I start my own business, hire the very people I felt intimidated by?

Every day is a mix of the whirlwind same old following conundrum. The prestigious FAANG jobs pay well but do I want to be a corporate slave? I could go into research but I don’t have the patience nor the acumen for it. The arts seem promising but society won't promise me a future. 

I could dwell in the imaginary world above the surface I crafted in those haunting daydreams, erecting a utopia on expectations. My hands skim the surface, and I feel the cool air skip over my knuckles, before the water quells my efforts again. Perhaps I don't wish to spend my entire life chasing after some elusive revelation. Maybe I don’t want to anchor my entire existence in the realm of 'what if's' and a world that exists only in the mind.

Emotions churn within me like a tempest, oscillating between excitement and trepidation . Will I find my true calling, or will I be condemned to a life of unfulfilled potential? Will they hear my screams through the surface? The pressure is suffocating, the waters around me grow darker, threatening to engulf me in a wave of indecision. I kick and thrash against the stifling grip of the water as my arm breaks the surface again. I cry out in joy; perhaps I could try for government services! The precious moment of clarity is pierced as I go under again and the water tightens its vise-like grip.

I look up at the night sky through the crack in the surface of the murky waters I've forced myself into, silently praying to the stars for answers. It almost feels like my uncertainty’s shed blood, my hands grisly with the apathy of my actions, or  the lack thereof. There’s a tombstone for all of my forsaken hopes.

I calm my body and tread the smothering waters gently. I have struggled against the dark waters for so long, screamed myself hoarse, all in the hopes that someone above the surface would hear me. Maybe they won’t. No - maybe I don’t need them to.

I stop fighting the waters, stop fighting myself as the water rears back in surprise. The pressure eases, and I tread faster. I know I can work hard, I know I am not exceptionally gifted but if worked on long enough, I can learn whatever I set my mind to. The water retreats faster now, I can almost feel the current pushing me along. Perhaps, it’s not as if I can’t do what my friends are doing, but simply don’t want to. My dreams are my own and my ambitions will not be caged by those who are governed by their arrogance in thinking that their dreams are the only ‘right’ ones. There is a sense of solace in the realization. A gentle breeze caresses my wet brow dripping stinging salt water into my eyes, as I break the surface and finally, breathe.

Illustration Credits: Navya Singh,2nd Year, EE

title: Edition 61 | Sink or Swim
biliner:
“In the face of adversity, she chose not to drown away, but to rise up, to bear witness, and
to be the unwavering voice that cried out for a better, more sustainable future.” Read on as Sara Sanwal, 3rd year, B Des illustrates the tale of a young B Tech student of Almora, exhibiting resilience and purpose in the face of adversity.
body:
They say that being a student means bearing the torch for the future. Yet, imagine holding that torch in your PG in Shahbad Dairy, only to have the light abruptly extinguished, leaving you stumbling in the dark with your roommates. Imagine leaving your hometown, a place so vastly different from the bustling streets of Delhi, all in pursuit of giving your all to this city, to make your parents proud. You're already grappling with the challenge of adapting, and then suddenly, you find yourself evicted—evicted by the force of nature itself.

This story encapsulates the journey of one exceptionally brave girl.Hailing from Almora, she is passionately pursuing BTech at DTU, navigating the vast cityscape entirely on her own. Throughout this journey, one steadfast companion has never left her side: her camera. Photography is not just a hobby for her, but a cherished gift from her parents back when she was in the 10th grade. They scrimped and saved for an entire year to bestow this precious tool upon her.

In the recent Delhi flood, she found herself forcibly evicted from her ground floor room. Her belongings floated alongside those of her roommates, a somber testament to the rising water. The creeping water forced initial attempts at evacuation. The relentless rain showed no signs of stopping. Gradually, there was no sanctuary left. She was on the streets.

In that dire moment, clutching her camera tightly, a stark realization dawned upon her. She had contemplated this scenario in the past, but now it all fell into a relentless sequence. 

The memories of pollution-choked skies, suffocating smog, and merciless heat waves resurfaced with a vengeance. Her heart ached for her homeland, where the air was still crisp and the rivers flowed clear. She longed for herself to experience the purity of nature that had nurtured her into you she was. She could no longer be a passive observer to the degradation unfolding around her. In the midst of the chaos, she grappled with questions that gnawed at her soul. Was there meaning to her endeavors? Was she destined to be a mere spectator, swept away by the tide of inexorable change? In that pivotal moment, standing amidst the deluge, her resolve solidified. With her camera as her weapon, she vowed to capture the stark realities of climate change in Delhi.Her images testified to the city's resilience. Each photograph demanded acknowledgment, action. In the face of adversity, she chose not to drown away, but to rise up, to bear witness, and to be the unwavering voice that cried out for a better, more sustainable future.

title: Edition 61 | Pulse - The Desire Or The Duty
biliner:
“My heart belongs to the turf and track, 
While I remind myself I am my family’s back.
The helpless body just rests there without moving
For my wish and would are too differing.”
Read on and let Bilal Khan's beautiful composition prompt you to consider whether to choose duty or a desire.
body:
“My heart belongs to the turf and track, 

While I remind myself I am my family’s back.

The helpless body just rests there without moving

For my wish and would are too differing.”

Read on and let Bilal Khan's beautiful composition prompt you to consider whether to choose duty or a desire.

It is one of those scorching mornings of June.

Yet somehow my body feels cold, the reason you will know soon.

A strange friction rubs against my athletic body,

Praying to me to end this self inflicted tyranny.

I get myself to my study table

As I strive to do more than I am able.

Thoughts of uncertainty engulf my brain,

Yet my heart has hope, this would be worth the pain.

My heart belongs to the turf and track, 

While I remind myself I am my family’s back.

The helpless body just rests there without moving

For my wish and would are too differing.

The dichotomy inside of me drenches me with despair.

Pushing away the table, I get up from that “chained” chair.

I look at the fields from the paned window,

The thing I desperately need to end this state of sorrow.

My limbs wanting to go there and run away free,

The walls of this dark room curtail me.

I shut my eyes and recall my purpose.

A disappointed smile, a silent gasp as I unwillingly end this fidgeting fuss.

I take a slow walk back to my place.

A book in front of me, all I can do is a compelled and lost gaze.

Those thoughts plunge me once again,

Even after plucking them out of my head with utter disdain.

My desire or my duty, what to follow?

I only go back and continue to look out of the window.
