title: Edition 61|Intellectually Unemployed
biliner:
“Do we really have to climb a cliff and jump from it, to say, we went through it? Why is it that there is a social dictation that tells us what our experiences should be?” 
Read on as Siddharth Malik ponders over and unravels the intricacies of an unconventional, yet gratifying career option.
body:
“Do we really have to climb a cliff and jump from it, to say, we went through it? Why is it that there is a social dictation that tells us what our experiences should be?” 

The first few days of February when it was always almost too cold but not quite, and I was trying to adjust to this jarring and hustling life of being a university student, I would often find solace in reading, picking up a novel in the morning and finishing it by the time I reach home any day and every day, I always used to expect that one day, a dark cloak would fall over me and before I knew it, I would be thrown into a gloomy room and made a member of a secret society. Maybe that was too much of every single fantasy film and book that you should not read after you leave a certain age group, but I did, and still do, because somehow, neither I nor the things that I love, seem to evolve. (Except for my dog - he died, and that too was not an evolutionary process).

But that is only as long as you can block the outside world and try to ignore or gloss over real, moving things. I got so caught up in the fear of not stepping in, of not crossing lines that I surrounded myself with exceedingly and very consciously, that somehow, the only thing that I never stepped into was figuring out what life path I am going to choose. University is not only a place where you get a degree, but also a place where you experiment, try new things, make some progress, fail, realize what it is to have things rectified, and repeat. And you need to go through this, the brunt of it all, to experience life at University at its best and worst, at the height of its vibrancy, and through all its monotones. But why?

Do we really have to climb a cliff and jump from it, to say, we went through it? Why is it that there is a social dictation that tells us what our experiences should be? What if I did not want to poke my nose out of the novels that I loved and read during those winters? Why is it that having an active grasp of existential realism is the only acceptable way of progression? If some of us do think that poetry, essays, novels, and essentially words are where we belong, where our true passion resides, then why shouldn't we grasp it, take risks - risks that are worth taking, because, just so you are aware, people have found ways to capitalize their hobby of reading, that Oscar Wilde once called a staple for the ‘relaxation of the intellectually unemployed’. Not anymore!

Nowadays, you can pursue reading as a career by starting a blog of your own, where you can post reviews of the books you’ve read, while also discussing the characters, themes, and critical perceptions associated with it. You can also try to start a podcast, where you can invite authors or people from the publishing industry and discuss with them the various stages of publishing as well as the process of writing. And hey, there are organizations that pay you for sending reviews of books you read, as freelancers. So the next time you spend your entire night reading rather than sleeping and following a socially dictated routine, just remind yourself: it’s work!

title: एडिशन ६१ | छलांग
biliner: उस्ताद ने पूछा “डर लग रहा है क्या तुझे !” मैंने जवाब दिया “ज़रा सा भी नहीं !” और छलांग लगा दी।
body:
१५ हज़ार फ़ीट की ऊंचाई पर उड़ते विमान से एक पैराशूट के भरोसे छलांग एक ज़िंदादिल इंसान ही लगा सकता है। कूदने के पश्चात २-३ मिनट तक ३०० किमी/घंटा की रफ़्तार से गिरने के बाद धरातल से कुछ ही मीटर ऊपर पैराशूट को खोल एक सुरक्षित लैंडिंग करनी होती है। एकाएक जवान विमान से कूदते और बादलों में कहीं गुम होते जा रहे थे। मेरी बारी आने तक शून्य तापमान में भी मुझे पसीना आ रहा था, गला सूख रहा था लेकिन इतना समय कहाँ कि डर सकें। निकास द्वार पर लगे बत्ती के हरा होते ही उस्ताद ने पूछा “डर लग रहा है क्या तुझे !”

मैंने जवाब दिया “ज़रा सा भी नहीं !” और छलांग लगा दी। ठंडी हवा से मेरा चेहरा सुन्न पड़ गया। धुंध भरे बादलों को अपने नीचे देख डर से दिल सहम गया था । थोड़ी देर में यह डर भी गायब हो गया और मेरी आँखों से आंसू बहने लगे जिनको मैं पोंछ सकने में भी असमर्थ था । इस एक पल को जीने के लिए मैंने जितना भी संघर्ष किया था, वह सब मुझे याद आ गया। 

मैंने इंजीनियरिंग के पहले साल में एन.सी.सी. की भर्ती में भाग लिया था लेकिन चोट के कारण मेरा चयन नहीं हुआ। दृढ़ आत्मविश्वास एवं कठिन परिश्रम के परिणामस्वरूप इंजीनियरिंग के दूसरे साल में मेरा चयन हुआ। इसी के साथ बिगुल भी बज गया। रोज़ सुबह सूरज से पहले उठ कर दौड़ना और व्यायाम करना। सप्ताह के ६ दिन विश्वविद्यालय की दिनचर्या में तल्लीनता के साथ लगे रहना और प्रत्येक रविवार को एन.सी.सी. में रगड़ा खाना तो मेरे लिए आम बात थी। कभी-कभी दोस्तों के साथ मस्ती कर लेता था लेकिन सेना के प्रति लिए संकल्प को अनुशासन और समर्पण के साथ पूरा किया। एक दिन यकायक मेरे घर डाक द्वारा एस.एस.बी. से कॉल लेटर आया जिसे पढ़कर, बचपन से देखा मेरा सपना साकार होता हुआ दिखा। भारतीय सैन्य अकादमी से महीनों की कठिन तपस्या और प्रशिक्षण प्राप्त कर सेना में अधिकृत होने के पश्चात मैंने पैरा (विशेष बल)  के लिए स्वेच्छा से भाग लिया। उसी के प्रशिक्षण के लिए आज मैंने उड़ते विमान से छलांग लगाई थी। 

इतने में मैंने अनुमान लगाया कि मैं सतह से २०० -३०० मीटर ही ऊपर हूँ। बड़ी ही सतर्कता से मैंने अपने पैराशूट को खोला और एक सुरक्षित लैंडिंग को अंजाम दिया। मैंने अपनी माँ का आभार व्यक्त किया और नम आँखें लिए धरती माँ की गोद में लेट गया।

title: Edition 61 | Wistful Sound of the Hallowed Halls
biliner: “A mix of humility and excitement courses through my veins as I prepare for the doors to swing open with a bubbling crowd of students. Will they recognize me as their own? Will they feel the same spark that ignited within me all those years ago?”  Read on as Gurashima Kaur, 2nd year, B. Des. invokes the trepid feelings of uncertainty residing within us.
body:
“A mix of humility and excitement courses through my veins as I prepare for the doors to swing open with a bubbling crowd of students. Will they recognize me as their own? Will they feel the same spark that ignited within me all those years ago?”  
Read on as Gurashima Kaur , 2nd year, B. Des. invokes the trepid feelings of uncertainty residing within us.

Walking through these foyers, I feel my heartbeat picking up as it did on my first day in this college. Today is my first day, just not as a student this time. I enter the class and the memories come rushing back like a gust of wind. 

I take a while to settle in before the students barge in for the lecture. I meticulously arrange my notes and place them on the table. A woman walks past the door and gives me a quick smile. Before I could register who she was, she had already exited the corridor. 

I glance over at the empty benches, seeking something that wasn’t known to me. The tables scribbled with notes brought back nostalgia. I walk to the end of the class and imagine myself standing on the dais and addressing a class of 80 students. 

“What do you wish to become when you grow up?” 

”A teacher!”

The voice of a five-year-old me rings in my head as if the words were spoken afresh yesterday. My heart swells with pride as I recall donning that cap and gown on my graduation day. 

A mix of humility and excitement courses through my veins as I prepare for the doors to swing open with a bubbling crowd of students. Will they recognize me as their own? Will they feel the same spark that ignited within me all those years ago? I became acutely aware of the responsibility bestowed on me. The weight of it fuels determination in me and pushes away any self-doubt still lingering at the corners of my mind. 

I hear whispers murmuring in the corridors. The students must be making their way to my class. I cross the empty benches and take my place at the podium. I swiftly look at the time on my watch. Any minute now. The first group of students walks in through the doors. Two girls and two boys. I couldn’t help but see a reflection of my friend’s group in them. They greet me and take their seats. I smile politely and welcome them. The class fills up soon. 

With every fiber of my being, now electrified with enthusiasm, I commence my first lecture as a professor. I take a deep breath. 

“Good morning class….”

title: Edition 61 | Sinking Dreams
biliner: "The startup was more than just a venture. It was the product of sleepless nights, countless brainstorming sessions, and the unwavering belief that I could make a difference in the world through my vision." Read on as Dhruv Rahuja, 2nd year, CSE (@dhruv.rahuja) beautifully covers the entire feeling of navigating crossroads, having the chance to change your destiny but choosing...;
body:
"The startup was more than just a venture. It was the product of sleepless nights, countless brainstorming sessions, and the unwavering belief that I could make a difference in the world through my vision." 

Read on as Dhruv Rahuja, 2nd year, CSE beautifully covers the entire feeling of navigating crossroads, having the chance to change your destiny but choosing...;

As I stood at Titanic Point on a sunny Tuesday in August, I inadvertently eavesdropped on a group of first-year students engaged in a heated debate, struggling to decide on what to wear for their Freshers’ Party. I whispered to myself, “If only my problems were as easy as theirs.” The sky mirrored the deep blue colour of my shirt, and my mood echoed the same hue.

A few minutes back, I received a job offer that I could’ve only imagined getting when I first entered college. As I pondered over how this job offer might provide some much-needed relief to the strained financial situation at home, my inner voice whispered, "And what about the startup you've poured your heart and soul into for the past two years?", and a wave of uncertainty washed over me.

The startup was more than just a venture. It was the product of sleepless nights, countless brainstorming sessions, and the unwavering belief that I could make a difference in the world through my vision. 

Despite the setback of not securing the expected funding and my co-founder’s resignation earlier this year, I remained resolute in my pursuit of building my startup. While placements were initially intended as a fallback plan, I had never envisioned the possibility of resorting to them. As I sank further into contemplation, I looked at the setting sun, and a sudden clarity washed over me. 

The Titanic Point, once a symbol of my dilemmas, now held a different meaning. As my startup’s ship sank, I found myself plunged into the icy ocean of uncertainty. The job offer exuded a sense of stability, much like the floating piece of wood to help me stay afloat and survive the chilly night. With a faint sigh, I decided to accept the job offer, all the while vowing to "never let go" of my startup and hoping to rebuild it someday.

body:
“The bandhgala disseminated more than what could be expected. He donned the purpose-built piece of his wardrobe to places where he was expected to meet such people as his parents. “He is an officer already,” the woman clad in a silk saree uttered nonchalantly.”

Read on as Dheeresh Chandra, MCE, 3rd Year, and Anshita Garg,  COE, 3rd Year, eloquently unveils the intricate dance between tradition and destiny, capturing the essence of navigating crossroads in a world adorned with bandhgalas and aspirations.
 

The bright patio lights appeared but gigantic to his semi-closed eyes as he gazed through the window across the portico and the gardens, hoping to at least behold the real-world horizon when no light appeared at the end of the tunnel for him. Home was but a fleeting caravan, furcated by the lines of well-mannered yet agonizing upbringing, and more so because he couldn’t decide which one to call home, his mom’s bungalow or his dad’s.

There was more to the life of a bureaucrat’s son than most of the masses would comprehend, with family time as a stubborn member of the bucket list and courtesy prevailing over freedom in every act of life. He was a sharp kid in school, thanks to the genes he had inherited, as noted by his ‘friends’. His father had gifted him a bandhgala, explicitly representing the obvious, on his 18th, which he had ironically considered the most well-thought gift of the day. 

The bandhgala disseminated more than what could be expected. He donned the purpose-built piece of his wardrobe to places where he was expected to meet such people as his parents. “He is an officer already,” the woman clad in a silk saree uttered nonchalantly. The aura of the profession had crept adagio into his veins. Despite having gone for a degree in technical education, he bustled throughout the day to draw time for both the things at hand and fared pretty well to not let his technical education taint the coruscating kaleidoscope of history, polity and economics. 

Being pretty much at par with foreign relations and friendships, he does subsume those in college within the broad horizon of support he has gotten so far from all spheres of life, right from dreaming of it in the bandhgala, and through the entire period of preparation before his attempt of the coveted exam. True to what they say, time in college lets one herald a rousing change in the course of their life.

“Are you comfortable with the bandhgala’s buttoned-up collar?” Mother asked.

“Pretty much,” he indisputably agreed, for the bandhgala, however buttoned-up, had already let the tiny ray of hope out to light the way for him through the tunnel to the end, letting him free into the correct comprehension of his goals and dreams.

title: Edition 62 | Interview - Cultural Council
biliner:
“It's a momentous occasion to be a part of the 50th edition of Engifest. The milestone signifies not just a celebration of the festival but also a testament to the enduring cultural spirit at DTU. It's a celebration of the festival's enduring legacy and the collective efforts of the Cultural Council and DTU community.”

DTU Times interviewed the outgoing Cultural Council (2023-24) of DTU. Read on as they look back on their years of organising the Engifest and the legacy they leave behind.
body:
DTU Times interviewed the outgoing Cultural Council (2023-24) of DTU - Kumar Samyak (Cultural Secretary), Vishnu Dubey (Joint Cultural Secretary), Akampreet Singh Sandhu (Joint Cultural Secretary), Divya Tomar (Joint Cultural Secretary), Naman Goyal (Treasurer), Udit Negi (Joint Treasurer),  Shaurya Garg (Joint Treasurer), Priyanshi Anand (Joint Treasurer).

The last edition of Engifest was a tremendous success. What is the process of inviting celebrities, and how does the Cultural Council plan to raise the bar this year?

The process of inviting celebrities typically involves reaching out to their management teams, negotiating terms, and ensuring logistical arrangements. We curate a list based on youth hype and budget, categorise for day or pronite, and the council then narrows it down through a ruthless vote. Our artist team, armed with tenacity, hits them up through managers, personal connections or through various artist management companies. This year, we plan to raise the bar by incorporating diverse performances, engaging the audience in unique ways, and introducing surprises that resonate with the current cultural trends.

What do you think is the main ingredient to make a fest successful?

Building a fest from scratch is incredibly exciting, as it involves crafting a unique experience and bringing ideas to life. Understanding the pulse of the audience, offering diverse and appealing events, and fostering a sense of inclusivity contribute significantly to the success of any cultural festival. From captivating creatives around the college to a stellar artist lineup, proper security, and efficient management – all efforts are geared towards crafting an unforgettable experience for the attendees.

After three years since the onset of COVID-19, 2023 marked the return to organising fully offline events. How does it feel to be back and actively engaged in planning and executing offline events?

There's an appreciation and a sense of nostalgia for the classic elements of event organising that we might have put on hold for a while during the pandemic. The return is exhilarating. It feels like a reconnection with the essence of cultural celebrations. Being actively engaged in planning and executing offline events brings a sense of vibrancy and shared joy that virtual events couldn't fully capture.

How does it feel to be doing the 50th edition of Engifest, India's Biggest College Cultural Festival?

It's a momentous occasion to be a part of the 50th edition of Engifest. The milestone signifies not just a celebration of the festival but also a testament to the enduring cultural spirit at DTU. It's a celebration of the festival's enduring legacy and the collective efforts of the Cultural Council and DTU community. The anticipation surrounding this milestone edition adds extra significance to the event, making it a cherished moment in Engifest's history.

title: Edition 62 | Interview - Mr. Abhishek Mishra, Faculty, Drishti IAS
biliner:
“I would like to mention that both extroverted and introverted individuals can find Civil Services suitable, as personality transformations are observed during the preparation and service period. The examination has a broader purpose of preparing individuals for life, offering enduring knowledge and skills.”
In a recent interview with DTU Times at Yuvaan, Mr. Abhishek Mishra shared his insights on engineers in civil services, managing college curriculum and UPSC preparation.
body:
“I would like to mention that both extroverted and introverted individuals can find Civil Services suitable, as personality transformations are observed during the preparation and service period. The examination has a broader purpose of preparing individuals for life, offering enduring knowledge and skills.”

In a recent interview with DTU Times at Yuvaan, Mr. Abhishek Mishra shared his insights on engineers in civil services, managing college curriculum and UPSC preparation.

What are the benefits and drawbacks that engineers might encounter during UPSC preparation and in civil services?

I believe there are many advantages to being an engineer and attempting to pursue civil services. The major aspect of this exam, as per recent trends, indicates that a greater number of engineers qualify. What aids engineers in this exam is their background in a professional degree, where they become accustomed to long hours of work. Due to the discipline and logical ability developed during engineering, they perform well compared to students from other streams. 

There are numerous college students who are preparing for UPSC along with their academic commitments. What would be your advice to such students?

In the context of engineering colleges, there is considerable pressure on students' time to complete the college curriculum. I suggest optimising time and focusing on basics such as reading NCERT books to build a strong foundation. Consistency and dedicating around 2 hours daily for preparation, is stressed. Online courses are recommended for flexibility, allowing students to self-pace their preparation while eliminating the challenges of travelling long distances for offline coaching.

How can a college student assess if a career in Civil Services aligns with their interests or aspirations?

I recommend reviewing the experiences of other students from an engineering background. The decision also hinges on an individual’s preferences and personality. Apart from that, I would like to mention that both extroverted and introverted individuals can find Civil Services suitable, as personality transformations are observed during the preparation and service period. The examination has a broader purpose of preparing individuals for life, offering enduring knowledge and skills.

We see a lot of students who try to clear the Civil Services Examination for years, but the result does not turn out to be in their favor. What would be your advice to such aspirants?

Accepting that life extends beyond UPSC is important. Even if success in the exam isn't attained, the understanding gained about the nation's geography and economics and the mere fact that one understands the true sense of every column of the newspaper, is something to be considered a significant personal achievement. One should see success beyond entering civil services, and in becoming a good citizen of the nation. There are many examples of individuals excelling in other fields after not being able to clear the exam. I would advise students to take the journey as steps in life, giving one's best without fixating on success or failure.

title: Edition 62 | Interview - Prateek Narang
biliner:
“The most important thing is to start. In college, we often think there is a lot of time to study. We are often negligent with our responsibilities and thus lose a lot of precious time in the process. Computer science is an ocean, and you need to taste a lot of things, so you must start early. I would say, start from day one itself, focus on what your aspiration is, and start working towards it instead of doing too many things.”

In a recent interview with DTU Times at IEEE’s inaugration, Mr. Prateek Narang shared his career evolution as a professional coding instructor.
body:
“The most important thing is to start. In college, we often think there is a lot of time to study. We are often negligent with our responsibilities and thus lose a lot of precious time in the process. Computer science is an ocean, and you need to taste a lot of things, so you must start early. I would say, start from day one itself, focus on what your aspiration is, and start working towards it instead of doing too many things.”

In a recent interview with DTU Times at IEEE’s inaugration, Mr. Prateek Narang shared his career evolution as a professional coding instructor. 

How did you come up with ‘CodingMinutes’? What sets it apart from other education platforms?

As an engineer, I look for problems to solve. I was very interested in teaching and wanted to do something around that, so that is how I started my career. Apart from that, I realised during COVID that a lot of students were facing an issue — they wanted good quality resources, but lacked monetary assistance. There was also an obvious economic strain because of hefty academic fees. I decided that I should bring affordable, quality courses, and that is how CodingMinutes was born.

As a professional coding instructor, what challenges do you commonly encounter during teaching, and how do you overcome them?

Each student is different, everyone has different learning capacities, and they absorb information at a different pace. The major challenge is to have all these students on the same page. As a teacher, we must ensure that everyone understands everything properly. What I try to do is that I try to make things as simple as possible.

With the growing popularity of AI, what is your opinion on the oversaturation of jobs?

Every invention is initially met with scrutiny. For instance, with the invention of apps like Uber and Ola, people thought that job opportunities would decrease but a new kind of demand was created and fulfilled. Similarly, with AI-based solutions, we are going to be using AI in different areas of our life, so there would be jobs coming up in those areas. AI is not going to replace the jobs but it is going to make us work more smartly.

If you were to go back in the past, what is the one advice you would give to your student self that you can still live by to this date?

The most important thing is to start. In college, we often think there is a lot of time to study. We are often negligent with our responsibilities and thus lose a lot of precious time in the process. Computer science is an ocean, and you need to taste a lot of things, so you must start early. I would say, start from day one itself, focus on what your aspiration is, and start working towards it instead of doing too many things. Work or devote most of your time towards what is taking you closer towards your goal.

Coming back to DTU, your alma mater, must bring back memories. How do you think the education system here in terms of technology has changed from your period of education to the current period of education?

It’s always a proud moment to be invited by your alma mater, so I feel very happy to be at DTU. You all are amazing people, and I am very thankful for being invited and, though I am not up to date with what is going on with the college, I see a lot of people on LinkedIn doing good stuff and achieving great jobs, so hopefully the college is doing well and, I hope that it scales up exponentially.

title: Edition 62 |Through the Lenses of Time
biliner:
“A pair of magical glasses meant to show things the way they’d been 15 years ago would’ve seemed less incredulous to her if the glasses didn’t look like an ungodly monstrosity. She looked around one last time, hidden behind the trees near Raj Soin hall, for anyone who might recognise her.”

Read on and take a deep dive into the past with this beautiful composition written by Navya Singh.
body:
A pair of magical glasses meant to show things the way they’d been 15 years ago would’ve seemed less incredulous to her if the glasses didn’t look like an ungodly monstrosity. She looked around one last time, hidden behind the trees near Raj Soin hall, for anyone who might recognise her. It was probably an impolite joke, enticing her to believe in ‘magic’ just to catch her wearing this horror. She sighed as she put them on; prank or no, she couldn't afford to miss out on the possibility that this thing might actually work. 

She looked around with her hideous new eyes at… nothing. Where there had been the Academic block a few seconds ago, was just empty land, littered with trees and wild vegetation. That answered the question about the potential prank situation, she supposed. 

She headed towards the Electrical Department, passing by OAT on her way. She ogled open-mouthed at 5 year olds sitting in huddles, discussing tech internships and placements. These glasses worked too well for her comfort.

Upon reaching the familiar confines of her department, she looked through the windows to yet again see toddlers sitting in the class. She blinked in surprise as she recognised her favourite professor. The face he must've once worn in his prime lacked the frown lines, and he looked considerably less follically challenged and was missing his characteristic stern set moustache. The classroom itself looked unblemished, missing the indentations and marks left by students long gone. For that matter, the very air around her felt cleaner, the colours around her popped brighter in the absence of the dreary grey fog that choked her city’s lungs everyday.

Monkeys swung from the branches of trees that should have been the pillars of Pragya Bhawan. People drove by in cars she could only remember seeing in the grainy pictures that emanated joy in a way she and those around her no longer remembered. She breathed in the silence, the beauty in the absence of things. She could get used to this version of DTU. Maybe she could wear these glasses to college every day, it would certainly lift her spirits to see kindergarteners arguing about recession. 

With a smile, she recognised her friend waving her short arms at her, her tiny toddler frame struggling as she ran up to her. She was about to tell her about what she’d found when the 6 year old said to her with a completely straight face, “Those are the ugliest eff-ing glasses I have ever seen.”

title: Edition 62 |Dear Diary
biliner:
“In a rare occurrence, I crossed paths with two students from my alma mater today. It felt as though I had been sucked into the lesser-read pages of history. I saw those two standing and giggling with their younger sibling, and it seemed like they had come to drop her off at her tuition class. As for me, I had come to drop off my son.”
Read on to find out what happens when a DTU alumnus crosses paths with two current students in this thought-provoking composition written by Dhruv Rahuja, 2nd year, CSE & Gurashima Kaur, 2nd year, B.Des.
body:
In a rare occurrence, I crossed paths with two students from my alma mater today. It felt as though I had been sucked into the lesser read pages of history. I saw those two standing and giggling with their younger sibling, and it seemed like they had come to drop her off at her tuition class. As for me, I had come to drop off my son. I can’t quite recall how I found myself in a conversation with them, but I vividly remember them saying out loud, the college where they were studying at. Looking at them both at that moment, I thought I found my tribe. 

Our conversation felt like an emotional pendulum swinging between excitement and uncertainty. I was delighted to hear about the exciting new changes they told me about, but a profound sense of desolation had crept beneath the surface of that amusement. It felt as if the very soul of our era was slipping away into the vast expanse of time. 

I couldn’t help but notice the palpable differences in their college experience compared to mine. The campus, once a familiar landscape of aged buildings now boasts sleek, modern structures. The bus-sized canteen near the science block has transformed into a proper outlet, and there are several small eateries on campus now instead of just one. Maggi Baba is replaced by the infamous Mic Mac. However, I was a bit dejected to learn that they hadn’t heard about Maggi Baba. They revealed a curriculum that has evolved significantly. The essence of exam season has shifted from the sight of stacked papers and books to dimly lit screens, and students now navigate through PDF files instead of flipping through the pages of their books. I sensed a hint of nostalgia for the times when the air was not intertwined with the constant hum of laptops.

But nonetheless, the camaraderie among the students remains timeless. I laughed to myself when they mentioned the late-night study sessions, tea breaks in the canteen, cursing the exam date sheet, and bunking classes because sleep is more important, at the end of the day.

Our conversation unveiled a shared anxiety for unfulfilled dreams and a thrill for the vast expanse of possibilities. Though I may be a mere spectator of the superficial changes now, it brings me respite in the fact that the fundamental essence of our era is unaltered. 

Until next time.

title: Edition 62 |If Corridors Could Talk
biliner:
"In the corridors, whispers of conversations linger, fragments of laughter float gently and tales weave through the air, sometimes laced with tears. All of these half done conversations lie beneath the layers of scribbles, dust and indents covering the walls of every building."
Read on as Kavya Agrawal shows us how the corridors remain a timeless witness to the dance of youth, education, and the unyielding passage of time.
body:
In the corridors, whispers of conversations linger, fragments of laughter float gently and tales weave through the air, sometimes laced with tears. All of these half done conversations lie beneath the layers of scribbles, dust and indents covering the walls of every building. Painted a dim color, under a shady light, these are for the students to annoyingly bustle through, pouring their hearts out to their friends or just laughing along and this never changes. 

“Oh god I just hope I pass this one time and I swear over everyone I know that I will start studying right from the beginning next semester” (knowing that this next semester that’s talked about every exam season never comes). This sentence echoing from years ago is replicated even now, making it hard for the wall to believe it’s been twenty five years since it was first uttered, only to be repeated every six months without fail, by students who just started their degrees and those graduating soon alike. 

“Want to go watch a movie this friday?” “I just finished watching that season last night?” That’s how fast the night changed as the corridor saw a boy trying to convince his friend to grab a late night show, enticing him with a reason to sneak out of the hostel to now watching them discuss how they watched the latest trend, which will die down in just a span of forty eight hours, from the comfort of their rooms without having to even sit together.

“Does this course even have an application in real life?” “Isn’t this pretty much outdated” But the corridors know better because it’s been the same old punctual professor who’s worked his way up the ranks but is stuck teaching twenty year olds the same fundamentals because no matter how much they’re questioned, the only thing that time is changing is the professor’s receding hairline and not his way of teaching.

“Let’s go to manali!” Now this is the one phrase that literally never changes and is followed up after weeks pass with “Next semester, for sure!” and even the corridors laugh because it is this innocence of the moment and how years have gone but it still seems that they’ve hit pause on the brink of teenagers turning into adults and it’s now a rite of passage.

title: Edition 62 | From that Dingy Corner
biliner:
“The times may have changed but the Times hadn’t. The pictures and the words still flowed the same way, and so did the dedication, effort and love that metamorphosed mere ideas and imaginations into actuality on paper.”

Read on to find out what happens when the past and the present encounter each other in the most unexpected manner in this nostalgic piece written by Bhuvi Pandey, 1st year, CHE.
body:
“The times may have changed but the Times hadn’t. The pictures and the words still flowed the same way, and so did the dedication, effort and love that metamorphosed mere ideas and imaginations into actuality on paper.”
 

That dingy corner of the library was rather unexciting for any passerby. Unlike its surroundings, which seemed to be brimming with untold stories and colourful gossip; a stony silence engulfed that corner of the library. 

And yet, fortuitously, in that seemingly spiritless area unfolded a conversation transcending through the gap of generations; when a flimsy newspaper titled ‘DCE Times,’ and a magazine by the name of ‘DTU Times,’ curiously eyed each other…

The older of the two looked away quickly and began mumbling something to itself, but not before passing a haughty smirk to its younger counterpart. 
Perplexed and slightly offended, the younger one, flashing its shiny pages began, “Is there any way I can help you, my friend?” Its youthful, expressive voice was like a whiff of fresh air for the lonely elder. 

Through its pages, which had also been shiny once but were now covered in dust and grime, it said, “My friend! Are these grey pages, flowing with inky experience, not enough to show just how much older I am than you?” 
The elderly voice seemed strangely familiar to the youngster which was odd because the two hadn’t ever met before. 

With a muddled mind and uncertain eyes, they both quickly peeked at the title that adorned each of them. And then it hit both of them. 

The times may have changed but the Times hadn’t. The pictures and the words still flowed the same way, and so did the dedication, effort and love that metamorphosed mere ideas and imaginations into actuality on paper. 

As the past and the present swelled with pride to realise how far they’ve come, and from where they’ve come respectively, they both eyed each other, yet again. But this time, the look was filled with newfound warmth and affection, a look that is reserved for ones that are our own. 

That dingy corner of the library continued to remain unnoticed. Students excitedly chattered their way into their surroundings, unmindful of how the stony silence of that corner had been converted into a perceptive peace by apparently inanimate bundles of paper.

title: Edition 62 | Metamorphosis
biliner: “I remember watching DTU students come to my school to judge a robotics workshop when I was a sixth grader. As a sixth grader, interacting with them meant everything to me - their style, their maturity, their knowledge. I wanted to be just like them; a boy, who longed to be a man.” Read on as down as Pulkit Garg, 2nd year, EE pens down the questions and the uncertainty that comes up, as a person transitions from boy to man.
body:
“I remember watching DTU students come to my school to judge a robotics workshop when I was a sixth grader. As a sixth grader, interacting with them meant everything to me - their style, their maturity, their knowledge. I wanted to be just like them; a boy, who longed to be a man.” Read on as down as Pulkit Garg, 2nd year, EE pens down the questions and the uncertainty that comes up, as a person transitions from boy to man. 

I look at those around me and I feel as if I’m the only boy in a crowd of men, a kid at the adult table. It makes me feel afraid to be happy. 

“You’ve grown into quite a big young man!” said my second-grade teacher as I bumped into her on a frigid December evening, recognition and happiness taking over her face.

For her, it was a moment of pride to see her student now towering over her when he once only reached to her waist.

For me, it held infinite questions,  because when really does a boy become a man?

I remember watching DTU students come to my school to judge a robotics workshop when I was a sixth grader. As a sixth grader, interacting with them meant everything to me - their style, their maturity, their knowledge. I wanted to be just like them; a boy, who longed to be a man.

And now that I am where they were, I feel anything but - I am a boy, who doesn’t know if he has yet become a man, though the world keeps telling me otherwise.

When does a boy become a man?

Is it when he substitutes the playground for the school campus?

Is it when the assembly ground becomes the OAT?

Is it when teachers become professors and percentages become GPAs?

Is it when you learn to face your fears rather than crying over them?

Is it when you grow hair on your face and dull the spark in your eye?

Is it when you lose your innocence and face the world, both inside and outside?

Is it when the nature of your questions changes from wondering about the nature of the universe to your place in it?

I look at those around me and I feel as if I’m the only boy in a crowd of men, a kid at the adult table. It makes me feel afraid to be happy. 

Happy, because I am taking time to metamorphosize.

Afraid, because I am taking time to metamorphosize, afraid to remain the only caterpillar in a sky full of butterflies.

What I didn’t realize, and what many of us don’t, is that metamorphosis is supposed to take time. 

Because in reality, nobody knows when someone becomes a man, only when they ought to.

Because a college like ours isn’t a race to the top - it's one massive cocoon, one with thousands of dissolved caterpillars inside it, where the substance of each dissolved caterpillar attempts to reform itself in the semblance of a butterfly, where some do come out early, and some later, all butterflies through and through.

Take your time boy. Your journey might be longer, but keep going, and you will yet be molded into a man.

body:
“The pathways once travelled with a sense of familiarity have now changed, guiding students towards new spots. However many of those same benches are still a witness to the endless conversations and youthful exuberance, they stand as silent sentinels, preserving memories of days gone by. ”

Read on as Aditya Khuntia, 1st year, MCE, takes you down memory lane, depicting changes and evolution of campus infrastructure over the years.

Nestled in the heart of academia, the campus stands as a testament to time, bearing witness to the winds of change. Each brick, each pathway, whispers tales of metamorphosis, resonating with nostalgia for those who’ve walked  its gracious green grounds.

In the yesteryears, the campus existed in a simpler form, a cocoon awaiting its transformation. The landscape was marked by the absence of the towering AB Block, an architectural marvel that now defines the skyline. Its absence, once conspicuous, now feels like a distant memory.

The arrival of the New Girls Hostel . Prior to its establishment, the campus lacked adequate housing for female students, underscoring the significance of this addition. Its presence became a cornerstone in shaping a more diverse and inclusive campus culture.  The new infrastructure, with its Russian brutalistic design, embodies modernity, offering an apartment-like ambiance, a departure from the traditional, classic hostel setup reminiscent of the past. Even after that each modification, each addition to the campus infrastructure, has  woven itself into the fabric of student life.

The pathways once traveled with a sense of familiarity have now changed, guiding students towards new spots. However many of those same benches are still a  witness to the endless conversations and youthful exuberance, they stand as silent sentinels, preserving memories of days gone by.  

Nostalgia lingers in the air, carrying whispers of bygone days when the campus bore a different view. Yet, with every alteration, the essence remains—a testament to growth and progress. As alumni reminisce about the past, their nostalgia is not merely for what was, but for the evolution that sculpted the campus into what it is today.

title: Edition 62 | Metamorphosis
biliner: “I remember watching DTU students come to my school to judge a robotics workshop when I was a sixth grader. As a sixth grader, interacting with them meant everything to me - their style, their maturity, their knowledge. I wanted to be just like them; a boy, who longed to be a man.” Read on as down as Pulkit Garg, 2nd year, EE pens down the questions and the uncertainty that comes up, as a person transitions from boy to man.
body:
“I remember watching DTU students come to my school to judge a robotics workshop when I was a sixth grader. As a sixth grader, interacting with them meant everything to me - their style, their maturity, their knowledge. I wanted to be just like them; a boy, who longed to be a man.” 

Read on as down as Pulkit Garg, 2nd Year, EE, pens down the questions and the uncertainty that comes up, as a person transitions from boy to man.

I look at those around me and I feel as if I’m the only boy in a crowd of men, a kid at the adult table. It makes me feel afraid to be happy. 

“You’ve grown into quite a big young man!” said my second-grade teacher as I bumped into her on a frigid December evening, recognition and happiness taking over her face.

For her, it was a moment of pride to see her student now towering over her when he once only reached to her waist.

For me, it held infinite questions,  because when really does a boy become a man?

I remember watching DTU students come to my school to judge a robotics workshop when I was a sixth grader. As a sixth grader, interacting with them meant everything to me - their style, their maturity, their knowledge. I wanted to be just like them; a boy, who longed to be a man.

And now that I am where they were, I feel anything but - I am a boy, who doesn’t know if he has yet become a man, though the world keeps telling me otherwise.

When does a boy become a man?

Is it when he substitutes the playground for the school campus?

Is it when the assembly ground becomes the OAT?

Is it when teachers become professors and percentages become GPAs?

Is it when you learn to face your fears rather than crying over them?

Is it when you grow hair on your face and dull the spark in your eye?

Is it when you lose your innocence and face the world, both inside and outside?

Is it when the nature of your questions changes from wondering about the nature of the universe to your place in it?

I look at those around me and I feel as if I’m the only boy in a crowd of men, a kid at the adult table. It makes me feel afraid to be happy. 

Happy, because I am taking time to metamorphosize.

Afraid, because I am taking time to metamorphosize, afraid to remain the only caterpillar in a sky full of butterflies.

What I didn’t realize, and what many of us don’t, is that metamorphosis is supposed to take time. 

Because in reality, nobody knows when someone becomes a man, only when they ought to.

Because a college like ours isn’t a race to the top - it's one massive cocoon, one with thousands of dissolved caterpillars inside it, where the substance of each dissolved caterpillar attempts to reform itself in the semblance of a butterfly, where some do come out early, and some later, all butterflies through and through.

Take your time boy. Your journey might be longer, but keep going, and you will yet be molded into a man.

title: Edition 62 | Those Days
biliner:
”I remember the only goals in my diary were going to college and vibing on “Kuch toh hua hai”. Rarely did I have those stretch marks on my forehead like the children these days. Yes, there was stress back then as well, but for who will buy the cassette of the latest songs first.”
Read on as Akansha Sethi, 1st year, ENE, draws parallels between the college life of today and the 90’s generation, where time was rather stress-free, devoid of the continuous hustle and competition of the youths of today. Songs that shaped our childhood, and which continue to impact us have been used in a rather fun and engaging way to put an important topic through.
body:
”I remember the only goals in my diary were going to college and vibing on “Kuch toh hua hai”. Rarely did I have those stretch marks on my forehead like the children these days. Yes, there was stress back then as well, but for who will buy the cassette of the latest songs first.”

Read on as Akansha Sethi, 1st year, ENE, draws parallels between the college life of today and the 90’s generation, where time was rather stress-free, devoid of the continuous hustle and competition of the youths of today. Songs that shaped our childhood, and which continue to impact us have been used in a rather fun and engaging way to put an important topic through.

One day, time will fly and then you will process what has changed so far. It seems like it was just yesterday when I was sitting at the oat with my seniors, and they told me this while all of us were listening to “Main Pal Do Pal Ka Shayar Hoon”. My golden days, they were indeed, everything was so simple yet so beautiful. I remember the only goals in my diary were going to college and vibing on “Kuch toh hua hai”. Rarely did I have those stretch marks on my forehead like the children these days. Yes, there was stress back then as well, but for who will buy the cassette of the latest songs first. It’s not that those days had no stress or things to worry about, but no matter what our problems used to be, we knew somehow our day would get its happy ending. From waiting eagerly with family to watch Ramayan to evening cricket sessions. While playing gully cricket, Lagaan’s “Baar Baar Haan” was the perfect competitive music we needed. With friends “Tere Jaisa Yaar Kahan” made all of us smile with an unexpressed feeling of gratitude. Moreover, the campus knew some secretive beautiful stories from “Ek Ladki Ko Dekha Toh Aisa Laga”, “Ye Dosti Hum Nahi Todenge”, and of course “Ramta Jogi”. Somehow that single radio made everything fall into place. Sometimes I wonder how lucky I was, as the heart knew what it always desired. Today when I see rock, hip-hop music, raps have conquered the market and more than half of the college would have them in their Spotify playlists, yet Lata Ji’s “Zindagi Aur Kuch Bhi Nahi Teri Meri Kahani Hai” has a special place in my heart. Well, I don't know about their choices but Arijit’s “Woh Din Bhi Kya Din” reminds me of those golden college days where life was just perfect and “Kal Ho Na Ho” was my very first mobile ringtone.

Illustration credits: Shriyanshi Moharana, 1st year, B.Des

title: संस्करण 62। स्मृति शेष
biliner:
“जीवन एक लम्बी सीढ़ी है, जिसके हर कदम पर एक नया पड़ाव आता है। ऐसे ही छोटे- छोटे पड़ावों को पार करते हुए, हर छोटी-बड़ी चीज़ को देखते हुए मैं उस जगह के समीप जा रहा हूँ, जिस से मेरी कॉलेज की सबसे खूबसूरत यादें जुड़ी हैं।”
पढ़िए इसी दिशा में राहुल देव, द्वितीय वर्ष, ई. ई. और दक्ष खंडेलवाल, द्वितीय वर्ष, ई. सी. ई. द्वारा लिखित एक लेख 'स्मृति शेष' जो उनकी रचनात्मकता के माध्यम से दर्शाता है कि व्यक्ति के जीवन में अपनों का कितना महत्व है।
body:
“जीवन एक लम्बी सीढ़ी है, जिसके हर कदम पर एक नया पड़ाव आता है। ऐसे ही छोटे- छोटे पड़ावों को पार करते हुए, हर छोटी-बड़ी चीज़ को देखते हुए मैं उस जगह के समीप जा रहा हूँ, जिस से मेरी कॉलेज की सबसे खूबसूरत यादें जुड़ी हैं।”

पढ़िए इसी दिशा में राहुल देव, द्वितीय वर्ष, ई. ई. और दक्ष खंडेलवाल, द्वितीय वर्ष, ई. सी. ई. द्वारा लिखित एक लेख 'स्मृति शेष' जो उनकी रचनात्मकता के माध्यम से दर्शाता है कि व्यक्ति के जीवन में अपनों का कितना महत्व है।

-  नैना! बेटा क्या हुआ? सब ठीक है तुम काफी व्याकुल लग रही हो?

-  हाँ! सब ठीक है पापा। 

    वो बस कॉलेज को लेकर थोड़ी सी घबराहट हो रही है। 

-  सभी को होती है। मुझे भी हुई थी। 

    डरने की कोई बात नहीं है। मैं तुम्हारे साथ ही हूँ। 

मेरे पापा कॉलेज के पहले दिन मेरे साथ आये हैं। तब तक आप उनसे बातें कीजिए और मैं कॉलेज जाती हूँ।   

जीवन एक लम्बी सीढ़ी है, जिसके हर कदम पर एक नया पड़ाव आता है। ऐसे ही छोटे- छोटे पड़ावों को पार करते हुए, हर छोटी-बड़ी चीज़ को देखते हुए मैं उस जगह के समीप जा रहा हूँ, जिस से मेरी कॉलेज की सबसे खूबसूरत यादें जुड़ी हैं। हाँ! नई इमारतें ज़रुर बन गई हैं पर हवा में आज भी वही अपनापन है, वातावरण में वही सुगंध है। यह पूरा दृश्य अतीत की उन सुखद यादों का स्मरण कराता है। 

छात्रों की इन छोटी-छोटी उत्साही टोलियों को देखकर मेरे मन में भी मेरे कॉलेज के दिनों की स्मृतियां ताज़ा हो गई। मेरी स्वीकृति के बिना ही मेरा दाखिला इंजीनियरिंग में करवा दिया गया था। औरों की तरह कॉलेज के शुरुआती दिन मेरे लिए भी काफ़ी कठिन थे। माँ के हाथ के खाने और मेस के खाने में ज़मीन-आसमान का अंतर होता है और इस अंतर से मेरे अंतर्मन में एक घमासान छिड़ा हुआ था। लेकिन हर युद्ध में कुछ पल शान्ति के तो मिलते ही है। मुझे वह शांति साहित्य से मिलती थी।  

मेरा मन शुरुआत से ही साहित्य में काफी लगता था। मेरा परिचय भी ऐसे ही लोगों से हुआ जिनको साहित्य व कविता वाचन में रूचि थी। नैना की माँ, सारिका भी साहित्य में रूचि रखती थी। उसको नित्य विभिन्न कवियों के काव्य सुनाने और रोज़ मिलने के कारण ही यह रूचि थोड़े ही दिनों में दिनचर्या में बदल गई। जिसका श्रेय डी.टी.यू. में साहित्यिक वातावरण को प्रेरित करती “सोसाइटीज” को भी जाता है। नित्य होने वाली कविता वाचन व वाद-विवाद प्रतियोगिताओं में मैं बढ़-चढ़कर हिस्सा लेता था। मैं और सारिका, हम दोनों बहुत से कार्यक्रमों में साथ ही भाग लेते थे। बितते समय के साथ हम दोनों काफी अच्छे दोस्त बन गए। हमने एक रोज़ एडमिन ब्लॉक के सामने वाले प्रांगण में साहित्य और एक दूसरे का साथ कभी ना छोड़ने का वादा किया। इसी कारण से उस जगह से मेरी बहुत सी यादें जुड़ी है। लेकिन नियति को कुछ और ही मंज़ूर था। साहित्य ने तो कभी मेरा साथ नहीं छोड़ा लेकिन नैना को मेरे हाथों में सौंप कर सारिका ने मेरा साथ छोड़ दिया। तब से नैना और उसकी खुशियाँ ही मेरे लिए सबकुछ है। मेरे साहित्य लेखन में प्राप्त सफलताओं का श्रेय इस सुन्दर कैंपस को ही जाता है। 

-  क्या हुआ पापा! सब ठीक है?

-  हाँ! हाँ! मुझे क्या होगा बस कुछ याद आ गया था। 

-  पापा, आपको कुछ होगा भी नहीं।  

     मैं हूँ ना। (हाहा)

title: Edition 62 | Whispered Thoughts of Candescent Memories
biliner:
“I ruminate about the myriad of questions that flowed from exhausting relatives, finding the answers to which had me running from post to poll. After all these years, my recollection of these uncertainties is but faint. However, there is one question that ceases to leave my memory. 
 ‘What is DTU?’”
Read on as Ayush Das Gupta, 1st year, EE and Dhedhanved Aggarwall, 1st year, IT, charter a sombre course through an unfamiliarly nostalgic sea, searching for memories that last.
body:
“I ruminate about the myriad of questions that flowed from exhausting relatives, finding the answers to which had me running from post to poll. After all these years, my recollection of these uncertainties is but faint. However, there is one question that ceases to leave my memory. 

 ‘What is DTU?’”

As I sit across the table,  the same one I spent hours perusing college manuals after JEE, I am lost in thought in this busy city of Bangalore. I step back to reminisce about the past, that gushing feeling of uncertainty and excitement is anything but succinct as it lingers on fresh as ever. I ruminate about the myriad of questions that flowed from exhausting relatives, finding the answers to which had me running from post to poll . After all these years, my recollection of these uncertainties is but faint. However, there is one question that ceases to leave my memory. 

 “What is DTU?”

 An interesting question to ponder on contemplatively yet a question also asked from a space of genuine intrigue. A question asked to me by an alumnus taking the shape of my uncle to whom, ironically, I had gone for guidance. 

25 years, an expanse of time morbidly large for us individuals, yet for an institute preceding our independence it is akin to a clap, the void between our hands covered instantaneously but the collision reverbing unabashed. A time ago in history when our institution became a deemed university, promptly accompanied by a name change. But for many the old name of “DCE” still rings true, evidently when even a graduate was befuddled. But to me the main crux of the conversation was the question which came after, “Why DTU?” At the time I gave superficial reasonings, reasonings I know to be false now. Reasonings taught to be reasoned about, conjecture only to placate expectations but being anything but pertinent.

Sneaking away to the neighbour’s house to eat a plethora of sweets unavailable to me at home, cracking the password my parents set on the cable, spending nights awake on my amphone, dreading an unannounced visit, and what I consider to be my pièce de resistance, almost setting the house on fire by lighting firecrackers indoors. These are but an inkling of the memories I do not choose to recall but come to me on their own accord. Some make me laugh, most make me cringe, but none make me regret, a feeling invariably growing as I mature.

Right now I am filled with nostalgia, an unseen warmth floods my body, permeating till the ends of every appendage.  “We did not know we were making memories, we were just having fun”, a quote preached by a greater being, Winnie the Pooh being the bishop. I chose DTU to collect more of these droplets of time, keeping them unfiltered and raw, so that when the nights seem long, I can savour them and smile.
